vi: 1.This is the translated text.

en: The longest day of my life began tardily. I woke up late, took too long in the shower, and ended up having to enjoy my breakfast in the passenger seat of my mom’s minivan at 7:17 that Wednesday morning.
vi: The longest day of my life started quite late. I woke up late, hummed for too long in the bathroom, and as a result, had to enjoy breakfast in my mom's minivan at 7:17 AM that Wednesday.
tr: The longest day of my life started late. I woke up late that Wednesday morning, spent a lot of time in the shower, and had to eat my breakfast in the passenger seat of my mom's minivan at 7:17 AM.
es: The longest day of my life started with a delay. I woke up late, spent too much time in the shower, and in the end, I had to enjoy breakfast in the passenger seat of my mother's minivan at 7:17 in the morning on a Wednesday.

en: I usually got a ride to school with my best friend, Ben Starling, but Ben had gone to school on time, making him useless to me. “On time” for us was thirty minutes before school actually started, because the half hour before the first bell was the highlight of our social calendars: standing outside the side door that led into the band room and just talking. Most of my friends were in band, and most of my free time during school was spent within twenty feet of the band room. But I was not in the band, because I suffer from the kind of tone deafness that is generally associated with actual deafness. I was going to be twenty minutes late, which technically meant that I’d still be ten minutes early for school itself.
vi: On regular days, I would hitch a ride with my closest buddy, Ben Starling, but that day Ben had already cruised to school on time, so I couldn't rely on him. "On time" for us meant thirty minutes before classes started, because the precious half-hour before the first bell was the highlight of our social schedule: gathering and chatting outside the side door of the gym and music room. Most of my friends played musical instruments, and most of my free time at school was spent within a few meters around the music room. But I didn't play any instruments at all, because I had a condition called tone-deafness, which is generally related to actual deafness. Today I would be twenty minutes late, which technically meant I would still arrive ten minutes before class started.
tr: Usually, my closest friend Ben Starling would take me to school, but Ben, becoming useless to me, had gone to school on time. For us, "on time" was thirty minutes before school started because the half-hour before the first bell was the most important part of our social program: standing in front of the side door to the band room and just talking. Most of my friends were in the band, and most of my free time at school was spent within five meters of the band room. But I wasn't in the band because I suffered from tone deafness, which is usually associated with actual deafness. I was going to be twenty minutes late, which technically meant I would still be there ten minutes before class started.
es: I used to go to school in my best friend Ben Starling's car, but Ben had left on time, so I couldn't rely on him. For us, "on time" meant half an hour before classes started, because those thirty minutes before the first bell rang were the highlight of our social agenda. We would stand in front of the side door that led to the high school band rehearsal room and chat. Since most of my friends played in the band, I spent almost all my free hours at school less than five meters from the rehearsal room. But I didn't play, because I have less of an ear for music than a deaf person. That day I was going to be twenty minutes late, which technically meant that I would still arrive ten minutes before classes started.

en: As she drove, Mom was asking me about classes and finals and prom.
vi: While driving, my mom asked me about school, exams, and the graduation prom.
tr: My mom asked me questions about classes, finals, and the prom while she was driving the car.
es: While driving, my mother asked me about classes, exams, and the prom.

en: “I don’t believe in prom,” I reminded her as she rounded a corner. I expertly angled my raisin bran to accommodate the g-forces. I’d done this before.
vi: "I never enjoy parties, Mom," I said as she turned a corner. Immediately, I skillfully tilted the cereal to balance with gravity. I've done this trick many times.
tr: “I don't believe in luck,” I reminded, while turning a corner. To adapt to the G-force, I skillfully adjusted the angle of my breakfast cereal. I had done this before.
es: —I don't believe in prom dances —I reminded him as I turned a corner. I skillfully tilted my cereal to adjust it to the force of gravity. It wasn't the first time I had done it.

en: “Well, there’s no harm in just going with a friend. I’m sure you could ask Cassie Hiney.” And I could have asked Cassie Hiney, who was actually perfectly nice and pleasant and cute, despite having a fantastically unfortunate last name.
vi: “Well, what's wrong with going with a friend, dear?” “Surely you can invite Cassie Hiney.” I would definitely invite Cassie Hiney, a truly nice, friendly, and stunningly beautiful girl, but unfortunately, she has an extremely sensitive last name[3].
tr: “There is no harm in going with a friend. I am sure you can invite Cassie Hiney.” Despite having an extraordinarily unfortunate last name despite, I could actually invite the quite nice, beautiful, and charming Cassie Hiney.
es: —Well, there's nothing wrong with going with a friend. I'm sure you could ask Cassie Hiney. Yes, he could have asked Cassie Hiney, who was very nice, friendly, and pretty, despite her tremendously unfortunate last name, which in English means "butt".

en: “It’s not just that I don’t like prom. I also don’t like people who like prom,” I explained, although this was, in point of fact, untrue. Ben was absolutely gaga over the idea of going.
vi: “Not just because I don't like the party. I don't even like the people who like the party,” I tried to explain, though to be honest, it wasn't quite true. Ben was the one who was all excited and frantic about this party.
tr: “I don't just dislike balls, I also dislike people who enjoy balls,” I explained, even though it wasn't actually true. I was absolutely dying to go.
es: —It's not that I don't like prom dances. It's that I also don't like the people who like prom dances —I explained to my mother. Although in reality it was not true. Ben had insisted on going.

en: Mom turned into school, and I held the mostly empty bowl with both hands as we drove over a speed bump. I glanced over at the senior parking lot. Margo Roth Spiegelman’s silver Honda was parked in its usual spot. Mom pulled the minivan into a cul-de-sac outside the band room and kissed me on the cheek. I could see Ben and my other friends standing in a semicircle.
vi: Mom turned into the school, and I held the nearly empty bowl tightly with both hands as we went over the speed bumps. I quickly glanced at the senior student parking lot. Margo Roth Spiegelman's silver Honda was parked in its usual spot. Mom pulled the car into a dead-end near the music room and kissed me on the cheek goodbye. I caught sight of Ben and a few other guys standing in a semicircle.
tr: My mom turned towards the school, and I held the nearly empty bowl with both hands as we went over a speed bump. I glanced at the senior parking lot. Margo Roth Spiegelman's silver Honda was parked in its usual spot. My mom turned the car towards a dead end outside the band room and kissed me on the cheek. I could see my friends and I standing in a semicircle.
es: My mother turned towards the school, and I held the almost empty bowl with both hands as we went over a speed bump. I glanced at the senior student parking lot. Margo Roth Spiegelman's silver Honda was parked in its usual spot. My mother pulled the car into an alley in front of the rehearsal room and gave me a kiss on the cheek. As I got out, I saw Ben and my other friends, gathered in a semicircle.

en: I walked up to them, and the half circle effortlessly expanded to include me. They were talking about my ex-girlfriend Suzie Chung, who played cello and was apparently creating quite a stir by dating a baseball player named Taddy Mac. Whether this was his given name, I did not know. But at any rate, Suzie had decided to go to prom with Taddy Mac. Another casualty.
vi: I went to where they were, and the semicircle immediately expanded to include me. They were talking about my ex-girlfriend, Suzie Chung, who played the cello and had clearly stirred up controversy by dating a baseball player named Taddy Mac. I don't even know if that's his real name. Anyway, Suzie had decided to go to the prom with Taddy Mac. Another victim.
tr: I walked towards them, and the semicircle effortlessly expanded to include me. They were talking about my ex-girlfriend Suzie Chung, who was attracting everyone's attention by dating a baseball player named Taddy Mac, who apparently played the cello. I didn't know if Taddy Mac was his real name. But in any case, Suzie had decided to go to the ball with Taddy Mac. Another loss.
es: I approached them, and the semicircle soon opened up to include me. They were talking about my ex-girlfriend, Suzie Chung, who played the cello and had apparently caused quite a stir because she was dating a baseball player named Taddy Mac. I didn't know if that was his real name. In any case, Suzie had decided to go to the prom with Taddy Mac. Another victim.

en: “Bro,” said Ben, standing across from me. He nodded his head and turned around. I followed him out of the circle and through the door. A small, olive-skinned creature who had hit puberty but never hit it very hard, Ben had been my best friend since fifth grade, when we both finally owned up to the fact that neither of us was likely to attract anyone else as a best friend. Plus, he tried hard, and I liked that—most of the time.
vi: "Hey man," Ben stood opposite me and called. He nodded as a signal and then left. I followed him out of the crowd, heading into the gym. A small, dark-skinned guy who had gone through puberty but never quite finished it in a grand way, Ben had been my best friend since fifth grade, when we both finally admitted that neither of us could find anyone else to be a close friend. However, he had tried very hard, and I liked that—most of the time.
tr: Standing in front of me, Ben said, "Buddy." He nodded his head and turned around. I followed him towards the door, stepping out of the circle. Ben, a small creature with wheat-colored skin who had reached adolescence but hadn't fully entered it, had been my best friend since fifth grade, ever since we both finally accepted that we couldn't attract anyone else as a best friend. And Ben tried very hard, which I liked... most of the time.
es: —Colleague —Ben said to me, who was in front of me. He moved his head, turned halfway around, walked away from the circle, and went in. I followed him. Ben, a short boy with olive skin who barely seemed to have reached puberty, had been my best friend since fifth grade, when we both finally admitted the evidence that neither of us was likely to find a better friend. Besides, he put a lot of effort into it, and I liked that... most of the time.

en: “How ya doin’?” I asked. We were safely inside, everyone else’s conversations making ours inaudible.
vi: “What's wrong, sir?” I asked. We were safe in the music room, the people around us talking enough to drown out our conversation.
tr: "How are you?" I asked. We had entered, and the conversations of the others were preventing ours from being heard.
es: —How are you? —I asked him. We were inside, in a safe place. The other conversations prevented ours from being heard.

en: “Radar is going to prom,” he said morosely. Radar was our other best friend. We called him Radar because he looked like a little bespectacled guy called Radar on this old TV show M*A*S*H, except 1. The TV Radar wasn’t black, and 2. At some point after the nicknaming, our Radar grew about six inches and started wearing contacts, so I suppose that 3. He actually didn’t look like the guy on M*A*S*H at all, but 4. With three and a half weeks left of high school, we weren’t very well going to renickname him.
vi: “Radar is going to the prom,” Ben grumbled. Radar is our awesome comrade. He is called Radar because he looks exactly like a scrawny guy with thick glasses named Radar from the old TV series M*A*S*H, except 1. TV Radar isn't black, and 2. At some point after being nicknamed, our Radar grew about fifteen centimeters taller and started wearing contact lenses, so I think that 3. He no longer looks like the guy from M*A*S*H, but 4. With only three and a half weeks until graduation, we couldn't be bothered to give him a new name.
tr: Grumpily, "Radar is going to the prom," he said. Radar was our other closest friend. We called him Radar because of that old TV show 1 Argoda kalça, kıç anlamlarına gelmektedir, (slang. n.) He looked like the guy with the small glasses in M*A*S*H, of course 1. The Radar on TV wasn't black and 2. A while after we gave him this nickname, our Radar grew fifteen centimeters and started wearing lenses, so I guess 3. Actually, he didn't look like the guy in M*A*S*H at all but 4. With three and a half weeks left until high school, we weren't going to try giving him a new nickname.
es: —Radar is going to the prom —he told me grumpily. Radar was our other best friend. We called him Radar because he looked like a short guy with glasses from the old TV series M*A*S*H who was called that, except that: 1) The TV Radar wasn't black, and 2) At some point after we gave him the nickname, our Radar grew about fifteen centimeters and got contact lenses, so I guess that, 3) In reality, he didn't look anything like the guy from M*A*S*H, but, 4) Since there were only three and a half weeks left until the end of the school year, we weren't too worried about the task of finding him another nickname.

en: “That girl Angela?” I asked. Radar never told us anything about his love life, but this did not dissuade us from frequent speculation.
vi: “That girl Angela?” I asked. Radar never reveals anything about his love life, but that doesn't stop us from gossiping about it.
tr: “With that girl named Angela?” I asked. Radar never talked to us about his love life, but that didn't stop us from frequently speculating.
es: —Angela? —I asked her. Radar never told us anything about his love life, which did not deter us from speculating every now and then.

en: Ben nodded, and then said, “You know my big plan to ask a freshbunny to prom because they’re the only girls who don’t know the Bloody Ben story?” I nodded.
vi: Ben nodded, then said, "You know my grand plan, right? Bringing a naive girl to the party because only the naive ones are unaware of the legend of Ben the Awkward." I nodded.
tr: I nodded in agreement. “You know, I'm thinking of inviting one of those freshmen to the ball just because they're the only ones who don't know the Bloody Ben story,” he said. I nodded in agreement.
es: Ben nodded. —Do you remember that I had thought about inviting a freshman to the dance, because they are the only ones who don't know the story of Bloody Ben? I nodded.

en: “Well,” Ben said, “this morning some darling little ninth-grade honeybunny came up to me and asked me if I was Bloody Ben, and I began to explain that it was a kidney infection, and she giggled and ran away. So that’s out.”
vi: “Tsk,” Ben continued, “this morning a cute little ninth-grade bunny came to ask if I was Ben Bỉ Bựa. I had to explain clearly that it was a kidney infection. The little girl giggled and ran away immediately. End of story.”
tr: “So,” said Ben, “this morning a small, cute bunny from the ninth grade came to me and asked if I was Bloody Ben, and I started to explain that it was a kidney infection, the girl giggled and ran away. So everything is out in the open.”
es: —Well —Ben continued—, this morning a very cute freshman came up to me and asked if I was Bloody Ben. I started to explain to her that it was a kidney infection, but she laughed and walked away. So that's it.

en: In tenth grade, Ben was hospitalized for a kidney infection, but Becca Arrington, Margo’s best friend, started a rumor that the real reason he had blood in his urine was due to chronic masturbation. Despite its medical implausibility, this story had haunted Ben ever since. “That sucks,” I said.
vi: Back in tenth grade, Ben had to be hospitalized due to a kidney infection, but Becca Arrington, Margo's best friend, sparked a rumor that the real reason Ben was urinating blood was because he had been masturbating excessively. Although medically unfounded, the rumors stuck to Ben ever since. "That's disgusting," I didn't know what else to say.
tr: Ben was hospitalized in the tenth grade due to a kidney infection, but Margo's best friend, Becca Arrington, spread a rumor that the real reason for blood in Ben's urine was chronic masturbation. Although not medically plausible, this story has haunted Ben ever since. "Terrible," I said.
es: Two years ago, they had to admit Ben to the hospital for a kidney infection, but Becca Arrington, Margo's best friend, spread the rumor that the real reason he was urinating blood was because he spent the day masturbating. Even though it was clinically implausible, Ben had been burdened with that story ever since. —What a piece of crap —I told him.

en: Ben started outlining plans for finding a date, but I was only half listening, because through the thickening mass of humanity crowding the hallway, I could see Margo Roth Spiegelman. She was next to her locker, standing beside her boyfriend, Jase. She wore a white skirt to her knees and a blue print top. I could see her collarbone. She was laughing at something hysterical—her shoulders bent forward, her big eyes crinkling at their corners, her mouth open wide. But it didn’t seem to be anything Jase had said, because she was looking away from him, across the hallway to a bank of lockers. I followed her eyes and saw Becca Arrington draped all over some baseball player like she was an ornament and he a Christmas tree. I smiled at Margo, even though I knew she couldn’t see me.
vi: Ben started planning to hook up with a girl, but I was only half-listening, as my eyes wandered over the increasingly crowded hallway, and I saw Margo Roth Spiegelman. She was standing by her locker, next to her boyfriend, Jase. Margo was wearing a knee-length white skirt and a blue shirt with a print on it. I could see her collarbones. Margo was laughing hard about something—her shoulders hunched forward, her big eyes glistening at the corners, her mouth wide open. But it didn't seem like she was laughing at something Jase said, because she wasn't looking at Jase; she was looking across the hallway at another row of lockers. I followed her gaze and saw Becca Arrington clinging to a baseball player like she was an ornament and he was a Christmas tree. I smiled at Margo, even though I knew she didn't see me.
tr: Ben started outlining plans to arrange a prom date, but I wasn't really listening because I could see Margo Roth Spiegelman among the crowd of people swarming the hallway. She was standing right in front of her locker, next to her boyfriend Jase. She was wearing a white skirt that came down to her knees and a blue printed top. I could see her collarbone. She was laughing at something, completely lost in the moment... her shoulders hunched forward, the corners of her big eyes wrinkled, her mouth wide open. But it didn't seem like it was something Jase had said because she was looking away from him, towards the row of lockers on the opposite side of the hallway. I followed her gaze and I saw Becca Arrington clinging all over a baseball player; as if she were an ornament and the kid a Christmas tree. Even though I knew she couldn't see me, I smiled at Margo.
es: Ben started telling me his plans to find a girl, but I was only half-listening, because amidst the increasingly dense crowd of people filling the lobby, I saw Margo Roth Spiegelman. She was next to her locker, beside her boyfriend, Jase. She was wearing a white knee-length skirt and a blue patterned top. I could see her collarbone. She was laughing hysterically. Her shoulders were hunched forward, the corners of her large eyes wrinkled, and her mouth open. But she didn't seem to be laughing at something Jase had said, as she was looking elsewhere, towards the lockers on the other side of the lobby. I followed her gaze and saw Becca Arrington on top of a baseball player, as if the guy were a Christmas tree and she an ornament. I smiled at Margo, even though I knew she couldn't see me.

en: “Bro, you should just hit that. Forget about Jase. God, that is one candy-coated honeybunny.” As we walked, I kept taking glances at her through the crowd, quick snapshots: a photographic series entitled Perfection Stands Still While Mortals Walk Past. As I got closer, I thought maybe she wasn’t laughing after all. Maybe she’d received a surprise or a gift or something. She couldn’t seem to close her mouth.
vi: "Step on the gas and go ahead." "Ignore that guy Jase." "Oh my God, she’s really a sugar-coated bunny," Ben mumbled. Walking, but my eyes still glanced at her through the crowd, capturing in my mind moments that could make a series of photos titled The Perfect Beauty in Stillness, only for mere mortals to pass by. Getting closer, I thought maybe Margo didn't smile at all. Maybe she was surprised or received a gift or something. It seemed like she couldn't close her mouth.
tr: “Buddy, give it a light. Forget about Jase. My God, this girl is a sugar-coated bunny.” As we walked, I kept glancing at Margo through the crowd; quick, fleeting snapshots: a photo series titled Mortals Pass By, Perfection Stands Still. As we got closer, I thought, maybe she wasn’t smiling after all. Maybe it was a surprise, maybe she had received a gift or something like that. She didn’t seem like she could close her mouth.
es: —You should go for it, buddy. Forget about Jase. God, that chick is smoking hot. As we moved forward, I kept glancing at her through the crowd, quick snapshots, a photographic series titled Perfection Stays Still While Mortals Pass By. As I got closer, I thought that maybe she wasn't laughing. Maybe she had been surprised, given a gift or something like that. It seemed like she couldn't close her mouth.

en: “Yeah,” I said to Ben, still not listening, still trying to see as much of her as I could without being too obvious. It wasn’t even that she was so pretty. She was just so awesome, and in the literal sense. And then we were too far past her, too many people walking between her and me, and I never even got close enough to hear her speak or understand whatever the hilarious surprise had been. Ben shook his head, because he had seen me see her a thousand times, and he was used to it.
vi: "Yeah," I absentmindedly answered Ben, but I wasn't really paying attention to what he was saying because I was trying to look at Margo as much as possible without being too obvious. It's not because Margo is pretty. She's stunningly beautiful, in the literal sense of the words. And then we were too far from her, with too many people walking back and forth between Margo and me, that I couldn't even get close enough to hear her voice, or to understand what interesting thing had surprised her so much. Ben nodded because he had seen me look at Margo like that a thousand times, to the point where he was too used to it.
tr: “Yes,” I said to Ben, still not listening, still trying to see Margo as much as possible without making it too obvious. It wasn’t about her being very beautiful or anything. Margo was incredible, in the truest sense of the word. Then we went far beyond her, there were too many people walking between her and me, and I couldn’t even get close enough to hear her talk or understand what the surprise, which was so funny, was. Ben nodded because he had seen me looking at Margo thousands of times and was used to it.
es: —Yes —I said to Ben. I kept not paying attention to him, I kept trying not to lose sight of Margo without making it too obvious. It's not that she was a beauty. She was simply stunning, in the literal sense. And then we left her behind, too many people were passing between her and me, and at no point had I gotten close enough to hear what she was saying or understand what the hilarious surprise had been. Ben shook his head. He had seen me looking at her a thousand times and was used to it.

en: “Honestly, she’s hot, but she’s not that hot. You know who’s seriously hot?”
vi: “Yeah, she's hot, but not that hot. Do you know who is really hot?”
tr: "Honestly, Margo is sexy but not that sexy. Do you know who is really sexy?"
es: —The truth is that she's good-looking, but not that much. Do you know who is really good-looking?

en: “Who?” I asked.
vi: "Who?" I asked.
tr: “Kim?” I asked.
es: —Who? —I asked him.

en: “Lacey,” he said, who was Margo’s other best friend. “Also your mom. Bro, I saw your mom kiss you on the cheek this morning, and forgive me, but I swear to God I was like, man, I wish I was Q. And also, I wish my cheeks had penises.” I elbowed him in the ribs, but I was still thinking about Margo, because she was the only legend who lived next door to me. Margo Roth Spiegelman, whose six-syllable name was often spoken in its entirety with a kind of quiet reverence. Margo Roth Spiegelman, whose stories of epic adventures would blow through school like a summer storm: an old guy living in a broken-down house in Hot Coffee, Mississippi, taught Margo how to play the guitar. Margo Roth Spiegelman, who spent three days traveling with the circus—they thought she had potential on the trapeze. Margo Roth Spiegelman, who drank a cup of herbal tea with the Mallionaires backstage after a concert in St. Louis while they drank whiskey. Margo Roth Spiegelman, who got into that concert by telling the bouncer she was the bassist’s girlfriend, and didn’t they recognize her, and come on guys seriously, my name is Margo Roth Spiegelman and if you go back there and ask the bassist to take one look at me, he will tell you that I either am his girlfriend or he wishes I was, and then the bouncer did so, and then the bassist said “yeah that’s my girlfriend let her in the show,” and then later the bassist wanted to hook up with her and she rejected the bassist from the Mallionaires.
vi: “Lacey,” Ben replied, Lacey is another close friend of Margo. “And your mom too. I saw your mom kiss you on the cheek this morning. Don’t blame me, I swear to God I thought: Oh man, I wish I were Q. And also, I wish my cheeks could grow some balls.” I elbowed him in the ribs, but I was still thinking about Margo, because she was the only legend living right next door to me. Margo Roth Spiegelman, that six-syllable name was often mentioned in full, accompanied by a bit of admiration. Margo Roth Spiegelman, the stories of her epic adventures could sweep through the school like a summer storm: for instance, the story of an old man living in a dilapidated house in Hot Coffee, Mississippi, who taught Margo to play the guitar. Margo Roth Spiegelman, the girl who traveled for three days with a circus—they thought she had a real talent for tightrope walking. Margo Roth Spiegelman, the girl who drank a cup of herbal tea with the band The Mallionaires backstage after a performance in St. Louis, while they drank whiskey. Margo Roth Spiegelman, the girl who got into that performance by telling the ticket checker that she was the bass guitarist's girlfriend. Didn't they recognize her? Come on man, seriously, I’m Margo Roth Spiegelman, now if you go inside and tell the bass guitarist to take one look at me, he’ll immediately tell you that I’m his girlfriend, or that he wants me to be his girlfriend. The ticket checker did just that, and the bassist said, “Yeah, that’s my girlfriend, let her in.” After that, the guy wanted to date Margo seriously, and she turned down the bassist of The Mallionaires.
tr: “Lacey,” he said. Lacey was Margo's other closest friend. “And your mom. Dude, I saw your mom kiss you on the cheek this morning and sorry, but I swear I was like: Man, I wish I were Q. ’s place. And also, I wish my cheeks had a penis.” I elbowed him in the ribs but was still thinking about Margo because she was the only legend who lived next door to us. Her full six-syllable name, usually spoken with a kind of awe, Margo Roth Spiegelman. Epic adventure stories, Margo Roth Spiegelman who stormed through school like a summer storm: An old man living in a dilapidated house in Hot Coffee, Mississippi, had taught Margo how to play the guitar. She spent three days with the circus Margo Roth Spiegelman, who spent her time wandering... they thought she had potential on the trapeze. Margo Roth Spiegelman, who got into this concert by telling the guard at the door that she was the bassist's girlfriend. “Don't you recognize me? Come on guys, seriously, my name is Margo Roth Spiegelman, if you go and ask the bassist to take a look at me, he will either tell you that I am his girlfriend or that he wants me to be.” When the guard did exactly that, the bassist said, “Yes, she is my girlfriend, let her into the show,” later he tried to hit on Margo, and Margo rejected The Mallionaires' bassist.

This morning I saw your mother giving you a kiss and, forgive me, but I swear to God I thought: "Damn, I wish I were Q. And I wish I had dicks on my cheeks." I elbowed him in the ribs, although I kept thinking about Margo, because she was the only myth living next door to my house. Margo Roth Spiegelman, whose six-syllable name we used to say in full with a kind of silent reverence. Margo Roth Spiegelman, whose epic adventures circulated around the school like a summer storm. An old man who lived in a ramshackle house in Hot Coffee, Mississippi, had taught Margo to play the guitar. Margo Roth Spiegelman, who had traveled for three days with a circus, where they thought she had potential for the trapeze. Margo Roth Spiegelman, who had sipped herbal tea backstage with the Mallionaires after a concert in Saint Louis, while they drank whiskey. Margo Roth Spiegelman, who had sneaked into that concert by telling the security guard that she was the bassist's girlfriend, didn't they recognize her?, come on, guys, seriously, I'm Margo Roth Spiegelman, and if you're going to ask the bassist to come see who I am, he'll either say I'm his girlfriend or that he wishes I were, and then the security guard went to ask him, and the bassist said: "Yes, she's my girlfriend, let her in," and then the bassist wanted to make out with her, but she rejected the bassist of the Mallionaires!

en: The stories, when they were shared, inevitably ended with, I mean, can you believe it? We often could not, but they always proved true.
vi: Those stories, when retold, always end with the phrase "So there, can you believe it?" Usually, it's unbelievable, but those are always true stories.
tr: When stories were shared with others, they inevitably ended with the sentence "So, can you believe it?" We usually couldn't believe it, but their truth was always proven.
es: When we talked about his stories, we always ended up saying, "Wow, can you imagine that?". In general, we couldn't imagine them, but they always turned out to be true.

en: And then we were at our lockers. Radar was leaning against Ben’s locker, typing into a handheld device.

es: And we arrived at our lockers. Radar was leaning against Ben's, typing on his handheld computer.

en: “So you’re going to prom,” I said to him. He looked up, and then looked back down.

tr: I said to Radar, "So you're going to the ball." He looked up, then back down again.
es: —So you're going to the dance —I said to her. He lifted his gaze and then lowered it again.

en: “I’m de-vandalizing the Omnictionary article about a former prime minister of France. Last night someone deleted the entire entry and then replaced it with the sentence ‘Jacques Chirac is a gay,’ which as it happens is incorrect both factually and grammatically.” Radar is a big-time editor of this online user-created reference source called Omnictionary. His whole life is devoted to the maintenance and well-being of Omnictionary. This was but one of several reasons why his having a prom date was somewhat surprising.
vi: “I am correcting an article in the Encyclopedia of Everything about the former Prime Minister of France. His whole life, he has been dedicated to maintaining and developing this Encyclopedia. This is one of the reasons why it is so surprising that he is going on a date to a gala.
tr: “I am correcting the vandalism on an Omnictionary2 article about the former French prime minister. His whole life was dedicated to the maintenance and well-being of Omnictionary. This was one of the various reasons why it was so surprising that he was going to the ball with someone.

Radar is an active editor of the Omnictionary, an online encyclopedia created by users. He dedicates his entire life to maintaining and caring for the Omnictionary. And that was one of the various reasons why it surprised us that he had invited a girl to the prom.

en: “So you’re going to prom,” I repeated.
vi: “So you will be attending the graduation ball, right,” I reiterated.
tr: “So, you are going to the ball,” I repeated.
es: —So you're going to the dance —I repeated.

en: “Sorry,” he said without looking up. It was a well-known fact that I was opposed to prom. Absolutely nothing about any of it appealed to me—not slow dancing, not fast dancing, not the dresses, and definitely not the rented tuxedo. Renting a tuxedo seemed to me an excellent way to contract some hideous disease from its previous tenant, and I did not aspire to become the world’s only virgin with pubic lice.
vi: “Sorry,” he said without bothering to look up. Everyone knows I dread the prom. Absolutely nothing about that prom appeals to me—slow dancing, fast dancing, fancy dresses, rented tuxedos, nothing at all. Renting a tuxedo, to me, is the perfect way to catch some horrible disease from whoever wore that suit before, and I have no desire to be the only pure guy in the world covered in a swarm of lice.
tr: An internet encyclopedia similar to Wikipedia. After this name was used in the book, a similar website was launched but it is currently out of service, (tr. n.) “Sorry,” he said without raising his head. Nothing about the ball seemed appealing to me at all... neither slow dancing, nor fast dancing, nor the dresses nor the rented tuxedos. Renting a tuxedo seemed to me like a perfect way to catch a terrible disease from the previous renter, and I wasn't eager to be the world's only virgin carrying pubic lice.
es: —Sorry —he replied without raising his gaze. Everyone knew that I refused to go to the dance. It didn't interest me in the slightest: neither slow dances, nor fast dances, nor the suits, and even less the rented tuxedo. Renting a tuxedo seemed to me an excellent way to catch any dreadful disease from the previous renter, and it was not my intention to become the only virgin in the world with crabs.

en: “Bro,” Ben said to Radar, “the freshhoneys know about the Bloody Ben story.” Radar put the handheld away finally and nodded sympathetically. “So anyway,” Ben continued, “my two remaining strategies are either to purchase a prom date on the Internet or fly to Missouri and kidnap some nice corn-fed little honeybunny.” I’d tried telling Ben that “honeybunny” sounded more sexist and lame than retro-cool, but he refused to abandon the practice. He called his own mother a honeybunny. There was no fixing him.
vi: "Hey man," Ben said to Radar, "the little bunnies already know all about Ben the Jerk." Finally, Radar put away his handheld device, nodding sympathetically and understandingly. "Anyway," Ben continued, "my two remaining strategies are to advertise on the Internet for a prom date, or fly to Missouri to kidnap some cute, obedient, dumb bunny." I had tried to tell Ben that "bunny" sounded too sexist and weak, lacking any personality, but he still wouldn't change his habit. He even called his own mother a bunny. This guy is truly hopeless.
tr: “Buddy,” said Ben to Radar, “the chicks know the Bloody Ben story.” Radar finally put the gadget he was holding aside and nodded understandingly. Ben continued, “Anyway, my remaining two strategies are either to find a prom date online or to fly to Missouri and kidnap a nice, little corn-fed bunny.” I had tried to tell Ben that the word “bunny” sounded more sexist and pathetic than “retro,” but he wouldn’t give up the habit. He even called his own mother “bunny.” There was no way to correct Ben.
es: —Colleague —Ben said to Radar—, the freshmen have found out about the story of Bloody Ben. —Radar finally put away his computer and nodded with a sympathetic expression—. So the only two strategies I have left are to find a date for the dance online or fly to Missouri and kidnap some corn-fed chick. I had tried to explain to Ben that "pava" sounded much more sexist and pathetic than "retro-cool," but he refused to stop saying it. He called his own mother "pava." He was hopeless.

en: “I’ll ask Angela if she knows anybody,” Radar said. “Although getting you a date to prom will be harder than turning lead into gold.”

es: —I'll ask Angela if she knows anyone —said Radar—. Although getting you a date for the dance will be harder than turning lead into gold.

en: “Getting you a date to prom is so hard that the hypothetical idea itself is actually used to cut diamonds,” I added.
vi: “Getting a girl to agree to go to the dance with you is so tough that just the hypothesis alone is enough to cut diamonds,” I added.
tr: “Setting up a ball date for you is so difficult that the very idea itself could actually be used to cut diamonds,” I added.
es: —Getting a date for the dance is so tough that just thinking about it could cut diamonds —I added.

en: Radar tapped a locker twice with his fist to express his approval, and then came back with another. “Ben, getting you a date to prom is so hard that the American government believes the problem cannot be solved with diplomacy, but will instead require force.”
vi: Radar lightly punched the locker twice to show his approval and continued to the conclusion. "Ben, getting a girl to agree to go to the prom with you is so challenging that the United States government believes the issue cannot be resolved through diplomacy and must resort to force."
tr: Radar lightly tapped the cabinet twice with his fist to show he agreed and continued with another one. "I tell you, getting you a prom date is so difficult that the American government believes the problem can't be solved with diplomacy and instead requires brute force."
es: Radar gave a couple of punches to a locker to show he agreed and then released another phrase: —Ben, getting you a date for the dance is so tough that the United States government believes the problem cannot be resolved through diplomatic means, but will require the use of force.

en: I was trying to think of another one when we all three simultaneously saw the human-shaped container of anabolic steroids known as Chuck Parson walking toward us with some intent. Chuck Parson did not participate in organized sports, because to do so would distract from the larger goal of his life: to one day be convicted of homicide. “Hey, faggots,” he called.
vi: I was still thinking about the next part when all three of us saw the muscle-building hormone container shaped like a human named Chuck Parson angrily approaching us. Chuck Parson didn't play on any sports team because it would distract him from his life's grand goal: to one day be convicted of murder. "Hey, you fags," he called.
tr: I was trying to think of another one when we all saw, at that moment, the human-shaped anabolic steroid container known as Chuck Parson walking towards us with a purpose. Chuck Parson did not participate in sports because it would distract him from the greatest goal of his life: to one day be convicted of murder. "Hey, faggots," he called out.
es: I was thinking about another occurrence when the three of us simultaneously saw the human-shaped bottle of anabolic steroids known as Chuck Parson approaching us with some purpose. Chuck Parson didn't participate in team sports because that would distract him from his main goal in life: to one day be convicted of homicide. —Hello, faggots —he said.

en: “Chuck,” I answered, as friendly as I could muster. Chuck hadn’t given us any serious trouble in a couple years—someone in cool kid land laid down the edict that we were to be left alone. So it was a little unusual for him even to talk to us.
vi: "Hello Chuck," I replied, trying to be as conciliatory as possible. In recent years, Chuck hasn't had any serious conflicts with us—some of the more influential members had declared that this meant we were safe. So when Chuck himself started a conversation with us, it seemed a bit strange.
tr: As friendly as I could manage, I replied, "Chuck." Chuck hadn't caused us any serious problems for a few years... someone from the land of the cool kids had issued a decree that we should be left alone. So it was a bit strange for him to even talk to us.
es: —Chuck —I responded as amicably as I could. Chuck hadn't caused us any serious problems in the last two years, because someone from the cool kids' side had given the order to leave us alone, so Chuck didn't even speak to us.

en: Maybe because I spoke and maybe not, he slammed his hands against the lockers on either side of me and then leaned in close enough for me to contemplate his toothpaste brand. “What do you know about Margo and Jase?”
vi: Maybe it was because I opened my mouth, or maybe not, but Chuck slammed both fists onto the locker doors, pinning me in between, his face so close that I could easily guess which toothpaste he used. "What do you know about Margo and Jase?"
tr: Maybe because I was talking or maybe for another reason, he placed his hands on the cupboards on either side of me and leaned in so close that I could guess the brand of his toothpaste. "What do you know about Margo and Jase?"
es: Maybe because I was the one who had answered him, or maybe not, he placed both hands on the locker, with me in the middle, and came close enough for me to consider what brand of toothpaste he used. —What do you know about Margo and Jase?

en: “Uh,” I said. I thought of everything I knew about them: Jase was Margo Roth Spiegelman’s first and only serious boyfriend. They began dating at the tail end of last year. They were both going to University of Florida next year. Jase got a baseball scholarship there. He was never over at her house, except to pick her up. She never acted as if she liked him all that much, but then she never acted as if she liked anyone all that much. “Nothing,” I said finally.
vi: “Uh,” I replied, thinking about everything I knew about those two: Jase was Margo Roth Spiegelman's first and only serious boyfriend. They started dating late last year. Next year, they will both be going to the University of Florida. Jase got a scholarship because he will be playing on the school's baseball team. He never stayed long in her house, except when picking up Margo. She never seemed to like him that much, but she never seemed to like anyone that much. “Don’t know anything,” I finally said.
tr: “Well,” I said. I thought about everything I knew about them: Jase was Margo Roth Spiegelman's first and only serious boyfriend. They had started dating at the very end of last year. Next year, both of them would be going to the University of Florida. Jase had gotten a baseball scholarship there. Jase never went to Margo’s house... except when he went to pick her up at the door. Margo never acted like she liked Jase that much, but then again, she never acted like she liked anyone that much. “Nothing,” I said finally.
es: —Ugh —I replied. I thought about everything I knew about them: Jase was Margo Roth Spiegelman's first and only serious boyfriend. They had started dating at the end of the previous year. Both were going to attend the University of Florida the following year. Jase had received a scholarship to play on the baseball team. He had never been inside Margo's house, he only picked her up. Margo didn't seem to like him that much, but the truth was she never seemed to like anyone that much. —Nothing —I finally replied to him.

en: “Don’t shit me around,” he growled.

en: He considered my answer for a minute, and I tried hard to stare at his close-set eyes. He nodded very slightly, pushed off the lockers, and walked away to attend his first-period class: The Care and Feeding of Pectoral Muscles. The second bell rang. One minute to class. Radar and I had calc; Ben had finite mathematics. The classrooms were adjacent; we walked toward them together, the three of us in a row, trusting that the tide of classmates would part enough to let us by, and it did.
vi: It considered my answer for a moment, while I tried my best to look straight into its closely set eyes. Chuck nodded very slightly, left the row of lockers, and went to his first-period class: Chest Care and Nutrition. The second bell rang. One minute left before class starts. Radar and I had calculus, while Ben had combinatorial mathematics. The classrooms were right next to each other, we walked in, the three of us in a row, believing our friends would make enough space for us to pass, and they did.
tr: He reviewed my answer for a moment, and I struggled to look into his closely set eyes. He nodded faintly, pulled his hand from the cupboard, and left to attend his first class: Care and Development of Chest Muscles, as the second bell rang. There was one minute left until the class started. Radar and I had mathematics, while Ben had finite mathematics. Our classrooms were adjacent; we walked towards them, trusting that the stream of our classmates would part enough to let us pass, and it did.
es: He considered my answer for a minute, and I tried with all my might not to avert my gaze from his crossed eyes. He very gently nodded his head, stepped away from the locker, and went to his first class of the morning: Pectoral Muscle Maintenance. The second bell rang. There was one minute left before classes started. Radar and I had calculus, and Ben had finite mathematics. Our classes were next to each other. We headed to them together, the three of us in a row, trusting that the human tide would part enough to let us through, and it did.

en: I said, “Getting you a date to prom is so hard that a thousand monkeys typing at a thousand typewriters for a thousand years would never once type ‘I will go to prom with Ben.’”

es: —Getting you a date for the dance is so hard that a thousand monkeys typing on a thousand typewriters for a thousand years wouldn't write "I'll go to the prom with Ben" even once —I said.

en: Ben could not resist tearing himself apart. “My prom prospects are so poor that Q’s grandma turned me down. She said she was waiting for Radar to ask her.”

es: Ben couldn't resist beating himself up: —I have so few chances that even Q's grandmother has rejected me. She told me she was waiting for Radar to ask her.

vi: Radar slowly nodded. "That's right, Q. Your grandma likes her comrades."

en: It was so pathetically easy to forget about Chuck, to talk about prom even though I didn’t give a shit about prom. Such was life that morning: nothing really mattered that much, not the good things and not the bad ones. We were in the business of mutual amusement, and we were reasonably prosperous.
vi: It was so easy to forget Chuck, to eagerly discuss the ball even though I didn't care about it at all. The events of that morning: nothing was really too important, neither the good nor the bad. We were only busy entertaining each other, and we were leisurely generous in a very rightful way.
tr: Ignoring Chuck and talking about the prom, even though I didn't care at all, was pathetically easy. That morning, life was like this: Nothing was that important, neither the good things nor the bad things. We were in shared amusement and we were quite successful.
es: It was pathetically easy to forget about Chuck and talk about the prom, even though I didn't give a damn. That's how life was that morning: nothing mattered too much, neither the good things nor the bad. We were dedicated to having fun, and we were doing reasonably well.

en: I spent the next three hours in classrooms, trying not to look at the clocks above various blackboards, and then looking at the clocks, and then being amazed that only a few minutes had passed since I last looked at the clock. I’d had nearly four years of experience looking at these clocks, but their sluggishness never ceased to surprise. If I am ever told that I have one day to live, I will head straight for the hallowed halls of Winter Park High School, where a day has been known to last a thousand years.
vi: The next three hours I spent in class, trying not to look up at the clocks hanging on the blackboards, then looking at the clock, then panicking when I realized only a few minutes had passed since the last time I checked the time. I had nearly four years of experience watching the clock, but that snail's pace had never ceased to amaze me. If I were to live just one more day, I would rush to the endless corridors of Winter Park school, where everyone knows a day feels like a thousand years.
tr: Trying not to look at the clocks on various boards, but then looking at the clocks and then being surprised that only a few minutes had passed since I last looked, I spent the next three hours in different classes. I had almost four years of experience with looking at these clocks, but their sluggishness surprised me every time. If I were told I had only one day left, I would go straight to the sacred corridors of Winter Park High School, where one day felt like a thousand years.
es: I spent the next three hours in class, trying not to look at the clocks above the various blackboards, and then looking at them and being surprised that only a few minutes had passed since the last time I had looked. Even though I had almost four years of experience looking at those clocks, their slowness never ceased to amaze me. If I am ever told that I have one day left to live, I will go straight to the sacred halls of Winter Park High School, where it is known that a day lasts a thousand years.

es: He looked up and smiled. A girl accustomed to compliments. —Well, he has never invited me to go out with you all.

en: “But really, you wouldn’t worry? I mean, we’ve been dating for five weeks, and he’s never even taken me to his house.” Ben and I exchanged a knowing glance, and I scrunched up my face to suppress laughter. “What?” she asked.

en: “Nothing,” I said. “Honestly, Angela. If he was forcing you to hang out with us and taking you to his house all the time—”

es: —Nothing —I replied—. Honestly, Angela, if he forced you to go out with us and took you to his house every other day...

en: Radar threw his books into his locker and shut it. The din of conversation around us quieted just a bit as he turned his eyes toward the heavens and shouted, “IT IS NOT MY FAULT THAT MY PARENTS OWN THE WORLD’S LARGEST COLLECTION OF BLACK SANTAS.”

tr: He threw the radar books into the cupboard and closed the door. The conversations around us quieted a bit as he turned his eyes to the sky and shouted: “IT'S NOT MY FAULT THAT MY PARENTS HAVE THE WORLD'S LARGEST BLACK SANTA CLAUS COLLECTION.”
es: Radar threw his books into the locker and closed it. The noise of conversations around us quieted a bit as he looked up at the sky and shouted: —IT'S NOT MY FAULT THAT MY PARENTS HAVE THE WORLD'S LARGEST COLLECTION OF BLACK SANTA CLAUSES.

en: I’d heard Radar say “the world’s largest collection of black Santas” perhaps a thousand times in my life, and it never became any less funny to me. But he wasn’t kidding. I remembered the first time I visited. I was maybe thirteen. It was spring, many months past Christmas, and yet black Santas lined the windowsills. Paper cutouts of black Santas hung from the stairway banister. Black Santa candles adorned the dining room table. A black Santa oil painting hung above the mantel, which was itself lined with black Santa figurines. They had a black Santa Pez dispenser purchased from Namibia. The light-up plastic black Santa that stood in their postage-stamp front yard from Thanksgiving to New Year’s spent the rest of the year proudly keeping watch in the corner of the guest bathroom, a bathroom with homemade black Santa wallpaper created with paint and a Santa-shaped sponge.
vi: I have heard Radar groan about “the world's largest collection of Black Santas” thousands of times in my life, and I have never been able to stifle a laugh because of it. But Radar wasn’t joking. I still remember the first time I went to his house. I think I was thirteen then. It was spring, several months after Christmas, yet there were still countless Black Santas hanging on the window sills. Paper Black Santas were hanging along the stair railings. Black Santa-shaped candles were decorating the dining table. An oil painting of a Black Santa hung above the fireplace, and on the mantelpiece was a series of Black Santa figurines. In the house, there was a candy jar shaped like a Black Santa bought from Namibia. A Black Santa lamp, usually placed next to the mailbox in the front yard from Thanksgiving to New Year, stood proudly in the corner of the spare bathroom at other times of the year, a bathroom with homemade wallpaper featuring Black Santa motifs and a Black Santa-shaped loofah.
tr: I must have heard Radar's phrase "the world's largest collection of black Santa Clauses" thousands of times throughout my life, and it never lost its humor. But Radar wasn't joking. I remembered my first visit there. I think I was thirteen years old. It was spring, months had passed since Christmas, yet black Santa Clauses were lined up on the window sills. Paper black Santa Clauses were hung on the railings. The dining table was adorned with black Santa Claus candles. A painting of a black Santa Claus in oil paint was hung above the fireplace mantle, which was also decorated with black Santa Claus figurines. There were Pez dispensers in the shape of black Santa Clauses from Namibia. The lighted plastic black Santa Claus that stood in their tiny front yard from Thanksgiving to New Year's spent the rest of the year proudly guarding the corner of the guest bathroom, which was covered with homemade black Santa Claus wallpaper made from paint and Santa Claus-shaped sponges.
es: Although I had heard Radar say "the world's largest collection of Black Santa Clauses" about a thousand times in my life, it never ceased to amuse me. But he wasn't joking. I remembered the first time I had gone to his house. I was about thirteen years old. It was spring, several months after Christmas, but the Santa Clauses were still on the window sills. Paper Black Santa Clauses hung from the stair railing. Candles with Black Santa Clauses adorned the dining table. A painting of a Black Santa Claus was hung above the fireplace, on whose mantel also stood figurines of Black Santa Clauses. They had a PEZ dispenser with a Black Santa Claus head bought in Namibia. The plastic, light-up Black Santa Claus that they placed in the tiny yard from Thanksgiving to New Year's spent the rest of the year proudly watching over a corner of the guest bathroom, a bathroom wallpapered with homemade paper featuring painted Black Santa Clauses and a sponge in the shape of Santa Claus.

en: In every room, save Radar’s, their home was awash in black Santadom—plaster and plastic and marble and clay and wood and resin and cloth. In total, Radar’s parents owned more than twelve hundred black Santas of various sorts. As a plaque beside their front door proclaimed, Radar’s house was an officially registered Santa Landmark according to the Society for Christmas.
vi: In every room, except Radar's room, the kingdom of Black Santas expanded everywhere—on plaster, plastic, marble, clay, wood, and fabric. In total, Radar’s parents owned over twelve hundred Black Santas in every form imaginable. As solemnly written on a small plaque next to the front door, Radar's house was a Santa Claus monument officially recognized by the Christmas Association.
tr: All the rooms except Radar's were filled with black Santa Clauses... plaster, plastic, marble, clay, wood, wax, fabric. Radar's parents had more than twelve hundred black Santa Clauses in total, of various kinds. As declared on a sign next to their front door, Radar's house was officially registered as a Santa Claus city landmark by the Christmas Society.
es: All the rooms in the house, except Radar's, were filled with Black Santa Clauses made of plaster, plastic, marble, clay, wood, resin, and fabric. In total, Radar's parents had more than twelve hundred Black Santa Clauses of all kinds. As stated on a plaque above the front door, Radar's house was an official Santa Claus Monument, according to the Christmas Society.

en: “You just gotta tell her, man,” I said. “You just gotta say, ‘Angela, I really like you, but there’s something you need to know: when we go to my house and hook up, we’ll be watched by the twenty-four hundred eyes of twelve hundred black Santas.”
vi: “You just need to talk to Angela,” I said. “Something like, ‘Angela, I really like you, but there’s something you need to know: when we’re at my house and close together, we’ll be watched by two thousand four hundred eyes of one thousand two hundred black Santas.’”
tr: “Buddy, you need to tell Angela,” I said. “What you need to say is this: ‘Angela, I really like you, but there’s something you need to know: When we go to my place and fool around, we will be watched by twelve hundred black Santa Clauses' two thousand four hundred eyes.”
es: —You just have to tell her, man —I said to him—. You just have to say: "Angela, I really like you, but there's something you need to know: when we go to my house and we make out, two thousand four hundred eyes of twelve hundred black Santa Clauses will be watching us."

en: Radar ran a hand through his buzz cut and shook his head. “Yeah, I don’t think I’ll put it exactly like that, but I’ll deal with it.”
vi: Radar scratched his crew-cut head, shaking it. "Yeah, I didn't think I would say exactly that, but I'll handle it."
tr: Radar ran his hand through his cropped hair and nodded. "Yes, I don't think I would explain it exactly like that, but I'll handle it."
es: —Yes —agreed Radar, running a hand over his shaved head and nodding—. I don't think I'll tell him exactly like that, but I'll come up with something.

en: I headed off to government, Ben to an elective about video game design. I watched clocks through two more classes, and then finally the relief radiated out of my chest when I was finished— the end of each day like a dry run for our graduation less than a month away.
vi: I attended the class on state and government, while Ben took an elective course on video game design. I kept glancing at the clock throughout the next two periods, and finally, a sigh of relief escaped my chest when the class ended—the last part of the day always felt like a marathon with less than a month left until graduation.
tr: I set out for the political science class, while I had an elective course on computer game design. After attending two more classes and finishing my work, a sense of relief finally spread from my chest throughout my body... the end of each day felt like a rehearsal for our graduation, which was less than a month away.
es: I went to the politics class, and Ben to an elective on video game design. I watched clocks during two more classes and, in the end, when I finished, my chest radiated relief. The end of each day was like a preview of our graduation, which was just over a month away.

en: I went home. I ate two peanut butter and jelly sandwiches as an early dinner. I watched poker on TV. My parents came home at six, hugged each other, and hugged me. We ate a macaroni casserole as a proper dinner. They asked me about school. They asked me about prom. They marveled at what a wonderful job they’d done raising me. They told me about their days dealing with people who had been raised less brilliantly. They went to watch TV. I went to my room to check my email. I wrote a little bit about The Great Gatsby for English. I read some of The Federalist Papers as early prep for my government final. I IM’ed with Ben, and then Radar came online. In our conversation, he used the phrase “the world’s largest collection of black Santas” four times, and I laughed each time. I told him I was happy for him, having a girlfriend. He said it would be a great summer. I agreed. It was May fifth, but it didn’t have to be. My days had a pleasant identicalness about them. I had always liked that: I liked routine. I liked being bored. I didn’t want to, but I did. And so May fifth could have been any day—until just before midnight, when Margo Roth Spiegelman slid open my screenless bedroom window for the first time since telling me to close it nine years before.
vi: I went home. Ate two pieces of bread with peanut butter and jam as a snack. Watched poker on TV. My parents came home at six o'clock, hugged each other and hugged me. A proper dinner with baked pasta. My parents asked me about school. About the graduation prom. My parents marveled that raising me was an achievement of theirs. That in their daily work they have to deal with people who grew up with less attentive care. My parents went to watch TV. I went to my room to check emails. I wrote a bit about The Great Gatsby for English class. I read a bit of The Federalist Papers, preparing for the government and politics exam. I chatted online with Ben, and after a while Radar also came online. During the conversation, he mentioned "the world's largest collection of black Santas" four times, each time making me chuckle. I told him that I was very happy he had a girlfriend. He said this summer would be fun. I agreed. Today is the fifth of May, but it doesn't really matter. My days are pleasantly similar. I always liked it that way: a regular routine. I liked the feeling of slight boredom. I didn't want to like it, but I did. And so the fifth of May could be any day—until just before midnight that night, when Margo Roth Spiegelman slid open the screenless window of my room, for the first time since she told me to close it nine years ago.
tr: I went home. Before dinner, I ate two peanut butter and jelly sandwiches. I watched poker on TV. At six, my parents came home, hugged each other first, then hugged me. We ate baked pasta as a proper dinner. They asked questions about school. They asked questions about the prom. They marveled at what a great job they did raising me. They talked about their days spent dealing with people who weren't raised as skillfully as I was. They went to watch TV. I went to my room to check my emails. I wrote something about The Great Gatsby for English class. I read some of The Federalist Papers in preparation for my political science exam. I messaged with Ben online, then Radar came online. Radar used the phrase "the world's largest collection of black Santas" four times during our conversation, and I laughed each time. I told him I was happy for him because he had a girlfriend. He said it was going to be a great summer. I agreed. It was the fifth of May, but it didn't have to be. My days were passing in a happy monotony. I had always loved this: I loved the routine. I loved being bored. I didn't want to, but I loved it. So the fifth of May could have been any day... until just before midnight; until Margo Roth Spiegelman, for the first time since she told me to close it nine years ago, pushed open my bedroom window, which no longer had a screen.
es: I returned home. I ate two peanut butter and jelly sandwiches for a snack. I watched poker on TV. My parents arrived at six, they hugged each other and then hugged me. We had macaroni for dinner. They asked me about school. Then they asked me about the prom. They marveled at how well they had raised me. They told me that in their time they had to deal with people who weren't raised as well. They went to watch TV. I went to my room to check the mail. I wrote for a while about The Great Gatsby for literature class. I read The Federalist for a while to prepare in advance for the final politics exam. I chatted with Ben and then Radar logged on too. In our conversation, he used the phrase "the world's largest collection of black Santas" four times and I laughed each time. I told him I was glad he had a girlfriend. He said that summer would be great. I agreed. It was May 5th, but it could have been any other day. My days were peacefully identical to each other. I had always liked it. I liked the routine. I liked being bored. I didn't want to, but I liked it. And that's why that May 5th could have been any other day... until just before midnight, when Margo Roth Spiegelman opened my bedroom window, without a screen, for the first time since that night she had asked me to close it, nine years ago.

tr: When I heard the window open, I turned around instantly; Margo's blue eyes were looking at me.

en: I swiveled around when I heard the window open, and Margo’s blue eyes were staring back at me. Her eyes were all I could see at first, but as my vision adjusted, I realized she was wearing black face paint and a black hoodie. “Are you having cybersex?” she asked.

tr: When I heard the window open, I turned around instantly; Margo's blue eyes were looking at me. At first, the only thing I could see were her eyes, but after focusing, I noticed that her face was painted black and she was wearing a black hooded jacket. "Are you having virtual sex?" she asked.

en: I laughed awkwardly, then walked over and knelt by the window, my face inches from hers. I couldn’t imagine why she was here, in my window, like this. “To what do I owe the pleasure?” I asked. Margo and I were still friendly, I guess, but we weren’t meet-in-the-dead-of-night-wearing-black-face-paint friendly. She had friends for that, I’m sure. I just wasn’t among them.

I asked. Margo and I were still friends, I thought, but not the kind of friends who meet-in-the-middle-of-the-night-with-blackened-faces. I was sure she had friends for this kind of situation. And I was not one of those friends.
tr: Strangely, I laughed, then walked over there, knelt by the window, and sat down, my face very close to hers. I couldn't guess why she was here, at my window, in this manner. “To what do I owe this honor?” I asked. I was still close with Margo, I think, but not close enough to arrange a “meeting in the dead of night with a face painted black.” She had friends for that. I just wasn't among them.

I couldn't imagine why he was there, at my window, with his face painted. —To what do I owe the pleasure? —I asked him. Margo and I still had a good vibe, I suppose, but not to the point of meeting in the middle of the night with our faces painted black. For that, she already had her friends, surely. I was not among them.

tr: “You have your own car,” I reminded.
