en: Margo puffed out her cheeks and sighed. “Right, but the thing is that my parents have taken the keys to my car and locked them inside a safe, which they put under their bed, and Myrna Mount-weazel”— who was her dog—“is sleeping inside their room. And Myrna Mountweazel has a freaking aneurysm whenever she catches sight of me. I mean, I could totally sneak in there and steal the safe and crack it and get my keys out and drive away, but the thing is that it’s not even worth trying because Myrna Mountweazel is just going to bark like crazy if I so much as crack open the door. So like I said, I need a car. Also, I need you to drive it, because I have to do eleven things tonight, and at least five of them involve a getaway man.”
vi: Margo sighed deeply. "Yes, but the problem is that my parents keep my car keys in a safe, under the bed, and Myrna Mountweazel"—Margo's dog—"sleeps in their room. And Myrna Mountweazel has a fit every time she sees me. I mean, I could totally sneak into the room, grab the safe, break it open to get the car keys, and drive away, but the problem is that there's no point in trying because as soon as I open the door, Myrna Mountweazel will start barking like crazy. So, like I said, I need a car. I also need you to drive because tonight I have eleven things to do, and at least the first five require an accomplice to break me out."
tr: Margo puffed out her cheeks and sighed. “True, but the thing is, my mom and dad took my car keys and locked them in a safe under their bed, and Myma Mountweazel,” Margo’s dog, “is sleeping in their room and the moment she sees me, Myma Mountweazel’s damn aneurysm acts up. So actually, I could quietly enter the room, steal the safe, break it open to get my keys, and drive away, but the problem is, it's not even worth trying because even if I just crack the door open, Myrna Mountweazel will bark like crazy. So, as I said, I need the car. Also, you need to drive because I have to do eleven things tonight and at least five of them require someone to help me escape, buddy.”
es: Margo puffed out her cheeks and sighed. —True, but it turns out that my parents have taken the car keys from me and put them in a safe, which they left under their bed, and Myrna Mountweazel, the dog, is sleeping in their room. And Myrna Mountweazel has a damn stroke every time she sees me. So, I could perfectly sneak into the room, steal the safe, break it open, grab the keys, and take off, but the thing is, it's not worth trying because Myrna Mountweazel will start barking like crazy as soon as I peek through the door. So, as I was saying, I need a car. And I also need you to drive, because tonight I have to do eleven things, and at least five require someone to be waiting for me to make a quick getaway.

en: When I let my sight unfocus, she became nothing but eyes, floating in the ether. And then I locked back on her, and I could see the outline of her face, the paint still wet against her skin. Her cheekbones triangulating into her chin, her pitch-black lips barely turned to a smile. “Any felonies?” I asked.
vi: When I didn't focus my gaze anywhere, Margo seemed to dissolve and float in the air, leaving only her eyes. But when I focused on her, I could see the outline of her face, the black color still wet on Margo's skin. Her cheekbones and chin formed a triangle, and her dark lips faintly curved into a smile. "Is there any robbery, murder, or rape?" I asked.
tr: When I stopped focusing my gaze, Margo's image turned into just eyes floating in the air. Then I locked onto her again and could see the contours of her face, the paint on her skin was still wet. Her cheekbones formed a triangle down to her chin, a barely noticeable smile appeared on her pitch-black lips. "Will it involve any crime?" I asked.
es: When I didn't focus my gaze, Margo was all eyes floating in space. Then I would refocus and see the outline of her face, the paint still wet on her skin. Her cheekbones triangulated towards her chin, and her lips, black as coal, barely formed a smile. —Any crime? —I asked him.

en: “Hmm,” said Margo. “Remind me if breaking and entering is a felony.”
vi: "Hmm," Margo replied. "Remind me if breaking and entering is considered robbery, murder, or rape."
tr: “Hmm,” said Margo. “Remind me, was breaking and entering a crime?” I answered firmly, “No.”
es: —Hmm —Margo replied to me—. Remind me if breaking and entering is a crime.

en: “No,” I answered firmly.
vi: “No,” I replied succinctly.
tr: “Remind me, was breaking and entering a crime?” I answered firmly, “No.”
es: —No —I replied in a firm tone.

en: “No it’s not a felony or no you won’t help?”
vi: “If it's not considered robbery, murder, or rape, will you not help me?”
tr: “No, is it not a crime, or no, I will not help?”
es: —Is it not a crime, or are you not going to help me?

en: “No I won’t help. Can’t you enlist some of your underlings to drive you around?” Lacey and/or Becca were always doing her bidding.
vi: “No, I can't help you. Can't you find a junior to take you?” Lacey and/or Becca always obediently followed Margo.
tr: “No, I will not help. Can't you ask one of your minions to drive you around?” Lacey and/or Becca always followed his orders.
es: —I'm not going to help you. Can't you recruit one of your subordinates to take you? Lacey and/or Becca always did what she said.

en: “They’re part of the problem, actually,” Margo said.
vi: “Actually, they are part of the problem,” Margo said.
tr: “They are actually part of the problem,” said Margo.
es: —The truth is that they are part of the problem —Margo told me.

en: “What’s the problem?” I asked.
vi: “What’s the matter?” I asked.
tr: “What’s the problem?” I asked.
es: —What problem? —I asked him.

en: “There are eleven problems,” she said somewhat impatiently.
vi: “There are eleven issues in total,” she said, looking impatient.
tr: “There are eleven problems,” he said impatiently.
es: —There are eleven problems —he answered me with some impatience.

en: “No felonies,” I said.
vi: “No burning houses, killing people, or forcing innocent girls,” I stipulated.
tr: “There is no crime,” I said.
es: —Without crimes —I said.

en: “I swear to God that you will not be asked to commit a felony.”
vi: “I swear to God that you will not commit such a grave sin.”
tr: “I swear you won't need to commit a crime.”
es: —I swear to God that I will not ask you to commit any crime.

en: And right then, the floodlights came on all around Margo’s house. In one swift motion, she somersaulted through my window, into my room, and then rolled beneath my bed. Within seconds, her dad was standing on the patio outside. “Margo!” he shouted. “I saw you!”
vi: And at that very moment, Margo's house suddenly lit up brightly. Quick as a flash, she somersaulted through the window into my room, rolling under the bed. A split second later, Margo's dad was yelling from the back porch. "Margo! I see you!"
tr: And at that very moment, lights came on all over Margo's house. In a single swift motion, Margo tumbled through the window into my room and rolled under my bed. Within seconds, her father was standing on the terrace outside. “Margo!” he shouted. “I saw you!” I heard a muffled voice from under my bed.
es: And at that precise moment, all the lights surrounding Margo's house turned on. In a quick movement, she jumped through my window, got into my room, and threw herself under my bed. In a matter of seconds, his father came out into the yard. —Margo! —he shouted—. I saw you!

en: From beneath my bed, I heard a muffled, “Oh, Christ.” Margo scooted out from under the bed, stood up, walked to the window, and said, “Come on, Dad. I’m just trying to have a chat with Quentin. You’re always telling me what a fantastic influence he could be on me and everything.”
vi: I heard a groaning sound from under the bed, "Oh my God!" Margo crawled out from under the bed, stood up, went to the window, and said, "Dad, I was just talking to Quentin." "You always say he has a positive influence on me."
tr: “I saw you!” I heard a muffled voice from under my bed. “Oh, God.” Margo quickly emerged from under the bed, stood up, and walked towards the window. “Come on, Dad. I'm just trying to chat with Quentin. You always say how extraordinary Quentin's influence on me can be and all that.”
es: From under the bed came a muffled "Oh, damn." Margo quickly got out, stood up, approached the window, and said: —Let's go, Dad. I'm just trying to chat with Quentin. You spend the whole day telling me that he would be a fantastic influence and all that.

en: “Just chatting with Quentin?”
vi: "Just talking to Quentin?"
tr: “Are you just chatting with Quentin?”
es: "Are you just chatting with Quentin?"

en: “Yes.”
vi: “Yes.”
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “Then why are you wearing black face paint?”
vi: “Why do you have to paint your face so black like that?”
tr: “Then why is there black paint on your face?”
es: —And then why did you paint your face black?

en: Margo faltered for only the briefest moment. “Dad, to answer that question would take hours of backstory, and I know that you’re probably very tired, so just go back t—”
vi: Margo was momentarily startled for a very brief second. “Explaining everything in detail would take a long time, you must be tired now, so go to sl...”
tr: Margo hesitated for a very brief moment. “Dad, answering this question would require me to tell stories for hours, and I know you're probably very tired, so just go back...”
es: Margo hesitated for just a moment. —Dad, answering that question would take hours and I know you're probably very tired, so go back to...

en: “In the house,” he thundered. “This minute!”
vi: “Go home immediately,” Margo's dad roared. “Right now!”
tr: “Eve,” roared her father. “Immediately!”
es: —Home! —he shouted—. Right now!

en: Margo grabbed hold of my shirt, whispered, “Back in a minute,” in my ear, and then climbed out the window.
vi: Margo tugged at my sleeve, whispered "I'll be back in a minute" into my ear, then climbed out the window.
tr: Margo grabbed my shirt. “I will be back in a minute,” she whispered and climbed out the window.
es: Margo grabbed me by the shirt, whispered in my ear "I'll be back in a minute," and went out the window.

en: As soon as she left, I grabbed my car keys from my desk. The keys are mine; the car, tragically, is not. On my sixteenth birthday, my parents gave me a very small gift, and I knew the moment they handed it to me that it was a car key, and I about peed myself, because they’d said over and over again that they couldn’t afford to give me a car. But when they handed me the tiny wrapped box, I knew they’d been tricking me, that I was getting a car after all. I tore off the wrapping paper and popped open the little box. Indeed, it contained a key.
vi: As soon as Margo left, I grabbed the car keys from the table. The keys were mine, but the car, ironically, was not. On my sixteenth birthday, my parents gave me a very small gift, and I immediately understood that they were giving me a car key. I was so happy I almost peed myself because my parents had always said they couldn't afford to buy me a car. But when they handed me the tiny gift box, I knew right away that they had just been teasing before, and that I was finally getting a car. I tore off the wrapping paper and opened the little box. Sure enough, inside was a key.
tr: As soon as Margo left, I grabbed my keys from my desk. The keys are mine, tragically, not the car. On my sixteenth birthday, my mom and dad gave me a very small gift, and the moment they handed it to me, I knew it was a car key; I was almost going to pee my pants with excitement because they had repeatedly told me they couldn't afford a car. But when they gave me that tiny, wrapped box, I thought they had tricked me and that I finally had a car. I tore open the package and quickly opened the small box. Indeed, there was a key inside.
es: As soon as he left, I grabbed the car keys from the table. The keys are mine, although the tragic part is that the car isn't. When I turned sixteen, my parents gave me a very small gift. I knew as soon as they gave it to me that it was car keys, and I almost peed myself, because they had told me a thousand times that they couldn't buy me a car. But when they handed me the wrapped little box, I thought they had been joking and that I would finally have a car. I took off the wrapping and opened the little box, which indeed contained a key.

en: Upon close inspection, it contained a Chrysler key. A key for a Chrysler minivan. The one and the same Chrysler minivan owned by my mother.
vi: Upon closer inspection, it was a Chrysler car key. The key to a Chrysler minivan. It was indeed mom's Chrysler minivan.
tr: When I took a closer look, I saw that there was a Chrysler key inside. A Chrysler minivan key. The exact same Chrysler minivan that my mother owned.
es: I observed it and discovered that it was the key to a Chrysler. The key to a Chrysler minivan. Exactly to my mother's Chrysler minivan.

en: “My present is a key to your car?” I asked my mom.
vi: "Is the gift for me your car keys, Mom?" I asked her.
tr: I asked my mother, "Is my gift the key to your car?" "Tom," she said to my father, "I told you he would get his hopes up."
es: —Will you give me a key to your car? —I asked my mother.

en: “Tom,” she said to my dad, “I told you he would get his hopes up.”

tr: I asked my mother, "Is my gift the key to your car?" "Tom," she said to my father, "I told you he would get his hopes up."
es: —Tom —he said to my father—, I told you I would give him false hopes.

en: “Oh, don’t blame me,” my dad said. “You’re just sublimating your own frustration with my income.”

tr: My father said, "Ah, don't blame me." "You are only cleansing your own frustration with my gain."
es: —Don't blame me —my father replied to him—. You are sublimating your own frustrations about my salary.

en: “Isn’t that snap analysis a tad passive-aggressive?” my mother asked.
vi: “Isn't that a somewhat passive-aggressive hasty analysis?” Mom asked back.
tr: My mother asked, "Isn't this quick analysis a bit passive-aggressive?"
es: —Doesn't this analysis you're giving me have a bit of passive aggression? —my mother asked him.

en: “Aren’t rhetorical accusations of passive aggression inherently passive-aggressive?” my dad responded, and they went on like that for a while.
vi: “When making a rhetorical accusation of passive-aggressive behavior, isn't it true that those very accusations are inherently passive-aggressive themselves?” Dad retorted, and Mom and Dad continued like that for quite a while.
tr: “Aren't grandiose accusations about passive aggression essentially passive-aggressive themselves?” replied my father, and they continued like this for a while.
es: —And aren't accusations of passive aggression passive aggressions by nature? —my father replied. And they continued like that for a while.

en: The long and short of it was this: I had access to the vehicular awesomeness that is a late-model Chrysler minivan, except for when my mom was driving it. And since she drove to work every morning, I could only use the car on weekends. Well, weekends and the middle of the goddamned night.
vi: But sooner or later, it all comes down to this: I get to enjoy the wonderful transportation of the old Chrysler minivan, except when my mom is driving. And since my mom drives to work every morning, I can only use it on weekends. Well, weekends and the odd hours around midnight.
tr: Long story short: I had the opportunity to ride in a vehicular marvel, a brand-new Chrysler minivan, except when my mom was using it. And since my mom drove to work every day, I could only use the car on weekends. On weekends and, of course, in the dead of night.
es: The issue was the following: I would have access to that vehicular phenomenon that is the latest model Chrysler minivan, except when my mother used it. And since my mother drove to work every morning, I could only use it on weekends. Well, on weekends and in the middle of the damn night.

en: It took Margo more than the promised minute to return to my window, but not much more. But in the time she was gone, I’d started to waffle again. “I’ve got school tomorrow,” I told her.
vi: Margo took more than a minute as promised to return to my window, but not too long. Just as we were about to set off, my mind started to feel cluttered. "I have to go to school tomorrow," I said to Margo.
tr: It took Margo longer than the promised minute to return to my window, but not by much. However, during the time she was gone, I had been rambling to myself. "I have school tomorrow," I said.
es: Margo took longer than the promised minute to return to my window, though not much longer. But during her absence, I began to change my mind. —I have class tomorrow —I told him.

en: “Yeah, I know,” Margo answered. “There’s school tomorrow and the day after that, and thinking about that too long could make a girl bonkers. So, yeah. It’s a school night. That’s why we’ve got to get going, because we’ve got to be back by morning.”
vi: “Yeah, I know,” Margo replied. “We have to go to school tomorrow, and the day after too, but boys taking a long time to think things through can drive girls crazy. Alright, let's consider this night school. So now we go, because we have to be back before dawn.”
tr: Margo replied, "Yes, I know." 'There is school tomorrow and the day after that, thinking about this for too long can drive a girl crazy. So yes, there is school tomorrow. That's why we have to start, because we need to be back by morning."
es: —Yes, I know —Margo replied to me—. We have class tomorrow, and the day after tomorrow, and if I think about it too much, I'll end up going crazy. So yes, it is a night before class. That's why we have to leave now, because we need to be back by morning.

en: “I don’t know.”
vi: “I don't know.”
tr: "I don't know."
es: —I don't know…

en: “Q,” she said. “Q. Darling. How long have we been dear friends?”
vi: “Q,” she said. “Q. My good friend. How long have we been close friends?”
tr: “Q,” said Dedi. “Q. My dear. How long have we been good friends?”
es: —Q —he told me—. Q. Darling. How long have we been very good friends?

en: “We’re not friends. We’re neighbors.”
vi: "We are not friends. We are neighbors."
tr: “We are not friends, we are neighbors.”
es: —We are not friends. We are neighbors.

en: “Oh, Christ, Q. Am I not nice to you? Do I not order my various and sundry minions to be kind to you at school?”
vi: “Oh my God, Q, oh Q. Have I done anything bad to you?” “Didn't I tell my countless juniors at school to be nice to you?”
tr: “Ah, my God, Q. Am I not treating you well? Didn't I order them to be polite to you at school, to use all kinds of commands?’
es: —Damn, Q. Am I not nice to you? Don't I tell my buddies to treat you well at school?

en: “Uh-huh,” I answered dubiously, although in point of fact I’d always figured it was Margo who had stopped Chuck Parson and his ilk from screwing with us.
vi: "Hmm," I mumbled, although I had always suspected that it was Margo who had stopped Chuck Parson and his gang from messing with us.
tr: “Uh-huh,” I replied suspiciously, I had always suspected that it was actually Margo who prevented Chuck Parson and his ilk from bothering us.
es: —Ugh —I replied warily, although the truth was that I had always assumed it was Margo who had prevented Chuck Parson and his ilk from messing with us.

en: She blinked. She’d even painted her eyelids. “Q,” she said, “we have to go.”
vi: She blinked, her entire row of lashes also darkened. "Q," Margo said, "we have to go."
tr: He winked. He had even painted my eyelids. “Q,” he said, “we must go.”
es: Blinked. She had painted her eyelids black. —Q —he told me—, we have to go.

en: And so I went. I slid out the window, and we ran along the side of my house, heads down, until we opened the doors of the minivan. Margo whispered not to close the doors—too much noise—so with the doors open, I put it in neutral, pushed off the cement with my foot, and then let the minivan roll down the driveway. We rolled slowly past a couple houses before I turned on the engine and the headlights. We closed the doors, and then I drove through the serpentine streets of Jefferson Park’s endlessness, the houses all still new-looking and plastic, like a toy village housing tens of thousands of real people.
vi: And so I went. I quietly jumped through the window, and we crouched and ran along the side of the house until we could open the door of the minivan. Margo whispered not to close the car door—it would make too much noise—so with the door left open, I didn't start the car but pushed my foot against the cement, letting the car slowly roll down the road. We slowly passed a few houses before I started the engine and turned on the lights. We closed the car door, and I began driving through the seemingly endless winding streets of Jefferson Park, the houses still new and made of plastic, looking like a toy village with tens of thousands of real people.
tr: I went too. I slid out through the window and ran along the side of my house, heads down, until I opened the car doors. Margo whispered not to close the doors because it would make too much noise, so with the doors left open, I put the car in neutral, pushed it with my foot, and slid it down the path between the garage and the street. I didn't turn on the engine or the headlights Before that, we slowly passed in front of a few houses. We closed the doors and then I drove the car through the winding streets of Jefferson Park's infinity, with all the houses still looking new and plastic, like a toy village housing tens of thousands of real people.
es: And I went. I jumped out the window and we ran along the side wall of my house with our heads down until we opened the doors of the minivan. Margo whispered to me not to close the doors —too much noise—, so, with the doors open, I put the car in neutral, pushed off with my foot on the asphalt, and the minivan rolled down the driveway. We moved slowly past a couple of houses and then I turned on the engine and the lights. We closed the doors and I drove through the winding streets of the endless Jefferson Park, with its houses that still looked new and plastic, like a toy town that housed tens of thousands of real people.

en: Margo started talking. “The thing is they don’t even really care; they just feel like my exploits make them look bad. Just now, do you know what he said? He said, ‘I don’t care if you screw up your life, but don’t embarrass us in front of the Jacobsens—they’re our friends.’ Ridiculous. And you have no idea how hard they’ve made it to get out of that goddamned house. You know how in prison-escape movies they put bundled-up clothes under the blankets to make it look like there’s a person in there?” I nodded. “Yeah, well, Mom put a goddamned baby monitor in my room so she could hear my sleep-breathing all night. So I just had to pay Ruthie five bucks to sleep in my room, and then I put bundled-up clothes in her room.” Ruthie is Margo’s little sister. “It’s Mission: Impossible shit now. Used to be I could just sneak out like a regular goddamned American—just climb out the window and jump off the roof. But God, these days, it’s like living in a fascist dictatorship.”
vi: Margo began to tell. "The problem is that my parents don't really care, no matter how many cool feats I achieve, they just see it as ruining their reputation. Like just now, do you know what my dad said? 'I don't care what you do with your life, but don't embarrass us in front of the Jacobsens—they're friends of ours.' It's really funny. And you have no idea how much my parents have scraped to get that huge house. You know in those prison break movies, where they stuff clothes under the blanket to pretend someone's lying there?" I nodded. "Yeah, well, my mom set up this stupid baby monitor in my room to listen to me breathe while I sleep every night. So I had to pay Ruthie five bucks to sleep in my room, while I stuffed a bunch of clothes on her bed." Ruthie is Margo's younger sister. "So it turned into a whole Mission Impossible thing. I used to just sneak out of the house, like any normal damn American—just climb out the window and jump off the roof. But my god, now it's like living under a fascist dictatorship."
tr: Margo started talking. “The thing is, they don't even care, they just feel like my adventures make them look bad. Do you know what my dad just said? He said: ‘I don't care if you mess up your life, but don't embarrass us in front of the Jacobsens... they are our friends.’ Ridiculous. And you can't even imagine how hard they make it to get out of that damn house. You know in prison break movies, they put bundled clothes under the blanket to make it look like someone is there?’ I nodded. “Well, my mom put a damn baby monitor in my room so she could hear me breathing all night. So I had to pay Ruthie five dollars to sleep in my room and put the bundled clothes in her room.” Ruthie is Margo’s sister. “Now it’s like damn Mission Impossible. I used to be able to sneak out like a regular, damn American... just climbing out the window and jumping off the roof was enough. But God, these days it’s like living in a fascist dictatorship.”
es: Margo began to speak. —The thing is, they don't even care, they just think my exploits make them look bad. Do you know what my father just told me? He said: "I don't care if you screw up your life, but don't embarrass us in front of the Jacobsens. They are our friends." Ridiculous. And you can't imagine how hard it was for me to get out of that damn house. Have you seen those movies where they escape from jail and put clothes under the sheets to make it look like there's someone in the bed? —I nodded—. Yeah, well, my mother put a crappy baby monitor in my room to hear my breathing all night while I sleep. So I had to give Ruthie five bucks to sleep in my room, and then I got dressed in hers. —Ruthie is Margo's younger sister—. Now it's a damn Mission Impossible. It used to be about sneaking out like in any normal damn house, climbing out the window and jumping, but, damn, lately it's like living in a fascist dictatorship.

en: “Are you going to tell me where we’re going?”
vi: “Can you tell me where we are going?”
tr: “Are you going to tell me where we are going?”
es: —Are you going to tell me where we are going?

en: “Well, first we’re going to Publix. Because for reasons I’ll explain later, I need you to go grocery shopping for me. And then to Wal-Mart.”
vi: “Well, first go to Publix supermarket. For reasons I will explain later, I need you to go in and buy things for me. Then we will go to the Wal-Mart store.”
tr: “Well, first we are going to Publix. Because of reasons I will explain later. You need to do grocery shopping for me. Then to Walmart.”
es: —Well, first we will go to Publix. Because, for reasons that I will explain to you later, I need you to buy me some things at the supermarket. And then we will go to Walmart.

en: “What, we’re just gonna go on a grand tour of every commercial establishment in Central Florida?” I asked.
vi: “What, are we going to take a grand tour through the shopping spots in Central Florida?” I asked.
tr: "So what, are we going to take a big tour that includes all the commercial businesses in Central Florida?" I asked.
es: —What? Are we going to tour all the stores in Florida? —I asked him.

en: “Tonight, darling, we are going to right a lot of wrongs. And we are going to wrong some rights. The first shall be last; the last shall be first; the meek shall do some earth-inheriting. But before we can radically reshape the world, we need to shop.” I pulled into the Publix then, the parking lot almost entirely empty, and parked.
vi: “Tonight, my dear friend, we will correct many wrongs. And we will do some wrongs to the right things. The first will be last and the last will be first, the meek will inherit the earth, just you wait and see. But before we can fundamentally reshape the world, we need to go shopping first.” So I drove to Publix, the parking lot was almost empty, and we parked.
tr: “Darling, tonight we will make many wrongs right. And we will make some rights wrong. The first will be last, the last will be first, and the humble will inherit the earth. 4 But before radically reshaping the world, go shopping There is a reference to the 4 Gospels, (cf. n.) we are.” At this moment, I entered Publix, the parking lot was almost completely empty, I parked.
es: —Honey, tonight you and I are going to correct a bunch of mistakes. And we are going to introduce mistakes into some things that are right. The first will be last, the last will be first, and the meek shall inherit the earth. But before we can totally reorganize the world, we have to buy several things. So I pulled into the Publix parking lot, almost empty, and parked.

en: “Listen,” she said, “how much money do you have on you right now?”
vi: “Hey,” Margo said, “how much money do you have right now?”
tr: “Listen,” he said, “how much money do you have on you right now?”
es: —Hey, how much money do you have on you? —he asked me.

en: “Zero dollars and zero cents,” I answered. I turned off the ignition and looked over at her. She wriggled a hand into a pocket of her tight, dark jeans and pulled out several hundred-dollar bills. “Fortunately, the good Lord has provided,” she said.

en: Margo managed to speak in her usual manic soliloquy without answering my question. “Did you know that for pretty much the entire history of the human species, the average life span was less than thirty years? You could count on ten years or so of real adulthood, right? There was no planning for retirement. There was no planning for a career. There was no planning. No time for planning. No time for a future. But then the life spans started getting longer, and people started having more and more future, and so they spent more time thinking about it. About the future. And now life has become the future. Every moment of your life is lived for the future—you go to high school so you can go to college so you can get a good job so you can get a nice house so you can afford to send your kids to college so they can get a good job so they can get a nice house so they can afford to send their kids to college.”
vi: Margo responded in a monologue style mixed with a familiar excitement without directly answering my question. "You know, from ancient times and for a very long period in human history, the average lifespan of humans was less than thirty. That means people had about ten years of adulthood, right? So there was no need to plan for retirement. No career planning either. No concept of planning at all. There was no time to plan. No time for the future. But then lifespans started to lengthen, and people began to have more of what we call the future, so they spent more time thinking about it. Thinking about the future. And now life has become the future. Every moment in your life is lived for the future—you go to high school to get into college to get a good job to buy a nice house to earn money to send your kids to college so they can get good jobs to buy nice houses to earn money to send their kids to college."
tr: Margo, as usual, managed to speak in her crazy monologue without answering my question. “Did you know that for almost all of human history, the average lifespan was less than thirty years? You could only count on living a real adulthood for about ten years, right? There was no planning for retirement. There was no planning for a career. There was no planning. There was no time to make plans. There was no time for the future. But then lifespans started to increase, and people began to have more and more of a future, so they spent more time thinking about it. About the future. And now life has become the future. Every moment of your life is lived for the future... you go to high school so you can go to college, so you can get a good job, so you can buy a nice house, so you can afford to send your kids to college, so your kids can get a good job, so they can buy a nice house, so they can afford to send their kids to college.”
es: Margo managed to unleash one of her usual frenetic monologues without answering my question. —Did you know that, for almost the entire history of the human species, the average lifespan has been less than thirty years? They had about ten years of adult life, right? They didn't plan for retirement. They didn't plan their professional career. They didn't plan anything. They didn't have time to make plans. They didn't have time to think about the future. But then life expectancy started to increase and people began to have more and more future, so they spent more time thinking about it. About the future. And now life has become the future. You live every moment of your life for the future… You go to high school so you can go to college, and that way you can find a good job, and that way you can buy a nice house, and that way you can afford to send your kids to college so they can find a good job and that way they can buy a nice house and that way they can afford to send their kids to college.

en: Margo patted me in the middle of the back softly. “I mean, obviously this is all going to be revealed to you before the night is over.” And then, in boating supplies, Margo located an air horn. She took it out of the box and held it up in the air, and I said, “No,” and she said, “No what?” And I said, “No, don’t blow the air horn,” except when I got to about the b in blow, she squeezed on it and it let out an excruciatingly loud honk that felt in my head like the auditory equivalent of an aneurysm, and then she said, “I’m sorry, I couldn’t hear you. What was that?” And I said, “Stop b—” and then she did it again.
vi: Margo gently patted my back. "Didn't I tell you that everything would become clear before dawn?" And then, in the boating equipment section, Margo picked up an air horn. She took it out of the box and raised it high, and I immediately said, "No, don't," and Margo asked back, "What do you mean, don't?" I continued, "You can't use an air horn here," but I had barely said the "u" in "use" when she pressed the horn and a piercing shriek tore through the air, buzzing in my head, as if my blood vessels were swelling and pounding. Margo calmly asked, "Sorry, I didn't hear you, what did you just say?" And I was in the middle of saying "Don't b..." when she pressed the horn again.
tr: Margo gently patted my shoulder. “I mean, it's obvious M, all of this will come out before the night is over.” Then she found a horn among the boating supplies. She took the horn out of its box and raised it in the air, “No,” I said, “What no?” she said. I said, “No, don't blow the horn,” but as I got to the 'b' of 'blow,' Margo squeezed the horn and it emitted an unbearably loud sound that felt like the auditory equivalent of an aneurysm in my head. Then, “Sorry, I couldn't hear you. What did you say?” she said. “Don't bl...” I said and then she did it again.

She took it out of the box and raised her arm. —No —I told him. —No what? —he asked me. —Don't honk the horn —I replied to him. Although when I was on the "t" of "toques", he pressed and the horn let out a dreadful buzz that resonated in my head like the auditory equivalent of a stroke. —Sorry. I didn't hear you. What were you saying? —he asked me. —Stop t… And he honked the horn again.

en: A Wal-Mart employee just a little older than us walked up to us then and said, “Hey, you can’t use that in here,” and Margo said, with seeming sincerity, “Sorry, I didn’t know that,” and the guy said, “Oh, it’s cool. I don’t mind, actually.” And then the conversation seemed over, except the guy could not stop looking at Margo, and honestly I don’t blame him, because she is hard to stop looking at, and then finally he said, “What are you guys up to tonight?”

Finally, he said, "Do you two have any plans now?"

en: Margo hid the fish between folded pairs of shorts in Becca’s closet. I could hear footsteps upstairs, and tapped Margo on the shoulder and looked at her, my eyes bulging. In an elegant motion—the kind you associate with calligraphy or Zorro—she spray-painted the letter M onto the wall above the desk.

en: I swore, and before I could even start to stand, I felt Margo’s hands pulling me up, and then we were in the car and I was driving in reverse with the lights off, which is how I nearly came to run over the mostly naked starting shortstop of the Winter Park High School Wildcats baseball team. Jase was running very fast, but he didn’t seem to be running anyplace in particular. I felt another stab of regret as we backed up past him, so I rolled the window halfway down and threw his polo in his general direction. Fortunately, I don’t think he saw either Margo or me, and he had no reason to recognize the minivan since—and I don’t want to sound bitter or anything by dwelling on this—I can’t drive it to school.

In a second we were in the car, and I backed up without turning on the lights, which is more or less how I passed through the almost deserted torpedo station of the Wildcats baseball team from Winter Park. Jase was running at full speed, but he didn't seem to be heading anywhere in particular. I felt another pang of remorse as I passed by him, so I rolled down the window halfway and threw him the shirt. I don't think he saw either Margo or me, luckily. There was no reason for him to recognize the minivan either, given that —and I don't want to sound bitter by insisting on this— I can't use it to go to school.

en: And so we sat there, she with her nail polish balanced on the dash, and me with a shaky finger on the pulse of myself. It was a good color of nail polish, and Margo had nice fingers, thinner and bonier than the rest of her, which was all curves and soft edges. She had the kind of fingers you want to interlace with your own. I remembered them against my hip bone in Wal-Mart, which felt like days ago. My heartbeat slowed. And I tried to tell myself: Margo’s right. There’s nothing out here to be afraid of, not in this little city on this quiet night.

Margo had the kind of fingers that made others just want to intertwine their hands with hers. I remembered those fingers on my hip in the Wal-Mart aisle, as if it had been many days ago. There is nothing to fear on this quiet night, in this small town.

en: She’d only taken one stride when the house lit up like a municipal Christmas tree, and a siren started blaring. I briefly contemplated abandoning Margo to her fate, but just kept breathing in through the nose and out through the mouth as she ran toward the house. She heaved the fish through a window, but the sirens were so loud I could barely even hear the glass breaking. And then, just because she’s Margo Roth Spiegelman, she took a moment to carefully spray-paint a lovely M on the part of the window that wasn’t shattered. Then she was running all out toward the car, and I had a foot on the accelerator and a foot on the brake, and the Chrysler felt at that moment like a Thoroughbred racehorse. Margo ran so fast her hat blew off behind her, and then she jumped into the car, and we were gone before she even got the door closed.

en: She laughed, waved her hand at me, and said, “You just love my big ass.” I turned from the road for a second and glanced over, and I shouldn’t have, because she could read my face and my face said: Well, first off I wouldn’t say it’s big exactly and second off, it is kind of spectacular. But it was more than that. You can’t divorce Margo the person from Margo the body. You can’t see one without seeing the other. You looked at Margo’s eyes and you saw both their blueness and their Margo-ness. In the end, you could not say that Margo Roth Spiegelman was fat, or that she was skinny, any more than you can say that the Eiffel Tower is or is not lonely. Margo’s beauty was a kind of sealed vessel of perfection—uncracked and uncrackable.

We found Lacey’s black SUV parked in front of the sushi restaurant. We stopped a block away in the first parking spot we could find not beneath a streetlight.
vi: I drove along Jefferson Park to avoid passing by my house and Margo's, in case our parents woke up and discovered we had snuck out. We followed the lake (Jefferson Lake), turned at Jefferson Court, into the central shopping street of the entire Jefferson Park area, which was eerily quiet and deserted at this hour. We saw Lacey's black SUV parked in front of a sushi restaurant. I parked the car a building away, the first available spot without streetlights.
tr: I drove the car around Jefferson Park, so we could avoid passing by our houses, in case our parents had woken up and noticed we weren't home. We went along the lake (Jefferson Lake), then turned towards Jefferson Courthouse. we went to the small, artificial center of Jefferson Park, which looked eerily deserted and silent. We found Lacey's black SUV parked in front of the sushi restaurant. We stopped a block away, in the first parking spot we found that wasn't under a streetlight.
es: I took a detour through Jefferson Park to avoid passing by our houses, just in case our parents had woken up and discovered that we weren't there. We skirted the lake (Jefferson Lake), turned onto Jefferson Court, and headed towards the small, artificial center of Jefferson Park, which seemed eerily deserted and quiet. We found Lacey's black SUV parked in front of the sushi restaurant. We parked a block away, in the first spot we found that wasn't under a streetlight.

en: “Would you please hand me the last fish?” Margo asked me. I was glad to get rid of the fish because it was already starting to smell. And then Margo wrote on the paper wrapper in her lettering: your Friendship with ms Sleeps with The fishes We wove our way around the circular glow of the streetlights, walking as casually as two people can when one of them (Margo) is holding a sizable fish wrapped in paper and the other one (me) is holding a can of blue spray paint. A dog barked, and we both froze, but then it was quiet again, and soon we were at Lacey’s car.
vi: “Could you please give me the last fish?” Margo asked. I was relieved to get rid of that fish because it was starting to smell. And Margo wrote on the wrapping paper in her style: your FriendShip with ms has Slept with the Fishes We avoided the beams of streetlights, walking as naturally as possible even though one person (Margo) was holding a large fish wrapped in paper, and the other (me) was clutching a spray paint can. A dog barked incessantly, and the two of us froze, but then it quieted down, and we reached Lacey's car.
tr: “Can you pass me the last fish?” Margo asked. I was glad to be rid of the fish because it had already started to smell. Then Margo wrote on the wrapping paper in her own handwriting: Friendship with ms is Sleeping with Fish We moved forward in zigzags around the circular glows of the street lamps, walking as ordinarily as two people could, one (Margo) holding a large fish wrapped in paper and the other (me) holding a can of blue spray paint. A dog barked and we both froze, but then it got quiet again and soon we arrived at Lacey's car.
es: —Can you pass me the last fish, please? —Margo asked me. I was glad that we got rid of the fish, because it was already starting to smell. And then Margo wrote in her handwriting on the paper that wrapped it: "Your Friendship with ms Sleeps with The fishes". We weaved between the circular beams of light from the streetlights, walking as inconspicuously as two people can when one of them (Margo) is carrying a considerable-sized fish wrapped in paper, and the other (me) is carrying a can of blue spray paint. A dog barked, and we both froze, but it quickly quieted down and we soon reached Lacey's car.

en: “Well, that makes it harder,” Margo said, seeing it was locked. She reached into her pocket and pulled out a length of wire that had once been a coat hanger. It took her less than a minute to jimmy the lock open. I was duly awed.
vi: “Well, this is going to be harder,” Margo said when she saw the car was locked. She searched in her bag and took out a piece of wire that used to be a coat hanger. In less than a minute, Margo had the car door open. I could only stand there in awe.
tr: “Well, this makes things even more difficult,” said Margo when she saw that the car was locked. She reached into her pocket and pulled out a piece of wire that was once a clothes hanger. It took her less than a minute to unlock the car. Of course, I was impressed.
es: —Well, this complicates things —said Margo upon seeing that it was closed. He put a hand in his pocket and took out a piece of wire that had once been a hanger. It took him less than a minute to unlock the lock. I was surprised, of course.

en: Once she had the driver’s-side door open, she reached over and opened my side. “Hey, help me get the seat up,” she whispered. Together we pulled the backseat up. Margo slipped the fish underneath it, and then she counted to three, and in one motion we slammed the seat down on the fish. I heard the disgusting sound of catfish guts exploding. I let myself imagine the way Lacey’s SUV would smell after just one day of roasting in the sun, and I’ll admit that a kind of serenity washed over me. And then Margo said, “Put an M on the roof for me.”
vi: Opening the door on the driver's side, Margo leaned over to open the other door for me. "Hey, help me lift the seat up," she whispered. We lifted the back seat together. Margo shoved the fish underneath and counted to three, and with a single motion, we dropped the seat down, crushing the fish. I heard the disgusting sound of the fish's guts being squished flat. I allowed myself to imagine how Lacey's SUV would smell after a day roasting in the sunlight, and I had to admit that a feeling of serene satisfaction welled up inside me. Then Margo said, "Spray an M on the roof for me."
tr: As soon as the driver opened his door, he reached over and opened mine too. "Hey, help me lift the seat up," he whispered. Together, we lifted the back seat up. Margo shoved the fish under the seat, then counted to three, and in one swift motion, we lowered the seat onto the fish. I heard the disgusting sound of the catfish's internal organs bursting. I tried to imagine how Lacey's car would smell after just one day baking in the sun, and I confess, a kind of peace washed over me. Then Margo said, "Write an M on the ceiling for me."
es: As soon as he had opened the driver's door, he extended his arm and opened the one on my side. —Hey, help me lift the seat —he whispered to me. We lifted the seat between the two of us. Margo put the fish underneath, counted to three, and in one swift motion, we put the seat back in place. I heard the disgusting sound of the catfish's guts bursting. I imagined how Lacey's SUV would smell after a day baking in the sun, and I admit a kind of serenity washed over me. —Make an M on the ceiling —Margo asked me.

en: I didn’t even have to think about it for a full second before I nodded, scrambled up onto the back bumper, and then leaned over, quickly spraying a gigantic M all across the roof. Generally, I am opposed to vandalism. But I am also generally opposed to Lacey Pemberton—and in the end, that proved to be the more deeply held conviction. I jumped off the car. I ran through the darkness—my breath coming fast and short—for the block back to the minivan. As I put my hand on the steering wheel, I noticed my pointer finger was blue. I held it up for Margo to see. She smiled, and held out her own blue finger, and then they touched, and her blue finger was pushing against mine softly and my pulse failed to slow. And then after a long time, she said, “Part Nine— downtown.”
vi: Without thinking for even a second, I nodded immediately, climbed onto the rear bumper, leaned forward, and quickly sprayed a giant letter M on the roof of the car. In general, I am against all forms of vandalism. But in general, I am also against Lacey Pemberton–and ultimately, that is a deeper and more profound verdict. I jumped off the car, ran quickly in the dark–starting to breathe more heavily and rapidly–towards the minivan a block away. When I placed my hand on the steering wheel, I realized my index finger was blue. I held it up for Margo to see. She laughed, held up her own blue finger, and our fingers touched, Margo's soft blue finger touching mine, and the blood in my veins couldn't slow down. After a long moment, Margo finally said: “Part Nine–downtown.”
tr: I didn't need to think for even a second before nodding my head, I climbed onto the rear bumper, then bent down and quickly spray-painted a huge M across the roof. Normally, I was against vandalism. But normally, I was also against Lacey Pemberton... and after all, this proved to be a more deeply held belief. It landed. I jumped out of the car. I ran along the block towards the minivan, taking quick and short breaths into the darkness. As I put my hand on the steering wheel, I noticed that my index finger was blue. I raised my finger for Margo to see. She smiled and extended her own blue finger, then our fingers touched, her blue finger softly pushing mine, and my pulse couldn't slow down. After a long while, Margo said, “Section Nine... downtown.”
es: I didn't think about it for even a second. I nodded, climbed onto the rear bumper, leaned forward, and quickly sprayed a giant M on the roof. Normally, I'm against vandalism, but I'm also normally against Lacey Pemberton, and in the end, the latter turned out to be my most deeply held conviction. I jumped off the car and ran in the darkness —my breathing becoming more rapid and shorter— towards the minivan. As I put my hand on the steering wheel, I saw that my index finger was blue. I lifted it so Margo could see it. She smiled, lifted her blue finger, and we touched, her blue finger gently pushing mine, and my pulse couldn't slow down. —Ninth part —he said after a good while—:

en: It was 2:49 in the morning. I had never, in my entire life, felt less tired.
vi: It was 2:49 AM. Never in my entire life had I felt so exhausted.
tr: It was 2:49 in the morning. I had never felt less tired in my entire life.
es: To the center. It was 2:49 in the morning. Never in my entire life had I been less tired.

en: Tourists never go to downtown Orlando, because there’s nothing there but a few skyscrapers owned by banks and insurance companies. It’s the kind of downtown that becomes absolutely deserted at night and on the weekends, except for a few nightclubs half-filled with the desperate and the desperately lame. As I followed Margo’s directions through the maze of one-way streets, we saw a few people sleeping on the sidewalk or sitting on benches, but nobody was moving. Margo rolled down the window, and I felt the thick air blow across my face, warmer than night ought to be. I glanced over and saw strands of hair blowing all around her face. Even though I could see her there, I felt entirely alone among these big and empty buildings, like I’d survived the apocalypse and the world had been given to me, this whole and amazing and endless world, mine for the exploring.
vi: Tourists never come to downtown Orlando because there's nothing there except a few skyscrapers belonging to banks and insurance companies. The downtown area is completely deserted at night and on weekends, except for a few scattered nightclubs, half of whose patrons are either miserable or miserably staggering. As I drove, Margo directed me through the maze of one-way streets, and we saw a few people sleeping on the sidewalks or sprawled on benches, but none of them were moving. Margo rolled down the car window, and the air from outside rushed onto my face, warmer than the usual night weather. I glanced over and saw a few strands of her hair blowing across her face. Even though Margo was right there, I still felt completely alone among these massive, empty skyscrapers, as if I were the sole survivor of an apocalypse and the world had been entrusted to me, this entire endless and hidden world full of surprises, all for me to explore to my heart's content.
tr: Tourists never go to downtown Orlando because there is nothing there except for a few skyscrapers belonging to banks and insurance companies. This is the kind of downtown that is completely deserted at night and on weekends, except for a few nightclubs half-filled with the desperate and the desperately boring. As I navigated through the labyrinth of one-way streets according to Margo's directions, we saw a few people sleeping on the sidewalk or sitting on benches, but no one was moving. Margo rolled down the window, and I felt the stale air blowing against my face, warmer than it should have been at night. When I looked at Margo, I saw strands of hair flying all over her face. Even though I could see Margo there, I felt completely alone among these big and empty buildings; as if I had survived the apocalypse and the world had been granted to me, as if this amazing and endless world was mine to explore.
es: Tourists never go to downtown Orlando because it has nothing, aside from several skyscrapers of banks and insurance companies. It is one of those downtowns that become absolutely deserted at night and on weekends, except for a couple of half-empty nightclubs for the desperate and the desperately bored. While following Margo's directions through the maze of one-way streets, we saw several people sleeping on the sidewalks or sitting on benches, but no one was moving. Margo rolled down the window and I felt a dense gust of air on my face, warmer than usual at night. I looked at Margo and saw strands of hair flying around her face. Even though I was looking at her, I felt completely alone amidst those tall and empty buildings, as if I had survived the apocalypse, and the world, that whole surprising and infinite world, opened up before me for exploration.

en: “You just giving me the tour?” I asked.
vi: “Are you just going to lead me around in circles like this?” I asked.
tr: “Are you just taking me for a ride?” I asked.
es: —Are you taking me on a sightseeing tour? —I asked him.

en: “No,” she said. “I’m trying to get to the SunTrust Building. It’s right next to the Asparagus.”
vi: “No,” Margo replied. “I’m giving directions to the SunTrust building, right next to the Asparagus Tree.”
tr: “No,” he said. “I am trying to reach the SunTrust building. Right next to Kuşkonmaz.”
es: —No —he answered me—. I'm trying to get to the SunTrust Building. It's right next to the Asparagus.

en: “Oh,” I said, because for once on this night I had useful information. “That’s on South.” I drove down a few blocks and then turned. Margo pointed happily, and yes, there, before us, was the Asparagus.
vi: “Oh,” I exclaimed, for the first time tonight I knew some useful information. “That place is to the south.” I drove through a few blocks and then turned. Margo cheerfully pointed, yes, there it was, in front of us, the Asparagus Tree.
tr: “Yes,” I said, because tonight I had received useful information for the first time. “It’s down south.” I drove a few more blocks and turned. Margo pointed happily with her hand and yes, Asparagus was right there, directly in front of us.
es: —Ah —I said, because for the first time that night I had useful information—. It's to the south. I left several blocks behind and turned. Margo pointed very happily, and yes, in front of us was the Asparagus.

en: The Asparagus is not, technically, an asparagus spear, nor is it derived from asparagus parts. It is just a sculpture that bears an uncanny resemblance to a thirty-foot-tall piece of asparagus— although I’ve also heard it likened to:
vi: The Asparagus Tree is actually not the asparagus shoot growing from the ground, nor is it related to any part of the asparagus. It is merely a sculpture that bizarrely resembles an asparagus tree about ten meters tall, though I have also heard many people say that it looks like:
tr: Technically, the asparagus is neither an asparagus shoot nor made up of asparagus parts. It's just a sculpture that bears a mysterious resemblance to a roughly nine-meter piece of asparagus... However, I had also heard that it resembles the following:
es: Technically, the Asparagus is neither an asparagus nor a derivative of asparagus. It is a rare ten-meter sculpture that looks like an asparagus, although I have also heard it compared to:

en: 1. A green-glass beanstalk
vi: 1. A bean plant climbing on green glass
tr: 1. Beanstalk made of green glass
es: 1. A glass bean stalk.

en: 2. An abstract representation of a tree
vi: 2. An abstract simulation of a tree
tr: 2. An abstract representation of a tree
es: 2. An abstract representation of a tree.

en: 3. A greener, glassier, uglier Washington Monument
vi: 3. The Washington Monument, a greener version, seems more like scrap and uglier
tr: 3. A greener, more glassy, uglier Washington Monument
es: 3. A monument to Washington, but green, made of glass, and ugly.

en: 4. The Jolly Green Giant’s gigantic jolly green phallus
vi: 4. The giant green phallic statue of the Jolly Green Giant
tr: 4. The cheerful green giant's cheerful green gigantic penis
es: 4. The cheerful and gigantic green phallus of the giant from the Green Giant brand.

en: At any rate, it certainly does not look like a Tower of Light, which is the actual name of the sculpture. I pulled in front of a parking meter and looked over at Margo. I caught her staring into the middle distance just for a moment, her eyes blank, looking not at the Asparagus, but past it. It was the first time I thought something might be wrong—not my-boyfriend-is-an-ass wrong, but really wrong. And I should have said something. Of course. I should have said thing after thing after thing after thing. But I only said, “May I ask why you have taken me to the Asparagus?”
vi: From every angle, the sculpture didn't resemble the Tower of Light, its real name, at all. I stopped in front of a clock post in the parking lot and looked over at Margo, seeing her staring blankly into the distance, her eyes empty, not looking at the Asparagus Tree but gazing far beyond it. For the first time, I felt that something was wrong—not the my-boyfriend-is-a-jerk kind of wrong, but something truly amiss. I should have said something. Probably. I should have talked about this, that, here, there. But I only said, "Let me ask you, why did you bring me to the Asparagus Tree?"
tr: In any case, it didn't look like the real name of the statue, which was Light Tower. I parked in front of a parking meter and looked at Margo. I caught her for a moment staring into the distance with blank eyes, not at Asparagus, but beyond it. This was the first moment I thought something might be wrong—not the "my boyfriend is a jerk" kind of wrong, but a real wrong. I should have said something. Undoubtedly, I should have said one thing after another and another, but I only said, "Can I ask why you brought me to Asparagus?"
es: In any case, what is beyond the slightest doubt is that it does not seem like a Tower of Light, which is what the sculpture is actually called. I parked in front of a parking meter and looked at Margo. I caught her staring straight ahead with expressionless eyes, but she wasn't looking at the Asparagus, she was looking beyond it. For the first time, I thought that maybe something was wrong, not the kind of "my boyfriend is an asshole" wrong, but something truly bad. And I should have said something. Of course. I should have said a million things. But I just said: —Can I ask you why you have brought me to the Asparagus?

en: She turned her head to me and shot me a smile. Margo was so beautiful that even her fake smiles were convincing. “We gotta check on our progress. And the best place to do that is from the top of the SunTrust Building.”
vi: She turned around and smiled at me. Margo was so beautiful that even her fake smiles were believable. "We will check the progress of the work. And the ideal place to do that is from the roof of the SunTrust building."
tr: She turned her head to me and smiled. Margo was so beautiful that even her fake smiles were convincing. "We need to check our progress. And the best place to do that is the top of the SunTrust building."
es: She turned towards me and gave me a smile. Margo was so beautiful that even her fake smiles were convincing. —Let's evaluate our progress. And the best place to do it is at the top of the SunTrust Building.

en: I rolled my eyes. “Nope. No. No way. You said no breaking and entering.”
vi: I widened my eyes. "No. No way. Not a chance. You said there would be no sneaking in and out without permission."
tr: I rolled my eyes. “No. Absolutely not. You said no breaking and entering.”
es: I looked at the sky. —No. No. Impossible. You said there would be no breaking and entering.

en: “This isn’t breaking and entering. It’s just entering, because there’s an unlocked door.”
vi: “This is not a stealthy break-in. Just go in, because there is an unlocked door.”
tr: "This is not a home invasion. We are just going to enter because it is an unlocked door."
es: —It is not a breaking and entering. Just go in, because there is a door that is not locked.

en: “Margo, that’s ridiculous. Of c—”
vi: “Margo, that's so ridiculous. All...”
tr: “Margo, this is so ridiculous. Of course...”
es: —Margo, it's ridiculous. I assu…

en: “I will acknowledge that over the course of the evening there has been both breaking and entering. There was entering at Becca’s house. There was breaking at Jase’s house. And there will be entering here. But there has never been simultaneous breaking and entering. Theoretically, the cops could charge us with breaking, and they could charge us with entering, but they could not charge us with breaking and entering. So I’ve kept my promise.”
vi: “Let me recap for you, tonight we've been involved in a bunch of sneaky break-ins and unauthorized entries. Breaking into Becca's house. Slipping into Jase's house. Now we're going to enter here properly. But we can't both sneak in and enter at will. Technically, the police could arrest us for sneaky break-ins or unauthorized entries, but they can't arrest us for both sneaky break-ins and unauthorized entries. So I'm still keeping my promise.”
tr: “I admit, throughout the night we entered different households without permission. We entered Becca's house without permission. We entered Jase's house without permission. Here, we will just enter. None of these fully count as trespassing. In theory, the police could charge us with unauthorized entry. They can accuse us, but they cannot charge us with trespassing. So, I kept my word.”
es: —I am willing to admit that tonight there has been a break-in. We have broken into Becca's place and Jase's place. But in this case, the police won't be able to accuse us of breaking and entering, since we are not going to enter a dwelling. —I'm sure the SunTrust Building has a security guard or something —I told him.

en: “Surely the SunTrust Building has, like, a security guard or whatever,” I said.
vi: “The SunTrust building must have some security personnel or something,” I said.
tr: “Surely, there must be a security guard or something at the SunTrust building,” I said.
es: —I'm sure the SunTrust Building has a security guard or something —I told him.

en: “They do,” she said, unbuckling her seat belt. “Of course they do. His name is Gus.”
vi: “Yes,” she replied, unbuckling her seatbelt. “Of course they have security. His name is Gus.”
tr: “Yes,” he said, unbuckling his seatbelt. “Of course there is. His name is Gus.”
es: —Yes, it has a security guard —he answered me as he unbuckled his seatbelt—. Of course. His name is Gus.

en: We walked in through the front door. Sitting behind a broad, semicircular desk sat a young guy with a struggling goatee wearing a Regents Security uniform. “What’s up, Margo?” he said.
vi: We entered through the main gate. Sitting behind a wide semicircular desk was a young man with a faint goatee, wearing a Regents Security company uniform. "What's up, Margo?" he asked.
tr: We walked in through the door. Behind a wide, circular table, a young man with a thin goatee, wearing a Regents Security uniform, was sitting. "How are you, Margo?" he said.
es: We crossed the main door. On the other side of a semicircular counter sat a young man with an incipient goatee, dressed in a security guard uniform. —How are you, Margo?

en: “Hey, Gus,” she answered.
vi: “Hello, Gus,” she replied.
tr: “Hi Gus,” Margo replied.
es: —he asked her. —Hi, Gus —Margo replied.

en: “Who’s the kid?”
vi: "Which kid is that?"
tr: "Who is the child?""
es: —Who is this kid?

en: WE ARE THE SAME AGE! I wanted to shout, but I let Margo talk for me. “This is my colleague, Q. Q, this is Gus.”
vi: WE ARE THE SAME AGE! I wanted to scream, but let Margo speak instead: "My classmate, his name is Q. Q, this is Gus."
tr: I wanted to shout, "WE'RE THE SAME AGE!" but I let Margo speak for me. “This is my coworker, Q. Q, this is Gus.”
es: “WE ARE THE SAME AGE!” I wanted to shout, but I let Margo speak for me. —This is my friend Q. Q, this is Gus.

en: “What’s up, Q?” asked Gus.
vi: “What’s going on, Q?” Gus asked.
tr: "How are you, Q?" asked Gus.
es: —What’s up, Q? —Gus asked me.

en: Oh, we’re just scattering some dead fish about town, breaking some windows, photographing naked guys, hanging out in skyscraper lobbies at three-fifteen in the morning, that kind of thing. “Not much,” I answered.
vi: Oh, we just scattered dead fish around the city, smashed a few windows, took photos of naked guys, and now we're going to have some fun in the hallway of a skyscraper at three fifteen in the morning, something like that. "Nothing significant," I replied.
tr: Ah, we're just wandering around the city distributing dead fish, breaking windows, taking photos of naked men, hanging out in skyscraper lobbies at three-thirty in the morning, things like that. "Not much," I replied.
es: "Well, nothing much, we're distributing a few dead fish around the city, breaking some windows, taking photos of naked guys, wandering around private skyscrapers at a quarter past three in the morning... you know, those kinds of things." —Not too much —I replied to him.

en: “Elevators are down for the night,” Gus said. “Had to shut ’em off at three. You’re welcome to take the stairs, though.”
vi: "The elevator doesn't go up at night," Gus said. "It has to be turned off at three o'clock. You two can just use the stairs."
tr: “The elevators are not working tonight,” said Gus. “I had to shut them down at three o'clock. Still, please go ahead and use the stairs.”
es: —The elevators don't work at night —said Gus—. I have to turn them off at three. But you can use the stairs.

en: “Cool. See ya, Gus.”
vi: "Alright, see you later, Gus."
tr: “Very well. See you, Gus.”
es: —Great. See you later, Gus.

en: “See ya, Margo.”
vi: "Yes, Margo."
tr: "See you, Margo.""
es: —See you later, Margo.

en: “How the hell do you know the security guard at the SunTrust Building?” I asked once we were safely in the stairwell.
vi: “How on earth do you know the security guard at the SunTrust building?” I asked as we both safely climbed the stairs.
tr: “For God's sake, how do you know the security guard at the SunTrust building?” I asked as soon as we reached the stairs.
es: —How the hell do you know the security guard at the SunTrust Building? —I asked him as soon as we were safe on the stairs.

en: “He was a senior when we were freshmen,” she answered. “We gotta hustle, okay? Time’s a-wastin’.” Margo started taking the stairs two at a time, flying up, one arm on the rail, and I tried to keep pace with her, but couldn’t. Margo didn’t play any sports, but she liked to run—I sometimes saw her running by herself listening to music in Jefferson Park. I, however, did not like to run. Or, for that matter, engage in any kind of physical exertion. But now I tried to keep up a steady pace, wiping the sweat off my forehead and ignoring the burning in my legs. When I got to the twenty-fifth floor, Margo was standing on the landing, waiting for me.
vi: “When we entered high school, he was in his final year,” Margo replied. “We need to hurry up.” “Time is wasting away.” She started taking the stairs two at a time, rushing up, one hand gripping the stair railing, and I struggled to keep up. Margo didn’t play any sports but liked to jog–I occasionally saw her running alone while listening to music in Jefferson Park. But I didn’t like running. Or maybe that’s why I didn’t participate in any strenuous physical activities. Now I tried to maintain a steady pace, wiping the sweat pouring down my forehead and ignoring the throbbing pain in my calves. When I reached the twenty-fifth floor, Margo was already standing at the landing, waiting for me.
tr: “When we were in the first grade, he was in the final grade,” she replied. “We need to hurry, okay? Time is passing.” Margo started climbing the stairs two at a time, one arm flying up the banister, and I tried to keep up with her but couldn't. Margo didn't do any sports, but she loved to run... Her I had seen him a few times running in Jefferson Park, listening to music alone. However, I did not like running or even engaging in any physical effort. But now, I was trying to keep up with him steadily, wiping the sweat from my forehead and ignoring the burning in my legs. When I reached the twenty-fifth floor, Margo was standing on the landing, waiting for me.
es: —He was in the last year of high school when we were in the first year —he answered me—. We have to hurry up, okay? We're running out of time. Margo started climbing the steps two at a time, at full speed and with one hand on the railing, and I tried to keep up with her, but I couldn't. Margo didn't play sports, but she liked to run. From time to time, I saw her in Jefferson Park running alone with her headphones on. But I didn't like running. In fact, I didn't like making the slightest physical effort. But I tried to keep a steady pace, wipe the sweat from my forehead, and ignore the burning in my legs. When I reached the twenty-fifth floor, Margo was waiting for me on the landing.

en: “Check it out,” she said. She opened the stairwell door and we were inside a huge room with an oak table as long as two cars, and a long bank of floor-to-ceiling windows. “Conference room,” she said. “It’s got the best view in the whole building.” I followed her as she walked along the windows. “Okay, so there,” she said pointing, “is Jefferson Park. See our houses? Lights still off, so that’s good.” She moved over a few panes. “Jase’s house. Lights off, no more cop cars. Excellent, although it might mean he’s made it home, which is unfortunate.” Becca’s house was too far away to see, even from up here.
vi: “Look at this,” she said, opening the door next to the stairs, and we walked into a spacious room with an oak table as long as two cars and walls with windows stretching from floor to ceiling. “Conference room,” Margo said. “In the whole building, this is the place with the best view.” I followed her as she walked along the row of windows. “There, that spot,” she said, pointing, “is Jefferson Park. Can you see our house? The lights are still off, so that's good.” She moved a few more windows down. “That's Jase's house. The lights are off, no more police cars. Great, although that could mean he's already sneaked back home, which is a bit boring.” Becca's house is too far away to see, even from here.
tr: “Take a look at this,” he said. He opened the door next to the stairs and we entered a huge room with an oak table as long as two cars and a long side surrounded by floor-to-ceiling windows. “Conference room,” he said. “It has the best view in the entire building.” I followed him as he walked by the windows. “Alright, there it is,” he said, pointing with his hand. “Jefferson Park. Do you see our houses? The lights are still off, that's good.” He took a few steps to the side. “Jase’s house. The lights are off, no more police cars. Perfect, but unfortunately, this might also mean that Jase has arrived home.” Becca’s house was too far to be seen, even from here.
es: —Take a look —he told me. He opened the stairway door and we entered a huge room with an oak table the size of two cars and some large windows that went from the floor to the ceiling. —The conference room —he explained to me—. It has the best views in the entire building. —I followed her as she walked through the room—. Well, there's Jefferson Park —she said, pointing—. Do you see our houses? The lights are still off, so that's perfect. —She moved forward a couple of windows—. Jase's house. The lights are off and no police cars. Excellent, although that could mean he's already home. Bad luck. Becca's house was too far away, even from that height.

en: She was quiet for a moment, and then she walked right up to the glass and leaned her forehead against it. I hung back, but then she grabbed my T-shirt and pulled me forward. I didn’t want our collective weight against a single pane of glass, but she kept pulling me forward, and I could feel her balled fist in my side, and finally I put my head against the glass as gently as possible and looked around.
vi: Margo was silent for a moment, then walked towards the glass door and pressed her forehead against it. I lingered behind, but she tugged at my t-shirt and pulled me forward. I didn't want to put the weight of both of us on a single pane of glass, but Margo kept pulling me, and I could feel her hand right next to mine. So, in the end, I rested my head against the glass, as cautiously as possible, and looked outside.
tr: Margo remained silent for a short while, then approached the very edge of the window and rested her forehead against it. I stayed behind, but she grabbed my t-shirt and pulled me forward. I didn't want to put our combined weight on a single window, but she kept pulling me, and I could feel her clenched fist beside me. Finally, I slowly placed my head against the window and looked around.
es: She stayed silent for a moment and then went to the window and pressed her forehead against the glass. I stayed behind, but she grabbed me by the shirt and pulled me. I didn't want the glass to have to bear the weight of both of us, but she kept pulling me, I felt her fist at my side, so in the end, I also pressed my head against the glass as gently as possible and took a look.

en: “I mean, well, maybe not,” I said, although it was. When I saw Orlando from an airplane, it looked like a LEGO set sunk into an ocean of green. Here, at night, it looked like a real place—but for the first time a place I could see. As I walked around the conference room, and then through the other offices on the floor, I could see it all: there was school. There was Jefferson Park. There, in the distance, Disney World. There was Wet ’n Wild. There, the 7-Eleven where Margo painted her nails and I fought for breath. It was all here—my whole world, and I could see it just by walking around a building. “It’s more impressive,” I said out loud. “From a distance, I mean. You can’t see the wear on things, you know? You can’t see the rust or the weeds or the paint cracking. You see the place as someone once imagined it.”
vi: “Well, maybe it's not that beautiful,” I replied, even though I actually found it beautiful. When I looked at Orlando from the plane, the city looked like a LEGO toy set dropped into a green ocean. But here, at night, the city was a real place–for the first time, a place I could see. As I walked around the conference room, then to other offices on the same floor, I could see it all: a whole picture. The school. There was Jefferson Park. In the distance was Disney World. Wet ’n Wild water park. There was the 7-Eleven store where Margo painted her nails while I struggled to catch my breath. It was all here–my entire world, and I could see it completely, just by leisurely walking around a building. “Impressive,” I said aloud. “I mean, from a distance. You don't see any flaws, you know what I mean? You can't see the rust, the overgrown weeds, or the peeling paint. You see the city just as someone once imagined it.”
tr: "Well, okay, maybe it's not like that," I said, even though it actually was. When I saw Orlando from a plane, it looked like a green ocean to me. It looked like a sunken LEGO set. From here, at night, it looked like a real place but one I was seeing for the first time. While walking in the conference room and the other offices on that floor, I could see everything. The school was there. Jefferson Park was there. Disney World was in the distance. Wet ’n Wild was there. The 7Eleven where Margo painted her nails and I struggled to breathe was there. Here they all were... my whole world. And I could see it just by walking inside a building. “More impressive,” I said out loud. “From a distance, I mean. You can't see the wear and tear on them, if you know what I mean. You can't see the rust, the weeds, or the paint cracking. You see this place as someone once imagined it.”
es: —Well, I don't know, maybe not —I replied, although it seemed nice to me. When I saw Orlando from a plane, it looked like a Lego piece submerged in a green sea. There, at night, it seemed like a real city, but a real city that I was seeing for the first time. I walked through the conference room, and then the other offices on the floor. The whole city could be seen. There was the institute. There, Jefferson Park. There, in the distance, Disney World. There, the Wet’n Wild water park. There, the 7-Eleven where Margo had painted her nails and I struggled to breathe. There was my entire world, and I could see it just by walking through a building. —It's more impressive —I said out loud—. From a distance, I mean. You don't see the wear and tear of things, you know? You don't see the rust, the weeds, and the peeling paint. You see places as someone once imagined them.
