en: Her forehead still against the glass, she turned to me and smiled. “Here’s a tip: you’re cute when you’re confident. And less when you’re not.” Before I had a chance to say anything, her eyes went back to the view and she started talking. “Here’s what’s not beautiful about it: from here, you can’t see the rust or the cracked paint or whatever, but you can tell what the place really is. You see how fake it all is. It’s not even hard enough to be made out of plastic. It’s a paper town. I mean look at it, Q: look at all those cul-de-sacs, those streets that turn in on themselves, all the houses that were built to fall apart. All those paper people living in their paper houses, burning the future to stay warm. All the paper kids drinking beer some bum bought for them at the paper convenience store. Everyone demented with the mania of owning things. All the things paper-thin and paper-frail. And all the people, too. I’ve lived here for eighteen years and I have never once in my life come across anyone who cares about anything that matters.”
vi: Margo still had her forehead pressed against the glass door, she turned back and smiled at me. "Here's the thing: you're adorable when you're confident. And less adorable when you're not." Before I could react, she had already turned her gaze back outside and started talking. "The ugly part is this: from here, you can't see the rust and decay, but you can tell what this place really is. You see that everything is just a facade. It's not even sturdy enough to say it's made of plastic or some synthetic material. This is a paper town. Look at it, Q: look at all those dead-end streets, those roads that loop back onto themselves, all those houses built just to be torn down. All those paper people living in those paper houses, burning their futures to keep warm. All those paper kids, drinking the beer some jobless bum bought for them at a paper convenience store. Everyone is going crazy in this frenzy of property ownership. All that fragile, paper-thin property. And all those people are just like paper. I've lived here for eighteen years, and I've never once in my life met anyone who cared about the things that really matter."
tr: With her forehead still pressed against the window, she turned to me and smiled. "Here's a piece of advice: You're charming when you're confident. When you're not confident, you're less charming." Before I could say anything, she turned back to the view and started talking: "The thing that's not beautiful here is this: You can't see the rust, the cracked paint from here, but you understand what this place really is. You see how everything is fake. It's not even as sturdy as something made of plastic. A city made of paper. So look at this, Q, look at all these dead-end streets, the roads that lead to the same place, all these houses built to fall apart. All these paper people living in their paper houses, burning the future to keep themselves warm. All the paper children drinking the beer that some thug got for them from a paper kiosk. Everyone is losing themselves in the madness of owning things. All these things are paper-thin and paper-fragile. And so are all the people. I've been living here for eighteen years and I've never once met a single person who cared about something truly important in my life."
es: She turned, without lifting her forehead from the glass, and smiled at me. —I give you your reward: you are cute when you trust yourself. And less cute when you don't. Before he had time to say anything, he turned his eyes to the city and continued speaking. —I'll tell you what I don't like: from here you can't see the rust, the peeling paint, and all that, but you see what it really is. You see how fake everything is. It's not even as tough as plastic. It's a paper town. Look at it, Q, look at all those alleys, those streets that turn back on themselves, all the houses they built just to fall apart. All those paper people living in their paper houses and burning the future to keep warm. All the paper kids drinking beer that some idiot bought for them at the paper store. Everyone going crazy with the obsession of owning things. All the things weak and fragile like paper. And all the people too. I've lived here for eighteen years and not once in my life have I met someone who cares about what really matters.

en: “I’ll try not to take that personally,” I said. We were both staring into the inky distance, the cul-de-sacs and quarter-acre lots. But her shoulder was against my arm, and the backs of our hands were touching, and although I was not looking at Margo, pressing myself against the glass felt almost like pressing myself against her.
vi: “I'll try not to think that you're talking about any specific person,” I said. We both looked at the ink-colored void, the dead-end streets, and the plots of land for houses. But her shoulder pressed against my arm, the backs of our hands touched, and even though I wasn't looking at Margo, pressing my face against the glass made me feel almost as if I were pressing my face against hers.

But Margo's shoulder was leaning against my arm, and the tops of our hands were touching; even though I wasn't looking at Margo, leaning against the window felt almost like leaning against her.
es: —I will try not to take it personally —I said to him. We both stayed watching the dark distance, the dead-end streets, and the thousand-square-meter plots. But Margo had her shoulder pressed against my arm, the backs of our hands touched, and although I wasn't looking at her, pressing against the glass was almost like pressing against her.

I just hate myself so much for even caring about my, quote, friends. I mean, just so you know, it’s not that I am oh-so-upset about Jason. Or Becca. Or even Lacey, although I actually liked her. But it was the last string. It was a lame string, for sure, but it was the one I had left, and every paper girl needs at least one string, right?”

It was definitely an insignificant thread, but it was the last thread, and every paper girl needs at least one thread, right?”

Look, just so you know, it's not that Jason affects me that much. Or Becca. Or even Lacey, although I really liked her. But it was the last thread. It was a weak thread, of course, but it was the only one I had left, and every paper girl needs at least one thread, right?

en: “That’s sweet,” she answered, her voice trailing off. She turned to me and nodded softly. I smiled. She smiled. I believed the smile. We walked to the stairs and then ran down them. At the bottom of each flight, I jumped off the bottom step and clicked my heels to make her laugh, and she laughed. I thought I was cheering her up. I thought she was cheerable. I thought maybe if I could be confident, something might happen between us.
vi: “So nice to me,” she replied, her voice fading. Margo turned back and nodded slightly. I smiled. She smiled. I believed that smile. We went to the stairs and then ran down the steps. At the end of each floor, I jumped over the last step and kicked my heels to make Margo laugh, and she did laugh. I thought I was making her happy. I thought she was easily cheerful and excited. I thought if I could be confident, maybe something could happen between us.
tr: “You are very sweet,” he replied as his voice gradually faded. He turned to me and slowly nodded his head. I smiled. He smiled. I believed in his smile. We walked to the stairs and then ran down. At the end of each floor, I jumped off the last step and clicked my heels to make him laugh, and he laughed. I thought I was cheering him up. I thought he could be cheered up. I thought that if I had confidence in myself, maybe something could happen between us.
es: —Very kind —he said to me in an increasingly subdued tone. He turned towards me and nodded softly. I smiled. She smiled. I believed her smile. We headed to the stairs and ran down. At the end of each flight, I would jump from the last step and click my heels to make her laugh, and Margo laughed. I thought I was cheering her up. I thought that maybe if I managed to trust myself, there could be something between us.

And the United States. And czarist Russia. Me, I’m Luxembourg. Just sitting around, tending sheep, and yodeling.

en: “Hmm,” I said. Chuck Parson was pretty horrible in all those years before he’d been reined in. Aside from the cafeteria conveyor belt debacle, he once grabbed me outside school while I waited for the bus and twisted my arm and kept saying, “Call yourself a faggot.” That was his all-purpose, I-have-a-vocabulary-of-twelve-words-so-don’t-expect-a-wide-variety-of-insults insult. And even though it was ridiculously childish, in the end I had to call myself a faggot, which really annoyed me, because 1. I don’t think that word should ever be used by anyone, let alone me, and 2. As it happens, I am not gay, and furthermore, 3. Chuck Parson made it out like calling yourself a faggot was the ultimate humiliation, even though there’s nothing at all embarrassing about being gay, which I was trying to say while he twisted my arm farther and farther toward my shoulder blade, but he just kept saying, “If you’re so proud of being a faggot, why don’t you admit that you’re a faggot, faggot?”
vi: "Hmm," I replied. Chuck Parson had been extremely terrible for many years before he was finally restrained. Besides the incident of throwing me onto the conveyor belt in the cafeteria, once he grabbed me at the school gate while I was waiting for the bus, twisted my arm behind my back, and ordered, "Admit that you're gay." It was the kind of insult-in-any-situation, because-my-vocabulary-only-has-twelve-words-so-don't-expect-me-to-insult-you-in-any-other-way kind of insult from Chuck. Even though this game was ridiculously childish, in the end, I still had to admit that I was gay, which really pissed me off because 1. I don't think anyone, let alone me, should say that word, 2. Even though it happened, I'm not gay, moreover 3. To Chuck, making someone admit they're gay was the worst form of slander, even though being gay is absolutely nothing to be ashamed of. I tried to tell Chuck that while he twisted my arm like he wanted to rip it out of its socket, but he insisted: "If you're so proud of being gay, why don't you just admit that you're gay, huh, you gay?"

And even though it was terribly childish, I eventually had to say that I was a fag, and it really bothered me because 1. And although it was ridiculously childish, in the end, I had to say I was a faggot, and it pissed me off because: 1) I believe no one should use that word, least of all me; 2) It turns out I'm not gay, and besides, 3) That Chuck Parson getting you to call yourself a faggot was the ultimate humiliation, even though there's nothing shameful about being gay, which I tried to explain to him while he twisted my arm and lifted it higher towards my shoulder blade, but he kept saying: "If you're so proud of being a faggot, why don't you admit you're a faggot, you're a faggot?"

en: In sixth grade, a bunch of kids including Margo and Chuck and me were forced by our parents to take ballroom dancing lessons at the Crown School of Humiliation, Degradation, and Dance. And how it worked was the boys would stand on one side and the girls would stand on the other and then when the teacher told us to, the boys would walk over to the girls and the boy would say, “May I have this dance?” and the girl would say, “You may.” Girls were not allowed to say no. But then one day—we were doing the fox-trot—Chuck Parson convinced every single girl to say no to me. Not anyone else. Just me. So I walked across to Mary Beth Shortz and I said, “May I have this dance?” and she said no. And then I asked another girl, and then another, and then Margo, who also said no, and then another, and then I started to cry.
vi: Back in sixth grade, the group of kids including Margo, Chuck, and me were forced by our parents to attend dance classes at Crown School, which specialized in character building and dance. During the lessons, the boys stood on one side, the girls on the other, and when the teacher instructed, the boys would step up to the girls and ask, "May I have this dance?" and the girls would reply, "Of course." The girls were not allowed to refuse. But one day–during the fox-trot lesson–Chuck Parson convinced every girl to refuse to dance with me. No one else. Just me. So when I approached Mary Beth Shortz and asked, "May I have this dance?" she said no. I asked another girl, then another, and even Margo, and she also said no, and another girl again, until I cried.
tr: In sixth grade, a group of kids including Margo, Chuck, and me were forced by our parents to take ballroom dance lessons at the Crown School of Humiliation, Degradation, and Dance. This is how it worked: The boys stood on one side, the girls on the other, and then when the teacher told us, the boys would go over to the girls and ask, 'Would you do me the honor of this dance?' and the girls would say, 'Of course.' The girls were not allowed to say no. But one day, while we were doing the foxtrot, Chuck Parson convinced all the girls to say no to me. Not to anyone else. Just to me. So I walked over to Mary Beth Shortz and asked, 'Would you do me the honor of this dance?' and she said no. Then I asked another girl, then another, then Margo who also said no, then another, and then I started to cry.
es: In sixth grade, a group of kids, including Margo, Chuck, and me, were forced by our parents to take dance classes at the School of Humiliation, Degradation, and Dance Crown. The boys had to stand on one side, the girls on the other, and when the teacher told us to, the boys would approach the girls and say, "May I have this dance?" and the girls would respond, "I grant you this dance." That's how it worked. The girls couldn't say no. But one day, while dancing the foxtrot, Chuck Parson convinced each and every girl to say no to me. To no one else. Just to me. I approached Mary Beth Shortz and said, "May I have this dance?" and she answered no. Then I asked another girl, and another, and Margo, who also said no, and then another, and in the end, I started to cry.

en: The only thing worse than getting rejected at dance school is crying about getting rejected at dance school, and the only thing worse than that is going to the dance teacher and saying through your tears, “The girls are saying no to me and they’re not supposedtuh.” So of course I went weeping to the teacher, and I spent the majority of middle school trying to live down that one embarrassing event. So, long story short, Chuck Parson kept me from ever dancing the fox-trot, which doesn’t seem like a particularly horrible thing to do to a sixth-grader. And I wasn’t really pissed about it anymore, or about everything else he’d done to me over the years. But I certainly wasn’t going to lament his suffering.
vi: The only thing worse than being rejected in dance class is crying because you were rejected in dance class, and the only thing worse than that is tearfully running to the teacher to tattle, "The girls won't dance with me and they shouldn't be allowed to do that." Of course, back then I did tattle to the teacher, and for most of the remaining years in middle school, I had to live with that embarrassing incident. In short, Chuck Parson made sure I never fox-trotted again. For a sixth grader, it wasn't exactly a huge catastrophe. I no longer really dwell on it, just like I don't dwell on the other things Chuck did to me over the years. But I certainly wouldn't shed a tear if something bad happened to him.

In short, Chuck Parson had forever prevented me, a sixth grader, from doing the foxtrot, which didn't even seem particularly terrible. I wasn't really angry about this incident anymore... or about everything else he had done to me over the years. But I definitely wasn't going to feel sorry for Chuck's suffering.
es: The only thing worse than being rejected by the dance school is crying because you were rejected by the dance school, and the only thing worse than that is going to the dance teacher and telling her while crying: "The girls have said no to me, and they’re not supposed to." So, of course, I went crying to the teacher, and I spent almost all the following years trying to get over that embarrassing episode. In short, Chuck Parson prevented me from dancing the foxtrot, which doesn’t seem like such a horrible punishment for a sixth grader. And the truth is, I was no longer angry about that, nor about anything he had done to me over the years. But it was clear that I wasn’t going to regret if he suffered either.

So we’re going to go up to his bedroom window, we’re gonna open it, we’re gonna take off our shoes, and then very quietly go inside, and I’m going to screw with Chuck. Then you and I are going to fan out to opposite sides of the house, and we’re going to cover every door handle in Vaseline, so even if someone wakes up, they’ll have a hella hard time getting out of the house in time to catch us. Then we’ll screw with Chuck some more, paint his house a little, and we’re out of there. And no talking.”

es: —Now don’t get hysterical on me, Q. The good news is that Chuck sleeps like a hibernating bear… I know because last year I had literature class with him and he didn’t even wake up when Miss Johnston hit him with Jane Eyre. So we’ll climb up to his room’s window, open it, take off our shoes, enter quietly, and I’ll take care of messing with Chuck. Then the two of us will spread out through the house and cover all the doorknobs with Vaseline so that if someone gets up, it’ll be really hard for them to get out of the house in time to catch us. Then we’ll mess with Chuck a bit more, paint the house a little, and leave. And not a word.

She nodded her head solemnly, and I nodded back, and then she let go of my hand. We scampered up to the window. I gently pushed the wooden casing up. It squeaked ever so quietly but opened in one motion. I looked in. It was dark, but I could see a body in a bed.

I looked inside. It was too dark, but I saw someone lying on the bed.

Although it was dark, I saw someone on a bed.

tr: Amherst was just a few blocks away. We parked in front of number 418, gathered our supplies, and ran across the lawn of Chuck's house, the morning dew on the grass soaking my pants.
es: Amherst was just a couple of blocks away. We parked in front of 418, grabbed the tools, and ran across Chuck's lawn. The dew covering the grass soaked my calves.

en: At his window, which was fortunately lower than that of Random Old Guy, I climbed in quietly and then pulled Margo up and in. Chuck Parson was asleep on his back. Margo walked over to him, tiptoeing, and I stood behind her, my heart pounding. He’d kill us both if he woke up. She pulled out the Veet, sprayed a dob of what looked like shaving cream onto her palm, and then softly and carefully spread it across Chuck’s right eyebrow. He didn’t so much as twitch.
vi: Fortunately, Chuck's window was lower than the window of Mr. Di Nham's room that we mistakenly entered earlier. I gently climbed inside and helped Margo follow. Chuck Parson was lying on his back, sound asleep. Margo tiptoed towards him, and I stood behind her, my heart pounding. If Chuck woke up, he could very well crush the two of us. Margo took out the Veet cream, sprayed a dollop that looked like shaving cream into her palm, and then carefully applied it to Chuck's right eyebrow. He didn't move a muscle.
tr: I quietly climbed through Chuck's window, which was thankfully lower than that of the Random Old Man, and pulled Margo up first, then inside. Chuck Parson was sleeping on his back. Margo tiptoed towards him, and I stood behind her, my heart pounding. If he woke up, he would kill us both. Margo took out the Veet, squeezed some of the stuff that looked like shaving cream into her palm, and then gently and carefully applied it to Chuck's right eyebrow. Chuck didn't even move.
es: I climbed silently to his window, which luckily was lower than that of the old man we had run into by chance, and pulled Margo in. Chuck Parson was sleeping on his back. Margo tiptoed towards him, and I stayed behind, my heart pounding. If he woke up, he would kill us both. Margo took out the Veet bottle, pressed it, put a ball that looked like shaving cream in her palm, and very gently and carefully spread it over Chuck's right eyebrow, who didn't even blink. Then Margo opened the Vaseline.

en: Then she opened the Vaseline—the lid made what seemed like a deafeningly loud clorp, but again Chuck showed no sign of waking. She scooped a huge gob of it into my hand, and then we headed off to opposite sides of the house. I went to the entryway first and slathered Vaseline on the front door’s doorknob, and then to the open door of a bedroom, where I Vaselined the inner knob and then quietly, with only the slightest creak, shut the door to the room.
vi: Then Margo opened the Vaseline jar—the lid popped off with a loud snap, but Chuck still didn't seem to wake up. Margo scooped a big handful into my hand, and we went in opposite directions in the house. I went from the front door, smearing Vaseline on the doorknob, then to a bedroom door that was ajar. I rubbed Vaseline on the inside doorknob, and gently, with just a slight click, closed the door.
tr: Then she opened the petroleum jelly... The lid made a plop sound loud enough to deafen ears, but Chuck still showed no sign of waking up. Margo poured the petroleum jelly into my hand, then we went towards different parts of the house. First, I went to the entrance and generously applied the petroleum jelly to the front door handle, then I went to an open bedroom door and applied the jelly to the inside handle, closing the door quietly with only a faint creak.
es: The lid made a pop that seemed deafening, but Chuck didn't show any signs of waking up either. She put a huge glob in my hand and we each went to one side of the house. I first went to the foyer and smeared Vaseline on the front door knob, then to the open door of a bedroom, where I applied Vaseline on the inner knob and then, very slowly, closed the door, which barely creaked.

en: Finally I returned to Chuck’s room—Margo was already there—and together we closed his door and then Vaselined the hell out of Chuck’s doorknob. We slathered every surface of his bedroom window with the rest of the Vaseline, hoping it would make it hard to open the window after we closed it shut on our way out.
vi: Finally, I returned to Chuck's room–Margo was already there–we closed the door together and smeared a large amount of Vaseline on the doorknob. We spread the remaining Vaseline all over the window frame of his room, hoping that it would make the window harder to open after we closed it on our way out.
tr: Finally, I returned to Chuck's room. Margo had already arrived, and together we closed Chuck's door and smeared vaseline on the doorknob. We generously applied petroleum jelly all over the window in the bedroom, hoping that it would make it harder to open the window after closing it when going outside.
es: Finally, I returned to Chuck's room —Margo was already there—, and together we closed the door and smeared the doorknob with Vaseline. We smeared the entire window of the room with the remaining Vaseline in the hope that, after closing it, it would be difficult to open.

en: Margo glanced at her watch and held up two fingers. We waited. And for those two minutes we just stared at each other, and I watched the blue in her eyes. It was nice—in the dark and the quiet, with no possibility of me saying anything to screw it up, and her eyes looking back, like there was something in me worth seeing.
vi: Margo glanced at the clock and raised two fingers. We waited. During those two minutes, we just looked at each other, and I gazed into the blue of her eyes. It was wonderful—in the darkness and quiet space, there was no risk of me saying something foolish to ruin the moment, and her eyes looked back at me, as if there was something in me worth looking at.
tr: Margo glanced at her watch and raised two fingers. We waited. During those two minutes, we just stared into each other's eyes, and I watched the blueness in her eyes. It was very nice... darkness and silence, without the possibility of me saying something that would ruin everything. And her eyes were looking at me too, as if there was something worth seeing in me.
es: Margo glanced at her watch and raised two fingers. We waited. And for two minutes we just stared at each other. I observed the blue of her eyes. It was beautiful. In the dark and in silence, without the possibility of me saying something and messing it up, and she returned my gaze, as if there was something in me worth seeing.

en: Margo nodded then, and I walked over to Chuck. I wrapped my hand in my T-shirt, as she’d told me to do, leaned forward, and—as softly as I could—pressed my finger against his forehead and then quickly wiped away the Veet. With it came every last hair that had been Chuck Parson’s right eyebrow. I was standing above Chuck with his right eyebrow on my T-shirt when his eyes shot open. Lightning fast, Margo grabbed his comforter and threw it over him, and when I looked up, the little ninja was already out the window. I followed as quickly as I could, as Chuck screamed, “MAMA! DAD! ROBBERY ROBBERY!”
vi: Then Margo nodded, and I approached Chuck. I wrapped my hand in the t-shirt, as Margo had instructed earlier, bent down and–as gently as possible–ran my finger over his forehead, quickly wiping off all the Veet cream. Along with every bit of hair that once was Chuck's right eyebrow. I was standing in front of Chuck with his right eyebrow on my t-shirt, when suddenly his eyes snapped open. In a flash, Margo grabbed the blanket and threw it over Chuck, and when I looked up, the ninja girl was already out the window. I hurriedly followed, while Chuck screamed at the top of his lungs, “MOM! OH MY GOD, MOM! THIEVES! THIEVES!”
tr: Margo nodded at that moment, and I approached Chuck. I wrapped my hand in my t-shirt, leaned forward as Margo had told me, and as quietly as I could, pressed my finger against Chuck’s eyebrow and quickly pulled the Veet. All the hairs on Chuck Parson’s right eyebrow came off one by one with it. When Chuck’s eyes opened, I was standing over him with his right eyebrow on my t-shirt. Margo threw the blanket at Chuck with lightning speed, and when I looked up, the little ninja was already out the window. As Chuck screamed, “MOM! DAD! THIEF! THIEF!”, I followed him as fast as I could.
es: Margo nodded and I approached Chuck. I wrapped my hand with the t-shirt, as she had told me, leaned forward and —as gently as I could— placed a finger on Chuck Parson's right eyebrow and quickly removed the depilatory cream, which took with it every last hair. I was still next to Chuck, with his right eyebrow on my t-shirt, when he opened his eyes. Margo grabbed the duvet like an arrow, threw it in his face, and when I looked up, the little ninja had already jumped out the window. I followed her as quickly as I could while Chuck screamed: MOM! DAD! THIEVES! THIEVES!

en: I wanted to say, The only thing we stole was your eyebrow, but I kept mum as I swung myself feetfirst out the window. I damn near landed on Margo, who was spray-painting an M onto the vinyl siding of Chuck’s house, and then we both grabbed our shoes and hauled ass to the minivan. When I looked back at the house, lights were on but no one was outside yet, a testament to the brilliant simplicity of the well-Vaselined doorknob. By the time Mr. (or possibly Mrs., I couldn’t really see) Parson pulled open the living room curtains and looked outside, we were driving in reverse back toward Princeton Street and the interstate.
vi: I really wanted to say, "We only took your eyebrow stuff," but I had to keep my mouth shut while swinging out the window. I almost fell on Margo while she was spraying an "M" on the plastic siding of Chuck's house, then we both grabbed our shoes and sprinted to the car. I turned back to look at the house; the lights were on but no one had come out yet, a testament to the effectiveness of the doorknobs meticulously treated with Vaseline. By the time Mr. (or maybe Mrs., I couldn't see clearly) Parson managed to pull up the living room curtains and look outside, we were already leisurely driving back to Princeton Street, onto the interstate highway.
tr: The only thing we stole was itchy, I wanted to say, but with my feet first, while I was dangling myself out of the window, I didn't even open my mouth. I landed right next to Margo, who had spray-painted an M on the facade of Chuck's house, then we both grabbed our shoes and bolted to the car. When I turned back to look at the house, the lights were on but no one had come out yet, a testament to the clever simplicity of the well-vaselined doorknob. By the time Mr. (or maybe Mrs., I hadn't seen clearly) Parson opened the living room curtains and looked out, we were already backing the car onto Princeton Avenue and heading back to the interstate.
es: I wanted to say: "The only thing we've stolen from you is your eyebrow," but I shut my mouth and jumped out the window. I almost landed on top of Margo, who was painting an M on the plastic siding of Chuck's house. Then we grabbed the shoes and hurried back to the car. I turned to look at the house and saw that the lights were on, but no one had come out yet, which brilliantly demonstrated how well I had greased the doorknob with Vaseline. When Mr. Parson (or maybe Mrs. Parson, to be honest I didn't see) drew the dining room curtains and took a look, we were already backing away towards Princeton Street and the highway.

en: “Yes!” I shouted. “God, that was brilliant.”
vi: "Alright!" I shouted. "Oh my god, that's absolutely amazing!"
tr: “Yes!” I shouted. “My God, that was amazing.”
es: —Yes! —I shouted—. Damn, it was awesome.

en: “Did you see it? His face without the eyebrow? He looks permanently doubtful, you know? Like, ‘oh, really? You’re saying I only have one eyebrow? Likely story.’ And I love making that asshole choose: better to shave off Lefty, or paint on Righty? Oh, I just love it. And how he yelled for his mama, that sniveling little shit.”
vi: "Did you see that? Chuck's missing one of his eyebrows. His face always has this perpetual look of skepticism, like 'oh, really? You guys are telling me I only have one eyebrow? What a load of nonsense.' I love making that loser choose: shave off the left one or draw in the right one? Oh, it's so much fun! He even yelled for his mom, such a crybaby."
tr: "Did you see?" "I mean, his eyebrowless face." "He will constantly be looking indecisively." "Oh, really? I only had one eyebrow." Are you saying that? You might be right,’ something like that. And the idea of making that jerk choose is great: Should he shave the left side too, or paint the right side? Oh, really great. How he called for his mom, the little brat.”
es: —Have you seen him? Have you seen his face without an eyebrow? He looks like a question mark. Like: "Seriously? Are you telling me I only have one eyebrow? Nonsense." And I loved having to decide whether to pluck his left eyebrow or his right one. Yes, I loved it. And how he screamed calling for his mom, the little crybaby.

en: “Wait, why do you hate him?”
vi: “Hey, why do you hate it?”
tr: “One second, why do you hate him?”
es: —Wait, why do you hate him?

en: “I didn’t say I hated him. I said he was a sniveling little shit.”
vi: "I never said I hated him." "I just said he's a crybaby."
tr: “I didn't say that I hated him. I said he was a little jerk.”
es: —I didn't say I hate him. I said he's a pathetic crybaby.

en: “But you were always kind of friends with him,” I said, or at least I thought she had been.
vi: “But it seems like you were always friends with him,” I said, at least I thought she used to be friends with Chuck.
tr: "But you were always kind of friends with him," I said, or at least that's what I thought.
es: —But you have always been her friend —I told her. Or at least I thought I was her friend.

en: “Yeah, well, I was always kind of friends with a lot of people,” she said. Margo leaned across the minivan and put her head on my bony shoulder, her hair falling against my neck. “I’m tired,” she said.
vi: “Oh, I'm always friends with a lot of people,” Margo replied. She leaned over and rested her head on my bony shoulder, her flowing hair brushing against my neck. “So tired,” Margo said.
tr: “Well, um, I was always kind of friends with a lot of people,” he said. He leaned in and put his head on my skinny shoulder, his hair falling onto my neck. “I’m tired,” he said.
es: —Yes, well, she was friends with a lot of people —he replied to me. Margo stretched out in the car, rested her head on my bony shoulder, and her hair slipped down my neck. —I am tired —she added.

en: “Caffeine,” I said. She reached into the back and grabbed us each a Mountain Dew, and I drank it in two long chugs.
vi: “Caffeine,” I said. She leaned back, grabbed a Mountain Dew for each of us, and I finished mine in two long gulps.
tr: “Caffeine,” I said. He reached back and grabbed a Mountain Dew for each of us, I drank mine in two big gulps.
es: —Caffeine —I told him. He reached back and grabbed two cans of Mountain Dew. I drank mine in two long gulps.

en: “So we’re going to SeaWorld,” she told me. “Part Eleven.”
vi: "Now let's go to the SeaWorld ocean world," Margo told me. "Part Eleven."
tr: “Now we are going to SeaWorld,” he said. “Chapter Eleven.”
es: —Well, let's go to SeaWorld —he told me—. Eleventh part.

en: “What, are we going to Free Willy or something?”
vi: "What, are we going to Rescue Willy or something like that?"
tr: “So, are we going to set Willy free or something?”
es: —How? Are we going to free Willy or something like that?

en: “No,” she said. “We’re just going to go to SeaWorld, that’s all. It’s the only theme park I haven’t broken into yet.”
vi: “No,” she replied. “We will only go to SeaWorld, that's it. That's the only park I haven't snuck into yet.”
tr: “No,” he said. “We’re just going to SeaWorld, that’s all. That’s the only amusement park I haven’t snuck into yet.”
es: —No —he replied to me—. We're simply going to SeaWorld, that's all. It's the only theme park I haven't broken into yet.

en: “We can’t break into SeaWorld,” I said, and then I pulled over into an empty furniture store parking lot and turned off the car.
vi: "We can't break into SeaWorld," I said, pulling the car into the parking lot of a furniture store and turning off the engine.
tr: "We can't enter SeaWorld without permission," I said and pulled into the empty parking lot of the furniture store, stopping the car.
es: —We can't raid SeaWorld —I told him. I pulled into the empty parking lot of a furniture store and turned off the car.

en: “We’re in a bit of a time crunch,” she told me, and then reached over to start the car again.
vi: "There isn't much time left," Margo said and reached out to restart the engine.
tr: "We are a bit pressed for time," he said to me, then reached out to start the car.
es: —The moment of truth has arrived —he told me, leaning over to restart the car.

en: I pushed her hand away. “We can’t break into SeaWorld,” I repeated.
vi: I pushed her hand away, repeating. "We can't break into SeaWorld."
tr: I pushed his hand aside. “We can't enter SeaWorld without permission,” I repeated.
es: I pushed his hands away. —We cannot raid SeaWorld —I repeated.

en: “There you go with the breaking again.” Margo paused and opened another Mountain Dew. Light reflected off the can onto her face, and for a second I could see her smiling at the thing she was about to say. “We’re not going to break anything. Don’t think of it as breaking in to SeaWorld. Think of it as visiting SeaWorld in the middle of the night for free.”
vi: “You're rambling about breaking in again,” Margo paused and opened another bottle of Mountain Dew. The light reflected through the bottle, casting over her face, and for a second, I saw Margo smile at what she was about to say. “We are not breaking in anywhere. Don't think of it as breaking into SeaWorld. Think of it as going to SeaWorld at midnight and getting in for free.”
tr: “Well, here we go again with the breaking and entering issue.” Margo paused and opened another Mountain Dew. The light reflected off the can onto her face, and for a second, I could see that she was smiling about what she was about to say. “There’s no breaking and entering. Don’t think of it as sneaking into SeaWorld. Think of it as getting a free tour of SeaWorld at midnight.”
es: —Here we go again with the raid. He fell silent for a moment and opened another can of Mountain Dew. The can cast light on his face and for a second I saw him smiling at what he was about to say. —We are not going to break in. Don't consider it a break-in. Consider it a free visit to SeaWorld in the middle of the night.

en: “Well, first off, we will get caught,” I said. I hadn’t started the minivan and was laying out the reasons I wouldn’t start it and wondering if she could see me in the dark.
vi: “Alright, first of all, we are going to get caught,” I said. I didn't start the engine and began explaining to Margo why I hadn't done it yet, wondering if she could see me in this darkness.
tr: “Well, first of all, we are going to get caught,” I said. I hadn't started the car, I was listing the reasons why I hadn't started it, and I was wondering if he could see me or not.
es: —Look, to begin with, they will catch us —I told him. I had not started the car. I was counting the reasons why I was not going to start it and wondering if Margo could see me in the dark.

en: “Of course we’ll get caught. So what?”
vi: “Of course we will be caught. So what?”
tr: “Of course, we will be caught. So what?”
es: —Of course they'll catch us. So what?

en: “It’s illegal.”
vi: “That is illegal.”
tr: “This is illegal.”
es: —It's illegal.

en: “Q, in the scheme of things, what kind of trouble can Sea-World get you into? I mean, Jesus, after everything I’ve done for you tonight, you can’t do one thing for me? You can’t just shut up and calm down and stop being so goddamned terrified of every little adventure?” And then under her breath she said, “I mean, God. Grow some nuts.”
vi: “Q, in your opinion, what kind of trouble could SeaWorld get you into?” I mean, God, after everything I've done for you tonight, can't you do one thing for me? Can't you stay calm and stop freaking out over every tiny adventure like this?” And then under her breath, Margo said, “I mean, come on, live a little.”
tr: “Q, what kind of trouble can SeaVVorld get you into? I mean, God, after all the things I've done for you tonight, can't you do just one thing for me? Can't you just shut up, calm down, and not freak out at every damn little adventure?” Then in a low voice, “I mean, God. Be a little brave,” he said.
es: —Q, what problem can SeaWorld cause you in comparative terms? I mean, damn, after everything I've done for you tonight, can't you do just one thing for me? Can't you shut up, calm down, and stop freaking out so much over every little adventure? —And in a low voice he added—: Damn, grow a pair.

en: And now I was mad. I ducked underneath my shoulder belt so I could lean across the console toward her. “After everything YOU did for ME?” I almost shouted. She wanted confident? I was getting confident. “Did you call MY friend’s father who was screwing MY boyfriend so no one would know that I was calling? Did you chauffeur MY ass all around the world not because you are oh-so-important to me but because I needed a ride and you were close by? Is that the kind of shit you’ve done for me tonight?”
vi: Now I'm really pissed off. I slipped my head through the cross-shoulder seatbelt so I could lean over the controls and look at her. “After everything YOU'VE done for ME?” I almost screamed. She wants confidence? I'm getting confident here. “Did you call my friend's dad, the friend who's clinging to MY boyfriend, so no one would find out that I made the call? Did you drive MY butt all over the place, not because you're oh-so-important to me, but because I needed a ride and you were right there? Is that the crap you did for me tonight?”
tr: So I got angry because of this. I ducked my head under the seatbelt so I could lean towards the other side of the console, towards Margo. “After all the things YOU did for ME, is that so?” I said, almost shouting. Did she want confidence? Well, I was confident. “So that no one would understand what I was looking for, did YOU call MY friend’s father who was screwing MY girlfriend? Did YOU drive ME around the world not because I was ‘so precious’ to you, but because I needed a car and you were nearby? Are these the kinds of things you did for me tonight?’
es: Then I went crazy. I went under the seatbelt so I could get closer to her. —After everything you've done for me? —I almost shouted. Didn't you want me to trust myself? Well, there you had it—. Did you call my friend's father, who was screwing my boyfriend, so no one would find out that it was me who called? Have you acted as my chauffeur not because you're important to me, but because I needed a car and you were available? Is that the crap you've done for me tonight?

en: She wouldn’t look at me. She just stared straight ahead at the vinyl siding of the furniture store. “You think I needed you? You don’t think I could have given Myrna Mountweazel a Benadryl so she’d sleep through my stealing the safe from under my parents’ bed? Or snuck into your bedroom while you were sleeping and taken your car key? I didn’t need you, you idiot. I picked you. And then you picked me back.” Now she looked at me. “And that’s like a promise. At least for tonight. In sickness and in health. In good times and in bad. For richer, for poorer. Till dawn do us part.”
vi: Margo did not look at me. She just stared straight ahead, towards the plastic-covered doors of the furniture store. “You think I need you? Don't you think I could give Myrna Mountweazel a dose of Benadryl to make her sleep like a log while I snuck the safe out from under my parents' bed? Or sneak into your room while you're sleeping and swipe your car keys? I don't need you, you fool. I chose you. And then you chose me back.” Now Margo looked at me. “And that feels like a promise. At least for tonight. In sickness and in health. For better or for worse. For richer or for poorer. Until dawn do us part.”
tr: He wasn't looking at me. He was just staring straight ahead, looking at the front of the furniture store. "Do you think I need you? I can get the safe from under my parents' bed Don't you think I can give Myrna Mountweazel Benadryl to make her sleep? Or sneak into your room while you're asleep and take your car keys? I didn't need you, you fool. I chose you. Then you chose me too. At that moment, she looked at me. “And that's like some kind of promise. At least for tonight. In sickness and in health. In good times and in bad. In wealth and in poverty. Until dawn separates us.”
es: He didn't look at me. He looked straight ahead, towards the plastic covering of the furniture store. —Do you think I needed you? Don’t you think I could have given Myrna Mountweazel a sedative to make her sleep and stolen the box from under my parents' bed? Or sneaked into your room while you were sleeping and taken your car keys? I didn’t need you, idiot. I chose you. And then you chose me. —He looked at me—. And this is like a promise. At least for tonight. In sickness and in health. For better or for worse. For richer or for poorer. Until dawn do us part.

en: I started the car and pulled out of the parking lot, but all her teamwork stuff aside, I still felt like I was getting badgered into something, and I wanted the last word. “Fine, but when Sea-World, Incorporated or whatever sends a letter to Duke University saying that miscreant Quentin Jacobsen broke into their facility at four thirty in the morning with a wild-eyed lass at his side, Duke University will be mad. Also, my parents will be mad.”
vi: I started the engine and drove out of the parking lot, but putting aside all of Margo's team spirit, I still felt like I was being forced to do something, and I wanted to get to the bottom of it. "Alright, but when SeaWorld, the company, or any individual writes to Duke University, saying that the guilty Quentin Jacobsen broke into their facility at four-thirty in the morning with a wild-eyed companion, Duke University will go crazy. And my parents will go crazy too."
tr: I started the car and pulled out of the parking spot, but despite all that teamwork nonsense, I still felt like I was being forced into something with my head being chewed off, and I wanted to have the final say. “Fine. But SeaWorld or whatever, Duke University is going to be really mad when they get a letter saying that cruel Quentin Jacobsen, along with a wild-eyed girl, broke into their facilities at four in the morning. My parents are going to be really mad too.”
es: I started the car and left the parking lot, but, putting aside his spiel about teamwork, I felt that he was pressuring me and wanted to have the last word. —Very well, but when SeaWorld or whoever writes to Duke University saying that the unscrupulous Quentin Jacobsen broke into their building at four-thirty in the morning with a wild-eyed girl, Duke University will be furious. And my parents too.

en: “Q, you’re going to go to Duke. You’re going to be a very successful lawyer-or-something and get married and have babies and live your whole little life, and then you’re going to die, and in your last moments, when you’re choking on your own bile in the nursing home, you’ll say to yourself: ‘Well, I wasted my whole goddamned life, but at least I broke into SeaWorld with Margo Roth Spiegelman my senior year of high school. At least I carpe’d that one diem.’”
vi: “Q, you will attend Duke. You will become a successful lawyer-or-something, start a family, have children, and live out this ordinary life. In your final moments, on your deathbed, when you are bitter and choking back tears in the hospital, you will tell yourself: ‘Oh, I wasted this damn life, but at least in my final year of high school, I snuck into SeaWorld with Margo Roth Spiegelman. At least I had one glorious day, carpe diem.’”
tr: “Q, you will go to Duke. You will become a very successful lawyer, you will get married, you will have children, you will live that whole little life, then you will die and in your last moments, while choking on your own bile in a nursing home, you will say to yourself: Maybe, I might have wasted my entire damn life, but at least in my senior year of high school, I broke into SeaWorld with Margo Roth Spiegelman. At least I carpe'd one diem.”’
es: —Q, you will go to Duke. You will be a very successful lawyer, or whatever, you will get married, have children, live your mediocre life and die, and in your last moments, when you are drowning in your own bile in the nursing home, you will say to yourself: "Well, I wasted my whole fucking life, but at least in the last year of high school I got into SeaWorld with Margo Roth Spiegelman." At least, I carpe'd a diem."

en: “Noctem,” I corrected.
vi: “A glorious night, carpe noctem[5],” I corrected.
tr: “Noctem,” I corrected.
es: —Night —I corrected her.

en: “Okay, you are the Grammar King again. You’ve regained your throne. Now take me to SeaWorld.”
vi: “Alright, you're the Grammar King again. You've just reclaimed the throne. Now take me to SeaWorld.”
tr: ‘Alright, you are the Grammar King again. You have regained my throne. Now take me to SeaWorld.”
es: —Alright, you're the king of grammar again. You've just reclaimed the throne. Now take me to SeaWorld.

en: As we drove silently down I-4, I found myself thinking about the day that the guy in the gray suit showed up dead. Maybe that’s the reason she chose me, I thought. And that’s when, finally, I remembered what she said about the dead guy and the strings— and about herself and the strings.
vi: Quietly driving along the I-4 highway, I realized I was thinking about the man in the gray suit who was found dead that year. Maybe that's why she chose me, I thought. And then, finally, I remembered what Margo had said about the dead and the connections—about herself and the connections.
tr: As I quietly advanced on I-4, I found myself thinking about the day the man in the gray suit died. Maybe this is why Margo chose me, I thought. At that very moment, I finally remembered what Margo had said about the dead man and the ropes... and also what she had said about herself and the ropes.
es: As we moved silently along the I-4, I found myself thinking about the day the guy in the gray suit turned up dead. “Maybe that's why he chose me,” I thought. And at that moment, I finally remembered what he had told me about the dead man and the threads. And about her and the threads.

en: “Margo,” I said, breaking our silence.

tr: “Margo,” I said, breaking our silence.

en: “Q,” she said.

en: “You said . . . When the guy died, you said maybe all the strings inside him broke, and then you just said that about yourself, that the last string broke.”

es: —You said... When that guy died, you said that maybe his strings had broken inside, and a while ago you said the same about yourself, that the last string had broken.

en: She half laughed. “You worry too much. I don’t want some kids to find me swarmed with flies on a Saturday morning in Jefferson Park.” She waited a beat before delivering the punch line. “I’m too vain for that fate.”
vi: Margo half laughed. “You worry too much. I don't want some kid to find me covered in flies and ants on a Saturday morning in Jefferson Park.” She paused for a moment and then said the crux of it. “I’m too proud for an ending like that.”
tr: She was smiling. “You worry too much. I don’t want a few kids to find me in Jefferson Park on a Saturday morning with flies swarming over me.” She waited a moment before stating the crucial point. “I’m too flamboyant for that fate.”
es: He half-laughed. —You worry too much. I don't want some kids to find me covered in flies on a Saturday morning in Jefferson Park. —She paused for a moment before finishing the sentence—: I'm too vain to end up like that.

en: I laughed, relieved, and exited the interstate. We turned onto International Drive, the tourism capital of the world. There were a thousand shops on International Drive, and they all sold the exact same thing: crap. Crap molded into seashells, key rings, glass turtles, Florida-shaped refrigerator magnets, plastic pink flamingos, whatever. In fact, there were several stores on I-Drive that sold actual, literal armadillo crap—$4.95 a bag.
vi: I chuckled, sighed in relief, and drove off the interstate. We turned onto International Drive, the shopping capital of this place. There are up to a thousand stores on International Drive, all selling the same thing: junk. Junk in all shapes and forms: seashells, keychains, glass turtles, Florida-shaped refrigerator magnets, plastic flamingos, you name it. In fact, there are a few stores on I-Drive that sell literal junk, like armadillo poop, four dollars and ninety-five cents a bag.

Junk shaped like seashells, keychains, glass turtles, refrigerator magnets in the shape of Florida, pink plastic flamingos, you name it. In fact, there were even shops on International Boulevard that sold real armadillo poop... for $4.95 a bag.

en: “SeaWorld is just past the parkway,” Margo said. She was in the wayback of the minivan again, rifling through a backpack or something. “I got all these satellite maps and drew our plan of attack, but I can’t freaking find them anywhere. But anyway, just go right past the parkway, and on your left there will be this souvenir shop.”

Anyway, just go past the road with the trees, and on the left, there will be a souvenir shop.”

And while only a truly masochistic car thief would ever think of jacking the Chrysler, I still didn’t relish the thought of explaining to my mom how and why her car went missing in the small hours of a school night.

And although only a masochistic car thief would think of snatching the Chrysler, I didn't feel like explaining to my mother how and why her car had disappeared in the middle of the night on a school day.

en: We stood outside, leaning against the back of the minivan, the air so warm and thick I felt my clothes clinging to my skin. I felt scared again, as if people I couldn’t see were looking at me. It had been too dark for too long, and my gut ached from the hours of worrying. Margo had found her maps, and by the light of the street lamp, her spray-paint-blue fingertip traced our route. “I think there’s a fence right there,” she said, pointing to a wooden patch we’d hit just after crossing the parkway. “I read about it online. They installed it a few years ago after some drunk guy walked into the park in the middle of the night and decided to go swimming with Shamu, who promptly killed him.”
vi: We stood outside, leaning against the tail of the minivan, the air hot and heavy to the point that I felt my clothes sticking to my skin. I had that eerie feeling again, as if someone was watching me but I couldn't see them. The night dragged on too long, my stomach ached after hours of anxious tension. Margo had found the map, under the streetlight, her green paint-stained fingertip tracing the route. “I think there's a section of fence right here,” she said, pointing to a dense patch on the other side of the tree-lined road. “I read about it online. A few years ago, they put up the fence because some drunk guy wandered into the park at midnight and got the idea to swim with Shamu, so Shamu ate him.”
tr: We stood outside leaning against the back of the minivan, the air was so warm and dense that I felt my clothes sticking to me. I started to feel scared again, as if unseen people were watching me. It had been very dark for a long time and my stomach ached from the anxious hours. Margo found the maps and under the streetlamp's light, her spray-painted blue finger traced our route. "I think there's a fence right here," she said, pointing to a wooden spot we encountered just after crossing the boulevard. "I read something about this place on the internet. A drunk man decided to enter the park in the middle of the night and swim with Shamu, and the animal killed him."
es: We stayed outside, leaning against the back of the minivan. The air was so warm and dense that my clothes stuck to my skin. I was scared again, as if people I couldn't see were watching me. The night had been very long and I had been worried for so many hours that my stomach hurt. Margo had found the maps and was tracing our route with her blue finger under the streetlight. —I think there's a fence here —he told me, pointing to a wooded area we had encountered just after crossing the highway—. I read it on the internet. They put it up a few years ago because a drunk person entered the park in the middle of the night and decided to take a swim with the orca Shamu, who didn't take long to kill him.

en: “Seriously?”
vi: "Is that really true?"
tr: “Really?”
es: —Seriously?

en: “Yeah, so if that guy can make it in drunk, surely we can make it in sober. I mean, we’re ninjas.”

tr: "Yes, I mean if that guy can do it while he's drunk, we can definitely do it while we're sober. After all, we are ninjas."
es: —Yes, so if that guy could get in drunk, surely we, who haven't drunk, can also get in. Come on, we're ninjas.

en: “Well, maybe you’re a ninja,” I said.

es: —Well, maybe you are a ninja —I told her.

en: “You’re just a really loud, awkward ninja,” Margo said, “but we are both ninjas.” She tucked her hair behind her ears, pulled up her hood, and scrunched it shut with a drawstring; the streetlight lit up the sharp features of her pale face. Maybe we were both ninjas, but only she had the outfit.
vi: “You are the noisy and talkative ninja,” Margo said, “but we are both ninjas.” She tucked her hair behind her ear, put on her hat, and tightened the drawstring; the light from the streetlamp illuminated the sharp features on her pale face. Maybe we were both ninjas, but only Margo was dressed appropriately.
tr: “You’re just a really noisy, clumsy ninja,” said Margo, “but we’re both ninjas.” She tucked her hair behind her ears; pulled her hood over her head and tightened it with a rustle; the street lamp illuminated the sharp features of her pale face. Maybe we were both ninjas, but she was the only one with equipment.
es: —We are both ninjas, only you are a clumsy and noisy ninja —said Margo. She tucked her hair behind her ears, put on the hood, and tied it with the cord. The streetlamp illuminated the sharp features of her pale face. Maybe we were both ninjas, but only she looked like one.

en: “Okay,” she said. “Memorize the map.” By far the most terrifying part of the half-mile-long journey Margo had plotted for us was the moat. SeaWorld was shaped like a triangle. One side was protected by a road, which Margo figured was regularly patrolled by night watchmen. The second side was guarded by a lake that was at least a mile around, and the third side had a drainage ditch; from the map, it looked to be about as wide as a two-lane road. And where there are water-filled drainage ditches near lakes in Florida, there are often alligators.
vi: “Alright,” she said. “Remember the map.” At this point, the most perilous part of the half-mile journey Margo had outlined was the moat. The terrain of SeaWorld was like a triangle. One side was the road, which Margo reasoned would frequently have security personnel patrolling at night. The second side bordered a lake with a circumference of at least a mile, and the third side adjoined a drainage ditch. From the map, this moat appeared to be as wide as a two-lane road. And in Florida, where there is a drainage ditch next to a lake, there are often alligators.
tr: ‘Okay,’ he said. ‘Memorize the map.’ The most terrifying part by far of the roughly one-kilometer journey Margo had planned for us was the ditch. SeaWorld was triangular in shape. One side, according to Margo's estimation, was guarded by a street patrolled by night watchmen, the second side was watched over by a lake with a circumference of at least one kilometer, and the third side had a drainage channel; on the map, it appeared to be about two lanes wide. It looked as wide as a road. And in Florida, if there are drainage canals filled with water near the lakes, there are usually alligators there.
es: —Alright —he told me—, memorize the map. The most terrifying part of the nearly one-kilometer route that Margo had mapped out was, by far, the moat. SeaWorld was triangular in shape. One side was protected by a road on which Margo assumed night watchmen patrolled permanently. The second side was protected by a lake with a perimeter of almost two kilometers, and on the third side, there was a drainage ditch. According to the map, it seemed to be as wide as a two-lane road. And in Florida, drainage ditches next to lakes usually have alligators.

en: Margo grabbed me by both shoulders and turned me toward her. “We’re going to get caught, probably, and when we do, just let me talk. You just look cute and be that weird mix of innocent and confident, and we’ll be fine.”
vi: Margo put both hands on my shoulders and turned me to face her. "We might get caught, maybe, in that case, just let me do all the talking. You just need to act kind of innocent and straightforward, and we'll be fine."
tr: Margo grabbed me by both shoulders and turned me towards her. “We will probably get caught, and when we do, let me do the talking. You just need to look cute and display that weirdly innocent yet confident demeanor of yours, and everything will be fine.”
es: Margo grabbed me by the shoulders and turned me towards her. —Surely they will catch us, so when they do, let me do the talking. You just focus on looking good, half innocent, half confident, and everything will be fine.

en: I locked the car, tried to pat down my puffy hair, and whispered, “I’m a ninja.” I didn’t mean for Margo to hear, but she piped up. “Damned right you are! Now let’s go.”
vi: I locked the bike, tried to smooth down my messy hair, and muttered, "I am a ninja." I didn't mean for Margo to hear it, but she exclaimed, "Damn, you really are a ninja." "Let's go quickly."
tr: I locked the car, tried to smooth down my frizzy hair, and whispered, "I am a ninja." I hadn't intended for Margo to hear, but she suddenly responded. "You definitely are! Now let's go."
es: I locked the car, tried to smooth down my disheveled hair with my hand, and murmured: —I am a ninja. He didn't intend for Margo to hear him, but suddenly he blurted out: —Of course, damn it! Now, let's go.

en: We jogged across I-Drive and then started bushwhacking through a thicket of tall shrubs and oak trees. I started to worry about poison ivy, but ninjas don’t worry about poison ivy, so I led the trail, my arms in front of me, pushing aside briars and brush as we walked toward the moat. Finally the trees stopped and the field opened up, and I could see the parkway on our right and the moat straight ahead of us. People could have seen us from the road if there had been any cars, but there weren’t. Together we took off running through the brush, and then made a sharp turn toward the parkway. Margo said, “Now, now!” and I dashed across the six lanes of highway. Even though it was empty, something felt exhilarating and wrong about running across a road that big.
vi: We walked through I-Drive, starting to find our way through the dense oaks and tangled bushes. I was a bit worried about the ivy's toxins, but ninjas aren't afraid of ivy toxins, so I charged ahead, arms raised in front of me, pushing the thorny branches aside to move towards the moat. Finally getting through the patch of trees and with a clearer view, I saw the road with rows of trees on the right and the moat straight ahead. Anyone sitting in a car on the road would surely see us, but there were no cars at all. We ran through the bushes together, turning towards the row of trees. Margo said, "Come on, come on!" and I darted across the six-lane highway. Even though there wasn't a soul on the road, I still felt a surge of excitement and a huge sense of wrongdoing as I dashed across such a big road.
tr: We ran to the other side of the boulevard, then lay in ambush in the greenery made up of long bushes and oaks. I had started to worry about poison ivy, but since ninjas wouldn't worry about poison ivy, I led the way towards the ditch, arms forward, pushing aside thorny bushes and shrubs. Finally, the trees ended and the clearing emerged, allowing me to see the boulevard to my right and the ditch directly in front of us. If there had been a few cars, people could have seen us from the road, but there were no cars at all. We moved to run through the greenery together and then made a sharp turn towards the boulevard. Margo said, "Now, now!" and I dashed across the six lanes of the main road. Even though the road was empty, there was something both thrilling and wrong about running across such a big street.
es: We ran along International Drive and then made our way through tall bushes and oaks. I started to worry about poison ivy, but ninjas don't worry about those things, so I took the lead, with my arms outstretched, and pushed aside the brambles and weeds as we advanced toward the moat. Eventually, the wooded area ended and we reached an open field. I could see the highway to our right and the moat directly ahead. We could have been seen from the road if any cars had passed by, but none did. We ran through the underbrush and made a sharp turn toward the highway. —Now! Now! —exclaimed Margo. And I ran across the six lanes of the highway. Although it was empty, crossing such a large road seemed thrilling and inappropriate to me.

en: We made it across and then knelt down in the knee-high grass beside the parkway. Margo pointed to the strip of trees between SeaWorld’s endlessly gigantic parking lot and the black standing water of the moat. We ran for a minute along that line of trees, and then Margo pulled on the back of my shirt, and said quietly, “Now the moat.”

We ran along the tree line for about a minute, then Margo tugged at the back of my shirt and whispered, "Just wade through the water."

Margo pointed to the row of trees between SeaWorld's vast, enormous parking area and the dark, still water in the ditch. We ran along this row of trees for a minute, then Margo pulled me by the back of my shirt and quietly said, "Now into the ditch."

en: And I didn’t think about the alligators or the disgusting layer of brackish algae. I just got a running start and jumped as far as I could. I landed in waist-deep water and then high-stepped across. The water smelled rank and felt slimy on my skin, but at least I wasn’t wet above my waist. Or at least I wasn’t until Margo jumped in, splashing water all over me. I turned around and splashed her. She faux-retched.
vi: And I no longer thought about crocodiles or the stagnant, foul-smelling muddy swamp. I just took a running start and jumped as far as I could. I landed in waist-deep water and continued to wade forward. The water reeked and felt slimy on my skin, but at least from the waist up I was dry. Or at least I was until Margo jumped in, splashing water all over me. I turned around and splashed her back. Margo pretended to choke on water and grumbled:
tr: And I didn't think about the crocodiles or the disgusting layer of algae. I just started running and jumped as far as I could. I landed in water up to my waist, then crossed with long strides. The water smelled disgusting and created a slimy feeling on my skin, but at least I wasn't wet above my waist. Or at least not until Margo jumped in, splashing water all over me. I turned around and splashed her back. She pretended to gag.
es: And I didn't think about the alligators or the disgusting layer of brackish algae. I took a running start and jumped as far as I could. I landed in water up to my waist and strode forward with large steps. The water smelled rotten and was full of mud, but at least I hadn't gotten wet from the waist up. Or at least until Margo jumped and splashed me. I turned and splashed her back. She pretended she was going to vomit.

en: “Ooh, touché.”

en: I was watching Margo pull herself up out of the moat. And I was feeling thoroughly pleased about the lack of alligators. And my pulse was acceptable, if brisk. And beneath her unzipped hoodie, her black T-shirt had become clingy in the water. In short, a lot of things were going pretty well when I saw in my peripheral vision a slithering in the water beside Margo. Margo started to step out of the water, and I could see her Achilles tendon tensing, and before I could even say anything, the snake lashed out and bit her left ankle, right below the line of her jeans.
vi: I watched Margo climb up from the moat. I was secretly relieved that we didn't have to deal with any crocodiles. My pulse, if it was racing, was still at an acceptable level. Underneath Margo's unbuttoned coat, her black T-shirt was soaking wet. In short, many things were going smoothly, but suddenly I caught a glimpse of something shimmering on the water's surface right next to Margo. She jumped onto the shore, I saw Margo's Achilles tendon tighten, and before I could shout, the snake had already struck, biting her left ankle just below the hem of her jeans.
tr: I was watching Margo pull herself up from the ditch. And I was genuinely glad for the absence of crocodiles. And although my pulse was a bit fast, it was at an acceptable rate. And the black t-shirt under Margo's unzipped hooded jacket was wet and clinging to her. In short, many things were going quite well until I noticed out of the corner of my eye that there was something crawling in the water next to Margo. Margo started to get out of the water, I could see her Achilles tendon tensing, and before I could say anything, the snake attacked and bit her left ankle just below her cuff.
es: I watched Margo coming out of the pit, delighted that there were no alligators. My pulse was acceptable, though accelerated. The water clung to Margo's body, making the black t-shirt she wore under her unbuttoned sweatshirt stick to her. In short, almost everything was perfect when I saw out of the corner of my eye something slithering in the water near Margo. Margo started to get out of the water, and I saw her Achilles tendon tighten. Before I could open my mouth, the snake lunged at her and bit her left ankle, right where her jeans ended.

en: “Shit!” Margo said, and she looked down and then said “Shit!” again. The snake was still attached. I dove down and grabbed the snake by the tail and ripped it from Margo’s leg and threw it into the moat. “Ow, God,” she said. “What was it? Was it a moccasin?”
vi: "Oh no!" Margo exclaimed, she looked down and said again, "Oh no!" The snake still hadn't left Margo's leg. I rushed over, grabbed the snake's tail, yanked it off her leg, and threw it straight into the moat. "Oh my God," Margo cried out. "What was that? Was it a cobra?"
tr: “Damn it!” said Margo, looked down and then again, “Damn it!” she said. The snake was still on her foot. I reached down, grabbed the snake by its tail, and yanked it off Margo’s leg, throwing it into the ditch. “Oh, God,” she said. “What was that? Was it a venomous water snake?”
es: —Shit! —exclaimed Margo. She looked down and repeated—: Shit! The snake was still clinging to her ankle. I dived in, grabbed the snake by the tail, tore it off Margo's leg, and threw it into the pit. —Oh, damn —he said—. What was it? Was it a cotton mouth?

en: “I don’t know. Lie down, lie down,” I said, and then I took her leg in my hands, and I pulled up her jeans. There were two drops of blood coming out where the fangs had been, and I leaned down and put my mouth on the wound and sucked as hard as I could, trying to draw out the venom. I spit, and was going to go back to her leg when she said, “Wait, I see it.” I jumped up, terrified, and she said, “No, no, God, it’s just a garter snake.” She was pointing into the moat, and I followed her finger and could see the little garter snake skirting along the surface, swimming beneath a floodlight’s skirt. From the well-lit distance, the thing didn’t look much scarier than a baby lizard.
vi: "I don't know." "Lie down, lie down," I said, then lifted Margo's leg in my hands and rolled up the cuff of her jeans. Two drops of blood oozed from the bite, I bent down, pressed my mouth to the wound, and sucked hard, trying to draw out the venom. I spat out the blood, intending to suck again, but she said, "Wait, I see it. "I jumped up in a panic, Margo said, "Oh my God, it's okay, this species isn't venomous. " She pointed towards the moat, I followed Margo's finger and saw a small striped snake gliding along the edge of the water, swimming right where the light shone down. In the light, the snake looked just like a small lizard, not very scary.
tr: “I don't know. Lie down, lie down,” I said and grabbed his leg, pulling up his jeans. Two drops of blood had come out from where the snake had bitten, I bent down and placed my mouth over the wound, trying to suck out the venom as strongly as I could. I spat, was about to go back to his leg when he said, “Wait, I see it.” I jumped up in horror and Margo said, “No no, God, it's just a small snake.” She was pointing inside the ditch, my finger followed I did, and near the surface, I could see a small snake swimming at the edge of a projector light. From the well-lit distance, the creature didn't look more frightening than a baby lizard.
es: —I don't know. Lie down, lie down —I ordered him. I grabbed his leg and rolled up his jeans. The fangs had left two small holes from which a drop of blood was oozing. I bent down, put my mouth on the wound, and sucked with all my strength to try to extract the venom. I spat, and was about to suck again when Margo said: —Wait, I see her. I jumped up, terrified. —No, no —he kept saying—. Damn, it's just a snake. He pointed to the pit. I followed his finger and saw the small snake slithering across the surface, just below the beam of a spotlight. From a distance, it didn't look much more fearsome than a lizard.

en: “Thank God,” I said, sitting down next to her and catching my breath.
vi: “Thank goodness,” I said, sitting down next to Margo and catching my breath.
tr: “Thank God,” I said as I sat down next to Margo to catch my breath.
es: —Thank God —I said, sitting down next to him and catching my breath.

en: After looking at the bite and seeing that the bleeding had already stopped, she asked, “How was making out with my leg?”
vi: After looking at the bite and realizing the bleeding had stopped, she asked me, "How does biting my leg feel?"
tr: After looking at the bite and seeing that the bleeding had already stopped, she asked, “How was it to mess with my leg?”
es: After taking a look at the bite and seeing that it was no longer bleeding, he asked me: —How was the steak you had with my leg?

The rides aren’t working. Everything cool is locked up. Most of the animals are put into different tanks at night.” She turned her head and appraised the SeaWorld we could see. “I guess the pleasure isn’t being inside.”

I could smell her next to me, the sweat and the algae from the moat, her shampoo like lilacs, and the smell of her skin like crushed almonds.

en: I felt tired for the first time, and I thought of us lying down on some grassy patch of SeaWorld together, me on my back and she on her side with her arm draped against me, her head on my shoulder, facing me. Not doing anything—just lying there together beneath the sky, the night here so well lit that it drowns out the stars. And maybe I could feel her breathe against my neck, and maybe we could just stay there until morning and then the people would walk past as they came into the park, and they would see us and think that we were tourists, too, and we could just disappear into them.
vi: The first time I felt tired. And I imagined the scene of us lying next to each other on the grass at SeaWorld, me lying on my back and Margo lying on her side, her arm draped over me, her head resting on my shoulder and looking at me. Doing nothing at all—just lying next to each other under the sky, the night here still so bright, obscuring all the stars. And it seemed like I could feel Margo's breath gently caressing my neck, and maybe we could just lie there until morning, people starting to walk past us as they enter, they would see us and think that we were visitors too, and then we would just blend in and disappear among the tourists.

Maybe I feel her breath on my neck and maybe we stay there until morning, then as people come to the park, they walk past us, see us and think we are tourists too, and we disappear among them.

And maybe I felt her breath on my neck, and maybe we would stay there until morning, and then people would pass by us as they entered the park, see us, and think we were tourists too, and we could disappear among them.

en: I looked up at her, and for a moment I didn’t know why she’d said my name, but then I snapped out of my half-sleep. And I heard it. The Muzak from the speakers had been turned up, only it wasn’t Muzak anymore—it was real music. This old, jazzy song my dad likes called “Stars Fell on Alabama.” Even through the tinny speakers you could hear that whoever was singing it could sing a thousand goddamned notes at once.
vi: I looked up at her, for a moment I didn't understand why she called my name, but then I completely snapped out of my half-awake, half-dreaming state. And I heard it. The speakers were playing music, but it was no longer gentle instrumental music, it was real music. An old jazz song that my father liked, called "Stars Fell on Alabama." Through the tiny speakers, you could hear the singer seemingly hitting a thousand notes at once.
tr: I looked up at him and for a moment I didn't understand why he said my name, but then suddenly I shook off my drowsy state and came to my senses. And I heard it. The volume of the soft music coming from the speakers had increased, but it was no longer soft music... it was real music. It was that old jazz song called Stars Fell on Alabama, which my father loved. Even from the worthless speakers, it was possible to understand that the singer could hit a thousand damn notes at once.
es: I looked at her and for a moment I didn't understand why she had said my name, but suddenly I woke up from my reverie. And I heard it. They had turned up the background music, only it was no longer background music. It was real music. An old jazz tune that my father likes called "Stars Fell on Alabama." Even with those tiny speakers, you could tell that the singer could hit a thousand damn notes at once.

en: And I felt the unbroken line of me and of her stretching back from our cribs to the dead guy to acquaintanceship to now. And I wanted to tell her that the pleasure for me wasn’t planning or doing or leaving; the pleasure was in seeing our strings cross and separate and then come back together—but that seemed too cheesy to say, and anyway, she was standing up.
vi: And I feel the seamless thread connecting me to her, stretching all the way from when we were toddlers in the crib, to the man who died years ago, to the closeness of today. And I want to tell Margo that the most enjoyable part for me isn't in the planning, the action, or the escape; the most enjoyable part is seeing our threads meet, then separate, and come back together again–but saying it like that seems too cheesy, and besides, she was already standing up.
tr: I felt the unbroken bond between him and me, stretching from our cradles to the dead man, from the dead man to our acquaintance, and from there to the present day. And I wanted to tell him that for me, the pleasure wasn't in planning or doing or leaving that place, but in seeing our strings intersect and diverge, then come together again... but these seemed too trivial to say, and besides, he was already getting up.
es: And I felt that the lines of his life and mine extended from our cradle to the dead guy, from when we met until that moment. And I wanted to tell him that for me the pleasure was not in planning, doing, or not doing. The pleasure was in observing our threads crossing, separating, and coming together again. But it seemed too cheesy to me, and besides, he had already gotten up.
