en: I stood up and reached out my hand and said, “May I have this dance?” Margo curtsied, gave me her hand, and said, “You may,” and then my hand was on the curve between her waist and her hip, and her hand was on my shoulder. And then step-step-sidestep, step-step-sidestep. We fox-trotted all the way around the seal tank, and still the song kept going on about the stars falling. “Sixth-grade slow dance,” Margo announced, and we switched positions, her hands on my shoulders and mine on her hips, elbows locked, two feet between us. And then we fox-trotted some more, until the song ended. I stepped forward and dipped Margo, just as they’d taught us to do at Crown School of Dance. She raised one leg and gave me all her weight as I dipped her. She either trusted me or wanted to fall.
vi: I stood up, extended my hand, and said, "May I invite you to dance this dance?" Margo curtsied, gave me her hand, and said, "Sure." I placed my hand on the curve between her waist and hip, and her hand rested on my shoulder. Step-step-step sideways. Step-step-step sideways. We danced the fox-trot around the seal area, the song still humming about the falling stars in the sky. "The slow sixth-grade dance," Margo said, and we changed positions, her hand on my shoulder and my hand on her hip, elbows interlocked, the two of us only half a meter apart. Then we danced the fox-trot again until the song ended. I took a step forward and dipped Margo, as we were taught back at Crown Dance School. Margo lifted one leg, putting all her weight on me as I supported her back. She trusted me, or she wanted to fall.
tr: I stood up, extended my hand, and said, "Would you honor me with this dance?" Margo curtsied, extended her hand, and said, "Of course," then my hand was on the curve between her hip and waist, and her hand was on my shoulder. And then step-side-step, step-side-step... We did the foxtrot from one end of the seal pool to the other, and the song about shooting stars was still playing. Margo said, "Sixth-grade style slow dance," we switched places, her hands were on my shoulders and my hand was on her hip, our elbows locked, half a meter between us. Then we did a bit more foxtrot... until the song ended. I stepped forward and made Margo lean back, just as they taught us at Crown Dance School. When I dipped her, she lifted one leg and put all her weight on me. Either she trusted me or she wanted to fall.
es: I got up, extended my hand, and said to him: —Will you grant me this dance? Margo curtsied to me and took my hand. —I grant you that —he replied to me. And then I placed my hand on the curve between her waist and her hip, and she rested hers on my shoulder. And one two to the side, one two to the side. We circled the seal aquarium dancing foxtrot, while the song about falling stars kept playing. —Slow dance from sixth grade —commented Margo. We changed positions. She placed her hands on my shoulders and I held her by the hips, with elbows closed, half a meter apart. And then we continued with the foxtrot until the song ended. I took a step forward and dipped Margo, as we had been taught at the Crown Dance School. She lifted one leg and let all her weight fall on me. Either she trusted me or she wanted to fall.

tr: Either she trusted me or she wanted to fall.

My parents generally believed that I was the most well-adjusted and not-likely-to-break-into-SeaWorld person on the planet, since my psychological well-being was proof of their professional talents.

en: I took my time going home, avoiding interstates in favor of back roads. Margo and I were listening to the radio, trying to figure out what station had been playing “Stars Fell on Alabama,” but then she turned it down and said, “All in all, I think it was a success.”

en: It was 5:42 when I turned into Jefferson Park. We drove down Jefferson Drive to Jefferson Court and then turned onto our road, Jefferson Way. I killed the headlights one last time and idled up my driveway. I didn’t know what to say, and Margo wasn’t saying anything. We filled a 7-Eleven bag with trash, trying to make the Chrysler look and feel as if the past six hours had not happened. In another bag, she gave me the remnants of the Vaseline, the spray paint, and the last full Mountain Dew. My brain raced with fatigue.

We stuffed all the trash into a 7-Eleven bag, trying to erase any traces so the Chrysler would look as if it hadn't just been through the past six hours. In another bag, Margo handed me the remaining items, Vaseline, spray paint, and the last bottle of Mountain Dew. My mind was racing with overwhelming fatigue.

We filled a bag from 7-Eleven with trash to make it look like the Chrysler was as if the last six hours hadn't existed. Margo gave me another bag with the remains of the Vaseline, the paint can, and the last can of Mountain Dew. My brain was fighting against exhaustion.

en: With a bag in each hand, I paused for a moment outside the van, staring at her. “Well, it was a helluva night,” I said finally.

es: I stood for a moment in front of the minivan, with a bag in each hand, and looked at Margo. —Well, it has been a fantastic night —I finally admitted.

en: “Come here,” she said, and I took a step forward. She hugged me, and the bags made it hard to hug her back, but if I dropped them I might wake someone. I could feel her on her tiptoes and then her mouth was right up against my ear and she said, very clearly, “I. Will. Miss. Hanging. Out. With. You.”
vi: “Come here,” Margo said, and I took a step forward. She hugged me, the bags made it difficult for me to hug her back, but if I put the bags down, I might wake someone up. I felt Margo rise on her toes and her lips right next to my ear, each word clear, “I. Will. Miss. The. Times. Playing. With. You.”
tr: “Come here,” he said, and I took a step forward. He hugged me, the bags made it difficult for me to hug him back, but if I let go, I might wake someone up. I could feel him standing on his tiptoes, his lips were close to my ear and clearly, “With you. Hanging out. I will miss it,” he said.
es: —Come here —he told me. I took a step forward. He hugged me, and the bags made it difficult for me to hug him back, but if I let them go, I might wake someone up. I noticed that he stood on tiptoe and suddenly brought his mouth close to my ear and said very clearly: —I will miss going out with you. —You don't have to —I replied out loud.

en: “You don’t have to,” I answered aloud. I tried to hide my disappointment. “If you don’t like them anymore,” I said, “just hang out with me. My friends are actually, like, nice.”
vi: “Why does it have to be like this,” I said loudly, trying to hide my disappointment. “If you don't like them anymore, then hang out with me. My friends are actually quite fun.”
tr: "You don't have to," I replied loudly. I was trying to hide my disappointment. "If you don't like them anymore," I said, "hang out with me. My friends are actually quite nice."
es: —You don't have to —I replied out loud. I tried to hide my disappointment—. If you no longer get along with your friends, go out with me. Mine are very nice.

en: Her lips were so close to me that I could feel her smile. “I’m afraid it’s not possible,” she whispered. She let go then, but kept looking at me, taking step after step backward. She raised her eyebrows finally, and smiled, and I believed the smile. I watched her climb up a tree and then lift herself onto the roof outside of her second-floor bedroom window. She jimmied her window open and crawled inside.
vi: Margo's lips were so close that I could feel her smile. “I’m afraid it won’t work,” she whispered. Then she moved away, but still looked at me, stepping back one step at a time. Finally, she raised her eyebrows, smiled, and I believed in that smile. I watched Margo climb up the tree, reaching the roof above her second-floor bedroom window. She pried open the window and crawled inside.
tr: His lips were so close to me that I could feel him smiling. "I'm afraid that's not possible," he whispered. Then he let me go, but as he stepped back, he continued to look at me ended. Finally, he raised his eyebrows and smiled, and I believed his smile. I watched him climb a tree, then step onto the ledge in front of the second-floor bedroom window. He forced the window open and crawled inside.
es: Her lips were so close to me that I could feel her smile. —I'm afraid it's not possible —he whispered. He stepped back, but kept looking at me as he retreated step by step. In the end, he raised his eyebrows, smiled, and I believed his smile. I watched her climb a tree and ascend to the ledge of her bedroom window on the second floor. She opened the window and slipped inside.

en: I walked through my unlocked front door, tiptoed through the kitchen to my bedroom, peeled off my jeans, threw them into a corner of the closet back near the window screen, downloaded the picture of Jase, and got into bed, my mind booming with the things I would say to her at school.

en: I’d been asleep for just about thirty minutes when my alarm clock went off at 6:32. But I did not personally notice that my alarm clock was going off for seventeen minutes, not until I felt hands on my shoulders and heard the distant voice of my mother saying, “Good morning, sleepyhead.”

It wasn't until I felt someone shaking my shoulder and vaguely heard my mother calling, "Wake up, sleepyhead," that I started to become slightly alert.

es: I had slept for about half an hour when the alarm clock went off. 6:32. But for seventeen minutes I didn't even realize that the alarm clock was ringing, until I felt hands on my shoulders and heard my mother's distant voice. —Good morning, sleepyhead —he said to me.

Also, I wanted to see how he would behave around Margo.

en: When I walked into the kitchen, Dad was telling Mom something while they ate at the breakfast counter. Dad paused when he saw me and said, “How’d you sleep?”

en: “I slept fantastically,” I said, which was true. Briefly, but well.

en: He smiled. “I was just telling your mom that I have this recurring anxiety dream,” he said. “So I’m in college. And I’m taking a Hebrew class, except the professor doesn’t speak Hebrew, and the tests aren’t in Hebrew—they’re in gibberish. But everyone is acting like this made-up language with a made-up alphabet is Hebrew. And so I have this test, and I have to write in a language I don’t know using an alphabet I can’t decipher.”
vi: Dad smiled. "I just told Mom that I keep having this recurring dream that's quite stressful," Dad said. "In the dream, I go to college and take a Hebrew class, but the teacher doesn't know Hebrew, and the test isn't in Hebrew either—it's all a bunch of meaningless gibberish. But everyone acts as if that patched-up, nonsensical language and alphabet is actually Hebrew. I still have to take the test and write in a language I don't know at all, using letters I'm completely unfamiliar with."
tr: She smiled. "I was just telling your mother about a recurring anxiety dream I had," she said. "I'm in college. And I'm taking a Hebrew class, but the professor doesn't speak Hebrew and the exams aren't in Hebrew either... they're in some gibberish language. But everyone acts like this made-up language with a made-up alphabet is Hebrew. So I end up taking the exam and have to write in a language I don't know using an alphabet I can't decipher."
es: He smiled. —I was telling your mother that I have a recurring and distressing dream —he explained to me—. I'm at the university, in a Hebrew class, although the professor doesn't speak Hebrew and the exams are not in Hebrew. They are in an incomprehensible jargon. But everyone acts as if that invented language, with an invented alphabet, were Hebrew. So I have that exam in front of me and I must write in a language I don't know using an alphabet I can't decipher.

en: “Interesting,” I said, although in point of fact it wasn’t. Nothing is as boring as other people’s dreams.
vi: "Sounds interesting," I said, though it actually wasn't that interesting. Nothing is as dull and boring as someone else's dream.
tr: "Interesting," I said, although it wasn't actually so. There is nothing as boring as other people's dreams.
es: —Interesting —I said, although it didn't really seem that way to me. There is nothing more boring than other people's dreams.

en: “It’s a metaphor for adolescence,” my mother piped up. “Writing in a language—adulthood—you can’t comprehend, using an alphabet—mature social interaction—you can’t recognize.” My mother worked with crazy teenagers in juvenile detention centers and prisons. I think that’s why she never really worried about me—as long as I wasn’t ritually decapitating gerbils or urinating on my own face, she figured I was a success.
vi: “That is a metaphor referring to youth,” my mother spoke up. “Written in a language–adulthood–that we do not understand, using an alphabet–social interactions perceived with maturity–that we do not recognize.” My mother worked with crazy and insane teenagers in reform schools and juvenile detention centers. I think that’s why she never really worried about me–as long as I wasn’t dismembering pet mice for sacrifices or peeing on my own face, she concluded that she had successfully raised me.
tr: “This is a metaphor for your adolescence,” my mother began. “Writing in a language you don't understand is adulthood, using an unfamiliar alphabet is mature social communication.” My mother worked with troubled youths in reformatories and juvenile prisons. I think the reason she never seriously worried about me was this... As long as I wasn't tearing off rodents' heads for rituals or peeing on my own face, she considered me a success.
es: —It's a metaphor for adolescence —my mother interjected—. Writing in a language (adulthood) that you don't understand and using an alphabet (mature social interaction) that you don't recognize. My mother worked with crazy teenagers in juvenile centers and prisons. I think that's why she never worried about me. Since I didn't spend my time decapitating rodents or peeing on my own face, it was clear that I was a success.

en: A normal mother might have said, “Hey, I notice you look like you’re coming down off a meth binge and smell vaguely of algae. Were you perchance dancing with a snakebit Margo Roth Spiegelman a couple hours ago?” But no. They preferred dreams.

tr: A normal mother might have said: "Hey, you look like you've returned from a weed trip and you faintly smell of seaweed. Is it possible that a few hours ago you danced with Margo Roth Spiegelman, who might have been bitten by a snake?” But no. They preferred dreams.

By any chance, were you dancing with Margo Roth Spiegelman a couple of hours ago, who had just been bitten by a snake?" But no. My parents preferred dreams.

en: As I walked up toward the band kids, Ben shouted, “Jacobsen, was I dreaming or did you—” I gave him the slightest shake of my head, and he changed gears midsentence— “and me go on a wild adventure in French Polynesia last night, traveling in a sailboat made of bananas?”

tr: As I walked towards the binoculars, Ben shouted: "Jacobsen, was I dreaming or did you..." I looked at him and nodded slightly, and he shifted gears mid-sentence: "... and I yesterday Did we have a wild adventure in French Polynesia, traveling by night on a sailboat made of bananas?"
es: As I approached the boys in the band, Ben shouted: —Jacobsen, was I dreaming or…? —I gave him a discreet nod and he changed the second part of the sentence—. Or did you and I have a wild adventure last night in French Polynesia, traveling on a boat made of bananas?

en: “That was one delicious sailboat,” I answered. Radar raised his eyes at me and ambled into the shade of a tree. I followed him. “Asked Angela about a date for Ben. No dice.” I glanced over at Ben, who was talking animatedly, a coffee stirrer dancing in his mouth as he spoke.

No luck.” I glanced at Ben, that monkey was chattering away, a coffee stirrer bouncing in his mouth with every word.
tr: “It was a very delicious sailboat,” I replied. Radar looked at me and walked, swaying, towards the shade of a tree. I followed him. “I asked Angela for a girl for Ben. In vain.” I glanced at Ben, who was speaking cheerfully, with a drink stirrer dancing in his mouth as he talked.

en: “That sucks,” I said. “It’s all good, though. He and I will hang out and have a marathon session of Resurrection or something.”

en: Ben came over then, and said, “Are you trying to be subtle? Because I know you’re talking about the honeybunnyless prom tragedy that is my life.” He turned around and headed inside. Radar and I followed him and crossed through the rehearsal room, where the first and second-year students were chatting while sitting among a bunch of instrument cases.

en: “Why do you even want to go?” I asked.

en: “Bro, it’s our senior prom. It’s my last best chance to be some honeybunny’s fondest high school memory.” I rolled my eyes.
vi: “The senior prom, man. My last perfect chance to create the most heart-throbbing memory of my school life with a sweet, innocent girl.” I listened with my eyes wide open.

es: —Buddy, it's our prom. It's my last chance to become a fond memory of high school for some girl. I looked at the ceiling.

en: The first bell rang, meaning five minutes to class, and like Pavlov’s dogs, people started rushing around, filling up the hallways. Ben and Radar and I stood by Radar’s locker. “So why’d you call me at three in the morning for Chuck Parson’s address?”

Ben, Radar, and I stood next to Radar's locker. "Why the heck did you call me at three in the morning asking for Chuck Parson's address?"

es: The first bell rang, which meant that there were five minutes left before classes started, and everyone started running like Pavlov's dogs. The hallways filled with people. en: I was mulling over how to best answer that question when I saw Chuck Parson walking toward us. I elbowed Ben’s side and cut my eyes toward Chuck. Chuck, incidentally, had decided that the best strategy was to shave off Lefty. “Holy shitstickers,” Ben said.
vi: I was racking my brain to come up with the most satisfactory answer when I suddenly saw Chuck Parson approaching. I nudged Ben and glanced towards Chuck. As a consequence of last night's event, Chuck had decided that the most effective strategy was to shave his left side clean. "Oh my god," Ben's jaw dropped.
tr: When I saw Chuck Parson coming towards us, I was racking my brain on how to best answer this question. I nudged Ben's side with my elbow and pointed at Chuck with a glance. Coincidentally, Chuck had decided that the best strategy was to shave the left side as well. "Wow," said Ben.
es: I was thinking about how to respond to his question when I saw Chuck Parson coming towards us. I elbowed Ben and pointed at Chuck with my eyes. By the way, Chuck had decided that the best strategy was to shave his left eyebrow. —What a pain in the ass —said Ben.

en: Soon enough, Chuck was in my face as I scrunched back against the locker, his forehead deliciously hairless. “What are you assholes looking at?”
vi: Immediately, Chuck was looming in front of me as I leaned against the locker, his smooth forehead looking quite appealing. "What are you damn bastards looking at?"

es: At that moment, Chuck pushed me against the locker and brought his face close to mine, a pretty face without eyebrows. —What are you looking at, dumbass?

en: “Nothing,” said Radar. “We’re certainly not looking at your eyebrows.” Chuck flicked Radar off, slammed an open palm against the locker next to me, and walked away.

en: “What an amazing coincidence,” I said. It was life as it had always been—only more fatigued. I had hoped that last night would change my life, but it hadn’t—at least not yet.

en: The second bell rang. We hustled off to class.

es: The second bell rang and we immediately went to class.

en: I became extremely tired during calc first period. I mean, I had been tired since waking, but combining fatigue with calculus seemed unfair. To stay awake, I was scribbling a note to Margo— nothing I’d ever send to her, just a summary of my favorite moments from the night before—but even that could not keep me awake. At some point, my pen just stopped moving, and I found my field of vision shrinking and shrinking, and then I was trying to remember if tunnel vision was a symptom of fatigue. I decided it must be, because there was only one thing in front of me, and it was Mr. Jiminez at the blackboard, and this was the only thing that my brain could process, and so when Mr. Jiminez said, “Quentin?” I was extraordinarily confused, because the one thing happening in my universe was Mr. Jiminez writing on the blackboard, and I couldn’t fathom how he could be both an auditory and a visual presence in my life.
vi: I started feeling utterly exhausted during the first period of calculus. In fact, I had felt weary since waking up, but combining that fatigue with calculus seemed somewhat unfair. To stay awake, I scribbled a few lines for Margo—there was no way I would ever send them to her, just a summary of my favorite moments from the previous night—yet my eyes were still drooping shut. At some point, I couldn't even hold my pen anymore, my field of vision kept narrowing, narrowing, and I racked my brain to recall if tunnel vision was a symptom of exhaustion. I figured it must be, because the only person I could see in front of me was Mr. Jiminez at the blackboard. Perhaps this was the only information my brain could process, so when Mr. Jiminez said, "Quentin?", I was extremely confused. The only thing happening in my universe was Mr. Jiminez writing something on the board, and I couldn't understand how he could exist in my life in both audible and visible forms like that.
tr: I started to feel extremely tired during the first math class. I mean, I had been tired since I woke up, but the combination of tiredness and math seemed unfair. To stay awake, I scribbled a note to Margo—it wasn't something I would actually send her, just a summary of my favorite moments from the previous night—but even that couldn't keep me awake. At one point, my pen stopped moving, and I found my field of vision narrowing; then I tried to remember if tunnel vision was a symptom of tiredness. I decided it must be because there was only one thing in front of me, and that was Mr. Jiminez on the board, the only thing my brain could perceive, and on top of that, when Mr. Jiminez said, "Quentin?" I was extremely confused because the only thing in my universe was Mr. Jiminez writing on the board, and I couldn't comprehend how he could have both an auditory and visual presence in my life.
es: During the first calculus class, I felt tremendously tired. Well, I had been tired since I woke up, but combining tiredness with calculus seemed unfair to me. To stay awake, I dedicated myself to writing a note to Margo —considering that I wasn't going to send it, it was just a simple summary of my favorite moments from the previous night—, but even that didn't work. At a certain point, my pen stopped moving and I felt my field of vision narrowing more and more, so I tried to remember if tunnel vision was a symptom of tiredness. I concluded that it must be, because before me I saw only one thing, Mr. Jiminez at the board, it was the only thing my brain processed, and when Mr. Jiminez said "Quentin?", I was very confused, because the only thing happening in my universe was Mr. Jiminez writing on the board, so I didn't understand how he could be both an acoustic and visual presence at the same time.

But then after considerable struggle, my brain was able to tell my arm to lower itself, and my arm was able to do so, and then finally I said, “I just needed to ask to go to the bathroom?”

Then with considerable effort, my brain finally told my arm to lower, the arm obeyed, and finally I said, “May I go to the restroom?”

en: I walked to the bathroom, splashed water on my face, and then leaned over the sink, close to the mirror, and appraised myself. I tried to rub the bloodshotedness out of my eyes, but I couldn’t. And then I had a brilliant idea. I went into a stall, put the seat down, sat down, leaned against the side, and fell asleep. The sleep lasted for about sixteen milliseconds before the second period bell rang. I got up and walked to Latin, and then to physics, and then finally it was fourth period, and I found Ben in the cafeteria and said, “I really need a nap or something.”
vi: I went into the bathroom, splashed water on my face, then leaned on the sink, got close to the mirror, and scrutinized my face. I tried rubbing my bloodshot eyes but it didn't help at all. And then I came up with a brilliant idea. I went into a stall, closed the toilet lid, sat on it, leaned against the wall, and slept. The sleep lasted about sixteen milliseconds before the bell for the second period rang. I got up and went to Latin class, then physics. Finally, it was the fourth period, I caught up with Ben in the cafeteria and said, “I really need to take a nap or something.”
tr: I went to the bathroom and splashed water on my face, then leaned over the sink, approached the mirror, and examined myself. I tried to fix my bloodshot eyes by rubbing them, but I couldn't. Then a great idea came to my mind. I entered one of the stalls, closed the toilet lid, sat down, leaned to the side, and fell asleep; I managed to sleep for about sixteen milliseconds before the second bell rang. I got up and went to Latin class, then physics, and finally, the break came. I found Ben in the cafeteria and said, "I really need a short nap."
es: I went to the bathroom, splashed water on my face, approached the mirror above the sink, and observed myself. I rubbed my eyes to eliminate the redness, but I couldn't. And then a brilliant idea occurred to me. I entered a stall, lowered the lid, sat down, leaned against the wall, and fell asleep. The sleep lasted about sixteen milliseconds, until the bell for the second period rang. I got up and went to Latin class, then to physics, and finally it was lunchtime. I found Ben in the cafeteria. —I need a nap —I told him.

en: “Let’s have lunch with RHAPAW,” he answered.
vi: “Let's have lunch with RHAPAW,” Ben replied.
tr: “Come on, let's go out for lunch with SESIB,” he said.
es: —Let's go eat at Chuco —he answered me.

en: RHAPAW was a fifteen-year-old Buick that had been driven with impunity by all three of Ben’s older siblings and was, by the time it reached Ben, composed primarily out of duct tape and spackle. Her full name was Rode Hard And Put Away Wet, but we called her RHAPAW for short. RHAPAW ran not on gasoline, but on the inexhaustible fuel of human hope. You would sit on the blisteringly hot vinyl seat and hope she would start, and then Ben would turn the key and the engine would turn over a couple times, like a fish on land making its last, meager, dying flops. And then you would hope harder, and the engine would turn over a couple more times. You hoped some more, and it would finally catch.
vi: RHAPAW was a fifteen-year-old Buick, which Ben's three older siblings had driven carefree year after year. By the time it came into Ben's possession, RHAPAW's main structure was duct tape and putty. Its full name was "Rồ Hơi Ả Pắn Ả Wa," abbreviated to RHAPAW for short. It didn't run on gasoline but on an eternal fuel called "the hope of humanity." Just sit on the burning hot nylon seat and hope it would run, then Ben would turn the key, the engine would start up and down a few times, like a fish on land flailing its last desperate kicks before dying. So you had to hope even more intensely, and the engine would come back to life a few more times. Hope again, and finally, it would take a breath.
tr: SESIB was a fifteen-year-old Buick that had been recklessly used by Ben's three older brothers, and by the time it was given to Ben, it was essentially made up of duct tape and filler. Its full name was Drive Hard Leave Wet, but we simply called it SESIB. SESIB didn't run on gasoline but on the inexhaustible fuel of human hope. You would sit on its vinyl seat, hot enough to be called scorching, and hope it would start; then Ben would turn the key and the engine would sputter a few times, like a weak, lifeless fish gasping its last on dry land. Then you would hope some more, and the engine would sputter a few more times. You would hope a bit more, and finally, it would start.
es: The Chuco was a fifteen-year-old Buick that Ben's three older brothers had driven with impunity, so by the time it got to him, it was basically duct tape and putty. Its full name was Churro de Coche, but we called it Chuco for short. The Chuco didn't run on gasoline, but on the inexhaustible fuel of hope. You would sit on the scorching plastic seat and wait for it to start, then Ben would turn the key and the engine would turn over a couple of times, like a fish out of water giving its last flaps before dying. You kept waiting and the engine would turn over a couple more times. You waited some more and eventually it would start.

en: Ben started RHAPAW and turned the AC on high. Three of the four windows didn’t even open, but the air conditioner worked magnificently, though for the first few minutes it was just hot air blasting out of the vents and mixing with the hot stale air in the car. I reclined the passenger seat all the way back, so that I was almost lying down, and I told him everything: Margo at my window, the Wal-Mart, the revenge, the SunTrust Building, entering the wrong house, SeaWorld, the I-will-miss-hanging-out-with-you.

I stretched out on the back seat, almost lying flat, and I told Ben everything: Margo at my window, Wal-Mart, the revenge plot, the SunTrust building, breaking into the wrong house, SeaWorld, and the I'll-miss-hanging-out-with-you moment.
tr: Ben started the SESIB and turned on the air conditioner. Three of the four windows wouldn't even open, but the air conditioner was working magnificently; still, for the first few minutes, only hot air was gushing out of the vents, mixing with the hot, stale air inside the car. Wanting to almost lie down, I reclined the passenger seat and told Ben everything: Margo at my window, Walmart, the revenge, the SunTrust building, entering the wrong house, SeaWorld, "I'll miss hanging out with you."
es: Ben turned on the Chuco and cranked the air conditioning to the max. Three of the four windows wouldn't open, but the air conditioning worked wonderfully, although for the first few minutes it was nothing but hot air coming out of the vents and mixing with the stale air of the car. I reclined the passenger seat all the way back until I was almost lying down and told him everything: Margo at my window, the Walmart, the revenge, the SunTrust Building, entering a house that wasn't ours, the SeaWorld, and the I'll miss going out with you.

en: “Shrinkage may have played a role, since he was under significant anxiety, but have you ever seen a pencil?” I asked him, and Ben nodded. “Well, have you ever seen a pencil eraser?” He nodded again. “Well, have you ever seen the little shavings of rubber left on the paper after you erase something?” More nodding. “I’d say three shavings long and one shaving wide,” I said. Ben had taken a lot of crap from guys like Jason Worthington and Chuck Parson, so I figured he was entitled to enjoy it a little. But he didn’t even laugh. He was just shaking his head slowly, awestruck.
vi: “Sun could be a contributing factor, because at that time the boy was extremely stressed, but have you ever seen a pencil?” I asked, and Ben nodded. “Well, have you ever seen the eraser attached to the end of the pencil?” Ben nodded again. “Well, have you ever seen the tiny eraser shavings left on the paper when you erase something?” Another nod. “I think the length is about three shavings, the width about one shaving,” I concluded. Ben had to endure a lot of pranks from guys like Jase Worthington and Chuck Parson, so I thought he deserved a little bit of fun. But Ben didn't even laugh. He just slowly shook his head, looking bewildered.

He had suffered a lot from kids like Jason Worthington and Chuck Parson, so I thought he deserved to enjoy this situation a bit. But he didn’t even laugh. He just slowly nodded, entranced.

Ben had swallowed a lot of crap from guys like Jason Worthington and Chuck Parson, so I thought he had the right to have a little fun. But he didn't even laugh. He just shook his head slowly, astonished.

en: After they got out, Ben dropped Radar off at his house right by the Jefferson Park “village center,” near where Lacey lived. Then he took me home. I noticed Margo’s car was not parked in her driveway, either. So she hadn’t skipped school to sleep. She’d skipped school for another adventure—a me-less adventure. She’d probably spent her day spreading hair-removal cream on the pillows of other enemies or something. I felt a little left out as I walked into the house, but of course she knew I would never have joined her anyway—I cared too much about a day of school. And who even knew if it would be just a day for Margo. Maybe she was off on another three-day jaunt to Mississippi, or temporarily joining the circus. But it wasn’t either of those, of course. It was something I couldn’t imagine, that I would never imagine, because I couldn’t be Margo.
vi: Leaving the gym, Ben dropped Radar off at his house, right next to the "navel of the village" Jefferson Park, near Lacey's house. Then he took me home. I noticed that Margo's car wasn't parked in her driveway either. So she wasn't skipping school to sleep at home. Margo wasn't coming to school because she was busy with another adventure—a non-Quentin adventure. Maybe she spent the whole day smearing hair removal cream on the pillows of other enemies, or something like that. As I walked into the house, I felt left out, but of course, Margo knew I would never join her again—I prioritized a day at school too much. Who knows, maybe it was just a day for Margo. Maybe she took another three-day trip to Mississippi, or wandered off with a circus troupe. But of course, reality wasn't any of the above scenarios. But it is something I cannot imagine, because how could I possibly be Margo.
tr: After they went outside, I took Radar to Jefferson Park "village center" near where Lacey was sitting He dropped her off at the house right next to mine. Then he took me home. I noticed that Margo's car wasn't parked in the driveway either. So she hadn't skipped school to sleep. She had skipped school for another adventure...an adventure without me. She had probably spent her day putting hair removal cream on the pillows of her other enemies or something. I felt a bit left out as I walked into the house, but of course, she knew I would never, under any circumstances, join her...I cared too much about the school day. And who could have known that I would be just one day for Margo. Maybe she had gone on a three-day trip to Mississippi or temporarily joined a circus. But of course, it was none of those things. It was something I couldn't imagine, something I would never imagine, because I couldn't be like Margo.
es: When they left, Ben took Radar to his house, towards the "center" of Jefferson Park, near where Lacey lived, and then he accompanied me. I saw that Margo's car wasn't parked at her house either, so she hadn't skipped classes to sleep. She would have skipped classes for another one of her adventures, an adventure without me. She was probably spending the day spreading depilatory cream on the pillows of other enemies or something like that. I entered the house feeling a bit abandoned, although of course Margo knew that I wouldn't have gone with her anyway, because I wouldn't want to miss a day of class. And who knew if it would have been just one day. Maybe she had gone on another three-day excursion through Mississippi or had temporarily joined the circus. But it wouldn't be either of those things, of course. It was something I couldn't imagine, would never imagine, because I couldn't be Margo.

en: I wondered what stories she would come home with this time. And I wondered if she would tell them to me, sitting across from me at lunch. Maybe, I thought, this is what she meant by I will miss hanging out with you. She knew she was heading somewhere for another of her brief respites from Orlando’s paperness. But when she came back, who knew? She couldn’t spend the last weeks of school with the friends she’d always had, so maybe she would spend them with me after all.
vi: I wonder what she will bring home this time. And I wonder if she will tell me when the two of us sit across from each other having lunch. Maybe, I think, this is what Margo meant when she said she would miss the times playing with me. She knew that she already had a place to go, to temporarily escape the dull, paper-like monotony of Orlando. But when will Margo come back? Who knows. She didn't want to spend the last weeks of high school with her longtime friends, so maybe she will end up wanting to spend time with me.
tr: I wondered what stories I would come home with during this time. And whether you would tell them to me while sitting across from me at lunch. Maybe, I thought, when you said you would miss hanging out with me, this is what you meant. He knew I would set out somewhere to take a break from Orlando's paperwork. But who knows when he would come back. He couldn't spend the last weeks of school with his usual friends, so maybe despite everything, he would spend them with me.
es: I wondered what stories he would come home with this time. And I wondered if he would sit in front of me at mealtime and tell me about them. I thought that maybe that's what he meant when he said he would miss going out with me. I knew he would go somewhere to take another of his brief breaks from Orlando, the paper town. But when he came back, who knew? He couldn't spend the last weeks of school with the friends he had always had, so maybe after all, he would spend them with me.

en: She didn’t have to be gone long for the rumors to start. Ben called me that night after dinner. “I hear she’s not answering her phone. Someone on Facebook said she’d told them she might move into a secret storage room in Tomorrowland at Disney.”
vi: It didn't take long for rumors to spread once Margo disappeared. That evening, after dinner, Ben called me. "I heard that Margo isn't answering her phone. Someone on Facebook said that Margo mentioned she was moving to a secret storage room in Tomorrowland at Disney."
tr: It didn't take long for rumors to start once Margo was gone. That night, after dinner, Ben called. "I heard Margo isn't answering her phone. Someone on Facebook said she told them she might move to a secret warehouse in Disney Tomorrowland."
es: It didn't take long for the rumors to start spreading. Ben called me that night, after dinner. —I have heard that he doesn't answer the phone. Someone mentioned on Facebook that he said he might move to a secret warehouse in Tomorrowland, at Disneyland.

en: “That’s idiotic,” I said.
vi: "Nonsense," I said.
tr: "That's so stupid," I said.
es: —What nonsense —I told him.

en: “I know. I mean, Tomorrowland is by far the crappiest of the Lands. Someone else said she met a guy online.”
vi: “I know, Tomorrowland is the weirdest of all the Lands. Someone even said Margo met a guy online.”
tr: "I know. I mean, Tomorrowland is by far Disney's crappiest park. Someone else also said that Margo met a boy online."
es: —I already know. Well, Tomorrowland is by far the tackiest part. And someone said they met a guy online.

en: “Ridiculous,” I said.
vi: "Nonsense," I snapped.
tr: “Very silly,” I said.
es: —Ridiculous —I insisted.

en: “Okay, fine, but what?”
vi: “Okay, fine, but so what?”
tr: “Alright, but what could have happened?”
es: —Okay, very well, but then?

en: “She’s somewhere by herself having the kind of fun we can only imagine,” I said.
vi: “Margo is somewhere on her own, experiencing the kind of fun that we can only imagine,” I said.
tr: “Somewhere, he must be amusing himself in a way we can only dream of,” I said.
es: —He must be out there having fun on his own in something we can't even imagine —I replied to him.

en: Ben giggled. “Are you saying that she’s playing with herself?”
vi: Ben giggled. "You mean Margo played by herself?"
tr: Ben giggled. “Are you saying she's playing with herself?” I whined.
es: Ben let out a chuckle. —Are you saying she likes to have fun alone?

en: I groaned. “Come on, Ben. I mean she’s just doing Margo stuff. Making stories. Rocking worlds.”
vi: I groaned. "Stop it, Ben. Margo is doing things in Margo's style. Weaving stories. Shaking worlds."
tr: “Don't, Ben. I just meant she's doing Margo-like things. Creating stories. Shaking worlds.”
es: I grunted. —Come on, Ben. I mean, he must be doing his own things. Making up stories. Turning the world upside down.

en: That night, I lay on my side, staring out the window into the invisible world outside. I kept trying to fall asleep, but then my eyes would dart open, just to check. I couldn’t help but hope that Margo Roth Spiegelman would return to my window and drag my tired ass through one more night I’d never forget.
vi: That night, I lay on my side, gazing out the window into the invisible world outside. I tried to sleep, but then my eyes would snap open, just to check. I couldn't help but hope that Margo Roth Spiegelman would come back to the window and drag my exhausted self on another unforgettable adventure.
tr: That night, I lay on my side and looked out the window at the invisible world outside. I tried to sleep, but my eyes kept opening... just to check. All I could do was hope that Margo Roth Spiegelman would turn up at my window and drag my tired ass into another night I would never forget.
es: That night I lay on my side in bed and observed the invisible world on the other side of the window. I tried to fall asleep, but my eyes kept opening every so often to check. I couldn't help but hope that Margo Roth Spiegelman would come back to my window and drag my tired ass through another unforgettable night.

tr: Margo used to leave so often that even though there were no Find Margo meetings organized at school, we all felt her absence.

en: Margo left often enough that there weren’t any Find Margo rallies at school or anything, but we all felt her absence. High school is neither a democracy nor a dictatorship—nor, contrary to popular belief, an anarchic state. High school is a divine-right monarchy. And when the queen goes on vacation, things change. Specifically, they get worse. It was during Margo’s trip to Mississippi sophomore year, for example, that Becca had unleashed the Bloody Ben story to the world. And this was no different. The little girl with her finger in the dam had run off. Flooding was inevitable.
vi: Occasionally, Margo would disappear, so there wouldn't be any Find Margo campaigns at school or anything like that, but we all felt her absence. High school is not a democracy or a dictatorship—nor is it a chaotic state as many people mistakenly believe. High school is a monarchy that worships its queen. So when the queen goes on vacation, things immediately go awry. Specifically, everything starts to get chaotic and deteriorate. For instance, during the time Margo was off to Mississippi in tenth grade, Becca leaked the story of Ben the Bloody to the entire world. This time, it would be the same old scenario. The girl who saved the dike with her finger was gone. Flooding was inevitable.
tr: Margo used to leave so often that even though there were no Find Margo meetings organized at school, we all felt her absence. High school is neither a democracy nor a dictatorship... nor an anarchic system contrary to popular belief. High school is a monarchy with a divine right to rule. And when the Queen goes on vacation, things change. To be more specific, things get worse. For example, Becca's Bloody Ben story was unleashed upon the world when Margo went to Mississippi in her sophomore year. Now, the situation was no different. The little girl who had her finger in the dam had fled. A flood was inevitable.
es: Margo escaped so often that in high school no patrols were organized to look for her, but we all felt her absence. High school is neither a democracy nor a dictatorship. Nor, as is often believed, an anarchic state. High school is a monarchy by divine right. And when the queen goes on vacation, things change. Specifically, for the worse. For example, in sophomore year, when Margo was traveling through Mississippi, Becca released the story of Bloody Ben to the world. And this time was no different. The girl who used to plug the holes had left. The flood was inevitable.

en: That morning, I was on time for once and got a ride with Ben. We found everyone unusually quiet outside the band room. “Dude,” our friend Frank said with great seriousness.
vi: That morning, I got to school on time and hitched a ride with Ben. We noticed that everyone was unusually quiet outside the music room. "Hey man," Frank from the group said in a very serious tone.
tr: That morning, for the first time, I left on time and went to school with Ben. Outside the band room, we found everyone unusually quiet. Our friend Frank said with great seriousness, "Dude."
es: That morning, since for once I was punctual, Ben drove me to school. We found everyone strangely silent at the door of the rehearsal room. —Uncle —said our friend Frank very seriously.

en: “What?”
vi: "What's going on?"
tr: “What happened?”
es: —What's happening?

en: “Chuck Parson, Taddy Mac, and Clint Bauer took Clint’s Tahoe and ran over twelve bikes belonging to freshmen and sophomores.”
vi: "Chuck Parson, Taddy Mac, and Clint Bauer got into Clint's Tahoe and ran over twelve bicycles belonging to the ninth and tenth graders."
tr: “Chuck Parson, Taddy Mac, and Clint Bauer took Clint’s Tahoe and ran over twelve bicycles belonging to the first and second graders.”
es: —Chuck Parson, Taddy Mac, and Clint Bauer took Clint's Tahoe and ran over twelve bikes belonging to first and second-year students.

en: “That sucks,” I said, shaking my head.
vi: "Oh my goodness," I shook my head and exclaimed.
tr: “Terrible,” I said, shaking my head.
es: —Don't mess with me —I replied, shaking my head.

en: Our friend Ashley added, “Also, yesterday somebody posted our phone numbers in the boys’ bathroom with—well, with dirty stuff.”
vi: Ashley added, "That's not all, yesterday someone put our phone number on the wall of the men's restroom with... hmm... some very unsanitary comments."
tr: Our friend Ashley added, "Also, yesterday someone wrote our phone numbers in the men's restroom, with some... dirty thing," she added.
es: —And yesterday someone posted our phone numbers in the boys' bathroom with... well, with obscenities —added our friend Ashley.

en: I shook my head again, and then joined the silence. We couldn’t turn them in; we’d tried that plenty in middle school, and it inevitably resulted in more punishment. Usually, we’d just have to wait until someone like Margo reminded everyone what immature jackasses they all were.
vi: I shook my head again and joined the silence with them. We couldn't expose those guys; back in middle school, we had tried many times, and the inevitable consequence was that the punishments for us kept piling up. Usually, we would wait until someone like Margo reminded them of how utterly foolish and stupid they were.
tr: I nodded my head again, then joined the silence. We couldn't complain about them; we had tried many times in middle school and it had inevitably resulted in more punishment. We usually had to rely on someone like Margo to remind everyone how immature fools they were.
es: I shook my head again and I too remained silent. We couldn't report them. We had tried many times before high school, and the inevitable result had been that they bullied us even more. In general, we could only hope that someone like Margo would remind them how immature and idiotic they were.

en: But Margo had given me a way of starting a counteroffensive. And I was just about to say something when, in my peripheral vision, I saw a large individual running toward us at a full sprint. He wore a black ski mask and carried a large, complex green water cannon. As he ran past he tagged me on the shoulder and I lost my footing, landing against the cracked concrete on my left side. As he reached the door, he turned back and shouted toward me, “You screw with us and you’re gonna get smackdown.” The voice was not familiar to me.
vi: But Margo had unveiled to me how to resist those old tricks of bullying the newcomers, the strong preying on the weak. I was about to speak when I suddenly caught sight of a large figure running at full speed towards us. He was wearing a black ski mask and carrying a huge, menacing green water gun. As he rushed past, he bumped into my shoulder, causing me to lose my balance and fall sideways onto the rough concrete. "If you mess with us, you'll get what's coming to you." I couldn't recognize whose voice it was.
tr: Ama Margo had given me a way to initiate a counterattack. I was just about to say something when I saw, out of the corner of my eye, a burly figure running towards us at full speed. He was wearing a black ski mask and carrying a large, green water gun. As he ran past me, he bumped into my shoulder, causing me to lose my balance and fall onto my left side on the cracked concrete. When he reached the door, he turned back and shouted at me: "If you mess with us, you'll face defeat." The voice was not familiar.
es: But Margo had taught me a way to start the counteroffensive. And I was about to say something when I saw out of the corner of my eye a tall guy running towards us. He was wearing a black ski mask and holding a sophisticated green water cannon in his hands. As he passed, he hit me on the shoulder, I lost my balance and landed on my side on the cracked cement. When he reached the door, he turned and shouted at me: —You dedicate yourself to screwing us over, so we're going to impale you. The voice didn't sound familiar to me at all.

en: Ben and another of our friends picked me up. My shoulder hurt, but I didn’t want to rub it. “You okay?” asked Radar.
vi: Ben and another kid from the group helped me stand up. My shoulder ached, but I didn't want to test it. "Are you okay?" Radar asked.
tr: Ben and another friend lifted me up. My shoulder was hurting, but I didn't want to rub it. "Are you okay?" asked Radar.
es: Ben and another friend helped me get up. My shoulder hurt, but I didn't want to rub it. —Are you okay? —Radar asked me.

en: “Yeah, I’m fine.” I rubbed the shoulder now.
vi: “It's okay,” I replied, starting to massage my shoulders.
tr: “Yes, I'm fine.” I was now rubbing my shoulder.
es: —Yes, very well. Then I did rub my shoulder.

en: Radar shook his head. “Someone needs to tell him that while it is possible to get smacked down, and it is also possible to get a smackdown, it is not possible to get ‘smackdown.’” I laughed. Someone nodded toward the parking lot, and I looked up to see two little freshmen guys walking toward us, their T-shirts hanging wet and limp from their narrow frames.
vi: Radar shook his head. "Someone needs to tell that guy that you can get hit, you can also hit, but you can't get hit." I laughed. Someone nodded towards the parking lot, I looked over and saw two ninth graders walking around, their baggy t-shirts wet on their skinny frames.
tr: Radar nodded his head. “Someone needs to tell him that while it is possible to be defeated and even to be made to suffer defeat, it is not possible to 'take' defeat.” I laughed. Someone pointed with their head towards my parking spot, and when I looked up, I saw two first graders walking towards us, their t-shirts clinging wet and limp to their skinny bodies.
es: Radar shook his head. —Someone should explain to him that, although it is possible to give a beating, and also to administer a beating, it is not possible to "beating-ize" anyone. I laughed. Someone pointed to the parking lot, I looked up and saw two first-year kids approaching us with wet and sagging shirts.

en: “It was pee!” one of them shouted at us. The other one didn’t say anything; he just held his hands far away from his T-shirt, which only sort of worked. I could see rivulets of liquid snaking from his sleeve down his arm.
vi: “That’s urine, guys!” one boy shouted at us. The other boy said nothing, just tried to hold his shirt sleeve away, which seemed to help a bit. I saw streaks of liquid snaking down his arm from the sleeve.
tr: One of them shouted at us, "Pee!" The other one didn't say anything; he was just holding his hands away from his t-shirt, but it wasn't doing much good. I saw trickles of liquid winding down from his t-shirt to his arms.
es: —They were pissed! —one of them shouted at us. The other said nothing. He just kept pulling his hands away from the shirt, which didn't quite work. I saw streams running down from the sleeves to his arms.

en: “Was it animal pee or human pee?” someone asked.
vi: “Is this the urine of an animal or a person?” someone asked.
tr: “Was it animal pee, or human pee?” someone asked.
es: —Animal or human urine? —someone asked.

en: “How would I know! What, am I an expert in the study of pee?”
vi: "How would I know! Am I supposed to be a urine expert or something?"
tr: “How should I know! Am I an expert in pee?”
es: —How am I supposed to know! What, am I an expert in piss?

en: I walked over to the kid. I put my hand on the top of his head, the only place that seemed totally dry. “We’ll fix this,” I said. The second bell rang, and Radar and I raced to calc. As I slid into my desk I dinged my arm, and the pain radiated into my shoulder. Radar tapped his notebook, where he’d circled a note: Shoulder okay?
vi: I walked over to the ninth grader, placed my hand on his head, the only spot that seemed completely dry. "We will sort this out," I said. The second bell rang, Radar and I rushed into calculus class. As I slid into my seat, I accidentally hit my elbow, pain shooting up to my shoulder. Radar tapped on his notebook, on the page he had written and circled: How's the shoulder?
tr: I approached the child. I placed my hand on the only part of him that seemed completely dry, the top of his head. “We will fix this,” I said. The second bell rang, and we rushed to math class with Radar. As I took my seat, I cracked my arm and pain spread to my shoulder. Radar tapped his notebook, where he had circled a note: Is your shoulder okay?
es: I approached the boy and placed my hand on his head, which was the only thing that seemed completely dry. —This is not going to stay like this —I told him. The second bell rang and Radar and I ran to calculus class. As I sat down at my desk, I hit my arm, and the pain shot up to my shoulder. Radar pointed to his notebook, where he had written a note surrounded by a circle: "Shoulder OK?".

en: I wrote on the corner of my notebook: Compared to those freshmen, I spent the morning in a field of rainbows frolicking with puppies.
vi: I wrote on the corner of my notebook: Compared to those two new soldiers, I had a morning frolicking with a litter of puppies under the rainbows.
tr: I also wrote in the corner of my notebook: Compared to the first graders, I spent the morning jumping and playing with puppies in a meadow filled with rainbows.
es: I wrote in the corner of my notebook: "Compared to the little kids, I have spent the morning in a field of rainbows playing with little animals."

en: Radar laughed enough for Mr. Jiminez to shoot him a look. I wrote, I have a plan, but we have to figure out who it was.
vi: Radar chuckled softly, enough for Mr. Jiminez to shoot him a glance. I continued writing, I have a plan, but I need to know who the mastermind is first.
tr: Radar laughed just enough for Bay Jiminez to give him a look. I wrote, I have a plan, but we need to figure out who he is.
es: Radar laughed so loudly that Mr. Jiminez gave him a look. I wrote: "I have a plan, but we need to find out who he was."

en: Radar wrote back, Jasper Hanson, and circled it several times. That was a surprise.
vi: Radar rewrote, Jasper Hanson, and circled the name several times. What a surprise.
tr: In response to the radar, Jasper Hanson wrote and circled it several times. This was surprising indeed.
es: Radar wrote "Jasper Hanson" and circled it several times. I was surprised.

en: How do you know?
vi: How did you know?
tr: How do you know?
es: "How do you know?"

en: Radar wrote, You didn’t notice? Dumbass was wearing his own football jersey.
vi: Radar continued, "Don't you recognize him?" "That idiot is always wearing his uniform."
tr: Radar, didn't you notice? That idiot was wearing his own football jersey, he wrote.
es: Radar wrote: "Didn't you see him? The idiot was wearing the football jersey with his name on it."

en: Jasper Hanson was a junior. I’d always thought him harmless, and actually sort of nice—in that bumbling, dude-how’s-it-going kind of way. Not the kind of guy you’d expect to see shooting geysers of pee at freshmen. Honestly, in the governmental bureaucracy of Winter Park High School, Jasper Hanson was like Deputy Assistant Undersecretary of Athletics and Malfeasance. When a guy like that gets promoted to Executive Vice President of Urine Gunning, immediate action must be taken.
vi: Jasper Hanson is in the eleventh grade. I always thought he was harmless, even likable–the kind of kid who says "Hey buddy, what's up?" Not the kind who would dare to spray urine all over the ninth graders. Honestly, in the bureaucratic system of Winter Park High School, Jasper Hanson holds the rank of Assistant Deputy Undersecretary of Sports and Pranks. When a guy like this gets promoted to Vice President in charge of Urinary Tract Weaponry, urgent action is required.
tr: Jasper Hanson was in a grade below us. I had always thought of him as harmless, even somewhat a good person... like those who awkwardly ask "how's it going, buddy". He wasn't the type of kid you'd expect to spray pee on freshmen. In fact, at Winter Park High School's administrative bureaucracy, Jasper Hanson was the Deputy Undersecretary for Athletics and Misconduct. If such a kid is being promoted to Vice President of Pee Spraying, immediate action is necessary.
es: Jasper Hanson was a third-year student. He had always thought he was a quiet and nice guy, one of those slightly clumsy ones who ask you: "Dude, how's it going?". He didn't expect to see him launching geysers of pee at the first-years. Honestly, in the governmental hierarchy of Winter Park High School, Jasper Hanson was like the assistant deputy of Athletics and Illicit Activities. When a guy like that gets promoted to executive vice president of Urinary Armament, you have to take immediate action.

en: 1. $200 in cash should be provided to each of the 12 people whose bikes your colleagues destroyed via Chevy Tahoe. This shouldn’t be a problem, given your magnificent wealth.
vi: 1. 200 dollars in cash need to be given to each of the 12 students whose bicycles were crushed under the wheels of your Chevy Tahoe by you and your classmates. This amount should not be an issue, considering your ample wealth.
tr: Each of the 12 people whose bicycles were destroyed by your coworkers' Chevy Tahoe should be provided with $200 in cash. Considering your magnificent wealth, this should not be an issue.
es: 1. You must give two hundred dollars in cash to each of the twelve people whose bicycles were destroyed by your friends with the Chevy Tahoe. It shouldn't be a problem for you, given your immense wealth.

en: 2. This graffiti situation in the boys’ bathroom has to stop.
vi: 2. The act of writing graffiti in the men's restroom must be stopped.
tr: The graffiti situation in the men's restroom must end.
es: 2. The issue of graffiti in the boys' bathroom must come to an end.

vi: 3. Water guns? Peeing? Really? Come on, guys, be serious.
tr: Water guns? With pee? Really? Grow up a little.
es: 3. Water cannons? With urine? Really? Grow up a little.

vi: 4. You need to behave kindly towards the students in the school, especially those who are less fortunate socially than you.
tr: You should treat your schoolmates with respect, especially those who are less fortunate socially.
es: 4. You should treat your peers with respect, especially those who are socially less fortunate than you.

en: 5. You should probably instruct members of your clan to behave in similarly considerate ways.
vi: 5. You might also need to remind your younger associates to behave in a similarly mature and proper manner.
tr: You should probably instruct the members of your clan to behave similarly thoughtfully.
es: 5. He should probably instruct the members of his clan to behave considerately as well.

en: I realize that it will be very difficult to accomplish some of these tasks. But then again, it will also be very difficult not to share the attached photograph with the world.
vi: I realize that some of the tasks above will be very difficult to complete. But once again, not sharing the attached photo with the whole world is also a very difficult thing to do.

es: I am aware that completing some of these tasks will be very difficult. But in that case, it will also be very difficult not to share the attached photograph with everyone.

en: I understand that you do not control Chuck and Jasper.
