en: But you see, I am in a similar situation. I do not control the little devil sitting on my left shoulder. The devil is saying, “PRINT THE PICTURE PRINT THE PICTURE TAPE IT UP ALL OVER SCHOOL DO IT DO IT DO IT.” And then on my right shoulder, there is a little tiny white angel. And the angel is saying, “Man, I sure as shit hope all those freshmen get their money bright and early on Monday morning.”
vi: But you see, I'm in a similar situation. I don't manage the little devil sitting on my left shoulder. That little devil is screaming, "PRINT THE PICTURES PRINT THE PICTURES POST THEM ALL OVER THE SCHOOL DO IT NOW DO IT NOW DO IT NOW." And then on my right shoulder, there's a tiny white angel, whispering, "Oh my, I have a firm hope as solid as waste that by early Monday morning the new recruits will get their money properly."
tr: But you see, I am in a similar situation. I cannot control the little devil sitting on my left shoulder. The devil says: "PRINT THE PHOTO PRINT THE PHOTO STICK IT EVERYWHERE IN THE SCHOOL DO IT DO IT DO IT." Then on my right shoulder, there is a small, tiny white angel. And the angel says; "My friend, all those first graders' money on Monday" I hope they will pick me up early in the morning."
es: But, you see, I am in a situation similar to yours. I don't control the little devil sitting on my left shoulder. The devil tells me: "PRINT THE PHOTO PRINT THE PHOTO HANG IT ALL OVER THE INSTITUTE DO IT DO IT DO IT." But on my right shoulder, I have a little white angel. And the angel tells me: "Man, I bet those first-year kids get their money first thing Monday morning."

en: So do I, little angel. So do I.
vi: Me too, little angel. I hope so too.
tr: Me too, little angel. Me too.
es: Me too, little angel, me too.

en: Best wishes,
vi: Best wishes,
tr: With my best wishes,
es: My best wishes,

en: Your Friendly Neighborhood Nemesis
vi: Your Friendly Avenger
tr: You Get Your Eternal Enemy Neighbor
es: Your friendly neighbor Nemesis.

en: He did not reply, and he didn’t need to. Everything had been said.
vi: He did not answer, and he did not need to. Everything was laid out clearly.
tr: Jase didn't respond, and he didn't need to. Everything had been said.
es: He didn't answer me, although it wasn't necessary. We had already said everything to each other.

en: Ben came over after dinner and we played Resurrection, pausing every half hour or so to call Radar, who was on a date with Angela. We left him eleven messages, each more annoying and salacious than the last. It was after nine o’clock when the doorbell rang. “Quentin!” my mom shouted. Ben and I figured it was Radar, so we paused the game and walked out into the living room. Chuck Parson and Jason Worthington were standing in my doorway. I walked over to them, and Jason said, “Hey, Quentin,” and I nodded my head. Jason glanced over at Chuck, who looked at me and mumbled, “Sorry, Quentin.”
vi: After dinner, Ben dropped by and we played Resurrection, pausing every half hour to call Radar, who was on a date with Angela. We sent Radar eleven messages, each one more suggestive and provocative than the last. Past nine in the evening, the doorbell rang. “Quentin!” my mom called. Ben and I guessed that Radar had arrived, so we took a break from the game and went to the living room together. Chuck Parson and Jason Worthington were standing at my doorstep. I approached, and Jason said, “Hi, Quentin,” to which I nodded. Jason glanced at Chuck, and he looked at me, mumbling, “Sorry, Quentin.”
tr: After dinner, Ben came over, and we played Resurrection, pausing about every half hour to call Radar, who was out on a date with Angela. We left eleven messages, each more annoying and obscene than the last. When the doorbell rang, it was past nine o'clock. My mom shouted, "Quentin!" Thinking it was Radar, we paused the game and went to the living room. Standing at my door were Chuck Parson and Jason Worthington. I approached them, and Jason said, "Hey, Quentin," to which I nodded in greeting. Jason glanced at Chuck, who muttered, "Sorry, Quentin," while looking at me.
es: Ben stopped by my house after dinner and we were playing Resurrection, pausing roughly every half hour to call Radar, who had gone out with Angela. We left him eleven messages, each one more impertinent and lascivious than the previous. It was past nine when the doorbell rang. —Quentin! —shouted my mother. Ben and I assumed it was Radar, so we paused the game and went out to the dining room. Chuck Parson and Jason Worthington were at the entrance. I approached them. —Hello, Quentin —said Jason. I greeted him with a nod. Jason glanced at Chuck, who looked at me and murmured: —Sorry, Quentin.

en: “For what?” I asked.
vi: “For what reason?” I asked.
tr: "Why?" I asked.
es: —Why? —I asked him.

en: “For telling Jasper to piss-gun those freshmen,” he mumbled. He paused, and then said, “And the bikes.”
vi: “Because I urged Jasper to shoot the water gun at the ninth graders,” he continued to mumble, pausing before finishing, “And because of the bikes.”
tr: “Because I told Jasper to squirt pee at the first graders,” he muttered. He paused and then said, “And also for the bikes.”
es: —For telling Jasper to shoot pee at the first-year kids —he murmured. He paused and continued—: And for the bikes.

en: Ben opened his arms, as if to hug. “C’mere, bro,” he said.
vi: Ben stretched out his arms as if wanting to hug, "Brother, come here," he said.
tr: He opened his arms as if to hug. "Come here, brother," he said.
es: Ben opened his arms, as if he were going to hug him. —Come here, buddy —he said to him.

en: “What?”
vi: "What?"
tr: “What?”
es: —What?

en: “C’mere,” he said again. Chuck stepped forward. “Closer,” Ben said. Chuck was standing fully in the entryway now, maybe a foot from Ben. Out of nowhere, Ben slammed a punch into Chuck’s gut. Chuck barely flinched, but he immediately reared back to clobber Ben. Jase grabbed his arm, though. “Chill, bro,” Jase said. “It’s not like it hurt.” Jase reached out his hand, to shake. “I like your guts, bro,” he said. “I mean, you’re an asshole. But still.” I shook his hand.
vi: “Come here,” it repeated. Chuck stepped forward, “Closer,” Ben said. Chuck was now completely inside my house, about a foot away from Ben. Suddenly, Ben punched Chuck in the stomach. Chuck wasn't hurt at all, but he immediately stepped back to get ready to hit Ben. However, Jase held his hand. “Calm down, man,” Jase said. “Doesn't seem like it hurt.” Jase extended his hand for a shake, “I like your resilience, buddy,” he said. “You're a pain, but I like you.” I shook Jase's hand.
tr: "Come here," he said again. Chuck took a step forward. "Closer," said Ben. Chuck was now standing completely in the entrance, about half a meter away from Ben. Suddenly, Ben punched Chuck in the stomach. Chuck didn't even flinch but immediately moved to retaliate against Ben. Luckily, Jase grabbed his arm caught. “Calm down, brother,” he said. “It didn't even hurt.” Jase extended his hand for a handshake. “I like your courage, brother,” he said. “I mean, you're a total ass. But still.” I shook his hand.
es: —That you come —he repeated to her. Chuck took a step forward. —Closer —said Ben. Chuck advanced to the entrance, a step ahead of Ben. And suddenly, Ben punched him in the stomach. Chuck barely flinched. He took a step back to hit Ben, but Jase grabbed him by the arm. —Calm down, buddy —Jase told him—. It didn't hurt that much either. He extended his hand for me to shake it. —I like that you have guts, mate. Well, you're an asshole. But it doesn't matter. I shook his hand.

en: They left then, getting into Jase’s Lexus and backing down the driveway. As soon as I closed the front door, Ben let out a mighty groan. “Ahhhhhhhggg. Oh, sweet Lord Jesus, my hand.” He attempted to make a fist and winced. “I think Chuck Parson had a textbook strapped to his stomach.”
vi: Then those two guys left in Jase's Lexus, reversing down the road. I had just closed the front door when Ben let out a stream of groans, "Ahhhhhhhhggg." "Oh sweet Lord, my hand." He tried to clench his hand and his face twisted as if it were torn. "Chuck Parson must have shielded himself with a thick textbook."
tr: Then they got into Jase's Lexus and reversed down the driveway. As soon as the front door closed, Ben let out a scream. “Ahhhhhhh. Oh, dear God, my hand.” He tried to clench his fist and winced. “I think Chuck Parson had stuck a textbook to his stomach.”
es: They got into Jase's Lexus, backed up, and drove away. As soon as I closed the door, Ben let out a loud roar. —Ayyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy. Damn, my hand. —Ben tried to close his fist and grimaced in pain—. I think Chuck Parson had put a book in his stomach.

en: “Those are called abs,” I told him.
vi: "That's called abdominal muscles, sir," I said.
tr: “They are called karm muscles,” I said.
es: —They are called sit-ups —I explained to him.

en: “Oh, yeah. I’ve heard of those.” I clapped him on the back and we headed back to the bedroom to play Resurrection. We’d just unpaused it when Ben said, “By the way, did you notice that Jase says ‘bro’? I’ve totally brought bro back. Just with the sheer force of my own awesomeness.”
vi: “Oh, right. I've heard about it too.” I patted its back and we both went back to my room to play Resurrection. We had just started playing again when Ben said, “Hey, did you hear Jase say 'comrade'? I decline that comrade title. Only with the impulse from my own magic.”
tr: “Ah, yes. I had heard something about them.” I patted him lightly on the back and we headed back to the bedroom to play Resurrection again. We had just restarted the game when Ben said, “By the way, did you notice that Jase called me ‘brother’? I brought back the word brother. Just by the sheer power of my own magnificence.”
es: —Yes, of course. I've heard of them. I gave him a pat on the back and we went back to the room to continue playing Resurrection. We had just taken off the pause when Ben said: —By the way, have you noticed that Jase says "mate"? I've brought it back into fashion. And only with the power of my brilliance.

en: “Yeah, you’re spending Friday night gaming and nursing the hand you broke while trying to sucker punch somebody. No wonder Jase Worthington has chosen to hitch his star to your wagon.”
vi: “Yeah, on Friday night he played video games and bandaged his ruined hand because he foolishly thought he could land a single punch to someone's stomach. No wonder Jase Worthington had to humbly lower himself before him.”
tr: “Yes, you spend your Friday night playing games and rubbing the hand you broke while trying to throw an unexpected punch at someone. No wonder Jason Worthington looks up to you as an example to rise.”
es: —Yes, you spend Friday night playing and nursing your hand, which you broke trying to punch a guy. No wonder Jase Worthington has decided to cozy up to your tree.

en: “At least I’m good at Resurrection,” he said, whereupon he shot me in the back even though we were playing in team mode.
vi: "When all is said and done, I am a Resurrection superstar," Ben said, immediately shooting me in the back even though we were playing in team mode.
tr: “At least I'm good at Resurrection,” he said, and immediately after, despite us being a team, he shot me in the back.
es: —At least I'm good at Resurrection —he told me. And he shot me in the back, even though we were playing as a team.

en: We played for a while longer, until Ben just curled onto the floor, holding the controller up to his chest, and went to sleep. I was tired, too—it had been a long day. I figured Margo would be back by Monday anyway, but even so, I felt a little pride at having been the person who stemmed the tide of lame.
vi: We played for a while longer, until Ben curled up on the floor, clutching the game controller to his chest, and fell fast asleep. I was tired too—it had been a long day. I was sure Margo would be back by Monday, but even so, I felt a bit proud of being the one to hold back the tide of monotony.
tr: We played for a while longer, until Ben, with the gamepad on his chest, curled up on the floor and fell asleep. I was tired too... it had been a long day. I thought Margo would have returned by Monday anyway, but I still felt a bit proud of being the one who prevented the boredom.
es: We played a little longer, until Ben curled up on the floor, with the controller pressed to his chest, and fell asleep. I was tired too. It had been a long day. I assumed that Margo would be back on Monday, but even so, I felt a bit proud of having been the person who had stopped the storm.

tr: I thought Margo would have returned by Monday anyway, but I still felt a bit proud of being the one who prevented the boredom.

en: Every morning, I now looked up through my bedroom window to check whether there was any sign of life in Margo’s room. She always kept her rattan shades closed, but since she’d left, her mom or somebody had pulled them up, so I could see a little snippet of blue wall and white ceiling. On that Saturday morning, with her only forty-eight hours gone, I figured she wouldn’t be home yet, but even so, I felt a flicker of disappointment when I saw the shade still pulled up.
vi: Now every morning when I wake up, I look out the window of my room to see if there are any signs that someone is in Margo's room. She usually lowers the bamboo blinds, but since Margo hasn't been home, her mother or someone else has pulled the blinds up, so I can see a patch of blue wall and a white ceiling. That Saturday morning, Margo had only been missing for forty-eight hours, so I guessed she probably wouldn't be back right away. Even so, I still felt a bit of disappointment when I saw the neatly rolled-up bamboo blinds.
tr: Now, every morning, I would look out of my window to check if there was any sign of life in Margo's room. She always kept her bamboo blinds closed, but after she left, her mother or someone else had opened them, so I could see a small piece of the blue wall and the white ceiling. That Saturday morning, forty-eight hours after she had left, I had calculated that she had not yet returned home, but still felt a twinge of disappointment when I saw that the blinds were still open.
es: Every morning I looked out the window of my room to check if there was any sign of life in Margo's room. She always had the wicker blinds down, but since she had left, her mother or someone else in the house had raised them, so I could see a bit of blue wall and white ceiling. That Saturday morning, since it had only been forty-eight hours since she had run away, I assumed she still wouldn't be home, but I still felt a bit disappointed to see that the blind was still up.

en: I brushed my teeth and then, after briefly kicking at Ben in an attempt to wake him, walked out in shorts and a T-shirt. Five people were seated at the dining room table. My mom and dad. Margo’s mom and dad. And a tall, stout African-American man with oversize glasses wearing a gray suit, holding a manila folder.
vi: After kicking Ben a few times and he still wouldn't get up, I brushed my teeth, put on shorts and a t-shirt, and left the room. There were five people sitting at the dining table. My parents. Margo's parents. And a tall, well-built African man, wearing large glasses, a gray suit, and holding a briefcase.
tr: I brushed my teeth, then after kicking Ben briefly to wake him up, I left the room wearing shorts and a t-shirt. There were five people at the dining table. My mom, my dad. Margo's mom and dad. And a tall, burly, black man with oversized glasses, wearing a gray suit, holding a cardboard file.
es: I brushed my teeth and then, after giving Ben a few little kicks to try to wake him up, I went out in shorts and a t-shirt. There were five people sitting at the dining table: my parents, Margo's parents, and a tall, burly African American man with huge glasses, a gray suit, and a brown folder in his hands.

en: “Uh, hi,” I said.
vi: “Oh, hello everyone,” I said.
tr: "Uh, hi," I said.
es: —Oh, hi —I said.

en: “Quentin,” my mom asked, “did you see Margo on Wednesday night?”
vi: "Quentin," my mom asked me, "did you see your friend Margo on Wednesday night?"
tr: “Quentin,” my mom said, “did you see Margo on Wednesday night?”
es: —Quentin, did you see Margo on Wednesday night? —my mother asked me.

en: I walked into the dining room and leaned against the wall, standing opposite the stranger. I’d thought of my answer to this question already. “Yeah,” I said. “She showed up at my window at like midnight and we talked for a minute and then Mr. Spiegelman caught her and she went back to her house.”
vi: I went straight into the dining room and stood leaning against the wall, facing the strange guest. I had already planned how to answer this question. "Yes," I replied. "Around midnight, he stood by my window, we talked for about a minute, then Mr. Spiegelman called and he went home."
tr: I walked into the dining room and leaned against the wall, standing in front of the stranger. I had already thought about my answer to this question. “Yes,” I said. “She appeared at my window around midnight, we talked for a minute, then Mr. Spiegelman caught her and Margo went back home.”
es: I entered the dining room and leaned against the wall, facing the stranger. I already had the answer to that question thought out. —Yes —I answered him—. She appeared at my window around twelve, we talked for a minute and then Mr. Spiegelman caught her and she had to go back home.

en: “And was that—? Did you see her after that?” Mr. Spiegelman asked. He seemed quite calm.
vi: “Is that all? Did you see him again after that?” Uncle Spiegelman asked, looking quite calm.
tr: “And this... Did you see her after that?” asked Mr. Spiegelman. He seemed quite calm.
es: —And that was...? Have you seen her since? —Mr. Spiegelman asked me. He seemed quite calm.

en: “No, why?” I asked.
vi: "No." "What's the matter?" I asked.
tr: “No, why?” I asked.
es: —No, why? —I asked.

en: Margo’s mom answered, her voice shrill. “Well,” she said, “it seems that Margo has run away. Again.” She sighed. “This would be—what is it, Josh, the fourth time?”
vi: Margo's mother answered. “It looks like she has run away from home.” “Once again.” She sighed. “This is–how many times now, Josh, the fourth time, right?”
tr: Margo's mother answered in a high-pitched voice. "Well," she said, "it looks like Margo ran away from home. Again." She sighed. "How many times is this, Josh... the fourth time?"
es: —Well —Margo's mother replied in a sharp tone—, it looks like Margo has run away. Again. —She sighed—. This must be… how many times now, Josh? Four?

en: “Oh, I’ve lost count,” her dad answered, annoyed.
vi: “Oh, there are too many to remember,” Margo's dad replied grumpily.
tr: “Ah, I forgot my number,” his father replied angrily.
es: —Ugh, I've lost count —replied her husband, annoyed.

en: The African-American man spoke up then. “Fifth time you’ve filed a report.” The man nodded at me and said, “Detective Otis Warren.”
vi: Then the man of color spoke up. “This is the fifth time you have reported.” He nodded to me and said, “I am Detective Otis Warren.”
tr: At that point, the black man intervened. “You are reporting five times.” The man nodded towards me and said, “Detective Otis Warren.”
es: Then the African American intervened. —The fifth time they have filed a complaint. —He greeted me with a nod and said—: Detective Otis Warren.

en: “Quentin Jacobsen,” I said.
vi: "I am Quentin Jacobsen," I introduced myself.
tr: "Quentin Jacobsen," I said.
es: —Quentin Jacobsen —I said.

en: Mom stood up and put her hands on Mrs. Spiegelman’s shoulders. “Debbie,” she said, “I’m so sorry. It’s a very frustrating situation.” I knew this trick. It was a psychology trick called empathic listening. You say what the person is feeling so they feel understood. Mom does it to me all the time.
vi: Mom stood up and placed her hands on Ms. Spiegelman's shoulders. "Debbie," she said, "I'm so sorry. This must be so exhausting for you." I knew my mom's trick all too well. It's a technique in psychology called empathetic listening and understanding. You articulate the feelings of the person you're talking to so that they feel heard. Mom uses this trick on me all the time.
tr: Mom stood up and put her hands on Mrs. Spiegelman's shoulders. “Debbie,” she said, “I’m very sorry. It’s a very frustrating situation.” I knew this trick. It was a psychology trick called empathetic listening. You say what the person is feeling so they think they are understood. Mom used to do this to me all the time.
es: My mother stood up and placed her hands on Mrs. Spiegelman's shoulders. —Debbie —he said—, I'm very sorry. It's a very frustrating situation. I knew that trick. It was a psychological trick called empathetic listening. You say what the person is feeling so that they feel understood. My mother does it with me all the time.

en: “I’m not frustrated,” Mrs. Spiegelman answered. “I’m done.”
vi: “I am not tired or exhausted at all,” Ms. Spiegelman replied. “I am really fed up.”
tr: “I’m not upset,” replied Mrs. Spiegelman. “I’m just tired of it.”
es: —I am not frustrated —Mrs. Spiegelman replied to him—. It's over.

en: “That’s right,” Mr. Spiegelman said. “We’ve got a locksmith coming this afternoon. We’re changing the locks. She’s eighteen. I mean, the detective has just said there’s nothing we can do—”
vi: “That's right,” Mr. Spiegelman agreed. “We have an appointment with the locksmith this afternoon. We will change all the locks. He's eighteen now. The detective also just said that we can't do anything–”
tr: “Right,” said Mr. Spiegelman. “A locksmith will come this afternoon. We are changing the locks. Margo is eighteen years old. So, the detective just said there’s nothing we can do...”
es: —Exactly —said Mr. Spiegelman—. This afternoon a locksmith will come. We will change the locks. He is eighteen years old. Anyway, the detective just told us that we can't do anything...

en: “Well,” Detective Warren interrupted, “I didn’t quite say that. I said that she’s not a missing minor, and so she has the right to leave home.”
vi: “Ahem,” Detective Warren interrupted, “I didn't exactly say that. I said that Margo is not a missing minor, meaning she has the right to leave home.”
tr: "Well," Detective Warren interrupted, "I didn't say it exactly like that. I said that since she is not a minor, she has the right to leave home."
es: —Well —Detective Warren interrupted him—, I didn't say that exactly. I said that she is not a minor, so she has the right to leave home.

en: Mr. Spiegelman continued talking to my mom. “We’re happy to pay for her to go to college, but we can’t support this . . . this silliness. Connie, she’s eighteen! And still so self-centered! She needs to see some consequences.”
vi: Uncle Spiegelman continued talking to my mother. "My wife and I are willing to pay for her to go to college, but we cannot tolerate... such foolishness." "Connie, my daughter is eighteen years old! And yet she is still selfish and does whatever she wants!" "She needs to experience some consequences."
tr: Mr. Spiegelman continued talking with my mother. “We will, of course, cover the university expenses, but this... we cannot support this foolishness. Connie, she is eighteen years old! And still very selfish! She needs to see the consequences of this.”
es: Mr. Spiegelman continued talking with my mother. —We are okay with paying for her college, but we are not going to tolerate these… these foolishness. Connie, she is eighteen years old! And she is still self-centered! She needs to see the consequences.

en: My mom removed her hands from Mrs. Spiegelman. “I would argue she needs to see loving consequences,” my mom said.
vi: My mother lifted her hand off Ms. Spiegelman's shoulder. "I think the girl needs to experience the consequences of loving affection," my mother said.
tr: My mother withdrew her hands from Mrs. Spiegelman. "I would argue that it should yield loving results," my mother said.
es: My mother removed her hands from Mrs. Spiegelman's shoulders. —I would say that the consequences to consider are those of affection —my mother told him.

en: “Well, she’s not your daughter, Connie. She hasn’t walked all over you like a doormat for a decade. We’ve got another child to think about.”
vi: "Oh Connie, it's not your child. It hasn't visited you in almost ten years. My family still has another one to take care of."
tr: "She is not your daughter, Connie. She hasn't been trampling over you like a doormat for ten years. We have another child to think about."
es: —Well, she's not your daughter, Connie. She hasn't been walking all over you like a doormat for ten years. We have to think about our other daughter.

en: “And ourselves,” Mr. Spiegelman added. He looked up at me then. “Quentin, I’m sorry if she tried to drag you into her little game. You can imagine how . . . just how embarrassing this is for us. You’re such a good boy, and she . . . well.”
vi: “And us too,” Uncle Spiegelman added, then turned to me. “Quentin, I'm sorry if Margo has dragged you into her nonsense. Do you understand... how embarrassed we are about this. You are a serious boy, and she... oh.”
tr: “And also ourselves,” added Mr. Spiegelman. Then he looked at me. “Quentin, I'm sorry if he tried to drag you into his little game. You can imagine how... how embarrassing this is for us. You are a very good kid, but he is... a thing.”
es: —And in us —added Mr. Spiegelman. He looked up at me—. Quentin, I'm sorry she tried to involve you in her little game. You can imagine how... how embarrassed we are. You're a good boy, and she... Well.

en: I pushed myself off the wall and stood up straight. I knew Margo’s parents a little, but I’d never seen them act so bitchy. No wonder she was annoyed with them Wednesday night. I glanced over at the detective. He was flipping through pages in the folder. “She’s been known to leave a bit of a bread crumb trail; is that right?”
vi: I no longer lean against the wall but stand upright. I have a vague understanding of Margo's parents, but I have never seen them behave so poorly. No wonder Margo was angry with her parents on Wednesday night. I glance at the inspector, who is flipping through the pages of the file. "Margo has always left some breadcrumbs as a sign, hasn't she?"
tr: I pushed myself off the wall and stood up straight. I knew Margo's parents a little, but I had never seen them act so viciously. It was no wonder Margo was mad at them on Wednesday night. I glanced at the detective. He was flipping through the pages of the file. “She is known to leave trails of breadcrumbs, correct?” “Clues,” said Mr. Spiegelman, now standing.
es: I separated myself from the wall and stood up, very stiff. I knew Margo's parents a little, but I had never seen them act with such bad temper. It didn't surprise me that she was angry with them on Wednesday night. I looked at the detective. He was flipping through the pages of the folder. —He has always left some trace, hasn't he?

en: “Clues,” Mr. Spiegelman said, standing up now. The detective had placed the folder on the table, and Margo’s dad leaned forward to look at it with him. “Clues everywhere. The day she ran away to Mississippi, she ate alphabet soup and left exactly four letters in her soup bowl: An M, an I, an S, and a P. She was disappointed when we didn’t piece it together, although as I told her when she finally returned: ‘How can we find you when all we know is Mississippi? It’s a big state, Margo!’”
vi: “The clues,” Mr. Spiegelman said, standing up. The detective placed the file on the table, and Margo's father leaned in to look at it. “Clues are everywhere. On the day she left for Mississippi, she ate alphabet soup and left exactly four letters in the bowl: M, I, S, and P. She was disappointed when we didn't put those letters together, even though when she finally came home, I said: ‘How could we find you knowing only Mississippi? Margo, that's a huge state!’”
tr: “She is known to leave trails of breadcrumbs, correct?” “Clues,” said Mr. Spiegelman, now standing. The detective had placed the file on the table, and Margo's father leaned forward to look at it with him. “Clues everywhere. The day she ran away to Mississippi, she had a soup made of letter-shaped noodles and left exactly four letters in the soup bowl: An M, an I, an S, and a P. She was disappointed when we couldn't piece it together, but when she finally returned, I told her: How can we find you when all we know is Mississippi? It's a big state, Margo!”
es: —he said. —Clues —Mr. Spiegelman replied, standing up. The detective left the folder on the table, and Margo's father leaned in to take a look. —Clues everywhere. The day she left for Mississippi, she ate alphabet soup and left exactly four letters in the bowl: an M, an I, an S, and a P. She was disappointed because we couldn't put them together, although, as I told her when she finally returned: "How are we supposed to find you if all we know is 'Mississippi'? It's a big state, Margo."

en: The detective cleared his throat. “And she left Minnie Mouse on her bed when she spent a night inside Disney World.”
vi: The inspector cleared his throat. "And Margo left the Minnie Mouse plush toy on the bed when she stayed a night at Disney World."
tr: The detective cleared his throat. “And when he spent a night inside Disney World, he left Minnie Mouse in his bed.”
es: The detective cleared his throat. —And he left Minnie Mouse on his bed when he sneaked into Disney World one night.

en: “Yes,” her mom said. “The clues. The stupid clues. But you can never follow them anywhere, trust me.”
vi: “That's right,” Margo's mother said. “The clues. The stupid clues. The clues that lead nowhere, trust me.”
tr: “Yes,” said her mother. “Clues. Stupid clues. But you can never follow them, believe me.”
es: —Yes —said his mother—. Clues. Stupid clues. But you can never follow them, believe me.

en: The detective looked up from his notebook. “We’ll get the word out, of course, but she can’t be compelled to come home; you shouldn’t necessarily expect her back under your roof in the near future.”
vi: The detective looked up from his notebook and spoke. “Of course, we will get to the bottom of this, but we can't force Margo to come back right away. For now, you shouldn't expect her to return home.”
tr: The detective lifted his head from his notebook. "We will spread the news, of course, but he cannot be forced to come home; you should not expect him to be under your roof again in the near future."
es: The detective lifted his eyes from the folder. —We will spread the word, of course, but we cannot force her to return home in any way. You should not necessarily count on her coming back under your roof in the immediate future.

en: “I don’t want her under our roof.” Mrs. Spiegelman raised a tissue to her eyes, although I heard no crying in her voice. “I know that’s terrible, but it’s true.”
vi: “I don't want to see her face at home anymore.” Ms. Spiegelman lifted a tissue to dab at her eyes, but I didn't hear any sobbing in her voice. “I know it's terrible, but it's true.”
tr: “I don't want him under our roof.” Mrs. Spiegelman brought a handkerchief to her eye, yet her voice didn't sound like she was crying at all. “I know it's terrible, but it's the truth.”
es: —I don't want her under our roof. —Mrs. Spiegelman brought a handkerchief to her eyes, although she didn't seem to be crying—. I know it's terrible, but it's the truth.

en: “Deb,” my mom said in her therapist voice.
vi: "Sister Deb," my mother said in a therapist's voice.
tr: “Deb,” said my mom in a therapist's voice.
es: —Deb —said my mother in her psychologist tone.

en: Mrs. Spiegelman just shook her head—the smallest shake. “What can we do? We told the detective. We filed a report. She’s an adult, Connie.”
vi: Ms. Spiegelman just shook her head—the slightest shake. "What could my husband and I do? We reported it to the detective. We made a report. She's grown up now, Connie."
tr: Bayan Spiegelman just nodded... A very small nod. “What can we do? We told the detective. We filed a missing person report. She's an adult, Connie.”
es: Mrs. Spiegelman merely nodded slightly. —What can we do? We have told the detective. We have filed a report. She is an adult, Connie.

en: “She’s your adult,” my mom said, still calm.
vi: “It is your eldest child,” my mother said, still keeping a calm voice.
tr: "He is your grown-up," said my mother, still calmly.
es: —She is your adult daughter —said my mother, still calm.

en: “Oh, come on, Connie. Look, is it sick that it’s a blessing to have her out of the house? Of course it’s sick. But she was a sickness in this family! How do you look for someone who announces she won’t be found, who always leaves clues that lead nowhere, who runs away constantly? You can’t!”
vi: “Oh, come on Connie. You see, if we consider Margo leaving home a blessing, is that so bad? Of course, it's bad. But Margo is a disease in my house! How can you find someone who declares that no one will find them, someone who always leaves clues that lead nowhere, someone who runs away from home at the slightest provocation? You can't find that!”
tr: “Oh, don't do it, Connie. Is it a disease to consider leaving him outside the house a favor? Of course, it's diseased. But he is a disease in this family! How do you search for someone who declares they won't be found, always leaves clues that lead nowhere, and constantly runs away from home? You can't search!”
es: —Let's go, Connie. Isn't it crazy that we're delighted she left home? Of course it's crazy. But she was driving the whole family crazy. How do you look for someone who insists they won't be found, who always leaves clues that lead nowhere, who escapes every now and then? It's impossible!

en: My mom and dad shared a glance, and then the detective spoke to me. “Son, I’m wondering if we can chat privately?” I nodded. We ended up in my parents’ bedroom, he in an easy chair and me sitting on the corner of their bed.
vi: My parents glanced at each other, then the detective spoke to me. “Son, can we talk privately for a bit?” I nodded. The detective and I went into my parents' room, he sat on a folding chair while I sat on the edge of the bed.
tr: My mom and dad exchanged glances, then the detective spoke to me. "Kid, can we talk in private?" I nodded in agreement. We found ourselves in my parents' room, he settled into a comfortable chair, and I sat on the edge of the bed.
es: My mother and my father looked at each other, and then the detective turned to me. —Son, I wonder if we could talk in private. I nodded. We went into my parents' room. He sat in an armchair and I sat on the edge of the bed.

en: “Kid,” he said once he’d settled into the chair, “let me give you some advice: never work for the government. Because when you work for the government, you work for the people. And when you work for the people, you have to interact with the people, even the Spiegelmans.” I laughed a little.
vi: "My child," he said as he sat comfortably in the chair, "let me give you this advice: never work for the government. Because when you work for the government, you have to serve the people. And when you serve the people, you have to interact with others, even people like the Spiegelman couple." I smiled slightly.
tr: “Child,” he said as soon as he sat down, “let me give you some advice: Never work for the government. Because when you work for the government, you work for the people. And when you work for the people, you have to interact with people, even with the Spiegelmans.” I laughed a little.
es: —Boy —he said to me once he had settled into the armchair—, allow me to give you some advice: never work for the government. Because when you work for the government, you work for the people. And when you work for the people, you have to interact with them, even with the Spiegelmans. I let out a giggle.

en: “Let me be frank with you, kid. Those people know how to parent like I know how to diet. I’ve worked with them before, and I don’t like them. I don’t care if you tell her parents where she is, but I’d appreciate it if you told me.”
vi: “Let me be frank with you. That couple knows how to be parents just as much as I know how to diet. I've dealt with them before, and I don't like either of them. I don't care if you tell Margo's parents where she went or not, but I would appreciate it if you let me know.”
tr: “Let me be honest with you, kid. These people know how to be parents as much as I know how to diet. I’ve worked with them before and I didn’t like them. I don’t care if you tell Margo’s parents where she is, but I’d be grateful if you tell me.”
es: —Allow me to be honest with you, kid —he continued saying to me—. These people know as much about being parents as I do about dieting. I've worked with them before and I don't like them. I don't care if you don't tell Margo's parents where she is, but I would appreciate it if you told me.

en: “I don’t know,” I said. “I really don’t.”
vi: "I don't know," I replied. "I really don't know, sir."
tr: "I don't know," I said. "Really."
es: —I don't know —I replied—. Honestly, I don't know.

en: “Kid, I’ve been thinking about this girl. This stuff she does— she breaks into Disney World, for instance, right? She goes to Mississippi and leaves alphabet soup clues. She organizes a huge campaign to toilet paper houses.”
vi: "Son, I've been thinking a lot about this girl Margo." "The things she does—like breaking into Disney World, right? She goes to Mississippi and leaves clues in a bowl of soup." "She organizes a large-scale campaign to cover houses with toilet paper."
tr: “Son, I was thinking about this girl. The things she does... She sneaks into Disney World, for example, right? She goes to Mississippi and leaves clues in her soup with letters. She organizes a big campaign to toilet paper houses.”
es: —Boy, I've been thinking about the girl. What she does... She sneaks into Disney World, for example, right? She goes to Mississippi and leaves clues with alphabet soup. She organizes a big campaign to toilet paper houses.

en: “How do you know about that?” Two years before, Margo had led the TP-ing of two hundred houses in a single night. Needless to say, I wasn’t invited on that adventure.
vi: "How did you know about that?" Two years ago, Margo had orchestrated a mission to cover two hundred houses with toilet paper in just one night. Needless to say, I wasn't invited to join in on the fun.
tr: "How do you know this?" Two years ago, Margo had led an overnight toilet paper attack on two hundred houses. Needless to say, I had not been invited to this adventure.
es: —How do you know? Two years ago, Margo had led the wallpapering of two hundred houses in a single night. It goes without saying that she didn't invite me to participate in that adventure.

en: “I worked this case before. So, kid, here’s where I need your help: who plans this stuff? These crazy schemes? She’s the mouthpiece for it all, the one crazy enough to do everything. But who plans it? Who’s sitting around with notebooks full of diagrams figuring out how much toilet paper you need to toilet paper a ton of houses?”
vi: “I have been following that case.” “So, my boy, this is where I need your help: who planned all of this?” “These crazy coordinated attacks?” “That girl Margo is the spokesperson for all of it, the one crazy enough to do it all.” “But who calculated the plan?” “Who sat amidst the messy diagrams, figuring out how much toilet paper was needed to cover so many houses?”
tr: “I had previously been involved in this event. So, kid, the point where I need your help is this: Who is planning these things? These crazy projects. Margo is the spokesperson for all of them, capable of doing everything The person who is crazy. But who is planning? Who is filling notebooks with diagrams showing how much toilet paper is needed to attack a ton of houses?”
es: —I have worked on this case before. So, kid, I need you to help me. Who plans these things? These crazy projects? She is the spokesperson for all of this, the only one crazy enough to do it. But who plans it? Who sits with notebooks full of diagrams to calculate how much toilet paper is needed to wallpaper a bunch of houses?

en: “It’s all her, I assume.”
vi: "I guess they are all Margo."
tr: “I think it's all Margo's doing.”
es: —I suppose her.

en: “But she might have a partner, somebody helpin’ her do all these big and brilliant things, and maybe the person who’s in on her secret isn’t the obvious person, isn’t her best friend or her boyfriend. Maybe it’s somebody you wouldn’t think of right off,” he said. He took a breath and was about to say something more when I cut him off.
vi: “But surely the girl must have an accomplice, someone helping her carry out all these grand and daring things, and maybe that hidden person is not someone everyone knows, not Margo's best friend or boyfriend. It could be someone you wouldn't immediately think of.” He took a breath, about to continue, when I interrupted him.
tr: “But he might have a partner, someone who helps him do all these great and clever things and maybe shares his secret; someone who is not obviously in the picture, not his best friend or boyfriend. Maybe someone who wouldn't immediately come to mind,” he said. He took a breath, he was about to say something more when I interrupted him.
es: —But she must have a partner, someone who helps her do all these outrageous and brilliant things. And maybe the person who shares her secret is not the most obvious one, not her best friend or her boyfriend. Maybe it's someone you would never think of —he told me. The detective took a breath and was about to say something else when I interrupted him.

en: “I don’t know where she is,” I said. “I swear to God.”
vi: "I don't know where Margo is," I said. "I swear to God."
tr: “I don't know where she is,” I said. “I swear.” “I'm just checking, kid.
es: —I don't know where it is. I swear to God.

en: “Just checking, kid. Anyway, you know something, don’t you? So let’s start there.” I told him everything. I trusted the guy. He took a few notes while I talked, but nothing very detailed. And something about telling him, and his scribbling in the notebook, and her parents being so lame—something about all of it made the possibility of her being lastingly missing well up in me for the first time. I felt the worry start to snatch at my breath when I finished talking. The detective didn’t say anything for a while. He just leaned forward in the chair and stared past me until he’d seen whatever he was waiting to see, and then he started talking.
vi: "Just consider it carefully." "Anyway, you know something, don't you?" "So let's start from there." So I told him everything. I trusted this man. He took a few notes while I spoke, but nothing too detailed. And there was something in telling him, in the brief notes on the page, in the weariness of Margo's parents—something in all of it made me feel for the first time a gnawing sensation that Margo might be missing for a long time. Anxiety seemed to choke my breath as I stopped speaking. The detective was silent for a moment. He just leaned out of his chair, staring intently over my shoulder until he saw something he had been waiting to see, then he began to speak.
tr: “I swear.” “I'm just checking, kid. Anyway, you know something, don't you? Then let's start from there.” I told him everything. I had trusted the man. He took a few notes while I was talking, but none of them were very detailed. And telling the man, his scribbling in the notebook, the badness of her parents... Made me feel, for the first time, the possibility that Margo might really be missing. When I finished talking, I felt my breath starting to catch from worry. The detective didn't say anything for a while. He just leaned forward in the chair and looked past me until he saw whatever he was expecting to see, then he started to speak.
es: —I just wanted to make sure, boy. Anyway, you know something, right? Let's start from there. I told him everything. I trusted that guy. He took some notes while I talked, though without too many details. But in telling him, and seeing him scribbling in the notebook, and realizing the stupidity of Margo's parents... for the first time, I considered the possibility that she might have disappeared for a long time. When I finished talking, I was so worried that I started to run out of breath. The detective didn't say anything for a while. He leaned forward and looked into the distance until he found what he was looking for, and then he started to speak.

en: “Listen, kid. This is what happens: somebody—girl usually— got a free spirit, doesn’t get on too good with her parents. These kids, they’re like tied-down helium balloons. They strain against the string and strain against it, and then something happens, and that string gets cut, and they just float away. And maybe you never see the balloon again. It lands in Canada or somethin’, gets work at a restaurant, and before the balloon even notices, it’s been pouring coffee in that same diner to the same sad bastards for thirty years. Or maybe three or four years from now, or three or four days from now, the prevailing winds take the balloon back home, because it needs money, or it sobered up, or it misses its kid brother. But listen, kid, that string gets cut all the time.”
vi: “Listen, son. This is how it goes: someone—usually a girl—has a free spirit and doesn't really get along with her parents. Those kids, they're like helium-filled balloons tied down. They rise up and want to break free from the string, and then something happens, the string snaps, and they drift away. You might never see that balloon again. It lands in Canada or somewhere, gets a job in a restaurant. And before the balloon realizes it, it's been serving coffee in that dingy café to those boring customers for thirty years. Or maybe in a few years, or a few days, strong winds bring the balloon back home because it needs money, or because it aches, it misses its little brother at home. But listen, the string keeps snapping all the time.”
tr: “Listen, kid. It usually goes like this: Typically, a girl is a free spirit and doesn't get along too well with her parents. These kids are like helium-filled balloons tied down. They struggle against the string, struggle and struggle, then something happens, the string breaks, and at that moment, they fly away. Maybe you'll never see the balloon again. It might land in Canada or somewhere, find a job in a restaurant, and before the balloon even realizes it, it's been serving coffee to the same gloomy drifters in the same diner for thirty years. Or maybe three or four years later, or three or four days later, the wind brings the balloon back home because either it needs money, has come to its senses, or misses its brother. But listen, kid, that string always breaks.”
es: —Look, kid. Here's the thing: someone with a free spirit, usually a girl, doesn't get along too well with her parents. These kids are like helium balloons tied down. They pull on the string over and over again, until finally the string breaks and they fly away. And maybe you'll never see that balloon again, because it lands in Canada or wherever, finds a job in a restaurant, and before the balloon realizes it, it's been thirty years in the same café serving coffee to the same sons of bitches. Or maybe in three or four years, or in three or four days, the prevailing winds bring the balloon back home, because it needs money, or because it has changed its mind, or because it misses its little brother. But, look, kid, the string keeps breaking.

en: “Yeah, bu—”
vi: “Yes, like–”
tr: “Yes, but...”
es: —Yes, bu…

en: “I’m not finished, kid. The thing about these balloons is that there are so goddamned many of them. The sky is choked full of them, rubbing up against one another as they float to here or from there, and every one of those damned balloons ends up on my desk one way or another, and after a while a man can get discouraged. Everywhere the balloons, and each of them with a mother or a father, or God forbid both, and after a while, you can’t even see ’em individually. You look up at all the balloons in the sky and you can see all of the balloons, but you cannot see any one balloon.” He paused then, and inhaled sharply, as if he was realizing something. “But then every now and again you talk to some big-eyed kid with too much hair for his head and you want to lie to him because he seems like a good kid. And you feel bad for this kid, because the only thing worse than the skyful of balloons you see is what he sees: a clear blue day interrupted by just the one balloon. But once that string gets cut, kid, you can’t uncut it. Do you get what I’m saying?”
vi: "I haven't finished speaking yet, son. The problem with balloons is that there are too many of them. The sky is crowded with balloons, they rub against each other as they drift from place to place, and each one of those damn balloons somehow ends up on my desk, and if this keeps happening, a man can get discouraged. Balloons everywhere, each with a mother or a father, or heaven forbid, both, and it keeps happening until you can't see each one anymore. You look up at the balloons in the sky, you see all those balloons, but you can't see each one clearly." He paused, taking a deep breath, as if realizing something. "But then, from there, anytime, when talking to some wide-eyed, tousle-haired kid, you don't want to tell him the truth because he looks like a good kid. And you suddenly feel sorry for the boy, because the only thing worse than the sky full of balloons you see is what the boy sees: a clear day broken by a single balloon. But son, once the string is cut, you can't reverse that. Do you understand what I've just said?"
tr: “I'm not done yet, kid. The thing about these balloons is that there are really a lot of them. The sky is crammed full of them, they bump into each other as they float around, and every single one of these damn balloons somehow ends up on my desk, and after a while, you get tired of it. Balloons everywhere, each one has a mother or a father or, God forbid, both, and after a while, you can't see them individually anymore. You look at all the balloons in the sky and you can see all of them, but you can never see just one balloon.” He paused then and took a deep breath, as if he had realized something. “But then, once in a while, you talk to a kid with too much hair for his head and big eyes, and you want to lie to him, because he looks like a good kid. Then you feel bad for that kid because the only thing worse than the balloon-filled sky you see is what he sees: A clear, blue sky interrupted by just one balloon. But once the string is broken, you can't take it back, kid. Do you understand what I'm saying?”
es: —I'm not finished, kid. The problem with these damn balloons is that there are so many of them. The sky is full of balloons flying from one side to the other and colliding with each other, and each and every one of these damn balloons ends up on my desk for one reason or another, and over time you get discouraged. Balloons everywhere, each one with a father or a mother, or if you're lucky, with both, and in the end, you can't even see them individually. You look up at the balloons in the sky and see them as a whole, but you no longer see them one by one. —He fell silent and took a deep breath, as if he had just realized something—. But every now and then you talk to a kid with big eyes and too much hair on his head, and you want to lie to him because he seems like a good kid. And you feel sorry for him, because the only thing worse than the sky full of balloons you see is what he sees: a clear blue day with a single balloon. But when the string breaks, kid, you can't glue it back together. Do you understand what I'm trying to tell you?

en: I nodded, although I wasn’t sure I did understand. He stood up. “I do think she’ll be back soon, kid. If that helps.”
vi: I nodded, though I wasn't sure I understood. He stood up. “I think the girl will be back soon, son. If saying it like that makes you feel better.”
tr: I nodded my head up and down, though I wasn't quite sure I understood. He stood up. "I think he'll be back soon, son. If it will help.""
es: I nodded, although I wasn't sure I had understood. He stood up. —I think he will return soon, boy. For what it's worth.

en: I liked the image of Margo as a balloon, but I figured that in his urge for the poetic, the detective had seen more worry in me than the pang I’d actually felt. I knew she’d be back. She’d deflate and float back to Jefferson Park. She always had.
vi: I like to imagine Margo as a balloon, but it seems that in the midst of the poetic surge just now, the detective saw through to a lot of worries within me, even more than the impulses I was actually feeling. I know Margo will come back. She will deflate and drift back to Jefferson Park. She always does.
tr: I liked imagining Margo as a balloon, but while the detective approached the matter poetically, I thought he saw worry in me rather than the sudden pang I actually felt. I knew Margo would come back. She would deflate and float back towards Jefferson Park. She had always done so.
es: I liked the image of Margo as a balloon, but I thought that, in his desire to be poetic, the detective had seen me as much more worried than I actually was. I knew she would come back. She would deflate and fly back to Jefferson Park. She had always come back.

en: I followed the detective back to the dining room, and then he said he wanted to go back over to the Spiegelmans’ house and pick through her room a little. Mrs. Spiegelman gave me a hug and said, “You’ve always been such a good boy; I’m sorry she ever got you caught up in this ridiculousness.” Mr. Spiegelman shook my hand, and they left. As soon as the door closed, my dad said, “Wow.”
vi: I followed the detective back to the dining room, then he said he wanted to go to the Spiegelman house and take a look at Margo's room. Ms. Spiegelman hugged me and said, "You've always been a serious young man, I'm sorry that Margo dragged you into this ridiculous game." Mr. Spiegelman shook my hand, then they left. As soon as the door closed, my dad exclaimed, "Oh!"
tr: I followed the detective back to the dining room, then he said he wanted to return to the Spiegelmans' house and examine Margo's room a bit. Mrs. Spiegelman hugged me and said, "You have always been a very good child; I'm sorry if he dragged you into this nonsense." Mr. Spiegelman shook my hand and they left. As soon as the door closed, my father said, "Wow."
es: I returned to the dining room with the detective, who said he wanted to go back to the Spiegelman house to take a look in Margo's room. Mrs. Spiegelman hugged me. "You have always been a good boy," he told me. "I'm sorry that you have to get mixed up in these ridiculous things." Mr. Spiegelman shook my hand and they left. As soon as the door was closed, my father said:

en: “Wow,” agreed Mom.
vi: "Oh!" my mother responded.
tr: “Wow,” my mom chimed in.
es: —Wow. —Wow —confirmed my mother.

en: My dad put his arm around me. “Those are some very troubling dynamics, eh, bud?”
vi: Dad put his arm around my shoulder. "Those were some very troublesome impulses just now, weren't they, my boy?"
tr: My father wrapped his arm around me. “These are very disturbing actions, aren't they buddy?”
es: My father put his arm around my shoulders. —They have opted for a dynamic that only creates problems, haven't they?

en: “They’re kind of assholes,” I said. My parents always liked it when I cursed in front of them. I could see the pleasure of it in their faces. It signified that I trusted them, that I was myself in front of them. But even so, they seemed sad.
vi: "That couple stinks to high heaven," I said. My parents always found it amusing when I grumbled and cursed in front of them. I immediately saw the look of satisfaction on the faces of my creators. Openly cursing like that was a signal that I trusted my parents, that I was revealing myself in front of them. Even though that was indeed the case, my parents still looked somewhat sad.
tr: “They look like idiots,” I said. My parents liked it when I swore in front of them. I could see from their expressions that they were pleased by this. This showed that I trusted them, that I was being myself in front of them. But despite this, they looked sad.
es: —They are idiots —I told him. My parents liked it when I said swear words in front of them. I saw the pleasure on their faces. It meant that I trusted them, that I was myself in front of them. But, even so, they seemed sad.

en: “Margo’s parents suffer a severe narcissistic injury whenever she acts out,” Dad said to me.
vi: "Margo's parents must have been deeply hurt in their pride when she behaved like that," Dad told me.
tr: “Whenever Margo does something mischievous, her mother and father suffer the pain of a serious narcissistic wound,” said my father.
es: —Margo's parents suffer a serious blow to their narcissism every time their daughter misbehaves —my father told me.

en: “It prevents them from parenting effectively,” my mom added.
vi: "That makes them unable to be effective parents," my mother added.
tr: “This also prevents them from parenting effectively,” my mother added.
es: —And that prevents them from behaving as effective parents —added my mother.

en: “They’re assholes,” I repeated.
vi: “They stink,” I repeated.
tr: “They are really assholes,” I repeated.
es: —They are idiots —I repeated.

en: “Honestly,” my dad said, “they’re probably right. She probably is in need of attention. And God knows, I would need attention, too, if I had those two for parents.”
vi: “To be honest,” Dad continued, “maybe they have a point. Maybe Margo needs everyone to pay attention to her. And God knows, I would need everyone to pay attention to me if those two were my parents.”
tr: “If you ask me,” said my father, “they're probably right. Margo is most likely in need of attention. And God knows, if these two were my parents, I would need attention too.”
es: —To be honest —said my father—, they are probably right. Margo probably needs attention. And God knows I would need attention too if those two were my parents.

en: “When she comes back,” my mom said, “she’s going to be devastated. To be abandoned like that! Shut out when you most need to be loved.”
vi: “When Margo comes back,” mother said, “she will be exhausted. Being abandoned like that! Being pushed away when she needed love the most.”
tr: “When Margo returns,” said my mother, “she will be devastated. To be abandoned like this!.. To be left out when she needs to be loved the most...”
es: —When she comes back, she will be devastated —commented my mother—. To be abandoned like that… Rejected when you need affection the most.

en: “Maybe she could live here when she comes back,” I said, and in saying it I realized what a fantastically great idea it was. My mom’s eyes lit up, too, but then she saw something in my dad’s expression and answered me in her usual measured way.
vi: "When you come back, maybe Margo should just stay here," I said, and as I uttered those words, I realized it was indeed a brilliant idea. My mother raised her eyebrows slightly, but she immediately read something on my father's face, so she responded to me in her usual measured tone.
tr: “Maybe she can live here when she arrives,” I said, and as I spoke, I realized what a wonderful idea it was. My mother's eyes lit up too, but then she saw something in my father's expression and responded to me with her usual measured demeanor.
es: —Maybe I could live here when I come back —I said. And when I said it, I realized that it was an absolutely brilliant idea. My mother's eyes also sparkled, but then she saw something in my father's expression and replied to me with her usual restraint.

en: “Well, she’d certainly be welcome, although that would come with its own challenges—being next door to the Spiegelmans. But when she returns to school, please do tell her that she’s welcome here, and that if she doesn’t want to stay with us, there are many resources available to her that we’re happy to discuss.”
vi: “Um, we certainly welcome Margo, though it is somewhat awkward—we are neighbors with the Spiegelmans. But when Margo returns to school, tell her that we welcome her to come here. If Margo doesn't want to stay at our house, there are still plenty of other suitable places we can comfortably consider.”
tr: “Well, she can come if she wants, but there are some issues with this situation... Like being next to the Spiegelmans. But when she returns to school, please tell her that we invited her here and that if she doesn't want to stay with us, we would be happy to discuss many other options.”
es: —Well, it would certainly be welcome, although it would have its inconveniences…: living next to the Spiegelmans. But when she returns to the institute, please tell her that she is welcome here, and if she doesn't want to stay with us, there are many other solutions we would love to discuss with her.

en: Ben came out then, his bedhead seeming to challenge our basic understanding of the force gravity exerts upon matter. “Mr. and Mrs. Jacobsen—always a pleasure.”
vi: At that moment, Ben walked out, his messy hair defying all basic understanding of gravity's effect on matter. "Hello Mr. and Mrs. Jacobsen—always a pleasure to see you."
tr: At that moment, Ben arrived, his hair in a state that seemed to defy our understanding of gravity, as if he had just gotten out of bed. “Mr. and Mrs. Jacobsen... it's so nice to see you.”
es: At that moment, Ben appeared with his hair so tangled that it seemed to defy our basic understanding of the effect of gravity on matter. —Mr. and Mrs. Jacobsen, delighted to see you, as always.

en: “Good morning, Ben. I wasn’t aware you were staying the night.”
vi: "Hello, Ben. We didn't know you were staying overnight."
tr: "Good morning, Ben. I didn't realize you stayed the night."
es: —Good morning, Ben. I didn't know you had stayed the night.

en: “Neither was I, actually,” he said. “What’s wrong?”
vi: "Actually, I don't know why either," Ben said. "What just happened?"
tr: "I wasn't either, actually," he said. "Is there a problem?"
es: —The truth is that I don't either —said Ben—. Is something wrong?

en: I told Ben about the detective and the Spiegelmans and Margo being technically a missing adult. And when I had finished, he nodded and said, “We should probably discuss this over a piping hot plate of Resurrection.” I smiled and followed him back to my room. Radar came over shortly thereafter, and as soon as he arrived, I was kicked off the team, because we were facing a difficult mission and despite being the only one of us who actually owned the game, I wasn’t very good at Resurrection. As I watched them tramp through a ghoul-infested space station, Ben said, “Goblin, Radar, goblin.”
vi: I told Ben about the detective and the Spiegelman couple, and that technically, Margo was a missing adult. When I finished, Ben nodded and said, “We should discuss this over a hot plate of Resurrection.” I laughed and followed him back to my room. Not long after, Radar arrived, and right then I was kicked off the team, because we were playing a difficult part, and despite the fact that I was the only one among the three of us who owned the game, my Resurrection skills were just average. And then I went back and started from the A’s.

en: But I was distracted by Margo’s music collection. She liked everything. I could never have imagined her listening to all these old records. I’d seen her listening to music while running, but I’d never suspected this kind of obsession. I’d never heard of most of the bands, and I was surprised to learn that vinyl records were even being produced for the newer ones.

en: I kept going through the A’s and then the B’s—making my way through the Beatles and the Blind Boys of Alabama and Blondie—and I started to rifle through them more quickly, so quickly that I didn’t even see the back cover of Billy Bragg’s Mermaid Avenue until I was looking at the Buzzcocks. I stopped, went back, and pulled out the Billy Bragg record. The front was a photograph of urban row houses. But on the back, Woody Guthrie was staring at me, a cigarette hanging out of his lips, holding a guitar that said THIS MACHINE KILLS FASCISTS.
vi: I walked from A to B–through the Beatles, Blind Boys of Alabama, and Blondie–I started to skim faster, so fast that it seemed I didn't look at the back cover of Billy Bragg's Mermaid Avenue until I glanced at the Buzzcocks. I stopped, turned back, and pulled out the Billy Bragg record. The front cover showed a row of identical storefront buildings. But on the back, Woody Guthrie stared at me, a cigar dangling from his lips, with a guitar that had the words THIS MACHINE KILLS FASCISTS.
tr: I continued to review the A’s, then moved on to the B’s. After passing by the Beatles, Blind Boys of Alabama, and Blondie, I started to skim faster, too fast to see the back cover of Billy Bragg’s Mermaid Avenue until I got to the Buzzcocks. I stopped, went back, and pulled out the Billy Bragg record. There was a photo of rows of houses in a city on the front. But on the back, Woody Guthrie was looking at me, a cigarette dangling from his lips, holding a guitar that said THIS MACHINE KILLS FASCISTS.
es: I kept moving through A, then through B —making my way between the Beatles, the Blind Boys of Alabama, and Blondie—, and I started to browse them faster, so fast that I didn't even notice the back cover of Mermaid Avenue by Billy Bragg until I was looking at the Buzzcocks. I stopped, went back, and took out the Billy Bragg record. The cover was a photograph of terraced houses in a city. But on the other side, Woody Guthrie was staring at me, with a cigarette between his lips and a guitar that said: THIS MACHINE KILLS FASCISTS.

es: Unfortunately, what was inside was just a record. And the record looked exactly like a record. I put it on Margo's turntable and eventually figured out how to turn it on and place the needle. It was a guy singing Woody Guthrie songs. He sang better than him.

Not bad, actually.

"Walt Whitman’s Niece" was the first on side B. It wasn't bad, actually.

en: “Can you please keep watch for your mom for us?” I asked. She nodded and left. I closed the door.

en: “What’s up?” I asked Radar. He motioned us over to the computer. “In the week before she left, Margo was on Omnictionary a bunch. I can tell from minutes logged by her username, which she stored in her passwords. But she erased her browsing history, so I can’t tell what she was looking at.”
vi: “What is it?” I asked Radar. He waved us over to the computer. “In the week before she left, Margo spent quite a bit of time on Omnictionary. I know because of the number of minutes logged in under Margo's name, and she had saved the password on the computer. But Margo deleted all her search history, so we can't know what information she was looking for.”

I know this from the minutes she was connected with her username, which has been saved in her passwords. But she deleted her browsing history, so I don't know what she was looking for.

en: Radar stood up. “It really seems like she’s drawing a pretty straight line; there’s gotta be something in that book. It’s weird, though—I mean, no offense, but if she always left clues for her parents, why would she leave them for you this time?”

es: Radar stood up. —The truth is that it seems he has drawn a perfectly straight line. There must be something in that book. But it seems strange to me… Well, no offense, but if he has always left clues for his parents, why would he leave them for you this time?

en: I shrugged my shoulders. I didn’t know the answer, but of course I had my hopes: maybe Margo needed to see my confidence. Maybe this time she wanted to be found, and to be found by me. Maybe—just as she had chosen me on the longest night, she had chosen me again. And maybe untold riches awaited he who found her.
vi: I shrugged. I didn't have an answer, but of course, I held onto hope: maybe Margo wanted to see my confidence. Maybe this time she wanted to be found, and found by me. Maybe—just like she chose me on that longest night, this time she chose me again. And maybe the secret treasure is waiting for someone to find her.
tr: I shrugged. I didn't know the answer, but of course, I had hopes: Maybe Margo needed to see my trust. Maybe this time she wanted to be found by me. Maybe... just as she chose me on that long night, she had chosen me again. And maybe unknown treasures awaited the person who found her.
es: I shrugged. I couldn't answer him, although of course I harbored hopes: maybe Margo wanted to see that I trusted myself. Maybe this time she wanted to be found, for me to find her. Maybe... just as she had chosen me for the longest night, she had chosen me again. And maybe incalculable riches awaited the one who found her.

I read a little from the introduction and then paged through the book.
