tr: If you fail to bring me back the first time, protect your courage,
es: If you don't find me at first, don't lose heart,

en: Missing me one place search another,
vi: If you lose my trace here, search for me elsewhere.
tr: If you miss me somewhere, look for me elsewhere,
es: if I am not in one place, you will find me in another,

en: I stop some where waiting for you
vi: Somewhere, I will stop and wait for you.
tr: I am standing somewhere, waiting for you
es: somewhere I wait for you.

en: It became a weekend of reading, of trying to see her in the fragments of the poem she’d left for me. I could never get anywhere with the lines, but I kept thinking about them anyway, because I didn’t want to disappoint her. She wanted me to play out the string, to find the place where she had stopped and was waiting for me, to follow the bread crumb trail until it dead-ended into her.
vi: All weekend I just read, trying to find Margo in the pieces of poetry she left for me. Maybe the lines of poetry wouldn't lead me anywhere, but I thought about them anyway, because I didn't want to disappoint Margo. She wanted me to follow the thread, find where she had stopped and waited for me, follow the trail of breadcrumbs until it ended at Margo.
tr: The weekend was spent reading, trying to see her in the fragments of poetry she left behind for me. I wasn't getting anywhere with the verses, but I kept thinking about them because I didn't want to disappoint her. She wanted me to pull all the strings, find the place where she was waiting for me, and follow the traces she left from the breadcrumb trails until there was no other way out but her.
es: I spent the weekend reading, trying to see her in the fragments of the poem she had left me. I wasn't getting anywhere with those lines, but I kept thinking about them because I didn't want to disappoint her. Margo wanted me to follow the thread, to find the place where she was waiting for me, to follow her trail until I reached her.

tr: An extraordinary event occurred on Monday morning.

en: Monday morning, an extraordinary event occurred. I was late, which was normal; and then my mom dropped me off at school, which was normal; and then I stood outside talking with everyone for a while, which was normal; and then Ben and I headed inside, which was normal. But as soon as we swung open the steel door, Ben’s face became a mix of excitement and panic, like he’d just been picked out of a crowd by a magician for the get-sawn-in-half trick. I followed his gaze down the hall.
vi: Monday morning, an unusual event occurred. I was late for school, which was normal; my mom dropped me off at school, which was normal; I stood outside chatting with other kids, which was normal; then Ben and I went inside, which was also normal. But as soon as he pushed open the metal door, Ben's face turned into a chaotic mix of excitement and terror, as if a magician had just picked him out of the crowd to assist in a saw-through-the-body trick. Following Ben's gaze, I looked down the hallway.
tr: An extraordinary event occurred on Monday morning. I was late, that was normal; then my mom dropped me off at school, that was normal; then I stood outside for a while talking to everyone, that was normal; then Ben and Radar headed inside, that was also normal. But as soon as we pulled open the steel door, Ben's face took on a mixture of panic and excitement... as if a magician had just picked him out of the crowd to perform a sawing-in-half trick. I followed his gaze down the corridor.
es: On Monday morning, an extraordinary event occurred. I was running late, which was normal, so my mother drove me to school, which was also normal. I stayed outside chatting for a while with everyone, which was normal, and then Ben and I went inside, which was also normal. But as soon as we pushed the steel door, Ben's face turned into a mix of nerves and panic, as if a magician had just chosen him to perform the trick of sawing him in half. I followed his gaze down the hallway.

en: Denim miniskirt. Tight white T-shirt. Scooped neck. Extraordinarily olive skin. Legs that make you care about legs. Perfectly coiffed curly brown hair. A laminated button reading ME FOR PROM QUEEN. Lacey Pemberton. Walking toward us. By the band room.
vi: Short denim skirt. Tight white t-shirt. Bare neck. Beautifully tanned skin. Legs that make people dream of legs. Perfect wavy brown hair. A shiny badge with the words CHOOSE ME AS PROM QUEEN. Lacey Pemberton. Walking towards us. Right next to the music room.
tr: Denim mini skirt. Tight white t-shirt. Low neckline. Unusually tan skin. Legs that make you notice legs. Perfectly styled curly, brown hair. A badge that says PROM QUEEN AS ME. Lacey Pemberton. She was walking towards us. Next to the band room.
es: Denim miniskirt. Tight white t-shirt. Generous neckline. Extraordinarily olive skin. Legs that sparked your interest in legs. Perfectly styled curly brown hair. A button that said VOTE ME FOR PROM QUEEN. Lacey Pemberton. Approaching us by the rehearsal room.

en: “Lacey Pemberton,” Ben whispered, even though she was about three steps from us and could clearly hear him, and in fact flashed a faux-bashful smile upon hearing her name.
vi: "Lacey Pemberton," Ben whispered, even though she was only three steps away from us and could clearly hear those words. In fact, a fake smile briefly appeared on Lacey's lips when she heard her name mentioned.
tr: "Lacey Pemberton," Ben whispered, even though Lacey was only about three steps away from us and could clearly hear him, and indeed, upon hearing her name, a fake smile quickly appeared and disappeared on her face.
es: —Lacey Pemberton —whispered Ben, even though the girl was about three steps away from us and could perfectly hear him. And, in fact, she flashed a falsely shy smile upon hearing her name.

en: “Quentin,” she said to me, and more than anything else, I found it impossible that she knew my name. She motioned with her head, and I followed her past the band room, over to a bank of lockers. Ben kept pace with me.
vi: "Quentin," Lacey said to me, and above all, the fact that Lacey knew my name was an impossibility. She nodded her head to signal, and I followed Lacey through the music room, to the front of the row of personal lockers. Ben followed closely behind me.
tr: “Quentin,” she said to me, and first of all, I found it incredible that she knew my name. She nodded and I followed her past the band room towards the lockers. She matched my pace.
es: —Quentin —he said to me. What seemed most incredible to me was that she knew my name. She made a gesture with her head and I crossed the rehearsal room behind her until we reached a block of lockers. Ben stayed by my side.

en: “Hi, Lacey,” I said once she stopped walking. I could smell her perfume, and I remembered the smell of it in her SUV, remembered the crunch of the catfish as Margo and I slammed her seat down.
vi: "Hello Lacey," I said when she had stopped. I smelled Lacey's perfume, and I still remembered this scent in her SUV, remembered the crackling sound from the catfish when Margo and I pressed the car seat against it.
tr: "Hi, Lacey," I said when she stopped. I could smell her perfume, and I remembered the scent from her car, just like with Margo Like I remember the sound the catfish made when we lowered your chair to the ground.
es: —Hello, Lacey —I greeted when she stopped. As her perfume reached me, I remembered that smell in her SUV and the crunch of the catfish while Margo and I lowered the seat.

en: “I hear you were with Margo.”
vi: "I heard you went with Margo."
tr: “I heard you were with Margo.”
es: —They told me you were with Margo.

en: I just looked at her.
vi: I just looked at Lacey.
tr: I just looked at her.
es: I limited myself to looking at her.

en: “That night, with the fish? In my car? And in Becca’s closet? And through Jase’s window?”
vi: “That night, and the fish? In my car? In Becca's room? And through Jase's window?”
tr: “That night, you know, during the fish incident? In my car? And in Becca’s closet? At Jase’s window?”
es: —The other night, with the fish. In my car. And in Becca's closet. And at Jase's window.

en: I kept looking. I wasn’t sure what to say. A man can live a long and adventurous life without ever being spoken to by Lacey Pemberton, and when that rare opportunity does arise, one does not wish to misspeak. So Ben spoke for me. “Yeah, they hung out,” Ben said, as if Margo and I were tight.
vi: I kept looking. I didn't know what to say. One can live a long life full of adventurous exploits without recounting it to Lacey Pemberton, but when that rare opportunity suddenly arises, one wouldn't want to speak carelessly. So Ben spoke up for me, “Yeah, it's those two.” Ben spoke as if Margo and I were very close.
tr: I kept looking. I wasn't sure what to say; one could live a long and adventurous life without ever talking to Lacey Pemberton, and when faced with this rare opportunity, you wouldn't want to misrepresent yourself. So Ben spoke for me. "Yeah, they're hooked," he said, as if we were tight with Margo.
es: I kept looking at her. I didn't know what to say. One can have a long and adventurous life without Lacey Pemberton ever having spoken a word to them, but when that rare occasion arises, one does not want to say the wrong thing. So Ben spoke for me. —Yes, they went out together —said Ben, as if Margo and I were close.

en: “Was she mad at me?” Lacey asked after a moment. She was looking down; I could see her brown eye shadow.
vi: "Is Margo really mad at me?" Lacey asked after a while. She lowered her eyes, and I could see her thick brown eyelashes.
tr: “Was he angry with me?” Lacey asked shortly after. She was looking down; I could see her brown eye shadow.
es: —Was she angry with me? —asked Lacey a little later. She was looking at the ground. I saw her brown eye shadow.

en: “What?”
vi: "What?"
tr: “What?”
es: —What?

en: She spoke quietly then, the tiniest crack in her voice, and all at once Lacey Pemberton was not Lacey Pemberton. She was just—like, a person. “Was she, you know, pissed at me about something?”
vi: At that moment, Lacey spoke very softly, with tiny cracks in her voice, and immediately Lacey Pemberton was no longer Lacey Pemberton. She was just–like, an ordinary person. "You know, do you have any idea why Margo is so mad at me?"
tr: Then she spoke quietly, her voice cracked a little, and suddenly it was as if Lacey Pemberton was not Lacey Pemberton. She was a complete... human being. “Was she, you know, angry about something?”
es: Then she spoke very slowly, with a slightly broken voice, and suddenly Lacey Pemberton was no longer Lacey Pemberton. She was just... a person. —You know, if she was mad at me for something.

en: I thought about how to answer that for a while. “Uh, she was a little disappointed that you didn’t tell her about Jase and Becca, but you know Margo. She’ll get over it.”
vi: For a moment, I thought about how to respond properly. "Well, Margo was a bit disappointed that you didn't tell her about Jase and Becca, but you know how Margo is. She'll get over it."
tr: I thought for a while about how to answer this. “Oh, she was a bit disappointed that you didn't tell her anything about Jase and Becca, but you know Margo. She'll get over it.”
es: I thought for a second about what to answer. —Well, she was a bit disappointed because you hadn't told her about Jase and Becca, but you know Margo. She'll get over it.

en: Lacey started walking down the hall. Ben and I let her go, but then she slowed down. She wanted us to walk with her. Ben nudged me, and then we started walking together. “I didn’t even know about Jase and Becca. That’s the thing. God, I hope I can explain that to her soon. For a while, I was really worried that maybe she had like really left, but then I went into her locker ’cause I know her combination and she still has all her pictures up and everything, and all her books are stacked there.”
vi: Lacey started walking down the hallway. Ben and I let her go, but then Lacey slowed down. She wanted us to go with her. Ben gently nudged me, and we went together. “I don't know anything about Jase and Becca. That's the problem. God, I hope I can explain to Margo soon. Sometimes I'm really afraid that maybe Margo has left for good, but I checked her locker because I know her combination, and I saw all her pictures, books, everything still there.”
tr: Lacey started to move down the corridor. We allowed her to go with Ben, but then she slowed down. She wanted us to walk with her. Ben nudged me with his elbow and we started walking together. “I didn’t even know Jase and Becca. That’s the point. God, I hope I can explain this to her soon. For a while, I was worried she might really be gone, but then I checked her locker, because I know the combination, and all her pictures and stuff are still there, all her books piled up.”
es: Lacey started walking down the hallway. Ben and I let her go, but suddenly she slowed down. She wanted us to go with her. Ben gave me a little push and we started walking together. —The problem is that I didn't even know about Jase and Becca —said Lacey—. I hope I can explain it to her soon. For a moment I was worried that she really wanted to leave, but then I opened her locker, because I know her combination, and all her photos and everything else are still there, the books too.

en: “That’s good,” I said.
vi: "That's good," I said.
tr: “That’s good,” I said.
es: —Good sign —I replied to him.

en: “Yeah, but it’s been like four days. That’s almost a record for her. And you know, this has really sucked, because Craig knew, and I was so pissed at him for not telling me that I broke up with him, and now I’m out a prom date, and my best friend is off wherever, in New York or whatever, thinking I did something I would NEVER do.” I shot a look to Ben. Ben shot a look back to me.
vi: “Yeah, but it's been about four days already. That's almost a record for Margo. And you know what, there's this really annoying thing, because Craig knew about Jase and Becca, and I'm mad at him for not telling me, so I broke up with him. Now I've ruined my prom plans, my best friend is off somewhere only God knows, maybe New York or anywhere, still mad at me for something I NEVER did.” I squinted at Ben. Ben squinted back at me.
tr: “Yes, but it has been about four days. This is almost a record for him. And this is really a terrible situation because Craig knew, and I was so mad at him for not telling me that I broke up with him and "Now I don't have a ball escort, and my best friend is somewhere, in New York or something, thinking that I did something I would NEVER do." I glanced at Ben. Ben glanced at me too.
es: —Yes, but it's already been four days. It's almost a record for her. And well, it's crap, because Craig knew it, and I got so mad because he didn't tell me that I broke up with him, and now I don't have a date for the dance, and my best friend has taken off who knows where, to New York or some other place, thinking I did something I would NEVER do. I glanced at Ben, and Ben glanced at me.

en: “I have to run to class,” I said. “But why do you say she’s in New York?”
vi: “I have to go to class,” I said. “But why did you say Margo is in New York?”
tr: “I need to get to class,” I said. “But why do you say it's in New York?”
es: —I have to run to class —I told him—. Why did you say he is in New York?

en: “I guess she told Jase like two days before she left that New York was the only place in America where a person could actually live a halfway livable life. Maybe she was just saying it. I don’t know.”
vi: “It seems that two days before leaving, Margo told Jase that New York is the only place in America where one can truly live a halfway decent life. Maybe she was just speaking offhandedly. I don't know.”
tr: “I think he told Jase, like two days before he left, that New York is the only place in America where a person can really live a decent life. Maybe he was just saying it. I don't know.”
es: —I think two days before leaving, he told Jase that New York was the only place in the country where one could live a halfway decent life. Maybe he said it just to say something. I don't know.

en: “Okay, I gotta run,” I said.
vi: “Alright, I have to run,” I said.
tr: “Okay, I have to go,” I said.
es: —Okay, I'm running off —I told him.

en: I knew Ben would never convince Lacey to go to prom with him, but I figured he at least deserved the opportunity. I jogged through the halls toward my locker, rubbing Radar’s head as I ran past him. He was talking to Angela and a freshman girl in band. “Don’t thank me. Thank Q,” I heard him say to the freshman, and she called out, “Thank you for my two hundred dollars!” Without looking back I shouted, “Don’t thank me, thank Margo Roth Spiegelman!” because of course she’d given me the tools I needed.
vi: I know it's hard for Ben to invite Lacey to the prom, but at least he deserves a chance. I walked briskly down the hallway towards my locker, reaching out to ruffle Radar's hair as I passed by him. He was talking to Angela and a ninth-grade girl who also played in the band. "Don't thank me. Thank Q," I heard Radar say to the girl, and she exclaimed, "Thank you for the two hundred dollars!" Without looking back, I shouted, "Don't thank me, thank Margo Roth Spiegelman!" because of course she had given me the tool I needed.
tr: I knew that Ben could never convince Lacey to go to the prom with him, but I thought he at least deserved a chance. As I was running through the corridors towards my locker, I patted Radar on the head as I passed by him. He was talking to Angela and a freshman girl from the band. To the freshman girl, he said, “Don’t thank me. Thank Q,” I heard him say, and then the girl shouted, “Thanks for the two hundred dollars!” Without looking back, I shouted, “Don’t thank me, thank Margo Roth Spiegelman!” after all, she was the one who gave me the tools I needed.
es: I knew that Ben would never convince Lacey to go to the dance with him, but I thought he at least deserved a chance. I ran through the hallways to my locker and as I passed by Radar, I gave him a tap on the head. Radar was talking to Angela and a freshman from the band. —Don't thank me. Thank Q —I heard him say to the first-year girl. —Thank you for the two hundred dollars! —the girl said to me. —Don't thank me, thank Margo Roth Spiegelman! —I shouted without turning my head. Because it was clear that Margo was the one who had provided me with the necessary tools.

en: I made it to my locker and grabbed my calc notebook, but then I just stayed, even after the second bell rang, standing still in the middle of the hallway while people rushed past me in both directions, like I was the median in their freeway. Another kid thanked me for his two hundred dollars. I smiled at him. The school felt more mine than in all my four years there. We’d gotten a measure of justice for the bikeless band geeks. Lacey Pemberton had spoken to me. Chuck Parson had apologized.
vi: I opened my locker, grabbed my calculus notebook, but I still stood there, even though the second bell had rung, standing still in the hallway while everyone around me zipped past in both directions, as if I were the divider on their highway. Another kid thanked me for the two hundred dollars he received. I smiled at the boy. I felt the school was more mine than ever in the past four years. We had found a fair solution for the bike-less class. Lacey Pemberton had talked to me. Chuck Parson had apologized.
tr: I reached my locker and took my math notebook, but even after the second bell rang, I just stood there, motionless in the middle of the corridor as people rushed past me in both directions as if I were the median strip in their path. Another kid thanked me for the two hundred dollars. I smiled. The school felt more like mine than it had during the four years I had been there. We had provided some justice for the band geeks without bikes. Lacey Pemberton had talked to me. Chuck Parson had apologized.
es: I opened the locker and grabbed the calculus notebook, but then I stood still, even though the second bell had already rung, motionless in the middle of the hallway while people ran past me in both directions, as if I were the median of their highway. Another boy thanked me for the two hundred dollars. I smiled at him. The high school felt more like mine than it had in the four years I had been there. We had done justice for the band geeks who had lost their bicycles. Lacey Pemberton had talked to me. Chuck Parson had apologized.

en: I knew these halls so well—and finally it was starting to feel like they knew me, too. I stood there as the third bell rang and the crowds dwindled. Only then did I walk to calc, sitting down just after Mr. Jiminez had started another interminable lecture.
vi: I know these hallways all too well–and eventually, I even started to feel that they knew me. I was still standing there when the third bell rang and the crowd began to disperse. Only then did I enter the calculus class, sitting down right after Mr. Jiminez began another interminable lecture.
tr: I knew these corridors so well... and eventually, it felt like they were starting to know me too. I stood there as the crowd gradually thinned out when the third bell rang. But later I entered math class and sat down in my seat right after Mr. Jiminez started another endless lesson.
es: I knew those hallways very well, and in the end, it started to seem like they knew me too. I stood there while the third bell rang and the crowd dispersed. Only then did I head to calculus class and sit down just after Mr. Jiminez had started another of his endless lessons.

en: I’d brought Margo’s copy of Leaves of Grass to school, and I started reading the highlighted parts of “Song of Myself” again, under the desk while Mr. Jiminez scratched away at the blackboard. There were no direct references to New York that I could see. I handed it to Radar after a few minutes, and he looked at it for a while before writing on the corner of his notebook closest to me, The green highlighting must mean something. Maybe she wants you to open the door of your mind? I shrugged, and wrote back, Or maybe she just read the poem on two different days with two different highlighters.
vi: I brought Margo's "The Grass Wings" to school, hid the book in my desk, and started rereading the marked lines in the poem "Soliloquy" while Mr. Jiminez scratched words on the board. There was no mention of New York. A few minutes later, I handed the book to Radar, who looked at it for a moment and then wrote on the corner of his notebook, closest to me, The green highlights must mean something. Maybe Margo wants you to open your mind? I shrugged, wrote back, Or maybe Margo just read the poem on two different days, with two different highlighters.
tr: I had brought Margo's Leaves of Grass to school, and while Mr. Jiminez was scribbling something on the board, I started rereading the underlined sections of Song of Myself under the desk. As far as I could see, there was no direct reference to New York. A few minutes later, I handed the book to Radar, and before writing a note on the corner of his notebook closest to me, he looked at the book for a while. Those marked in green must mean something. Maybe it wants you to open the door of your mind? I shrugged and in response, wrote, Maybe he read the poem on two different days with two different pens.
es: I had taken Margo's copy of Leaves of Grass to class, so I opened it under the table and started reading the marked passages from "Song of Myself" again while Mr. Jiminez wrote on the board. I didn't see any direct references to New York. A few minutes later, I passed the book to Radar, who flipped through it for a while and then wrote in the corner of his notebook: "The green highlighting must mean something. Maybe it wants you to open the door of your mind." I shrugged and wrote back: "Or maybe she just read the poem on two different days with two different highlighters."

en: A few minutes later, as I glanced toward the clock for only the thirty-seventh time, I saw Ben Starling standing outside the classroom door, a hall pass in his hand, dancing a spastic jig.
vi: A few minutes later, when I glanced at the clock for the thirty-seventh time, I saw Ben Starling standing outside the classroom door, a hall pass[7] in his hand, bouncing like crazy to a jig.
tr: A few minutes later, while looking at the clock for only the thirty-seventh time, I saw Ben Starling standing outside the classroom door, doing a silly dance with a permission slip in his hand.
es: A few minutes later, after looking at the clock for only the thirty-seventh time, I saw Ben Starling on the other side of the classroom door, doing a jerky dance and holding a hall pass in his hand.

en: When the bell rang for lunch, I raced to my locker, but somehow Ben had beaten me there, and somehow he was talking to Lacey Pemberton. He was crowding her, slumping slightly so he could talk toward her face. Talking to Ben could make me feel a little claustrophobic sometimes, and I wasn’t even a hot girl.
vi: When the lunch bell rang, I rushed straight to my locker, but somehow Ben had beaten me there, and somehow he was talking to Lacey Pemberton. Ben stood close to Lacey, slightly tilting his head to look directly at her. Talking to Ben sometimes made me feel claustrophobic, and it's not like I was some hot girl or anything.
tr: When the lunch bell rang, I ran to my locker, but somehow Ben had beaten me there, and somehow he was talking to Lacey Pemberton. He was leaning towards Lacey, almost climbing on top of her to talk to her face. Talking to Ben sometimes made me feel claustrophobic, and I wasn't even a sexy girl.
es: When the lunch bell rang, I ran to my locker, but Ben had managed to get there before me and was talking to Lacey Pemberton. He was leaning in towards her, slightly hunched to speak to her face to face. Talking to Ben sometimes felt a bit claustrophobic, and that was even though I wasn't a hot girl.

en: “Hey, guys,” I said when I got up to them.
vi: "Hello, friends," I said upon arriving.
tr: "Hey, guys," I said when I reached them.
es: —Hello, guys —I said to them upon arriving.

en: “Hey,” Lacey answered, taking an obvious step back from Ben. “Ben was just bringing me up-to-date on Margo. No one ever went into her room, you know. She said her parents didn’t allow her to have friends over.”
vi: “Hi,” Lacey said, taking a clear step back to avoid Ben. “Ben just told me some things about Margo. You know, no one has ever been in her room. Margo said that her parents don't allow her to invite friends over.”
tr: “Hi,” Lacey responded, taking a noticeable step back from Ben. “Ben was giving me the latest updates about Margo. You know, no one had entered her room. She used to say that her parents didn’t allow her to bring friends over.”
es: —Hello —Lacey replied, taking a step back to move away from Ben—. Ben was telling me the latest news about Margo. No one ever went into her room, you know. She said that her parents didn't allow her friends to come over.

en: “Really?” Lacey nodded. “Did you know that Margo owns, like, a thousand records?”
vi: “Really?” Lacey nodded. “So, do you know that Margo has about, let's see, one thousand records?”
tr: “Really?” Lacey nodded. “Did you know that Margo had about a thousand records?”
es: —Really? Lacey nodded. —Did you know that Margo has about a thousand records?

en: Lacey threw up her hands. “No, that’s what Ben was saying! Margo never talked about music. I mean, she would say she liked something on the radio or whatever. But—no. She’s so weird.”
vi: Lacey raised both hands. "Not at all, Ben just asked the same thing! Margo never talks about music. Actually, she does mention liking this or that on the radio or somewhere. But–no mention of records at all. She's really strange."
tr: Lacey raised her hands. “No, I was saying that too! Margo never talked about music. I mean, she would say she liked something on the radio or whatever. But... no. Is Margo very strange?’
es: —I asked her. Lacey raised her hands. —No. That’s what Ben was telling me. Margo never talked about music. Well, she would say she liked a song that was playing on the radio and things like that. But… no. She’s very strange.

en: I shrugged. Maybe she was weird, or maybe the rest of us were weird. Lacey kept talking. “But we were just saying that Walt Whitman was from New York.”
vi: I shrugged. Maybe Margo is strange, or maybe the rest of us are the strange ones. Lacey continued. “But we were just talking about how Walt Whitman was from New York.”
tr: I shrugged my shoulders. Maybe Margo was weird or the rest of us were weird. Lacey kept talking. “But we were just talking about how Walt Whitman was from New York.”
es: I shrugged. Maybe she was strange, or maybe the strange ones were the rest of us. Lacey kept talking. —But we were saying that Walt Whitman was from New York.

en: “And according to Omnictionary, Woody Guthrie lived there for a long time, too,” Ben said.
vi: "And according to the Complete Chronicles, Woody Guthrie also lived there for a long time," Ben added.
tr: "And according to Omnictionary, Woody Guthrie also lived there for a long time," said Ben.
es: —And according to the Omnictionary, Woody Guthrie also lived in New York for a long time —said Ben.

en: I nodded. “I can totally see her in New York. I think we have to figure out the next clue, though. It can’t end with the book. There must be some code in the highlighted lines or something.”
vi: I nodded. "I think it's very likely that Margo is in New York. But we probably have to find the next clue. We can't just stop at the book. There must be something undeciphered from the marked lines of poetry."
tr: I nodded my head. “I can imagine Margo in New York. Still, we need to solve the next clue. I don't think it ends with the book. There must be some kind of code in the underlined lines.”
es: I nodded. —I can perfectly imagine her in New York. But I think we need to discover the next clue. It can't be just the book. There must be some kind of code in the marked verses or something like that.

en: “Yeah, can I look at it during lunch?”
vi: "Sure, can I take a look at the book during lunch?"
tr: “Yes, can I look at the book during lunch?”
es: —Yes. Can I take a look while I eat?

en: “Yeah,” I said. “Or I can make you a copy in the library if you want.”
vi: "Sure," I said. "Or if you want, I can make a copy for you in the library."
tr: “Of course,” I said. “Or if you prefer, I can make a copy for you in the library.”
es: —Sure —I replied—. Or if you want, I can make photocopies for you at the library.

en: “Nah, I can just read it. I mean, I don’t know crap about poetry. Oh, but anyway, I have a cousin in college there, at NYU, and I sent her a flyer she could print. So I’m going to tell her to put them up in record stores. I mean, I know there are a lot of record stores, but still.”
vi: “No need, I'm just reading. Actually, I don't understand much about poetry at all. Oh, but anyway, I have a cousin who's studying there, at New York University, I can send her the flyer to print out. I'll ask her to leave the flyers at the music stores. Of course, there are many music stores, but it's worth a try.”
tr: No, just reading is enough. I mean, I don't know anything about poetry. Ah, whatever... I have a cousin there, at New York University, I sent him a flyer that he can print out. I'll tell him to post the flyers in music stores. I mean, I know there are a lot of music stores there, but still...”
es: —No need. I just want to read it. Wow, I don't understand a damn thing about poetry. But a cousin of mine goes to New York University, and I sent her a poster to print. I'm going to ask her to hang it in record stores. Well, I know there are a lot of record stores, but anyway.

en: “Good idea,” I said. They started to walk to the cafeteria, and I followed them.
vi: "That's a good idea," I said. Ben and Lacey started heading to the cafeteria, and I followed them.
tr: “Good idea,” I said. They started walking towards the cafeteria, and I followed them.
es: —Good idea —I told him. They headed to the cafeteria and I followed them.

en: “Hey,” Ben asked Lacey, “what color is your dress?”
vi: “Hey,” Ben asked Lacey, “what color is your dress?”
tr: Ben called out, "Hey, Acey, what color is your dress?""
es: —Hey —asked Ben to Lacey—, what color is your dress?

en: “Um, it’s kind of sapphire, why?”
vi: "Uh, like sapphire blue, how about that?"
tr: “Hmm, like a sapphire, why?””
es: —Hmm, except for the sapphire blue. Why?

en: “Just want to make sure my tux matches,” Ben said. I’d never seen Ben’s smile so giddy-ridiculous, and that’s saying something, because he was a fairly giddy-ridiculous person.
vi: “Then I'll match my formal suit to it,” Ben replied. I had never seen Ben smile so goofily, and that says something, because he was already quite goofy.
tr: “I just wanted to make sure my tuxedo would fit,” said Ben. I had never seen Ben's smile so cheesy and ridiculous, and this was really an important detail because Ben was normally quite a cheesy and ridiculous person.
es: —To make sure it matches my tuxedo —Ben replied. I had never seen such a ridiculous and silly smile on Ben, and that's saying something, because he was quite a ridiculous and silly person.

en: Lacey nodded. “Well, but we don’t want to be too matchy-matchy. Maybe if you go traditional: black tux and a black vest?”
vi: Lacey nodded. “Alright, but we shouldn't be too much of a perfect match. Maybe you should just stick to tradition: a black suit?”
tr: Lacey nodded. “Okay, but we don't want to be too conventional. Maybe you can go traditional: Black tuxedo with a black vest?”
es: Lacey nodded. —Well, but let's not go too coordinated either. You could go traditional, with a black tuxedo and a black vest.

en: “No cummerbund, you don’t think?”
vi: “Not wearing a wide belt, do you think that's appropriate?”
tr: "Should I wear a sash?""
es: —Without a girdle, what do you think?

en: “Well, they’re okay, but you don’t want to get one with really fat pleats, you know?”
vi: "Alright, that's fine. But don't wear too many frilly, ruffled clothes."
tr: “Well, that would be fine, but it would be better if you didn't buy the ones with really thick pleats.”
es: —Well, the sashes are fine, but without too many folds, you know?

en: They kept talking—apparently, the ideal level of pleat-fatness is a conversational topic to which hours can be devoted—but I stopped listening as I waited in the Pizza Hut line. Ben had found his prom date, and Lacey had found a boy who would happily talk prom for hours. Now everyone had a date—except me, and I wasn’t going. The only girl I’d want to take was off tramping some kind of perpetual journey or something.
vi: The two kept talking endlessly–clearly, the ideal ratio of water spinach to water was a topic that could be discussed for hours–but I stopped paying attention while queuing up at Pizza Hut. Ben had found a date for the prom, and Lacey had found a guy who was excited to talk about the prom for hours. Now everyone had a partner–except for me, and I wasn't going to the prom. The only girl I wanted to accompany was embarking on an endless journey or something like that.
tr: They kept talking, apparently, the ideal thickness of the battery was a topic that could be discussed for hours, but Pizza Hut I had stopped listening while waiting. I had found my prom date, and Lacey had found a guy to talk about the prom with for hours, contentedly. Now everyone had a date... except me, and I wasn't going to the prom. The only girl I would want to take was slowly advancing on some kind of eternal journey.
es: They kept talking —apparently, the ideal level of folds is a topic of conversation to which they can dedicate hours—, but I stopped listening while I waited in line at Pizza Hut. Ben had found a partner for the dance, and Lacey had found a guy who could spend hours talking about the dance, enchanted by life. Now everyone had a partner… except me, who wasn't going to go. The only girl I would have liked to take had embarked on an eternal journey.

en: When we sat down, Lacey started reading “Song of Myself,” and she agreed that none of it sounded like anything and certainly none of it sounded like Margo. We still had no idea what, if anything, Margo was trying to say. She gave the book back to me, and they started talking about prom again.
vi: When we sat down to eat, Lacey began reading "Song of Myself," and agreed that the verses didn't convey anything, nor did they resemble Margo at all. We still hadn't figured out what Margo meant, if she was indeed implying something. Lacey handed the book back to me, then she and he continued to chatter about the prom.
tr: When we sat down, Lacey started reading My Song and agreed that none of them resembled anything, and certainly not Margo. We still didn't know what Margo was trying to tell us, if she was trying to say anything at all. Lacey handed the book back to me and they started talking about the prom again.
es: When we sat down, Lacey started to read "Song of Myself" and agreed that it didn't sound like anything, and certainly didn't sound like Margo. We still had no idea what Margo was trying to say, if she was trying to say anything at all. She handed the book back to me and they started talking about the dance again.

en: All afternoon, I kept feeling like it wasn’t doing any good to look at the highlighted quotes, but then I would get bored and reach into my backpack and put the book on my lap and go back to it. I had English at the end of the day, seventh period, and we were just starting to read Moby Dick, so Dr. Holden was talking quite a lot about fishing in the nineteenth century. I kept Moby Dick on the desk and Whitman in my lap, but even being in English class couldn’t help. For once, I went a few minutes without looking at the clock, so I was surprised by the bell ringing, and took longer than everyone else to get my backpack packed. As I slung it over one shoulder and started to leave, Dr. Holden smiled at me and said, “Walt Whitman, huh?”
vi: All afternoon, I had the feeling that just looking at those marked lines of poetry wouldn't help at all. But then I got bored, rummaged through my backpack, took out the poetry book, placed it on my lap, and read it again. My last subject was National Language, seventh period, and the whole class had just started on Moby Dick, so Ms. Holden was lecturing quite a bit about nineteenth-century whaling. I placed Moby Dick on the desk and Whitman on my lap, but even sitting in National Language class didn't add any effect. There were moments when I didn't look at the clock for several minutes, so I was a bit surprised when the bell rang, thus taking more time to pack up my books than the others. As I slung my backpack over my shoulder and started to leave the class, Ms. Holden smiled at me and said, "Walt Whitman, huh?"
tr: All afternoon, I kept feeling like there was no point in looking at the underlined words, but then I got bored and reached into my back pocket, put the book on my lap, and went back to looking at the lines. At the end of the day, we had literature class in the seventh period and we were just starting to read Moby Dick, so Dr. Holden was talking quite a bit about fishing in the nineteenth century. I held Moby Dick on my desk and Whitman on my lap, but even being in literature class didn't help. For the first time, I went on for a few minutes without looking at the clock, so when the bell rang, I was surprised, and it took me longer than everyone else to gather my backpack. As I slung my bag over one shoulder and walked out, Dr. Holden smiled at me and said, "So, Walt Whitman."
es: All afternoon I had the feeling that I wasn't on the right track searching through the marked quotes, but in the end, I got bored, took the book out of my backpack, put it on my knees, and continued with it. The last class was literature and we were starting to read Moby Dick, so Dr. Holden kept talking about fishing in the 19th century. I left Moby Dick on the table and Whitman on my knees, but even being in literature class didn't help. For once, I didn't look at the clock for several minutes, so the bell surprised me and I took longer than the others to gather my things. As I slung my backpack over one shoulder and started to leave, Dr. Holden smiled at me. —Walt Whitman, eh? —he asked me.

en: I nodded sheepishly.
vi: I nodded in embarrassment.
tr: I nodded my head in an embarrassed manner.
es: I nodded, embarrassed.

en: “Good stuff,” she said. “So good that I’m almost okay with you reading it in class. But not quite.” I mumbled sorry and then walked out to the senior parking lot.
vi: “Not bad,” she said. “Good enough that I almost agreed to let you read during class. But not for too long.” I mumbled an apology and walked to the senior student parking lot.
tr: “Good book,” he said. “So good that reading it in class is almost not a problem for me. Almost.” “I'm sorry,” I murmured, then went out to the senior parking lot.
es: —It's very good —he told me—. So good that I'm almost in agreement for you to read it in class. But not entirely. I murmured an apology and headed to the senior student parking lot.

en: While Ben and Radar banded, I sat in RHAPAW with the doors open, a slow husky breeze blowing through. I read from The Federalist Papers to prepare for a quiz I had the next day in government, but my mind kept returning to its continuous loop: Guthrie and Whitman and New York and Margo. Had she gone to New York to immerse herself in folk music? Was there some secret folk music-loving Margo I’d never known? Was she maybe staying in an apartment where one of them had once lived? And why did she want to tell me about it?
vi: While Ben and Radar were practicing music, I sat in RHAPAW with the car door open, a gentle breeze slowly caressing through. I was reading The Federalist Papers to prepare for tomorrow's government class test, but my mind kept wandering between Guthrie, Whitman, New York, and Margo. Did Margo go to New York to pursue country music? Is there a secret Margo passionate about country music that I never knew about? Is she living in an apartment that one of them once lived in? And why did she want to tell me all of that?
tr: While I was in the band with Radar, I sat in SESIB with the doors open; a light, cool breeze was blowing. To prepare for my political science exam the next day, I read some of the Federalist Papers. I read it, but my mind kept getting stuck in its endless loop: Guthrie, Whitman, New York, and Margo. Had he gone to New York to bury himself in folk music? Was there a Margo who loved folk music that I didn't know about? Maybe he was staying in a house where they once lived? And why did he want to tell me this?
es: While Ben and Radar were rehearsing, I sat in the Chuco with the doors open. A light Eskimo breeze was blowing. I read the Federalist to prepare for a politics exam I had the next day, but my mind had entered a loop: Guthrie, Whitman, New York, and Margo. Had she gone to New York to dive into folk music? Was there some secret folk musician there that I didn't know about? Was she perhaps in an apartment where one of them had once lived? And why did she want me to know?

en: I saw Ben and Radar approaching in the sideview mirror, Radar swinging his sax case as he walked quickly toward RHAPAW. They hustled in through the already-open door, and Ben turned the key and RHAPAW sputtered, and then we hoped, and then she sputtered again, and then we hoped some more, and finally she gurgled to life. Ben raced out of the parking lot and turned off campus before saying to me, “CAN YOU BELIEVE THIS SHIT!” He could hardly contain his glee.
vi: Looking through the side mirror, I saw Ben and Radar approaching. Radar was swinging the saxophone case as he walked briskly to RHAPAW. The two of them rushed in through the open door, Ben inserted the key into the ignition, and RHAPAW started to sputter. We hoped, it sputtered again, we hoped a little more, and finally, it coughed to life. Ben managed to speed through the parking lot, turning out of the school before shouting at me, “CAN YOU BELIEVE IT?” He could hardly contain his excitement.
tr: I saw Ben and Radar approaching from the window, Radar was swinging his saxophone case as he walked quickly towards SESIB. They hurriedly got into the car through the already open door, Ben turned the ignition and SESIB sputtered, we hoped, it sputtered again, we hoped a bit more, and finally it coughed to life. Ben first quickly drove out of the parking lot and away from the school, then he shouted at me: "CAN YOU BELIEVE THIS NONSENSE!" He couldn't contain his joy.
es: I saw Ben and Radar approaching through the side mirror, Radar swinging his sax case as he hurried towards the RHAPAW. They got in, Ben turned the key, and the RHAPAW sputtered. We waited a moment and the car sputtered again. We kept waiting and finally it responded. Ben drove out of the parking lot and off the campus. —CAN YOU BELIEVE THIS SHIT? —he shouted, unable to contain his joy.

en: He started hitting the car’s horn, but of course the horn didn’t work, so every time he hit it, he just yelled, “BEEP! BEEP! BEEP! HONK IF YOU’RE GOING TO PROM WITH TRUE-BLUE HONEYBUNNY LACEY PEMBERTON! HONK, BABY, HONK!”
vi: Ben started honking the horn, but of course, the horn didn't work, so every time he honked, Ben would shout, "BEEP! BEEP! BEEP! HONK IF YOU'RE GOING TO PROM WITH SUPER BUNNY LACEY PEMBERTON! HONK, HONK!"
tr: He started hitting the car horn, but of course, the horn didn't work, so he shouted every time he hit it: "BEEP! BEEP! BEEP! IF LOYAL BUNNY LACEY PEMBERTON IS GOING TO THE PROM WITH YOU, HONK! HONK, SWEETIE, HONK!"
es: He started honking the horn, but of course it didn't work, so every time he honked, he shouted: BEEP! BEEP! BEEP! HONK IF YOU'RE GOING TO THE DANCE WITH A TURKEY, WITH LACEY PEMBERTON! HONK, BABY, HONK!

en: Ben could hardly shut up the whole way home. “You know what did it? Aside from desperation? I guess she and Becca Arrington are fighting because Becca’s, you know, a cheater, and I think she started to feel bad about the whole Bloody Ben thing. She didn’t say that, but she sort of acted it. So in the end, Bloody Ben is going to get me some puh-lay-hey.” I was happy for him and everything, but I wanted to focus on the game of getting to Margo.
vi: Ben hardly turned off the speaker the entire way home. “Do you guys know what has really happened? Besides the feeling of despair? I guess Lacey and Becca Arrington are fighting because, as you all know, Becca is quite the cunning trickster. I also think Lacey is starting to feel remorseful about the whole Ben Bullshit thing. He didn’t say it outright, but he behaved somewhat like that. So in the end, Ben Bullshit will get me some attention.” I was very happy for Ben and all, but I wanted to focus on the game leading to Margo.
tr: On the way home, Ben almost couldn't shut his mouth. "Do you know why that is? Besides the desperation, I mean. I think he's fighting with Becca Arrington because Becca is being sneaky and all that Bloody Ben stuff is making him feel bad. He didn't say it, but he kind of acted that way. So in the end, Bloody Ben is going to bring me some toys." Okay, I was happy for Ben, but I wanted to focus on the game of reaching Margo.
es: He could barely keep his mouth shut on the way home. —Do you know why she accepted? Apart from being desperate? I think she had a fight with Becca Arrington, because you know, Becca deceived her, and I think she was starting to feel bad about the whole Bloody Ben thing. She didn't tell me, but it seemed like it. So in the end, I'll have some drama thanks to Bloody Ben. I was happy for him, of course, but I wanted to focus on how to reach Margo.

en: “Do you guys have any ideas at all?”
vi: "Do you have any more ideas?"
tr: "Children, do you have any ideas?""
es: —Guys, has any idea occurred to you?

en: It was quiet for a moment, and then Radar looked at me through the rearview mirror and said, “That doors thing is the only one marked different from the others, and it’s also the most random; I really think that’s the one with the clue. What is it again?”
vi: The whole group fell silent for a moment, then Radar looked at me through the rearview mirror and said, "The line about the door is the only one that stands out from the rest, and it's also the most random. I really think that line holds a clue." "What is the whole line again?"
tr: There was a moment of silence, then Radar looked at me through the rearview mirror. "That door thing is the only one marked differently from the others, and also the most random one; I really think the one with the clue is that one." By the way, what was it?"
es: For a moment there was no response, but then Radar looked at me through the rearview mirror and said: —The thing about the doors is the only thing marked in a different color from the rest, and it's also the most unexpected. I think the clue is there. What did it say?

en: “‘Unscrew the locks from the doors! / Unscrew the doors themselves from their jambs!’” I replied.
vi: “Remove the lock from the door! / Remove the door itself from the frame!” I repeated.
tr: "Remove the locks from the doors! / Remove the doors from their frames!" I replied.
es: —"Tear the bolts from the doors! / Tear the doors from their hinges!" I replied.

en: “Admittedly, Jefferson Park is not really the best place to unscrew the doors of closed-mindedness from their jambs,” Radar allowed. “Maybe that’s what she’s saying. Like the paper town thing she said about Orlando? Maybe she’s saying that’s why she left.”
vi: “I must admit, Jefferson Park isn't really the ideal place to unlock the doors of narrow-mindedness from their frames,” Radar confirmed. “Maybe that's what Margo meant. As she said, Orlando is a paper town, right? Maybe Margo is explaining why she left.”
tr: Radar said, "Undoubtedly, Jefferson Park is not the best place to pry open the doors of narrow-mindedness." "Maybe that's what Margo meant. Like that paper town thing she said about Orlando? Maybe she's saying that's why she left."
es: —You have to admit that Jefferson Park is not the best place to unhinge the doors of the narrow-minded —said Radar—. Maybe that's what he means. Like what he said about Orlando being a paper town. Maybe what he means is that's why he left.

en: Ben slowed for a stoplight and then turned around to look at Radar. “Bro,” he said, “I think you guys are giving Margo Honey-bunny way too much credit.”
vi: Ben slowed down to stop at the traffic light, then turned to look at Radar. "Hey buddy," Ben said, "I think you guys are overcomplicating the Margo rabbit."
tr: I slowed down because of the red light, then turned around to look at Radar. "Brother," he said, "I think you kids are giving too much credit to Margo's rabbit trails."
es: Ben stopped at a traffic light and turned to look at Radar. —Colleague —he said—, I think you are giving that girl too much credit.

en: “How’s that?” I asked.
vi: "What do you mean?" I asked.
tr: “What do you mean?” I asked.
es: —What do you mean? —I asked him.

en: “Unscrew the locks from the doors,” he said. “Unscrew the doors themselves from their jambs.”
vi: "Remove the lock from the door!" Ben said. "Remove the door itself from the frame!"
tr: “Remove the locks from the doors,” he said. “Remove the doors from their frames.”
es: —"Tear the bolts off the doors," he commented—. "Tear the doors off the hinges."

en: “Yeah,” I said. The light turned green and Ben hit the gas. RHAPAW shuddered like she might disintegrate but then began to move.
vi: "Oh right," I exclaimed. The light turned green and Ben stepped on the gas. RHAPAW shook violently as if it was about to fall apart, but then it continued to roll on.
tr: “Yes,” I said. The light turned green and Ben stepped on the gas. SESIB rattled as if it was going to fall apart, but then it started to move.
es: —Yes —I said. The traffic light turned green and Ben stepped on the accelerator. The Chuco trembled as if it were about to disintegrate, but it started to move.

en: “It’s not poetry. It’s not metaphor. It’s instructions. We are supposed to go to Margo’s room and unscrew the lock from the door and unscrew the door itself from its jamb.”
vi: "That is not poetry. Nor is it a metaphor. Those are instructions. We will have to enter Margo's room, remove the lock from the door, and take the door itself off its frame."
tr: “This is not a poem. It is not a metaphor. These are instructions. We need to go to Margo's room, remove the lock from the door, and take the door off its hinges.”
es: —It is not poetry. It is not a metaphor. They are instructions. We are supposed to go to Margo's room, break the lock off the door, and take the door off its hinges.

en: Radar looked at me in the rearview mirror, and I looked back at him. “Sometimes,” Radar said to me, “he’s so retarded that he becomes kind of brilliant.”
vi: Radar looked at me through the rearview mirror, and I looked back at him. “Sometimes,” Radar said to me, “my friend is so slow that it becomes superhuman.”
tr: Radar looked at me through the rearview mirror, and I looked back at him. “Sometimes,” Radar said to me, “she is so idiotic that she turns into a diamond.”
es: Radar looked at me through the rearview mirror and I returned his gaze. —He's so crazy that sometimes he ends up being a genius —Radar told me.

tr: After parking on our driveway, we crossed the lawn that separated Margo's house from mine, just like we did on Saturday.

en: After parking in my driveway, we walked across the strip of grass that separated Margo’s house from mine, just as we had Saturday. Ruthie answered the door and said her parents wouldn’t be home until six; Myrna Mountweazel ran excited circles around us; we went upstairs. Ruthie brought us a toolbox from the garage, and then we all stared at the door leading to Margo’s bedroom for a while. We were not handy people.
vi: After parking in my driveway, we walked across the strip of grass separating Margo's house from mine, just like we did on Saturday. Ruthie opened the door and said her parents wouldn't be home until six; Myrna Mountweazel was bustling around us; we all went upstairs. Ruthie brought us a toolbox from the garage, and then we all stood there staring at Margo's bedroom door for a moment. None of us were handy enough to handle this task.
tr: After parking on our driveway, we crossed the lawn that separated Margo's house from mine, just like we did on Saturday. Ruthie opened the door and said that her parents wouldn't be home until six; Myrna Mountweazel ran around us excitedly in circles; we went upstairs. Ruthie brought us a toolbox from the garage, then we all stared at the door leading to Margo's room for a while. We were not handy people.
es: We parked in front of my house and crossed the strip of grass that separates Margo's house from mine, just as we had done on Saturday. Ruthie opened the door and told us that her parents wouldn't be home until six. Myrna Mountweazel, nervous, circled around us. We went upstairs. Ruthie brought us a toolbox from the garage, and for a moment we all stood staring at the door to Margo's room. We weren't very handy.

en: “What the hell are you supposed to do?” asked Ben.
vi: “What the hell are we going to do now?” Ben asked.
tr: “Damn, it's a hellish job,” said Ben.
es: —What the hell are you supposed to do? —asked Ben.

en: “Don’t curse in front of Ruthie,” I said.
vi: "Don't curse in front of Ruthie," I reminded him.
tr: "Don't swear in front of Ruthie," I said.
es: —Don't talk like that in front of Ruthie —I told him.

en: “Ruthie, do you mind if I say hell?”
vi: "Ruthie, do you mind when I talk about demons?"
tr: “Ruthie, would it be a problem for you if I said hell?”
es: —Ruthie, do you mind if I say damn?

en: “We don’t believe in hell,” she said, by way of answering.
vi: “Ghosts aren't real,” Ruthie said in response.
tr: “We don't believe in hell,” he replied.
es: —We don't believe in the devil —the girl replied to him.

en: Radar interrupted. “People,” he said. “People. The door.” Radar dug out a Phillips-head screwdriver from the mess of a toolbox and knelt down, unscrewing the locking doorknob. I grabbed a bigger screwdriver and tried to unscrew the hinges, but there didn’t seem to be any screws involved. I looked at the door some more. Eventually, Ruthie got bored and went downstairs to watch TV.
vi: Radar interrupted. "Now," he said firmly, "let's focus. The door." Radar pulled out a flathead screwdriver from the pile of tools and bent down to remove the door handle. I grabbed a larger screwdriver and tried to remove the hinges, but there didn't seem to be any screws. I examined the door a bit more. Eventually, Ruthie got bored and went downstairs to watch TV.
tr: Radar intervened. "Folks," he said. "Folks. The door." He rummaged through the messy toolbox, pulled out a Phillips screwdriver, and knelt down, removing the door handle where the lock was. I tried to take a larger screwdriver to remove the hinges, but there didn't seem to be any screws. I looked at the door a bit more. Finally, Ruthie got bored and went downstairs to watch TV.
es: Radar interrupted. —Uncles —he said—. Uncles, the door. Radar took a screwdriver from the pile of tools, knelt down, and unscrewed the door handle. I grabbed a larger screwdriver and tried to unscrew the hinges, but there didn't seem to be any screws, so I set about looking for them. In the end, Ruthie got bored and went to watch TV.

en: Radar got the doorknob loose, and we each, in turn, peered inside at the unpainted, unfinished wood around the knob. No message. No note. Nothing. Annoyed, I moved onto the hinges, wondering how to open them. I swung the door open and shut, trying to understand its mechanics. “That poem is so damned long,” I said. “You’d think old Walt could have taken a line or two to tell us how to unscrew the door itself from its jamb.”
vi: Radar managed to loosen the door handle, and we took turns peeking inside the rough, unpainted wood around the handle. There was no message. Not a single note. Nothing at all. Annoyed, I turned back to the hinge, fumbling with how to remove it. I opened and closed the door, trying to understand the principle of the hinge bar. “That poem is disgustingly long,” I said. “Do you think old poet Walt wrote a line or two somewhere on how to remove the door from the frame?”
tr: Radar loosened the door handle and each of us, in turn, carefully looked inside the unpainted, unpolished wood around the handle. There was no message. There was no note. Feeling frustrated, I continued to work on the hinges, wondering how to open it, opening and closing the door to understand its mechanism. "That poem is so long," I said, "One thinks that old Walt would at least spare a line or two to tell us how to remove the door from its frame.""
es: Radar took out the knob, and one by one we took a look at the unpainted and unpolished hole. No message. No note. Nothing. Angry, I looked again at the hinges, wondering how to open them. I opened and closed the door, trying to understand the mechanism. —The poem is fucking long —I said—. Do you think old Walt resorted to a verse or two to tell us how to rip the door off its hinges?

en: Only when he responded did I realize Radar was sitting at Margo’s computer. “According to Omnictionary,” he said, “we’re looking at a butt hinge. And you just use the screwdriver as a lever to pop out the pin. Incidentally, some vandal has added that butt hinges function well because they are powered by farts. Oh, Omnictionary. Wilt thou ever be accurate?”
vi: Only when Radar spoke did I realize he was sitting in front of Margo's computer. "According to the Complete Encyclopedia of Everything," he said, "we need to find the leaf hinge first. Just use a screwdriver to pry the pin up. By the way, some idiot also added that the leaf hinge works smoothly when the lane is broken. Oh, Complete Encyclopedia of Everything. Are you kidding me?”
tr: I only realized Radar was sitting at Margo's computer when he responded to me. “According to Omnictionary,” he said, “we are looking at a door hinge. And you are using the screwdriver as a lever to remove the hinge. By chance, I discovered that a vandal wrote that the door hinges are strong because they are reinforced with farts. Ah, Omnictionary. Will you ever provide complete information?”
es: I didn't realize that Radar was sitting in front of Margo's computer until he answered me. —According to the Omnictionary, we are looking for a hinge. en: My mom told me once about this crazy kid she worked with. He was a completely normal kid until he was nine, when his dad died. And even though obviously a lot of nine-year-olds have had a lot of dead fathers and most of the time the kids don’t go crazy, I guess this kid was an exception.

en: So what he did was he took a pencil and one of those steel compass things, and he started drawing circles onto a piece of paper. All the circles exactly two inches in diameter. And he would draw the circles until the entire piece of paper was completely black, and then he would get another piece of paper and draw more circles, and he did this every day, all day, and didn’t pay attention in school and drew circles all over all of his tests and shit, and my mom said that this kid’s problem was that he had created a routine to cope with his loss, only the routine became destructive. So anyway, then my mom made him cry about his dad or whatever and the kid stopped drawing circles and presumably lived happily ever after. But I think about the circles kid sometimes, because I can sort of understand him. I always liked routine. I suppose I never found boredom very boring. I doubted I could explain it to someone like Margo, but drawing circles through life struck me as a kind of reasonable insanity.

He didn't pay attention in class, he drew circles on all the exams, and my mother told me that the boy's problem was that he had created a routine to cope with his loss, but the routine had become destructive. The fact is that my mother managed to make him cry for his father, and the boy stopped drawing circles and apparently lived happily ever since. But every now and then I think about the boy with the circles, because in some way I understand him. I've always liked routines. I suppose that being bored never really bored me too much. en: I lay down and started to feel a little depressed about prom. I refused to feel any kind of sadness over the fact that I wasn’t going to prom, but I had—stupidly, embarrassingly—thought of finding Margo, and getting her to come home with me just in time for prom, like late on Saturday night, and we’d walk into the Hilton ballroom wearing jeans and ratty T-shirts, and we’d be just in time for the last dance, and we’d dance while everyone pointed at us and marveled at the return of Margo, and then we’d fox-trot the hell out of there and go get ice cream at Friendly’s. So yes, like Ben, I harbored ridiculous prom fantasies. But at least I didn’t say mine out loud.

When the last one came off, the door creaked and started to fall, so I swung it all the way open against the wall with one hand, and as I swung it, I saw a tiny piece of paper—about the size of my thumbnail—flutter down from the door’s top hinge. Typical Margo. Why hide something in her own room when she could hide it in mine? I wondered when she’d done it, how she’d gotten in. I couldn’t help but smile.

tr: I nodded my head and pulled the sheet back up to my chin. Even though the bucket had been cleaned, I could still smell the vomit beneath the detergent, for some reason the smell reminded me of the act of vomiting, making me want to vomit again, but I breathed more slowly until I heard the Chrysler backing out of the driveway. It was 07:32. For the first time, I thought, I could leave on time. Not to school, of course. But still.
es: I nodded and pulled the blankets up to my chin. Although the trash can was clean, I could still smell vomit beneath the detergent, and that smell reminded me of the act of vomiting, which for some reason made me want to vomit again, but I breathed slowly through my mouth until I heard the Chrysler backing down the driveway. It was 7:32. I thought that for once I wouldn't be late. Not for going to school, I admit. But still.

en: I showered and brushed my teeth and put on dark jeans and a plain black T-shirt. I put Margo’s scrap of newspaper in my pocket. I hammered the pins back into their hinges, and then packed. I didn’t really know what to throw into my backpack, but I included the doorjamb-opening screwdriver, a printout of the satellite map, directions, a bottle of water, and in case she was there, the Whitman. I wanted to ask her about it.
vi: I showered, brushed my teeth, slipped into a pair of dark jeans and a plain black t-shirt, and tucked Margo's newspaper clipping into my pocket. I nailed the hinge back in place, then got ready to hit the road. I wasn't sure what to pack in my backpack, but I had a screwdriver to remove the door frame's vertical bar, a printed satellite map, directions, a water bottle, and a book of Whitman's poetry, just in case Margo was there. I wanted to ask her about that poetry book.
tr: I took a shower, brushed my teeth, and put on my dark jeans and a plain black t-shirt. I put Margo's piece of newspaper in my pocket. I hammered the hinges into place and got ready. I wasn't exactly sure what to pack in my backpack, but I added a screwdriver for opening door frames, a printout of the satellite map, the directions, a bottle of water, and Whitman in case Margo was there. I wanted to ask her questions about the book.
es: I took a shower, brushed my teeth, and put on some dark jeans and a black t-shirt. I slipped the piece of newspaper into my pocket. I placed the nails in the hinges and prepared the backpack. The truth is, I didn't know what to pack, but I included the screwdriver to open doors, a copy of the map, directions to get there, a bottle of water, and the Whitman book, just in case it was there. I wanted to ask him some questions.

en: Ben and Radar showed up at eight on the dot. I got in the backseat. They were shouting along to a song by the Mountain Goats.
vi: Ben and Radar arrived at exactly eight o'clock, not a second early or late. I sat in the back seat. The two of them were loudly singing along to a song by the band Mountain Goats.
tr: Ben and Radar arrived exactly at eight o'clock. I sat in the back seat. They were shouting along to a song by the Mountain Goats.
es: Ben and Radar showed up at eight o'clock sharp. I sat in the back seat. They were loudly singing a song by the Mountain Goats.

en: Ben turned around and offered me his fist. I punched it softly, even though I hated that greeting. “Q!” he shouted over the music. “How good does this feel?”
vi: Ben turned around and extended his fist towards me. I lightly bumped it back, even though I didn't like that way of greeting. "Q!" he shouted, drowning out the music. "How awesome is this game?"
tr: He turned his back and extended his fist towards me. Even though I hated this greeting, I lightly bumped his fist. “Q!” he shouted, overpowering the music. “Doesn't this feel so good?”
es: Ben turned around and extended his fist to me. I gave him a gentle punch, even though I hated that way of greeting. —Q! —he shouted over the music—. What do you think?

en: And I knew exactly what Ben meant: he meant listening to the Mountain Goats with your friends in a car that runs on a Wednesday morning in May on the way to Margo and whatever Margotastic prize came with finding her. “It beats calculus,” I answered. The music was too loud for us to talk. Once we got out of Jefferson Park, we rolled down the one window that worked so the world would know we had good taste in music.
vi: I understand exactly what Ben means: listening to Mountain Goats music with comrades in a car cruising on a Wednesday morning in May, on the road leading to Margo, and any award as awesome-as-Margo if we find her. "Way cooler than calculus," I respond. The music is loud and lively, making it hard to talk to each other. Leaving the Jefferson Park area, we roll down a functioning window so that people know we have great taste in music.
tr: I understood very well what Ben meant: In May, on a Wednesday morning, he was referring to listening to Mountain Goats with your friends in a car heading towards Margo and whatever Margoesque prize would be won by finding her. "It beats math," I replied. The music was too loud for us to talk. As soon as we left Jefferson Park, we rolled down the only window that wasn't broken so the world could learn that our taste in music was good.
es: I knew exactly what he meant. He was referring to listening to the Mountain Goats with your friends in a car, on a Wednesday morning in May, in search of Margo and the fantastic prize that finding her would entail. —Nothing to do with calculus —I replied to him. The music was too loud to talk. As soon as we left Jefferson Park, we rolled down the only window that worked so the world would know we had good musical taste.

en: We drove all the way out Colonial Drive, past the movie theaters and the bookstores that I had been driving to and past my whole life. But this drive was different and better because it occurred during calculus, because it occurred with Ben and Radar, because it occurred on our way to where I believed I would find her. And finally, after twenty miles, Orlando gave way to the last remaining orange tree groves and undeveloped ranches—the endlessly flat land grown over thick with brush, the Spanish moss hanging off the branches of oak trees, still in the windless heat. This was the Florida where I used to spend mosquito-bitten, armadillo-chasing nights as a Boy Scout. The road was dominated now by pickup trucks, and every mile or so you could see a subdivision off the highway—little streets winding for no reason around houses that rose up out of nothing like a volcano of vinyl siding.
vi: We ran along Colonial Drive, past the movie theaters and bookstores that I had frequented my entire life. But this trip was different and much more enjoyable, because the journey took place during calculus class, because I was accompanied by Ben and Radar, because we were on our way to where I believed I would find Margo. And finally, after twenty miles, the city of Orlando gave way to the last orange groves and the still-untouched farms—the flat land stretching endlessly, thickening under the brush, Spanish moss clinging to the oak branches, freely hanging down in the windless heat. This is the Florida where I spent nights chasing armadillos, getting bitten all over by mosquitoes, back when I was a Boy Scout. On the road now were only pickup trucks, and every mile or so, there was a small subdivision off the highway—winding little streets for no reason, circling around houses that sprang up in the middle of nowhere, like a plastic-coated volcano.
tr: Throughout my life, we passed by the movie theaters and bookstores that I had driven past countless times, continuing towards Colonial Boulevard. But this time it was different and better because it was happening during math class, because it was happening with Radar and Ben, because it was happening while I was heading to the place where I believed I would find Margo. Finally, after about thirty-five kilometers, Orlando gave way to the last remaining orange groves and undeveloped farms... this endless flat land was covered with shrubs, parasitic plants hanging motionless in the windless hot air from the branches of oak trees. This was the Florida where I had spent mosquito-bitten nights chasing armadillos as a young scout. Now the street was dominated by pickup trucks, and every kilometer, it was possible to see a neighborhood branching off from the main road... narrow streets inexplicably surrounding houses that rose from nothing like a volcano made of insulated facades.
es: We advanced along Colonial Drive and left behind the cinemas and bookstores that I had passed by all my life. But this time it was different and better, because it was during calculus hour, because I was with Ben and Radar, and because we were on our way to the place where I believed I would find Margo. And in the end, after thirty kilometers, Orlando gave way to the last orange groves and undeveloped ranches: the endless plain all covered with shrubs, the black moss hanging from the branches of the oaks, motionless in the warm, windless morning. It was the Florida where I had spent nights being bitten by mosquitoes and hunting armadillos when I was a boy scout. The road was full of vans, and every two kilometers or so, there was an exit from the highway: small streets that whimsically wound around houses that appeared out of nowhere, like a volcano covered in plastic.

en: Farther out we passed a rotting wooden sign that said GROVE-POINT ACRES. A cracked blacktop road lasted only a couple hundred feet before dead-ending into an expanse of gray dirt, signaling that Grovepoint Acres was what my mom called a pseudovision—a subdivision abandoned before it could be completed. Pseudovisions had been pointed out to me a couple times before on drives with my parents, but I’d never seen one so desolate.
vi: Continuing on, we drove past an old wooden sign that read GROVEPOINT ACRES. A cracked black road stretched only a few hundred meters before ending in a gray patch of land, hinting that Grovepoint Acres was what my mother used to call a “ghost town”–a subdivision abandoned before construction was completed. On previous trips, my parents had pointed out ghost towns like this to me, but I had never seen one as desolate and barren as this.
tr: Further away, we saw a decayed wooden sign that read GROVEPOINT ACRES. The cracked asphalt road was only sixty meters long and ended in a wide, gray-looking dirt area, indicating that Grovepoint Acres was, as my mother put it, a semi-neighborhood, abandoned before it could be completed. Semi-neighborhoods had been shown to me a few times by my parents while driving around, but I had never seen one this desolate.
es: A little further on, we passed a worn wooden sign that said GROVEPOINT ACRES. A road with cracked asphalt less than a hundred meters long led to a large expanse of gray land, indicating that Grovepoint Acres was what my mother called a pseudovision, an abandoned development before it was completed. My parents had pointed out pseudovisions to me a couple of times while driving with them, but I had never seen one so desolate.

en: We were about five miles past Grovepoint Acres when Radar turned down the music and said, “Should be in about a mile.”
vi: We drove about five miles past Grovepoint Acres when Radar turned down the music and announced, "About one more mile to go.""
tr: Turning off the music on the radar, "It should be in about one and a half kilometers," he said, as we had passed Grovepoint Acres by about eight kilometers.
es: We had traveled a little over five kilometers from Grovepoint Acres when Radar turned off the music. —It must be about a kilometer away —he said.

en: I took a long breath. The excitement of being somewhere other than school had started to wane. This didn’t seem like a place where Margo would hide, or even visit. It was a far cry from New York City. This was the Florida you fly over, wondering why people ever thought to inhabit this peninsula. I stared at the empty asphalt, the heat distorting my vision. Ahead, I saw a strip mall wavering in the bright distance.
vi: I took a deep breath. The excitement of skipping school to go out had gradually faded. This place didn't seem like somewhere Margo would hide, or even visit. A world apart from New York City. This is the part of Florida that people just fly over, wondering how anyone could live on this peninsula. I stared at the empty asphalt road, the heat blurring my vision. Ahead, a strip of stores looked like a wavering shopping area in the distant sunlight.
tr: I took a deep breath. The excitement of being somewhere other than school had started to wane. This place didn’t look like somewhere Margo would hide or visit. It was a place completely different from New York. This was Florida, the place people flew over, wondering why anyone would think of settling on this peninsula. I looked at the empty asphalt, the heat was distorting my vision. In the distance, I saw a shopping center shimmering in the bright area, resembling a factory outlet store.
es: I took a deep breath. The excitement of not being at school had started to wane. It didn't seem like a place where Margo would hide, or even want to go. Nothing like New York. It was the Florida you see from a plane and wonder why anyone ever thought to populate this peninsula. I looked at the empty asphalt. The heat distorted my vision. In front of us, I saw a small shopping center shimmering in the distance.

en: “Is that it?” I asked, leaning forward and pointing.
vi: "Over there, right?" I asked, leaning forward to point.
tr: "This one?" I asked, leaning forward and pointing.
es: —Is that it? —I asked, leaning forward and pointing at it.

en: “Must be,” Radar said.
vi: “Of course,” Radar replied.
tr: "It should be so," said Radar.
es: —It must be —Radar answered me.

en: Ben pushed the power button on the stereo, and we all got very quiet as Ben pulled into a parking lot long since reclaimed by the gray sandy dirt. There had once been a sign for these four storefronts. A rusted pole stood about eight feet high by the side of the road. But the sign was long gone, snapped off by a hurricane or an accumulation of decay. The stores themselves had fared little better: it was a single-story building with a flat roof, and bare cinder block was visible in places. Strips of cracked paint wrinkled away from the walls, like insects clinging to a nest. Water stains formed brown abstract paintings between the store windows. The windows were boarded up with warped sheets of particleboard. I was struck by an awful thought, the kind that cannot be taken back once it escapes into the open air of consciousness: it seemed to me that this was not a place you go to live. It was a place you go to die.
vi: Ben pressed the sound system control button, and we were enveloped in silence as Ben pulled the car into a parking lot long claimed by a layer of gray sand. There used to be signs for four stores on this frontage. A rusty pole, about two and a half meters high, was planted by the roadside. But the signs had long since vanished, either blown away by some storm or due to accumulated decay. The row of stores fared slightly better: a single-story building with a flat roof, sparsely dotted with exposed concrete blocks. Strips of peeling paint clung to the walls, like insects desperately holding onto their nests. Water stains painted abstract brown patterns on the window panes. The windows were patched together with plywood sheets. A terrible thought burst into my mind, a thought that couldn't be contained once it had seeped into the atmosphere of awareness: it seemed this was not a place where people came to live. This was a place where people came to die.
tr: When I pressed the radio button and pulled the car into the parking lot that had long been overtaken by gray sandy soil, we all fell silent. Once, signs had been put up for the four stores here.
