A rusted pole about two and a half meters high stood by the side of the road. But the sign had long gone, either blown away by a hurricane or rotted away over time. The stores had held up a bit better: it was a single-story building with a flat roof, and in some places, bare concrete columns could be seen. The cracked paints had shriveled up like insects clinging to a nest. Water stains had formed brown abstract paintings between the display windows. Crooked plywood boards were nailed to the windows. I was struck by a horrifying thought; the kind of thought that, once it entered the skies of consciousness, would not be taken back: This place did not look like the kind of place to live. This was the kind of place to die.
es: Ben pressed the button on the music system and the three of us fell silent as he drove into a parking lot that had long been overtaken by gray sand. At one time, there had been a sign announcing the presence of four stores, because on one side of the road there was a worn-out post over two meters high, but the sign had long since disappeared. A hurricane might have torn it down or it might have rotted away with age. The stores hadn't fared much better. It was a single-story building with a flat roof, and in some places, the concrete blocks were exposed. The layers of paint were peeling off the walls like insects stuck to a nest. Damp stains formed abstract brown patterns between the shop windows. The shop windows were sealed with crooked sheets of chipboard. Suddenly, a horrible idea crossed my mind, one of those ideas you can't shake off once it crosses the threshold of consciousness: it seemed to me that this wasn't a place where one goes to live. It was a place where one goes to die.

en: As soon as the car stopped, my nose and mouth were flooded with the rancid smell of death. I had to swallow back a rush of puke that rose up into the raw soreness in the back of my throat. Only now, after all this lost time, did I realize how terribly I had misunderstood both her game and the prize for winning it.
vi: As soon as the car stopped, my nose and mouth were filled with the pungent smell of death. I had to swallow back the rising nausea that was burning and painful at the back of my throat. Only now, after all the lost time, did I realize how terribly wrong I had been about Margo's game and the reward for the winner.
tr: As soon as the car stopped, my nose and mouth were filled with the disgusting smell of death. I had to swallow the vomit that rose to my throat with raw bitterness. But now, after all this lost time, I realized how terribly I had misunderstood both Margo's game and the reward of winning.
es: As soon as the car stopped, the rancid smell of death invaded my nose and mouth. I had to swallow the mouthful of vomit that painfully rose up my throat. Only then, after having wasted so much time, did I understand how badly I had misinterpreted both Margo's game and the prize for winning it.

en: I get out of the car and Ben is standing next to me, and Radar next to him. And I know all at once that this isn’t funny, that this hasn’t been prove-to-me-you’re-good-enough-to-hang-out-with-me. I can hear Margo that night as we drove around Orlando. I can hear her saying to me, “I don’t want some kids to find me swarmed with flies on a Saturday morning in Jefferson Park.” Not wanting to be found by some kids in Jefferson Park isn’t the same thing as not wanting to die.
vi: I got out of the car, Ben stood next to me, and Radar next to him. I immediately understood that this was not fun at all, that it was not about proving-you-have-the-guts-to-hang-out-with-me. I heard Margo's voice that night when we drove around Orlando. I heard her say to me, "I don't want some kid to find me all covered in flies and ants on a Saturday morning in Jefferson Park." Not wanting to be found by kids in Jefferson Park does not mean not wanting to die.
tr: I am getting out of the car, Ben is standing next to me, and Radar is next to him. Suddenly, I realize that this isn't fun, "hanging out with me I understand that I am not something like "prove that you are good enough." I can hear Margo while wandering around Orlando that night. I can hear her saying to me, “I don’t want a few kids to find me in Jefferson Park on a Saturday morning with flies swarming over me.” Not wanting to be found in Jefferson Park by a few kids is not the same as not wanting to die.
es: I get out of the car. Ben stands next to me and Radar next to Ben. And suddenly I know that this isn't funny, that it's not about proving that I deserve to go out with her. I can hear Margo's words the night we roamed around Orlando. I hear her telling me: "I don't want some kids to find me covered in flies on a Saturday morning in Jefferson Park." Not wanting some kids to find you in Jefferson Park is not the same as not wanting to die.

en: There is no evidence that anyone has been here in a long time except for the smell, that sickly sour stench designed to keep the living from the dead. I tell myself she can’t smell like that, but of course she can. We all can. I hold my forearm up to my nose so I can smell sweat and skin and anything but death.
vi: There was nothing to indicate that anyone had been here for a long time, except for the smell, that sour, pungent, sickly smell that kept the living away from the dead. I told myself that Margo couldn't possibly smell like that, but of course she could. All of us could smell like that. I raised my arm to my nose to smell my sweat and skin, anything but the smell of death.
tr: Aside from the smell, this morbidly sharp stench designed to keep the living away from the dead, there is no evidence that anyone has been here for a long time. I tell myself that Margo couldn't smell like this, but of course, she could. We all could. I lift my arm to my nose to catch the scent of sweat and skin, anything other than death.
es: It doesn't seem like anyone has been here for a long time, except for the smell, that rancid and sweetish stench that distinguishes the dead from the living. I tell myself that Margo can't smell like that, but of course she can. We all can. I bring my arm to my nose to smell the sweat, the skin, and anything but death.

en: “MARGO?” Radar calls. A mockingbird perched on the rusted gutter of the building spits out two syllables in response. “MARGO!” he shouts again. Nothing. He digs a parabola into the sand with his foot and sighs. “Shit.”
vi: “MARGO?” Radar called. A mockingbird perched on the rusty gutter of the building, chirping back two syllables. “MARGO!” Radar called out again. Nothing. Radar kicked at the sand in frustration, cursing, “Damn it.”
tr: Radar calls out, "MARGO?" A mockingbird perched on the building's rusty grate responds with a two-syllable scream. Radar shouts again, "MARGO!" Nothing. He digs a parabola in the sand with his foot and sighs. "Damn it."
es: —MARGO? —shouts Radar. A bird perched on the rusty gutter of the building releases two syllables as a response. —MARGO! —Radar shouts again. Nothing. He kicks the sand and sighs. —Shit.

en: Standing before this building, I learn something about fear. I learn that it is not the idle fantasies of someone who maybe wants something important to happen to him, even if the important thing is horrible. It is not the disgust of seeing a dead stranger, and not the breathlessness of hearing a shotgun pumped outside of Becca Arrington’s house. This cannot be addressed by breathing exercises. This fear bears no analogy to any fear I knew before. This is the basest of all possible emotions, the feeling that was with us before we existed, before this building existed, before the earth existed. This is the fear that made fish crawl out onto dry land and evolve lungs, the fear that teaches us to run, the fear that makes us bury our dead.
vi: Standing in front of this building, I understand something about fear. I understand that it is not the dull hallucination of someone who perhaps wants something significant to happen to them, even if that significant thing is truly terrifying. It is not the feeling of horror when seeing a stranger die, nor the breathless moment when hearing the sound of gunfire from Becca Arrington's house. It cannot be calmed by breathing exercises. This fear bears no resemblance to the fears I have known before. It lies in the deepest place of all possible emotions, a feeling that follows us from before we existed, before this building existed, even before the earth existed. It is the fear that pushed fish from dry land to evolve lungs, the fear that taught us to run, the fear that makes us bury the deceased.
tr: While standing in front of this building, I am learning something about fear. I am learning that fear is not the empty fantasies of someone who wants something significant to happen to them, even if that significant thing is terrifying. Fear is not the disgust of seeing a stranger's corpse or the breathtaking sound of a gunshot outside Becca Arrington's house. This cannot be managed with breathing exercises. This fear is incomparable to the fears I have known before. This is the most fundamental of all possible emotions, a feeling that was with us before our existence, before this building existed, before the world existed. This is the fear that drove fish to crawl onto land and develop lungs, the fear that taught us to run, the fear that made us bury our dead.
es: Here, in front of this building, I learn something about fear. I learn that it is not the banal fantasies of someone who might want something important to happen to them, even if that important thing is terrible. It is not the disgust of seeing a stranger dead, nor the shortness of breath when you hear a shotgun being loaded in front of Becca Arrington's house. This fear is not resolved with breathing exercises. This is not comparable to any fear I have felt before. It is the lowest of all possible emotions, you feel that it was with us before you existed, before this building existed, before the Earth existed. It is the fear that made fish come out of the water and develop lungs, the fear that teaches us to run, the fear that makes us bury our dead.

en: The smell leaves me seized by desperate panic—panic not like my lungs are out of air, but like the atmosphere itself is out of air. I think maybe the reason I have spent most of my life being afraid is that I have been trying to prepare myself, to train my body for the real fear when it comes. But I am not prepared.
vi: That smell gripped me in a panic of despair—not panic as if my lungs had run out of air, but as if the entire biosphere had run out of air. I think the reason I worry most of the time is that I try to prepare myself, training my body to be ready to fight against the true fear when it comes. But I am not ready.
tr: Despair leaves me seized by a panic filled with helplessness... not a panic like my lungs running out of air, but a panic as if the atmosphere itself is running out of air. I think I spent most of my life in fear because when real fear came I was trying to prepare myself for him, to train my body. But I'm not ready.
es: The smell causes a desperate panic to take hold of me. Not like when my lungs run out of air, but like when the very atmosphere runs out of air. I think the reason I've spent most of my life scared is perhaps because I was trying to prepare and train my body for when real fear arrived. But I am not prepared.

en: “Bro, we should leave,” Ben says. “We should call the cops or something.” We have not looked at each other yet. We are all still looking at this building, this long-abandoned building that cannot possibly hold anything but corpses.
vi: “We should go, guys,” Ben spoke up. “We should call the police or something like that.” We still hadn't looked at each other. The three of us kept staring at the building, the place that had been abandoned for so long it couldn't hide anything except corpses.
tr: “Brother, we must go,” says Ben. “We should call the police or something.” We haven't looked at each other yet. We are still looking at the building, this building that has been abandoned for a long time, likely harboring nothing but corpses.
es: —Colleague, we should leave —says Ben—. We should call the cops or whoever. We still haven't looked at each other. The three of us continue looking at the building, an abandoned building that has been vacant for a long time and can only house corpses.

en: “No,” Radar says. “No no no no no. We call if there’s something to call about. She left the address for Q. Not for the cops. We have to find a way in there.”
vi: "No," Radar shouted. "No no no no no. We'll call when we have something to report. Margo left this address for Q. Not for the police. We have to find a way to get in there."
tr: “No,” says Radar. “No no no. If there’s something to search for, we’ll search. He left the address for Q. Not for the police, we have to find a way to get inside.”
es: —No —says Radar—. No no no no no. We'll call them if there's a reason to call them. She left the address to Q, not to the cops. We need to find a way to get in.

en: “In there?” Ben says dubiously.
vi: "In there?" Ben asked suspiciously.
tr: "Inside?" says Ben skeptically.
es: —Enter? —asks Ben doubtfully.

en: I clap Ben on the back, and for the first time all day, the three of us are looking not forward but at one another. That makes it bearable. Something about seeing them makes me feel as if she is not dead until we find her. “Yeah, in there,” I say.
vi: I patted Ben on the back, and for the first time all day, the three of us didn't look forward but turned to look at each other. That made it bearable. When I looked at my two friends, something told me that Margo wouldn't be dead until we found her. "Yes, let's go in there," I said.
tr: I pat Ben on the back and for the first time all day, the three of us look at each other instead of ahead. This makes the situation bearable. Something about seeing them makes me feel like Margo won't die until we find her. "Yes, inside," I say.
es: I give Ben a pat on the back, and for the first time all day, we don't look ahead, but instead, we look at each other. It makes it more bearable. When I look at them, something makes me feel that Margo isn't dead if we haven't found her. —Yes, come in —I say.

en: I don’t know who she is anymore, or who she was, but I need to find her.
vi: I no longer know who Margo is, or who she ever was, but I need to find her.
tr: I no longer know who Margo is or was, but I need to find her.
es: I no longer know who Margo is, or who she was, but I have to find her.

tr: We walk around the back of the building and find nothing but four steel doors and dwarf palms dotting the sixty-green grassy area.

en: We walk around the back of the building and find four locked steel doors and nothing but ranch land, patches of palmettos dotting an expanse of gold-green grass. The stench is worse here, and I feel afraid to keep walking. Ben and Radar are just behind me, to my right and left. We form a triangle together, walking slowly, our eyes scanning the area.
vi: We went to the back of the building and saw four locked iron doors. There was nothing but wasteland, with a few clumps of palm trees scattered across the vast half-yellow, half-green grass. The musty smell here was even stronger, making me hesitant to go further. Ben and Radar were right behind me, to my left and right. The three of us formed a triangular formation, walking slowly, eyes straining to observe our surroundings.
tr: We walk around the back of the building and find nothing but four steel doors and dwarf palms dotting the sixty-green grassy area. The foul smell is worse here, and I feel afraid to keep walking. Ben and Radar are right behind me, to my right and left. We form a triangle together, walking slowly, our eyes scanning the surroundings.
es: We circled the building to the back and found four closed steel doors, and nothing else except for land with dwarf palm trees scattered across an expanse of green grass with golden hues. It still smells worse here and I'm more scared to keep walking. Ben and Radar are right behind me, to my right and left, forming a triangle. We move slowly as we scan the area with our eyes.

en: “It’s a raccoon!” Ben shouts. “Oh, thank God. It’s a raccoon. Jesus.” Radar and I walk away from the building to join him near a shallow drainage ditch. A huge, bloated raccoon with matted hair lies dead, no visible trauma, its fur falling off, one of its ribs exposed. Radar turns away and heaves, but nothing comes out. I lean down next to him and put my arm between his shoulder blades, and when he gets his breath back, he says, “I am so fucking glad to see that dead fucking raccoon.”
vi: “A raccoon!” Ben shouted. “Oh, thank God, a raccoon, heavens and earth!” Radar and I immediately moved away from the building, towards where Ben was standing by a shallow drainage ditch. A huge raccoon, with thick matted fur, lay dead and bloated, with no obvious wounds, its fur decomposing, revealing a rib bone. Radar turned away and gagged, but didn't vomit. I bent down, wrapping my arms around its shoulders. When its breathing returned to normal, Radar said, “I’m terribly relieved that it’s the corpse of a terribly disgusting raccoon.”
tr: “It's a raccoon!” Ben shouts. “Oh, thank God. A raccoon. My God.” We move away from the building to join Ben by a shallow drainage ditch with Radar. A huge, swollen raccoon lies dead with matted fur, no visible trauma, its fur falling out, one of its ribs exposed. Radar turns around and retches, but nothing comes out. I lean down next to Radar and place my hand between his shoulder blades, and as he breathes, he says, “Damn, I'm so glad to see that damn dead raccoon.”
es: —A raccoon! —shouts Ben—. Thank you, my God. It's a raccoon. Shit. Radar and I move away from the building and head towards the animal, which is next to a shallow drainage ditch. A huge, swollen raccoon with matted fur lies dead, with no visible wounds. Its fur has fallen off, exposing a rib. Radar steps back gagging, but doesn't actually vomit. I lean down next to him and place my hand between his shoulder blades. —I'm so glad to see that damn raccoon dead —he tells me when he catches his breath.

en: But even so, I cannot picture her here alive. It occurs to me that the Whitman could be a suicide note. I think about things she highlighted: “To die is different from what any one supposed, and luckier.” “I bequeath myself to the dirt to grow from the grass I love, / If you want me again look for me under your bootsoles.” For a moment, I feel a flash of hope when I think about the last line of the poem: “I stop some where waiting for you.” But then I think that the I does not need to be a person. The I can also be a body.
vi: Even so, I still can't imagine Margo living here. I suddenly realized that Whitman's verses might be a suicide note. I thought of the lines she had marked: "And death is not what people imagine, and it is a blessing." “I return myself to the earth, nurturing the grasses I love, / If you want me, look for me under the soles of your boots.” In an instant, I saw a glimmer of hope when thinking about the last line of the poem: “Somewhere, I stop and wait for you.” But then I thought that I don't necessarily have to be a human being. I could also be a corpse.
tr: But despite everything, I can't imagine Margo alive here. The thought that Whitman's poem might be a suicide note crosses my mind. I think about the things she underlined: "To die is different from what anyone supposed, and luckier." "I bequeath myself to the dirt to grow from the grass I love, / If you want me again, look for me under your boot-soles." Thinking about the last line of the poem, I feel a wave of hope for a moment: "I stop somewhere waiting for you "you." But then I think that the word "I" does not have to be a person. "I" could also be a corpse.
es: But, even so, I can't imagine her alive here. It occurs to me that the Whitman could be a suicide note. I think of verses she had marked: "And to die is different from what anyone supposed, and luckier." "Let the mud be my inheritance, I want to grow from the grass I love; / If you want to find me, look for me under the soles of your shoes." For a moment I feel a flash of hope thinking about the last verse of the poem: "I stop somewhere waiting for you." But then I think that this first person doesn't have to be a person. It could also be a body.

en: Radar has walked away from the raccoon and is tugging on the handle of one of the four locked steel doors. I feel like praying for the dead—saying Kaddish for this raccoon—but I don’t even know how. I’m so sorry for him, and so sorry for how happy I am to see him like this.
vi: Radar stayed away from the raccoon, tugging at the handle of one of the four locked iron doors. I felt like praying for the departed—reciting a Kaddish for this raccoon—but I didn't even know how to do it. I mourned the animal and regretted feeling a silent joy at seeing it like that.
tr: Radar moves away from the raccoon and hangs onto the handle of one of the four steel doors. I actually want to pray for the dead, as if I should recite Kaddish for this raccoon, but I don't even know how to do it. I feel very sorry for it and I feel very sorry for being so happy to see it this way,
es: Radar has moved away from the raccoon and pulls the handle of one of the four steel doors. I feel the urge to pray for the dead, to recite the Kaddish for this raccoon, but I don't even know it. I feel very sorry for him and I feel very sorry for being so glad to see him like this.

en: “It’s giving a little,” Radar shouts to us. “Come help.”
vi: "We need more force," Radar called. "Help me again."
tr: “It's opening a bit,” Radar shouts towards us. “Come and help.”
es: —It's giving way a little —Radar shouts to us—. Come and help me.

en: Ben and I both put our arms around Radar’s waist and pull back. He puts his foot up against the wall to give himself extra leverage as he pulls, and then all at once they collapse onto me, Radar’s sweat-soaked T-shirt pressed up against my face. For a moment, I’m excited, thinking we’re in. But then I see Radar holding the door handle. I scramble up and look at the door. Still locked.
vi: Ben and I wrapped our arms around Radar's waist and pulled him back. He braced his feet against the wall for extra leverage, and then both of us fell heavily onto me. Radar's sweat-soaked back pressed against my face. For a moment, I was thrilled, thinking we had made it in. But then I saw Radar holding the door handle. I quickly got up to look at the door. Still firmly closed.
tr: We wrap our arms around Radar's waist and pull the door back with Ben. Radar braces his foot against the wall to give himself extra strength while pulling, then suddenly they collapse on top of me, Radar's sweat-soaked shirt sticking to my face. For a moment, I get excited, thinking we've made it inside. But then I see Radar holding the doorknob. With difficulty, I get up and look at the door. It's still locked.
es: Ben and I grabbed Radar by the waist and pulled him. Radar placed a foot on the wall to give himself more momentum, and suddenly the two of them fell on top of me, and I found myself with Radar's sweat-soaked shirt in my face. For a moment I got excited, thinking we had done it, but then I realized that Radar had the door handle in his hand. I got up and took a look at the door: it was still closed.

en: “Piece of shit forty-year-old goddamned doorknob,” Radar says. I’ve never heard him talk like this before.
vi: “This damn forty-year-old door handle!” Radar cursed. I had never heard it speak like that before.
tr: “Damn, you forty-year-old cursed door handle,” says Radar. I had never heard him talk like that before.
es: —Damn shitty apple from the year of the pear —grumbles Radar. I've never heard him speak like that.

en: “It’s okay,” I say. “There’s a way. There has to be.”
vi: "It's okay," I said. "There's a way. There has to be a way."
tr: “No problem,” I say. “There is a way. There must be.”
es: —Calm down —I tell him—. There must be a way. There has to be one.

en: We walk all the way around to the front of the building. No doors, no holes, no visible tunnels. But I need in. Ben and Radar try to peel the slabs of particleboard from the windows, but they’re all nailed shut. Radar kicks at the board, but it doesn’t give. Ben turns back to me. “There’s no glass behind one of these boards,” he says, and then he starts jogging away from the building, his sneakers splashing sand as he goes.
vi: We circled back to the front of the building. No doors, no openings, no sign of an underground passage. But I needed to get inside. Ben and Radar tried to pry the plywood off the windows, but everything was nailed down tight. Radar kicked the plywood to no avail. Ben turned back to me and said, "There's no glass behind the plywood," and he started to back up, his sneakers kicking up sand with each step.
tr: We walk the entire way back towards the front of the building. There is no door, no hole, no visible tunnel. But I need to get inside. Ben and Radar are trying to remove the boards from the window, but they are all nailed down. Radar kicks the board, but it doesn't give way. Ben turns to me. "There is no glass behind any of these panels," he says, then starts running away from the building, his sneakers kicking up sand as he goes.
es: We go around to the front of the building. We don't see doors, holes, or tunnels. But I have to get in. Ben and Radar try to pull the plywood sheets off the storefronts, but they are nailed down. Radar kicks them, but they don't budge. Ben comes back to my side. —Behind one of those panels, there is no glass —he tells me. And he runs off. As he runs, his shoes scatter the sand.

en: I give him a confused look. “I’m going to bust through the particleboard,” he explains.
vi: I didn't understand anything, looking at Ben questioningly. "I will break through that plywood," he explained.
tr: I give her a look that shows my confusion. “I will break the board,” she explains.
es: I look at him confused. —I am going to cross the plates —he explains to me.

en: “You can’t do that.” He is the smallest of our light trio. If anyone tries to smash through the boarded-up windows, it should be me.
vi: “You can't do it.” Ben was the smallest of the three. If someone was needed to break through those boarded-up windows, it should be me.
tr: "You can't do it." I, the smallest of our light trio. If someone is going to try to break the boards, it should be me.
es: —You won't be able to. He is the least corpulent of the three, which is saying something. If anyone has to try to get through the display window panels, it should be me.

en: He balls his hands into fists and then extends his fingers out. As I walk toward him, he starts talking to me. “When my mom was trying to keep me from getting beat up in third grade, she put me in tae kwon do. I only went to like three classes, and I only learned one thing, but the thing comes in handy sometimes: we watched this tae kwon do master punch through a thick wooden block, and we were all like, dude, how did he do that, and he told us that if you move as though your hand will go through the block, and if you believe that your hand will go through the block, then it will.”
vi: Ben clenched his hand into a fist and then stretched out his fingers. As I approached, he began to tell. "When I was in third grade, my mom tried to prevent me from being bullied by enrolling me in a taekwondo class. I think I only attended three sessions and learned just one move, but it was occasionally quite effective: the kids watched the taekwondo master punch through a thick wooden board, and they all marveled, asking how he did it. The master told the class that if we moved as if our hand would go through the board, and if we believed that our hand would go through, then it surely would."
tr: I clench my hands into fists, then extend my fingers. As I walk towards him, he starts talking to me. “When my mom tried to protect me from being beaten up in third grade, she enrolled me in taekwondo. I only went to about three lessons and learned just one thing, but sometimes that one thing works: We would watch the taekwondo master punch through a thick board, and we would all look like, dude, how did he do that, and the master told us if you move your hand as if it’s going through the board and believe that your hand will go through, then it will happen.”
es: Clench your fists and then extend your fingers. As I walk towards him, he starts to say to me: —In third grade, my mother tried to stop them from hitting me by signing me up for taekwondo. I only went to three classes, and I only learned one thing, but every now and then it's useful. We saw the taekwondo master break a thick block of wood and we all thought, dude, how did he do that, and he told us that if you act as if your hand is going to go through the block of wood, and if you believe that your hand is going to go through that block, then it goes through.

en: I’m about to refute this idiotic logic when he takes off, running past me in a blur. His acceleration continues as he approaches the board, and then utterly without fear, he leaps up at the last possible second, twists his body sideways—his shoulder out to bear the brunt of the force—and slams into the wood. I half-expect him to burst through and leave a Ben-shaped cutout, like a cartoon. Instead, he bounces off the board and falls onto his ass in a patch of bright grass amid the sea of sandy dirt. Ben rolls onto his side, rubbing his shoulder. “It broke,” he announces.
vi: I was about to refute that childish logic, when Ben took off, zooming past me like a blur. The closer he got to the wooden plank, the faster he accelerated, and finally, without any hesitation, he jumped at the last second, twisting his body—shoulder first to absorb the impact—and crashed into the wood. I half-expected him to break through the plank and leave a Ben-shaped hole, just like in a cartoon. But he bounced off the wood, landing flat on the bright patch of grass, in a cloud of dust. Ben rolled over, rubbing his shoulder. "It's broken," he declared.
tr: As he springs into action and runs past me in a blur, I am about to dismiss his foolish logic. He continues to accelerate as he approaches the board and then, completely fearlessly, at the very last possible second, he leaps into the air, twists his body sideways with his shoulder out to bear the brunt of the impact, and crashes into the board. Part of me expects Ben to smash through the board and leave a Ben-shaped hole in it like a cartoon character. Instead, he bounces off the board and lands on his backside on a bright patch of grass in the middle of the sandy soil sea. Ben rolls to the side, rubbing his shoulder. “It broke,” he declares.
es: I am about to refute that absurd logic when he starts running and passes in front of me like an arrow. He keeps accelerating as he approaches the plank and then, fearlessly, at the last second, he jumps, twists his body, throws out his shoulder to bear the brunt of the impact, and lands on the wood. I almost expect him to go through it and leave his silhouette cut out, like in cartoons. But he bounces off the plank and lands on his butt in a grassy area in the middle of the sand. Ben turns to one side, rubbing his shoulder. —It has broken —he says.

en: I assume he means his shoulder as I race toward him, but then he stands up, and I’m looking at a Ben-high crack in the particle-board. I start kicking at it, and the crack spreads horizontally, and then Radar and I get our fingers inside the crack and start tugging. I squint to keep the sweat from burning my eyes, and pull with all my force back and forth until the crack starts to make a jagged opening. Radar and I urge it on with silent work, until eventually he has to take a break and Ben replaces him. Finally we are able to punch a big chunk of the board into the minimall. I climb in feetfirst, landing blindly onto what feels like a stack of papers.
vi: I think Ben meant to say his shoulder was broken and rushed over, but then he stood up, and I saw a Ben-height crack on the plywood. I started kicking at it, the crack split open, then Radar and I managed to wedge our fingers into the crack and began pulling hard. I squinted to keep the sweat from running into my eyes and stinging them, pulling and pushing to widen the crack. Radar and I gritted our teeth and kept at it until Radar had to take a break to catch his breath and Ben took over. Finally, the three of us managed to make a sizable hole in the plywood to get inside this mini shopping area. I climbed in, blindly stepping onto something that felt like a pile of papers.
tr: As I run towards her, I assume she means her shoulder, but then she stands up and I look at the crack in the particle board at Ben's height. I start kicking, and the crack widens horizontally, then Radar and I start pulling ourselves up by sticking our fingers into the crack. Squinting to prevent the sweat from stinging my eyes, I look and swing back and forth with all my strength until I start creating a jagged opening. With silent effort, Radar and I press against the opening until he finally needs a break, then Ben takes his place. At last, we manage to punch a large, hefty piece of the board into the store. My feet climb first, and I blindly land on something that feels like a pile of paper.
es: I take for granted that he is talking about the shoulder and run towards him, but he gets up and I see a crack in the particle board at his height. I start kicking it and the crack expands horizontally. Then Radar and I stick our fingers into the crack and pull. I squint to avoid getting sweat in my eyes and pull with all my strength until the crack starts to form a jagged opening. We continue in silence until Radar needs to rest and Ben takes his place. In the end, we manage to throw a large piece of the board inside the place. I stick my feet in and land blindly on what seems to be a pile of papers.

en: The hole we’ve carved into this building gives a little light, but I can’t even make out the dimensions of the room, or whether there is a ceiling. The air in here is so stale and hot that inhaling and exhaling feel identical.
vi: A bit of light seeped inside through the hole we had just made, but I still couldn't make out the direction, nor could I tell if there was a ceiling above. The air in here was so stifling and oppressive that inhaling and exhaling felt almost the same.
tr: The hole we carved into the building lets in a bit of light, but I can't even make out the dimensions of the space or whether there is a ceiling. The air inside is so stale and hot that breathing in or out feels the same.
es: Through the hole we have opened, some light enters, but I cannot see the dimensions of the room, nor if there is a ceiling. The air is so warm and stale that inhaling produces the same sensation as exhaling.

en: I turn around and my chin hits Ben’s forehead. I find myself whispering, even though there’s no reason to. “Do you have a—”
vi: I turned around and my chin hit Ben's forehead. I whispered, even though there was no reason to whisper like that. "You have a–"
tr: I turn around and my chin hits Ben's forehead. Even though there is no reason, I find myself whispering. "Is there something..."
es: I turn and bump my chin against Ben's forehead. I find myself speaking in whispers, even though there's no reason for it. —Do you have a…?

en: “No,” he whispers back before I can finish. “Radar, did you bring a flashlight?”
vi: "No," Ben whispered back before I finished my sentence. "Radar, do you have a flashlight?"
tr: Before I can finish my sentence, Ben whispers in response, "No." "Radar, did you bring the flashlight?"
es: —No —he also answers me in whispers before I have finished saying it—. Radar, did you bring a flashlight?

en: I hear Radar coming through the hole. “I have one on my key chain. It’s not much, though.”
vi: I heard the sound of Radar climbing in. “There’s one on my keychain, but it’s not very bright.”
tr: I hear Radar going through the hole. "I have one on my keychain. It's not a big deal, though."
es: I hear Radar coming in through the hole. —I have one on the keychain, but it's not a big deal. Turn on the light.

en: The light comes on, and I still can’t see very well, but I can tell we’ve stepped into a big room filled with a labyrinth of metal shelves. The papers on the floor are pages from an old day-by-day calendar, the days scattered through the room, all of them yellowing and mouse-bit. I wonder if this might once have been a little bookstore, although it’s been decades since these shelves held anything but dust.
vi: The light shone in, I still couldn't see anything clearly, but it could be said that we were in a large room, filled with a labyrinth of iron shelves. The pile of papers on the floor was from a daily torn calendar, the scattered pages falling all over the room, all yellowed and gnawed by mice. I wondered if this place had ever been a small bookstore, though decades had passed and there was nothing on the shelves but dust.
tr: The light is on and I still can't see very well, but I can understand that we have stepped into a large room filled with a labyrinth of metal shelves. The papers on the floor are pages from an old calendar, days scattered around the room, all yellowed and gnawed by mice. I wonder if this place was once a small bookstore, however, these shelves haven't held anything but dust for decades.
es: I still can't see very well, but it's clear that we have entered a large room with a labyrinth of metal shelves. The papers on the floor are pages from an old calendar. The days are scattered around the room, all of them yellowed and gnawed by mice. I wonder if this could have been a bookstore, although the shelves have housed nothing but dust for decades.

en: We fall into line behind Radar. I hear something creak above us, and we all stop moving. I try to swallow the panic. I can hear each of Radar’s and Ben’s breaths, their shuffling footsteps. I want out of here, but that could be Margo creaking for all I know. It could also be crack addicts.
vi: We walked in single file behind Radar. I heard a creaking sound above, and we all stopped. Trying to swallow the feeling of panic, I could hear every breath of Radar and Ben, every rustling step. I wanted to get out of this place, but it could be Margo signaling to me. It could also be the cunning addicts.
tr: We line up behind Radar. I hear something creaking above us and we all stop moving. I try to suppress my panic. I can hear Radar and Ben's breaths and my feet scraping the ground. I want to get out of here, but it could just be Margo who's creaking. Or cocaine addicts.
es: We line up behind Radar. I hear something creak above us and the three of us stand still. I try to swallow my panic. I hear Radar and Ben's breathing, their shuffling footsteps. I want to get out of here, but the creaking could be Margo. It could also be crack addicts.

en: “Just the building settling,” Radar whispers, but he seems less sure than usual. I stand there unable to move. After a moment, I hear Ben’s voice. “The last time I was this scared, I peed myself.”
vi: “It's just the building settling down after that little shake,” Radar whispered, but he didn't sound as confident as usual. I stood frozen. A moment later, I heard Ben's voice. “The last time I was this scared, I nearly peed my pants.”
tr: “The floors are settling,” whispers Radar, but he seems less sure than usual. I stand there unable to move. A minute later, I hear Ben’s voice. “The last time I was this scared, I peed my pants.”
es: —They are the foundations of the building —whispers Radar, although he seems less sure than usual. I stay where I am, unable to move. At that moment, I hear Ben's voice. —The last time I was this scared, I peed myself.

en: “The last time I was this scared,” Radar says, “I actually had to face a Dark Lord in order to make the world safe for wizards.”
vi: "The last time I was this scared," Radar chimed in, "I actually had to face the Dark Lord for the safety of the wizarding world."
tr: “The last time I was this scared,” says Radar, “I had to face the Dark Lord to make the world safe for wizards.”
es: —The last time I was this scared —said Radar— I had to face a Dark Lord to keep the wizards safe.

en: I made a feeble attempt. “The last time I was this scared I had to sleep in Mommy’s room.”
vi: I made a feeble effort. "The last time I was this scared, I had to sleep in my mother's room."
tr: I am making a weak attempt. "The last time I was this scared, I had to sleep in my mother's room."
es: I made a feeble attempt: —The last time I was this scared, I had to sleep in my mother's room.

en: Ben chuckles. “Q, if I were you, I would get that scared Every. Single. Night.”
vi: Ben chuckled. "Q, if I were you, I would want to be this scared Every. Night."
tr: I'm giggling. "Q, if I were you, I would always be that scared. Every. Night."
es: Ben lets out a chuckle. —Q, if I were you, I would be so scared every night.

en: I’m not up for laughing, but their laughter makes the room feel safer, and so we begin to explore. We walk through each row of shelves, finding nothing but a few copies of Reader’s Digest from the 1970s lying on the floor. After a while, I find my eyes adjusting to the darkness, and in the gray light we start walking in different directions at different speeds.
vi: I wasn't in the mood to laugh, but the laughter of the two made the room feel safer, and we began to explore. The three of us walked past each row of iron shelves, seeing nothing but a few issues of Reader’s Digest from the 1970s on the floor. After a while, our eyes adjusted to the darkness, and in the dim light, we began to move in different directions, at different paces.
tr: I'm not in the mood to laugh, but their laughter makes the room feel safer, and so we begin to investigate. We examine each row of shelves and find nothing but a few issues of Readers Digest from the 1970s lying on the floor. After a while, my eyes adjust to the darkness, and in the gray light, we start walking in different directions at different speeds.
es: I'm not in the mood to laugh, but their laughter makes the room seem safe, so we start to explore it. We pass between the rows of shelves, but the only thing we find are some copies of Reader's Digest from the seventies lying on the floor. After a while, my eyes have adjusted to the darkness and half in the dark we start to walk in different directions and at different speeds.

en: “No one leaves the room until everyone leaves the room,” I whisper, and they whisper okay’s back. I get to a side wall of the room and find the first evidence that someone has been here since everyone left. A jagged semicircular, waist-high tunnel has been cut out of the wall. The words TROLL HOLE have been spray-painted in orange above the hole, with a helpful arrow pointing down to the hole. “Guys,” Radar says, so loud that the spell breaks for just a moment. I follow his voice and find him standing by the opposite wall, his flashlight illuminating another Troll Hole. The graffiti doesn’t look particularly like Margo’s, but it’s hard to tell for sure. I’ve only seen her spray-paint a single letter.
vi: “No one leaves this room until we all leave together, okay?” I whispered the agreement, and the other two whispered their consent. I approached a partition wall in the room and discovered the first evidence that someone had entered here after the building was abandoned. A jagged semicircular hole, about waist-high, had been chiseled through the wall. The words DEMON HOLE were spray-painted in orange above it, with an arrow helpfully pointing down to the hole below. “Hey,” Radar called out, loud enough that it seemed to shatter for a moment. I walked towards the sound and saw Radar standing in front of another section of wall, flashlight illuminating another Demon Hole. The graffiti style didn’t particularly resemble Margo’s, but it was hard to be certain. I had only seen her spray-paint a single letter.
tr: “No one leaves the room until everyone is mirrored,” I whisper, and they whisper back in agreement. I move towards one of the walls of the room and find the first evidence that someone has been here since it was abandoned. A semi-circular, indented, waist-high tunnel has been dug into the wall. Above, the words DWARF HOLE are written in orange spray paint, accompanied by an auxiliary arrow pointing to the hole below. “Kids,” says Radar, so loudly that the spell is broken for just a moment. I follow his voice and find him standing against the opposite wall, his flashlight illuminating another Dwarf Hole. The graffiti doesn't particularly look like it belongs to Margo, but it's hard to say for sure. After all, I had seen her write a single letter with spray paint.
es: —Let no one leave until we all leave —I whisper. They whisper to me that they agree. I go towards a side wall of the room and find the first evidence that someone has been here after everyone else had left. On the wall, at waist height, there is a more or less semicircular tunnel. Above the hole, the words TROLL HOLE are written in orange spray, along with a helpful arrow pointing to the hole. —Guys —says Radar so loudly that for a moment the spell is broken. I follow his voice and find him on the other side of the wall, illuminating another Troll Hole with the flashlight. The graffiti doesn't look much like Margo's, but I couldn't be sure. I've only seen her paint one letter.

en: Radar shines the light through the hole as I duck down and lead the way through. This room is entirely empty except for a rolled carpet in one corner. As the flashlight scans the floor, I can see glue stains on the concrete from where the carpet had once been. Across the room, I can just make out another hole cut into the wall, this time without the graffiti.
vi: Radar shone the light through the hole while I bent down and crawled through first. The room on this side was completely empty, except for a rolled-up carpet in the corner. When the light shone on the floor, I saw glue streaks still on the concrete, where there must have been a carpet before. Looking across the room, I saw another vent hole on the wall, this time without any writing.
tr: Radar shines the light into the hole, and I crouch down and go inside. This room is completely empty except for a rolled-up rug in one corner. As the flashlight scans the area, I can see adhesive stains on the concrete where a carpet once was. On the opposite side of the room, I can see just another hole dug into the wall, but this time there is no writing on the wall.
es: Radar focuses the flashlight towards the hole, and I crouch down and enter first. The only thing in the room is a rolled-up carpet in a corner. The flashlight scans the floor and I see glue stains on the concrete, where the carpet used to be. At the back of the room, I discover another hole in the wall, this time without graffiti.

en: I crawl through that Troll Hole into a room lined with clothing racks, the stainless-steel poles still bolted into walls wine-stained with water damage. This room is better lit, and it takes me a moment to realize it’s because there are several holes in the roof—tar paper hangs down, and I can see places where the roof sags against exposed steel girders.
vi: I crawled through that Devil's Hole into a room with rows of clothes hooks, the stainless steel posts still sturdy amidst the water-stained, patchy walls. This room was brighter; it took me a moment to realize it was because of several holes in the roof—the tarred paper had worn away, and I could see the spots where the roof pressed against the now-exposed iron beams.
tr: I crawl through the Dwarf Hole into a room lined with clothes hangers, stainless steel poles still bearing water stains It remains attached to the walls. This room gets better light, and it doesn't take me long to realize that it's because there are a lot of holes in the roof... The tarred paper is hanging down, and I can see the places where the steel beams are exposed in the roof.
es: I crawl through that Troll Hole into a room with rows of clothing racks. The stainless steel hangers are still hanging on the walls with wine-colored and damp stains. This room is more illuminated, and it takes me a moment to realize that it's because there are several holes in the ceiling. The asphalt fabric is hanging down, and I see parts where the ceiling is sagging over exposed iron beams.

en: “Souvenir store,” Ben whispers in front of me, and I know immediately he is right.
vi: “Souvenir shop,” Ben whispered in front of me, and I immediately realized he was right.
tr: In front of me, Ben whispers, "Gift shop," and I immediately realize he is right.
es: —A souvenir shop —whispers Ben in front of me. And at that moment I realize that he is right.

en: In the middle of the room five display cases form a pentagon. The glass that once kept the tourists from their tourist crap has mostly been shattered and lies in shards around the cases. The gray paint peels off the wall in odd and beautiful patterns, each cracked polygon of paint a snowflake of decay.
vi: In the middle of the room, there were five display cabinets arranged in a pentagon shape. The glass that once separated tourists from the useless souvenirs was mostly shattered, with shards of glass scattered around the cabinets. The gray paint peeled off the walls into amusing patterns, each cracked polygon forming the shape of a withered snowflake.
tr: The five display cases in the middle of the room form a pentagon. The glass that once kept tourists away from tourist knick-knacks is mostly shattered. Gray paint is peeling off the wall with strange and beautiful patterns, each crack in the paint resembling a snowflake formed by decay.
es: In the middle of the room, five display cases form a pentagon. The glass that once separated tourists from their tourist trinkets is shattered on the floor, around the display cases. The gray paint peels off the walls, forming beautiful patterns. Each polygon of peeled paint is like a snowflake of decay.

en: Strangely, though, there’s still some merchandise: there’s a Mickey Mouse phone I recognize from some way back part of childhood. Moth-bit but still-folded SUNNY ORLANDO T-shirts are on display, splattered with broken glass. Beneath the glass cases, Radar finds a box filled with maps and old tourist brochures advertising Gator World and Crystal Gardens and fun houses that no longer exist. Ben waves me over and silently points out the green glass alligator tchotchke lying alone in the case, almost buried in the dust. This is the value of our souvenirs, I think: you can’t give this shit away.
vi: But strangely, there were still some traces of commerce: a Mickey Mouse phone, the kind I had seen when I was a kid. Some ORLANDO SUNSHINE t-shirts, nibbled by cockroaches but still folded and displayed, mixed with broken glass shards. Under the glass cabinet, Radar found a box full of maps and travel books, advertising Gator World, Crystal Gardens, and those now-defunct funhouses. Ben waved at me, silently pointing to a green glass alligator souvenir, lying alone in a display case, almost buried in dust. This is the value of souvenirs, I thought to myself: we can never throw them away.
tr: Strangely, there are still some items left: A Mickey Mouse phone that I remember from a part of my childhood. The SUNSHINE ORLANDO t-shirts, which have been eaten by moths but are still folded, are still in the display, with broken glass scattered over them. Under the glass displays, they find a box full of old tourist brochures advertising now-defunct amusement parks like Alligator World, Crystal Gardens, and others, along with radar maps. He calls me over and silently points to a green glass alligator figurine standing alone in the display, almost buried in dust. This is the value of our memories: it's impossible to give away these absurdities.
es: But the strange thing is that there are still some items left. There is a Mickey Mouse phone that reminds me of my childhood. In the display cases, sprinkled with broken glass, there are moth-eaten t-shirts, still folded, that say ORLANDO IN THE SUN. Under the display cases, Radar finds a box full of maps and old tourist brochures advertising Gator World, Crystal Gardens, and other attractions that no longer exist. Ben gestures with his hand and without saying anything points to the green glass alligator in a box, almost buried in the dust. This is what our memories are worth, I think. You can't give this crap away.

en: We make our way back through the empty room and the shelved room and crawl through the last Troll Hole. This room looks like an office only without computers, and it appears to have been abandoned in a great hurry, like its employees were beamed up to space or something. Twenty desks sit in four rows. There are still pens on some of the desks, and they all feature oversize paper calendars lying flat against the desks. On each calendar, it is perpetually February of 1986. Ben pushes a cloth desk chair and it spins, creaking rhythmically. Thousands of Post-it notes advertising The Martin-Gale Mortgage Corp. are piled beside one desk in a rickety pyramid. Open boxes contain stacks of paper from old dot matrix printers, detailing the expenses and income of the Martin-Gale Mortgage Corp. On one of the desks, someone has stacked brochures for subdivisions into a single-story house of cards. I spread the brochures out, thinking that they may hold a clue, but no.
vi: We went back, through the empty room and the room with many iron shelves, crawling through the last Devil's Hole. This area looked like an office, except there were no computers, and it seemed to have been abandoned hastily, as if the employees had been suddenly abducted into space or something like that. Twenty desks arranged in four rows. Here and there were some pens on the desks, and each desk still had large wall calendars. All the calendars stopped at February 1986. Ben pushed a fabric-covered chair, the swivel chair creaking rhythmically. Thousands of note pads advertising Martin-Gale Mortgage Company were piled next to a desk, forming a wobbly pyramid. Uncovered boxes, containing stacks of paper from ancient dot matrix printers, held the financial statistics of Martin-Gale Mortgage Company. On another desk, someone had arranged brochures of subdivisions into the shape of a one-story house. I knocked over the brochures, hoping they held some clue, but they didn't.
tr: First, we go back through the empty room, then through the room with shelves, and finally crawl through the last Dwarf Hole. This room looks like an office, but there are no computers, and it seems to have been abandoned in a great hurry, as if its workers were teleported to space or something. There are twenty desks arranged in four rows. Some desks still have pens on them, and all the desks feature large calendars lying flat on top of them. Each calendar shows February 1986. I push a fabric-covered chair, and the chair spins with a rhythmic creak. Next to one desk, thousands of sticky notes advertising the MartinGale Mortgage Company are piled up in a pyramid shape. In open boxes, there are printouts from old dot matrix printers, MartinGale There are stacks of papers showing the details of the income and expenses of the Mortgage Company. On top of one of the desks, someone has arranged neighborhood brochures to form a single-story house out of a card. Thinking there might be a clue inside them, I spread out the brochures, but there isn't.
es: We go back through the empty room and the room with the shelves, and we crawl through the last Troll Hole. This room looks like an office, only it doesn't have computers, and it gives the impression that it was abandoned in a hurry, as if the workers had been teleported into space or something like that. Twenty tables arranged in four rows. There are still pens on some tables, and all of them are covered with giant paper calendars. All the calendars stopped in February 1986. Ben pushes a desk chair, which squeaks rhythmically as it turns. Thousands of post-it notes with advertisements for the Martin-Gale mortgage company are piled in an unstable pyramid shape under a table. There are open boxes with stacks of paper from old dot matrix printers detailing the expenses and income of the Martin-Gale company. On one of the tables, someone has stacked brochures of housing developments to form a one-story house. I spread out the brochures to see if they hide any clues, but no.

en: Radar fingers through the papers, whispering, “Nothing after 1986.” I start to go through the desk drawers. I find Q-tips and stickpins. Pens and pencils packed a dozen each in flimsy cardboard packaging with retro fonts and design. Napkins. A pair of golf gloves.
vi: Radar ran his finger through the pile of papers and said quietly, “Nothing after 1986.” I started looking through the desk drawers. There were cotton swabs and tie pins. Pens and pencils by the dozen in rickety cardboard boxes, printed and styled old look. Napkin. A pair of golf gloves.
tr: Radar, "There is nothing after 1986," he whispers while shuffling the papers with his fingers. I start to inspect the desk drawers. I find cotton swabs and tie pins. Dozens of fountain pens and pencils, packaged in cardboard boxes with old-fashioned fonts and designs. Paper napkins. A pair of golf gloves.
es: —Nothing after 1986 —sighs Radar, running his fingers over the papers. I start to check the drawers. I find cotton swabs and pins. Pens and pencils packed ten by ten in cardboard boxes with retro letters and designs. Paper napkins. A pair of golf gloves.

en: “Do you guys see anything,” I ask, “that gives any hint that anyone has been here in the last, say, twenty years?”
vi: "Have you two seen anything that indicates someone has been here in the last, let's see, twenty years or so?" I asked.
tr: “Children, do you see anything?” I ask. “Any clue that someone has been here in the last twenty years?”
es: —Do you see the slightest indication that anyone has been here in the last twenty years, for instance? —I ask them.

en: “Nothing but the Troll Holes,” Ben answers. It’s a tomb, everything wrapped in dust.
vi: "Nothing except the Ghouls," Ben replied. This place is a tomb, everything lies still under the dust.
tr: “There is nothing but Dwarf Holes,” Ben replies. This place is a tomb, everything is covered in dust.
es: —Only the Troll Holes —Ben answers me. It is a tomb, all covered in dust.

en: “So why did she lead us here?” asks Radar. We are speaking now.
vi: “So why did Margo bring us here?” Radar asked. We could speak normally now, no longer whispering.
tr: “Then why did Margo direct us here?” asks Radar. We are talking now.
es: —And then why did you bring us here? —asks Radar. We finally started talking.

en: “Dunno,” I say. She is clearly not here.
vi: "I don't know," I replied. Clearly, Margo is not here.
tr: "I don't know," I say. Clearly, Margo is not here.
es: —No idea —I answered. There is no doubt that Margo is not here.

en: “There are some spots,” Radar says, “with less dust. There’s a dustless rectangle in the empty room, like something was moved. But I don’t know.”
vi: “There are a few places with less dust,” Radar said. “A dust-free rectangle in an otherwise empty room, as if something had been moved. But I don't know.”
tr: “There are some places,” says Radar, “that are less dusty. In the empty room, there is a dust-free rectangle, as if something has been removed. But I don't know.”
es: —There are spots with less dust —says Radar—. In the empty room, there is a dust-free rectangle, as if something had been moved. But I don't know.

en: “And there’s that painted part,” Ben says. Ben points and Radar’s flashlight shows me that a piece of the far wall in this office has been brushed over with white primer, like someone got the idea to remodel the place but abandoned the project after half an hour. I walk over to the wall, and up close, I can see that there’s some red graffiti behind the white paint. But I can only see occasional hints of the red paint bleeding through—not nearly enough to make anything out. There’s a can of primer up against the wall, open. I kneel down and push my finger into the paint. There’s a hard surface, but it breaks easily, and my finger comes up drenched in white. As the paint drips off my finger, I don’t say anything, because we’ve all come to the same conclusion, that someone has been here recently after all, and then the building creaks again and Radar drops the flashlight and curses.
vi: "And there are some painted spots," Ben added. Ben pointed, and Radar's light followed, illuminating a patch in the far corner of this office wall. The patch was covered with primer, as if someone had the idea to redesign this place but abandoned the project after about half an hour. I approached the patch, and up close, I saw red graffiti under the white paint. But I could only see glimpses of red seeping through the white—almost impossible to discern what it was. A can of primer was right next to the wall, still open. I knelt down and dipped my finger into the paint. The surface of the paint had hardened, but it easily cracked, and when I pulled my finger out, it was completely covered in white. As drops of paint fell from my finger, I said nothing because we all reached the same conclusion: someone had been here recently. The creaking sound echoed again somewhere in the building, and Radar dropped his flashlight.
tr: “And there's this painted section,” says Ben. He points, and Radar's flashlight shows that part of the office's opposite wall is painted with white primer, as if someone had the idea to make a change to the room but abandoned the project half an hour later. I walk towards the wall and, upon getting closer, I can see that there is red graffiti under the white paint. But I can only see traces of the red graffiti... definitely not enough to make out anything. There is an open paint can directly opposite the wall. I kneel down and press my finger into the paint. The surface is hard but breaks easily, and my finger comes out covered in white. As the paint drips from my finger, nothing I'm not saying anything because we all come to the same conclusion that someone recently came here, then the building creaks again and Radar drops the flashlight and curses.
es: —And this section is painted —observes Ben, pointing to a wall. Radar's flashlight shows me that on the back wall of the office there is a section that has been given a coat of white paint, as if someone had thought of remodeling it but abandoned the project after half an hour. I approach the wall and see that underneath the paint there is something written in red. But I only see traces of red paint seeping through, not enough to know what it says. Next to the wall, there is an open can of white paint. I kneel down and dip my finger into the paint. The surface is hard, but it breaks easily, so I pull out my white finger. I say nothing while the paint drips from my finger, because we have all come to the same conclusion: someone has been here recently. And then the building creaks again, and Radar drops the flashlight and lets out a curse.

en: “This is freaky,” he says.
vi: "Disgusting," he muttered angrily.
tr: "This is very scary," he says.
es: —This is very strange —he comments.

en: “Guys,” Ben says. The flashlight is still on the ground, and I take a step back, to pick it up, but then I see Ben pointing. He is pointing at the wall. A trick of the indirect light has made the graffiti letters float up through the coat of primer, a ghost-gray print I recognize immediately as Margo’s.
vi: “Look,” Ben exclaimed. The flashlight was still on the floor, I stepped back to pick it up, but at that moment I saw what Ben was pointing at. He was pointing at a section of the wall. The play of reflected light had revealed some graffiti letters, making them stand out from the white paint covering them, the eerie handwriting I immediately recognized as Margo's.
tr: “Kids,” says Ben. The flashlight is still on the ground, I take a step back to pick it up but then I see Ben pointing at something. He is pointing at the wall. Thanks to the indirect light, the letters on the wall writing become readable through the layer of primer paint, and I see a faint writing that I immediately understand is Margo’s.
es: —Guys —says Ben. As the flashlight is still on the ground, I take a step back to pick it up, but then I see Ben pointing. What he's pointing at is the wall. With the indirect light, the letters of the graffiti have pierced through the layer of paint. In that moment, I know that those ghostly gray letters are from Margo.

en: YOU WILL GO TO THE PAPER TOWNS
vi: WILL COME TO PAPER CITIES
tr: YOU WILL GO TO PAPER TOWNS AND NEVER COME BACK
es: YOU WILL GO TO THE PAPER TOWNS

vi: AND WILL NEVER RETURN
