en: I pick up the flashlight and shine it on the paint directly, and the message disappears. But when I shine it against a different part of the wall, I can read it again. “Shit,” Radar says under his breath.
vi: I picked up the flashlight and shone it directly on the paint, the message immediately disappeared. But when I shone the light on other parts of the wall in the room, I could read those letters again. "What the hell," Radar said under his breath.
tr: I pick up the flashlight from the ground and point it directly at the paint, and the message disappears. But when I point the flashlight at another part of the wall, I can read the writing again. "Damn," Radar says in a low voice.
es: I grab the flashlight, shine it directly at the painting, and the message disappears. But when I focus on another area of the wall, it becomes readable again. —Shit —says Radar in a low voice.

en: And now Ben says, “Bro, can we go now? Because the last time I was this scared . . . screw it. I’m freaked out. There’s nothing funny about this shit.”
vi: And now Ben spoke up, "Guys, can we go now? Because the last time I was this scared... damn it, I'm scared out of my wits here. This game is no fun at all."
tr: Now I say, "Brother, can we leave now? Because the last time I was this scared... screw it. I'm terrified. There's nothing funny about this shitty situation," he says.
es: —Colleague, can we leave now? —asks Ben—. Because the last time I was this scared... To hell with it. I'm terrified. This shit isn't fun at all.

en: There’s nothing funny about this shit is the closest Ben can come to the terror I feel, maybe. And it is close enough for me. I fast-walk toward the Troll Hole. I can feel the walls closing in on us.
vi: This game is not fun at all, it's the closest way Ben can reach the horror I'm feeling, perhaps. And for me, that's close enough. I quickly walked towards the Devil's Hole. It feels like the walls are closing in behind us.
tr: There is nothing funny about this shitty situation, maybe the closest Ben can get to the horror I feel. And for me, that's close enough. I quickly walk towards the Dwarf Hole. I can feel the walls closing in on us.
es: I think "This shit isn't fun at all" is what comes closest to my own terror. And for me, that's close enough. I hurry towards the Troll Hole. I feel the walls closing in on us.

tr: I can feel the walls closing in on us.

en: Ben and Radar dropped me off at my house—even though they’d skipped school, they couldn’t afford to skip band practice. I sat alone with “Song of Myself” for a long time, and for about the tenth time I tried to read the entire poem starting at the beginning, but the problem was that it’s like eighty pages long and weird and repetitive, and although I could understand each word of it, I couldn’t understand anything about it as a whole. Even though I knew the highlighted parts were probably the only important parts, I wanted to know whether it was a suicide-note kind of poem. But I couldn’t make sense of it.
vi: Ben and Radar dropped me off at home—those two were willing to skip school but definitely wouldn't miss band practice. I sat alone for a long time with "Song of Myself." It must have been the tenth time I tried to read the entire poem from start to finish, but the problem was that the poem was about eighty pages long, convoluted, and repetitive. Even though I understood each individual word, when combined into a whole, I just couldn't make sense of it. Even knowing that perhaps only the marked parts were important, I still wanted to figure out whether this was a kind of suicide note poetry. But I still couldn't make any sense of it.
tr: Ben and Radar dropped me off at home... despite skipping school, don't skip band practice. For a long time, I sat alone with My Song and tried to read the entire poem from start to finish for about the tenth time, but the thing was, the poem was about eighty pages long, strange, and overly repetitive, and although I could understand every word, I couldn't understand anything as a whole. Even though I knew that the underlined sections were probably the only important parts, I wanted to understand whether it was a poem in the style of a suicide note. But I couldn't make any sense of it.
es: Ben and Radar dropped me off at home. Although they hadn't gone to class, they couldn't afford to skip rehearsal. I sat for a good while with "Song of Myself," and for the umpteenth time, I tried to read the entire poem, starting from the beginning, but the problem was that it's like eighty pages long, it's weird and repetitive, and even though I understood all the words, I didn't understand what it was trying to say. Even though I knew that probably the only important parts were the marked verses, I wanted to know if the poem was some kind of suicide note. But I didn't understand anything.

en: I was ten confusing pages into the poem when I got so freaked out that I decided to call the detective. I dug his business card out of a pair of shorts in the laundry hamper. He answered on the second ring.
vi: After reading a dozen pages of the book, feeling utterly confused, I decided to call the detective. I retrieved his business card from the pocket of my shorts, which I had tossed into the dirty laundry basket. He picked up on the second ring.
tr: When I became frightened enough to decide to call the detective, I had gone through ten confusing pages of the poem. I found and pulled out the detective's business card from the shorts in the laundry basket. He answered on the second ring.
es: I had already read ten confusing pages when I became so hysterical that I decided to call the detective. I took his card out of a pair of shorts from the dirty laundry basket. He answered on the second ring.

en: “Warren.”
vi: "Warren, listen."
tr: "Warren."
es: —Warren.

en: “Hi, um, it’s Quentin Jacobsen. I’m a friend of Margo Roth Spiegelman?”
vi: "Uh, yes, I am Quentin Jacobsen, a friend of Margo Roth Spiegelman, do you remember me?"
tr: "Hello, um, I am Quentin Jacobsen. I am a friend of Margo Roth Spiegelman, but?"
es: Hello, um, I am Quentin Jacobsen, a friend of Margo Roth Spiegelman.

en: “Sure, kid, I remember you. What’s up?”
vi: “I remember, son. What's the matter?”
tr: “Of course, child, I remember you. How are you?”
es: —Of course, boy, I remember you. What’s happening?

en: I told him about the clues and the minimall and about paper towns, about how she had called Orlando a paper town from the top of the SunTrust Building, but she hadn’t used it in the plural, about her telling me that she wouldn’t want to be found, about finding her underneath our bootsoles. He didn’t even tell me not to break into abandoned buildings, or ask why I was at an abandoned building at 10 A.M. on a school day. He just waited until I stopped talking and said, “Jesus, kid, you’re almost a detective. All you need now is a gun, a gut, and three ex-wives. So what’s your theory?”
vi: I told him about the clues, the mini shopping mall, about the paper towns and how Margo called Orlando a paper town when we looked down from the SunTrust building, but she didn't use the plural form. I recounted how Margo told me that she didn't want to be found, and to look for her under the soles of boots. He didn't even raise his voice to tell me not to go into abandoned buildings, nor did he ask why I was in an abandoned building at 10 AM on a school day. He just waited until I finished speaking before saying, "Good Lord, boy, you're almost a detective already. Now you just need a gun, a detective's intuition, and three ex-wives. So what's your hypothesis?"
tr: I told her about the clues in the small shopping center and the paper towns, how she called Orlando a paper town from the top of the SunTrust building but didn't use it in plural, how she told me she didn't want to be found, and the matter of finding her under the soles of my shoes. She didn't tell me not to trespass into abandoned buildings or even ask why I was in an abandoned building at ten in the morning on a school day. She just let me talk He waited until he finished and said, "My God, son, you're almost a detective. Now all you need is a gun, courage, and three ex-wives. So, what's your theory?"
es: I told him about the clues, the mall, and the paper towns, I explained that from the top of the SunTrust Building she had told me that Orlando was a paper town, but she hadn't talked about towns in plural, that she had told me she didn't want to be found and about looking for her under the soles of our shoes. The detective didn't even tell me that I shouldn't enter abandoned buildings, nor did he ask me what I was doing there at ten in the morning on a school day. He waited until I had finished speaking. —For God's sake, boy, you're almost a detective. The only thing you're missing is a gun, a good belly, and three ex-wives. What's your theory?

en: “I’m worried that she might have, um, I guess killed herself.”
vi: "It's possible that Margo, um, I'm afraid she might have committed suicide."
tr: “I am worried that he might have, umm, killed himself.”
es: —I'm worried that he might have... well, that he might have committed suicide, I suppose.

en: “It never crossed my mind this girl did anything but run off, kid. I can see your case, but you gotta remember she’s done this before. The clues, I mean. Adds drama to the whole enterprise. Honestly, kid, if she wanted you to find her—dead or alive—you already would have.”
vi: “In my mind, I always believed that the girl just ran away, son. I understand your reasoning, but you should also remember that the girl has behaved like this before. I mean the clues that were left behind. Adding more drama to the whole process. Honestly, son, if Margo wants you to find her—alive or dead—then you will find her.”
tr: “The thought that this girl did anything other than run away never even crossed my mind, son. I can understand her situation, but you must remember that she has done this before. Clues... add excitement to this whole endeavor. Honestly, son, if she wanted you to find herdead or aliveyou would have found her by now.”
es: —It has never crossed my mind that this girl did anything other than run away, boy. I understand what you're telling me, but remember that she has done it before. I'm referring to the clues. She adds a bit of drama that way. Honestly, if she had wanted you to find her, alive or dead, you would have found her by now.

en: “But don’t you—”
vi: “But you don't–”
tr: “But you too...”
es: —But didn't you…?

en: “Kid, the unfortunate thing is that she’s a legal adult with free will, you know? Let me give you some advice: let her come home. I mean, at some point, you gotta stop looking up at the sky, or one of these days you’ll look back down and see that you floated away, too.”
vi: "Son, the unfortunate thing is that Margo is already a legally recognized adult, with a free will, you understand? My advice to you is this: let her come back on her own." "What I mean is that eventually, you will stop looking up at the sky, or one of these days, you will look down and realize that you yourself have drifted away."
tr: “Child, the unfortunate thing is that he is legally an adult with free will. Let me give you some advice: Let him come home. At some point, you will have to stop looking at the sky, or one day you will look down and see that you have flown away too.”
es: —Boy, we have the bad luck that legally she is an adult and free, you know? Allow me to give you some advice: wait for her to come back. Well, at some point you'll stop looking at the sky, or one of these days you'll look down and see that you too have flown away.

en: I hung up with a bad taste in my mouth—I realized it wasn’t Warren’s poetry that would take me to Margo. I kept thinking about those lines at the end Margo had underlined: “I bequeath myself to the dirt to grow from the grass I love, / If you want me again look for me under your bootsoles.” That grass, Whitman writes in the first few pages, is “the beautiful uncut hair of graves.” But where were the graves? Where were the paper towns?
vi: I put the phone down with an uncomfortable feeling in my mouth—I realized that Dr. Warren's poetic substance would not lead me to Margo. I pondered over the last lines that Margo had underlined: "I give myself back to the earth, nourishing the grasses I love, / If you want me, look for me under your boot-soles." That grass, Whitman wrote in the first pages, is "the beautiful uncut hair of graves." But where are the graves? Where are the paper towns?
tr: I hung up the phone with a bad taste in my mouth... I had realized that what would lead me to Margo was not Warren's poem. I kept thinking about the lines Margo had underlined at the end: “I bequeath myself to the dirt to grow from the grass I love, / If you want me again, look for me under your boot-soles.” According to what Whitman wrote in the first few pages, that grass was the “beautiful uncut hair of graves.” But where were the graves? Where were the paper towns?
es: I hung up with a bad taste in my mouth. It was clear that what would lead me to Margo would not be Warren's poetry. I kept thinking about the final verses that Margo had marked: "Let the mud be my heir, I want to grow from the grass I love; / If you want to find me, look for me under the sole of your shoes." In the first pages, Whitman writes that this grass, this herb, is "the loose and beautiful hair of graves." But where were the graves? Where were the paper towns?

en: I logged onto Omnictionary to see if it knew anything more about the phrase “paper towns” than I did. They had an extremely thoughtful and helpful entry created by a user named skunkbutt: “A Paper Town is a town that’s got a paper mill in it.” This was the shortcoming of Omnictionary: the stuff written by Radar was thorough and extremely helpful; the unedited work of skunk-butt left something to be desired. But when I searched the whole Web, I found something interesting buried forty entries down on a forum about real estate in Kansas.
vi: I logged into the Encyclopedia of Everything to see if there was any information about "paper towns" that I didn't know. There was an extremely insightful and useful entry from a user named mongchonhoi: "A Paper Town is a town where there is a paper mill." This is the downside of the Encyclopedia of Everything: the things Radar writes are extremely detailed and absolutely useful; while mongchonhoi's crude work only teases the issue, leaving people wanting more. But when I searched more broadly across the internet, I found about forty interesting entries, buried deep within a real estate forum in Kansas.
tr: “Paper towns” sözü hakkında benden daha fazla bir şey bilip bilmediğini görmek için Omnictionary’ye girdim. Kokarcakıç adlı bir kullanıcı tarafından yaratılmış, aşırı derecede düşünceli ve yararlı bir girdi vardı: “Paper Town, içinde kâğıt fabrikası olan bir şehirdir.” Bu Omnictionary’nin kusuruydu: Radar tarafından yazılan şeyler eksiksiz ve aşırı derecede yararlıydı; kokarcakıç’ın editlenmemiş yazısıysa hiç tatmin edici değildi. Ama bütün interneti taradığımda, Kansas’taki gayrimenkullerle ilgili bir forumda yaklaşık kırk girdi alta gömülmüş ilginç bir şey buldum.
es: I entered the Omnictionary to see if anything more was known about the expression "paper towns." I found an enormously detailed and useful entry created by a user named skunkbutt: "A Paper Town is a town with a paper factory." That was the flaw of the Omnictionary: the entries written by Radar were exhaustive and tremendously useful, but the one by this skunkbutt left much to be desired. But when I searched the web in general, I found something interesting hidden among the entries of a forum about real estate properties in Kansas.

en: Looks like Madison Estates isn’t going to get built; my husband and I bought property there, but someone called this week to say they’re refunding us our deposit because they didn’t presell enough houses to finance the project. Another paper town for KS! —Marge in Cawker, KS
vi: It seems that the Madison real estate area will never be completed; my spouse and I placed an order for a house there, but during the week someone called us, informing that our deposit would be refunded because they couldn't sell enough houses in advance to fund the project. Another paper city for Kansas! –Marge in Cawker, KS A ghost town!
tr: It looks like the Madison Homes won't be built; my husband and I bought an ordinary house, but this week someone called to tell us they would refund our deposit because they didn't sell enough homes to finance the project. Another paper town for Kansas! Marge from Cawker, Kansas.
es: It seems that Madison Estates is not going to be built. My husband and I bought a house, but this week they called us to say that they are going to return our deposit because they have not sold enough houses to finance the project. Another paper city for Kansas! - Marge, Cawker, Kansas.

en: A pseudovision! You will go to the pseudovisions and you will never come back. I took a deep breath and stared at the screen for a while.
vi: –Marge in Cawker, KS A ghost town! They will come to ghost towns and will never return. I took a deep breath and stared at the computer screen for a while.
tr: I feel semtimsi! You will go to the semtimsis and never return. I took a deep breath and stared at the screen for a while.
es: A pseudovision! You will go to the pseudovisions and you will never return. I took a deep breath and kept looking at the screen.

en: The conclusion seemed inescapable. Even with everything broken and decided inside her, she couldn’t quite allow herself to disappear for good. And she had decided to leave her body—to leave it for me—in a shadow version of our subdivision, where her first strings had broken. She had said she didn’t want her body found by random kids—and it made sense that out of everyone she knew, she would pick me to find her. She wouldn’t be hurting me in a new way. I’d done it before. I had experience in the field.
vi: It seemed impossible to avoid that outcome. Even though everything inside her had shattered and reached a verdict, Margo seemingly did not allow herself to disappear forever. And she decided to leave her body behind–leave it for me–in the guise of our ghost town, where her first threads had snapped. Margo had said that she didn't want her body to be found by random children–and it could be understood that among those who knew her, Margo would choose me to be the one to find her. She would not hurt me in a new way. I had done that before. I have experience in this field.
tr: The outcome seemed inevitable; despite everything that had broken inside her and all the decisions she had made, Margo had not accepted disappearing forever. And she had decided not to leave her body in an imaginary version of our neighborhood where the first ties had broken. She had said she didn't want her body to be found by random children... and it made sense that she had chosen me to find her among all her acquaintances. She wouldn't have hurt me in a different way. I had done this before. I had experience in the field.
es: The conclusion seemed irrefutable. Although everything inside her had broken and she had made her decision, she did not allow herself to disappear forever, so she had decided to leave her body —leave it to me— in a gloomy version of our neighborhood, where the first threads had broken. She had said that she didn't want any child to find her body, and it seemed logical that, of all the people she knew, she chose me to find it. It wouldn't hurt me as much because it wouldn't be new to me. It had already happened to me before. I had experience in the matter.

en: I saw that Radar was online and was clicking over to talk to him when an IM from him popped up on my screen.
vi: I saw Radar was online, intended to call it to talk, then saw its message appear on my screen.
tr: I saw that Radar was online and when a message popped up on my screen, I clicked on it to talk to him.
es: I saw that Radar was online, and I was about to click to talk to him when a message from him appeared on the screen.

en: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Hey.
vi: GLOBALCITIZENOFTHETOTALBOOK96: Êu.
tr: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Hello.
es: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Hello.

en: QTHERESURRECTION: Paper towns = pseudovisions.
vi: QKẺHỒISINH: Paper towns = ghost towns.
tr: RESURRECTIONIST: Paper towns = neighborhood-like places.
es: QTHERESURRECTION: Paper towns = pseudovisions.

en: I think she wants me to find her body. Because she thinks I can handle it. Because we found that dead guy when we were kids.
vi: I think Margo wanted me to find her body. Because she thought I could handle it. Because when we were kids, we discovered a dead body.
tr: I think your body wants me to find it. Because he thinks I can handle it. Because we found that dead man when we were children.
es: I think she wants me to find her body. Because she thinks I will be able to handle it. Because we found a dead guy when we were kids.

en: I sent him the link.
vi: I sent the link to Radar.
tr: I sent her the internet address.
es: I sent him the link.

en: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Slow down. Let me look at the link.
vi: CITIZENOFTHEUNIVERSE96: Hold on, let me read from the link first.
tr: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Slow down. Let me check the address.
es: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Calm down. Wait until they see the link.

en: QTHERESURRECTION: K.
vi: QKẺHỒISINH: Yes.
tr: DİRİLİŞÇİQ: Okay.
es: QTHERESURRECTION: OK.

en: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Okay, don’t be so morbid. You don’t know anything for sure. I think she’s probably fine.
vi: CITIZENOFTHEWORLD96: Alright, don't overthink it. You still don't have anything certain yet. I think Margo will be fine.
tr: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Okay, don't be so morbid. You don't know anything for sure. Margo is probably fine.
es: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Okay, don't be so macabre. You don't know anything for sure. I think it's probably fine.

en: QTHERESURRECTION: No you don’t.
vi: QKẺHỒISINH: Don't fool me.
tr: RESURRECTION ÇIQ: No, you are not thinking.
es: QTHERESURRECTION: No, you don't believe it.

en: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Okay, I don’t. But if anybody’s alive in the face of this evidence . . .
vi: CITIZENOFTHEWORLD96: Alright, I won't deceive you. But if there is someone still alive regardless of this evidence...
tr: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Okay, I don't think so. But in response to this evidence, if someone is alive...
es: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Okay, I don't believe it. But she might be alive despite the evidence...

en: QTHERESURRECTION: Yeah, I guess. I’m gonna go lie down. My parents get home soon.
vi: QKẺHỒISINH: Yeah, let's say so. I'm going to lie down for a bit, my parents are coming home soon.
tr: DIRILIŞÇIQ: Yes, I think so. I will go and lie down. My mom and dad will come home soon.
es: QTHERESURRECTION: Yes, I suppose. I'm going to bed. My parents will be here soon.

en: But I couldn’t calm down, so I called Ben from bed and told him my theory.
vi: But I couldn't stay calm, so I lay on the bed and called Ben, telling him my hypothesis.
tr: But I couldn't calm down, so I called Ben from bed and told him my theory.
es: But I couldn't calm down, so I called Ben from the bed and told him my theory.

en: “Pretty morbid shit, bro. But she’s fine. It’s all part of some game she’s playing.”
vi: "You're overthinking it, driving yourself crazy. But Margo is fine. It's all just part of some game she's playing."
tr: “A rather sickly nonsense, my brother. But Margo is good. It's all part of the game she plays.”
es: —What macabre shit, buddy. Margo is fine. She's just playing.

en: “You’re being kind of cavalier about it.”
vi: "You are starting to become indifferent about this."
tr: “You are being a bit thoughtless about this matter.”
es: —It doesn't seem to worry you too much.

en: He sighed. “Whatever, it’s a little lame of her to, like, hijack the last three weeks of high school, you know? She’s got you all worried, and she’s got Lacey all worried, and prom is in like three days, you know? Can’t we just have a fun prom?”
vi: Ben sighed. "Anyway, Margo played, well, a bit unfairly. You see, out of nowhere, she launched a surprise attack in the last three weeks of high school. You also saw, Margo made everyone worried, Lacey freaked out, and the prom is only three days away. Can't we have a fun graduation prom?”
tr: He sighed. “Whatever, it's partly his stupidity, I mean, stealing the last three weeks of school and all... It worried you, it worried Lacey, and the prom is in like three days, you know. Can't we just have a fun prom?”
es: He sighed. —Well, it's a bummer on their part to make you miss the last three weeks of class, you know? You're very worried, and Lacey is very worried, and there are three days left until the dance, you know? Can't we just have a peaceful dance and have fun?

en: “Are you serious? She could be dead, Ben.”
vi: “Are you serious?” “Margo might be dead, Ben.””
tr: “Are you serious? Margo might be dead, Ben.”
es: —Are you serious? Ben, she could be dead.

en: “She’s not dead. She’s a drama queen. Wants attention. I mean, I know her parents are assholes, but they know her better than we do, don’t they? And they think so, too.”
vi: “He won't die. Margo is the queen of making things up. She wants attention. I know Margo's parents aren't great, but they know Margo better than we do, right? And they think the same way.”
tr: “He hasn't died. He wants attention. I mean, I know his parents are shitty, but they know him better than we do, right? And they think so too.”
es: —She is not dead. She is the queen of drama. She wants to get attention. Look, I know her parents are assholes, but they know her better than we do, right? And her parents think the same.

en: “You can be such a tool,” I said.
vi: “You are a loser,” I cursed.
tr: "You can be such an ass-head," I said.
es: —When you want to be, you are a perfect jerk.

en: “Whatever, bro. We both had a long day. Too much drama. I’ll TTYS.” I wanted to ridicule him for using chatspeak IRL, but I found myself lacking the energy.
vi: "You can say whatever you want." "Both of us just had a long day." "Too much drama." "I'm going to GTSY." I was about to tease him about using such internet slang, but I didn't have the energy to joke anymore.
tr: "Anyway, my brother. We both had a long day. We experienced a lot of excitement. KIB." I wanted to make fun of him for using internet slang in real life, but I felt like I didn't have the energy.
es: —Whatever you say, buddy. The day has been long for both of us. Too much melodrama. TTYS. I wanted to laugh at him for using chat acronyms IRL, but I didn't have the strength.

en: After I hung up with Ben, I went back online, looking for a list of pseudovisions in Florida. I couldn’t find a list anywhere, but after searching “abandoned subdivisions” and “Grovepoint Acres” and the like for a while, I managed to compile a list of five places within three hours of Jefferson Park. I printed out a map of Central Florida, tacked the map to the wall above my computer, and then added a tack for each of the five locations. Looking at the map, I could detect no pattern among them. They were randomly distributed among the far-flung suburbs, and it would take me at least a week to get to all of them. Why hadn’t she left me a specific place? All these scary-as-hell clues. All this intimation of tragedy. But no place. Nothing to hold on to. Like trying to climb a mountain of gravel.
vi: After hanging up with Ben, I went back online, looking for a list of ghost towns in Florida. I didn't find any such list, but after searching for "abandoned subdivisions" and "Grovepoint Acres," something similar, I gathered a list of five locations within about a three-hour drive from Jefferson Park. I printed out a map of Central Florida, pinned it to the wall above my computer, and marked those five places with pushpins. Looking at the map, I didn't see any connection. Those locations were scattered in remote suburbs, and it would probably take at least a week to visit them all. Why didn't Margo narrow it down to a specific area for me? All these creepy-to-the-point-of-gross clues. All this proximity to disaster. But not a single place. Nothing to hold on to. Like having to climb a mountain full of loose rocks.
tr: After hanging up the phone with Ben, I went back online to search for a list of neighborhoods in Florida. I couldn’t find a list anywhere, but after searching for a while with terms like “abandoned neighborhoods” and “Grovepoint Acres,” I managed to list five places located within a three-hour distance from Jefferson Park. I printed out a map of Central Florida and pinned it to the wall above my computer, then added a pin for each of the five places. Looking at the map, I couldn’t find any connection between them. They were randomly scattered across remote outskirts, and reaching each of them would take at least It would take my whole week. Why hadn't he specified a particular place for me? All these hellish, terrifying clues. All these implications of tragedy. But there was no place. There was nothing to hold on to. It was like trying to climb a mountain made of pebbles.
es: I hung up and went back online in search of a list of Florida's pseudo-visions. I couldn't find it anywhere, but after typing "abandoned developments," "Grovepoint Acres," and things like that for a while, I managed to get a list of five places less than three hours from Jefferson Park. I printed a map of central Florida, pinned it to the wall above the computer, and put a pin in each of the five locations. At first glance, I didn't detect the slightest connection between them. They were randomly scattered among the farthest developments, so I would need at least a week to visit them all. Why hadn't he left me a specific place? Several damn sinister clues, several hints of tragedy, but not a single place. Nothing to hold on to. Like trying to climb a gravel mountain.

en: Ben gave me permission to borrow RHAPAW the next day, since he was going to be driving around, prom shopping with Lacey in her SUV. So for once I didn’t have to sit outside the band room—the seventh-period bell rang and I raced out to his car. I lacked Ben’s talent for getting RHAPAW to start, so I was one of the first people to arrive at the senior parking lot and one of the last to leave, but finally the engine caught, and I was off to Grovepoint Acres.
vi: The next day, Ben lent me RHAPAW because he would be driving Lacey's SUV around to shop for the graduation party. So this time I didn't have to wait outside the music room–as soon as the bell rang to end the seventh period, I dashed to the car. But I couldn't start RHAPAW as easily as Ben, so even though I was one of the first to arrive at the senior parking lot, I was one of the last to leave. Eventually, the engine did start, and I headed straight to Grovepoint Acres.
tr: The next day, since Ben would be driving around in Lacey's jeep for prom shopping, he allowed me to borrow SESIB. So, for the first time, I didn't have to sit outside the band room... the seventh bell rang, and I ran to Ben's car. Since I lacked the ability to start Ben's SESIB, I was one of the first to reach the senior parking lot and one of the last to leave, but I finally got the engine running and headed towards Grovepoint Acres.
es: Ben gave me permission to take the Chuco the next day, because he was going shopping with Lacey in his SUV. So for once, I didn't have to wait at the rehearsal room door. The bell rang and I ran to his car. Since I didn't have Ben's talent for starting the Chuco, I was one of the first to arrive at the senior parking lot and one of the last to leave, but in the end, the engine caught and I set off towards Grovepoint Acres.

en: I drove out of town on Colonial, driving slowly, watching for any other pseudovisions I might have missed online. A long line of cars trailed behind me, and I felt anxious about holding them up; I marveled at how I could still have room to worry about such petty, ridiculous crap as whether the guy in the SUV behind me thought I was an excessively cautious driver. I wanted Margo’s disappearance to change me; but it hadn’t, not really.
vi: I drove along Colonial Road, slowly driving to see if there was any ghost town I had missed when searching online. A long line of cars followed behind my car. I felt a bit flustered seeing that scene, then immediately admired myself for still having the energy to worry about such childish, trivial, and silly things: wondering if the guy in the SUV behind me thought I was an overly cautious driver, driving as slow as a turtle. I had hoped that Margo's disappearance would change me; but it didn't change much, not significantly.
tr: Driving slowly out of the city on Colonial Boulevard, I kept an eye out for other neighborhoods I might have missed on the internet. A long line of cars formed behind me, and I felt uneasy for delaying them; I marveled at how I still had room to worry about such trivial, ridiculous things, like whether the man in the SUV behind me thought I was an overly cautious driver. I wished Margo's disappearance had changed me, but it hadn't, not exactly.
es: I drove slowly through Colonial, looking for other pseudovisions that might have escaped me in the net. There was a long line of cars behind me, and I was anxious thinking that I was creating a traffic jam. I was surprised that I could still worry about insignificant and ridiculous bullshit like whether the guy in the car behind me thought I was driving too cautiously. I would have liked Margo's disappearance to have changed me, but the truth was that it hadn't.

en: As the line of cars snaked behind me like some kind of unwilling funeral procession, I found myself talking out loud to her. I will play out the string. I will not betray your trust. I will find you.
vi: When the line of cars behind kept stretching out like an unwilling funeral procession, I realized I was speaking loudly to her. I will follow the connection. I will not betray your trust. I will find you.
tr: As the line of cars snaked behind me like a reluctant funeral procession, I found myself talking out loud to Margo. I will pull all the strings. I will not break your trust. I will find you.
es: While the line of cars crawled behind me like a reluctant funeral procession, I found myself talking to Margo out loud. «I will follow the thread. I will not betray your trust. I will find you».

en: Talking like this to her kept me calm, strangely. It kept me from imagining the possibilities. I came again to the sagging wooden sign for Grovepoint Acres. I could almost hear the sighs of relief from the bottleneck behind me as I turned left onto the dead-end asphalt road. It looked like a driveway without a house. I left RHAPAW running and got out. From close up, I could see that Grovepoint Acres was more finished than it initially appeared. Two dirt roads ending in cul-de-sacs had been cut into the dusty ground, although the roads had eroded so much I could barely see their outlines. As I walked up and down both streets, I could feel the heat in my nose with each breath. The scalding sun made it hard to move, but I knew the beautiful, if morbid, truth: heat made death reek, and Grovepoint Acres smelled like nothing except cooked air and car exhaust—our cumulative exhalations held close to the surface by the humidity.
vi: Strangely, speaking out loud like that made me calmer. I no longer conjured up hypotheses. Passing the old wooden sign that read Grovepoint Acres again, I almost heard a sigh of relief from the bottleneck behind me as I turned left onto the paved dead-end road. It looked like a path that didn't lead to any house. I let RHAPAW run the entire length of that road. Up close, Grovepoint Acres seemed more complete than it initially appeared. Two dirt roads led into a cul-de-sac, intersecting each other into dusty patches. Although the roads were heavily eroded, I could still faintly see the edges. Walking back and forth on those two streets, I felt the heat emanating from my nostrils with each breath. The sun was scorching, making the walk quite tiring, but I understood a beautiful, albeit slightly foolish, truth: the heat would force the smell of death to rise, and Grovepoint Acres only emitted the scent of heated air and car exhaust—the accumulated emissions pushed down close to the ground by the humidity.
tr: Strangely, talking to him this way calmed me down. It prevented me from imagining the possibilities. I arrived again at the crooked, wooden Grovepoint Acres sign. As I turned left onto the dead-end asphalt road, I could almost hear the sighs of relief from those behind me. It looked like a driveway without a house. I left the SESIB running and got out. Up close, the Grovepoint Acres’ initially I could see that it was more completed than it appeared. Two dirt roads that ended in dead ends were dug into the dusty ground; although the roads were quite worn, I could barely see their outlines. As I walked back and forth on both roads, I could feel the warmth in my nose with every breath. The scorching sun made it difficult to move, but I knew the truth that felt good despite being a bit sickly: The heat smelled of death, and Grovepoint Acres smelled of nothing but cooked air and car exhaust...
es: As strange as it may seem, speaking to her out loud calmed me. It prevented me from imagining the various possibilities. I reached the worn wooden sign of Grovepoint Acres. I almost heard the sighs of relief from those following me when I turned left onto the dead-end paved road. It seemed like an access road to a house but without a house. I left the Chuco running and got out. As I approached, I saw that Grovepoint Acres was more rundown than it initially appeared. They had opened two dead-end dirt roads in the ground, although they had eroded so much that the outlines were barely visible. I walked up and down the two streets, feeling the heat in my nose with each breath. The scorching sun made movement difficult, but I knew the pretty, though macabre, truth: heat makes the dead stink, and Grovepoint Acres only smelled of hot air and exhaust fumes. The humidity caused the accumulation of exhalations to linger in the air around me.

en: I looked for evidence she had been there: footprints or something written in the dirt or some memento. But I seemed to be the first person to walk on these unnamed dirt streets in years. The ground was flat, and not much brush had grown back yet, so I could see for a ways in every direction. No tents. No campfires. No Margo.
vi: I searched for evidence that Margo had been here: footprints, something written on the ground, or some kind of memento. But it seemed that after many years, I was the first person to set foot on these nameless dusty streets. The ground was flat, and the shrubs had not grown much, so I could see in all directions. No tents. No signs of fire. No Margo.
tr: I searched for evidence that Margo had been there: footprints, something written in the dirt, or a keepsake. But I seemed to be the first person to walk these nameless dirt roads in years. The ground was flat and not many bushes had grown yet, so I could see quite far in every direction. There was no tent. There was no campfire. There was no Margo.
es: I looked for evidence that Margo had been there: footprints, something written in the dirt, or anything she might have left behind, but it seemed like I was the first person to walk those nameless streets in years. The ground was flat and not much grass had grown yet, so I had a clear view in all directions. I saw no tents, no traces of campfires, and no Margo.

en: I got back in RHAPAW and drove to I-4 and then went northeast of town, up to a place called Holly Meadows. I drove past Holly Meadows three times before I finally found it—everything in the area was oak trees and ranch land, and Holly Meadows—lacking a sign at its entrance—didn’t stand out much. But once I drove a few feet down a dirt road through the initial roadside stand of oak and pine trees, it was every bit as desolate as Grovepoint Acres. The main dirt road just slowly evaporated into a field of dirt. There were no other roads that I could make out, but as I walked around, I did find a few spray-painted wooden stakes lying on the ground; I guessed that they had once been lot line markers. I couldn’t smell or see anything suspicious, but even so I felt a fear standing on my chest, and at first I couldn’t understand why, but then I saw it: when they’d clear-cut the area to build, they’d left a solitary live oak tree near the back of the field. And the gnarled tree with its thick-barked branches looked so much like the one where we’d found Robert Joyner in Jefferson Park that I felt sure she was there, on the other side of the tree.
vi: I turned back to RHAPAW, drove onto the I-4 highway, and then headed northeast of the city to a place called Holly Meadows. I drove past Holly Meadows three times before actually finding it—the entire area was just oak trees and vacant land, and Holly Meadows—with no sign at the entrance—wasn't very noticeable. I drove a few meters along the dirt road through the first cluster of oak and pine trees, and this place seemed no less desolate than Grovepoint Acres. The main dirt road gradually blurred into a field of soil. I didn't see any other roads, but as I went around, I did see some painted wooden stakes lying scattered on the ground; they probably once marked the boundaries. I didn't smell or detect anything suspicious, yet I still felt a fear rising in my chest. At first, I didn't understand why, but then I realized: when they cleared the land for construction, they left a single oak tree at the far end of the field. And the twisted trunk with its thick bark looked very much like the tree from long ago in Jefferson Park, where we had found Robert Joyner, so much so that I was almost certain Margo was there, behind the trunk.
tr: I went back to SESIB and drove to I4, then went to a place called Holly Meadows in the northeast of the city. I passed by Holly Meadows three times until I finally found it... The only things around were oak trees and farmland, and Holly Meadows, which had no sign at its entrance, didn't stand out much. But as soon as I moved a few meters along the dirt road branching off from the first road with oak and pine trees, the place became as desolate as Grovepoint Acres. The main dirt road slowly evaporated and turned into a dirt field. I couldn't see any other road, but while walking around, I found a few spray-painted wooden stakes on the ground; I guessed they were once boundary markers for the plots. I couldn't see or smell anything suspicious, but I still felt a fear pressing on my chest. At first, I didn't understand why, but then I saw it: when they cleared the land for construction, they had left a solitary oak tree near the back boundary. And this crooked tree, with its thick-barked branches, reminded me of Robert Joyner in Jefferson Park. It looked so much like the place we were in that I was almost certain Margo was there, on the other side of the tree.
es: I returned to Chuco, headed to I-4, and turned northeast of the city, towards a place called Holly Meadows. I passed it by three times before finally finding it, because the whole area was surrounded by oaks and ranches, and since there was no sign indicating the entrance, Holly Meadows was not visible. But as soon as I advanced a few meters on an unpaved road between the oaks and pines, everything appeared as desolate as in Grovepoint Acres. The main road slowly dissolved into a dirt terrain. I didn't see any other roads, but while walking I discovered several wooden posts on the ground painted with spray paint. I assumed they had been used to delineate the land. I didn't smell or see anything suspicious, but still, I felt fear taking hold of me, and at first, I didn't understand why, but then I saw it: when clearing the area to build, they had left a solitary oak at the back of the field. And the twisted tree, with its branches covered in thick bark, looked so much like the tree where we had found Robert Joyner, in Jefferson Park, that I was sure Margo was there, on the other side of the tree.

en: And for the first time, I had to picture it: Margo Roth Spiegelman, slumped against the tree, her eyes silent, the black blood pouring out of her mouth, everything bloated and distorted because I had taken so long to find her. She had trusted me to find her sooner. She had trusted me with her last night. And I had failed her. And even though the air tasted like nothing but it-might-rain-later, I was sure I’d found her.
vi: And for the first time, I had to imagine this: Margo Roth Spiegelman, slumped against a tree, her eyes vacant, black blood pouring from her mouth, everything swollen and deformed because I had taken too long to find her. Margo had believed that I would find her sooner. That night she had placed her trust in me. And I had betrayed that trust. And although the air only smelled of impending rain, I was certain that I would find Margo there.
tr: I had to bring that moment to my mind for the first time: Margo Itoth Spiegelman, leaning against the trunk of the tree, her eyes dull, black blood flowing from her mouth, her whole body swollen and decomposed because it took me so long to find her. She had trusted me to find her sooner. She had trusted me on her last night. And I had let her down. Even though there was no other taste in the air except the taste of "it might rain later," I was sure I had found Margo.
es: And for the first time, I had to imagine it: Margo Roth Spiegelman collapsed on the tree, her eyes silent, dark blood coming out of her mouth, all swollen and deformed because it had taken too long to find her. She had trusted that I would find her sooner. She had entrusted me with her last night. And I had failed her. And although the smell of the air only suggested that rain was coming, I was sure that I had found her.

en: But no. It was only a tree, alone in the empty silver dirt. I sat down against the tree and let my breath come back. I hated doing this alone. I hated it. If she thought Robert Joyner had prepared me for this, she was wrong. I didn’t know Robert Joyner. I didn’t love Robert Joyner.
vi: But no. There was only the tree, solitary on the silver-gray ground. I crouched down, leaning against the tree trunk and tried to catch my breath. I hated having to go through this alone. I hated it. If Margo thought that the Robert Joyner incident had prepared me, she was wrong. I didn't know Robert Joyner. I didn't have any affection for Robert Joyner.
tr: But no. This was just a tree, a solitary tree in the empty silver-colored soil. I sat down leaning against the trunk of the tree and caught my breath. I hated doing this alone. I hated it. If Robert Joyner thought he was preparing me for this, he was wrong. I didn't know Robert Joyner. I didn't like Robert Joyner.
es: But no. It was just a solitary tree in the gray land. I sat down, leaned against the trunk, and waited to catch my breath. I hated being alone in those moments. I hated it. If Margo thought that Robert Joyner had prepared me for this, she was wrong. I didn't know Robert Joyner. I didn't love Robert Joyner.

en: I hit at the dirt with the heels of my fists, and then pounded it again and again, the sand scattering around my hands until I was hitting the bare roots of the tree, and I kept it up, the pain shooting up through my palms and wrists. I had not cried for Margo until then, but now finally I did, pounding against the ground and shouting because there was no one to hear: I missed her I missed her I missed her I miss her.
vi: I pounded my fist into the ground, punching repeatedly, sand swirling up until I hit the exposed roots of a tree. I still didn't stop, the sharp pain shooting through my hand and wrist. I had never cried because of Margo, until then, now I couldn't hold back anymore. I kept pounding the ground and screaming because there was no one here to hear: I miss Margo, miss her, miss, miss, miss.
tr: I punched the ground, then punched it again and again, until I hit the tree's exposed roots, sand scattering around from between my hands, I continued, the pain rapidly increasing as it passed through my palms and wrists. Until then, I hadn't cried for Margo, but finally, at that moment, I cried, punching the ground and shouting because there was no one to hear: I miss her I miss her I miss her I miss her I miss her.
es: I pounded the ground with my knuckles and kept hitting it over and over again. The sand gave way around my hands until I reached the tree roots, and I kept hitting. Pain shot up through my palms and wrists. Until that moment, I hadn't cried for Margo, but I finally did, pounding the ground and screaming because no one could hear me. I missed her I missed her I missed her I miss her.

en: I stayed there even after my arms got tired and my eyes dried up, sitting there and thinking about her until the light got gray.
vi: I stayed there until my arms went numb and my eyes dried out, just sitting there thinking about her, until day turned to night.
tr: Even after my arms grew tired and my eyes dried up, I sat there and stayed, thinking about it until the light turned gray.
es: I stayed there, even though my arms were exhausted and my eyes had dried up. I sat thinking about her until the light turned gray.

tr: Even after my arms grew tired and my eyes dried up, I sat there and stayed, thinking about it until the light turned gray.

en: The next morning at school, I found Ben standing beside the band door talking to Lacey, Radar, and Angela in the shade of a tree with low-hanging branches. It was hard for me to listen as they talked about prom, and about how Lacey was feuding with Becca or whatever. I was waiting for a chance to tell them what I’d seen, but then when I had the chance, when I finally said, “I took a pretty long look at the two pseudovisions but didn’t find much,” I realized that there was nothing new to say, really.
vi: The next morning at school, I saw Ben standing next to the music room, talking to Lacey, Radar, and Angela under a low-hanging tree canopy. I had no interest in listening to them discuss the prom, or things like how Lacey had a huge fight with Becca. I waited for the moment to tell them what I had seen, but when that moment came, I ended up saying only, "Yesterday I thoroughly checked out two ghost towns but found nothing noteworthy." In fact, I felt there was nothing new to tell them.
tr: The next day at school, I found Ben talking with Lacey, Radar, and Angela in the shade of a low-branched tree next to the band room door. It was hard for me to listen while they talked about prom and how Lacey harbored animosity towards Becca. I was waiting for an opportunity to tell them what I had seen, but then when I finally got the chance and said, "I looked at two umbrellas for quite a long time but didn't find much," I realized there really wasn't anything new to say.
es: The next day I found Ben by the rehearsal room door, chatting with Lacey, Radar, and Angela in the shade of a low-branched tree. I found it difficult to hear them talk about the dance, about Lacey having fought with Becca, or whatever else. I was waiting for the opportunity to tell them what I had seen, but when I finally had it, I realized that I actually had nothing new to tell. —I thoroughly reviewed two pseudovisions, but I found nothing.

en: No one even seemed that concerned, except Lacey. She shook her head as I talked about the pseudovisions, and then said, “I was reading online last night that people who are suicidal end relationships with people they’re angry with. And they give away their stuff. Margo gave me like five pairs of jeans last week because she said I could wear them better, which isn’t even true because she’s so much more, like, curvy.” I liked Lacey, but I saw Margo’s point about the undermining.
vi: None of them seemed to care, except for Lacey. She shook her head when I mentioned ghost towns, then said, "Last night I read online that people who choose to commit suicide often cut ties with those who have made them angry before. And they give away their belongings. Last week Margo gave me five pairs of jeans, she said I looked better in them, but actually, it was just flattery, Margo has, um, much better curves than I do." I liked Lacey, but I also remembered what Margo had said about her liking to "put down" her friends.
tr: Nobody seemed that worried, except for Lacey. She nodded while I talked about my neighborhood friends. "Last night on the internet, I read that people with suicidal tendencies end relationships with those they are angry with. And they give away their belongings. Last week, Margo gave me about five pairs of jeans, saying they fit me better, which isn't even true because she's much more, well, curvy." I liked Lacey, but I understood what Margo meant about Lacey always trying to harm her.
es: Nobody seemed particularly interested, except for Lacey, who was shaking her head while recounting the pseudovisions. —Last night I read on the internet that people who commit suicide break off relationships with those they are angry with. And they give away their things. Last week Margo gave me five pairs of jeans because she said they would fit me better, and it's not true, because she has a lot more curves. I liked Lacey, but I understood what Margo had told me about her always undermining her.

en: Something about telling us that story made her start to cry, and Ben put an arm around her, and she tucked her head into his shoulder, which was hard to do, because in her heels she was actually taller than him.
vi: It seems that recounting that story made Lacey so emotional that she started to cry. Ben put his arm around Lacey and she rested her head on his shoulder, which was actually a bit difficult because when wearing high heels, Lacey was slightly taller than Ben.
tr: Something about telling us this story made her start crying, Ben put his arm around her and Lacey rested her head on Ben's shoulder, which was difficult because in her high heels, Lacey was taller than Ben.
es: When she told us, she started to cry. Ben put an arm around her waist, and she rested her head on his shoulder, which was not easy for her because, with heels, she was taller than him.

en: “Lacey, we just have to find a location. I mean, talk to your friends. Did she ever mention paper towns? Did she ever talk about a specific place? Was there some subdivision somewhere that meant something to her?” She shrugged into Ben’s shoulder.
vi: “It's okay, Lacey, we just have to find the right place. Try talking to our friends and see what they say. Did Margo ever mention anything about the paper towns to anyone? Did she ever talk about any specific locations? Is there a particular subdivision somewhere that holds special meaning for Margo?” Lacey nestled deeper into Ben's shoulder.
tr: “Lacey, we just need to find one location. So, talk to your friends. Did he ever mention paper towns? Did he ever mention a specific Did he mention the place? Was there a neighborhood that had any meaning for him?" She shrugged and buried herself in Ben's shoulder.
es: —Lacey, we have to find her. Anyway, talk to your friends. Did she ever talk about paper towns? Did she talk about any specific place? Was there any subdivision somewhere that meant something to her? Lacey shrugged, still leaning on Ben.

en: “Bro, don’t push her,” Ben said. I sighed, but shut up.
vi: “Alright, don't rush Lacey too much,” Ben said. I sighed, saying nothing more.
tr: “Brother, don't force him,” said Ben. I sighed but kept my mouth shut.
es: —Colleague, don't pressure her —Ben warned me. I sighed, but I didn't say anything.

en: “I’m on the online stuff,” Radar said, “but her username hasn’t logged on to Omnictionary since she left.”
vi: “I have been following online,” Radar said, “but Margo's username hasn't logged into Omnictionary since she left.”
tr: “I’m in the internet business,” said Radar, “but the username hasn’t logged into Omnictionary since you left.”
es: —I'm on the internet —said Radar—, but their username hasn't logged into Omnictionary since they left.

en: And then all at once they were back on the topic of prom. Lacey emerged from Ben’s shoulder still looking sad and distracted, but she tried to smile as Radar and Ben swapped tales of corsage purchasing.
vi: Then immediately the whole group returned to the topic of the graduation party. Lacey lifted her head from Ben's shoulder, still looking downcast and distracted, but tried to smile as she listened to Radar and Ben discussing boutonnieres.
tr: And suddenly they returned to the topic of the prom. Lacey, still looking upset and distracted, lifted her head from Ben's shoulder but tried to laugh while Ben and Radar shared stories about getting corsages for each other.
es: And suddenly they returned to the topic of the dance. Lacey lifted her head from Ben's shoulder with a sad and distracted air, but tried to smile while Radar and Ben exchanged stories about buying flowers.

en: The day passed as it always did—in slow motion, with a thousand plaintive glances at the clock. But now it was even more unbearable, because every minute I wasted in school was another minute in which I failed to find her.
vi: The day passed like any other day—slowly, with a thousand weary glances at the clock. But now everything was even more unbearable, because every minute I wasted at school was another minute I failed to find Margo.
tr: The day passed as usual... in slow motion, casting thousands of tearful glances at the clock. But now it was even more unbearable because every minute I spent at school was another minute I failed to find her.
es: The day went by as usual, in slow motion and with a thousand pitiful glances at the clock. But it was even more unbearable, because every minute lost at the institute was another minute he couldn't find her.

en: My only vaguely interesting class that day was English, when Dr. Holden completely ruined Moby Dick for me by incorrectly assuming we’d all read it and talking about Captain Ahab and his obsession with finding and killing this white whale. But it was fun to watch her get more and more excited as she talked. “Ahab’s a madman railing against fate. You never see Ahab wanting anything else in this whole novel, do you? He has a singular obsession. And because he is the captain of his ship, no one can stop him. You can argue—indeed, you may argue, if you choose to write about him for your final reaction papers—that Ahab is a fool for being obsessed. But you could also argue that there is something tragically heroic about fighting this battle he is doomed to lose. Is Ahab’s hope a kind of insanity, or is it the very definition of humanness?” I wrote down as much as I could of what she said, realizing that I could probably pull off my final reaction paper without actually reading the book. As she talked, it occurred to me that Dr. Holden was unusually good at reading stuff. And she’d said she liked Whitman. So when the bell rang, I took Leaves of Grass from my bag and then zipped it back up slowly while everyone raced off either to home or to extracurriculars. I waited behind someone asking for an extension on an already late paper, and then he left.
vi: The only somewhat exciting class for me that day was National Language. Ms. Holden completely ruined Moby Dick for me by assuming that we had all read the book. She innocently lectured about Captain Ahab with his passion for hunting down some white whale. But watching her get more and more engrossed in her lecture was quite interesting. “Ahab is a madman sailing against fate. Throughout the entire novel, you don’t see him pursuing anything else, right? He has only one obsession. And because he is the captain, no one on the ship can stop him. You could argue—and surely you could make your own argument if you choose to write about him in your final essay—that Ahab is a mad fool because of that passion. But you could also argue that there is something epic and tragic about Ahab engaging in a battle he is certain to lose. Is Ahab’s hope a form of desperate madness, or is it a powerful embodiment of humanity?” I quickly scribbled down as much as I could of Ms. Holden’s words, realizing that I could neatly submit my final paper without actually reading the entire book. While listening to the lecture, I suddenly realized that Ms. Holden had an extraordinary ability to understand literature. She also once mentioned that she liked Whitman. So when the bell rang, I took out Leaves of Grass and slowly flipped through it while the other students either left or went to do some extracurricular activities. I waited behind a student who was asking for an extension on a late assignment, and then they left the classroom.
tr: The only slightly interesting class that day was my literature class where Dr. Holden, assuming we had all read Moby Dick, completely ruined the book for me by talking about Captain Ahab and his obsession with finding and killing that white whale. But it was fun to watch him get more and more excited as he talked. “Ahab is a madman who curses fate. In the novel, you didn't see Ahab want anything else, did you? He has a single obsession. And because he's the captain of the ship, no one can stop him. If you choose to write about him in your final papers, you can argue that Ahab is a fool because of his obsession... But you can also discuss that there is something tragically heroic in his continuing this doomed struggle. Is Ahab's hope something akin to madness, or is it the very definition of humanity?” Realizing that I could ace the final paper without actually reading the book, I wrote down as much as I could from what he said. As he spoke, it occurred to me that Dr. Holden was unusually good at reading things. And he had said he liked Whitman. So when the bell rang, I took out my Grass Blades from my bag, while everyone else hurriedly went either home or to places unrelated to class, I slowly zipped up my bag. I waited behind someone who was asking for extra time for an already late assignment, then the kid left.
es: The only remotely interesting class that day was literature, when Dr. Holden spoiled the ending of Moby Dick by assuming, mistakenly, that we had all read it and talking about Captain Ahab and his obsession with finding and killing the white whale. But it was fun to see how excited she got as she spoke. —Ahab is a madman who rants about fate. Throughout the entire novel, it is clear he wants nothing else, right? He has a single obsession. And since he is the captain of the ship, no one can stop him. You can argue (in fact, you have to argue if you decide to do your final paper on Moby Dick) that Ahab is mad because he is obsessed. But you could also argue that there is something tragically heroic about fighting a battle he is doomed to lose. Is Ahab's hope a kind of madness or is it the symbol of what it means to be human? I took notes on everything I could, thinking that I would surely be able to do the end-of-term paper without having read the book. While Dr. Holden was speaking, I thought she was an extraordinary reader. And she had told me that she liked Whitman. So when the bell rang, I took Leaves of Grass out of my backpack and closed it slowly while everyone else ran off to their homes or extracurricular activities. I waited behind a classmate who asked for an extension to submit a paper.

en: “It’s my favorite Whitman reader,” she said.
vi: “Here is my Whitman fan reader,” she said to me.
tr: “Here is my favorite Whitman reader,” he said.
es: —My favorite Whitman reader —Dr. Holden told me when the student left.

en: I forced a smile. “Do you know Margo Roth Spiegelman?” I asked.
vi: I forced a smile. "Do you know Margo Roth Spiegelman?" I asked.
tr: I smiled with difficulty. “Do you know Margo Roth Spiegelman?” I asked.
es: I forced a smile. —Do you know Margo Roth Spiegelman? —I asked him.

en: She sat down behind her desk and motioned for me to sit. “I never had her in class,” Dr. Holden said, “but I’ve certainly heard of her. I know that she ran away.”
vi: She sat down at the table and moved aside to make room for me. "Margo never registered for my class," Ms. Holden said, "but I certainly have heard of her. I also know that she has left."
tr: He sat at his desk and motioned for me to sit as well. "He never attended my class," said Dr. Holden, "but I definitely heard about him. I know he ran away from home."
es: He sat at his table and indicated with a gesture that I should sit as well. —I've never had her in class —Dr. Holden replied to me—, but I've heard of her, of course. I know she has escaped.

en: “She sort of left me this book of poems before she, uh, disappeared.” I handed the book over, and Dr. Holden began paging through it slowly. As she did, I told her, “I’ve been thinking a lot about the highlighted parts. If you go to the end of ‘Song of Myself,’ she highlights this stuff about dying. Like, ‘If you want me again look for me under your bootsoles.’”
vi: “She left me this book before she, uh, disappeared.” I handed over the book, and Ms. Holden began to slowly turn each page. Meanwhile, I continued, “I’ve thought a lot about the highlighted passages. If you look at the end of the poem ‘Song of Myself,’ you’ll see that Margo highlighted the lines about death. Like the line ‘If you want me, look for me under your boot-soles.’”
tr: “This poetry book was left to me, well, before disappearing.” I handed the book to him and Dr. Holden slowly started turning the pages. I continued talking as he turned the pages. “I thought a lot about the underlined sections. If you go to the end of My Own Song, he underlined these things about dying. Things like: ‘If you want me again, look for me under your soles.’”
es: —Well, he left me this book of poems before… disappearing. I handed her the book, and Dr. Holden began to leaf through it slowly. As she turned the pages, I said to her: —I have pondered a lot over the marked verses. At the end of the "Song of Myself" it points out that about death. That part of "If you want to find me, look for me under the sole of your shoes."

en: “She left this for you,” Dr. Holden said quietly.
vi: “Did he leave the book for you?” Miss Holden said softly.
tr: “He left this for you,” said Dr. Holden quietly.
es: —He left you this book —murmured Dr. Holden as if to herself.

en: “Yeah,” I said.
vi: "Yes," I replied.
tr: "Yes," I said.
es: —Yes —I replied to him.

en: She flipped back and tapped at the green highlighted quote with her fingernail. “What is this about the doorjambs? That’s a great moment in the poem, where Whitman—I mean, you can feel him shouting at you: ‘Open the doors! In fact, remove the doors!’”
vi: Ms. Holden flipped back, her fingertip pointing to the section marked in green. "What about the part about these doors?" "A brilliant moment in the entire poem, when Whitman—it feels like he's speaking directly to you: 'Open the doors! Throw the doors wide open!'"
tr: He turned it over again and lightly tapped the word underlined in green with his fingernail. “What's the deal with the door frames? This is a wonderful moment in the poem, you can feel Whitman shouting at you: ‘Open the doors! In fact, break down the doors!”’
es: He kept turning the pages and pointed with his nail to the quote highlighted in green fluorescent. —What is this about the hinges? It is a great moment in the poem, in which Whitman... Well, you hear him shouting at you: "Open the doors! In fact, tear them off!"

en: “She actually left me something else inside my doorjamb.”
vi: "Indeed, Margo left something else in the door frame of my room."
tr: “Actually, he left something else inside the frame of my door.”
es: —He left something inside the hinge of my door.

en: Dr. Holden laughed. “Wow. Clever. But it’s such a great poem—I hate to see it reduced to such a literal reading. And she seems to have responded very darkly to what is finally a very optimistic poem. The poem is about our connectedness—each of us sharing the same root system like leaves of grass.”
vi: Ms. Holden burst out laughing. "Wow! That's clever! But this is truly a great poem—I don't like to just understand it in a purely literal sense. It seems that Margo had a somewhat ambiguous reaction to a poem that is actually very optimistic and cheerful. This poem talks about the connection that binds us together—we all share the same root system, like blades of grass."
tr: Dr. Holden laughed. “Wow. Smart. But this is such a wonderful poem that... I hate to see it reduced to such a plain reading. And it seems like you have reacted very darkly to a poem that is ultimately very optimistic. This poem is about our connectedness... about each of us sharing the same root system like blades of grass.”
es: The doctor Holden laughed. —Wow. Smart. But it's a very good poem... I don't like it at all when it's reduced to a literal reading. And it seems that he reacted very enigmatically to a poem that is ultimately very optimistic. The poem is about our connection, that we all share the same roots, like blades of grass.

en: “But, I mean, from what she highlighted, it seems kinda like a suicide note,” I said. Dr. Holden read the last stanzas again and then looked up at me.
vi: “But with the marked passages, it seems like Margo also had a death wish, ma'am.” I said. Ms. Holden reread the final stanzas and then looked at me.
tr: “But I mean, from what you underlined, it looks like a suicide note,” I said. Dr. Holden read the last stanzas again and looked up at me.
es: —But, well, from what it indicated, it seems like some kind of suicide note —I told him. Dr. Holden read the last stanzas again and looked at me.

en: “What a mistake it is to distill this poem into something hopeless. I hope that’s not the case, Quentin. If you read the whole poem, I don’t see how you can come to any conclusion except that life is sacred and valuable. But—who knows. Maybe she skimmed it for what she was looking for. We often read poems that way. But if so, she completely misunderstood what Whitman was asking of her.”
vi: “Imputing a sense of despair to this poem is a mistake. I hope that’s not the case here, Quentin. If you read the entire poem, I don’t think you could come to any conclusion other than recognizing that life is sacred and precious. But—who knows. Maybe Margo just picked out the parts she needed to find. Sometimes we do read poetry that way. But if that’s the case, then Margo completely misunderstood what Whitman expected of his readers.”
tr: “What a great mistake it is to dissect this poem into something hopeless. I hope that's not the case, Quentin. If you read the entire poem, I don't understand how you could come to any other conclusion than that life is sacred and valuable. But... who knows. Maybe he skimmed through the poem for what he was looking for. That's usually how we read poems. But if that's the case, he completely misunderstood what Whitman wanted from him.”
es: —It is a big mistake to summarize this poem as something without hope. I hope that is not the case, Quentin. If you read the whole poem, I don't understand how you can come to any other conclusion than that life is sacred and valuable. But... who knows. Maybe he took a glance to find what he was looking for. We often read poems like that. But if that was the case, he totally misunderstood what Whitman was asking of him.

en: “And what’s that?”
vi: "And what is that expectation?"
tr: “What is that?”
es: —And what did he ask for?

en: She closed the book and looked right at me in a way that made it impossible for me to hold her gaze. “What do you think of it?”
vi: Ms. Holden closed the book, looking straight at me with eyes that made me too embarrassed to look back. "What do you think it is?"
tr: He closed the book and looked at me in a way that made it impossible for me to return his gaze. “What are you thinking?”
es: He closed the book and looked at me so intently that I couldn't hold his gaze. —What do you think?

en: “I don’t know,” I said, staring at a stack of graded papers on her desk. “I’ve tried to read it straight through a bunch of times, but I haven’t gotten very far. Mostly I just read the parts she highlighted. I’m reading it to try to understand Margo, not to try to understand Whitman.”
vi: “I don't know,” I replied, my eyes glued to the stack of graded papers on her desk. “Countless times I've tried to read and understand, but I never get very far. Mostly, I just read the highlighted parts. I read to try to understand Margo, not to try to understand Whitman.”
tr: “I don't know,” I said, looking at the pile of graded assignments on his desk. “I tried to read it straight through many times, but I couldn't get very far. Mostly, I just read the sections she underlined. I'm reading the poem to try to understand Margo, not to try to understand Whitman.”
es: —I don't know —I replied, looking at a pile of graded papers on her desk—. I've tried to read it all the way through many times, but I haven't gotten very far. I practically only read the parts that Margo has marked. I read it to try to understand her, not Whitman.

en: She picked up a pencil and wrote something on the back of an envelope. “Hold on. I’m writing that down.”
vi: She took a pencil and wrote something on the back of an envelope. "Wait a minute. I am rewriting that idea."
tr: He took a pen and wrote something on the back of an envelope. “Wait. I'm writing this down.”
es: He took a pencil and wrote something on the back of an envelope. —Go on. I'm writing it down.

en: “What?”
vi: “What?”
tr: “What?”
es: —What?

en: “What you just said,” she explained.
vi: “What you just said,” she explained.
tr: “As you said,” he explained.
es: —What you just said —he explained to me.

en: “Why?”
vi: “Why?”
tr: “Why?”
es: —Why?

en: “Because I think that is precisely what Whitman would have wanted. For you to see ‘Song of Myself’ not just as a poem but as a way into understanding another. But I wonder if maybe you have to read it as a poem, instead of just reading these fragments for quotes and clues. I do think there are some interesting connections between the poet in ‘Song of Myself’ and Margo Spiegelman—all that wild charisma and wanderlust. But a poem can’t do its work if you only read snippets of it.”
vi: "Because I believe that is exactly what Whitman intended. For you to see that 'Song of Myself' is not just a poem but also a way to understand others. But I don't know if you can read it like an ordinary poem, rather than just reading excerpts and looking for clues. I truly believe there are interesting connections between the poet in 'Song of Myself' and Margo Spiegelman—all those wild personalities and the wandering spirit. But a poem cannot be complete if you only read fragments of it."
tr: “Because I think this is exactly what Whitman would want. For you to see Your Own Song not just as a poem, but also as a way to understand someone else. But instead of reading these pieces made up of just quotes and hints, perhaps you should read it as a poem. I think there are interesting connections between the poet in Your Own Song and Margo Spiegelman... all that wild charisma and passion for travel. If you only read small parts of it, a poem doesn't achieve its purpose.”
es: —Because I believe it is exactly what Whitman would have wanted. For you to consider "Song of Myself" not as a mere poem, but as a way to understand something else. But I wonder if you shouldn't read it as a poem, not just those fragments in search of quotes and clues. I think there are interesting connections between the poet of "Song of Myself" and Margo Spiegelman... That wild charisma and that wandering spirit. But poems don't work if you only read them in pieces.

en: “Okay, thanks,” I said. I took the book and stood up. I didn’t feel much better.
vi: "Yes, thank you, ma'am," I said, taking the book and standing up. I didn't feel much better.
tr: “Well, thank you,” I said. I took the book and stood up. It couldn't be said that I felt any better. ()
es: —Alright, thank you —I said to him. I grabbed the book and stood up. I didn't feel much better.

en: I got a ride home with Ben that afternoon and stayed at his house until he left to go pick up Radar for some pre-prom party being thrown by our friend Jake, whose parents were out of town. Ben asked me to go, but I didn’t feel like it.
vi: In the afternoon, I went home with Ben and stayed at his place until he had to go pick up Radar for a pre-prom party at Jake's, our friend's house, since Jake's parents were not home. Ben invited me to go along, but I wasn't very interested.
tr: In the afternoon, I went home with Ben and stayed at his house until we went to pick up Radar for a pre-prom party given by our friend Jake, whose parents were out of town. Ben wanted me to go too, but I wasn't in the mood.
es: That afternoon I drove back with Ben and stayed at his house until he went to pick up Radar to go to a sort of pre-prom party at our friend Jake's house, whose parents were out of town. Ben asked me to join, but I didn't feel like it.

en: I walked back to my house, across the park where Margo and I had found the dead guy. I remembered that morning, and I felt something twist at my gut in the remembering of it—not because of the dead guy, but because I remembered that she had found him first. Even in my own neighborhood’s playground, I’d been unable to find a body on my own—how the hell would I do it now?
vi: I walked home, passing through the park where Margo and I had found the man who had committed suicide years ago. I still remember that morning, and my stomach suddenly churned at the memory—not because of the dead body, but because I recalled that she had found him first. Even in the playground near my house, I had never found a dead body myself—so now, what the hell am I supposed to do?
tr: Walking, I passed through the park where Margo and I found the dead man and turned back. I remembered that morning, and with that memory, I felt something turning in my stomach... not because of the dead man, but because I remembered that Margo was the one who found him first. Even in a playground in my own neighborhood, I was incapable of finding a dead body on my own... How was I going to do it now?
es: I walked back home and crossed the park where Margo and I had found the dead body. I remembered that morning, and as I recalled it, I felt my stomach churn, not because of the dead body, but because I remembered that she had seen it first. Not even in the playground of our neighborhood had I been able to find a corpse by myself... How the hell was I going to find it at that moment?

en: I tried to read “Song of Myself” again when I got home that night, but despite Dr. Holden’s advice, it still turned into a jumble of nonsensical words.
vi: I tried to read "Tự khúc" again when I was at home that night, but despite Ms. Holden's advice, the poem still jumbled into a bunch of meaningless words.
tr: That night when I came home, I tried to read My Own Song again, but despite Dr. Holden's advice, the poem was still turning into a jumble of meaningless words.
es: I tried to read "Song of Myself" again when I got home that night, but, despite Dr. Holden's advice, it still seemed like a jumble of meaningless words to me.
