God, let's not even go there. I have a lot to do. Look, if I get a chance, I'll call you later.
es: ITWASAKIDNEYINFECTION: Colleague, the dance starts in eleven hours and forty minutes. I have to pick up Lacey in less than nine hours. I still haven't cleaned and polished the Chuco, which, by the way, you left in a terrible state. Then I have to shower, shave, trim my nose hairs, and polish myself up too. Damn, let's not start. I have a lot to do. Look, I'll call you later if I can.

She wants to have a nice prom. I want to have a nice prom. It’s not my fault that Margo Roth Spiegelman didn’t want us to have a nice prom.

en: I didn’t know what to say. He was right, maybe. Maybe she deserved to be forgotten. But at any rate, I couldn’t forget her.

tr: I didn't know what to say. Maybe he was right. Maybe Margo deserved to be forgotten. But in any case, I couldn't forget her.
es: I didn't know what to say. Maybe she was right. Maybe Margo deserved to be forgotten. But, in any case, I couldn't forget her.

en: My mom and dad were still in bed, watching an old movie on TV. “Can I take the minivan?” I asked.
vi: Mom and Dad are still in bed, watching an old movie on TV. "Can I take the car?" I asked.
tr: My mom and dad were still in bed, watching an old movie on TV. "Can I take the minivan?" I asked.
es: My mother and my father were still in bed, watching an old movie on TV. —Can I take the car? —I asked.

en: “Sure, why?”
vi: "Sure, what's the matter, dear?"
tr: “Of course, why?”
es: —Of course, why?

en: “Decided to go to prom,” I answered hurriedly. The lie occurred to me as I told it. “Gotta pick out a tux and then get over to Ben’s. We’re both going stag.” My mom sat up, smiling.
vi: “I've changed my mind, I'll go to the party,” I replied quickly. The lie just slipped out as I opened my mouth. “I'll go pick out a suit and then head over to Ben's place, we'll go together.” Mom immediately sat up, a smile spreading across her face.
tr: “I decided to go to Baloya,” I replied hastily. This lie came to my mind as I spoke. “After choosing a tuxedo, I must go to Ben’s; we are both going without dates.” My mother straightened up with a smile.
es: —I have decided to go to the prom —I answered immediately. The lie occurred to me as I was saying it—. I have to pick up a tuxedo and stop by Ben's house. We will go just the two of us. My mother sat up smiling.

en: “Well, I think that’s great, hon. It’ll be great for you. Will you come back so we can take pictures?”
vi: "That's more like it, that's good." "You two have fun together, are you coming home so that your parents can take a commemorative photo?"
tr: “Well, I think this is great, sweetie. It will be very good for you. Will you come back so we can take a photo?”
es: —Well, great, darling. You will have a fantastic time. Will you come back so we can take pictures of you?

en: “Mom, do you really need pictures of me going to prom stag? I mean, hasn’t my life been humiliating enough?”
vi: "Mom, do you really need evidence photos of me going to a party? Isn't my life pathetic enough already?"
tr: “Anne, do you really need a photo of me going to the prom without a date? I mean, hasn't my life been embarrassing enough already?”
es: —Mom, do you really need pictures of me going to the dance alone? I mean, hasn't my life been humiliating enough already?

en: She laughed.
vi: Mom laughed heartily.
tr: She laughed.
es: He laughed.

en: “Call before curfew,” my dad said, which was midnight.
vi: "Call before curfew," Dad reminded, which means before midnight.
tr: "Come back before your curfew," said my father, as it was midnight.
es: —Call before curfew —my father told me. The curfew was at midnight.

en: “Sure thing,” I said. It was so easy to lie to them that I found myself wondering why I’d never much done it before that night with Margo.
vi: "Definitely," I replied. The lie to my parents was so smooth that I wondered why I had never utilized this ability before the night I went with Margo.
tr: “Absolutely,” I said. It was so easy to lie to them that I wondered why I hadn't done it more often before that night with Margo.
es: —Of course —I replied. It was so easy to lie to them that I found myself wondering why, until that night with Margo, I had hardly done it.

en: I took I-4 west toward Kissimmee and the theme parks, and then passed I-Drive where Margo and I had broken into SeaWorld, and then took Highway 27 down toward Haines City. There are a lot of lakes down there, and wherever there are lakes in Florida, there are rich people to congregate around them, so it seemed an unlikely place for a pseudovision. But the Website I’d found had been very specific about there being this huge parcel of oft-foreclosed land that no one had ever managed to develop. I recognized the place immediately, because every other subdivision on the access road was walled in, whereas Quail Hollow was just a plastic sign hammered into the ground. As I turned in, little plastic posters read FOR SALE, PRIME LOCATION, and GREAT DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIE$!
vi: I entered the I-4 highway, heading west towards Kissimmee and the theme parks, passing I-Drive where Margo and I had sneaked into SeaWorld, then followed Highway 27 down to the city of Haines. This area has many lakes, and in Florida, wherever there are lakes, the wealthy tend to gather, so this place is unlikely to be suitable for a ghost town. But the website I checked had specifically mentioned that there was a large foreclosed property that had long been abandoned and untouched for development. I immediately recognized that lot, because every subdivision along the road had walls, while Quail Hollow only had a plastic sign stuck in the ground. When I arrived, I read the flyers advertising LAND FOR SALE, IDEAL LOCATION, and OPPORTUNITY TO BOOST $!
tr: I headed towards Kissimmee and the amusement parks, getting onto Route 14, then passed the Boulevard where Margo and I had trespassed into SeaWorld, and then onto Route 27 heading towards Haines City. I got onto the highway. There are many lakes in Haines City, and wherever there are lakes in Florida, there are also wealthy people gathered around them, so it didn't seem like a likely place for a neighborhood. However, the website I found was adamant that it was a huge parcel of land that no one had managed to develop. I recognized it immediately because while all the other neighborhoods along the road were surrounded by walls, Quail Hollow was just a plastic sign staked into the ground. As I turned in, I saw small plastic signs that read FOR SALE, CENTRAL AREA, and GREAT DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES!
es: I took the I-4 towards Kissimmee and the theme parks, passed onto I-Drive, from where Margo and I had entered SeaWorld, and then took Highway 27 towards Haines City. In that area, there are many lakes, and around the lakes in Florida, the rich always congregate, so it seemed unlikely to find a pseudovision. But the website I had consulted offered concrete details about a foreclosed land where no one had yet built. I recognized it immediately because access to all the other developments was fenced off, while in Quail Hollow there was just a simple plastic sign stuck in the ground. Upon entering, I saw plastic signs saying FOR SALE, IDEAL LOCATION, and GREAT DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES.

en: Unlike the previous pseudovisions, someone was keeping up Quail Hollow. No houses had been built, but the lots were marked with surveying stakes, and the grass was freshly mown. All the streets were paved and named with road signs. In the subdivision’s center, a perfectly circular lake had been dug and then, for some reason, drained. As I drove up in the minivan, I could see it was about ten feet deep and several hundred feet in diameter. A hose snaked across the bottom of the crater to the middle, where a steel-and-aluminum fountain rose from the bottom to eye level. I found myself feeling thankful the lake was empty, so I wouldn’t have to stare into the water and wonder if she was in the bottom somewhere, expecting me to put on scuba gear to find her.
vi: Unlike previous ghost towns, Quail Hollow has someone looking after it. No houses have been built yet, but the lots are marked with boundary stakes, and the grass has been freshly cut. The streets in this area are paved and properly named. In the center of the subdivision, a perfectly round lake has been dug, but for some reason, no water has been led into it yet. Driving by, I estimated the lake to be about three meters deep, with a diameter of over a hundred meters. A rubber pipe runs windingly inside the lake, connected to the center, where a fountain made of aluminum and steel is erected from the bottom up to eye level. I was glad the lake was dry, meaning I didn't have to stare at the water, wondering if Margo was at the bottom, waiting for me to dive in and find her.
tr: Unlike the previous neighborhoods, someone was keeping Quail Hollow alive. No houses had been built, but the plots were marked with survey stakes and the lawns were freshly mowed. All the streets were paved and named with street signs. In the center of the neighborhood, a perfectly circular lake had been dug and then for some reason drained. As we moved forward in the minivan, about three meters of the lake I could see that it was round and about 100 meters in diameter. A hose, passing from the bottom of the crater, was winding its way towards the middle part where a steel and aluminum fountain rose from the bottom to eye level. I found myself grateful that the lake was empty, so I wouldn't have to look into the water and wonder if Margo was somewhere at the bottom, waiting for me to dive in with a scuba tank to find her.
es: Unlike the previous pseudovisions, someone was in charge of maintaining Quail Hollow. They hadn't built houses, but the plots were marked with posts and the grass was freshly mowed. All the streets were paved and had name plates. In the center of the development, they had built a perfectly circular lake and, for some reason, they had drained it. As I approached with the car, I saw that it must have been about a meter deep and about one hundred fifty in diameter. A hose zigzagged across the bottom to the center, where a steel and aluminum fountain stood. I found myself glad that the lake was empty, because that way I wouldn't have to stare at the water wondering if Margo was at the bottom, waiting for me to put on a diving suit to find her.

en: I felt certain Margo could not be in Quail Hollow. It abutted too many subdivisions for it to be a good place to hide, whether you were a person or a body. But I looked anyway, and as I idled down the streets in the minivan, I felt so hopeless. I wanted to be happy that it wasn’t here. But if it wasn’t Quail Hollow, it would be the next place, or the one after that, or the one after that. Or maybe I’d never find her. Was that the better fate?
vi: I feel certain that Margo is not at Quail Hollow. This place is surrounded by too many subdivisions, it can't be an ideal spot to hide, whether alive or dead. But I still examined it carefully, and as I sat in the car absentmindedly looking down the streets, I felt truly hopeless. I almost wanted to be glad that it wasn't this place. But if it's not Quail Hollow, then it could be the next location, or the one after that, or the one after that again. Or maybe I will never find Margo. Is that a better fate?
tr: I was sure that Margo couldn’t be in Quail Hollow. This place was too adjacent to other neighborhoods to be suitable for hiding, whether you were a person or a corpse. But I looked anyway, and as I wandered the streets aimlessly, I felt very hopeless. I wanted to be happy that it wasn’t the place. But if it wasn’t Quail Hollow, it would be the next place or the one after that or the one after that... Or maybe I would never find her. Was that a better fate?
es: I was sure I couldn't be in Quail Hollow. It bordered too many developments to be a good place to hide, whether you were alive or dead. But, anyway, I looked, and as I drove through the streets, I felt increasingly hopeless. I wanted to be glad that it wasn't there. But if it wasn't Quail Hollow, it would be the next one, or the next one, or the next one. Or maybe I would never find it. Was that the best thing that could happen?

en: I finished my rounds, finding nothing, and headed back toward the highway. I got lunch at a drive-thru and then ate as I drove out west toward the minimall.
vi: In conclusion, there was nothing at Quail Hollow, so I got back on the highway. I bought lunch at a drive-in, eating while driving west, heading to the mini shopping center from the other day.
tr: I finished my patrol without finding anything and returned to the main road. I got lunch from a place that serves cars, then ate it while driving west towards the small shopping mall.
es: I finished the round without having found anything and returned to the highway. I bought something to eat at a drive-thru restaurant and ate while driving west, towards the small abandoned shopping center.

tr: I got lunch from a place that serves cars, then ate it while driving west towards the small shopping mall.

en: As I pulled into the minimall parking lot, I noticed that blue painters’ tape had been used to seal our hole in the board. I wondered who could have been there after us.
vi: When I pulled into the parking lot next to the mini shopping area, I noticed that someone had covered the hole we made in the plywood the other day with thick blue tape. I wonder who was here after we left.
tr: As I was pulling into the parking lot of the small shopping center, I noticed that blue electrical tape was used to cover the hole we had made in our sign. I wondered who could have come here after us.
es: Upon entering the parking lot, I noticed that they had covered the hole we had made in the particle board with blue adhesive tape. I wondered who had been there after us.

en: I drove around to the back and parked the minivan next to a rusted Dumpster that hadn’t encountered a garbage truck in decades. I figured I could bust through the painters’ tape if I needed to, and I was walking around toward the front when I noticed that the steel back doors to the stores didn’t have any visible hinges.
vi: I drove to the back, parked next to a large rusty dumpster that hadn't seen a garbage truck in decades. I figured if necessary, I would just push through the tape, so I started to walk around to the front but then noticed that the metal back doors weren't attached to any hinges.
tr: I drove around and moved the car to the back, parking the minivan next to a shabby dumpster that hadn't encountered a garbage truck in decades. I thought I could pierce through the electrical tape if necessary; I was heading towards the front when I noticed that the steel back doors leading to the stores had no visible hinges.
es: I drove the car to the back and parked next to a rusty dumpster that hadn't seen a garbage truck in decades. I figured I could slip through the adhesive tape if necessary, and I was heading towards the facade when I noticed that the steel doors at the back of the stores didn't have visible hinges.

en: I’d learned a thing or two about hinges thanks to Margo, and I realized why we hadn’t had any luck pulling on all those doors: they opened in. I walked up to the door to the mortgage company office and pushed. It opened with no resistance whatsoever. God, we were such idiots. Surely, whoever cared for the building knew about the unlocked door, which made the painters’ tape seem even more out of place.
vi: Thanks to Margo, I gained a bit of expertise about door hinges and realized why the three of us couldn't pull those doors open: because they all opened inward. I went to the office door of the mortgage company and pushed in. The door swung open effortlessly. My God, the other day all three of us were really clueless. Surely someone concerned about this building already knew about the unlocked door, so the blue tape on the other side seemed even more redundant.
tr: Thanks to Margo, I had learned a thing or two about hinges and realized why we never had any luck pulling all those doors: They opened inward. I went to the mortgage company's office and pushed the door. It opened without any resistance. God, we were so stupid. Surely whoever was in charge of the building was aware of the unlocked door, which made the electrical tape even more pointless.
es: Thanks to Margo, I had learned a couple of things about hinges, so I understood why we hadn't had any luck pulling on those doors: they opened inward. I approached the door of the mortgage company's office and pushed. It opened without the slightest resistance. Damn, we were such idiots. Undoubtedly, the person in charge of the building knew that the door wasn't locked, which made the adhesive tape seem even more out of place.

en: I wiggled out of the backpack I’d packed that morning and pulled out my dad’s high-powered Maglite and flashed it around the room. Something sizable in the rafters scurried. I shivered. Little lizards jump-ran through the path of the light.
vi: I dropped the backpack I had packed since the morning, took out my dad's high-powered Maglite flashlight, and shone it around the room. It seemed like something large had just scurried away among the beams on the roof. I shivered. Some small lizards jumped into the dark corner, avoiding the path of the light.
tr: I took out the backpack I had prepared that morning and lit up the room with my dad's high-powered Maglite. Something rather large quickly fled from the roof beam. I shuddered. Small lizards scurried away, jumping from the places illuminated by the light.
es: I took off the backpack I had prepared in the morning, took out my father's powerful flashlight, and shone the light around the entire room. Something of considerable size ran across the beams. I shuddered. Several lizards moved in the beam of light.

en: A single shaft of light from a hole in the ceiling shone in the front corner of the room, and sunlight peeked out from behind the particleboard, but I mostly relied on the flashlight. I walked up and down the rows of desks, looking at the items we’d found in the drawers, which we’d left. It was profoundly creepy to see desktop after desktop with the same unmarked calendar: February 1986. February 1986. February 1986. June 1986. February 1986. I spun around and shone the light on a desk in the very center of the room. The calendar had been changed to June. I leaned in close and looked at the paper of the calendar, hoping to see a jagged edge where previous months had been torn off, or some marks on the page where a pen had pushed through the paper, but there was nothing different from the other calendars, save the date.
vi: The only beam of light through a hole in the ceiling fell into the front corner of the room, and a bit of sunlight peeked through the plywood, but I mostly relied on the flashlight. I walked back and forth through the rows of tables, looking at the things we had seen in the drawers and left behind. A creepy feeling surged up terribly as I looked from table to table, each one holding a calendar page without any notes: February 1986. February 1986. February 1986. June 1986. February 1986. I turned around and shone the light on the table in the middle of the room. The calendar was turned to June. I leaned in closer and scrutinized the calendar page, hoping to see a ragged edge where the previous months had been torn off, or some mark on the paper indicating that a pen had passed over it, but there was nothing different from the other calendar pages, except the dates.
tr: A single beam of light coming from the hole in the ceiling illuminated the front corner of the room, and sunlight was seeping in from behind the chipboard, but I mostly relied on the flashlight. I walked back and forth among the rows of desks, looking at the items we found in the drawers and left there. Seeing the same unmarked calendar on the desks one after another was chilling enough to seep into one's soul: February 1986. February 1986. February 1986. June 1986. February 1986. I turned around and shone the light on the desk in the very center of the room. The calendar had moved to June. I leaned in closer and looked at the calendar page, hoping to see a jagged edge where previous months had been torn off or some marks where a pen had left an impression on the paper, but there was nothing different from the other calendars, except for the date.
es: A single ray of light could be seen coming from a hole in the ceiling, in the front corner of the room, and some light filtered in from the other side of the conglomerate, but it practically depended on the flashlight. I walked through the rows of tables observing the objects we had found in the drawers and had left there. It was absolutely creepy to see table after table with the same calendar: February 1986. February 1986. February 1986. June 1986. February 1986. I turned and focused on a table located in the center of the room. They had changed the calendar to June. I leaned in and observed the calendar paper expecting to see the jagged block left after tearing off the pages, or some pen mark on the page, but the only difference from the other calendars was the date.

en: With the flashlight crooked between my neck and shoulder, I started to look through desk drawers again, paying special attention to the June desk: some napkins, some still-sharp pencils, memos about mortgages addressed to one Dennis McMahon, an empty pack of Marlboro Lights, and an almost-full bottle of red nail polish.
vi: Holding the flashlight between my neck and shoulder, I checked the drawers again, paying special attention to the June desk: a few napkins, some still-sharp pencils, notes on the mortgages of a certain Dennis McMahon, an empty pack of Marlboro cigarettes, and a nearly full bottle of red nail polish.
tr: With the flashlight wedged between my neck and shoulder, I began to carefully examine the desk drawers again, paying special attention to the June table: a few napkins, a few still sharp pencils, notes about mortgages addressed to someone named Dennis McMahon, an empty pack of Marlboro Lights, and an almost full bottle of red nail polish.
es: I placed the flashlight between my neck and shoulder, and started searching the drawers again, paying special attention to the June table: napkins, sharpened pencils, mortgage reports addressed to a certain Dennis McMahon, an empty pack of Marlboro Light, and an almost full bottle of red nail polish.

en: I took the flashlight in one hand and the nail polish in the other and stared at it closely. So red it was almost black. I’d seen this color before. It had been on the minivan’s dash that night. Suddenly, the scurrying in the rafters and the creaking in the building became irrelevant—I felt a perverted euphoria. I couldn’t know if it was the same bottle, of course, but it was certainly the same color.
vi: I switched the flashlight to one hand, held the nail polish bottle in the other, and observed carefully. The red color was so dark it almost looked black. I had seen this red color before. On the dashboard of the minivan that night. Suddenly, the large creatures lurking on the roof and the creaking sounds in the building no longer mattered–I just felt a strange exhilaration. Of course, I couldn't know if it was the same bottle of polish, but it was definitely the same shade.
tr: I took the flashlight in one hand and the nail polish in the other, and looked closely at the bottle. It was so red that it was almost black. I had seen this color before. This nail polish was on the panel of the minivan that night. Suddenly, the scurrying in the rafters and the creaking inside the building became insignificant... I felt a perverse excitement. Of course, I couldn't know if it was the same bottle, but it was definitely the same color.
es: I grabbed the flashlight with one hand, the nail polish with the other, and observed it closely. It was so red that it almost looked black. I had seen that color before that night. On the dashboard of the minivan. Suddenly, the running on the beams and the creaking of the building became irrelevant. I felt a perverse euphoria. I couldn't know if it was the same bottle, of course, but it was definitely the same color.

en: I rotated the bottle around and saw, unambiguously, a tiny smear of blue spray paint on the outside of the bottle. From her spray-painted fingers. I could be sure now. She’d been here after we parted ways that morning. Maybe she was still staying here. Maybe she only showed up late at night. Maybe she had taped up the particleboard to keep her privacy.
vi: I rotated the jar and saw, without a doubt, a tiny smudge of sky-blue paint on its surface. Smeared from Margo's sky-blue paint-stained finger. Now I could be certain. She had come here after we said goodbye that morning. Perhaps she was still here. Perhaps she would only appear late at night. Perhaps she had taped the plywood to maintain her privacy.
tr: I turned the bottle around and saw, undeniably, the stain of blue spray paint on the outside of the bottle. It was coming from her spray-painted fingers. Now I could be sure. After we parted ways that morning, Margo had come here. Maybe she was still staying here. Maybe she only appeared late at night. Maybe she had taped the sign to protect her privacy.
es: I turned the jar and saw without the slightest doubt a tiny blue spray stain on the outside of the glass. From his spray-stained fingers. Then I was sure. He had been there after we parted that morning. Maybe he was still there. Maybe he only came out at night. Maybe he had put the tape on the conglomerate to maintain privacy.

en: I resolved right then to stay until morning. If Margo had slept here, I could, too. And thus commenced a brief conversation with myself.
vi: I immediately decided that I would stay here until morning. If Margo could sleep in this place, then I could sleep too. And thus, a brief self-examination took place.
tr: At that moment, I made a firm decision to stay there until morning. If Margo had slept here, I could sleep too. Thus, a brief conversation began between myself and me.
es: At that moment, I decided to stay until the next day. If Margo had slept there, I could do it too. And so began a brief conversation with myself.

en: Me: But the rats.
vi: Me: There are still those rats.
tr: Ben: But mice.
es: Me: But there are rats.

en: Me: Yeah, but they seem to stay in the ceiling.
vi: Me: Yeah, but it seems like they only parade on the ceiling.
tr: Ben: Yes, but they look like they're melting on the ceiling.
es: Me: Yes, but it seems they stay on the roof.

en: Me: But the lizards.
vi: Me: More lizards.
tr: Ben: But lizards.
es: Me: But there are lizards.

en: Me: Oh, come on. You used to pull their tails off when you were little. You’re not scared of lizards.
vi: Me: More lizards. Me: Oh well, when I was a kid, I used to pull off lizard tails. What is the lizard afraid of?
tr: Ben: Oh, come on. When you were little, you used to pull off my tails. You're not afraid of lizards.
es: Me: Oh, come on. When you were little, you used to cut off their tails. Lizards don't scare you.

en: Me: But the rats.
vi: Me: But what about the mouse?
tr: Ben: But mice.
es: Me: But there are rats.

en: Me: Rats can’t really hurt you anyway. They’re more scared of you than you are of them.
vi: Me: After all, who can a mouse hurt? Mice are more afraid of us than we are of them.
tr: Ben: Mice can't really hurt you anyway. They are more afraid of you than you are of them.
es: Me: But the rats can't hurt you. You scare them more than they scare you.

en: Me: Okay, but what about the rats?
vi: Me: Well, what about the rats?
tr: Ben: But what about the mice?
es: Me: Okay, but what about the rats?

en: Me: Shut up.
vi: Me: Stop it right now.
tr: Ben: Shut your mouth.
es: Me: Shut up.

en: In the end, the rats didn’t matter, not really, because I was in a place where Margo had been alive. I was in a place that saw her after I did, and the warmth of that made the minimall almost comfortable. I mean, I didn’t feel like an infant being held by Mommy or anything, but my breath had stopped catching each time I heard a noise. And in becoming comfortable, I found it easier to explore. I knew there was more to find, and now, I felt ready to find it.
vi: In the end, the actual rats didn't really matter because I was where Margo had been. I was in a place that had seen her after I had seen her, and the warmth from that thought made this mini-mall almost pleasant. I didn't feel like a child, always having my mother close by, but I still held my breath whenever I heard a strange noise. And because of the pleasant feeling, this place became easier to explore. There was much to discover, and now, I was ready.
tr: In the end, the mice didn't matter much because I was in a place where Margo was alive. I was in a place where she had been seen after me, and the warmth of that made this small shopping mall almost comfortable. So, I didn't feel like a baby being hugged by its mother or anything, but my breath no longer stopped every time I heard a sound. And being relaxed made it easier to do research. I knew there was more to be found, and now I felt ready to find it.
es: In the end, it didn't matter that there were rats, at least not much, because I was in a place where Margo had been alive. I was in a place that had seen her after me, and that warmth made the mall an almost comfortable place. Well, I didn't feel like a child in his mother's arms, but I no longer ran out of breath every time I heard a noise. And as I felt more comfortable, it became easier for me to explore. I knew there were still things to find, and I was ready to find them.

en: I left the office, ducking through a Troll Hole into the room with the labyrinthine shelves. I walked up and down the aisles for a while. At the end of the room I crawled through the next Troll Hole into the empty room. I sat down on the carpet rolled against the far wall. The cracked white paint crunched against my back. I stayed there for a while, long enough that the jagged beam of light coming through a hole in the ceiling crept an inch along the floor as I let myself become accustomed to the sounds.
vi: I left the office, crawled through a Devil's Hole into the maze-like room of iron shelves. I walked back and forth along the aisle between the rows of shelves for a moment, reached the end of the room, and through the next Devil's Hole into an empty room. I sat down on the rolled-up carpet, leaning against the wall in the corner of the room. The patchy white paint behind me sounded more brittle and cracked. I sat there for a while, long enough for the slanted beam of light from the ceiling to crawl a few inches across the floor, while I gradually adapted to the sounds.
tr: I crawled out of the office through a Dwarf Hole leading to a room with labyrinth-like shelves. I walked back and forth among them for a while. At the end of the room, I crawled through the next Dwarf Hole into an empty room. I sat on the rolled-up carpet in front of the opposite wall. The cracked white paint crackled behind my back. I stayed there for a while; long enough for the beam of light coming through the hole in the ceiling to shift a few centimeters on the floor as I let myself get used to the sounds.
es: I went through a Troll Hole and arrived at the labyrinth of shelves room. I walked through the aisles for a good while. Eventually, I went into the next Troll Hole and crawled to the empty room. I sat on the rolled-up carpet against the back wall. The chipped white paint creaked as I leaned my back against it. I stayed there for a while, long enough for the jagged ray of light coming through a hole in the ceiling to move three centimeters across the floor as I got used to the sounds.

en: After a while, I got bored and crawled through the last Troll Hole into the souvenir shop. I rifled through the T-shirts. I pulled the box of tourist brochures out from under the display case and looked through them, looking for some hand-scrawled message from Margo, but I found nothing.
vi: After a while, I got bored and crawled through the last Ghost Hole into the souvenir room. I browsed through the T-shirts. I pulled out the travel book box from under the display case and looked through it, searching to see if Margo had scribbled a few words, but I found nothing.
tr: After a while, I got bored and crawled through the last Dwarf Hole to the gift shop. I quickly looked at the t-shirts. I pulled the box of tourist brochures from under the display and examined the brochures, looking for a handwritten message from Margo, but I found nothing.
es: After a while, I got bored and crawled through the last Troll Hole to the souvenir shop. I rummaged through the T-shirts. I took the box of tourist brochures from the display case and leafed through them looking for any handwritten message from Margo, but I found nothing.

en: I returned to the room I now found myself calling the library. I thumbed through the Reader’s Digests and found a stack of National Geographics from the 1960s, but the box was covered in so much dust that I knew Margo had never been inside it.
vi: I returned to the room I now call the library. Flipping through the pile of Reader’s Digest magazines, I found a stack of National Geographic issues from the 1960s. But these items were covered in layers of dust, so I knew Margo had never looked through them.
tr: I returned to the room I now found myself calling the library. I flipped through the pages of Reader’s Digest with my finger and found a stack of National Geographic from the 1960s, but the box was so covered in dust that I knew Margo had never touched it.
es: I returned to the room that I found myself calling the library. I flipped through the Reader’s Digests and found a stack of National Geographics from the 1960s, but the box was so covered in dust that it was clear Margo hadn't taken out its contents.

en: I began to find evidence of human habitation only when I got back to the empty room. On the wall with the rolled-up carpet, I discovered nine thumbtack holes in the cracked and paint-peeled wall. Four of the holes made an approximate square, and then there were five holes inside the square. I thought perhaps Margo had stayed here long enough to hang up some posters, although there were none obviously missing from her room when we searched it.
vi: It wasn't until I returned to the empty room that I found evidence of human activity. On the wall near the rolled-up carpet, I discovered nine pinholes on the cracked and peeling painted surface. Four holes formed a relatively square shape, and within that square, there were five more holes. I guessed that Margo had probably been here for quite a while, long enough to want to hang some kind of poster, although we didn't find anything missing when we searched her room.
tr: However, when I returned to the empty room, I began to find evidence of human habitation. I discovered nine thumbtack holes in the cracked and peeling wall where a poster had been hung. Four of the holes formed a shape close to a square, and then five more were inside the square. I thought that Margo might have stayed here long enough to hang a few posters, but when we searched, there was nothing noticeably missing from her room.
es: I didn't start finding signs that someone had been there until I returned to the empty room. On the chipped wall of the carpet, I discovered nine thumbtack holes. Four holes formed a sort of square, and the other five were inside the square. I thought that maybe Margo had spent enough time there to hang some posters, although at first glance it didn't seem like any were missing when we inspected her room.

en: I unrolled the carpet partway and immediately found something else: a flattened, empty box that had once contained twenty-four nutrition bars. I found myself able to imagine Margo here, leaning against the wall with musty rolled-up carpet for a seat, eating a nutrition bar. She is all alone, with only this to eat. Maybe she drives once a day to a convenience store to buy a sandwich and some Mountain Dew, but most of every day is spent here, on or near this carpet. This image seemed too sad to be true—it all struck me as so lonely and so very unMargo. But all the evidence of the past ten days accumulated toward a surprising conclusion: Margo herself was—at least part of the time—very unMargo.
vi: I had spread the carpet halfway when I discovered something else: an empty, flat-folded box that had once contained twenty-four synthetic nutrition bars. I began to imagine Margo had been here, leaning against the wall, sitting on the musty rolled-up carpet, eating a nutrition bar. She was completely alone, with only this to eat. Maybe every day Margo still drove to the convenience store to buy sandwiches and a few bottles of Mountain Dew, but most of the time she was here, on or near the carpet. That image seemed too bleak to be true–it all conjured up in my mind a Margo who was too lonely and too unlike-Margo. But all the evidence from the past ten days pointed to a surprising conclusion: Margo–at least at times–was very unlike Margo.
tr: I partially opened the drawer and found something else inside: a flattened, empty box that once contained twenty-four wafers. I could imagine Margo here, using the moldy carpet as a seat, leaning against the wall, and eating a wafer. Completely alone, with only these wafers as food. Maybe she goes to a market once a day to get a sandwich and a few Mountain Dews, but she spends most of her days here, on or beside this carpet. This vision seemed too pitiful to be real... it struck me that all of this was very lonely and very unMargo-like. But when all the evidence of the last ten days was accumulated, a surprising result emerged: even Margo herself was, at least sometimes, very unMargo-like.
es: I unrolled part of the carpet and immediately found something else: a crushed box that had once contained twenty-four cereal bars. I found myself imagining Margo there, sitting on the rolled-up and moldy carpet, leaning against the wall and eating a cereal bar. She is alone and has nothing else to eat. Maybe once a day she drives to a store to buy herself a sandwich and some Mountain Dew, but she spends most of the day on this carpet or near it. It seemed too sad an image to be real. Too lonely and not at all like Margo. But the clues from the last ten days seemed to lead to a surprising conclusion: Margo was —at least a good part of the time— very unlike Margo.

en: I rolled out the carpet farther and found a blue knit blanket, almost newspaper thin. I grabbed it and held it to my face and there, God, yes. Her smell. The lilac shampoo and the almond in her skin lotion and beneath all of that the faint sweetness of the skin itself.
vi: I spread out the rest of the carpet and saw a sky-blue knitted wool blanket, thin almost like newspaper. I hurriedly grabbed it and brought it to my face, yes, thank God, that's right. The scent of Margo. Lilac-scented shampoo and almond-scented lotion, with a faint sweetness of skin lingering within.
tr: I opened the carpet further and found an almost paper-thin blue knitted blanket. I took the blanket and held it up to my face and there, my God, yes... Margo's scent. Lilac shampoo, almond skin lotion, and beneath it all, the intoxicating sweetness of her skin.
es: I unrolled the carpet a bit more and found a blue knitted blanket, almost as thin as a newspaper. I picked it up, brought it to my face and yes, yes. Its smell. The lilac shampoo and almond lotion, and beyond that, the faint softness of her skin.

en: And I could picture her again: she unravels the carpet halfway each night so her hip isn’t against bare concrete as she lies on her side. She crawls beneath the blanket, uses the rest of the carpet as a pillow, and sleeps. But why here? How is this better than home? And if it’s so great, why leave? These are the things I cannot imagine, and I realize that I cannot imagine them because I didn’t know Margo. I knew how she smelled, and I knew how she acted in front of me, and I knew how she acted in front of others, and I knew that she liked Mountain Dew and adventure and dramatic gestures, and I knew that she was funny and smart and just generally more than the rest of us. But I didn’t know what brought her here, or what kept her here, or what made her leave. I didn’t know why she owned thousands of records but never told anyone she even liked music. I didn’t know what she did at night, with the shades down, with the door locked, in the sealed privacy of her room.
vi: I imagine her again: every night Margo spreads this rug halfway so that her hip doesn't press against the hard concrete when she lies on her side. She curls up under this blanket, resting her head on the part of the rug that isn't fully spread out, and closes her eyes to sleep. But why here? What is better about this place than home? If she liked it here so much, why did she leave? Those things I can't imagine, I realize I can't imagine because I don't understand Margo. I know how she smells, I know how she behaves in front of me, I know how she behaves in front of others, I know she likes Mountain Dew, likes adventure and dramatic games, I also know she is funny, smart, and generally superior to the rest of us. But I don't know what brought Margo here, what made her stay here, what made her leave. I don't know why she has thousands of records but never tells anyone how much she loves music. I don't know what she does every night, behind the discreetly drawn curtains, behind the locked door, in the inviolable private space that is her room.
tr: And I could picture her again: Every night she would roll the carpet halfway open, so that when she lay on her side, her hip wouldn't rest on the bare concrete. She would crawl under the blanket, her honey uses the rest as a pillow and sleeps. But why is she here? How could this place be better than home? And if it’s so great, why is she leaving? These are things I can’t imagine, and I realize that I can’t imagine them because I don’t know Margo. I knew how she smelled, I knew how she behaved in front of me, I knew how she behaved in front of others, I knew she loved Mountain Dew, adventure, and dramatic gestures, I knew she was fun, smart, and generally more than the rest of us. But I didn’t know what brought her here, or what kept her here, or what made her leave. I didn’t know why she had thousands of records, yet never told anyone she loved music. I didn’t know what she did at night, with the blinds closed, the door locked, in the secret privacy of her room.
es: And I imagined her again: she unrolls part of the carpet every night so she doesn't dig her hip into the concrete when she sleeps on her side. She gets under the blanket, uses the rest of the carpet as a pillow, and falls asleep. But why here? Why is it better here than at her house? And if it's so good, why leave? That's what I couldn't imagine, and I realize that I couldn't imagine it because I didn't know Margo. I knew her smell, and I knew how she acted with me, and I knew how she acted with others, and I knew she liked Mountain Dew, adventure, and dramatic gestures, and I knew she was funny, smart, and generally superior to all of us. But I didn't know what had brought her there, or what had kept her there, or what had made her leave there. I didn't know why she had thousands of records, but had never told anyone she liked music. I didn't know what she did at night, in the dark, with the door closed, in the sealed privacy of her room.

en: And maybe this was what I needed to do above all. I needed to discover what Margo was like when she wasn’t being Margo.
vi: And perhaps more than anything, this is what I need to do. I need to find out what Margo is like when she is not being Margo.
tr: And maybe this was what I needed to do before anything else. I needed to discover what Margo looked like when she wasn't being Margo.
es: And maybe it was what I needed more than anything. I needed to discover what Margo was like when she wasn't being Margo.

en: I lay there with the her-scented blanket for a while, staring up at the ceiling. I could see a sliver of late-afternoon sky through a crack in the roof, like a jagged canvas painted a bright blue. This would be the perfect place to sleep: one could see stars at night without getting rained on.
vi: I lay there for a while in the blanket that smelled of Margo, staring up at the ceiling. The twilight sky filtered through the crack in the roof, like a canvas torn to reveal a pale blue strip. This must be the perfect place to fall asleep: at night, you can watch the stars without fearing the rain.
tr: I lay there for a while, staring at the ceiling with a blanket that smelled like him. Through a crack in the roof, I could see a thin piece of the sky in the afternoon, like a rough canvas painted bright blue. This would be a perfect place to sleep: One could see the stars at night without getting rained on.
es: I lay down for a while with the blanket that smelled like her and looked at the ceiling. Through a hole, I could see a small piece of the afternoon sky, like a jagged canvas painted blue. It was the perfect place to sleep. You could see the stars at night without getting wet if it rained.

en: I called my parents to check in. My dad answered, and I said we were in the car on the way to meet Radar and Angela, and that I was staying with Ben overnight. He told me not to drink, and I told him I wouldn’t, and he said he was proud of me for going to prom, and I wondered if he would be proud of me for doing what I was actually doing.
vi: I called home to report my safety. Dad answered the phone, I said we were in the car, on the way to Radar and Angela's place, and I would stay with Ben all night. Dad told me not to drink recklessly, I replied I wouldn't, and he said he was very happy that I went to the prom. And I wondered if he would still be happy if he really knew what I was doing.
tr: I called my mom and dad to inform them. My dad answered, I told him that we were on the road with Radar and Angela and that I would stay at Ben's place for the night. He told me not to drink, and I told him I wouldn't, he said he was proud of me for going to the prom, and I wondered if he would be proud of me for what I was actually doing.
es: I called my parents. My father answered, and I told him that we were in the car, that we were going to pick up Radar and Angela, and that I would stay with Ben all night. He asked me not to drink, I told him I wouldn't, he said he was proud of me for deciding to go to the prom, and I wondered if he would be proud of me for deciding to do what I was actually doing.

en: This place was boring. I mean, once you got past the rodents and the mysterious the-building-is-falling-apart groans in the walls, there wasn’t anything to do. No Internet, no TV, no music. I was bored, so it again confused me that she would pick this place, since Margo always struck me as a person with a very limited tolerance for boredom. Maybe she liked the idea of slumming it? Unlikely. Margo wore designer jeans to break into SeaWorld.
vi: This place is boring. Once you've gotten the upper hand over the gang of rodents and deciphered the mysterious groans of the building-about-to-collapse echoing from the walls, there's nothing left to do. No Internet, no TV, no music. I'm bored, so I don't understand why Margo chose this place; she always gave the impression that she had very little tolerance for boredom. Or does she like this dilapidated scene? Could it be. With that Margo who wore stylish jeans to break into SeaWorld.
tr: This place was boring. I mean, once you got past the rodents and the mysterious "building is falling apart" creaks, there was nothing to do. No internet, no television, no music. I was bored, so the fact that he had chosen this place puzzled me again; because Margo had always caught my attention as a person with limited tolerance for boredom. Did she like the idea of living in a ruin? It was quite unlikely. Margo was wearing designer jeans while sneaking into SeaWorld.
es: The place was a bore. I mean that once you got past the rodents and the mysterious creaking of the walls, as if the building was about to collapse, there was nothing to do. No internet, no TV, no music. I was bored, so it kept puzzling me that she had chosen that place, because Margo had always seemed to me like someone with a very limited tolerance for boredom. Maybe she liked the idea of living like a poor person. I doubt it. Margo wore brand-name jeans when we snuck into SeaWorld.

en: It was the lack of alternative stimuli that led me back to “Song of Myself,” the only certain gift I had from her. I moved to a water-stained patch of concrete floor directly beneath the hole in the ceiling, sat down cross-legged, and angled my body so the light shone upon the book. And for some reason, finally, I could read it.
vi: It was the lack of alternative stimuli that brought me back to "Self-Elegy," the only certain gift I received from Margo. I went to the floor, stained with long-dried water marks, directly under the hole in the ceiling, sat cross-legged, and leaned to let the light shine down on the page. In the end, somehow, I managed to read through it.
tr: It was the lack of an alternative stimulus that brought me back to My Own Song, the only gift I received from it. I moved to a water-stained part of the concrete floor, directly under the hole in the ceiling, sat cross-legged, and adjusted my body angle so that the light would illuminate the book. And somehow, I was finally able to read the poem.
es: The absence of alternative stimuli led me back to "Song of Myself," the only gift that had undoubtedly been left for me. I moved to a spot on the cement floor that had water stains, directly under the hole in the roof, sat cross-legged, and tilted the book so that the ray of light fell directly on it. And for some reason, I was finally able to read it.

en: The thing is that the poem starts out really slowly—it’s just sort of a long introduction, but around the ninetieth line, Whitman finally starts to tell a bit of a story, and that’s where it picked up for me. So Whitman is sitting around (which he calls loafing) on the grass, and then:
vi: The problem is that the poem starts extremely slowly—the introduction drags on and on, and it isn't until the ninth line that Whitman finally begins to reveal the story, and that's where I started to understand. So Whitman is sitting idly (which he calls being at ease) on the grass, then:
tr: The thing is, the poem starts very slowly... There is a kind of long introduction, but around the ninetieth line, Whitman finally starts telling a bit of a story, and this is where the poem picks up pace for me. In the end, Whitman is sitting idly on the grass (which he calls loafing) and then:
es: The thing is that the poem starts very slowly, with a sort of long introduction, but around verse ninety Whitman finally begins to tell a story, so I started from there. Whitman is sitting on the grass (he says lying down), and then:
