en: There was the hope Dr. Holden had talked about—the grass was a metaphor for his hope. But that’s not all. He continues,
vi: This is the hope that Ms. Holden mentioned–grass is a metaphor for hope. But that's not all, the poet continues:
tr: This was the hope that Dr. Holden talked about... The grass was a metaphor for Whitman's hope. But that's not all. It continues as follows:
es: There was the hope that Dr. Holden had told me about. The grass was a metaphor for hope. But that's not all. It goes on to say:

en: Or I guess it is the handkerchief of the Lord,
vi: Or perhaps that is the handkerchief of the Person,
tr: Or maybe I think it's God's handkerchief,
es: Or the handkerchief of God,

en: A scented gift and remembrancer designedly dropped,
vi: The gift carries a fragrance, a keepsake bestowed by Him.
tr: A fragrant gift and a deliberately dropped keepsake,
es: a fragrant garment deliberately dropped,

en: Like grass is a metaphor for God’s greatness or something. . . .
vi: It's like grass is a metaphor for the greatness of God, and there's more... Or perhaps grass is just like children...
tr: As if the grass is a metaphor for something like the grandeur of God...
es: The grass is a metaphor for the greatness of God, or something like that.

en: Or I guess the grass is itself a child . . . .
vi: Or perhaps grass is just like children...
tr: Or maybe I think the grass itself is a child...
es: Or I suspect that the grass itself is a child...

en: And then soon after that,
vi: And right after that,
tr: And a little after this,
es: And something later:

en: Or I guess it is a uniform hieroglyphic,
vi: Or perhaps grass is a uniform pictogram,
tr: Or perhaps I think it is a monotonous hieroglyph,
es: A uniform hieroglyph,

en: And it means, Sprouting alike in broad zones and narrow
vi: Rising up amidst the vast forest and from a limited corner,
tr: And this means to sprout in wide areas and narrow areas without discrimination,
es: what it means: I grow equally in the vast regions and in the narrow ones,

en: zones,
vi: Rising up amidst the vast forest and from a limited corner,
tr: And this means to sprout in wide areas and narrow areas without discrimination,
es: what it means: I grow equally in the vast regions and in the narrow ones,

en: Growing among black folks as among white.
vi: Green grows among black friends as well as white friends.
tr: Growing up among white people as well as within black communities.
es: I grow equally among blacks and whites.

en: So maybe the grass is a metaphor for our equality and our essential connectedness, as Dr. Holden had said. And then finally, he says of grass,
vi: So perhaps grass is a metaphor for equality and the close connection between us, as Ms. Holden mentioned. And Whitman's final words about grass:
tr: So maybe grass is a metaphor for our equality and fundamental interconnectedness, just as Dr. Holden said. And then finally, he says this about the grass:
es: So maybe the grass is a metaphor that we are equal and basically connected, as Dr. Holden had told me. And then it says about the grass:

en: And now it seems to me the beautiful uncut hair of graves.
vi: And now to me, the grass is the hair of the grave, hanging loose without the sorrow of cutting.
tr: And now it seems to me like the uncut beautiful hair of graves.
es: And now it seems to me that it is the loose and beautiful hair of the tombs.

en: So grass is death, too—it grows out of our buried bodies. The grass was so many different things at once, it was bewildering. So grass is a metaphor for life, and for death, and for equality, and for connectedness, and for children, and for God, and for hope.
vi: Thus, grass is also death–growing from the buried bodies. There are too many layers of meaning in the image of grass; it truly is a tangled mess. In summary, grass is a metaphor for life, death, equality, connection, and it alludes to children, God, and hope.
tr: So, grass at the same time is death... growing out from our buried bodies. Grass simultaneously expressed so many different things that it was astonishing. So, grass was a metaphor for life, for death, for equality, for connectedness, for children, for God, and for hope.
es: So the grass is also death. It grows above our buried bodies. The grass was many different things at once. It was bewildering. The grass is a metaphor for life, and for death, and for equality, and for our interconnectedness, and for children, and for God, and for hope.

en: I couldn’t figure out which of these ideas, if any, was at the core of the poem. But thinking about the grass and all the different ways you can see it made me think about all the ways I’d seen and mis-seen Margo. There was no shortage of ways to see her. I’d been focused on what had become of her, but now with my head trying to understand the multiplicity of grass and her smell from the blanket still in my throat, I realized that the most important question was who I was looking for. If “What is the grass?” has such a complicated answer, I thought, so, too, must “Who is Margo Roth Spiegelman?” Like a metaphor rendered incomprehensible by its ubiquity, there was room enough in what she had left me for endless imaginings, for an infinite set of Margos.
vi: I have yet to figure out what, if anything, in these images is the essence of this poem. But thinking about grass and the different ways of perceiving it makes me think of all the ways I have seen and mis-seen Margo. There is no shortage of ways to look at her. I was too focused on what she became, but now, as I try to understand the multifaceted nature of grass, with Margo's scent still lingering in my throat from the blanket, I realize that the most important question is: who am I trying to find. If "What is grass?" requires such a complex answer, then the same must be true for the question "Who is Margo Roth Spiegelman?" Like a metaphor that cannot be instantly conveyed in its entirety by its simultaneous layers of meaning, in what Margo left for me, there is enough room for endless imaginations, for an unlimited series of different Margos.
tr: I couldn't understand which of these ideas, if any, was the essence of the poem. But thinking about the grass and all the different ways to understand it made me think about all the ways I understood and misunderstood Margo. There was no lack of ways to see her. I had focused on what had happened to her, but now, with my mind trying to understand the variety of the grass and the scent of the blanket still in my nose, I realized that the most important question was whom I was searching for. If the question "What is grass?" has such a complex answer, I thought that the question "Who is Margo Roth Spiegelman?" must be the same. Like a metaphor that becomes incomprehensible because it is everywhere, in what she left for me, there was enough room for endless dreams and an unlimited group of Margos.
es: I couldn't figure out which of these ideas was the crux of the poem, assuming any of them were. But thinking about the grass and the different ways of seeing it made me think about all the ways I had seen and misseen Margo. The ways of seeing her were not few. I had focused on what had become of her, but there, trying to understand the multiplicity of the grass and with the smell of the blanket still in my throat, I realized that the more important question was who I was looking for. I thought that if it was so complicated to answer the question "What is the grass?", it must also be complicated to answer the question "Who is Margo Roth Spiegelman?". Like a metaphor elusive in its breadth, in what she had left me, there was room to imagine infinitely, for an infinite series of Margos.

en: I had to narrow her down, and I figured there had to be things here that I was seeing wrong or not seeing. I wanted to tear off the roof and light up the whole place so that I could see it all at once, instead of one flashlight beam at a time. I put aside Margo’s blanket and shouted, loud enough for all the rats to hear, “I Am Going To Find Something Here!”
vi: I have to narrow her down, and I realize that in this place, there must be things I have seen incorrectly or not seen at all. I want to tear open the roof above, illuminating every corner to see everything at once, rather than just following the scattered flashlight beams sweeping back and forth. I set Margo's blanket aside and shouted, loud enough for all the gnawing creatures to hear, "I Will Find Something In This Place!"
tr: I had to narrow Margo down and I thought there must be things here that I misunderstood or didn't understand. I wanted to hold and tear off the roof and light up this whole place so I could see everything at once instead of just one lantern light at a time. Putting Margo's blanket aside, I shouted loud enough for all the mice to hear, "I Will Find Something Here!"
es: I had to narrow it down, and I assumed that there had to be things I was seeing wrong or not seeing at all. I wanted to tear off the roof so that the light could come in and I could see everything at once, not each thing separately with the flashlight. I pulled Margo's blanket aside and shouted loud enough for the rats to hear me: —Am I going to find something here?

en: I went through each desk in the office again, but it seemed more and more obvious that Margo had used only the desk with the nail polish in the drawer and the calendar set to June.
vi: I checked each desk in the office, and the more I searched, the clearer it became that Margo only used the desk with the nail polish bottle in the drawer and the calendar stopped at June.
tr: I reviewed every desk in the office again, but it was becoming increasingly apparent that Margo only used the desk with nail polish in the drawer and the calendar set to June.
es: I returned to the desks in the office, but it seemed increasingly obvious that Margo had only used the one with the nail polish and the calendar set to the month of June.

en: I ducked through a Troll Hole and made my way back to the library, walking again through the abandoned metal shelves. On each shelf I looked for dustless shapes that would tell me Margo had used this space for something, but I couldn’t find any. But then my darting flashlight happened across something atop the shelf in a corner of the room, right near the boarded-up storefront window. It was the spine of a book.
vi: I crawled through the Devil's Hole, returned to the library, and once again walked along the empty iron shelves. On each shelf, I strained my eyes to see if there was any spot not covered in dust, indicating that Margo had used it for something, but I saw nothing. Then my flashlight happened to sweep over something on top of a shelf in the corner of the room, right near the front window blocked by plywood. It was the spine of a book.
tr: I crouched through a Dwarf Hole and walked back through the abandoned shelves, then proceeded in the library. I looked for dust-free shapes on each shelf that would show me Margo had used that area for something, but I found nothing. But then, my swiftly moving flashlight caught something at the top of a shelf in a corner of the room, just to the side of the store's boarded-up front window. It was the spine of a book.
es: I crawled through a Troll Hole, returned to the library, and once again wandered through the abandoned metal shelves. I searched all the shelves for dust-free marks that would indicate Margo had used them for something, but I found none. But suddenly, the flashlight beam passed over something on a shelf in a corner of the room, right next to the display case with the particle board. It was the spine of a book.

en: The book was called Roadside America: Your Travel Guide, and had been published in 1998, after this place had been abandoned. I flipped through it with the flashlight crooked between neck and shoulder. The book listed hundreds of attractions you could visit, from the world’s largest ball of twine in Darwin, Minnesota, to the world’s largest ball of stamps in Omaha, Nebraska. Someone had folded down the corners of several seemingly random pages. The book wasn’t too dusty. Maybe SeaWorld was only the first stop on some kind of whirlwind adventure. Yes. That made sense. That was Margo. She found out about this place somehow, came here to gather her supplies, spent a night or two, and then hit the road. I could imagine her pinballing among tourist traps.
vi: The book is titled Following America: A Travel Guide, published in 1998, after this place was abandoned. I wedged the flashlight between my neck and shoulder, flipping through the pages with my hands. The book lists hundreds of attractions to visit, from the world's largest ball of twine in Darwin, Minnesota, to the world's largest ball of stamps in Omaha, Nebraska. Someone had dog-eared a few pages seemingly at random. The book wasn't very dusty. Maybe SeaWorld was just the first stop in the whirlwind of adventures. Indeed. That makes a lot of sense. That's so Margo. Somehow she had discovered this place, came here to pack her bags, stayed a night or two, and then hit the road. I can picture her bouncing from one tourist trap to another.
tr: The book had "Along the Road America: Your Travel Guide" written on it and was published in 1998, after this place was abandoned. I turned the pages of the book with the flashlight I had wedged between my neck and shoulder. The book listed hundreds of interesting places to visit; from the world's largest ball of twine in Darwin, Minnesota, to the world's largest ball of stamps in Omaha, Nebraska. Someone had seemingly randomly dog-eared many pages. The book wasn't very dusty. Maybe SeaWorld was just the first stop in a whirlwind adventure. Yes. This made sense. This was Margo. Somehow she had discovered this place, come here to gather supplies, spent a night or two, and then set off. I could imagine her going from one tourist trap to another.
es: The book was titled Roadside America and had been published in 1998, after that place had been abandoned. I flipped through it holding the flashlight between my neck and shoulder. The book offered a list of hundreds of tourist attractions, from the world's largest ball of twine, in Darwin, Minnesota, to the world's largest ball of stamps, in Omaha, Nebraska. Someone had dog-eared several pages, seemingly at random. The book wasn't very dusty. Maybe SeaWorld had just been the first stop in some kind of whirlwind of adventures. Yes. It wasn't nonsense. That was Margo. Somehow she discovered that place, went to gather supplies, spent a night or two, and moved on. I imagined her wandering between tourist traps.

en: As the last light fled from the holes in the ceiling, I found more books above other bookshelves. The Rough Guide to Nepal; The Great Sights of Canada; America by Car; Fodor’s Guide to the Bahamas; Let’s Go Bhutan. There seemed to be no connection at all among the books, except that they were all about traveling and had all been published after the minimall was abandoned. I tucked the Maglite under my chin, scooped up the books into a stack that extended from my waist to my chest, and carried them into the empty room I was now imagining as the bedroom.
vi: As the last beam of light gradually faded through the hole in the ceiling, I found a few more books on the other shelves. A brief journey to Nepal; Majestic Canada; Roaming by car across America; Fodor's guide to the Bahamas; Onward to Bhutan. There seemed to be no connection between the books, except that they were all travel guides and were published after this mini-mall was abandoned. I tucked the flashlight under my chin, stacked all the books into a pile from waist-high to chest-high, and carried them to the empty room that I now imagined as the bedroom.
tr: As the last light escaped through the holes in the ceiling, I found other books on top of the other bookshelves. “Nepal Travel Guide”; “Canada’s "Important Landscapes"; "America by Car"; "Fodor's Bahamas Guide"; "Let's Go to Bhutan". There seemed to be no connection between all these books, except that they were all about travel and all published after the mall had been abandoned. I wedged the Maglite under my chin, embraced the books in a stack that stretched from my waist to my chest, and carried them to the empty room I now imagined as a bedroom.
es: As the last rays of light came through the holes in the roof, I found more books on other shelves: General Guide to Nepal, Great Attractions of Canada, America by Car, Fodor's Guide to the Bahamas, and Let's Go to Bhutan. There didn't seem to be the slightest connection between the books, except that they were all travel books and the publication date was after the building was abandoned. I tucked the flashlight under my chin, loaded the pile of books, which reached from my waist to my chest, into my arms, and carried them to the empty room, which I then imagined was the bedroom.

en: So it turned out that I did spend prom night with Margo, just not quite as I’d dreamed. Instead of busting into prom together, I sat against her rolled-up carpet with her ratty blanket draped over my knees, alternately reading travel guides by flashlight and sitting still in the dark as the cicadas hummed above and around me.
vi: It turns out I spent the prom night with Margo, just not quite like in my dreams. Instead of tearing up the dance floor together, I sat leaning against her rolled-up carpet, covering my knees with her old blanket, reading travel guides by flashlight, and sitting quietly in the dark as the cicadas harmonized melodiously above and around me.
tr: Thus, it felt like I spent the prom night with Margo, just not exactly as I had imagined. Instead of crashing the prom together, I sat on her messy blanket, leaning on the worn-out carpet, with cicadas chirping above and around me, sitting still in the dark and taking turns reading travel guides with a flashlight.
es: So it turned out that I did spend prom night with Margo, just not in the way I had dreamed. Instead of bursting into the dance together, I sat, leaning against her rolled-up carpet, with her knitted blanket covering my knees, and started reading travel guides by flashlight, motionless in the dark while the cicadas sang around me.

en: Maybe she had sat here in the cacophonous darkness and felt some kind of desperation take her over, and maybe she found it impossible to unthink the thought of death. I could imagine that, of course.
vi: Perhaps Margo had sat here, in this screaming darkness, feeling some kind of despair rising endlessly. And perhaps she realized that it was impossible not to rewind her thoughts about death. I imagine so, of course.
tr: Maybe he too had sat here in the discordant darkness, feeling a kind of helplessness take hold of him, and perhaps it had seemed impossible not to think of death. I could imagine this, of course.
es: Perhaps he had sat there, in the noisy darkness, and felt despair overwhelming him, and perhaps it was impossible for him not to think about death. I could imagine it, of course.

en: But I could also imagine this: Margo picking these books up at various garage sales, buying every travel guide she could get her hands on for a quarter or less. And then coming here—even before she disappeared—to read the books away from prying eyes. Reading them, trying to decide on destinations. Yes. She would stay on the road and in hiding, a balloon floating through the sky, eating up hundreds of miles a day with the help of a perpetual tailwind. And in this imagining, she was alive. Had she brought me here to give me the clues to piece together an itinerary? Maybe. Of course I was nowhere near an itinerary. Judging from the books, she could be in Jamaica or Namibia, Topeka or Beijing. But I had only just begun to look.
vi: But I also imagine this: Margo collected these books from various clearance sales, buying any travel guide she could find for under twenty-five cents. Then Margo came here—even before she disappeared—reading books and staying away from prying eyes. Read them all, trying to map out a journey. Exactly. She would wander without leaving a trace, a balloon drifting in the sky, following the eternal wind, leaving behind hundreds of miles each day. And in this imagination of mine, Margo is full of life. Did Margo lead me here to give me clues to piece together into a journey? Maybe. Of course, so far I haven't even come close to that journey. Based on the books, Margo could be in Jamaica or Namibia, Topeka or Beijing. But I have only just started searching.
tr: But I could also imagine this: that Margo had randomly found these books from various discount sales and bought all the travel guides she could get her hands on for a quarter or less. Then, even before she disappeared to read these books away from prying eyes, she had come here. Reading them while trying to decide where to go. Yes. She would travel in hiding; then, with the help of a gust of wind, she would cover hundreds of kilometers in a day, floating in the sky like a balloon. And in this dream, Margo was alive. Had she brought me here to give me the clues I needed to piece together a route? Maybe. Of course, I wasn't even close to a route. From what I could gather from the books, she could be in Jamaica, Namibia, Topeka, or Beijing. But I had just started looking.
es: But I could also imagine the following: Margo buying those books at various flea markets, buying all the travel guides that fell into her hands at bargain prices. Then going there—even before she disappeared—to read them away from prying eyes. Reading them and trying to decide where to go. Yes. She would travel and hide, a balloon flying through the sky, covering hundreds of kilometers a day with the help of a perpetual tailwind. And I imagined her alive. Had she brought me there to give me the clues to decipher the itinerary? Maybe. Of course, I was far from having deciphered the itinerary. Judging by the books, she could be in Jamaica, Namibia, Topeka, or Beijing. But I had only just begun to look.

tr: But I had just started looking.

en: In my dream, her head was on my shoulder as I lay on my back, only the corner of carpet between us and the concrete floor. Her arm was around my rib cage. We were just lying there, sleeping.
vi: I dreamed, Margo's head resting on my shoulder while I lay straight, with only the corner of the carpet between us and the concrete floor. Her arm wrapped around me. We lay there, sound asleep.
tr: In my room, while I was lying on my back, Margo's head was on my shoulder, with only the corner of the carpet and the concrete floor between us. Her arm was wrapped around my chest. We were just lying there, sleeping.
es: In my dream, I was lying on my back, and she had her head resting on my shoulder. Only the carpet separated us from the cement floor. She had her arm around my chest. We were simply lying down, sleeping.

en: God help me. The only teenaged guy in America who dreams of sleeping with girls, and just sleeping with them. And then my phone rang. It took two more rings before my fumbling hands found the phone lying on the unrolled carpet. It was 3:18 A.M. Ben was calling.
vi: God bless me. I am the only teenager in America who dreams of sleeping with girls, and just sleeping with them. Then the phone rang. It rang two more times before my hand fumbled to find the phone in the fold of the carpet. It was 3:18 AM. Ben was calling.
tr: God help me. The only young man in America who dreams of lying with girls, just lying. Then my phone rang. It took until the phone rang two more times for my clumsy hands to find the phone on the carpet. It was 3:18 AM. Ben was calling.
es: My God, help me. The only teenager in the country who dreams of sleeping with girls, and just sleeping. But then the mobile rang. My hands took two more rings to fumble for the phone, which was on top of the unrolled carpet. It was 3:18 in the morning. The one calling me was Ben.

en: “Good morning, Ben,” I said.
vi: “Hello Ben,” I said.
tr: "Good morning, Ben," I said.
es: —Good morning, Ben —I said to him.

en: “YESSS!!!!!” he answered, screaming, and I could tell right away that now was not the time to try to explain to him all I had learned and imagined about Margo. I could damn near smell the booze on his breath. That one word, in the way it was shouted, contained more exclamation points than anything Ben had ever said to me in his entire life.
vi: “YEAHHH!!!!!” Ben screamed in response, and I knew right away that now was not the time to try to explain to him all that I had just learned and imagined about Margo. I almost smelled the alcohol on his breath. Just the one word “yeah,” uttered in that manner, contained more emotion than anything Ben had ever said to me in his entire life.
tr: “YESSS!” he screamed in response, and at that moment, I realized it was not a good time to try to explain to him everything I had learned and imagined about Margo. I could almost smell the alcohol on his breath. That single word, the way he shouted it, contained more exclamation marks than anything Ben had ever said to me in his entire life.
es: —YESSS!!!!!! —he shouted at me. I knew immediately that it was not the time to explain everything I had discovered and imagined about Margo. I could almost smell his alcohol breath. That single word, as he had shouted it, had more exclamation marks than anything he had ever said to me in his entire life.

en: “I take it prom is going well?”
vi: “I understand that the party was very fun, right?”
tr: “So, I take it the ball is going well?”
es: —I understand that the dance is going well.

en: “YESSSS! Quentin Jacobsen! The Q! America’s greatest Quentin! Yes!” His voice got distant then but I could still hear him. “Everybody, hey, shut up, hold on, shut up—QUENTIN! JACOBSEN! IS INSIDE MY PHONE!” There was a cheer then, and Ben’s voice returned. “Yes, Quentin! Yes! Bro, you have got to come over here.”
vi: “YEAH! Quentin Jacobsen! Mr. Q! The greatest Quentin in America! That's right!” His voice seemed to move away from the phone but I could still hear it clearly. “Everyone, hey, quiet, quiet, quiet–QUENTIN! JACOBSEN! IS TALKING TO ME!” A burst of cheers erupted, followed by Ben's voice again. "Yes, Quentin! Yes! Comrade, you must come here."
tr: "YES! Quentin Jacobsen! Q! The greatest Quentin in America! Yes!" At that moment, his voice faded, but I could still hear him. "Guys, hey, shut up, wait, shut up... QUENTIN! JACOBSEN! INSIDE MY PHONE!" Then there was a cheer and Ben's voice returned. "Yes, Quentin! Yes! Brother, you need to come here."
es: —YESSS! Quentin Jacobsen! The Q! The best Quentin in the country! Yes! —His voice faded, though I could still hear it—. Alright, everyone shut up, wait, shut up... I HAVE QUENTIN ON THE PHONE! —I heard a cheer and then Ben's voice returned—. Yes, Quentin! Yes! Dude, you have to come.

en: “Where is here?” I asked.
vi: "Where is this?" I asked.
tr: “Where is that place?” I asked.
es: —Where to? —I asked him.

en: “Becca’s! Do you know where it is?”
vi: "Becca's house! Do you know where it is?"
tr: “Becca! Do you know where you are?”
es: —To Becca's house! Do you know where it is?

en: As it happened, I knew precisely where it was. I’d been in her basement. “I know where it is, but it’s the middle of the night, Ben. And I’m in—”
vi: That was a close call, I know exactly where that place is. I went into Becca's basement. "I know, but it's midnight." And I am–”
tr: I knew exactly where it was. I had gone to Becca's basement. “I know where it is, but it's midnight, Ben. And right now I...”
es: It turned out he knew exactly where it was. He had been in his basement. —I know where it is, but it's the middle of the night, Ben. And I'm in…

en: “YESSS!!! You have to come right now. Right now!”
vi: "Yes!!! You have to come right away! Right now and immediately!"
tr: "YESSS! You must come immediately. Immediately!"
es: —YESSS! You have to come right now. Right now!

en: “Ben, there are more important things going on,” I answered.
vi: "Ben, there are more important things," I replied.
tr: “Ben, daha önemli şeyler oluyor,” diye karşılık verdim.
es: —Ben, I have more important things to do —I replied.

en: “DESIGNATED DRIVER!”
vi: "DRIVER APPOINTED!"
tr: “DESIGNATED DRIVER!”
es: —IT'S YOUR TURN TO DRIVE!

en: “What?”
vi: “Huh?”
tr: “What?”
es: —What?

en: “You’re my designated driver! Yes! You are so designated! I love that you answered! That’s so awesome! I have to be home by six! And I designate you to get me there! YESSSSSSS!”
vi: “I appoint you as my driver! Yes! You deserve to be appointed! Your phone answering skills are excellent! Absolutely amazing! I must be home before six o'clock! And I appoint you to take me home! YAAAAAAA!”
tr: “You are my designated sober driver! Yes! You are so chosen! I loved that you answered the phone! So awesome! I need to be home by six! And I choose you to take me there! YEEES!”
es: —You have to drive! Yes! You have to! I'm glad you answered! It's fantastic! I have to be home by six! And you have to take me! YEEEESSSS!

en: “Can’t you just spend the night there?” I asked.
vi: “Can't you stay the whole night?” I asked.
tr: "Can't you spend the night there?" I asked.
es: —Can't you stay the night? —I asked him.

en: “NOOOO! Booooo. Booo on Quentin. Hey, everybody! Boooo Quentin!” And then I was booed. “Everybody’s drunk. Ben drunk. Lacey drunk. Radar drunk. Nobody drive. Home by six. Promised Mom. Boo, Sleepy Quentin! Yay, Designated Driver! YESSSS!”
vi: “NOOOO! Boo hoo hoo. Boo hoo hoo Quentin. Hey, everyone! Boo hoo hoo Quentin!” And the whole group booed me. “Everyone is drunk. Ben is drunk. Lacey is drunk. Radar is drunk. No one can drive. Be home before six o'clock. Promised mom already. Boo hoo, sleepyhead Quentin! Well, the designated driver! Yeah!”
tr: “NOOO! Boo. Boo Quentin. Hey, people! Boo Quentin!” And then I was booed. “Everyone is drunk. I'm drunk. Lacey is drunk. Radar is drunk. No one can drive. Home by six. I promised my mom. Boo, Sleepy Quentin! Long live the Designated Sober Driver! YES!”
es: —NOOO! Booo. A boo for Quentin. Come on, everyone! Boooo, Quentin! —And they booed me—. They're all drunk. Ben, drunk. Lacey, drunk. Radar, drunk. No one can drive. Home by six. I promised my mom. Booo, Quentin, sleepyhead! You have to drive! YESSS!

en: I took a long breath. If Margo were going to show up, she would have showed up by three. “I’ll be there in half an hour.”
vi: I took a deep breath. If Margo came back to this place, she must have arrived before three in the morning. "I'll be there in half an hour."
tr: I took a deep breath. If Margo were going to show up, she would have appeared by the count of three. "I'll be there in half an hour!"
es: I took a deep breath. If Margo had wanted to show up, she would have shown up before three. —I will be there in half an hour.

en: “YES YES YES YES YES YES YES YES YES YES YES YESSSSSS!!!! YES! YES!”
vi: “THAT'S IT! YES! YES! YES! YES! YES! YES! YES! YES! YES! YES! YESS!!!! YES! YES!”
tr: “YES YES YES YES YES YES YES YES YES YES YES YEEEEEES YES! YES!”
es: —YES YES YES YES YES YES YES YES YES YES YES YESSSSS!!!!!! YES! YES!

en: Ben was still making assertions of affirmation when I hung up the phone. I lay there for a moment, telling myself to get up, and then I did. Still half asleep, I crawled through Troll Holes past the library and into the office, then pulled open the back door and got into the minivan.

en: Now, I knew Ben was going to be drunk. I’d heard him on the phone. No sober person says “yes” that many times per minute. Nonetheless, when I pushed past some people smoking cigarettes on Becca’s front lawn and opened the door to her house, I did not expect to see Jase Worthington and two other baseball players holding a tuxedo-clad Ben upside down above a keg of beer. The spout of the beer keg was in Ben’s mouth, and the entire room was transfixed on him. They were all chanting in unison, “Eighteen, nineteen, twenty,” and for a moment, I thought Ben was getting—like—hazed or something. But no, as he sucked on that beer spout like it was mother’s milk, little trickles of beer spilled from the sides of his mouth, because he was smiling. “Twenty-three, twenty-four, twenty-five,” the people shouted, and you could hear their enthusiasm. Apparently, something remarkable was taking place.
vi: This time I knew Ben was completely drunk. Just hearing his voice on the phone was enough to tell. No one sober would spew out a string of "uh-huhs" and "yeahs" so densely in a minute like that. However, when I squeezed past a few people smoking on the lawn in front of Becca's house and opened the door, I didn't expect to see Jase Worthington and two other guys from the baseball team holding Ben, dressed in a tuxedo, upside down over a beer keg. The keg's tap was in Ben's mouth, and the whole room was focused on him. Everyone was counting in unison, "Eighteen, nineteen, twenty." At first, I thought Ben was being bullied or pranked. But no, he was eagerly chugging the beer as if it were mother's milk, with beer streams spilling from the corners of his mouth because he was laughing. "Twenty-three, twenty-four, twenty-five," everyone continued to chant, and you could hear the wild excitement in their voices. Clearly, a major event was taking place.

"Twenty-three, twenty-four, twenty-five," they shouted, and you could hear their excitement. Apparently, something remarkable was happening.

Angela and I left our afterparty to come here because Ben told me I’d be greeted as a king. I mean, they were chanting my name. Apparently they all think Ben is hilarious or something, and so they like us, too.”

That’s great,” and Ben said, “I’ve wanted to kiss you every single day for the last three years,” and Cassie said, “I think you should,” and then Ben said, “YES! That’s awesome!” But he didn’t kiss Cassie. He just turned around to me and said, “Cassie wants to kiss me!” And I said, “Yeah,” and he said, “That’s so awesome.” And then he seemed to forget about Cassie and me both, as if the idea of kissing Cassie Hiney felt better than actually kissing her ever could.

tr: “What? Ben, calm down.”

en: “KNEES!”

en: He lowered the beer sword and tapped me on each shoulder. “By the power of the superglue beer sword, I hereby designate you my driver!”

en: “YES!” he shouted. And then when I tried to get up, he pushed me back down with his non-beer-sworded hand, and he tapped me again with the beer sword, and he said, “By the power of the superglue beer sword, I hereby announce that you will be naked under your robe at graduation.”

He touched the sword to both of my shoulders again and solemnly said, “With the power of the super-glued beer can sword, I declare that you will be naked under your robe at the graduation ceremony.”

es: —YES! —he shouted. And when I tried to get up, he pushed me down with his free hand and once again passed the sword made of beer cans over my shoulders. —By the power of the sword of beer cans, I hereby declare that at the graduation you shall not wear clothes under the gown.

en: “What?” I stood then.
vi: “Huh?” I stood up abruptly.
tr: “What?” I stood up at that moment.

en: “YES! Me and you and Radar! Naked under our robes! At graduation! It will be so awesome!”

tr: “YES! Me, you, and Radar! Naked under our robes! At graduation! It will be so awesome!”
es: —YES! Radar, you and me! Naked under the gown! At graduation! It will be incredible!

en: “Well,” I said, “it will be really hot.”

es: —YES! —he answered me—. Swear that you will do it! I've already gotten Radar to swear it. RADAR, YOU SWORE IT, DIDN'T YOU?

vi: Radar slightly tilted his head, squinting and mumbling. "I swore."
tr: Radar slightly turned his head and opened his eyes. “I did,” he murmured.
es: Radar slightly turned his head and opened his eyes a little. —I have sworn it —he murmured.

en: “Well then, I swear, too,” I said.
vi: “Alright, that works, I swear too,” I said.
tr: “Well then, I swear too,” I said.
es: —Well, then I swear it too —I told him.

en: “YES!” Then Ben turned to Lacey. “I love you.”

tr: "YES!" Then Ben turned to Lacey. "I love you." 8 An American beer brand, (abbr. n.)

en: “I love you, too, Ben.”
vi: “I love you too, Ben.”
tr: “I love you too, Ben.”
es: —I love you too, Ben.

en: “No, I love you. Not like a sister loves a brother or like a friend loves a friend. I love you like a really drunk guy loves the best girl ever.” She smiled.
vi: “No, I love you. Not like a brother loves a sister, or friends love friends. I love you like a drunk loves the most adorable girl in the world.” Lacey smiled.
tr: “No, I love you. Not like a girl loves her brother or a friend loves a friend. I love you like a drunk man loves the best girl he's ever met.” Lacey smiled.
es: —No, I love you. Not like a sister loves her brother nor like a friend loves a friend. I love you like a completely drunk guy loves the best girl in the world. He smiled.

en: I took a step forward, trying to save him from further embarrassment, and placed a hand on his shoulder. “If we’re gonna get you home by six, we should be leaving,” I said.
vi: I stepped forward, trying to rescue him from further embarrassing himself, placed my hand on his shoulder, and said, "If you want to get home before six, we have to go."
tr: I took a step forward, placing a hand on Ben's shoulder to try to save him from a greater embarrassment. "If we need to get you home by six, we should leave now," I said.
es: I took a step forward with the intention of preventing him from continuing to make a fool of himself and placed a hand on his shoulder. —If we have to be at your house by six, we should be heading out —I told him.

en: “Okay,” he said. “I just gotta thank Becca for this awesome party.”
vi: “It’s alright,” Ben said. “I’m just going to thank Becca for throwing such a great party.”
tr: “Okay,” he said. “I just need to thank Becca for this amazing party.”
es: —Okay —he replied to me—. I'm going to thank Becca for this incredible party.

en: So Lacey and I followed Ben downstairs, where he opened the door to Becca’s room and said, “Your party kicked so much ass! Even though you suck so much! It’s like instead of blood, your heart pumps liquid suck! But thanks for the beer!” Becca was alone, lying on top of her covers, staring at the ceiling. She didn’t even glance over at him. She just mumbled, “Oh, go to hell, shit-face. I hope your date gives you her crabs.”
vi: Lacey and I followed Ben downstairs, Ben opened Becca's room door and said, "Your party is really funny! But you're so gross! It's like your heart pumps not blood but that gross-fluid. But thanks for the beer!" Becca was alone, lying on the bed, staring at the ceiling. Without bothering to look at Ben, Becca muttered, "Go to hell, you dumb face, I hope the crabs crawl from her to you."
tr: So, with Lacey, we followed Ben downstairs, Ben opened the door to Becca's bedroom and said, "Your party was so good! Even though you were pretty awful!.. It's like your heart pumps the liquid form of awfulness instead of blood! But thanks for the beer!” he said. Becca was lying alone on her sheets, staring at the ceiling. She didn't even look at Ben. She just muttered, "Oh, go to hell, shit face. I hope your girlfriend gives you pubic lice,” she mumbled.
es: Lacey and I followed him downstairs, where he opened the door to Becca's room and said: —Your party was awesome! Even though you suck! Your heart doesn't pump blood, but shit. But thanks for the beer. Becca was alone, lying on top of the bedspread and staring at the ceiling. She didn't even look at Ben. She merely murmured: —Ugh, go to hell, idiot. I hope your partner gives you crabs.

en: Without a hint of irony in his voice, Ben answered, “Great talking to you!” and then closed the door. I don’t think he had the faintest idea he’d just been insulted.
vi: Without a hint of malicious sarcasm, Ben replied, "Very nice talking to you!" and closed the door. I think Ben had no idea that Becca's words were actually very offensive.
tr: Without the slightest hint of mockery in his voice, Ben replied, "It was great talking to you!" and closed the door. I don't think he has the slightest idea that he was just insulted.
es: —Delighted to talk to you —Ben replied without a hint of irony. And he closed the door. I think he hadn't even realized that they had just insulted him.

en: And then we were upstairs again and getting ready to walk out the door. “Ben,” I said, “you’re going to have to leave the beer sword here.”

es: We went back up and headed to the door. —Ben —I told him—, you're going to have to leave the sword here. —Okay —he replied to me.

en: “Right,” he said, and then I grabbed the sword’s tip and tugged, but Ben refused to relinquish it. I was about to start screaming at his drunk ass when I realized he couldn’t let go of the sword.
vi: "Oh right," Ben said. I grabbed one end of the sword and pulled, but Ben wouldn't let go. I was about to get mad at this drunken monkey when I realized he couldn't release the sword.
tr: “Right,” he said, I grabbed the tip of the sword and pulled hard, but Ben refused to let go. Just as I was about to start yelling at his drunken face, I realized I couldn't let go of the sword.
es: I grabbed the end of the sword and pulled, but Ben refused to let it go. I was about to start yelling at him that he was a worthless drunk when I realized that I couldn't let go of the sword. —Ben, have you stuck the sword to your hand?

en: Lacey laughed. “Ben, did you glue yourself to the beer sword?”

tr: Lacey laughed. "Did you stick yourself to a beer sword?""
es: —Lacey asked him, laughing. —Yes —Ben replied—, I have glued it with Super Glue.

en: “No,” Ben answered. “I superglued. That way no one can steal it from me!”
vi: “No,” Ben replied. “I’m super attached. That way it won’t get stolen!”
tr: “No,” Ben replied. “I glued it super well. That way, no one can steal it from me!”
es: —Yes —Ben replied—, I have glued it with Super Glue. That way, no one will steal it from me.

en: “Good thinking,” Lacey deadpanned.
vi: “Sharp thinking,” Lacey tried to appear serious.
tr: “You’ve thought it through,” said Lacey with an emotionless expression.
es: —Well thought out —said Lacey, impassively.

en: Lacey and I managed to break off all the beer cans except the one that was superglued directly to Ben’s hand. No matter how hard I pulled, Ben’s hand just limply followed along, like the beer was the string and his hand the puppet. Finally, Lacey just said, “We gotta go.” So we did. We strapped Ben into the backseat of the minivan. Lacey sat next to him, because “I should make sure he doesn’t puke or beat himself to death with his beer hand or whatever.”
vi: Lacey and I managed to remove the beer cans, except for the last one which was stuck directly to Ben's hand. No matter how hard I pulled, Ben's hand would go limp and follow, as if the beer can was the string and Ben's hand was the puppet. Finally, Lacey said, "We have to go." So we got in the car, shoving Ben into the back seat of the minivan. Lacey sat next to him, because "I should keep an eye on him so he doesn't throw up or beat himself to death with this beer can hand."
tr: We managed to tear off all my beer cans with Lacey, except for the one that was directly glued to Ben's hand with super glue. No matter how hard I pulled, Ben's hand remained loosely attached. He followed the box, as if it were a string and his hand a puppet. Finally, Lacey said, "We should go." So we went. We strapped Ben into the back seat of the minivan with a seatbelt. Lacey sat next to him because she had to make sure he wouldn't throw up or beat himself to death with his own hand or something."
es: Lacey and I managed to remove all the cans except the one that was stuck to Ben's hand. No matter how hard he pulled, his hand followed, as if the can were the string and his hand the puppet. —We have to go —said Lacey finally. And we left. We sat Ben in the back seat and fastened his seatbelt. Lacey sat next to him because "this way I can make sure he doesn't throw up, hit himself with the beer can, and kill himself, or something like that."

en: But he was far enough gone for Lacey to feel comfortable talking about him. As I drove down the interstate, she said, “There’s something to be said for trying hard, you know? I mean, I know he tries too hard, but why is that such a bad thing? And he’s sweet, isn’t he?”
vi: But Ben was sleeping soundly, so Lacey could comfortably talk about it. As I was driving on the interstate, Lacey said, "You know, if you've made an effort, it needs to be recognized. I mean, Ben has tried his best, but why did things turn out so badly? He's sweet, isn't he?"
tr: Ama Ben, Lacey'nin onun hakkında konuşurken rahat hissi 'demeyeceği kadar ileri gitmişti. Eyaletler arası yolda ilerlerken Lacey, "Bu kadar çabalaması biraz abartı. Yani fazla gayret ettiğini biliyorum ama bu, neden bu kadar kötü bir şey olsun ki? Aslında tatlı birisi, değil mi?" dedi bana.
es: But he was so out of it that Lacey had no problem talking to me about him. —I have something to say about insistence, you know? —he told me as we drove down the highway—. Well, I know he insists too much, but why would that be bad? And besides, he's very sweet, isn't he?

en: “I guess so,” I said. Ben’s head was lolling around, seemingly unconnected to a spine. He didn’t strike me as particularly sweet, but whatever.
vi: “I think so too,” I replied. Ben's head wobbled all over the place, looking as if it had detached from his spine. To me, Ben wasn't particularly sweet, but it didn't matter.
tr: "I suppose so," I said. Ben's head was bobbing around, apparently not attached to a spine. It hadn't left an impression of sweetness on me, but whatever.
es: —I suppose —I replied to him. Ben's head hung as if it were not attached to his spine. It didn't seem particularly sweet to me, but oh well.

en: I dropped Lacey off first on the other side of Jefferson Park. When she leaned over and pecked him on the mouth, he perked up enough to mumble, “Yes.” She walked up to the driver’s-side door on the way to her condo. “Thanks,” she said. I just nodded.

tr: First, I dropped Lacey off on the other side of Jefferson Park. When Lacey leaned in and planted a kiss on Ben's lips, Ben was animated enough to murmur, "Yes." As Lacey walked towards the car, she approached the driver's side door. "Thank you," she said. I just nodded.
es: I first took Lacey to the other end of Jefferson Park. When Lacey leaned in and gave him a peck, he perked up enough to murmur, "Yes." Lacey approached the driver's door on her way home. —Thank you —he said to me. I nodded.

en: I drove across the subdivision. It wasn’t night and it wasn’t morning. Ben snored quietly in the back. I pulled up in front of his house, got out, opened the sliding door of the minivan, and unfastened his seat belt.
vi: I drove through this neighborhood. The sky was no longer dark but not yet light. Ben snored peacefully on the back seat. I stopped in front of his house, got out to open the car door, and unbuckled Ben's seatbelt.
tr: I drove the car to the other side of the neighborhood. It was neither night nor day. Ben was snoring quietly in the back. I pulled over in front of his house, got out, opened the sliding door of the minivan, and unbuckled the seatbelt.
es: I crossed the housing development. It was no longer night, but it still hadn't dawned. Ben was snoring softly in the back seat. I parked in front of his house, got out of the car, opened the sliding door of the minivan, and unbuckled his seatbelt.

en: “Time to go home, Benners.”
vi: "We're home, Ben."
tr: “It's time to go home, Benners.”
es: —Time to go home, Benners.

en: He sniffed and shook his head, then awoke. He reached up to rub his eyes and seemed surprised to find an empty can of Milwaukee’s Best Light attached to his right hand. He tried to make a fist and dented the can some, but did not dislodge it. He looked at it for a minute, and then nodded. “The Beast is stuck to me,” he noted.
vi: It sniffled and shook its head, then woke up. It intended to rub its eyes and seemed surprised to see an empty Milwaukee’s Best Light can stuck to its right hand. It tried to crush the can by squeezing it but to no avail. Ben looked at the beer can for about a minute, then nodded and exclaimed, "The monster keeps clinging to me!"
tr: He sniffled, nodded his head, then woke up. He raised his hands to rub his eyes and seemed surprised when he found an empty Milwaukee’s Best Light can stuck to his right hand. He tried to make a fist and crushed the can a bit but didn’t remove it. He looked at the can for a short while, then nodded his head. “The monster9 has stuck to me,” he reported. Milwaukee’s Best beer is also referred to as "The Beast" or "Canavar". (tr. n.)
es: He sniffed, moved his head, and woke up. He raised his hands to rub his eyes and seemed surprised to see a can of Milwaukee’s Best Light stuck to his hand. He tried to close his fist and dent the can a bit, but he couldn't tear it off. He looked at it for a minute and shook his head. "The Beast is stuck to me," he observed.

en: He climbed out of the minivan and staggered up the sidewalk to his house, and when he was standing on the front porch, he turned around, smiling. I waved at him. The beer waved back.
vi: He got out of the car, staggered onto the sidewalk to enter the house. When he was standing under the front porch, Ben turned around and smiled. I waved at it. The beer can waved back.
tr: Mirlivandan stumbled out of the car and onto the sidewalk in front of his house, and when he stopped on the front porch, he turned around with a smile. I waved at him. He waved back.
es: He jumped out of the car and staggered along the sidewalk to his house. When he reached the porch, he turned around smiling. I waved at him. The beer waved back at me.

tr: He waved back.

en: I slept for a few hours and then spent the morning poring over the travel guides I’d discovered the day before. I waited until noon to call Ben and Radar. I called Ben first. “Good morning, Sunshine,” I said.

tr: I slept for a few hours and then spent the morning reviewing the travel guides I had discovered the previous day. I waited until noon to call Radar and Ben. I called Ben first. "Good morning, sunshine," I said.
es: I slept for a few hours and then spent the morning carefully reading the travel guides I had found the day before. I waited until twelve to call Ben and Radar. I called Ben first. —Good morning, Your Honor —I said to him.

en: “Oh, God,” Ben said, his voice dripping abject misery. “Oh, sweet baby Jesus, come and comfort your little bro Ben. Oh, Lord. Shower me with your mercy.”
vi: “Oh, God,” Ben replied, his voice dripping with what sounded like utter despair. “Oh, sweet little God, please come here and soothe this brother Ben. Oh, please pour down upon me Your salvation.”
tr: “Oh, my God,” said Ben, the agony of disgrace flowing from his voice. “Oh, sweet Jesus, come and comfort your little brother Ben. Oh, my God. Wash the cursed one with your mercy.”
es: —Oh, my God —said Ben in a tone that exuded the most abject misery—. Oh, little Jesus of my life, come to console your brother Ben. Oh, Lord, fill me with your grace.

en: “There’ve been a lot of Margo developments,” I said excitedly, “so you need to come over. I’m gonna call Radar, too.”
vi: “There has been a lot of progress regarding Margo,” I said excitedly, “Get your butt over here. I will call Radar too.”

es: —I have a ton of news about Margo —I told him excitedly—, so you have to come. I'm going to call Radar too.

en: Ben seemed not to have heard me. “Hey, when my mom came into my room at nine o’clock this morning, why is it that as I reached up to yawn, she and I both discovered a beer can was stuck to my hand?”
vi: It seems like Ben didn't pay attention to what I just said. "Hey, my mom came into my room at nine o'clock this morning, and as I was sitting up yawning, my mom and I both discovered a beer can stuck to my hand. What's up with that?"
tr: Ben seemed like he hadn't heard me. "Hey, this morning when my mom came into my room at nine o'clock, while I was yawning and bringing my hand to my mouth, we both discovered that a beer can was stuck to my hand?"
es: Ben didn't seem to have heard me. —Hey, how is it possible that when my mother entered my room this morning at nine, and I stretched my arms, we discovered a beer can stuck to my hand?

en: “You superglued a bunch of beers together to make a beer sword, and then you superglued your hand to it.”
vi: "He super-glued a bunch of cans together into a beer can sword, then he super-glued his hand to it."
tr: “To make a beer sword, you glued a bunch of beers together with super glue and then glued your hand to it.”
es: —You glued a bunch of beer cans together to make a sword, and then you glued it to your hand.

en: “Oh, yeah. The beer sword. That rings a bell. ”
vi: "Uh uh. Sword of the beer can. Sounds familiar."
tr: “Ah, yes. The beer sword. This rings a bell.”
es: —Oh, yes. The beer sword. It rings a bell.

en: “Ben, come over.”
vi: "Ben, come to my house."

es: —Ben, come over here.

vi: "I feel very confused, sir."

es: —Colleague, you can't come. I have to sleep ten thousand hours. I have to drink ten thousand liters of water and take ten thousand ibuprofens. I'll see you tomorrow at the institute.

en: I took a deep breath and tried not to sound pissed. “I drove across Central Florida in the middle of the night to be sober at the world’s drunkest party and drive your soggy ass home, and this is—” I would have kept talking, but I noticed that Ben had hung up. He hung up on me. Asshole.
vi: I took a deep breath to keep from getting angry. “I drove across Central Florida at midnight to play the role of the only sober person at the world's drunkest party, to take your leaking ass home, and here–” I hadn't even finished speaking when I realized Ben had already hung up. He dared to hang up on me. That bastard.
tr: I took a deep breath and tried not to sound angry. “I drove all the way across Florida in the middle of the night, staying sober at the world's drunkest party just to get your clumsy ass home, and this.. I was going to continue talking, but I realized Ben had hung up. He had hung up on me. Jerk.
es: I took a deep breath and tried not to look disappointed. —I crossed central Florida in the middle of the night to arrive sober at the drunkest party in the world and leave your fat ass at home, and it's… I would have kept talking, but I realized that Ben had hung up. He had hung up on me. Asshole.

en: As time passed, I only got more pissed. It’s one thing not to give a shit about Margo. But really, Ben didn’t give a shit about me, either. Maybe our friendship had always been about convenience— he didn’t have anyone cooler than me to play video games with. And now he didn’t have to be nice to me, or care about the things I cared about, because he had Jase Worthington. He had the school keg stand record. He had a hot prom date. He’d jumped at his first opportunity to join the fraternity of vapid asshats.
vi: The more time passed, the more irritable I became. Not caring about Margo was one thing. But now, Ben didn't pay any attention to me either. Perhaps our friendship had always been just a convenience for him—he couldn't find anyone cooler than me to play video games with. Now he didn't need to be nice to me anymore, or care about the things I cared about, because he had Jase Worthington. Ben had become the beer pong champion at school. He had invited a hot girl to the prom. He had seized his first chance to join the ranks of the truly obnoxious guys.
tr: As time passed, I just got angrier. Not only did he not care about Margo at all... He didn't care about me either. Maybe our friendship had always been about the right circumstances... He had no one cooler than me to play computer games with. And now he didn't have to treat me well or care about the things I cared about because he had Jase Worthington. He had broken the school's keg stand record. He had a sexy prom date. He had jumped at the first opportunity to join the soulless jerks fraternity.
es: As time went by, I was getting more and more pissed off. One thing was that Margo didn't give a damn about him, but the truth was that Ben didn't give a damn about me either. Maybe our friendship had always been out of convenience, because he didn't have anyone better to play video games with. But from then on, he didn't have to be nice to me or care about the things that mattered to me, because he had Jase Worthington. He held the school record for keg stand. He had gone to the dance with a hot chick. He had taken the first opportunity to switch to the group of bland assholes.

en: Five minutes after he hung up on me, I called his cell again. He didn’t answer, so I left a message. “You want to be cool like Chuck, Bloody Ben? That’s what you always wanted? Well, congratulations. You got it. And you deserve him, because you’re also a shitbag. Don’t call back.”
vi: Five minutes after Ben hung up, I called back on his mobile phone. Ben didn't answer, so I left a message, "You want to be a big shot like Chuck, don't you, Ben the Jerk? You still crave that, huh? Oh, congratulations! You did it. You and he are a perfect match, because you're also a stinking pile. Don't call back."
tr: Five minutes after he hung up on me, I called his cell phone again. He didn't answer, so I left a message. “Do you want to be cool like Chuck, Bloody Ben? Is this what you've always wanted? Well, congratulations. Now it's in your hands. And you deserve it because you're crap too. Don't call back.”
es: Five minutes after he hung up on me, I called him back on his cell phone. Since he didn't answer, I left him a message: "Do you want to be cool like Chuck, Bloody Ben? Is that what you've always wanted? Well, congratulations. You've achieved it. And you deserve it because you're a piece of shit. No need to call me back."

en: Then I called Radar. “Hey,” I said.
vi: Then I called Radar. "Hello," I said.
tr: Then I called Radar. "Hey," I said.
es: Then I called Radar. —Hello —I said to him.

en: “Hey,” he answered. “I just threw up in the shower. Can I call you back?”
vi: "Hi," it replied. "I just threw up while I was showering. Can I call you back later?"
tr: "Hey," he said. "I just threw up in the shower. Can I call you later?"

en: “I’m too hungover to mediate,” Radar answered quietly. He lay down on the bed, his eyes half closed, and rubbed his buzzed hair. “It’s like I got hit by lightning.” He sniffed. “Okay, bring me up-to-date.” I sat down in the desk chair and told Radar about my evening in Margo’s vacation house, trying hard not to leave out any possibly helpful details. I knew Radar was better at puzzles than I, and I was hoping he’d piece together this one.

en: “Write this down,” he said. “Omaha, Nebraska. Sac City, Iowa. Alexandria, Indiana. Darwin, Minnesota. Hollywood, California. Alliance, Nebraska. Okay. Those are the locations of all the things she—well, or whoever read this book—found interesting.” He got up, motioned me out of the chair, and then swiveled to the computer. Radar had an amazing talent for carrying on conversations while typing. “There’s a map mash-up that allows you to enter multiple destinations and it will spit out a variety of itineraries. Not that she’d know about this program. But still, I want to see.”

Radar had the amazing talent of being able to talk and type at the same time. “There’s a computer program with an integrated map that allows you to input several locations, and it will outline different routes. I don't think Margo knew about the program, but I want to take a look.

en: Radar looked at me sideways. “Of course he is. You know your problem, Quentin? You keep expecting people not to be themselves. I mean, I could hate you for being massively unpunctual and for never being interested in anything other than Margo Roth Spiegelman, and for, like, never asking me about how it’s going with my girlfriend—but I don’t give a shit, man, because you’re you. My parents have a shit ton of black Santas, but that’s okay. They’re them. I’m too obsessed with a reference Web site to answer my phone sometimes when my friends call, or my girlfriend. That’s okay, too. That’s me. You like me anyway. And I like you. You’re funny, and you’re smart, and you may show up late, but you always show up eventually.”
vi: Radar looked askance at me. "Of course Ben is a jerk. But do you know what your problem is, Quentin? You keep expecting people not to be themselves. Think about it, I could be really annoyed with you for being incredibly late, having no interest in any topic except Margo Roth Spiegelman, or, like, never bothering to ask how things are going with my girlfriend. But I don't mind, buddy, because you are you. My parents hoard a ton of black Santas for no reason, but it's okay. Parents are parents. I'm so obsessed with a website that collects all sorts of information that I don't answer the phone when my friends or girlfriend call. But that's okay too. That's me. You still like me. I like you too. You're quirky, kind of weird, you're often late, but in the end, you're always there and that's what matters."

My parents have a ton of black Santa Clauses, but that's not a problem either. They are who they are. Sometimes I am so obsessed with a reference site that I don't answer the phone when my friends or girlfriend call. That's not a problem either. That's me. Every In any case, you love me. And I love you too. You are fun and smart, and you may come late but eventually, you will come."

I mean, I could hate you for always being late, for only caring about Margo Roth Spiegelman, and for never asking me how things are going with my girlfriend… but I don't give a damn, man, because that's just how you are. My parents have a ton of black Santa Clauses, but it's okay. That's just how they are. Sometimes I'm so obsessed with a website that I don't answer when my friends or my girlfriend call me, and that's okay too. That's just how I am. You appreciate me anyway. And I appreciate you. You're funny and smart, and it's true that you show up late, but in the end, you always show up.
