es: Although there was only one week left until the final exams, I spent Monday afternoon reading "Song of Myself." I wanted to go to the last two pseudovisions, but Ben needed his car. I was no longer looking for clues in the poem as much as I was mostly trying to find Margo herself. This time I had read about half of "Song of Myself" when I came across another part that I found myself reading and rereading.

en: “I think I will do nothing for a long time but listen,” Whitman writes. And then for two pages, he’s just hearing: hearing a steam whistle, hearing people’s voices, hearing an opera. He sits on the grass and lets the sound pour through him. And this is what I was trying to do, too, I guess: to listen to all the little sounds of her, because before any of it could make sense, it had to be heard. For so long, I hadn’t really heard Margo—I’d seen her screaming and thought her laughing—that now I figured it was my job. To try, even at this great remove, to hear the opera of her.
vi: “I think for a long time ahead, I will just listen,” Whitman wrote. And for the next two pages, he just listened: to the babbling brook, to people's voices, to the opera music. He sat on the grass and let the sounds wash over him. Perhaps that is also what I am trying to do: listen to all her most subtle sounds, because before understanding, one must first hear. It has been too long since I truly heard Margo—I saw her screaming and thought she was laughing—but now I realize that listening is what needs to be done. Trying, even from this vast distance, to hear Margo's opera.
tr: “I guess I will do nothing for a long time but listen,” writes Whitman. Then for two pages, he just hears: he hears the whistle of a steam, he hears the voices of people, he hears an opera. He sits on the grass and lets the sounds pass through him. And I guess that’s what I’m trying to do too: listen to all of Margo’s little sounds. Because before they mean anything, they must be heard. I hadn’t really heard Margo for a long time—I had seen her scream and thought she laughed—and now I understood that it was my job, even from this immense distance, to try to hear her opera.
es: “Now I will do nothing but listen,” writes Whitman. And on the next two pages, he only listens: the steam whistle, the sound of the human voice, the opera chorus… He sits on the grass and lets the sound penetrate his body. And that is what I was also trying to do, I suppose: to listen to all the little sounds of Margo, because before any of them could make sense, they had to be listened to. For a long time, I had not really listened to Margo—I had seen her shouting and thought she was laughing—and then I discovered that this was what I had to do. To try, even when separated by a great distance, to listen to her opera.

en: If I couldn’t hear Margo, I could at least listen to what she once heard, so I downloaded the album of Woody Guthrie covers. I sat at the computer, my eyes closed, elbows against the desk, and listened to a voice singing in a minor key. I tried to hear, inside a song I’d never heard before, the voice I had trouble remembering after twelve days.
vi: If I couldn't hear Margo, at least I could hear what she used to hear. So I downloaded an album of Woody Guthrie cover songs. I sat by the computer, closed my eyes, elbows resting on the table, listening to the voice in the minor key. I tried to hear, in a song I had never heard before, a voice I was beginning to find hard to remember after twelve days.
tr: If I couldn't hear Margo, at least I could listen to what she once heard, so I downloaded albums where Woody Guthrie's songs were rearranged. I sat at the computer, eyes closed, elbows resting on the table, listening to the singing voice. In a song I had never heard before, I tried to hear that voice which I struggled to remember twelve days later.
es: Since I couldn't hear Margo, at least I could hear what she had once heard, so I downloaded the Woody Guthrie cover album. I sat in front of the computer, with my eyes closed and my elbows on the table, and listened to a voice singing in a minor key. I tried to listen, in a song I hadn't heard before, to the voice that after twelve days was hard for me to remember.

en: I was still listening—but now to another of her favorites, Bob Dylan—when my mom got home. “Dad’s gonna be late,” she said through the closed door. “I thought I might make turkey burgers?”
vi: I was still listening to music–now it was another one of Margo's favorite singers, Bob Dylan–when I saw Mom come home. "Dad will be home late today," she said through my still-closed door. "Shall I make turkey sandwiches?"
tr: I was still listening when my mother came home... but now to another of her favorites, Bob Dylan. "Your father will be late," my mother said from behind the closed door. "I thought I could make turkey meatballs, but?.."
es: I was still listening, at that moment another of his favorites, Bob Dylan, when my mother arrived home. —Dad will arrive late —she told me from the other side of the closed door—. I was thinking of making turkey burgers.

en: “Sounds good,” I answered, and then closed my eyes again and listened to the music. I didn’t sit up again until Dad called me for dinner an album and a half later.
vi: “Yes, it's delicious,” I replied, then closed my eyes to listen to music again. After listening to another one and a half albums, I got up when my father called me for dinner.
tr: “Very nice,” I replied, then I closed my eyes again and listened to the music. I didn't straighten up from where I was sitting until my father called me for dinner when I was halfway through the second album.
es: —Sounds good —I replied. I closed my eyes again and listened to the music. I didn't get up from the chair until my father called me for dinner, an album and a half later.

en: At dinner, Mom and Dad were talking about politics in the Middle East. Even though they completely agreed with each other, they still managed to yell about it, saying that so-and-so was a liar, and so-and-so was a liar and a thief, and that the lot of them should resign. I focused on the turkey burger, which was excellent, dripping with ketchup and smothered with grilled onions.
vi: During dinner, my parents talked about the political situation in the Middle East. Even though they completely agreed with each other, they still loudly criticized, saying this-and-that was deceitful, this-and-that was fraudulent and thieving, and that the whole bunch should just resign already. I focused on my turkey sandwich, which was absolutely delicious, drenched in ketchup and fragrant grilled onions.
tr: At dinner, my mom and dad were talking about Middle Eastern politics. Despite being in complete agreement with each other, they still managed to shout that so-and-so is a liar, so-and-so is a liar and a thief, and that most of them should resign. I focused on the turkey meatball, which was delicious with ketchup and covered in onions.
es: During dinner, my parents talked about Middle Eastern politics. Although they were in complete agreement, they were yelling at the top of their lungs, saying that so-and-so was a liar, that so-and-so was a liar and a thief, and that almost all of them should resign. I focused on the turkey burger, which was delicious, drenched in ketchup and topped with fried onions.

en: “Okay, enough,” my mom said after a while. “Quentin, how was your day?”
vi: “Alright, let's stop here,” Mom concluded after a discussion. "How was today, Quentin?"
tr: “Alright, that's enough,” said my mother after a while. “Quentin, how was your day?”
es: —Well, that's enough —said my mother after a while—. Quentin, how was your day?

en: “Fine,” I said. “Getting ready for finals, I guess.”
vi: "I'm fine," I replied. "Ready for the exam, I think."
tr: “Good,” I said. “I guess I'm preparing for the exams.”
es: —Very well —I replied—. Preparing for the final exams, I suppose.

en: “I can’t believe this is your last week of classes,” Dad said. “It really does just seem like yesterday . . .”
vi: “I can't believe you're going to school for the last week,” Dad said. “It really feels like just yesterday...”
tr: “I can't believe this is the last week of his school,” said my dad. “It really feels like it was just yesterday...”
es: —I can't believe it's your last week of classes —said my father—. It seems like it was just yesterday…

en: “It does,” Mom said. A voice in my head was like: WARNING NOSTALGIA ALERT WARNING WARNING WARNING. Great people, my parents, but prone to bouts of crippling sentimentality.
vi: “That's right,” my mother said wistfully. A voice in my head was screaming: WARNING NOSTALGIA ALERT WARNING WARNING WARNING. My parents are the best in the world, but they are easily moved and sentimentally cheesy to an extreme.
tr: “Yes,” said my mother. A voice in my head started shouting: WARNING NOSTALGIA ALARM, WARNING WARNING WARNING. My parents are wonderful people but they tend to show paralyzing displays of excessive sentimentality.
es: —Yes —said my mother. In my head, a voice said: ATTENTION NOSTALGIA ALERT ATTENTION ATTENTION ATTENTION. My parents are good people, but prone to bouts of immense sentimentalism.

en: “We’re just very proud of you,” she said. “But, God, we’ll miss you next fall.”
vi: “Your father and I are very proud of you,” said Mom. “But oh my God, we will miss you so much next fall.”
tr: "We are proud of you," said my mother. "My God, we will miss you next fall."
es: —We are very proud of you —said my mother—, but, God, we will miss you next fall.

en: “Yeah, well, don’t speak too soon. I could still fail English.”
vi: “Oh, yes, but it's also too early to say. I might fail the National Language subject.”
tr: “Yes, well, don't speak too soon. I can still fail literature.”
es: —Yes, well, don't speak too soon. I can still fail literature.

en: My mom laughed, and then said, “Oh, guess who I saw at the YMCA yesterday? Betty Parson. She said Chuck was going to the University of Georgia next fall. I was pleased for him; he’s always struggled.”
vi: Mom laughed, then said, "Oh, do you know who I met yesterday at the Christian Youth Association? It was Ms. Betty Parson. She said that this fall Chuck will be going to the University of Georgia. I'm happy for Chuck, the boy has put in a lot of effort."
tr: My mom laughed and then said, "Ah, guess who I saw at the Young Men's Christian Association yesterday? Betty Parson. She said that Chuck will be going to Georgia University next fall. I'm happy for him; he always struggled."
es: My mother laughed and then said: —Ah, guess who I saw yesterday at the Young Men's Christian Association. Betty Parson. She told me that Chuck is going to the University of Georgia in the fall. I was happy for him. He has always struggled a lot.

en: “He’s an asshole,” I said.
vi: “It just stinks, Mom,” I said.
tr: "What an idiot," I said.
es: —He's an asshole —I said.

en: “Well,” my dad said, “he was a bully. And his behavior was deplorable.” This was typical of my parents: in their minds, no one was just an asshole. There was always something wrong with people other than just sucking: they had socialization disorders, or borderline personality syndrome, or whatever.
vi: "Sigh," Dad said, "Chuck often bullies his friends. Such behavior needs to be corrected." That's exactly how my parents think: in their eyes, no one is just plain bad. There is always something wrong with everyone, not because they are inherently evil: they have social communication disorders, borderline personality syndrome, something like that.
tr: “Well,” said my father, “he was a bully. And his behavior was deplorable.” This was typical of my parents: According to them, no one was just lousy, there was always something else wrong with people besides just being awful: They had social adaptation disorders... or personality disorders or whatever.
es: —Well —said my father—, he was a bully. And his behavior was deplorable. Typical of my parents. For them, no one was simply an asshole. People always had something going on that went beyond being a jerk: they had socialization disorders, or borderline personality disorder, or whatever.

en: My mom picked up the thread. “But Chuck has learning difficulties. He has all kinds of problems—just like anyone. I know it’s impossible for you to see peers this way, but when you’re older, you start to see them—the bad kids and the good kids and all kids—as people. They’re just people, who deserve to be cared for. Varying degrees of sick, varying degrees of neurotic, varying degrees of self-actualized. But you know, I always liked Betty, and I always had hopes for Chuck. So it’s good that he’s going to college, don’t you think?”
vi: Mom continued the story, "But Chuck had difficulties while studying. The boy faced all sorts of problems—like anyone else. I know you don't see your friends that way now, but when you grow older, you'll start to see it—the good ones, the bad ones, all your friends—they're all human. They all deserve to be cared for. With varying levels of physical, psychological, and self-actualization abilities. But you know, I always liked Ms. Betty Parson, always had hope for Chuck. So it's a good thing that the boy is going to college, don't you think?"
tr: My mom took control. “But Chuck has learning difficulties. He has all sorts of problems... just like everyone else. I know it's hard for you to see your peers this way, but when you get older, you'll start to see the bad kids, the good kids, and all the kids as people. They are just people who deserve to be cared about. Different degrees of sick, different degrees of neurotic, different degrees of accomplished. But you know, I've always liked Betty and I've always had hope for Chuck. So it's good that he's going to college, don't you think?”
es: My mother took the thread. —But Chuck has learning difficulties. He has all kinds of problems... like anyone else. I know it's impossible for you to see your classmates that way, but when you get older, you start to see them (the bad kids, the good ones, and everyone) as people. They are just people who deserve affection. Different levels of illness, different levels of neurosis, and different levels of self-actualization. But, look, I've always liked Betty and I've always had hopes for Chuck. So it's okay for him to go to college, don't you think, Quentin?

en: “Honestly, Mom, I don’t really care about him one way or another.” But I did think, if everyone is such a person, how come Mom and Dad still hated all the politicians in Israel and Palestine? They didn’t talk about them like they were people.
vi: “Mom, actually I don't really care about it, whether it's cut horizontally or vertically, it's the same to me.” But I do wonder, if everyone is human, why are my parents still upset about the politicians in Israel and Palestine? My parents don't talk about them as if they are human too.
tr: "Honestly, mom, one way or another, I don't really care about him." But I thought, if everyone is just human, how is it that my mom and dad still hated all the politicians in Israel and Palestine? They didn't talk about them as if they were human.
es: —Honestly, mom, I don't care in the slightest. But I thought that if everyone is a person, why did my parents hate the politicians of Israel and Palestine so much? They didn't talk about them as if they were people.

en: My dad finished chewing something and then put his fork down and looked at me. “The longer I do my job,” he said, “the more I realize that humans lack good mirrors. It’s so hard for anyone to show us how we look, and so hard for us to show anyone how we feel.”
vi: Dad stopped chewing something, put down the fork, and looked at me. "The more I work," Dad said, "the more I realize that people lack proper mirrors. It's really hard for someone to show us how we truly look, and it's really hard for us to tell others how we feel."
tr: My father finished chewing something and then put down his fork and looked at me. "The longer I do my job," he said, "the more I realize that people lack good mirrors. It's so hard for someone to show us how we look and for us to show someone how we feel."
es: My father finished chewing something, put the fork on the table, and looked at me. —The longer I work at my job —he told me—, the more I realize that human beings lack good mirrors. It is very difficult for anyone to show us how we are seen, and for us to show anyone how we feel.

en: “That is really lovely,” my mom said. I liked that they liked each other. “But isn’t it also that on some fundamental level we find it difficult to understand that other people are human beings in the same way that we are? We idealize them as gods or dismiss them as animals.”
vi: “It sounds so good,” Mom said. I like how my parents like each other like that. “But isn't it true that deep down, we find it hard to understand that others are human just as we are human? We idealize them as gods or categorize them as animals.”
tr: “This is really nice,” said my mother. I liked that they liked each other. “But fundamentally, isn't it difficult for us to understand that other people are human just like us? We idealize them as gods or reject them as animals.”
es: —Very beautiful —said my mother. I liked that they liked each other—. But, deep down, isn't that also what makes it so difficult for us to understand that others are human beings exactly like us? We idealize them as gods or discard them as animals.

en: “True. Consciousness makes for poor windows, too. I don’t think I’d ever thought about it quite that way.”
vi: "That's right. Perception also creates distorted windows. Perhaps you haven't thought much in that direction."
tr: “Correct. Consciousness also leads to narrow windows. I don't think I've ever thought about it this way.”
es: —True. Consciousness also closes windows. I think I had never thought about it in this sense.

en: I was sitting back. I was listening. And I was hearing something about her and about windows and mirrors. Chuck Parson was a person. Like me. Margo Roth Spiegelman was a person, too. And I had never quite thought of her that way, not really; it was a failure of all my previous imaginings. All along—not only since she left, but for a decade before—I had been imagining her without listening, without knowing that she made as poor a window as I did. And so I could not imagine her as a person who could feel fear, who could feel isolated in a roomful of people, who could be shy about her record collection because it was too personal to share. Someone who might read travel books to escape having to live in the town that so many people escape to. Someone who—because no one thought she was a person—had no one to really talk to.
vi: I sit in the back. I am listening. And I hear something about her, the windows and mirrors. Chuck Parson is a person. Just like me. Margo Roth Spiegelman is also a person. And I had never thought of her that way, not really; that was the failure of all my previous imaginings. For a long time—not just after she left, but for the decade before that—I had imagined Margo without listening, not knowing that the windows she put up were just as flawed as mine. Thus, I couldn't imagine her as a person who might also feel fear, feel isolated in a crowd, ashamed to keep a record collection because it was too personal to share. A person who might have read travel books to escape from life in a city where too many people flocked to. A person—because no one thought of her as a person—had no one to really talk to.
tr: I was leaning back. I was listening. And I was hearing something about Margo, windows, and mirrors. Chuck Parson He was a person. Like me. Margo Roth Spiegelman was also a person. And I had never thought of her this way, not exactly; this was the failure of all my previous conceptions. From the very beginning—not just since she left, but for the past ten years—I had imagined Margo without listening, without knowing that she had created a window as narrow as mine. And because of this, I couldn't conceive of her as a person; someone who could be scared, who could feel excluded in a room full of people, who could be shy about her record collection because it was too personal to share. Someone who could read travel guides to escape to a city where many people flee to live. Someone who really had no one to talk to because no one thought of her as a person.
es: I leaned back in the chair and listened. I heard things about my mother, about windows, and about mirrors. Chuck Parson was a person. Like me. Margo Roth Spiegelman was also a person. I had never thought of her that way, to be honest. In all my previous speculations, there was a flaw. Always — not just since she had left, but for the past ten years — I had imagined her without listening to her, without knowing that her window was as closed as mine. And that's why I didn't imagine her as a person who could be afraid, who could feel isolated in a room full of people, who could be embarrassed by her record collection because it was too personal to share. Someone who might read travel books to escape because she had to live in a city from which so many people escape. Someone who — since no one thought she was a person — had no one to talk to.

en: And all at once I knew how Margo Roth Spiegelman felt when she wasn’t being Margo Roth Spiegelman: she felt empty. She felt the unscaleable wall surrounding her. I thought of her asleep on the carpet with only that jagged sliver of sky above her. Maybe Margo felt comfortable there because Margo the person lived like that all the time: in an abandoned room with blocked-out windows, the only light pouring in through holes in the roof. Yes. The fundamental mistake I had always made—and that she had, in fairness, always led me to make—was this: Margo was not a miracle. She was not an adventure. She was not a fine and precious thing. She was a girl.
vi: And immediately I realized how Margo Roth Spiegelman felt when she was not Margo Roth Spiegelman: she was empty. She felt surrounded by an endless wall. I thought of her sleeping on the carpet with the torn sky above. Perhaps Margo felt comfortable there because Margo-the-person always lived like that: in an abandoned room with sealed windows, the only light coming through the holes in the ceiling. Exactly. The serious mistake I had always made–to be fair, she had always made me make–was this: Margo was not a miracle. She was not an adventure. She was not a precious, beautiful thing. Margo was a girl.
tr: And suddenly I understood how Margo Roth Spiegelman felt when she wasn't Margo Roth Spiegelman: She felt empty. She felt surrounded by walls that couldn't be climbed. I thought of her sleeping on the carpet, with only that narrow piece of sky above her. Maybe Margo felt comfortable there because the human Margo always lived like this: In an abandoned room with closed windows, the only light coming from the holes in the roof. Yes. The main mistake I always made, and to be honest, the one she always led me to make, was this: Margo was not a miracle. She was not an adventure. She was not something good and precious. She was a teenage girl.
es: And suddenly I understood how Margo Roth Spiegelman felt when she wasn't being Margo Roth Spiegelman: empty. She felt surrounded by an insurmountable wall. I thought of her sleeping on the carpet with only that jagged piece of sky above her head. Maybe she felt comfortable there because the person Margo always lived like that, in an abandoned room, with the windows covered, where light only came in through the holes in the ceiling. Yes. The fundamental mistake I had always made —and to be fair, she always led me to make— was this: Margo was not a miracle. She was not an adventure. She was not something perfect and precious. She was a girl.

tr: She was a teenage girl.

en: The clock was always punishing, but feeling like I was closer to unraveling the knots made time seem to stop entirely on Tuesday. We’d all decided to go to the minimall right after school, and the waiting was unbearable. When the bell finally rang for the end of English, I raced downstairs and was almost out the door when I realized we couldn’t leave until Ben and Radar finished band practice. I sat down outside the band room and took a personal pizza wrapped in napkins from my backpack, where I’d had it since lunch. I was through the first quarter when Lacey Pemberton sat down next to me. I offered her a piece. She declined.
vi: The clock seemed to torture me, but the intuition that I was about to untangle the knot made time seem to completely stand still on Tuesday. We all decided to go to the mini shopping mall right after school, the wait was unbearable. Finally, the bell signaling the end of Vietnamese class rang, I rushed down the stairs and was about to leave the gate when I remembered that Ben and Radar were still practicing music, so they couldn't leave immediately. I sat outside the music room, took a small pizza wrapped in a napkin from my backpack, which I had kept since lunch. I had eaten about a quarter when Lacey Pemberton came and sat next to me. I offered her some pizza, but Lacey declined.
tr: The clock was always punitive, but feeling that I was close to untying the knots made the day of the event seem like time had completely stopped. We had all decided to go to the mall right after school, and the wait was unbearable. When the bell finally rang, signaling the end of the literature class, I ran downstairs and was almost out the door when I realized we couldn't leave until Ben and Radar finished band practice. I sat outside the band room and took out a single-serving pizza wrapped in napkins that I had saved since lunch from my backpack. I had finished the first quarter when Lacey Pemberton sat down next to me. I offered her a slice too. She declined.
es: The clock was always relentless, but feeling that I was close to untying the knots made Tuesday seem to have stopped. We had decided to go to the abandoned mall right after class, so the wait became unbearable for me. When the bell finally rang, after literature class, I ran downstairs, and I was almost at the door when I realized that we couldn't leave until Ben and Radar had finished rehearsal. I sat down to wait for them and took out from my backpack a slice of pizza wrapped in paper napkins that I had left over from lunch. I hadn't eaten even a quarter of it when Lacey Pemberton sat down next to me. I offered her a piece, but she said no.

en: We talked about Margo, of course. The hole we had in common. “What I need to figure out,” I said, rubbing pizza grease onto my jeans, “is a place. But I don’t even know if I’m close with the pseudovisions. Sometimes I think we’re just entirely off track.”
vi: We talked about Margo, of course, the common gap between us. "I need to pinpoint," I said, wiping greasy hands on my jeans, "a location. But I'm not even sure if reasoning about ghost towns is the right direction. Sometimes I think we're completely off track."
tr: Of course, we talked about Margo. Our common problem. "The thing I need to figure out," I said, wiping the pizza grease on my jeans, "is a place. But I don't even know if I'm getting closer to solving it with the clues. Sometimes I think we're heading in a completely unrelated direction."
es: We are talking about Margo, of course. The problem we shared. —What I need to find out is the place —I said, wiping the pizza oil on my pants—. But I don't even know if I'm on the right track with the pseudovisions. Sometimes I think we are completely off track.

en: “Yeah, I don’t know. Honestly, everything else aside, I like finding stuff out about her. I mean, that I didn’t know before. I had no idea who she really was. I honestly never thought of her as anything but my crazy beautiful friend who does all the crazy beautiful things.”
vi: “Yeah, I don't know either. To be honest, putting everything aside, I like finding things related to Margo. Things I never knew before. I didn't know who she really was. Honestly, I never thought of anything other than seeing Margo as a crazy beautiful friend, doing all sorts of crazy beautiful things.”
tr: “Yes. I don't know. Honestly, above all, I love discovering things about him. Things I didn't know before, that is. I have no idea who he really is. Honestly, I never thought of him as anyone other than a crazy and beautiful friend who does insanely beautiful things.”
es: —Yes, I don't know. Honestly, putting everything else aside, I like discovering things about her. I mean, things I didn't know. I had no idea who she really was. The truth is that I always thought of her as a pretty and crazy friend who does all kinds of beautiful craziness.

en: “Right, but she didn’t come up with these things on the fly,” I said. “I mean, all of her adventures had a certain . . . I don’t know.”
vi: “Yeah, but Margo didn't impulsively do everything,” I said. “All of her adventures had something... I don't know.”
tr: “True, but he didn't do these things on a whim,” I said. “I mean, all his adventures had a certain... I don't know.”
es: —True, but he wouldn't do those things willingly —I told him—. I mean that all his adventures had a certain… I don't know.

en: “Elegance,” Lacey said. “She is the only person I know who’s not, like, grown up who has total elegance.”
vi: “Charming and glamorous,” Lacey said. “Margo is the only person I know who isn't, uh, an adult yet, but already has that charming glamour.”
tr: “Grace,” said Lacey. “She is the only person I know who is not an adult and possesses complete grace.”
es: —Elegance —added Lacey—. She is the only completely elegant young person I know.

en: “Yeah.”
vi: "Yes."
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “So it’s hard to imagine her in some gross unlit dusty room.”
vi: “So it's hard to imagine him in a dusty, dark, and damp room.”
tr: “That's why it's hard to imagine him in a lightless, disgusting, dusty room.”
es: —That's why it's hard for me to imagine her in a filthy, dark, and dusty room.

en: “Yeah,” I said. “With rats.”
vi: "Yes," I said. "There are also rats."
tr: “Yes,” I said. “With the mice.”
es: —Yes —I told him—. And with rats.

en: Lacey pulled her knees to her chest and assumed the fetal position. “Ick. That’s so not Margo.”
vi: Lacey hugged her knees to her chest, sitting like a baby in the womb. "Ugh. That doesn't seem much like Margo."
tr: Lacey pulled her knees to her chest and curled into a fetal position. "Eww. This is not like Margo at all."
es: Lacey brought her knees to her chest and adopted the fetal position. —How disgusting. That's not like Margo either.

en: Somehow Lacey got shotgun, although she was the shortest of us. Ben was driving. I sighed quite loudly as Radar, seated next to me, pulled out his handheld and started working on Omnictionary.
vi: Lacey sat in the front seat next to the driver, as she was the shortest of the group. Ben was driving. I sighed deeply while Radar, sitting next to me, had taken out his handheld computer and started working on the Omnictionary.
tr: Even though she was somehow the shortest of us, Lacey sat in the front seat. Ben was driving the car. When Radar, who was sitting next to me, took out his handheld computer and started working on Omnictionary, I sighed quite loudly.
es: I don't know how Lacey claimed the front passenger seat, even though she was the shortest of all. Ben was driving. I sighed loudly when Radar, who was sitting next to me, took out his pocket computer and started working on the Omnictionary.

en: “Just deleting vandalism on the Chuck Norris page,” he said. “For instance, while I do think Chuck Norris specializes in the roundhouse kick, I don’t think it’s accurate to say, ‘Chuck Norris’s tears can cure cancer, but unfortunately he has never cried.’ Anyway, vandalism-deletion only takes like four percent of my brain.”
vi: “Just deleted the nonsense in the article about Chuck Norris,” it said. “For example, I totally agree that Chuck Norris's signature move is the roundhouse kick, but I think it's too ridiculous to write something like this, ‘Chuck Norris's tears can cure cancer, but unfortunately, he never cries.’” The task of deleting-the-nonsense only occupies about four percent of my brain anyway.”
tr: “I am just deleting the vandalism on the Chuck Norris page,” he said. “For example, although I think Chuck Norris is an expert in flying kicks, I don't think it's right to say this: ‘Chuck Norris's tears can cure cancer, but unfortunately, he has never cried.’ Anyway, deleting vandalism occupies about four percent of my brain.”
es: —I am deleting the pranks from Chuck Norris's page —he told me—. For example, although I agree that he is a specialist in roundhouse kicks, I don't think it's correct to say: "Chuck Norris's tears cure cancer, but unfortunately he has never cried." But, well, deleting the pranks only requires four percent of my brain.

en: I understood Radar was trying to make me laugh, but I only wanted to talk about one thing. “I’m not convinced she’s in a pseudovision. Maybe that’s not even what she meant by ‘paper towns,’ you know? There are so many place hints, but nothing specific.”
vi: Even though I understood that Radar was trying to make a joke, I still only wanted to talk about one thing. "I don't believe that Margo is in some ghost town. That might not even be the 'paper towns' that Margo was talking about. There are too many clues about the locations, but nothing concrete."
tr: I understood that Radar was trying to make me laugh, but I only wanted to talk about one thing. ‘I am not convinced that Margo is in any part of town. Maybe this is not even what she meant by ‘paper towns’. There are a lot of hints, but nothing specific.”
es: I understood that Radar was trying to make me laugh, but I only wanted to talk about one thing. —I'm not convinced that she's in a pseudovision. Maybe she wasn't even referring to that with the "paper towns," you know? We have many clues about places, but nothing concrete.

en: Radar looked up for a second and then back down at the screen. “Personally, I think she’s far away, doing some ridiculous roadside attraction tour that she wrongly thinks she left enough clues to explain. So I think she’s currently in, like, Omaha, Nebraska, visiting the world’s largest ball of stamps, or in Minnesota checking out the world’s largest ball of twine.”
vi: Radar looked up for a second and then turned his eyes back to the screen, "Personally, I think Margo is far away by now, on some kind of thrilling tour and mistakenly believes she has left enough clues. So I think she is, let's see, in Omaha, Nebraska, visiting the world's largest ball of stamps, or in Minnesota admiring the world's largest ball of twine."
tr: Radar lifted his head for a second, then turned back to the screen. “Personally, I think the chest, which I left enough clues to be understood, has gone very far away on a ridiculous trip. So right now, I think he's visiting the world's largest ball of stamps in Omaha, Nebraska, or checking out the world's largest ball of yarn in Minnesota or something.”
es: Radar lifted his gaze for a second and then lowered it back to the screen. —Personally, I think she's far away, on a ridiculous tour of tourist spots and mistakenly believing that she has left enough clues to be found. So I think right now she's in Omaha, Nebraska, looking at the world's largest ball of stamps, or in Minnesota, checking out the world's largest ball of twine.

en: With a glance into the rearview mirror, Ben said, “So you think that Margo is on a national tour in search of various World’s Largest Balls?” Radar nodded.
vi: Glancing through the rearview mirror, Ben spoke up, "So you think Margo is on a cross-country tour admiring all kinds of the World's Largest Round Things, huh?" Radar nodded in agreement.
tr: Ben glanced in the rearview mirror and said, "So you think Margo is on a national tour chasing The Biggest Balls in Kenya?" Radar nodded in agreement.
es: —So, do you think Margo is on a tour around the country looking for the world's biggest balls? —asked Ben, looking in the rearview mirror. Radar nodded.

en: “Well,” Ben went on, “someone should just tell her to come on home, because she can find the world’s largest balls right here in Orlando, Florida. They’re located in a special display case known as ‘my scrotum.’”
vi: "Oh wow," Ben continued, "someone needs to tell Margo that she just needs to come home, because she will be stunned by the biggest pair of balls in the world right here, in the city of Orlando, Florida. That treasure is on display in a special exhibit called 'my place.'"
tr: “Well,” Ben continued, “someone needs to tell him to come home now, because he can find the world's largest balls right here in Orlando, Florida. They are placed in a special showcase known as ‘My Testicles’.”
es: —Well —Ben continued—, someone should tell him to come back home, because right here in Orlando, Florida, he can find the biggest balls in the world. They are in a special display case known as "my scrotum."

en: Radar laughed, and Ben continued. “I mean, seriously. My balls are so big that when you order french fries from McDonald’s, you can choose one of four sizes: small, medium, large, and my balls.”
vi: Radar laughed loudly, Ben added, "I'm serious." “My balls are so big that when you order fries at McDonald's, you can choose from four sizes: small, medium, large, and Ben's balls size.”
tr: Radar laughed and Ben continued: ‘I mean, seriously. They are as big as my balls, when you order fries from McDonald’s, you can choose from four sizes: small, medium, large, and my balls.”
es: Radar laughed. —I'm serious —Ben continued saying—. My balls are so big that, when you order fries at McDonald's, you can choose from four sizes: small, medium, large, and my balls.

en: Lacey cut her eyes at Ben and said, “Not. Appropriate.”
vi: Lacey couldn't bear to look at Ben anymore, saying, "None. Of. Your. Business."
tr: Lacey glanced at Ben out of the corner of her eye.
es: Lacey gave him a look and said to him:

en: “Sorry,” Ben mumbled. “I think she’s in Orlando,” he said. “Watching us look. And watching her parents not look.”
vi: “I'm sorry,” Ben whispered. “Margo is probably in Orlando,” he said. “Watching us look for her. And watching her parents not look.”
tr: “Not. Appropriate. At all.” “Sorry,” Ben muttered. “I think she’s in Orlando,” he said. “Watching us search for her. And watching her parents not search for her.”
es: —Out of place comment. —Sorry —murmured Ben—. I think Margo is in Orlando. Watching us look for her. And watching that her parents aren't looking for her.

en: “I’m still for New York,” Lacey said.
vi: "I still support the New York hypothesis," Lacey said.
tr: “I still say New York,” said Lacey.
es: —I still bet on New York —said Lacey.

en: “All still possible,” I said. A Margo for each of us—and each more mirror than window.
vi: “Anything is possible,” I said. Each Margo for each of us–and more mirrors than windows.
tr: “It’s all still possible,” I said. For each of us, a Margo... and each one resembles a mirror more than a window.
es: —Everything is possible —I replied. A Margo for each one of us... and each one was more a mirror than a window.

en: The minimall looked as it had a couple days before. Ben parked, and I took them through the push-open door to the office. Once everyone was inside, I said softly, “Don’t turn on the flashlight yet. Give your eyes a chance to adjust.” I felt fingernails dig at my forearm. I whispered, “It’s okay, Lace.”
vi: The mini shopping area still looked the same as a few days ago. Ben parked the car, and I led the group through the push-in door into the office area. Once everyone was inside, I whispered, "Don't turn on the flashlights yet, let your eyes adjust for a moment." There were a few fingernails digging into my forearm. "It's okay, Lacey," I murmured.
tr: The small shopping mall looked the same as it did a few days ago. I parked the car and led them through the door, pushing it open, and took them to the office. As soon as everyone entered, I quietly said, “Don't turn on the lights yet. Give your eyes a chance to adjust,” I said. I felt nails digging into my arm. “It's okay, Lace,” I whispered.
es: The shopping center looked the same as it did a couple of days before. Ben parked and I took them to the office through the door that opened by pushing. —Don't turn on the lanterns yet —I told them when we were all inside—. Wait until your eyes get used to the darkness. —I felt some nails running down my arm—. Calm down, Lace.

en: “Whoops,” she said. “Wrong arm.” She’d been searching, I realized, for Ben.
vi: "Oops," Lacey exclaimed. "Wrong hand." It turned out she was looking for Ben's hand.
tr: “Yes,” he said. “Wrong arm.” I realized he was looking for Ben.
es: —Oops —said Lacey—. I used the wrong arm. I understood that he was looking for Ben's.

en: Slowly, the room came into a hazy gray focus. I could see the desks lined up, still waiting for workers. I turned on my flashlight, and then everyone else turned theirs on as well. Ben and Lacey stayed together, walking toward the Troll Hole to explore the other rooms. Radar walked with me to Margo’s desk. He knelt down to look closely at the paper calendar frozen on June.
vi: Slowly, the room began to reveal faint, grayish shapes. I saw rows of tables, still waiting for the staff to arrive. I turned on my flashlight, and the others turned on theirs as well. Ben and Lacey went together, crawling through the Hole to explore other rooms. Radar went with me to Margo's desk. He knelt down to closely examine the calendar that had stopped at June.
tr: Slowly, the room took on a hazy gray appearance. I could still see the lined-up desks, waiting for the workers. I turned on my flashlight and then the others turned on theirs. Ben and Lacey stayed together, heading towards the Dwarf Hole to examine the other rooms. Radar walked with me towards Margo’s desk. He knelt down to take a closer look at the paper calendar frozen in June.
es: Little by little, the room began to take shape in a blurry gray. I saw the tables lined up, still waiting for the employees. I turned on the flashlight, and the others turned on theirs as well. Ben and Lacey headed together towards the Troll Hole to inspect the other rooms. Radar came with me to Margo's desk. He knelt down to closely observe the calendar frozen in the month of June.

en: I was leaning in next to him when I heard fast footsteps coming toward us.
vi: I was bending down towards it when I suddenly heard the sound of footsteps quickly approaching us.
tr: When I heard the fast approaching footsteps, I was leaning towards Radar.
es: I was leaning by his side when I heard quick steps approaching us.

en: “People,” Ben whispered urgently. He ducked down behind Margo’s desk, pulling Lacey with him.
vi: "Someone's here," Ben whispered urgently. He immediately crawled under Margo's table, pulling Lacey along.
tr: “There are thousands,” Ben whispered hurriedly. Pulling Lacey, he crouched behind Margo's desk.
es: —People —murmured Ben, crouching behind Margo's table and pulling Lacey.

en: “What? Where?”
vi: “What? Where?”
tr: “What? Where?”
es: —What? Where?

en: “Next room!” he said. “Wearing masks. Official-looking. Gotta go.”
vi: “Next room!” it said. “Wear a mask. Looks like government people. Let's go.”
tr: "They're in that room!" he said. "They are wearing masks. They look official. We need to go."
es: —In the other room! —he said—. They are wearing masks. They look like cops. Let's go.

en: Radar shone his flashlight in the direction of the Troll Hole but Ben knocked it down forcefully. “We. Have. To. Get. Out. Of. Here.” Lacey was looking up at me, big-eyed and probably a little bit pissed off that I’d falsely promised her safety.
vi: Radar shone the flashlight towards the Hole of Evil but Ben pulled him back forcefully. “We. Have. To. Get. Out. Of. Here.” Lacey looked at me, her eyes wide open, probably a bit annoyed because I had promised her that she would be safe.
tr: He aimed the radar flashlight at the Dwarf Hole, but Ben struck it forcefully, knocking the flashlight to the ground. “From here. We must. Get out.” Lacey was looking at me with wide eyes and, probably mistakenly, a bit angry because I had promised her we would be safe.
es: Radar focused his flashlight towards the Troll Hole, but Ben knocked it down with a swipe. —We have to get out of here! Lacey was staring at me with wide eyes, probably a little angry, because I had promised her that she wouldn't be in danger, and it didn't seem true.

en: “Okay,” I whispered. “Okay, everybody out, through the door. Very cool, very quick.” I had just started to walk when I heard a booming voice shout, “WHO GOES THERE!”
vi: “Alright,” I said. “Let's go out, through the doorway. Quick and tidy.” I had just taken a step when I heard a thunderous voice: “WHO'S IN THERE!”
tr: "Okay," I whispered. "Okay, everyone out, through the door. Very calmly, very quickly." I had just started to walk when I heard a booming voice shout. "WHO'S THERE!"
es: —Okay —I whispered—. Okay, everyone out, through the door. Calmly but quickly. I had just taken a step when I heard a booming voice shouting: WHO GOES THERE?

en: Shit. “Um,” I said, “we’re just visiting.” What an outlandishly lame thing to say. Through the Troll Hole, a white light blinded me. It might have been God Himself.
vi: How annoying. “Um,” I replied, “we're just looking around.” Truly a first-class cowardly excuse. From Lo Qui, a beam of white light blinded me. It could very well be God.
tr: Damn it. “Well,” I said, “we're just wandering around.” It was an extremely terrifying thing to say. The white light coming from the Dwarf Hole blinded me. This could have even been Tann himself.
es: Shit. —Ahem —I said—, we just came to take a look. What an outlandish nonsense. A white light coming from the Troll Hole blinded me. It could have been God himself.

en: “What are your intentions?” The voice had a slight faked Britishness to it.
vi: "What's the intention here?" The voice slightly feigned an English–English accent.
tr: "What is your intention?" There was a faint hint of a fake English accent in this voice.
es: —What are your intentions? The voice slightly imitated a British accent.

en: I watched Ben stand up next to me. It felt good not to be alone. “We’re here investigating a disappearance,” he said with great confidence. “We weren’t going to break anything.” The light snapped off, and I blinked away the blindness until I saw three figures, each wearing jeans, a T-shirt, and a mask with two circular filters. One of them pulled the mask up to his forehead and looked at us. I recognized the goatee and flat, wide mouth.
vi: I saw Ben standing up next to me. It's good not to be alone. "We are investigating a missing person case," he said with radiant confidence. "We don't intend to cause any harm." The light moved away, and I blinked in the darkness until I saw the shapes of three people, all wearing jeans, t-shirts, and gas masks. One person pulled the mask up to their forehead and looked at us. I recognized the goatee and the wide mouth with thin lips.
tr: I watched Ben stand up beside me. It felt good not to be alone. “We’re here to investigate a disappearance,” he said with great confidence. “We weren’t going to break anything.” The light went out, and I blinked away the blindness until I saw three silhouettes, both wearing jeans, t-shirts, and masks with two filters. One of them lifted his mask to his forehead and looked at us. I recognized this goatee, straight and wide mouth.
es: I observed Ben, who approached me. I felt better accompanied. —We are investigating a disappearance —said Ben very confidently—. We weren't going to break anything. The light moved away and I blinked until I saw three figures, all three wearing jeans, a t-shirt, and a mask with two round filters. One of them lifted the mask to their forehead and looked at us. I recognized the goatee and the large mouth.

en: “Gus?” asked Lacey. She stood up. The SunTrust security guard.
vi: "Mr. Gus?" Lacey asked, standing up. He is the security guard at the SunTrust building.
tr: “Gus?” asked Lacey. She stood up. The SunTrust security guard.
es: —Gus? —said Lacey, standing up. He was the SunTrust guard.

en: “Lacey Pemberton. Jesus. What are you doing here? With no mask? This place has a ton of asbestos.”
vi: “Lacey Pemberton. Oh my God. What are you guys doing here? No masks? There's a ton of asbestos here.”
tr: "Lacey Pemberton. My God. What are you doing here? And without a mask? There's a ton of asbestos here."
es: —Lacey Pemberton. For God's sake, what are you doing here? And without masks... There are tons of asbestos here.

en: “What are you doing here?”
vi: "What are you doing here?"
tr: “What are you doing here?”
es: —What are you doing here?

en: “Exploring,” he said. Somehow Ben was emboldened with enough confidence to walk up to the other guys and offer handshakes. They introduced themselves as Ace and the Carpenter. I would venture to guess that these were pseudonyms.
vi: “Exploring,” he replied. For some reason, Ben suddenly became more confident, stepping forward in front of the other two and proactively extending his hand for a handshake. They introduced themselves as Ace and Carpenter. I guessed that those were their “ghost” names.
tr: “I am investigating,” he said. Somehow, Ben had become confident enough to approach the other men and extend his hand to shake theirs. They introduced themselves as As and Carpenter. I'll bet these were their pseudonyms.
es: —Exploring —he replied. Ben felt confident enough to approach the other two boys and extend his hand to them. They introduced themselves as As and the Carpenter. I would dare to assume that they were pseudonyms.

en: We pulled around some rolling desk chairs and sat in an approximate circle. “Did you guys break the particleboard?” Gus asked.
vi: We pulled a few swivel chairs together, sitting in a near circle facing each other. "Were you the ones who punched through the wooden boards out there?" Gus asked.
tr: We pulled a few swivel chairs from around and sat in a circle. “Did you break the chipboard?” Gus asked.
es: We took office chairs with wheels and sat down forming more or less a circle. —Was it you who broke the plank? —asked Gus.

en: “Well, I did,” Ben explained.
vi: "I just hit it," Ben explained.
tr: "Well, I broke it," Ben explained.
es: —Well, it was me —Ben explained to him.

en: “We taped that up because we didn’t want anyone else in. If people can see a way in from the road, you get a lot of people coming in who don’t know shit about exploring. Bums and crack addicts and everything.”
vi: “We sealed it up because we didn't want others to get inside. If people from the street see an entrance, many will come, mostly those who know nothing about exploration. Wanderers, idlers, and addicts of all kinds.”
tr: "We taped it ourselves because we didn't want anyone else to come inside. If people see a way to get in from the road, many who don't know a damn thing about the research will come inside. Beggars, junkies, and the like."
es: —We sealed it with tape because we didn't want anyone else to enter. If from the road it looks like you can get in, a bunch of people who have no clue about exploring would come. Vagrants, crack addicts, and all that.

en: I stepped forward toward them and said, “So, you, uh, knew that Margo came here?”
vi: I walked towards them and asked, "So, do you guys, uh, know if Margo has been here?"
tr: I took a step towards them. "So, do you, um, know that Margo came here?" I said.
es: I took a step towards them. —So you guys… well… did you know that Margo was here?

en: Before Gus answered, Ace spoke through the mask. His voice was slightly modulated but easy to understand. “Man, Margo was here all the damned time. We only come here a few times a year; it’s got asbestos, and anyway, it’s not even that good. But we probably saw her, like, what, like more than half the time we came here in the last couple years. She was hot, huh?”
vi: Gus hadn't had time to reply when At spoke through the mask. His voice was slightly distorted but still understandable. “Heavens, Margo has been here all the time. We only come by a few times a year; this place has a lot of asbestos, and there's nothing particularly special about it. But in recent years, more than half the times we've come, we've seen the girl here. She's been doing quite well, hasn't she?”
tr: Before Gus could answer, As spoke from behind the mask. His voice had slightly changed, but it was easy to understand. “Dude, Margo was here all this damn time. We only come here a few times a year; there's asbestos here, and it's not even that good of a place. But probably, in the last few years when we came here, I mean, we saw her around half the time. She was sexy, wasn't she?”
es: —I asked. Before Gus could answer, As spoke without removing the mask. His voice was slightly modulated, but it was easy to understand him. —Uncle, Margo spent her life here. We only come a couple of times a year. There's asbestos and, well, it's nothing special. But surely we've seen her, I don't know, more than half the times we've come in the last two years. She was hot, huh? —Was he?

en: “Was?” asked Lacey pointedly.
vi: “Why 'already'?” Lacey asked perceptively.
tr: “What?” Lacey asked meaningfully.
es: —asked Lacey with emphasis.

en: “She ran away, right?”
vi: “The girl has left, hasn't she?”
tr: “He ran away, didn't he?”
es: —He has escaped, hasn't he?

en: “What do you know about that?” Lacey asked.
vi: "What do you know about that?" “Oh God, I don't know anything.
tr: “What do you know about this?” asked Lacey.
es: —What do you know about the matter? —Lacey asked them.

en: “Nothing, Jesus. I saw Margo with him,” Gus said, nodding toward me, “a couple weeks ago. And then I heard that she ran away. It occurred to me a few days later she might be here, so we visited.”
vi: “Oh God, I don't know anything. I saw Margo hanging out with this guy,” Gus said, pointing at me, “a few weeks ago. Then I heard she ran away from home. A few days later, I suddenly remembered she might have come here, so we decided to drop by and check it out.”
tr: "Nothing. I saw Margo with him," said Gus, nodding his head towards me, "a few weeks ago. Then I heard she ran away. A few days later, it occurred to me that she might be here, so we came here."
es: —Nothing, please. A couple of weeks ago I saw Margo with him —said Gus pointing at me—. And then they told me she had run away. A few days later it occurred to me that she might be here, so we came.

en: “I never got why she liked this place so much. There’s not much here,” said the Carpenter. “It’s not great exploring.”
vi: “I don't understand why the girl likes this place so much. There's nothing special about it,” said the Carpenter. “There's nothing exciting to explore.”
tr: “I never understood why you like this place so much. There isn't much here,” said the Carpenter. “It's not good for exploration.”
es: —I have never understood why he liked this place so much. There is hardly anything here —said the Carpenter—. Exploring here is no fun. —What is this "exploring"?

en: “What do you mean exploring?” Lacey asked Gus.
vi: “What do you mean by exploring?” Lacey asked Gus.
tr: Lacey asked Gus, "What do you mean by discovery?"
es: —asked Lacey to Gus.

en: “Urban exploring. We enter abandoned buildings, explore them, photograph them. We take nothing; we leave nothing. We’re just observers.”
vi: “Exploring the city. We go into abandoned buildings, explore and take photos. We don't take anything, nor do we leave anything behind, we just like to observe.”
tr: “Urban exploration. We enter abandoned buildings, explore them, take photographs. We take nothing; we leave nothing. We are just observers.”
es: —Urban exploration. We enter abandoned buildings, explore them, and take photos. We neither take nor leave anything. We are mere observers.

en: “It’s a hobby,” said Ace. “Gus used to let Margo tag along on exploring trips when we were still in school.”
vi: “Just a hobby,” At said. “Back in school, Gus often dragged Margo along on such adventures.”
tr: “This is a hobby,” said As. “When we were still in school, Gus allowed Margo to follow him on his expeditions.”
es: —It's a hobby —said As—. Gus used to let Margo join us in exploring when we were still in high school.

en: “She had a great eye, even though she was only, like, thirteen,” Gus said. “She could figure a way into anywhere. It was just occasional back then, but now we go out like three times a week. There’s places all over. There’s an abandoned mental hospital over in Clearwater. It’s amazing. You can see where they strapped down the crazies and gave them electroshock. And there’s an old jail out west of here. But she wasn’t really into it. She liked to break into the places, but then she just wanted to stay.”
vi: “The girl has a very keen eye, and back then she was only, let's see, thirteen years old,” Gus said. “She could find her way into anywhere. Back then it was only occasionally, but now we go exploring three times a week. There are places to see everywhere. There was a recently abandoned mental hospital in Clearwater. An amazing place. We got to see how they used to tie up the crazies and give them electric shocks. There's an old prison to the west of here. But Margo isn't really into exploring. She likes to get inside, but then she just wants to stay in one spot.”
tr: “He had an amazing eye, even though he was about thirteen years old,” said Gus. “He always found a way to get into everywhere. Back then, we would go whenever we had the chance, but now we go out about three times a week. There are places like this everywhere. There’s an abandoned mental hospital in Clearwater. It’s astonishing. You can see the place where they used to strap down the insane and give them electroshock therapy. And to the west of here, there’s an old prison. But Margo wasn’t too interested. She liked breaking into places but then just wanted to stay there.”
es: —He had a very good eye, even though he was only thirteen years old —said Gus—. He found a way to get into any place. Back then we did it occasionally, but now we go out about three times a week. There are places everywhere. In Clearwater, there is an abandoned psychiatric hospital. It's incredible. You can see where they used to tie up the crazies to give them electroshocks. And near here, to the west, there is an old jail. But Margo wasn't really into it. She liked to get in, but then she wanted to stay.

en: “Yeah, God that was annoying,” added Ace.
vi: “Yeah, it's so annoying I could die,” Át added.
tr: “Yes, my God, that was very annoying,” added As.
es: —Yeah, damn, it was a hassle —added As.

en: The Carpenter said, “She wouldn’t even, like, take pictures. Or run around and find stuff. She just wanted to go inside and, like, sit. Remember, she had that black notebook? And she would just sit in the corner and write, like she was in her house, doing homework or something.”
vi: The Carpenter said, "The girl didn't even bother to take pictures. She also didn't run around looking at this and that. She just wanted to get inside and sit down. Do you remember she always carried that black notebook? She would just sit in the corner and write, as if she were at home, like doing homework."
tr: The carpenter said, "He wouldn't even take photos or anything. Nor would he run around finding things. He just wanted to come in and sit down or something. Do you remember that black notebook of his? He would just sit in a corner and write, as if he were at home doing homework or something," he said.
es: —He didn't even take photos —said the Carpenter—. He didn't look for things around. He just wanted to come in and sit down. Do you remember the black notebook? He would sit in a corner and write, as if he were at home doing homework or something like that.

en: “Honestly,” Gus said, “she never really got what it’s all about. The adventure. She seemed pretty depressed, actually.”
vi: “Actually,” Gus said, “Margo never really participated in the fun. All those adventures. In fact, she seemed quite gloomy.”
tr: “Honestly,” said Gus, “he never really understood what all this was about. Adventure. He actually seemed to be depressed.”
es: —Honestly, she never understood what it was about —said Gus—. The adventure. In reality, she seemed quite depressed.

en: I wanted to let them keep talking, because I figured everything they said would help me imagine Margo. But all of a sudden, Lacey stood up and kicked her chair behind her. “And you never thought to ask her about how she was pretty depressed actually? Or why she hung out in these sketch-ass places? That never bothered you?” She was standing above him now, shouting, and he stood up, too, half a foot taller than her, and then the Carpenter said, “Jesus, somebody calm that bitch down.”
vi: I wanted to let them talk, because I realized that all those words would help me imagine Margo. But suddenly, Lacey stood up abruptly and kicked the chair behind her. "Have you guys never thought about asking why Margo was so down?" "Or why Margo followed you guys to these obscure places?" "Have you guys never wondered why?" Lacey stood right in front of Gus, screaming wildly. Gus also stood up, towering over Lacey by a whole head. The Carpenter intervened, "Oh my God, someone calm this shrew down."
tr: I wanted them to keep talking because I thought everything they said would help me imagine Margo. But suddenly, Lacey stood up and kicked her chair back. "And you, you never thought to ask her why she was actually depressed, did you? Or why she hung out in these crappy places? Didn't that ever bother you?" She was now standing over Gus, shouting. Gus stood up too, he was fifteen centimeters taller than Lacey, and then Carpenter said, "God, someone calm this whore down."
es: I wanted to let them keep talking, because I thought that everything they said would help me imagine Margo, but suddenly Lacey stood up and kicked her chair. —And it never occurred to you to ask her why she was depressed? Or why she spent the day in these shithole dives? Have you never considered it? He was in front of him, shouting at him from above, so Gus stood up as well. He was almost a handspan taller than her. —For God's sake, someone calm this bitch down a bit —said the Carpenter.

en: “Oh no you didn’t!” Ben yelled, and before I even knew what was going on, Ben tackled the Carpenter, who fell awkwardly out of his chair onto his shoulder. Ben straddled the guy and started pounding on him, furiously and awkwardly smacking and punching his mask, shouting, “SHE’S NOT THE BITCH, YOU ARE!” I scrambled up and grabbed one of Ben’s arms as Radar grabbed the other. We pulled him away, but he was still shouting, “I have a lot of anger right now! I was enjoying punching the guy! I want to go back to punching him!”
vi: "Oh no!" Ben screamed. Before I could understand what was happening, Ben had already closed in on the Carpenter, knocking him off his chair and slamming his shoulder onto the floor. Ben sat on top of him and began to pummel him furiously and foolishly, punching and slapping his mask, shouting, "YOU'RE NOTHING BUT A WITCH!" I lunged forward to grab one of Ben's arms, while Radar held the other. We pulled Ben away, but he kept yelling, "I'm furious! Hitting you is so much fun! Hitting you more would be even better!"

I want to keep punching him!”

I got up and grabbed Ben by one arm while Radar held him by the other. —I'm very pissed off! —he shouted as we pulled him away—. I was having fun hitting that guy! I want to hit him again!

es: —Ben —I said, trying to appear calm, with the tone my mother usually uses—. Ben, that's enough. You've made your point clear.

en: Radar knew what mattered. He returned immediately to the calendar, his eyes an inch away from the paper. “I don’t think anything was written on the May page,” he says. “The paper is pretty thin and I can’t see any marks. But it’s impossible to say for sure.” He went off to search for more clues, and I saw Lacey’s and Ben’s flashlights dipping as they went through a Troll Hole, but I just stood there in the office, imagining her. I thought of her following these guys, four years older than her, into abandoned buildings. That was Margo as I’d seen her. But then, inside the buildings, she is not the Margo I’d always imagined. While everyone else walks off to explore and take pictures and bounce around the walls, Margo sits on the floor, writing something.

en: We walked around for another hour, and just when I felt sure the trip had been a waste, my flashlight happened over the subdivision brochures that had been built into a house of cards when we first came here. One of the brochures was for Grovepoint Acres. My breath caught as I spread out the other brochures. I jogged to my backpack by the door and came back with a pen and a notebook and wrote down the names of all the advertised subdivisions. I recognized one immediately: Collier Farms—one of the two pseudovisions on my list I hadn’t yet visited. I finished copying the subdivision names and returned my notebook to my backpack. Call me selfish, but if I found her, I wanted it to be alone.

All the other subdivisions from the brochures turned out to exist— most of them on the north side of town, which had been totally developed a long time ago.

It turned out that all the other developments that appeared in the brochures existed, most of them north of the city. They had been completed a long time ago.

en: I only recognized the turnoff for Collier Farms because I’d become something of an expert in hard-to-see dirt access roads. But Collier Farms was like none of the other pseudovisions I’d seen, because it was wildly overgrown, as if it had been abandoned for fifty years. I didn’t know if it was older than the other pseudovisions, or if the low-lying, swamp-wet land made everything grow faster, but the Collier Farms access road became impassable just after I turned in because a thick grove of brambly brush had sprouted across the entire road.
vi: I recognized the turn into Collier Farms only because I had become an expert at identifying the faint roads blending into the ground. But Collier Farms was unlike any ghost town I had ever been to. This place was overgrown with weeds, as if it had been abandoned for fifty years. It was unclear whether this place had been abandoned longer than other ghost towns, or if the low terrain and swampy, damp soil caused everything to grow faster. As soon as I turned, I saw that I couldn't continue down the road into Collier Farms because the overgrown blackberry bushes blocked the entire path.
tr: I was able to notice the Collier Farms turnoff because I had become something of an expert at spotting hard-to-see dirt roads. But Collier Farms was unlike any other neighborhood I had seen, because it was overgrown with wild bushes as if it had been abandoned fifty years ago. I didn't know if it was older than the other neighborhoods or if it had a swampy ground that caused everything to grow faster, but the entrance road to Collier Farms became impassable right after I turned onto it because a dense thicket of thorny bushes had grown on both sides of the road.
es: I only recognized the turnoff to Collier Farms because I had become an expert in spotting hard-to-see unpaved roads. But Collier Farms was different from the other pseudovisions I had visited. It was extremely neglected, as if it had been abandoned for fifty years. I didn't know if it was older than the others or if the low, swampy land had made everything grow faster, but as soon as I took the turnoff, it became impossible to keep going because the entire road was covered with thick bushes.

en: I got out and walked. The overgrown grass scraped at my shins, and my sneakers sunk into the mud with each step. I couldn’t help but hope she had a tent pitched out here somewhere on some little piece of land two feet higher than everything else, keeping the rain off. I walked slowly, because there was more to see than at any of the others, more places to hide, and because I knew this pseudovision had a direct connection to the minimall. The ground was so thick I had to walk slowly as I let myself take in each new landscape, checking each place big enough to fit a person. At the end of the street I saw a blue-and-white cardboard box in the mud, and for a second it looked like the same nutrition bars I’d found in the minimall. But, no. A rotting container for a twelve-pack of beer. I trudged back to the minivan and headed for a place called Logan Pines farther to the north.
vi: I walked down on foot. The sedge grass brushed against my shins, and my sneakers sank into the mud with each step. I couldn't help but hope that Margo had set up a tent somewhere, on a small patch of land slightly higher than the rest by about half a meter and not waterlogged by rain. I walked slowly, because this place needed more observation than others, because there were more hiding spots, and because I knew this ghost town was directly connected to the mini-mall. The ground was very thick, and I walked really slowly to take in every new landscape, checking spots large enough to hide a person. At the end of the street, I saw a blue and white cardboard box on the muddy ground, for a moment it looked very much like the nutrition bar box I had seen in the mini-mall. But, no. It was an old, tattered box, the kind that holds twelve bottles of beer. I struggled back to the car, headed north, to a place called Logan Pines.

Somewhere out there, I had no choice but to hope for a piece of land elevated a meter above everything else, with a tent protecting it from the rain. I was walking slowly because there were more things to see and more places to hide than in other areas, and I also knew that this neighborhood had a direct connection to the shopping mall. Ground It was so dense that I had to walk slowly, checking every place large enough to fit a person on every flat surface. At the end of the road, I saw a blue and white cardboard box in the mud, and for a second, this box looked exactly like the ones I had seen in the shopping mall. But, no. This was a decaying twelve-pack of beer. I walked back to the minivan with heavy steps and set off towards a farther place to the north called Logan Pines.
es: I got out of the car and continued on foot. The undergrowth scratched my calves, and with each step, my sneakers sank into the mud. I couldn't help but hope that I had set up a tent on some piece of ground a few meters above the rest so that the rainwater wouldn't stagnate. I walked slowly because there were more things to see than in any of the other pseudo-visions, more places to hide, and because I knew that this complex was directly related to the abandoned shopping mall. The ground was so full of undergrowth that I had to move very slowly through each new scene and check that all the places were big enough to fit a person. At the end of the street, I saw a blue and white cardboard box in the mud, and for a moment, it seemed like the same box of cereal bars I had found in the shopping mall. But no. It was the torn-up box of a twelve-pack of beers. I struggled back to the car and headed to a place called Logan Pines, further north.

en: There was a pause, and then Ben used my full name. “Quentin,” he said, “I know you want to find her. I know she is the most important thing to you. And that’s cool. But we graduate in, like, a week. I’m not asking you to abandon the search. I’m asking you to come to a party with your two best friends who you have known for half your life. I’m asking you to spend two to three hours drinking sugary wine coolers like the pretty little girl you are, and then another two to three hours vomiting the aforementioned wine coolers through your nose. And then you can go back to poking around abandoned housing projects.”
vi: After a moment of silence, Ben called my full name, "Quentin," he said, "I know you want to find Margo. I know Margo is the most important thing to you. That's commendable. But we have just one more week until graduation. I'm not telling you to give up your search. I'm inviting you to come to a party with the two best friends you've known for half your life. I'm inviting you to spend about two or three hours sipping some sweet, cold drinks with a hint of alcohol, like a good girl, and another two or three hours throwing up those drinks through your nose. Then you can continue investigating abandoned house projects.”

After that, you can go back to looking at abandoned subdivisions.”

But we graduate next week. I'm not asking you to stop looking for her. I'm asking you to come to a party with your two best friends, whom you've known for half your life. And then you can continue wandering through abandoned neighborhoods.

But Ben was Ben, like Radar said. And I had nothing left to search after Logan Pines anyway. “I’ve got to go to this last place and then I’ll be over.”

But Ben was Ben, as Radar had said. And, anyway, I had nothing else to look for after Logan Pines. —I will go to this last one and then I will stop by Radar's house.

en: Because Logan Pines was the last pseudovision in Central Florida— or at least the last one I knew about—I had placed so much hope in it. But as I walked around its single dead-end street with a flashlight, I saw no tent. No campfire. No food wrappers. No sign of people. No Margo. At the end of the road, I found a single concrete foundation dug into the dirt. But there was nothing built atop it, just the hole cut into the earth like a dead mouth agape, tangles of briars and waist-high grass growing up all around. If she’d wanted me to see these places, I could not understand why. And if Margo had gone to the pseudovisions never to come back, she knew about a place I hadn’t uncovered in all my research.
vi: Because Logan Pines is the last ghost town in Central Florida—or at least the last one I know of—I placed a lot of hope in this place. But when I walked around the only dead-end street with a flashlight, I didn't see any shacks. There were no signs of fire. No food packaging. No traces of humans. No Margo. At the end of the road, I saw a single concrete foundation embedded in the ground. But nothing was built on top of it, just a sunken foundation pit like the gaping mouth of a corpse, with thorny bushes and waist-high weeds tangled and growing around it. If Margo really wanted me to see these places, I still don't understand why she wanted that. And if Margo had gone to these ghost towns and never returned, she knew of a place that my searches had not uncovered.
tr: Since Logan Pines was the last subdivision in Central Florida, or at least the last one I knew of, I had high hopes for this place. But as I wandered down its only dead-end street with a flashlight, I saw no tents. There were no campfires. There were no food wrappers, no signs of human presence. There was no Margo. At the end of the road, I found a single concrete foundation dug into the ground. But nothing had been built on it, just a hole dug into the ground like a dead, gaping mouth, a tangle of bushes, and waist-high weeds growing everywhere. If Margo had wanted me to see these places, I couldn't understand why. And if she had gone to subdivisions never to return, she knew of a place that I had not uncovered throughout my entire investigation.
es: I had placed great hopes in Logan Pines because it was the last pseudovision in central Florida, or at least the last one I had heard of. But I didn't see any tents as I walked down its only dead-end street with the flashlight in my hand. No sign of a campfire. No food wrappers. No trace of people. No trace of Margo. At the end of the road, I found a concrete hole sunk into the ground, but nothing had been built on top of it. It was just the hole, like the open mouth of a dead person, surrounded by a tangle of brambles and weeds almost a meter high. I didn't understand why Margo would have wanted me to see these places. And if she had gone to the pseudovisions never to return, she knew of a place I hadn't discovered in my research.

en: It took an hour and a half to drive back to Jefferson Park. I parked the minivan at home, changed into a polo shirt and my only nice pair of jeans, and walked down Jefferson Way to Jefferson Court, and then took a right onto Jefferson Road. A few cars were already lined up on both sides of Jefferson Place, Radar’s street. It was only eight-forty-five.

There were a few cars already parked along both sides of Jefferson Place, Radar's street. It was only eight-forty-five.
