I parked the minivan at home, changed my clothes, put on a turtleneck shirt and my only stylish jeans, and walked from Jefferson Road towards Jefferson Courthouse, then turned right onto Jefferson Street. A few cars had already lined up on both sides of Jefferson Square, which is Radar's street. It was only eight forty-five.
es: It took me an hour and a half to get back to Jefferson Park. I parked the car at home, put on a polo shirt and my only decent jeans, walked down Jefferson Way to Jefferson Court, and then turned right onto Jefferson Road. On Jefferson Place, Radar's street, there were already several cars parked on both sides. It was only a quarter to nine.

en: I opened the door and was greeted by Radar, who had an armful of plaster black Santas. “Gotta put away all of the nice ones,” he said. “God forbid one of them breaks.”
vi: I opened the door. Radar greeted me, arms full of black Santa Claus figurines made of plaster. "We have to put away the nicest ones," it said. "God forbid any of them get broken."
tr: I opened the door and was greeted by Radar holding an armful of plaster-made black Santa Clauses. “I must put away all the nice ones,” he said. “God forbid, one of them might break.”
es: I opened the door and found myself face to face with Radar, who was holding a bunch of black Santa Claus figurines made of plaster in his hands. —I have to keep the prettiest ones —he told me—, just in case one of them breaks.

en: “Need any help?” I asked. Radar nodded toward the living room, where the tables on either side of the couch held three sets of unnested black Santa nesting dolls. As I renested them, I couldn’t help but notice that they were really very beautiful— hand-painted and extraordinarily detailed. I didn’t say this to Radar, though, for fear that he would beat me to death with the black Santa lamp in the living room.
vi: “Do you need my help?” I asked. Radar nodded towards the living room. On the tables along the sofa were three sets of nesting dolls shaped like black Santa Clauses. While nesting them together, the smaller doll fitting neatly inside the larger one, I couldn't help but admire the very beautiful dolls—hand-painted and extremely delicate. But I didn't dare mention it to Radar for fear he would kill me with the black Santa Claus lamp in the living room.
tr: “Do you need help?” I asked. Radar nodded towards the living room, where there were three groups of unstacked black Santa Claus nesting dolls on the side tables of the sofa. While stacking them, I couldn't help but notice how beautiful they really were... They were hand-painted and extraordinarily detailed. Though I didn't tell Radar this, fearing he might beat me to death with the black Santa Claus lamp in the living room.
es: —Do you need help? —I asked him. Radar pointed out the dining room to me with his head. On the tables on either side of the sofa, there were three sets of Russian dolls shaped like black Santa Clauses. As I nested some inside the others, I couldn't help but notice that they were actually very beautiful. They were hand-painted with great detail. Although I didn't tell Radar, because I feared he might beat me to death with the black Santa Claus lamp from the dining room.

en: I carried the matryoshka dolls into the guest bedroom, where Radar was carefully stashing Santas into a dresser. “You know, when you see them all together, it really does make you question the way we imagine our myths.”
vi: I brought the set of dolls to the guest bedroom for Radar to carefully store in the drawer. "You know, seeing all these Black Santas together in one place really makes you question the way we imagine folklore."
tr: I moved the Matryoshka dolls to the guest room where Radar carefully hid Santa Clauses in the chiffonier. “When you see them all together, it really makes you question the way we imagine our myths.”
es: I took the Russian dolls to the guest room, where Radar was carefully placing Santa Claus in a dresser. —You know? When you see them all together, you wonder how we imagine our myths.

en: Radar rolled his eyes. “Yeah, I always find myself questioning the way I imagine my myths when I’m eating my Lucky Charms every morning with a goddamned black Santa spoon.”
vi: Radar's eyes widened. "Yeah, I always ask myself how I come up with my anecdotes while eating Lucky Charms cereal every morning with a spoon shaped like a Black Santa Claus."
tr: Radar rolled his eyes. “Yes, every morning while eating my Lucky Charms cereal with a damn black Santa Claus spoon, I constantly find myself questioning the way I imagine my myths.”
es: Radar looked at the ceiling. —Yes, I find myself wondering how I imagine my myths every morning, when I'm eating my cereal with a damn black Santa Claus spoon.

en: I felt a hand on my shoulder spinning me around. It was Ben, his feet fidgeting in fast-motion like he needed to pee or something. “We kissed. Like, she kissed me. About ten minutes ago. On Radar’s parents’ bed.”
vi: A hand placed on my shoulder and turned me around. It was Ben, his legs bouncing around like he needed to pee. "We kissed." Lacey kissed me. About ten minutes ago. On Radar's parents' bed."
tr: I felt a hand on my shoulder, turning me around. It was Ben, his feet were shuffling quickly, as if he needed to pee or something. “We kissed. I mean, she kissed me. About ten minutes ago. In Radar’s parents’ bed.”
es: I felt a hand rubbing my shoulder. It was Ben, who was moving his feet at full speed, as if he were about to pee himself. —We kissed. Well, she kissed me. About ten minutes ago. On Radar's parents' bed.

en: “That’s disgusting,” Radar said. “Don’t make out in my parents’ bed.”
vi: "Gross," Radar said. "Don't be making out on my parents' bed."
tr: “This is disgusting,” said Radar. “Don't mess around in my parents' bedroom.”
es: —How disgusting! —exclaimed Radar—. Don't mess around in my parents' bed.

en: “Wow, I figured you’d already gotten past that,” I said. “What with you being such a pimp and everything.”
vi: “Oh wow, I see you’ve got the hang of it already,” I teased. "You pimp!"
tr: "Oh my, I thought you were over all this," I said. "Because you're a complete pimp or something."
es: —Wow, I thought you were over that phase by now —I said to Ben—. Weren't you so cocky?

en: “Shut up, bro. I’m freaked out,” he said, looking at me, his eyes almost crossed. “I don’t think I’m very good.”
vi: "Stop it, it's so annoying!" Ben said, looking at me, almost straight in the eyes, "I don't think I did very well."
tr: "Shut up, brother. I'm going to lose my mind," he said, looking at me, his eyes almost crossed. "I don't think I'm very well."
es: —Shut up, buddy. I'm terrified —he replied, looking at me with almost cross-eyed eyes—. I don't think this is very good.

en: “At what?”
vi: “What are you doing?”
tr: “What?”
es: —In what?

en: “At kissing. And, I mean, she’s done a lot more kissing than me over the years. I don’t want to suck so bad she dumps me. Girls dig you,” he said to me, which was at best true only if you defined the word girls as “girls in the marching band.” “Bro, I’m asking for advice.”
vi: “It's her. Think about it, over the years Lacey has kissed way more than I have. I don't want to be so bad at kissing that she dumps me. The girls would bury you,” he said to me, which is only true if you define girls as “the girls in the marching band.” “Hey sir, I am asking for advice here.”
tr: “Kissing. And I mean, he has done the kissing thing much more than I have over the years. I don't want to be so terrible that he leaves me. Girls like you,” he said to me, which was only true if you defined girls as “the girls in the band.” “Brother, I need advice.”
es: —Kissing. And well, she has kissed much more than I have in recent years. I don't want to kiss so badly that she leaves me. You are liked by girls —he told me, which was only true, and hopefully, if by "girls" he meant the girls in the band—. Buddy, I'm asking you for advice.

en: I was tempted to bring up all Ben’s endless blather about the various ways in which he would rock various bodies, but I just said, “As far as I can tell, there are two basic rules: 1. Don’t bite anything without permission, and 2. The human tongue is like wasabi: it’s very powerful, and should be used sparingly.”
vi: I almost stirred up Ben's endless chatter about the different ways it could be applied with different girls, but then I just said, "In my humble opinion, there are two basic principles: 1. Don't bite randomly without permission, and 2. The human tongue is like mustard: intensely memorable, but use it sparingly."
tr: I intended to talk about all those endless ramblings of Ben's about the various ways he shakes various bodies, but I just said, "As far as I can tell, there are two basic rules: 1. Don't bite anything without permission and 2. The human tongue is like wasabi: It's very powerful and should be used sparingly."
es: I was tempted to ask him about the endless lectures he gave us on the various ways to excite different bodies, but I limited myself to saying: —As far as I know, there are two basic rules: 1) Don't bite anything without permission, and 2) The human tongue is like wasabi. It is very potent and should be used sparingly.

en: Ben’s eyes suddenly grew bright with panic. I winced, and said, “She’s standing behind me, isn’t she?”

es: —"The human tongue is like wasabi," —repeated Lacey in a deep and ridiculous voice that I hoped did not resemble mine.

es: I turned around—. The truth is, I think Ben's tongue is like sunscreen. It's good for your health and you should apply it generously.

en: The party ended up in the formal living room on the second floor of Radar’s house, all twenty of us. I leaned against a wall, my head inches from a black Santa portrait painted on velvet. Radar had one of those sectional couches, and everyone was crowded onto it. There was beer in a cooler by the TV, but no one was drinking. Instead, they were telling stories about one another. I’d heard most of them before—band camp stories and Ben Starling stories and first kiss stories—but Lacey hadn’t heard any of them, and anyway, they were still entertaining.
vi: The party wrapped up in the VIP lounge on the second floor of Radar's house, with a total of twenty kids. I leaned against the wall, my head a few inches away from a portrait of a black Santa Claus painted on velvet. Radar's house had a very large sofa, so everyone gathered around it. There was beer in a cooler next to the TV, but no one drank any. Instead, one after another, they told stories. Most of them I had heard before—awkward and hilarious stories, stories about Ben Starling, stories about first kisses—but Lacey hadn't heard any of them, and anyway, they were all very funny.

There was beer in the cooler next to the TV, but no one was drinking. Instead, they were telling stories about each other. I had heard most of them beforeband camp stories, Ben Starling stories, and first kiss storiesbut Lacey hadn't heard any of them, and somehow, they were still fun.
es: The party ended with twenty people crammed into the living room on the second floor of Radar's house. I leaned against a wall, with my head just a few centimeters away from a black Santa Claus painted on velvet. People had crowded onto one of those modular sofas. Next to the TV, there was a fridge with beers, but no one was drinking. They were telling stories to each other. I had heard most of them —stories about the band, about Ben Starling, about first kisses— but Lacey hadn't, and they were still funny anyway.

en: This was what I liked most about my friends: just sitting around and telling stories. Window stories and mirror stories. I only listened—the stories on my mind weren’t that funny.
vi: This is what I love most about my friends: just sitting together and chatting. Window stories and mirror stories. I just listen– the stories in my mind are not as cheerful and lively.

es: It was what I liked most about my friends, that we were content just sitting and telling stories. Window stories and mirror stories. I just listened. The stories I had in mind weren't as fun.

en: I couldn’t help but think about school and everything else ending. I liked standing just outside the couches and watching them—it was a kind of sad I didn’t mind, and so I just listened, letting all the happiness and the sadness of this ending swirl around in me, each sharpening the other. For the longest time, it felt kind of like my chest was cracking open, but not precisely in an unpleasant way.
vi: I can't help but think about high school and the end of it all. I like just standing next to the sofa and watching my friends—it seems a bit sad, but I feel okay, and I just listen, letting all the joys and sorrows of this ending swirl around me, one grinding against the other. For the longest moment, it felt like my chest was splitting open, but not in an unpleasant way.
tr: I couldn't help but think that school and everything else was over. I just enjoyed standing outside the couches and watching them... It was a kind of sadness that didn't bother me, and I just listened, allowing all the joy and sorrow of this ending vortex inside me to sharpen each other. For a long time, it felt like my chest was cracking open, but not exactly in a bad way.
es: I couldn't help thinking that high school and everything else was coming to an end. I liked being somewhat apart from the sofas, observing them. I didn't mind that it was a bit sad. I just listened, letting all the joy and all the sadness of that ending swirl around me, each intensifying the other. Almost all the time it felt like my chest was going to explode, but it wasn't exactly an unpleasant sensation.

en: I left just before midnight. Some people were staying later, but it was my curfew, and plus I didn’t feel like staying. Mom was half asleep on the couch, but she perked up when she saw me. “Did you have fun?”

es: I left just before twelve. Some were going to stay until later, but I had to be home at that time, and besides, I didn't feel like staying. My mother was half asleep on the couch, but she perked up as soon as she saw me. —Did you have a good time?

en: “Thanks,” I said.
vi: "Thank you, Mom," I said.
tr: "Thank you," I said.
es: —Thank you —I replied.

en: I went to bed with the Whitman, flipping to the part I’d liked before, where he spends all the time hearing the opera and the people.
vi: I climbed into bed with a Whitman book, turned to the part I like, where he spends all his time listening to opera and others.
tr: I got into bed with Whitman, turned the pages to the section I loved before, the place where all my time was spent hearing the opera and the people.
es: I got into bed with Whitman's book and flipped through the pages to the part I liked, where he dedicates himself to listening to opera and to people.

en: After all that hearing, he writes, “I am exposed . . . . cut by bitter and poisoned hail.” That was perfect, I thought: you listen to people so that you can imagine them, and you hear all the terrible and wonderful things people do to themselves and to one another, but in the end the listening exposes you even more than it exposes the people you’re trying to listen to.
vi: After all that listening, he wrote, "I am revealed... severed in the bitter hail." Perfect, I thought: I listen to others so that I can imagine them, I hear all the horrors and wonders that people inflict upon themselves and upon others, but ultimately, the act of listening reveals more about myself than it does about those I am striving to listen to.
tr: After hearing all of that, he writes: "I am exposed... I am being shattered by the bitter and poisonous hail." This is perfect, I thought: You listen to people to be able to imagine them and all the terrible and wonderful things people do to themselves and to each other You hear them, but in the end, listening reveals more about you than the people you are trying to listen to.
es: After listening to everything, he writes: "Angry and bitter waves cut me, I almost drown." I thought it was perfect. You listen to people to be able to imagine them, you hear all the terrible and wonderful things that people do to themselves and to others, but in the end, listening drowns you even more than the people you are trying to listen to.

en: Walking through pseudovisions and trying to listen to her does not crack the Margo Roth Spiegelman case so much as it cracks me. Pages later—hearing and exposed—Whitman starts to write about all the travel he can do by imagining, and lists all the places he can visit while loafing on the grass. “My palms cover continents,” he writes.
vi: Wandering through ghost towns and trying to listen to her didn't crack the shell of Margo Roth Spiegelman as much as it cracked me. A few pages later–listening and being exposed–Whitman began to write about all the journeys he could undertake in his imagination, and listed all the places he could visit while lying peacefully on the grass. “My palm covers continents,” he wrote.
tr: Wandering through the suburbs and trying to listen to him doesn't unravel the mystery of Margo Roth Spiegelman as much as it unravels me. On the following pages, Whitman starts writing about all the travels he can imagine, hearing and exposing, and lists all the places he can go by idling on the grass. “My palms cover continents,” he writes.
es: Exploring pseudovisions and trying to listen to Margo doesn't fracture the case of Margo Roth Spiegelman as much as it fractures me. A few pages later —listening and drowning—. Whitman begins to write about the journeys he can take with his imagination, and lists all the places he can go while lying in the grass. “The palms of my hands encompass continents,” he writes.

en: I kept thinking about maps, like the way sometimes when I was a kid I would look at atlases, and just the looking was kind of like being somewhere else. This is what I had to do. I had to hear and imagine my way into her map.
vi: I still think about maps, like when I was a child, sometimes I would look at maps, and just looking at them gave me a feeling as if I were somewhere else. This is what I have to do. I have to listen and imagine my path in her map.
tr: When I was a child, I continued to think about maps in the way I sometimes looked at atlases, and even the act of looking itself was in a way like being somewhere else. This was what I needed to do. I needed to hear and imagine my way into his map.
es: I think about maps, about how as a child I would occasionally look at an atlas, and just observing it was like being somewhere else. That was what I had to do. I had to listen and imagine my way on its map.

en: But hadn’t I been trying to do that? I looked up at the maps above my computer. I had tried to plot her possible travels, but just as the grass stood for too much, so Margo stood for too much. It seemed impossible to pin her down with maps. She was too small and the space covered by the maps too big. They were more than a waste of time—they were the physical representation of the total fruitlessness of all of it, my absolute inability to develop the kinds of palms that cover continents, to have the kind of mind that correctly imagines.
vi: But hadn't I already tried to do that? I had looked at the maps hanging above my computer. I had tried to chart out the route she might take, but like the grass carrying too many metaphors, Margo also had too many. It seemed impossible to pin her down on the maps. She was too small and the space on the maps was too large. These maps were more than just a waste of time—they were the tangible manifestation of completely useless conclusions, my absolute inability to create palms that could cover continents, to have a mind that could imagine correctly.
tr: But hadn't I tried to do this? I looked at the maps on top of my computer. I had tried to chart her possible journeys, but just as grass meant too much, Margo also meant too much. It seemed impossible to pinpoint her with maps. She was very small, while the area covered by the maps was very large. The maps were much more than a waste of time... they were physical representations of my absolute inability to develop continent-spanning hands and to possess the kind of mind that imagines properly, the total inefficiency of all this.
es: But hadn't I tried? I looked up at the maps that were above the computer. I had tried to trace her possible journeys, but Margo represented too many things, like the grass. It seemed impossible to locate her on the maps. She was too small and the space covered by the maps, too large. They were more than a waste of time. They were the physical representation of the inefficacy of it all, my absolute incapacity to develop palms that could encompass continents, to have a mind that could imagine correctly.

en: I got up and walked over to the maps and tore them off the wall, the pins and tacks flying out with the paper and falling to the ground. I balled up the maps and threw them in the garbage can. On my way back to bed I stepped on a tack, like an idiot, and even though I was annoyed and exhausted and out of pseudovisions and ideas, I had to pick up all the thumbtacks scattered around the carpet so I didn’t step on them later. I just wanted to punch the wall, but I had to pick up those stupid goddamned thumbtacks. When I finished, I got back into bed and socked my pillow, my teeth clenched.
vi: I stood up, went to the maps, and tore them off the wall, the thumbtacks popping out of the paper and scattering on the floor. I crumpled the maps and threw them all into the trash can. When I returned to the bed, I stupidly stepped on a thumbtack. Even though I was angry, exhausted, and out of ideas, drained of even the ghost towns, I still had to pick up the scattered thumbtacks on the carpet to avoid stepping on them again. I just wanted to pound the wall with all my might, but I had to pick up all these damn stupid thumbtacks first. Once done, I returned to the bed, punched the pillow hard, my teeth clenched tightly.
tr: I got out of bed, walked towards the maps, and took them off the wall, pins and tacks flying out of the paper and falling to the floor. I crumpled the maps into a ball and threw them into the trash can. As I was returning to bed, like an idiot, I stepped on a tack and, annoyed, tired, drained of my energy and ideas, I had to pick up all the tacks scattered on the carpet so I wouldn't step on them later. I just wanted to punch the wall, but I had to pick up those damn stupid tacks. When I finished, I went back to bed and punched the pillow, gritting my teeth.
es: I got up, went to the maps, and pulled them down. The thumbtacks came off with the paper and fell to the floor. I crumpled the maps and threw them in the trash can. On my way back to bed, I stepped on a thumbtack, like an idiot, and although I was angry, exhausted, and had run out of pseudo-visions and ideas, I had to pick up all the thumbtacks scattered on the carpet so I wouldn't step on them later. What my body wanted was to punch the wall, but I had to pick up the damn thumbtacks. When I was done, I got back into bed and punched the pillow with clenched teeth.

en: I started trying to read the Whitman again, but between it and thinking of Margo, I felt exposed enough for this night. So finally I put the book down. I couldn’t be bothered to get up and turn off the light. I just stared at the wall, my blinks growing longer. And every time I opened my eyes, I saw where each map had been—the four holes marking the rectangle, and the pinholes seemingly randomly distributed inside the rectangle. I’d seen a similar pattern before. In the empty room above the rolled-up carpet.
vi: I tried to read Whitman again, but between the pages of the book and thoughts of Margo, I felt that tonight I had been exposed enough already. Finally, I put the book down, not even bothering to get up and turn off the light. I just stared at the wall, gradually closing my eyes for longer periods. Every time I opened my eyes, I saw the wall with maps hanging on it—four holes forming a rectangle, with pinholes scattered within that rectangle. I had seen this pattern before. In the empty room, above the rolled-up carpet.
tr: I started trying to read Whitman again, but between thinking about poetry and Margo, I've had enough exposure for tonight I was feeling it. That's why I finally put the book aside. I didn't even have the strength to get up and turn off the light. I just stared at the wall, my blinks growing longer and longer. And every time I opened my eyes, I saw where each map used to be... four holes forming a rectangle, and the pinholes seemed randomly distributed within the rectangle. I had seen a similar shape before. In the empty room, on the rolled-up carpet.
es: I tried to keep reading Whitman's book, but between reading and not stopping thinking about Margo, I felt suffocated enough for that night, so in the end, I put the book down. I didn't even bother to get up to turn off the light. I stayed staring at the wall, blinking more and more. And every time I opened my eyes, I saw the piece of wall where the maps had been, the four holes forming a rectangle, and the holes inside the rectangle, scattered randomly. I had seen a similar drawing before. In the empty room, above the carpet.

en: A map. With plotted points.

en: He called at ten. I picked him up in the minivan and then we drove to Ben’s house, figuring that a surprise attack would be the only way to wake him up. But even singing “You Are My Sunshine” outside his window only resulted in him opening the window and spitting at us. “I’m not doing anything until noon,” he said authoritatively.
vi: Radar called at ten o'clock. I drove the minivan to pick him up and then went to Ben's house, hoping that a surprise attack was the only way to wake him up. But even singing "You Are My Sunshine" at the top of our lungs outside his window only resulted in him cracking the window open and haughtily telling us, "I'm not doing anything until noon."
tr: He called at ten o'clock. I picked him up with the minivan and then, thinking that a surprise attack would be the only way to wake him up, we went to Ben's house. But singing You Are My Sunshine outside his window it only resulted in him opening the window and spitting at us. "I won't do anything until noon," he said authoritatively.
es: He called me at ten. I picked him up by car and then we went to Ben's house, because we figured the only way to wake him up was with a surprise attack. But even though we sang "You Are My Sunshine" in front of his window, all we managed to do was get him to open it and yell at us. —I don't plan to do anything until twelve —he said authoritatively.

en: So it was just Radar and me on the drive out. He talked a little about Angela and how much he liked her and how weird it was to fall in love just a few months before they would leave for different colleges, but I found it hard to listen very well. I wanted that map. I wanted to see the places she’d pinpointed. I wanted to get those tacks back into the wall.
vi: So it was just Radar and me hitting the road. He talked a little about Angela, how much he liked her, and how strange it felt that after only a few months of dating, they were going to different colleges. But I could hardly listen properly. I wanted that map. I wanted to see the places Margo had marked. I wanted to pin those thumbtacks back on the wall.
tr: In the end, I was alone in the car with Radar. Radar talked a bit about Angela, how much he liked her, and how strange it was to fall in love just a few months before going to different universities, but it was hard to listen to him properly. I wanted that map. I wanted to see the places he had marked. I wanted to pin those tacks back on the wall.
es: So Radar and I went alone. He talked to me for a while about Angela, told me that he liked her a lot and that it was weird to fall in love a few months before each of them went to a different university, but I found it hard to pay attention. I wanted that map. I wanted to see the places she had marked. I wanted to pin the tacks back on the wall.

en: We walked in through the office, hustled through the library, paused briefly to examine the holes in the bedroom wall, and entered the souvenir shop. The place didn’t scare me at all anymore. Once we’d been in each room and established we were alone, I felt as safe as I did at home. Beneath a display counter, I found the box of maps and brochures I’d rifled through on prom night. I lifted it out and balanced it on the corners of a broken glass counter. Radar sorted through them initially, looking for anything with a map, and then I unfolded them, scanning for pinholes.
vi: We entered through the office area, hurried through the library, stopped to quickly check the holes in the bedroom walls, and then went to the souvenir shop. This place no longer scared me at all. Once inside and certain that I was alone, I felt as safe as if I were at home. Under a display counter, I saw the box containing maps and travel brochures that I had rummaged through during the night of the party. I picked up the box, balancing it on the corners of a display cabinet with broken glass. Radar sifted through it first, taking out everything with maps, then I opened them up to check for any holes.
tr: We entered inside by passing through the office, hurriedly passed through the library, paused briefly to examine the holes in the wall of the bedroom, and entered the gift shop. This place no longer scared me at all. As soon as we entered each room and confirmed we were alone, I felt as safe as I did at home. Under a display counter, I found the box of maps and brochures that I had quickly glanced at on the night of the ball. I took out the box, lifted it, and balanced it on the corners of a broken glass counter. First, Radar looked through the contents one by one, searching for something related to the map, then I spread them out, hoping to see pinholes.
es: We entered the office, rushed to the library, stopped for a moment to check the holes in the wall, and entered the souvenir shop. The building no longer scared me in the slightest. As soon as we had gone through all the rooms and confirmed that we were alone, I felt as safe as I did at home. Under a display case, I found the box of maps and brochures that I had rummaged through on the night of the dance. I lifted it and leaned it against the corner of a display case with broken glass. Radar was looking for anything that had a map, and I unfolded it and checked if it had holes.

en: We were getting near the bottom of the box when Radar pulled out a black-and-white brochure entitled FIVE THOUSAND AMERICAN CITIES. It was copyrighted 1972 by the Esso company. As I carefully unfolded the map, trying to smooth the creases, I saw a pinhole in a corner. “This is it,” I said, my voice rising. There was a small rip around the pinhole, like it’d been torn off the wall. It was a yellowing, brittle, classroom-size map of the United States printed thick with potential destinations. The rips in the map told me that she had not intended this as a clue— Margo was too precise and assured with her clues to muddy the waters. Somehow or another, we’d stumbled into something she hadn’t planned, and in seeing what she hadn’t planned, I thought again of how much she had planned. And maybe, I thought, that’s what she did in the quiet dark here. Traveling while loafing, like Whitman had, as she prepared for the real thing.
vi: Near the bottom of the box, Radar lifted up a stack of black and white prints titled FIVE THOUSAND AMERICAN CITIES. Copyright 1972 by the Esso company. When carefully opening it, trying to smooth out the curled edges, I saw a pinhole in the corner. “Here it is,” I whispered excitedly. Around the pinhole, there was a small tear, looking like the paper had been ripped off the wall. It was a map of the United States, the kind you hang in a classroom, with brittle and yellowed paper, densely printed with potential destinations. The small tear in the corner told me that Margo did not intend to leave this map as a clue—she was too precise and certain with her clues to play a misleading game. Fate had led us to a part Margo had not anticipated, and seeing what she had not anticipated made me think about how much she had planned. And perhaps, I thought, that’s what she had been doing in the quiet darkness here. Wandering while sitting still, like Whitman, while preparing for what was real.
tr: We were approaching the bottom of the box when Radar pulled out a black and white brochure titled FIVE THOUSAND AMERICAN CITIES. Copyrights had belonged to the Esso company since 1972. As he carefully opened the map, trying to smooth out the wrinkles, I saw a pinhole in the corner. “Here it is,” I said, my voice rising. There was a tear around the pinhole, as if it had been ripped off a wall. It was a yellowed, thin map of the United States, the kind used in classrooms, with possible direction names written in bold letters. The tears on the map showed me that this wasn’t designed as a clue... Margo didn’t leave clues that would muddy the waters. One way or another, we had stumbled upon something she hadn’t planned, and seeing what she hadn’t planned made me think again about how much she had planned. And maybe, I thought, in this silent darkness, what she was doing here It was. Traveling while idling as he prepared for the real thing, like Whitman did.
es: We were reaching the bottom of the box when Radar pulled out a black and white pamphlet titled FIVE THOUSAND AMERICAN CITIES. The copyright was from 1972, by the Esso company. As he carefully unfolded the map and tried to smooth out the creases, I saw a hole in the corner. "It's this one," I said, raising my voice. Next to the hole there was a torn piece, as if they had ripped the map off the wall. It was a yellowed and brittle map of the United States, the kind you find in classrooms, marked with possible destinations. From the creases in the map, I understood that Margo hadn't intended it to be a clue. She was too precise and sure with her clues to muddy the waters. In any case, we had found something she hadn't anticipated, and seeing what she hadn't anticipated, I thought again that she had anticipated many things. And I thought that maybe that was what she had done in that dark and silent room. Traveling while lying down, like Whitman, as she prepared for what she was really going to do.

en: I ran all the way back to the office and found a bunch of thumbtacks in a desk adjacent to Margo’s, before Radar and I carefully carried the unfurled map back to Margo’s room. I held it up against the wall while Radar tried to get the tacks into the corners, but three of the four corners had ripped, as had three of the five locations, presumably when the map was taken off the wall. “Higher and to the left,” he said. “No, down. Yeah. Don’t move.” Finally we got the map on the wall, and then we started lining up the holes in the map with the ones on the wall. We got all five pins in pretty easily. But some of these pinholes were also ripped, so it was impossible to tell their EXACT location. And exact location mattered in a map blackened with the names of five thousand places. The lettering was so small and exact that I had to stand up on the carpet and put my bare eyeballs inches away from the map even to guess each location. As I suggested town names, Radar pulled out his handheld and looked them up on Omnictionary.
vi: I ran straight to the office and saw a handful of push pins on the table next to Margo's desk. Then Radar and I carefully carried the flattened map to Margo's room. I held it up against the wall while Radar tried to pin the corners, but three out of the four corners were torn, as were three out of the five points on the map, likely torn when the map was removed from the wall. "Higher, to the left," Radar said. "No, down. There. Don't move." Finally, we had the map on the wall. We aligned the holes in the paper with the holes in the wall, and the five push pins easily went into place. But some holes on the map were torn too large to determine the EXACT position. And exact positioning is very valuable on a map densely packed with five thousand place names. The tiny, densely packed letters required me to stand on the rolled-up carpet and press my eyes close to guess each place name. While I read the city names aloud, Radar took out a handheld calculator and looked them up in the Everything Encyclopedia.
tr: I ran to the office and found a few thumbtacks on a desk close to Margo's before carefully carrying the map opened with Radar back to Margo's room. While Radar tried to place the thumbtacks in the corners, I lifted the map and stuck it to the wall, but probably three of the four corners were torn when the map was removed from the wall, as were three of the five marked places. "Higher and to the left," said Radar. "No, lower. Yes. Don't move." Finally, the map was on the wall, and then we started aligning the holes on the map with those on the wall. We placed all five pins quite easily. But a few of the pinholes were also torn, so it was impossible to determine their EXACT locations. And exact location mattered on a map darkened with the names of five thousand places. The letters were so small and thin that even to guess each location, I had to get on the carpet and bring my eyeball within a few centimeters of the map. While I threw out city names, Radar took out his handheld computer and looked up these names on Omnictionary.
es: I returned to the office and found a handful of thumbtacks on a table next to Margo's. Then Radar and I carefully carried the unfolded map to Margo's room. I held it against the wall while Radar tried to insert the thumbtacks into the holes, but three of the four corners had broken, as well as three of the five locations, probably from removing the map from the wall. —Higher up and to the left —Radar told me—. No, lower. Yes. Don't move. We finally pinned the map and started aligning the holes in the map with those on the wall. It didn't take us too long to assemble the five points. But, since some holes were torn, it was impossible to determine the EXACT location. And the exact location was important on a map that showed the names of five thousand towns. The lettering was so small that I had to get on the carpet and bring my eyes a few centimeters from the map to try to identify each town. I started saying names, and Radar took out his pocket computer and looked them up on the Omnictionary.

en: There were two unripped dots: one looked like Los Angeles, although there were a bunch of towns clustered so close together in Southern California that the type overlapped. The other unripped hole was over Chicago. There was a ripped one in New York that, judging from the location of the hole in the wall, was one of the five boroughs of New York City.
vi: There are two pinholes that are not torn: one seems to be Los Angeles, although there are a multitude of cities clustered together in Southern California, causing the print to overlap. Another intact pinhole is above Chicago. A torn pinhole in New York, based on the position of the hole on the wall, is in one of the five boroughs of New York City.
tr: There were two intact points: One looked like Los Angeles, but in Southern California, the cities were so closely clustered that the writings overlapped. The other intact spot was towards Chicago. There was a torn spot in New York; judging by the position of the hole on the wall, it was one of New York's five boroughs.
es: There were two holes without tears. One seemed to be Los Angeles, although in Southern California there were so many cities together that the names overlapped. The other intact hole was in Chicago. There was a torn one in New York, which, judging by its position on the wall, corresponded to one of the city's five boroughs.

en: “That makes sense with what we know.”
vi: “Matches with what we already know.”
tr: "With the information we have, this makes sense."
es: —It fits with what we know.

en: “Yeah,” I said. “But God, where in New York? That’s the question.”
vi: “Yes,” I said. “But my God, where in New York is this? That’s the problem.”
tr: “Yes,” I said. “But my God, where in New York? That’s the question.”
es: —Yes —I told him—. But, damn, which part of New York? That's the question.

en: “We’re missing something,” he says. “Some locational hint. What’re the other dots?”
vi: “We are missing something,” Radar said. “Some clue about the location. What are the remaining pinholes?”
tr: “We are missing something,” he said. “A clue about the location. What are the other points?”
es: —We missed something —he replied—. Some clue. Where are the other points?

en: “There’s another in New York State, but not near the city. I mean, look, all the towns are tiny. It might be Poughkeepsie or Woodstock or the Catskill Park.”
vi: "Another one in New York State, but not near the city." "You see, all the places are tiny." "It could be Poughkeepsie or Woodstock or Catskill Park."
tr: "There is one more in the State of New York, but it is not close to the city. I mean, look, all the towns are tiny. It could be Poughkeepsie, Woodstock, or Catskill Park."
es: —There is another one in the state of New York, but it is not near the city. Well, look, all the cities are tiny. It could be Poughkeepsie, Woodstock, or the Catskill park.

en: “Woodstock,” Radar said. “That’d be interesting. She’s not much of a hippie, but she has that whole free-spirit vibe.”
vi: “Woodstock,” Radar said. “This place is cool. Margo doesn't seem like a hippie, but she has the spirit of a free soul.”
tr: “Woodstock,” said Radar. “It would be interesting. Margo is not much of a hippie, but all that free spirit stuff suits her.”
es: —Woodstock —said Radar—. It would be interesting. Margo isn't very hippy, but she has that free spirit vibe.

en: “I don’t know,” I said. “The last one is either Washington, D.C., or else maybe Annapolis or Chesapeake Bay. That one could be a bunch of things, actually.”
vi: “I don't know,” I said. “The final point could be Washington, D.C., or Annapolis, or Chesapeake Bay. Actually, this point could be endless.”
tr: “I don't know,” I said. “The last one is either Washington D. C., or Annapolis or Chesapeake Bay. It could actually be one of many places.”
es: —I don't know —I replied—. The last one is in the city of Washington or maybe in Annapolis or the Chesapeake Bay. Actually, it could be in a bunch of places.

en: “It’d be helpful if there was only one point on the map,” Radar said sullenly.
vi: “It would be more useful if there was only one point on the map,” Radar snapped.
tr: "It would be good if there was only one point on the map," said Radar with a sullen face.
es: —It would help a bit if there was only one point on the map —said Radar in a somber tone.

en: “But she’s probably going from place to place,” I said. Tramping her perpetual journey.
vi: “But who knows if Margo wants to go from one place to another,” I said. Immersing herself in her endless journey.
tr: “But he is probably going from one place to another,” I said. Slowly progressing on his eternal journey.
es: —But surely he goes from one place to another —I told him. Embarking on his eternal journey.

en: I sat on the carpet for a while as Radar read to me more about New York, about the Catskill Mountains, about the nation’s capital, about the concert at Woodstock in 1969. Nothing seemed to help. I felt as if we’d played out the string and found nothing.
vi: I sat down on the carpet for a while as Radar read aloud information about New York, the Catskill Mountains, the capital, the Woodstock concert in 1969. It seemed like nothing was related. I felt like we were following a thread and finding nothing.
tr: Radar, while I was reading something about New York, the Catskill Mountains, national capital, the festival in Woodstock in 1969, I sat on the carpet for a while. Nothing seemed to help. I felt as if we had pulled all the strings but found nothing.
es: I sat for a while on the carpet while Radar read me information about New York, about the Catskill Mountains, about the capital of the country, and about the 1969 concert in Woodstock. Nothing seemed to help. I felt as if we had pulled the thread and found nothing.

en: After I dropped Radar off that afternoon, I sat around the house reading “Song of Myself” and halfheartedly studying for finals.
vi: That afternoon, after bringing Radar home, I sat around the house reading "Autobiography," half-focused on studying for exams.
tr: After dropping off Radar that afternoon, I sat around the house aimlessly, singing My Own Song and reluctantly studying for exams.
es: That afternoon, after dropping Radar off at his house, I sat down to read "Song of Myself" and study without much enthusiasm for the final exams.

en: I had calc and Latin on Monday, probably my two toughest subjects, and I couldn’t afford to ignore them completely. I studied most of Saturday night and throughout the day Sunday, but then a Margo idea popped into my head just after dinner, so I took a break from practicing Ovid translations and logged onto IM. I saw Lacey online. I’d only just gotten her screen name from Ben, but I figured I knew her well enough to IM her.
vi: Monday's exams were calculus and Latin, probably the two hardest subjects, so I couldn't completely neglect them. I studied almost all of Saturday night and all day Sunday, but just after dinner, thoughts of Margo suddenly popped into my head. I temporarily set aside my Ovid translation exercises and logged into online messaging. Lacey was online. I had just learned Lacey's online nickname through Ben, but I figured Lacey and I were familiar enough for me to send her a direct message right away.
tr: On Monday, I had exams in math and Latin; I think they were my two hardest subjects, and it was impossible to completely ignore them. I studied for most of Saturday night and throughout Sunday morning, but then, just after dinner, a sudden idea about Margo popped into my head, so I stopped working on Ovid translations and logged into the chat program. I saw that Lacey was online. I had just recently learned her username from Ben, but I thought we were now friends enough to message her.
es: On Monday, I had calculus and Latin, probably the two toughest subjects, so I couldn't afford to completely overlook them. I studied almost all Saturday night and Sunday, but right after dinner, an idea occurred to me. I set aside Ovid's translations for a moment and turned on the computer. I saw Lacey was online. I had just found out her nickname from Ben, but I figured I knew her well enough to write her a message.

en: I studied at my desk and waited for other people to come online. Ben did after a while, and I invited him into a chat room with me and Lacey. They did most of the talking—I was still sort of translating—until Radar logged in and joined the room. Then I put down my pencil for the night.
vi: I sat studying and waiting for the others to come online. A while later, Ben appeared, and I invited him into the chat room with me and Lacey. The two of them mostly talked to each other—I was still halfway through translating—until Radar logged in and joined us. At that point, I put down my pen and stopped studying.
tr: I studied in my room and waited for the others to come online. After a while, Ben came online, and I invited him to the chat room where Lacey and I were. They did most of the talking; I was still more or less translating until Radar logged in and joined the room. Then I put down my pen for the night.
es: I continued studying at my desk and waited for someone else to log in. After a while, Ben joined, and I invited him to a chat room with me and Lacey. The two of them talked almost the entire time —I kept translating— until Radar logged in and I invited him to the room. Then I stopped studying for the night.
