es: ITWASAKIDNEYINFECTION: I'm sorry, but I am completely right.

en: They went on like that, talking about their Margos, as I tried to map her route. If she hadn’t intended the map as a clue—and the ripped tack holes told me she hadn’t—I figured we’d gotten all the clues she’d intended for us and now much more. Surely I had what I needed, then. But I still felt very far away from her.
vi: They just kept going like that, talking to each other about their Margo, while I tried to map out her route. If Margo did not intend for the map to be a clue—and the torn holes on the map indicated that she did not—I concluded that we had all the clues she intentionally left behind, and now we had even more. So surely I had what I needed. But why did I still feel so distant from Margo.
tr: While I was trying to map out Ben's route, they continued talking about their own Margo like that. If he hadn't designated the map as a clue and the torn holes showed me he hadn't, I thought we had all the clues he designed for us and even more. Then I definitely had what I needed. But I still felt very far away from her.
es: They continued like this, chatting about their Margos, while I tried to trace their route. If he didn't intend for the map to be a clue —and the torn holes seemed to indicate he didn't—, I supposed we had all the clues he had anticipated and much more. Without a doubt, I had what I needed. But I still felt very far from her.

en: After three long hours alone with eight hundred words from Ovid on Monday morning, I walked through the halls feeling as if my brain might drip out of my ears. But I’d done okay. We had an hour and a half for lunch, to give our minds time to firm back up before the second exam period of the day. Radar was waiting for me at my locker.
vi: After three hours alone with eight hundred words of Ovid on Monday morning, I walked down the hallway, feeling like my brain was about to drip out of my ears. But I did fine on the test. We had an hour and a half for lunch, to give our brains time to solidify again before the second exam of the day. Radar was waiting in front of my locker.
tr: On Monday morning, after three long and lonely hours spent on eight hundred words of Ovid, feeling as if my brain was about to ooze out of my ears, I wandered the corridors. But it had gone well. We had an hour and a half for lunch and for our minds to solidify again before the second exam of the day. Radar was waiting for me at my locker.
es: On Monday morning, after three long hours alone with eight hundred words of Ovid, I crossed the hallways with the feeling that my brain was going to spill out of my ears. But I had done well. We had an hour and a half to eat and clear our heads before the second round of exams. Radar was waiting for me at my locker.

en: “I just bombed me some Spanish,” Radar said.
vi: “I just bombed myself in Spanish,” Radar said.
tr: “I just bombarded myself with Spanish.”
es: —I just failed Spanish —he told me.

en: “I’m sure you did okay.” He was going to Dartmouth on a huge scholarship. He was plenty smart.
vi: “You will definitely do well.” He will go to Dartmouth on a huge scholarship. Radar is more than smart enough.
tr: “I'm sure it went well.” He was going to Dartmouth with an enormous scholarship. He was very intelligent.
es: —I'm sure it went well for you. Radar had a good scholarship for Dartmouth. He was very intelligent.

en: “Dude, I don’t know. I kept falling asleep during the oral part. But listen, I was up half the night building this program. It’s so awesome. What it does is it allows you to enter a category—it can be a geographical area or like a family in the animal kingdom— and then you can read the first sentences of up to a hundred Omnictionary articles about your topic on a single page. So, like, say you are trying to find a particular kind of rabbit but can’t remember its name. You can read an introduction to all twenty-one species of rabbits on the same page in, like, three minutes.”
vi: “I don't know either, sir. I was dozing off during the oral exam. But hey, I stayed up until midnight to write this program. It's pretty neat. It allows you to enter an entry—maybe a geographical region or some animal genus—and then you can read the first sentences of about a hundred articles in the Encyclopedia of Everything on the subject you need, all on a single page. For example, you're looking for a certain type of rabbit but can't remember the exact name. You can read the introductions of all twenty-one rabbit species on the same page, in, let's see, three minutes.”
tr: “Dude, I don't know. I kept falling asleep during the oral part. But look, I stayed up almost all night to set up this program. It's an amazing thing. What it does is this: It allows you to enter a category—it could be a geographic area or a species in the animal kingdom or something—and then you can read the first sentences of a hundred Omnictionary articles related to the category you're looking for on a single page. So, like, let's say you're trying to find a specific type of rabbit but you can't remember its name. In about three minutes or so, you can read the entries of all twenty-one types of rabbits on the same page.”
es: —Uncle, I don't know. I almost fell asleep during the oral exam. But it's because I spent half the night awake working on a program. It's incredible. You type in a category (it can be either a geographical area or an animal species) and then you can read on a single page the first lines of about a hundred Omnictionary articles related to that topic. Let's say you're looking for a specific species of rabbit, but you can't remember the name. You can read the introduction of the twenty-one species of rabbit on the same page in three minutes.

en: “You did this the night before finals?” I asked.
vi: "Are you doing this the night before the exam?" I asked.
tr: “Did you do this the night before the finals?” I asked.
es: —Did you make that program the night before the final exams? —I asked him.

en: “Yeah, I know, right? Anyway I’ll email it to you. It’s nerd-tastic.”
vi: “Yeah, I know, so what? But I'll send it to you via email. This game is really mind-bending.”
tr: “Yes, yes I know. Anyway, I will send it to you by email. It's a very nerdy thing.”
es: —Yes, I already know, okay? Alright, I'll send it to you by mail. It's a geeky thing.

en: Ben showed up then. “I swear to God, Q, Lacey and I were up on IM until two o’clock in the morning playing on that site, the-longwayround? And having now plotted every single possible trip that Margo could have taken between Orlando and those five points, I realize I was wrong all this time. She’s not in Orlando. Radar’s right. She’s coming back here for graduation day.”
vi: Ben appeared. "Q, I swear to God, Lacey and I were online until two in the morning, messing around with that duongdaivongquanh site. After checking every route Margo could take from Orlando to those five points, I concluded that I had been completely wrong from the start. Margo is not in Orlando. Radar was right. She will come back on graduation day."
tr: At that moment, Ben appeared. ‘I swear, Q, Lacey and I were playing on that site and hanging out on the chat program until two in the morning, that On the uzunyoldan site? When I identified every possible trip Margo could have taken between these five points with Orlando, I realized that I had been wrong all this time. She is not in Orlando. Radar is right. She will come back here for graduation day.”
es: Then Ben appeared. —Q, I swear to God that Lacey and I were on the chat until two in the morning tangled up with the page you gave us. And now that we have mapped out all the routes Margo could have taken between Orlando and those five points, I realize that I have been wrong all along. She is not in Orlando. Radar is right. She will come back for graduation.

en: “Why?”
vi: "Why?"
tr: “Why?”
es: —Why?

en: “The timing is perfect. To drive from Orlando to New York to the mountains to Chicago to Los Angeles back to Orlando is like exactly a twenty-three-day trip. Plus, it’s a totally retarded joke, but it’s a Margo joke. You make everyone think you offed yourself. Surround yourself with an air of mystery so that everyone pays attention. And then right as all the attention starts to go away, you show up at graduation.”
vi: “The perfect timing. Driving from Orlando to New York to the mountains to Chicago to Los Angeles and then back to Orlando is exactly a twenty-three-day trip. Moreover, this trick is really deep, but that's Margo's style. Making everyone believe that she's gone. Creating a mysterious smoke screen, hiding herself in it so that everyone has to pay attention. And then when the attention starts to fade, suddenly showing up at graduation.”
tr: “The timing is perfect. Driving from Orlando to New York, to the mountains, to Chicago, to Los Angeles, and back to Orlando is exactly a twenty-three-day journey. This is really a lame joke but a Margo joke. Surround yourself with an air of mystery so everyone pays attention. Then, just as all the attention starts to fade, show up at graduation.”
es: —It is perfectly timed. Driving from Orlando to New York, to the mountains of Chicago, to Los Angeles and back to Orlando takes exactly twenty-three days. Besides, it’s a crazy joke, but it’s Margo’s thing. You make everyone think you’ve disappeared. You surround yourself with an aura of mystery so that everyone pays attention to you. And just when the interest starts to fade, you show up at graduation.

en: “No,” I said. “No way.” I knew Margo better than that by now. She did want attention. I believed that. But Margo didn’t play life for laughs. She didn’t get off on mere trickery.
vi: “No,” I said. “No way.” Now I understand Margo better. She wants to be noticed. I believe so. But Margo doesn't joke with life to have fun. She didn't leave just to play a prank like that.
tr: “No,” I said. “It's not possible.” By now, I had known Margo better than this. She wanted attention. I believed that. But Margo wouldn't play with life just for fun. She didn't take pleasure in sheer trickery.
es: —No —I said—. Impossible. I already knew Margo better. I did believe that she liked to attract attention, but Margo did not take life lightly. She hadn't disappeared to deceive us.

en: “I’m telling you, bro. Look for her at graduation. She’s gonna be there.” I just shook my head. Since everyone had the same lunch period, the cafeteria was beyond packed, so we exercised our rights as seniors and drove to Wendy’s. I tried to stay focused on my coming calc exam, but I was starting to feel like maybe there was more string to the story. If Ben was right about the twenty-three-day trip, that was very interesting, indeed. Maybe that’s what she’d been planning in her black notebook, a long and lonesome road trip. It didn’t explain everything, but it did fit with Margo as a planner. Not that this brought me closer to her. As hard as it is to pinpoint a dot inside a ripped segment of a map, it only becomes harder when the dot is moving.
vi: "Hey buddy, I'm talking to you." "Find Margo at that graduation ceremony." "She will show up, you'll see." I just shook my head. Everyone had lunch at the same time, so the cafeteria was packed, and we exercised our senior privilege by driving to Wendy's for ice cream. Trying to focus on the upcoming calculus exam, but I started to feel like the story needed more connections. If Ben was right about the twenty-three-day journey, that would indeed be very interesting. Maybe that's what Margo had planned in her black notebook, a long and solitary road trip. That doesn't explain everything, but it fits with a Margo who likes to plan. That doesn't mean it brings me any closer to her. Identifying a dot on a torn map was hard enough; when the dot moves, it's even harder.
tr: “I’m telling you, my brother. Call her at graduation. She will be there.” I just nodded. Since everyone had the same lunch break, the cafeteria was beyond packed, so as seniors, we used our privilege and drove to Wendy’s. I tried to focus on my upcoming math exam, but I started to feel like there were more threads in the story. If Ben was right about the twenty-three-day trip, this was really interesting. Maybe this was what he had planned in his black notebook, a long and lonely trip. It didn’t explain everything, but it fit Margo as a planner. Of course, this didn’t bring me any closer to her. It’s hard to pinpoint a spot on a torn map; moreover, if this spot is also moving, it becomes even harder to pinpoint.
es: —I'm telling you, buddy. Look for her at the graduation. She'll be there. I shook my head. Since everyone had the same lunch hour, the cafeteria was packed, so we exercised our right as seniors and drove to Wendy’s. I tried to focus on the calculus exam, but I started to feel that the story had more threads. If Ben was right about the twenty-three days of travel, the fact was certainly interesting. Maybe it was what he had planned in his black notebook, a long and lonely road trip. It didn’t explain everything, but it fit with Margo’s planning nature. And it didn’t bring me any closer to her. It was already hard enough to locate a point on a crumpled piece of map without the point moving.

en: After a long day of finals, returning to the comfortable impenetrability of “Song of Myself” was almost a relief. I had reached a weird part of the poem—after all this time listening and hearing people, and then traveling alongside them, Whitman stops hearing and he stops visiting, and he starts to become other people. Like, actually inhabit them. He tells the story of a ship’s captain who saved everyone on his boat except himself. The poet can tell the story, he argues, because he has become the captain. As he writes, “I am the man . . . . I suffered . . . . I was there.” A few lines later, it becomes even more clear that Whitman no longer needs to listen to become another: “I do not ask the wounded person how he feels . . . . I myself become the wounded person.”
vi: After a long day full of exams, returning to the pleasant inviolability of "Tự khúc" is almost a light relief. I read a very strange passage of the poem—after all the time listening and hearing people, then wandering with them, Whitman no longer listens and no longer wanders, he begins to become other people. As if truly being inside them. He tells the story of the captain of a ship who saved everyone on board, except himself. Whitman says that the poet can tell the story because he has become that captain. When he writes, "I am that man... I endure... I was there." A few lines later, it becomes even clearer that Whitman no longer needs to listen to become someone else: "I do not ask the wounded person how he feels... I myself become the wounded person."
tr: After a long exam day, returning to the peaceful incomprehensibility of My Own Song was almost comforting. I had reached a strange part of the poem... After spending so much time hearing, listening to, and wandering among people, Whitman hearing and stops visiting and starts becoming other people. As if he were living inside them. He tells the story of a captain who saved everyone on his ship except himself. The poet says he can tell the story because he is the captain. “I am that man... I suffered... I was there,” he writes. A few lines later, it becomes even clearer that Whitman no longer needs to listen to become others: “I do not ask the wounded person how he feels... I myself become the wounded person.”
es: After a long day of final exams, returning to the comfortable seclusion of "Song of Myself" was almost a relief. I had reached a strange part of the poem. After having been listening to and hearing people, and traveling with them, Whitman stops listening and traveling and starts becoming other people. As if he inhabited them. He tells the story of a ship captain who saved everyone except himself. The poet says he can tell that story because he has become the captain. And he writes: "I am the man, I suffered, I was there." A few verses later it becomes even clearer that Whitman no longer needs to listen to become another person: "I do not ask the wounded how he feels, I am the wounded."

en: I put the book down and lay on my side, staring out the window that had always been between us. It is not enough just to see her or hear her. To find Margo Roth Spiegelman, you must become Margo Roth Spiegelman.
vi: I put the book down and lay on my side, looking out the window that had always been between me and her. Just seeing or hearing her was not enough. To find Margo Roth Spiegelman, one must become Margo Roth Spiegelman.
tr: I put the book aside and turn sideways to look outside through the window that has always been between us. It is not enough to just see or hear her. To find Margo Roth Spiegelman, you must become Margo Roth Spiegelman.
es: I put down the book and lay on my side, looking through the window that had always been between us. It's not enough to see her or hear her. To find Margo Roth Spiegelman, you have to become Margo Roth Spiegelman.

en: And I had done many of the things she might have done: I had engineered a most unlikely prom coupling. I had quieted the hounds of caste warfare. I had come to feel comfortable inside the rat-infested haunted house where she did her best thinking. I had seen. I had listened. But I could not yet become the wounded person.
vi: I did many things she might have done: I created a pair least likely to attend a gala together. I silenced the hounds of the class war. I was naturally comfortable in the haunted house where the rats reigned supreme, where she had done most of her thinking. I saw. I listened. But I have yet to become the bearer of the wound.
tr: And I had done many of the things he might have done: I had arranged an impossible ballroom couple. I had silenced the dogs of social class warfare. I had managed to feel comfortable in the haunted house infested with mice, where my thinking action was at its best. I had seen. I had listened. But I had not yet become that wounded person.
es: And I had done many of the things that perhaps she had done. I had managed to unite the most unlikely couple at the dance. I had silenced the dogs of the caste war. I had managed to feel comfortable in the haunted, rat-filled house where Margo had planned everything. I had seen. I had listened. But I still couldn't become the wounded person.

en: I limped through my physics and government finals the next day and then stayed up till 2 A.M. on Tuesday finishing my final reaction paper for English about Moby Dick. Ahab was a hero, I decided. I had no particular reason for having decided this—particularly given that I hadn’t read the book—but I decided it and reacted thusly.
vi: The next day, I was sluggish throughout the physics exam and the government and politics class, then on Tuesday stayed up until 2 AM to finish the final essay for the National Language subject, about Moby Dick. Ahab is a hero, I have decided that. There is no particular reason for this decision—especially since I haven't read the book—but I have decided it and just went on writing.
tr: The next day, I barely passed my physics and politics exams, and then I stayed up until two in the morning to finish my final assignment on Moby Dick for literature. I decided that Ahab was a hero. I had no particular reason for this decision—especially considering I hadn't read the book—but I made the decision and reacted accordingly.
es: The next day I did the physics and politics exams as best as I could, and on Tuesday I stayed up until two in the morning finishing the end-of-course literature paper on Moby Dick. I decided that Ahab was a hero. I had no particular reason for making that decision—especially considering that I hadn't read the book—but I decided it and acted accordingly.

en: The abbreviated exam week meant that Wednesday was the last day of school for us. And all day long, it was hard not to walk around thinking about the lastness of it all: The last time I stand in a circle outside the band room in the shade of this oak tree that has protected generations of band geeks. The last time I eat pizza in the cafeteria with Ben. The last time I sit in this school scrawling an essay with a cramped hand into a blue book. The last time I glance up at the clock. The last time I see Chuck Parson prowling the halls, his smile half a sneer. God. I was becoming nostalgic for Chuck Parson. Something sick was happening inside of me.
vi: The shortened exam week means that Wednesday is our last day at school. Throughout that day, it was hard not to wander around, thinking about all the lasts: The last time standing with the group in a circle outside the music room, under the oak tree that has sheltered generations of talented musicians. The last time eating pizza in the cafeteria with Ben. The last time sitting in this school, one hand hurriedly writing an essay, the other hand wedged between the pages of a blue book. The last time glancing at the clock. The last time seeing Chuck Parson trudging through the hallway, with a fleetingly disdainful and nonchalant smile. Oh my. I'm starting to feel nostalgic about Chuck Parson, of all people. Some kind of illness must be taking over me.
tr: The shortened exam week meant that Wednesday was our last day of school. And all day, it was hard not to think about the finality of it all: in front of the band room, under the shade of that oak tree that had sheltered generations of band geeks, my last stand in a circle. My last pizza with Ben in the cafeteria. My last scribbled essay in a blue notebook, sitting in this school with my clenched hand. My last glance at the clock. Chuck Parson’s partially scornful smile as he patrolled the hallways for the last time. my view. My God. I was longing for Chuck Parson. Something sickly was happening inside me.
es: The shortened exam week meant that Wednesday was our last day of class. And throughout the day, I found it difficult not to wander around thinking about everything I was doing for the last time. The last time forming a circle by the rehearsal room door, in the shade of the oak tree that has sheltered generations of band geeks. The last time eating pizza in the cafeteria with Ben. The last time sitting in that high school writing a paper with one hand tucked into a blue book. The last time looking at the clock. The last time seeing Chuck Parson lurking in the hallways with a half-contemptuous smile. Damn. I was starting to feel nostalgic for Chuck Parson. I must have been sick.

en: It must have been like this for Margo, too. With all the planning she’d done, she must have known she was leaving, and even she couldn’t have been totally immune to the feeling. She’d had good days here. And on the last day, the bad days become so difficult to recall, because one way or another, she had made a life here, just as I had. The town was paper, but the memories were not. All the things I’d done here, all the love and pity and compassion and violence and spite, kept welling up inside me. These whitewashed cinder-block walls. My white walls. Margo’s white walls. We’d been captive in them for so long, stuck in their belly like Jonah.
vi: For Margo, it must have been the same. With all the time spent planning, she must have known she was going to leave, even though she wasn't entirely immune to emotions. She had some beautiful days here. In the final moments, it was hard to recall the bad days, because in one way or another, she had spent part of her life in this place, just like I did. This city is paper, but the memories are not. Everything I did here, all the affection, sorrow, compassion, cruelty, and malice, it's all filling up inside me. The white-painted honeycomb walls. My white walls. Margo's white walls. We had been trapped between those walls for too long, stuck in its belly like Jonah was stuck in the belly of the whale.
tr: It must have been the same for Margo. According to all the planning she did, she must have known she was going to leave, and even she wasn't completely devoid of emotions. She had had good days here. On one's last day, it becomes very difficult to remember the bad days because, one way or another, she too had built a life here just like I did. The city was made of paper, but the memories were not. Everything I did here, all that love, compassion, tenderness, violence, and hatred, continued to accumulate inside me. These whitewashed concrete walls. My white walls. Margo's white walls. We had been trapped among them for so long that we were stuck in their stomachs like Jonah.
es: Something like that Margo must have felt too. While she was making her plans, she undoubtedly knew she would leave, and surely even she couldn't be completely immune to that feeling. She had had good times at that school. And on the last day, it's very hard to remember the bad times, because in any case, she had made her life there, just like I did. The city was paper, but the memories were not. Everything she had done there, all the love, the sorrow, the compassion, the violence, and the resentment kept flowing from within me. Those whitewashed concrete walls. My white walls. Margo's white walls. For a long time, we had been captives within them, trapped in their stomach, like Jonah.

en: Throughout the day, I found myself thinking that maybe this feeling was why she’d planned everything so intricately and precisely: even if you want to leave, it is so hard. It took preparation, and maybe sitting in that minimall scrawling her plans was both intellectual and emotional practice—Margo’s way of imagining herself into her fate.
vi: All day long, I had thought that perhaps this emotion was the reason why she planned everything so meticulously and precisely: even if you want to go, leaving is still very difficult. It needs to be prepared, and perhaps sitting down to plan in that abandoned shopping mall was both an intellectual and emotional task—the way Margo envisioned herself embarking on her destiny.
tr: Throughout the day, I found myself thinking that perhaps this was the reason Margo planned everything so meticulously and precisely: Even if you wanted to leave, it was so difficult. You had to prepare, and maybe sitting in the shopping mall scribbling my plans was both a mental and emotional exercise... A way to imagine Margo living out her destiny.
es: Throughout the day, I found myself thinking that perhaps that feeling was the reason why Margo had planned everything so complexly and precisely. Even if you want to leave, it is very difficult. It required preparation, and perhaps sitting in that shopping mall to write her plans was both an intellectual and emotional task, her way of imagining herself at her destination.

en: Ben and Radar both had a marathon band practice to make sure they would rock “Pomp and Circumstance” at graduation. Lacey offered me a ride, but I decided to clean out my locker, because I didn’t really want to come back here and again have to feel like my lungs were drowning in this perverse nostalgia.
vi: Ben and Radar practiced music tirelessly to ensure that they would make everyone rock during the "Pomp and Circumstance" march at the graduation ceremony. Lacey said she could give me a ride home, but I decided to clean out my locker because I didn't want to come back to school and feel my lungs drowning in the stubborn nostalgia that surged up.
tr: Both Ben and Radar had a long band rehearsal to ensure they could play the Pomp and Circumstance march properly at graduation. Lacey offered to drive me, but I decided to clean out my locker because I really didn't want to have to come back here later and feel my lungs choking with this perverse longing.
es: Ben and Radar had a marathon rehearsal with the band to make sure they would play "Pomp and Circumstance" at graduation. Lacey offered to take me home, but I decided to empty my locker, because the truth was that I didn't feel like going back to the school and having to feel my lungs drowning in that stubborn nostalgia again.

en: My locker was an unadulterated crap hole—half trash can, half book storage. Her locker had been neatly stacked with textbooks when Lacey opened it, I remembered, as if she intended to come to school the next day. I pulled a garbage can over to the bank of lockers and opened mine up. I began by pulling off a picture of Radar and Ben and me goofing off. I put it inside my backpack and then started the disgusting process of picking through a year’s worth of accumulated filth—gum wrapped in scraps of notebook paper, pens out of ink, greasy napkins—and scraping it all into the garbage. All along, I kept thinking, I will never do this again, I will never be here again, this will never be my locker again, Radar and I will never write notes in calculus again, I will never see Margo across the hall again. This was the first time in my life that so many things would never happen again.
vi: My locker is purely a chaotic mess–half filled with trash, half filled with books. Margo's locker was still neatly organized when Lacey opened it, I still remember, as if Margo planned to return to school the very next day. I pulled the trash can closer to the row of lockers and opened mine. I started with a photo of Radar, Ben, and me, the three of us lazily staring blankly. I put the photo into my backpack, then began the horrifying process of picking out all the filthy things accumulated over the year–wads of gum wrapped in torn notebook paper, countless empty pens, grease-stained tissues–I tossed them all into the trash can. All the while, I kept thinking, I will never do this again, I will never be here again, this will never be my locker again, Radar and I will never pass notes in calculus again, I will never see Margo walking in the hallway again. For the first time in my life, there were so many things that would never happen again.
tr: My locker was a pure junk nest... partly a trash can, partly a book depot. I remembered that when Lacey opened it, Margo's textbooks were neatly arranged in her locker, as if she intended to come to school the next day. I pulled a trash can next to the row of lockers and opened mine, starting to take out the contents with a photo of Radar, Ben, and me goofing around. I put the photo in my backpack, then the filth that had accumulated over a year, notebook Gums wrapped in pieces of paper, pens with no ink, greasy napkins—I began the disgusting process of scraping them into the trash. From the beginning, I kept thinking: I will never do this again, I will never be here again, this will never be my locker again, I will never write notes in math with Radar again, I will never see Margo from the other side of the hallway again. This was the first time in my life that many things would never happen again.
es: My locker was a real shithole, half trash can and half book storage. I remembered that when Lacey opened Margo's locker, the books were perfectly stacked, as if she intended to go to class the next day. I placed a trash can on the bench and opened my locker. The first thing I did was peel off a photo of Radar, Ben, and me grinning from ear to ear. I put it in my backpack and started the disgusting process of rummaging through the junk accumulated over the whole year—gum wrapped in pieces of notebook paper, pens without ink, greasy napkins—and throwing it into the trash can. As I did so, I thought: "I will never do this again, I will never be here again, this locker will never be mine again, Radar and I will never write notes to each other in calculus class again, I will never see Margo in the hallway again." It was the first time in my life that so many things would never happen again.

en: And finally it was too much. I could not talk myself down from the feeling, and the feeling became unbearable. I reached in deep to the recesses of my locker. I pushed everything—photographs and notes and books—into the trash can. I left the locker open and walked away. As I walked past the band room, I could hear through the walls the muffled sounds of “Pomp and Circumstance.” I kept walking. It was hot outside, but not as hot as usual. It was bearable. There are sidewalks most of the way home, I thought. So I kept walking.
vi: And finally, it was too much. I couldn't control the flow of emotions, and the feelings became unbearable. I delved deep into the drawer, pulling out everything—photos, notes, and books—and swept them all into the trash. I left the drawer open and walked away. Passing by the music room, I heard the song "Pomp and Circumstance" muffled through the walls. I kept walking. Outside, it was hot, but not as hot as usual. Bearable. The way home was mostly sidewalk, I thought. So I kept walking.
tr: And in the end, it was too much. I couldn't overcome this feeling and it became unbearable. I reached into the depths, the insides of my closet. I threw everything—photos, notes, books—into the trash can. I left the closet open and walked away. As I passed by the band room, I could hear the muffled sound of "Pomp and Circumstance" from behind the walls. It was hot outside but not as much as usual. It was bearable. Most of the way home has a sidewalk, I thought. So I kept walking.
es: And in the end, it was too much. I couldn't shake off that feeling and it became unbearable. I extended my arms, reached deep into the locker, and pushed everything —photos, notes, and books— into the trash bin. I left the locker open and walked away. As I passed by the rehearsal room, I heard the muffled sound of "Pomp and Circumstance" on the other side of the wall. I kept walking. Outside, it was hot, though not as much as usual. It was bearable. "There are sidewalks for almost the entire way home," I thought. And I kept walking.

en: And as paralyzing and upsetting as all the never agains were, the final leaving felt perfect. Pure. The most distilled possible form of liberation. Everything that mattered except one lousy picture was in the trash, but it felt so great. I started jogging, wanting to put even more distance between myself and school.
vi: Just as dazed and worn out as all the never-agains, this final departure was truly perfect. Pure. The most easily distilled form of liberation. All attachments, except for a lousy photo, stayed in the trash, but the feeling was wonderful. I started to walk quickly, wanting to widen the distance between me and the school.
tr: No matter how paralyzing and upsetting the never-agains were, the feeling given by the last exit was perfect. It was pure. It was the most distilled form of salvation. Everything that mattered, except that lousy photo, was in the trash, but I felt great. I started running with the desire to put even more distance between me and the school.
es: And as paralyzing and sad as all those "never agains" were, it seemed perfect to leave like this for the last time. A pure departure. The most refined form of liberation possible. Everything important, except for one terrible photo, was in the trash, but I felt great. I started to run, because I wanted to put even more distance between the school and me.

en: It is so hard to leave—until you leave. And then it is the easiest goddamned thing in the world.
vi: Leaving is truly difficult—until we leave. And then it becomes the easiest thing in the world.
tr: Leaving is very hard... until you leave. After that, it's the easiest damn thing in the world.
es: Leaving is very hard... until you leave. Then it is the easiest thing in the world.

en: As I ran, I felt myself for the first time becoming Margo. I knew: she is not in Orlando. She is not in Florida. Leaving feels too good, once you leave. If I’d been in a car, and not on foot, I might have kept going, too. She was gone and not coming back for graduation or anything else. I felt sure of that now.
vi: While running, I felt like I was becoming Margo for the first time. I knew: she was not in Orlando. She was not in the state of Florida. Leaving felt too wonderful, once you had left. If I were in a car, not walking, I would have driven away forever. Margo had left and would not return for graduation or anything else. Now I felt certain.
tr: While running, for the first time, I felt like I was becoming Margo. I knew: She is not in Orlando. She is not in Florida. Once you leave, leaving feels really good. If I were in a car instead of on foot, I could have kept going too. Margo was gone and she wasn't coming back for graduation or anything else. I was sure of that now.
es: While I was running, I felt that for the first time I was becoming Margo. I knew it: "She is not in Orlando. She is not in Florida." Leaving is fantastic once you have left. If I had gone by car, not on foot, I probably would have kept going as well. Margo had left and was not going to return, neither for graduation nor for anything else. I was sure of it.

en: I leave, and the leaving is so exhilarating I know I can never go back. But then what? Do I just keep leaving places, and leaving them, and leaving them, tramping a perpetual journey?
vi: I left, and the departure was so exhilarating that I knew I might never return. But then what? Would I continue to leave somewhere, to depart and depart again, plunging myself into an endless journey?
tr: I am leaving, and leaving is so invigorating that I know I can never return. But what then? Will I just continue to leave places, slowly progressing on an eternal journey?
es: I'm leaving, and leaving is so stimulating that I know I can't go back. And then? Do I devote myself to leaving places over and over again? Do I embark on an eternal journey?

en: Ben and Radar drove past me a quarter mile from Jefferson Park, and Ben brought RHAPAW to a screeching halt right on Lakemont in spite of traffic everywhere, and I ran up to the car and got in. They wanted to play Resurrection at my house, but I had to tell them no, because I was closer than I’d ever been before.
vi: Ben and Radar drove by when I was a quarter mile from Jefferson Park. Ben abruptly stopped RHAPAW right on Lakemont, despite the surrounding traffic. I ran over and got into the car. The two guys wanted to come to my house to play Resurrection, but I had to say no, because I was closer than ever.
tr: Ben and Radar drove past me in a car five hundred meters from Jefferson Park, and despite there being traffic everywhere, Ben stopped the SESIB with a high-pitched sound right at Lakemont. I ran to the car and got in. They wanted to play Resurrection at my house, but I had to say no to them because I was closer than I had ever been before.
es: Ben and Radar passed by me half a kilometer from Jefferson Park. Ben slammed on the brakes right in front of Lakemont, even though the road was full of cars. I ran to the car and got in. They wanted to play Resurrection at my house, but I had to tell them no, because I was closer to Margo than ever.

en: All night Wednesday, and all day Thursday, I tried to use my new understanding of her to figure out some meaning to the clues I had—some relationship between the map and the travel books, or else some link between the Whitman and the map that would allow me to understand her travelogue. But increasingly I felt like maybe she had become too enthralled with the pleasure of leaving to construct a proper bread crumb trail. And if that were the case, the map she had never intended for us to see might be our best chance to find her. But no site on the map was adequately specific. Even the Catskill Park dot, which interested me because it was the only location not in or near a big city, was far too big and populous to find a single person. “Song of Myself” made references to places in New York City, but there were too many locations to track them all down. How do you pinpoint a spot on the map when the spot seems to be moving from metropolis to metropolis?
vi: Throughout Wednesday night and all day Thursday, I tried to leverage my new understanding of Margo to derive some meaning from the clues I had—the connection between the map and the travel books, or between Whitman and the map, connections that would help me understand her wanderlust language. But I increasingly felt that perhaps the joy of departure had captivated Margo to the extent that she didn't really care to leave a complete trail of breadcrumbs. If that were the case, the map Margo didn't intend for us to discover might be the best chance to find her. But no location on the map was precise enough. Even Catskill Park, which caught my attention because it was the only place not in or near a major city, was still too vast, too crowded to search for a single individual. "Song of Myself" led to places in New York City, but there were too many locations to track. How could one pinpoint a location on the map when that point seemed to always be moving from one city to another?
tr: All Wednesday night and Thursday, I tried to use my new understanding to find a connection between the clues I had, the travel guides, and the map; or between Whitman and the map, to understand his journey. But more and more, I was thinking, perhaps he had taken pleasure in abandoning the trail so much that it wouldn't form a proper trace from breadcrumbs. And if that was the case, the map he never planned for us to see might be our best chance to find him. But none of the locations on the map were clear enough. Even the point of interest, Catskill Park, which caught my attention because it was the only place not in or near a big city, was too large and crowded to find a single person. My Song referred to places in New York, but there were too many places to track them all. If the point seemed to be moving from one big city to another, how would you pinpoint that location on the map?
es: On Wednesday night and all of Thursday, I tried to use everything I already knew about Margo to find some meaning in the clues I had, some connection between the map and the travel books, or perhaps some link between Whitman and the map that would help me understand her travel diary. But I increasingly got the impression that maybe she was too fascinated by the pleasure of leaving to leave a breadcrumb trail. And if that was the case, the map she hadn't intended for us to see could be our best bet to find her. But the markings on the map weren't concrete enough. Even the Catskill Park, which interested me because it was the only spot not in a big city, not even close, was too large and had too many inhabitants to find one person. "Song of Myself" mentioned places in New York City, but there were too many locations to track them all. How do you locate a point on a map when it seems the point moves from one city to another?

en: I was already up and paging through travel guides when my parents came into my room on Friday morning. They rarely both entered the room at the same time, and I felt a ripple of nausea—maybe they had bad news about Margo—before I remembered it was my graduation day.
vi: On Friday morning, I had woken up and was flipping through travel guides when my parents came into my room. Both of them rarely came into my room at the same time, I started to feel uneasy—maybe there was bad news about Margo—then suddenly remembered that today was my graduation day.
tr: When my mom and dad entered my room on Friday, I had already gotten up and was flipping through the pages of travel guides. They rarely entered my room at the same time, and before I remembered that it was my graduation day, I felt a wave of nausea... Maybe they had bad news about Margo.
es: On Friday morning, I was already up, leafing through travel guides, when my parents entered my room. Since they rarely came in together, my stomach turned —maybe they had bad news about Margo—, but then I suddenly remembered it was my graduation day.

en: “Ready, bud?”
vi: "Ready, son?"
tr: “Are you ready, my friend?”
es: —Are you ready?

en: “Yeah. I mean, it’s not that big of a deal, but it’ll be fun.”
vi: "Yes. It's not very grand, but it will be fun."
tr: “Are you ready, my friend?” “Yes, I mean, it's not a big deal but it will be fun.”
es: —Yes. Well, it's not that important, but it will be fun.

en: “You only graduate from high school once,” Mom said.
vi: “You only graduate from high school once in your life,” said Mom.
tr: "You only graduate from high school once," said my mom.
es: "You only graduate once," my mother told me.

en: “Yeah,” I said. They sat down on the bed across from me. I noticed them share a glance and giggle. “What?” I asked.
vi: "Yes," I replied. My parents sat down on the edge of the bed and looked at me. Both of them giggled and glanced at each other. "What's going on?" I asked.
tr: “Yes,” I said. They sat on the bed across from me. I noticed them glancing at each other and giggling. “What?” I asked.
es: —Yes —I answered him. They sat on the bed. I noticed that they looked at each other and smiled. —What's happening? —I asked them.

en: “Well, we want to give you your graduation present,” Mom said. “We’re really proud of you, Quentin. You’re the greatest accomplishment of our lives, and this is just such a great day for you, and we’re— You’re just a great young man.”
vi: “Well, your father and I wanted to give you a graduation gift,” Mom said. “Quentin, we are really proud of you. You are the most precious treasure in our lives, today is a big day for you, and we–You really are a good boy.”
tr: “Well, we want to give you your graduation gift,” said my mom. “We are really proud of you, Quentin. You are the greatest achievement of our lives, and this is such a big day for you, and we... You are just a wonderful young man.”
es: —Well, we want to give you your graduation gift —said my mother—. We are very proud of you, Quentin. You are the greatest achievement of our life, today is a great day for you and we are… You are a great kid.

en: I smiled and looked down. And then my dad produced a very small gift wrapped in blue wrapping paper.
vi: I smiled and looked down. And then Dad took out a very small gift box, wrapped in sky-blue wrapping paper.
tr: I smiled and looked down. Then my father took out a very small gift wrapped in blue paper.
es: I smiled and lowered my gaze. Then my father took out a very small gift wrapped in blue paper.

en: “No,” I said, snatching it from him.
vi: “No,” I exclaimed, hastily grabbing it.
tr: "No," I said, grabbing it from his hand.
es: —No —I said, taking it out of his hands.

en: “Go ahead and open it.”
vi: "Open it, son.""
tr: “Go on, open it.”
es: —Come on, open it.

en: “No way,” I said, staring at it. It was the size of a key. It was the weight of a key. When I shook the box, it rattled like a key.
vi: “Impossible,” I said, still staring at the box. The size of a key. The weight of a key. I shook it, the box rattled like a key.
tr: "It can't be," I said, looking at the gift. It was the size of a key. It was the weight of a key. When I shook the box, it rattled like a key.
es: —It can't be —I said, looking at the little package. It was the size of a key. It weighed like a key. When shaking the box, it sounded like a key.

en: “Just open it, sweetie,” my mom urged.
vi: “Hurry up and open it, dear,” my mother urged me.
tr: "Just eat, sweetie," insisted my mom.
es: —Open it now, honey —my mother urged me.

en: I tore off the wrapping paper. A KEY! I examined it closely. A Ford key! Neither of our cars was a Ford. “You got me a car?!”
vi: I tore the wrapping paper. A KEY! I looked closely. A Ford car key! My family doesn't have any Ford. "Did you buy a car for me, Mom and Dad?"
tr: I tore the wrapping paper. A KEY! I examined it closely. A Ford key! Neither of our cars was a Ford. “Did you buy me a car?!””
es: I tore off the paper. A KEY! I examined it closely. The key to a Ford! None of our cars was a Ford. —Have you bought me a car?

en: “We did,” my dad said. “It’s not brand-new—but only two years old and just twenty thousand miles on it.” I jumped up and hugged both of them.
vi: "Yes," Dad said. "It's not brand new—but it's only been driven for two years and about twenty thousand miles."" I jumped up and hugged both my dad and mom.
tr: “We bought it,” said my dad. “It’s not new... but it’s only two years old and has only twenty thousand kilometers.” I jumped and hugged both of them.
es: —Exactly —my father replied to me—. It's not new, but it has only two years and thirty thousand kilometers. I jumped out of bed and hugged them both.

en: “It’s mine?”
vi: "Is it mine?"
tr: “Mine?”
es: —Is it mine?

en: “Yeah!” my mom almost shouted. I had a car! A car! Of my own!
vi: "Yes!" Mom almost shouted. I have a car! A car! My very own!
tr: “Yes!” my mom almost shouted. I had a car! A car! Mine!
es: —Yes! —my mother almost shouted. I already had a car! A car! Mine!

en: I disentangled myself from my parents and shouted “thank you thank you thank you thank you thank you thank you” as I raced through the living room, and yanked open the front door wearing only an old T-shirt and boxer shorts. There, parked in the driveway with a huge blue bow on it, was a Ford minivan.
vi: I pulled myself away from my parents and screamed, "Thank you, Dad! Thank you, Mom! Thank you, Dad! Thank you, Mom! Thank you, Dad! Thank you, Mom!" while dashing through the living room, flinging open the front door, wearing only an old t-shirt and shorts. There, parked in the driveway and adorned with a huge sky-blue bow, was a Ford minivan.
tr: I freed myself from them, running towards the living room, shouting, "thank you thank you thank you thank you thank you thank you" and quickly opened the street door, wearing only an old t-shirt and boxers. There, parked on the driveway with a huge blue bow on it, was a Ford minivan.
es: I let go of my parents, shouted "thank you thank you thank you thank you thank you thank you" while running through the dining room, and opened the front door dressed only in an old t-shirt and underwear. Parked in the driveway, with a huge blue bow, was a Ford minivan.

en: They’d given me a minivan. They could have picked any car, and they picked a minivan. A minivan. O God of Vehicular Justice, why dost thou mock me? Minivan, you albatross around my neck! You mark of Cain! You wretched beast of high ceilings and few horsepower!
vi: My parents gave me a minivan. They could have chosen any type of car, and they chose a minivan. A minivan. Oh, Vehicle Justice God, why do you mock me so? Minivan, you are a yoke around my neck, an indelible shame! You are a high-roofed, low-powered monster!
tr: They had given me a minivan. They could have chosen any car, and they chose a minivan. A minivan. Oh, God of Vehicle Justice, why are you mocking me? Minivan, the bane of my existence! You are my final curse! You miserable monster of high ceilings and low horsepower!
es: They had given me a minivan. They could have chosen any car, but they chose a minivan. A minivan. Oh, God of Vehicular Justice, why do you mock me? Minivan, you are my cross! You, mark of Cain! You, miserable beast with a high roof and few horsepower!

en: I put on a brave face when I turned around. “Thank you thank you thank you!” I said, although surely I didn’t sound quite as effusive now that I was completely faking it.
vi: I put on a brave face and turned around. "Thank you, Dad. Thank you, Mom!" I said, though my voice lacked enthusiasm because I was completely acting.
tr: When I turned my back, I put on a brave face. "Thank you thank you thank you!" I said, but since it was completely fake, my voice definitely didn't sound as enthusiastic anymore.
es: I put on a good face when I turned around. —Thank you, thank you, thank you! —I told them, although I was sure I didn't seem as effusive now that I was pretending.

en: “Well, we just knew how much you loved driving mine,” Mom said. She and Dad were beaming—clearly convinced they’d landed me the transportation of my dreams. “It’s great for getting around with your friends!” added my dad. And to think: these people specialize in the analysis and understanding of the human psyche.
vi: “We noticed that you really like driving your mom's car,” mom said. My parents beamed—clearly believing that they had given their son the vehicle of his dreams. “Hanging out with friends will be a lot of fun!” dad added. And just think: these two specialize in analyzing and understanding human psychology.
tr: “Well, we knew how much you loved driving mine,” said my mom. Both her and my dad's eyes were shining... clearly convinced they had provided me with the car of my dreams. “Great for driving around with your friends,” added my dad. Considering these people specialized in analyzing and understanding the human soul...
es: —Well, we knew you loved mine —my mother told me. They were both radiant, undoubtedly convinced that they had given me the vehicle of my dreams. —It's fantastic for you to go out there with your friends —added my father. And to think that they were specialists in analyzing and understanding human psychology...

en: “Listen,” Dad said, “we should get going pretty soon if we want to get good seats.”
vi: “Well,” Dad said, “we should go early to get good seats.”
tr: "Look," said my father, "if we want to get good seats, we should leave soon."
es: —Hey —said my father—, we should start thinking about leaving if we want to get good seats.

en: I hadn’t showered or dressed or anything. Well, not that I would technically be dressing, but still. “I don’t have to be there until twelve-thirty,” I said. “I need to, like, get ready.”
vi: I haven't showered or changed clothes, haven't done anything at all. Well, that doesn't mean I'll actually get dressed, but it still takes time. "You don't have to be there until twelve-thirty," I said. "I still need to get ready."
tr: I had neither taken a shower nor gotten dressed. Well, technically I wouldn't be dressed anyway, but still... “I don't have to be there until about the time of the fire,” I said. “I need to get ready and all.”
es: I hadn't showered, nor dressed, nor anything. Well, to be exact, I didn't have to dress either, but anyway. —I don't have to be there until twelve-thirty —I told them—. I have to get ready.

en: Dad frowned. “Well, I really want to have a good sight line so I can take some pic— ”
vi: Dad furrowed his brow, "Yes, but I want to sit somewhere with a good view to take pictures–"
tr: My father frowned. "Well, I really want to have a good perspective, so I can take photos..."
es: My father furrowed his brow. —Well, the truth is that I want to sit in a good row so I can take pho…

en: I interrupted him. “I can just take MY CAR,” I said. “I can drive MYSELF in MY CAR.” I smiled broadly.
vi: I interrupted my dad, "I can GO BY MYSELF," I said. "I can DRIVE MY OWN CAR to school," I grinned.
tr: I interrupted him. “I can take MY OWN CAR,” I said. “I can come with MY OWN CAR, BY MYSELF.” I smiled broadly.
es: —I can take MY CAR —I interrupted him—. I can go ALONE in MY CAR. I smiled from ear to ear.

en: “I know!” my mom said excitedly. And what the hell—a car’s a car, after all. Driving my own minivan was surely a step up from driving someone else’s.
vi: "Mom knows already!" Mom was also very happy. Heavens and earth, a car is still a car no matter what. Driving my minivan is definitely a step up compared to driving someone else's minivan.
tr: “I know!” my mother said excitedly. So what... a car is a car after all. Driving my own minivan was definitely a step forward compared to driving someone else's.
es: —I already know! —my mother replied enthusiastically. And what the hell, after all, a car is a car. I'm sure driving my minivan was a step above driving someone else's minivan.

es: I went back to the computer and informed Radar and Lacey (Ben wasn't online) about the car.

es: OMNICTIONARIAN96: It's really great news, truly. Can I stop by your house to leave a fridge in the trunk? I have to take my parents to the graduation and I don't want them to see it.

en: Ben came online then, SHOUTING about how he was already showered and naked and just needed to put on the cap and gown. We were all talking back and forth about our naked graduation. After everyone logged off to get ready, I got in the shower and stood up straight so that the water shot directly at my face, and I started thinking as the water pounded away at me. New York or California? Chicago or D.C.? I could go now, too, I thought. I had a car just as much as she did. I could go to the five spots on the map, and even if I didn’t find her, it would be more fun than another boiling summer in Orlando. But no. It’s like breaking into SeaWorld. It takes an immaculate plan, and then you execute it brilliantly, and then—nothing. And then it’s just Sea-World, except darker. She’d told me: the pleasure isn’t in doing the thing; the pleasure is in planning it.
vi: Ben went online, SCREAMING that he had bathed thoroughly, stark naked, and just needed to put on a hat and slip into his robe. We chatted about the graduation ceremony in the nude. After everyone had logged off to get ready, I went into the bathroom, stood straight to let the water hit my face directly, and started thinking while the water kept pouring. New York or California? Chicago or D.C.? Now I could go too, I thought. I have a car, just like she has one. I could go to all five points on the map, and even if I didn't find her, it would be more fun than a melting hot summer in Orlando. But no. It's like sneaking into SeaWorld. It requires meticulous planning, excellent execution, and then–nothing. And just like SeaWorld, except darker. Margo had told me: the fun part isn't in the execution; the fun part is in the planning process itself.
tr: Then Ben came online; he was already showered, naked, and just needed to put on the cap and gown, SHOUTING. We were all talking about our naked graduation. After everyone went offline to get ready, I stood up straight in the shower so the water would hit me directly in the face and started thinking as the water hit me. New York or California? Chicago or Washington? Now I can go too, I thought. Just like he had, I also had a car. I could go to the five locations on the map, and even if I didn't find her, it would be more fun than another scorching summer in Orlando. But no. It's like sneaking into SeaWorld. It requires a flawless plan, the plan is executed masterfully, and then... it leads nowhere. Then, it's just like SeaWorld, except darker. Margo had told me that the fun of it was not in the doing, but in the planning.
es: Then Ben entered the chat SHOUTING that he had already showered, that he was naked, and that he only needed to put on the gown and cap. We all talked for a good while about our graduation while naked. When everyone had disconnected to get ready, I got into the shower, lifted my head so the water would fall directly on my face, and as the water pounded me, I started to think. New York or California? Chicago or Washington? I could also go, I thought. I had a car, like her. I could go to the five points on the map and, even if I didn't find her, it would be more fun than spending another scorching summer in Orlando. But no. It was like sneaking into SeaWorld. It requires an impeccable plan, then you execute it brilliantly, and then… nothing. Then it's SeaWorld, only darker. Margo told me that the pleasure isn't in doing something. The pleasure is in planning it.

en: And that’s what I thought about as I stood beneath the showerhead: the planning. She sits in the minimall with her notebook, planning. Maybe she’s planning a road trip, using the map to imagine routes. She reads the Whitman and highlights “I tramp a perpetual journey,” because that’s the kind of thing she likes to imagine herself doing, the kind of thing she likes to plan.
vi: Those were the things I thought about while standing under the shower: the planning process. Margo sat in the mini-mall with a notebook, outlining plans. She might be arranging a road trip, using the map to visualize the routes. She read Whitman and marked “I embark on the perpetual journey,” because that’s the kind of thing she likes to imagine herself doing, the kind of thing she likes to plan.
tr: And this is what I was thinking while standing under the showerhead: planning. Margo is sitting in the mall with her notebook, planning something. Maybe she's using the map to imagine routes and plan a journey. She's reading Whitman and underlining the sentence "I am slowly advancing on an eternal journey" because it's the kind of thing she would enjoy imagining herself doing, the kind of thing she would enjoy planning.
es: And that's what she was thinking about under the shower stream: the plan. She is sitting in the abandoned shopping mall with her notebook, making plans. Maybe she is planning a road trip and using the map to see the routes. She reads Whitman and marks "The journey I have undertaken is eternal," because that's what she likes to imagine, the kind of things she likes to plan.

en: But is it the kind of thing she likes to actually do? No. Because Margo knows the secret of leaving, the secret I have only just now learned: leaving feels good and pure only when you leave something important, something that mattered to you. Pulling life out by the roots. But you can’t do that until your life has grown roots.
vi: But is that the kind of work she really likes to do? No. Because Margo knows the secret of leaving, the secret I have just understood: leaving is only wonderful and pure when you leave something important, something meaningful to you. Uprooting life from its roots. But you can't do that until your life has taken root.
tr: But is it really the kind of thing she would enjoy doing? No. Because Margo knows the secret of leaving a place, a secret I have only now learned: Leaving is only about an important place, a moment When a place with a soul is abandoned, it feels good and pure. Like uprooting life from its roots. But this is not possible until life has taken root.
es: But is it the kind of thing that he really likes to do? No. Because Margo knows the secret of leaving, the secret that I have just learned: leaving makes you feel good and is only authentic when you leave behind something important, something that mattered to you. Uprooting life from its roots. But you can't do it while your life hasn't taken root.

en: And so when she left, she left for good. But I could not believe she had left for a perpetual journey. She had, I felt sure, left for a place—a place where she could stay long enough for it to matter, long enough for the next leaving to feel as good as the last one had. There is a corner of the world somewhere far away from here where no one knows what “Margo Roth Spiegelman” means. And Margo is sitting in that corner, scrawling in her black notebook.
vi: So when Margo left, she left forever. But I don't believe that she left for an endless journey. I feel certain that she left to go to a place—a place where she could stay long enough for it to become meaningful, long enough so that the next departure would feel as wonderful as the previous one. There is a corner in this world, somewhere far from here, where no one knows what "Margo Roth Spiegelman" means. And Margo is sitting in that corner, writing in her black notebook.
tr: So when she left, she left never to return. But it was impossible for me to believe that she had embarked on an eternal journey. I was sure she had left to go somewhere... somewhere she could stay long enough for it to mean something, for the next departure to feel as good as the last one. Somewhere far from here, in a corner of the world where no one knows what the name "Margo Roth Spiegelman" means, Margo is sitting, scribbling something in her black notebook.
es: That's why when she left, she left for good. But I couldn't believe that she had embarked on an eternal journey. I was sure she had gone somewhere, to a place where she could stay long enough for it to matter to her, long enough so that the next departure would make her feel as good as the previous one. “There is a corner in the world, somewhere far away, where no one knows what 'Margo Roth Spiegelman' means. And Margo is sitting there, writing in her black notebook.”

en: The water began to get cold. I hadn’t so much as touched a bar of soap, but I got out, wrapped a towel around my waist, and sat down at the computer.
vi: The water is starting to get cold. Still haven't touched the soap, but I get out, wrap a towel around my waist, and sit down by the computer.
tr: The water started to cool down. I hadn't even touched the bar of soap, but I got out; I wrapped a towel around my waist and sat down at the computer.
es: The water started to cool down. I hadn't even touched the bar of soap, but I got out, wrapped a towel around my waist, and sat in front of the computer.

en: I dug up Radar’s email about his Omnictionary program and downloaded the plug-in. It really was pretty cool. First, I entered a zip code in downtown Chicago, clicked “location,” and asked for a radius of twenty miles. It spit back a hundred responses, from Navy Pier to Deerfield. The first sentence of each entry came up on my screen, and I read through them in about five minutes. Nothing stood out. Then I tried a zip code near the Catskill Park in New York. Fewer responses this time, eighty-two, organized by the date on which the Omnictionary page had been created. I started to read.
vi: I searched through Radar's email for the program in his Encyclopedia of Everything, and downloaded it to my computer. The program ran very smoothly. First, I entered the central Chicago area code, selected "location," and searched within a twenty-mile radius. Hundreds of results came up, from Navy Pier to Deerfield. The first sentence of each entry appeared on my screen, and I skimmed through them in about five minutes. Nothing stood out. I tried again with an area code near Catskill Park in New York. This time there were fewer results, eighty-two, sorted by the date the entries were created in the Encyclopedia of Everything.
tr: I searched for and found Radar's email about the Omnictionary program and downloaded the software. It was indeed quite good. First, I entered an area code in downtown Chicago, clicked the "location" button, and requested a radius of thirty kilometers. It provided a hundred results from Navy Pier to Deerfield. The first sentence of each entry appeared on my screen, and I read them all in about five minutes. Nothing caught my eye. Then I tried an area code near Catskill Park in New York. This time there were fewer results, eighty-two, and they were organized by the date the Omnictionary pages were created. I started reading.
es: I opened Radar's email with the Omnictionary program and downloaded it. The truth is that it was great. First, I entered the postal code for downtown Chicago, clicked "location," and requested a radius of thirty kilometers. I got a hundred responses, from Navy Pier to Deerfield. The first line of each entry appeared on the screen, so I read them in about five minutes. I didn't see anything noteworthy. Then I tried with the postal code for Catskill Park in New York. This time there were fewer results, eighty-two, organized by the date the page was created on Omnictionary. I started reading.

en: Woodstock, New York, is a town in Ulster County, New York, perhaps best known for the eponymous Woodstock concert [see Woodstock Concert] in 1969, a three-day event featuring acts from Jimi Hendrix to Janis Joplin, which actually occurred in a nearby town.
vi: I began reading: Woodstock, New York, is a town in Ulster County, New York, perhaps best known for the namesake music festival [see Woodstock Festival] in 1969, a three-day event featuring artists from Jimi Hendrix to Janis Joplin, which actually took place in a nearby town.
tr: Woodstock, New York, located in Ulster County, is a city known for the 1969 Woodstock concert, a three-day festival where many performers, from Jimi Hendrix to Janis Joplin, took the stage, although it was actually held in a nearby town [see. Woodstock Concert].
es: Woodstock, New York, is a city in Ulster County, New York, well known for the 1969 concert that bore its name (see Woodstock Concert), a three-day event where artists like Jimi Hendrix and Janis Joplin performed, although the concert was actually held in a nearby town.

en: The Catskill Park comprises 700,000 acres of land in the Catskill Mountains owned jointly by state and local governments, including a 5 percent share held by New York City, which gets much of its water from reservoirs partly inside the park.
vi: Catskill Park covers 2,800 square kilometers, located in the Catskill Mountains, co-managed by the federal government and local authorities, including 5 percent ownership by New York City; part of the city's drinking water is sourced from lakes in Catskill Park.
tr: Catskill Park encompasses a 700,000-acre area in the Catskill Mountains, jointly held by local governments and the state, including a five percent share held by New York City, which collects most of its water from reservoirs partially located within the park.
es: The Catskill Park covers almost three thousand square kilometers of the Catskill Mountains and is jointly owned by the State and local government, with a 5 percent stake held by New York City, which receives a good portion of its water from reservoirs located partially within the park.

en: Agloe, New York, is a fictitious village created by the Esso company in the early 1930s and inserted into tourist maps as a copyright trap, or paper town.
vi: Agloe, New York, is a fictitious village, created by the Esso company in the early 1930s and appearing on tourist maps, serving as a copyright trap, or a paper town.
tr: Agloe, New York, is an imaginary village established by the Esso company in the early 1930s and inserted into tourist maps as a copyright trap or a paper town.
es: Agloe, New York, is a fictional town created by the Esso company in the early 1930s and included in tourist maps as a trap to control copyright. These fictional towns are also called paper towns.

en: Located at the intersection of two dirt roads just north of Roscoe, NY, Agloe was the creation of mapmakers Otto G. Lindberg and Ernest Alpers, who invented the town name by anagramming their initials. Copyright traps have featured in mapmaking for centuries. Cartographers create fictional landmarks, streets, and municipalities and place them obscurely into their maps. If the fictional entry is found on another cartographer’s map, it becomes clear a map has been plagiarized. Copyright traps are also sometimes known as key traps, paper streets, and paper towns [see also fictitious entries]. Although few cartographic corporations acknowledge their existence, copyright traps remain a common feature even in contemporary maps.
vi: Located at the intersection of two dirt roads north of Roscoe, NY, Agloe is the creation of mapmakers Otto G. Lindberg and Ernest Alpers, who formed the name Agloe by combining the initials of their names. Copyright traps have existed in the cartography industry for many centuries. Cartographers create fictitious locations, streets, and cities, placing them in hard-to-find spots on their maps. If those fictitious place names are found on another cartographer's map, it is certain that a map has been illicitly copied. Copyright traps are also known as trap streets, paper streets, and paper towns [see fictitious entries]. Although only a few mapping entities acknowledge the existence of copyright traps, they remain a common feature in today's maps.
tr: Roscoe, located at the intersection of two dirt roads just north of New York, gets its name from the cartographer Otto G., who made an anagram from the first letters of their names. It is derived from Lindberg and Ernest Alpers. Copyright traps have been a part of mapmaking for centuries. Cartographers create imaginary boundary markers, streets, and areas and place them on their maps in a way that is difficult to understand. If the imaginary input appears on another cartographer's map, it reveals that the map has been copied and published. Copyright traps are sometimes called key traps, paper streets, and paper towns [see also imaginary inputs]. There are a few cartography institutions that exist Even if accepted, copyright traps have remained a common feature even in modern maps.
es: Agloe, situated at the intersection of two unpaved roads north of Roscoe, New York, was created by cartographers Otto G. Lindberg and Ernest Alpers, who invented the name of the town by forming an anagram with their initials. For centuries, traps have been introduced into maps to control copyright. Cartographers create fictitious places, streets, and towns and place them in an inconspicuous spot on their map. If the fictitious entry appears on another cartographer's map, it is evident that the map has been plagiarized. These traps are also known as key traps, paper streets, and paper towns (see also fictitious entries). Although very few cartographic companies admit their existence, the traps remain a frequent feature even in contemporary maps.

en: In the 1940s, Agloe, New York, began appearing on maps created by other companies. Esso suspected copyright infringement and prepared several lawsuits, but in fact, an unknown resident had built “The Agloe General Store” at the intersection that appeared on the Esso map.
vi: In the 1940s, Agloe, New York, began appearing on the maps of other companies. Esso suspected copyright infringement and prepared legal proceedings, but in reality, an unidentified person had built an "Agloe General Store" at the intersection that appeared on Esso's map.
tr: In the 1940s, Agloe, New York started appearing on maps made by other companies. Esso suspected copyright infringement and filed numerous lawsuits, but in fact, an unknown resident had established the Agloe Market at the intersection shown on the Esso map.
es: In the 1940s, Agloe, New York, began to appear on maps from other companies. Esso suspected that they had infringed copyright laws and prepared to sue them, but in reality, an unknown resident had built the Agloe Supermarket at the intersection that appeared on Esso's map.

tr: The still existing [citation needed] building is the only structure in Agloe, which continues to be recorded as having a population of zero and continues to appear on many maps.
es: The supermarket, which still stands (citation needed), is the only building in Agloe, which continues to appear on many maps and whose population is usually recorded as zero.

en: I recognized the capitalization immediately. The rules of capitalization are so unfair to words in the middle of a sentence. My throat tightened, but I forced myself to calm down. The comment had been left fifteen days ago. It had been sitting there all that time, waiting for me. I looked at the clock on the computer. I had just under twenty-four hours.
vi: I immediately recognized this capitalization style. The conventional capitalization rules are very unfair to words that are not at the beginning of a sentence. My throat suddenly tightened, but I forced myself to calm down. The comment was written fifteen days ago. It had always been there, waiting for me. Looking at the clock on the computer, I had less than twenty-four hours left.

My throat tightened, but I forced myself to calm down. The comment had been left fifteen days ago. It had been waiting for me there all this time. I looked at the computer's clock. Right now, I had less than twenty-four hours.
es: I recognized the capital letters immediately. “The rules of capitalization are very unfair to the words that are in the middle.” I felt a lump in my throat, but I forced myself to calm down. I had left the comment fifteen days ago. It had stayed there all that time, waiting for me. I looked at the computer clock. I had less than twenty-four hours left.

en: For the first time in weeks, she seemed completely and undeniably alive to me. She was alive. For one more day at least, she was alive. I had focused on her whereabouts for so long in an attempt to keep me from obsessively wondering whether she was alive that I had no idea how terrified I’d been until now, but oh, my God. She was alive.
vi: For the first time in weeks, Margo became completely, undeniably, alive to me. She was still alive. At least for one more day, she was still alive. I had focused for so long on Margo's wanderings, being obsessed with the tangled mess of wondering whether she was alive or not, for so long that I didn't realize how scared I had been until now. Oh, thank God. She was still alive.
tr: For the first time in weeks, Margo looked completely and undeniably alive to me. She was alive. At least for one more day, she was alive. To stop myself from wondering whether she was alive or not, for so long she had been I was so focused on the place that I had no idea how scared I had been until now, but oh, my God... He was alive.
es: For the first time in weeks, I had no doubt that she was alive. She was alive. And she would be alive for at least one more day. I had focused so much time on locating her, mainly to avoid obsessively asking myself if she was alive, that I hadn't realized how terrified I had been until then, but, oh, my God. She was alive.

Which puts you there just after one P.M., so you’re going to have to make up time when you can.”

I ran up the stairs two at a time, and so was a little out of breath when I knelt down next to them and said, “Okay, so I’m not going [breath] to walk, because I [breath] think I found Margo and [breath] I just have to go, and I’ll have my cell phone on [breath] and please don’t be pissed at me and thank you again for the car.”

They were making hand gestures at me. Since I climbed the steps two at a time, I was almost out of breath when I knelt beside them. —Well —I told them—, I'm not going to [breath] stay because [breath] I think I have found Margo and [breath] I have to leave right now, I have my phone with me [breath], please, don't be mad at me and thank you very much again for the car.

en: “The longer you wait, the better it feels,” he says. The sound soon changes from the clinking of pee-on-bottle to the blopping of pee-on-pee. And then, slowly, Ben’s smile fades.
