en: “Another bottle coming up!” In a flash, I can see Radar bent over the backseat, his head in the cooler, digging a bottle out of the ice. He opens it with his bare hand, cracks one of the back windows open, and pours the beer out through the crack. Then he leaps to the front, his head between Ben and me, and holds the bottle out for Ben, whose eyes are darting around in panic.
vi: “Another bottle over here!” In a flash, I saw Radar twist around, dive into the cooler, and quickly grab a bottle from the pile of ice. He twisted the cap off with his bare hands, pried open a window at the back, slipped the beer bottle out, and poured it away. Then he lunged forward, his head popping up between Ben and me, holding the bottle out to Ben. Ben's eyes were bulging with fright.
tr: “Another bottle is coming!” Suddenly, I can see Radar leaning towards the back seat, his head inside the cooler, pulling out a bottle from the ice. He opens the bottle with his hand, cracks open one of the rear windows, and pours the beer out through the gap. Then he leans forward, his head between Ben and me, and hands the bottle to Ben, whose eyes are filled with panic.
es: —Coming right up, another bottle! In a second, I see Radar leaning over the backrest, with his head in the cooler, pulling out a bottle from the ice. He opens it directly, lowers a window, sticks out the bottle, and empties it. Then he jumps forward, sticks his head between Ben and me, and hands the bottle to Ben, who looks from side to side terrified.

en: “The, uh, exchange is going to be, uh, complicated,” Ben says. There’s a lot of fumbling going on beneath that robe, and I’m trying not to imagine what’s happening when out from underneath a robe comes a Miller Lite bottle filled with pee (which looks astoundingly similar to Miller Lite). Ben deposits the full bottle in the cup holder, grabs the new one from Radar, and then sighs with relief.

en: “Ben, if you get pee in my brand-new car, I am going to cut your balls off.”

tr: "Ben, if you get pee on my brand new car, I'll cut off your balls.""
es: —Ben, if you splash my new car with piss, I'll cut your balls off.

en: Still peeing, Ben looks over at me, smirking. “You’re gonna need a hell of a big knife, bro.” And then finally I hear the stream slow. He’s soon finished, and then in one swift motion he throws the new bottle out the window. The full one follows.
vi: Still peeing, Ben looked over at me with a sly smile. "You're going to need a huge, terrifying knife." Then finally, I heard the flow slow down. It was almost done, and with a swift motion, he threw the new bottle out the window. Next came the full bottle.
tr: Ben, who is still peeing, looks at me and grins. "You really need a big knife, brother." Then I finally hear the flow slowing down. Soon after, he finishes his business and with a single swift motion, throws the new bottle out the window. The full one follows it.
es: He lifts his eyes towards me and throws me a superior smile without stopping peeing. —You're going to need a giant knife, buddy —he replies to me. And finally I hear that the stream weakens. It ends quickly, and with a swift motion, he throws the second bottle out the window. And then the first one.

en: But Ben is beaming. He is holding his fists in the air, triumphant, and he is shouting, “Not a drop on the seat! I’m Ben Starling. First clarinet, WPHS Marching Band. Keg Stand Record Holder. Pee-in-the-car champion. I shook up the world! I must be the greatest!”
vi: But Ben grinned widely. He triumphantly punched the air, shouting loudly, "Not a drop spilled in the car! I am Ben Starling. The number one clarinet of the Winter Park school marching band. Beer Pong Champion! Car-internal champion. I shake the world! I am the best!”
tr: But Ben's eyes are shining. He raises his fists in a gesture of victory and shouts: "Not a single drop on the seat! My name is Ben Starling. First clarinet in the WPL band. Barrel stance record holder. Champion of peeing in the car. I moved the world! I am the greatest!"
es: But Ben is radiant. He raises his triumphant fist and shouts: —Not a drop on the seat! I'm Ben Starling. First clarinet of the Winter Park band. Keg stand record holder. Champion of peeing in the car. Let the world tremble! I'm the best!

en: We spend the hour preparing for our first stop. This is an important stop, because I am very, very, very, very hungry and dehydrated. For some reason, talking about the food we’ll buy at the BP eases the pangs. Lacey prepares a grocery list for each of us, written in small letters on the backs of receipts she found in her purse. She makes Ben lean out the passenger-side window to see which side the gas cap is on. She forces us to memorize our grocery lists and then quizzes us. We talk through our visit to the gas station several times; it needs to be as well-executed as a stock car pit stop.

She asks Ben to lean out the passenger window to see which side the gas tank cap is on. She makes us memorize the list and then quizzes us on it. We review the gas station raid several times. It has to be as efficient as a pit stop.

en: “Six minutes,” I say, nodding my head. And Lacey and Ben repeat it also. “Six minutes.” “Six minutes.” At 5:35 P.M., with nine hundred miles to go, Radar informs us that, according to his handheld, the next exit will have a BP.

es: —Six minutes —I say, nodding. —Six minutes —repeat Lacey and Ben as well. At 5:35 in the afternoon, with fourteen hundred kilometers ahead of us, Radar informs us that, according to his computer, there is a BP gas station at the next exit.

en: As I pull into the gas station, Lacey and Radar are crouched behind the sliding door in the back. Ben, seat belt unbuckled, has one hand on the passenger-door handle and the other on the dashboard. I maintain as much speed as I can for as long as I can, and then slam on the brakes right in front of the gas tank. The minivan jolts to a halt, and we fly out the doors. Radar and I cross in front of the car; I toss him the keys and then run all out to the food mart. Lacey and Ben have beaten me to the doors, but only just barely. While Ben bolts for the bathroom, Lacey explains to the gray-haired woman (it is a woman!) that we’re going to be buying a lot of stuff, and that we’re in a huge hurry, and that she should just ring items up as we deliver them and that it will all go on her BP card, and the woman seems a little bewildered but agrees. Radar runs in, his robe aflutter, and hands Lacey the card.
vi: As I pulled the car close to the station, Lacey and Radar were ready by the sliding door on the side of the car. Ben, having unbuckled his seatbelt, placed one hand on the door handle and the other on the dashboard. I tried to maintain the highest speed possible for as long as possible, then slammed the brakes right in front of the gas station. The car jerked to a stop, and we burst out of the car. Radar and I crossed paths in front of the car, I tossed the keys to him and sprinted straight into the convenience store. Lacey and Ben reached the door before me, but just barely. While Ben dashed into the restroom, Lacey explained to the salt-and-pepper-haired woman (who turned out to be an older lady!) that we were going to buy a lot and were in a hurry, so she should start ringing up the items as soon as we brought them to the counter, and everything would be paid for with Lacey's BP card. The older lady seemed a bit confused, but agreed nonetheless. Radar ran in, his robe billowing, and handed the card to Lacey.
tr: As I pull into the gas station, Lacey and Radar are crouched by the sliding door in the back. Ben, whose seatbelt is unfastened, has one hand on the front door handle and the other on the panel. I maintain as much speed as I can for as long as I can, and then I slam on the brakes right in front of the gas pump. The minivan comes to a jarring stop, and we fly out of the doors. We meet Radar in front of the car; I toss him the keys and run all the way to the store. Lacey and Ben have passed me on their way to the door, but only just barely. As Ben darts towards the restroom, Lacey explains to the gray-haired woman (a woman, really!) that we’re going to buy a lot of things, we’re in a big hurry, she needs to ring up the items as we bring them, and it will all be charged to the BP card; the woman looks a bit bewildered but agrees. Radar runs in with his robe flapping and hands the card to Lacey.
es: As I enter the gas station, Lacey and Radar crouch behind the sliding door in the back. Ben, with his seatbelt unbuckled, has one hand on the passenger door handle and the other on the dashboard. I maintain the highest speed I can for as long as I can, and then brake hard in front of the gas pump. The minivan jerks and we rush out at full speed. Radar and I cross paths in front of the car. I toss him the keys and run towards the food section. Lacey and Ben push me against the doors, but it's not serious. While Ben runs to the bathroom, Lacey explains to the gray-haired woman (it is indeed a woman) that we are going to buy a lot of things, that we are in a huge hurry, and that she should start scanning the items as we bring them, charging everything to her BP card. The woman looks somewhat bewildered, but agrees. Radar runs in, with his gown flying, and hands the card to Lacey.

en: Meanwhile, I’m running through the aisles getting everything on my list. Lacey’s on liquids; Ben’s on nonperishable supplies; I’m on food. I sweep through the place like I’m a cheetah and the tortilla chips are injured gazelles. I run an armful of chips and beef jerky and peanuts to the front counter, then jog to the candy aisle. A handful of Mentos, a handful of Snickers, and— Oh, it’s not on the list, but screw it, I love Nerds, so I add three packages of Nerds. I run back and then head over to the “deli” counter, which consists of ancient turkey sandwiches wherein the turkey strongly resembles ham. I grab two of those. On my way back to the cash register, I stop for a couple Starbursts, a package of Twinkies, and an indeterminate number of GoFast nutrition bars. I run back. Ben’s standing there in his graduation gown, handing the woman T-shirts and four-dollar sunglasses. Lacey runs up with gallons of soda, energy drinks, and bottles of water. Big bottles, the kind of bottles that even Ben’s pee can’t fill.

I swept through the place as if I were a leopard and the packaged chips were a herd of wounded antelopes. I grabbed a bunch of potato chips, beef jerky, and peanuts, ran to the counter, then dashed to the candy section. A handful of Mentos, a handful of Snickers, and—oh, not on the list, but whatever, I like Nerds candy, so I grabbed three packs. I ran back to the checkout counter and continued with fresh food, including classic turkey sandwiches, where the turkey tasted just like bacon. I took two. On the way to the checkout counter, I stopped to grab some Starburst candy and Twinkies, plus an indeterminate amount of GoFast nutrition bars. I ran to the counter. Ben was standing there in his graduation gown, checking out a t-shirt and four-dollar sunglasses. Lacey ran over with several gallons of soda, energy drinks, and bottled water. Big bottles, the kind that even Ben's urine couldn't fill up.

Oh, it's not on the list, but I grab it, I love Nerds candies, so I add three boxes. I go back and head to the deli display, which is basically made up of stale turkey sandwiches where the turkey looks like ham. I grab two. Back at the checkout, I stop to grab a couple of packs of Starbursts, a pack of Twinkies, and an indeterminate amount of GoFast bars. I return to the checkout. en: “ONE MINUTE!” Lacey shouts, and I panic. I’m turning in circles, my eyes darting around the store, trying to remember what I’m forgetting. I glance down at my list. I seem to have everything, but I feel like there’s something important I’ve forgotten. Something. Come on, Jacobsen. Chips, candy, turkey-that-looks-like-ham, pbj, and—what? What are the other food groups? Meat, chips, candy, and, and, and, and cheese! “CRACKERS!” I say, much too loud, and then I dart to the crackers, grabbing cheese crackers and peanut butter crackers and some of Grandma’s peanut butter cookies for good measure, and then I run back and toss them across the counter. The woman has already bagged up four plastic bags of groceries. Almost a hundred dollars total, not even counting gas; I’ll be paying back Lacey’s parents all summer.
vi: “ONE MORE MINUTE!” Lacey shouted, and I panicked. I spun around, eyes darting all over the stall, trying to remember what I had forgotten. I glanced down at my list; it seemed I had everything, but I still felt like I was forgetting something very important. Something. Come on, Jacobsen. Chips, candy, turkey-that-looks-like-bacon, peanuts, beef jerky, and–what else? What was the other food group? Meat, potatoes, candy, and, and, and, and cheese! “CRACKERS!” I blurted out, a bit loudly, then dashed to the cracker aisle, grabbed cheese crackers, peanut butter crackers, added some Grandma’s peanut butter cookies, then ran back and dumped everything on the counter. The cashier had packed everything into four bags. It all came to nearly a hundred dollars, not counting the gas; I would have to pay Lacey’s parents back all summer.
tr: “ONE MINUTE!” shouts Lacey, and I panic. I draw circles, my eyes scan the store, trying to remember what I forgot. I take a look at my list. It seems like I got everything, but it feels like I forgot something important. Come on, Jacobs. Chips, candy, turkey that looks like ham, peanut butter and jelly sandwich, and... what? What’s the other food group? Meat, chips, candy and and and cheese! “CRACKERS!” I say louder than necessary and rush to the crackers, grabbing cheese crackers, peanut butter crackers, and a few extra Grandma’s cookies, then I run back and throw what I have onto the counter. The woman has already filled four plastic bags. Almost a hundred dollars in total, not even counting the gas; I will pay this money back to Lacey’s parents over the summer.
es: —ONE MINUTE! —shouts Lacey. It almost gave me a heart attack. I wander around the store, trying to remember what I have forgotten. I take a look at my list. It seems like everything is there, but I have the feeling that I'm forgetting something important. Something. "Come on, Jacobsen." Chips, candies, turkey sandwiches that look like ham... and what else? What other types of food are there? Meat, chips, candies and, and, and, and cheese! CRACKERS!, I shout out loud. I run towards the crackers, grab several packs with cheese and with peanut butter, and some grandma's cookies just in case, run back to the counter and put everything on the counter. The woman has already filled four plastic bags. Almost a hundred dollars in total, not counting the gas. I'll have to spend the summer paying back Lacey's parents.

en: There’s only one moment of pause, and it’s after the woman behind the counter swipes Lacey’s BP card. I glance at my watch. We’re supposed to leave in twenty seconds. Finally, I hear the receipt printing. The woman tears it out of the machine, Lacey scribbles her name, and then Ben and I grab the bags and dash for the car. Radar revs the engine as if to say hustle, and we are running through the parking lot, Ben’s robe flowing in the wind so that he looks vaguely like a dark wizard, except that his pale skinny legs are visible, and his arms hug plastic bags. I can see the back of Lacey’s legs beneath her dress, her calves tight in midstride. I don’t know how I look, but I know how I feel: Young. Goofy. Infinite. I watch as Lacey and Ben pile in through the open sliding door. I follow, landing on plastic bags and Lacey’s torso. Radar guns the car as I slam the sliding door shut, and then he peels out of the parking lot, marking the first time in the long and storied history of the minivan that anyone anywhere has ever used one to burn rubber. Radar turns left onto the highway at a somewhat unsafe speed, and then merges back onto the interstate. We’re four seconds ahead of schedule. And just like with the NASCAR pit stops, we share high-fives and backslaps. We are well supplied. Ben has plenty of containers into which he can urinate. I have adequate beef jerky rations. Lacey has her Mentos. Radar and Ben have T-shirts to wear over their robes. The minivan has become a biosphere—give us gas, and we can keep going forever.
vi: Only a single moment of quiet after the cashier swiped Lacey's card. I glanced at the clock. We needed to be on the road in twenty seconds. Finally, we heard the receipt being printed. The cashier tore the receipt from the printer, Lacey scribbled her signature, Ben and I grabbed the bags and dashed to the car. Radar had the engine running as if to say hurry up, we ran across the parking lot, Ben's robe billowing in the wind making him look somewhat like a dark wizard, except for the pale legs showing and his arms full of bags. I saw Lacey's calves under her skirt, her muscles tensing with each stride. I didn't know how I looked, but I knew how I felt: Young. Foolish. Limitless. I watched Ben and Lacey dive into the car through the already open sliding door. Next was me, landing on the bags and Lacey. Radar sped off as I slammed the sliding door shut, he swerved the car out of the parking lot, marking the first time in the long history of minivans that someone somewhere had driven fast enough to screech the tires. Radar turned left onto the highway at an unsafe speed, then merged back onto the interstate. We were four seconds ahead of schedule. And just like a NASCAR pit stop, we high-fived and congratulated each other. So we were all set. Ben had everything he needed in case he had to relieve himself. I had enough beef jerky. Lacey had Mentos. Radar and Ben had t-shirts to wear over their robes. The minivan had become a biosphere—just keep filling it with gas and we could go on forever.
tr: There is only a single moment of hesitation; the woman at the counter scans my BP card after Lacey. I glance at my watch. We need to leave within twenty seconds. I finally hear the receipt printing. The woman tears the receipt from the machine, scribbles Lacey's name, and Ben and I grab the bags and dash towards the car. Radar revs the engine as if urging us to hurry, and we run across the parking lot, Ben's robe fluttering in the wind, making him look vaguely like a dark wizard; only his pale, skinny legs are visible, and his arms are full of nylon bags. From under her dress, I can see the backs of Lacey's legs, her calves tightening mid-stride. I don't know how I look, but I know how I feel: Young. Foolish. Infinite. I watch Lacey and Ben dive into the open sliding door. Following them, I tumble onto Lacey with the nylon bags. As Ben noisily shuts the sliding door, Radar floors the gas pedal, then quickly exits the parking lot, and the minivan, which no one ever used to leave tire marks anywhere, long and full of stories is making a first in its ornate history. Radar turns left onto the main road at a speed that isn't very safe, then gets onto the interstate. We are four seconds ahead of schedule. And just like in NASCAR pit stops, we high-five each other. We have secured enough supplies. Ben has plenty of containers to pee in. I have my sufficient share of dried meat. Lacey has Mentos. Radar and Ben have t-shirts to wear instead of their robes. The minivan has turned into a biosphere... Give us gas, and we can keep going forever.
es: The only moment of pause is after the cashier has swiped Lacey's card. I look at the clock. We are supposed to leave in twenty seconds. I finally hear the ticket printing. The woman tears it from the machine, Lacey scribbles her signature, and Ben and I grab the bags and run to the car. Radar revs the engine, as if telling us to hurry up, and we run through the parking lot. With Ben's gown flying in the wind, he has a slight resemblance to a wizard, except that you can see his white legs and he is carrying plastic bags in his hands. I see the back of Lacey's legs under her dress, moving forward with tight calves. I don't know what I look like, but I know how I feel: young. Clumsy. Infinite. I watch Lacey and Ben entering through the sliding door. Then I enter, landing on top of plastic bags and on Lacey's torso. Radar starts the car as I close the door and speeds out of the parking lot, marking the first time in the long and notorious history of minivans that someone uses one to burn rubber. Radar turns left onto the highway at an unsafe speed and we get back on the interstate. We are four seconds ahead of schedule. And like in a NASCAR pit stop, we high-five and pat each other on the back. We are well-stocked. Ben has a bunch of pee containers. I have plenty of beef jerky rations. Lacey has her Mentos. Radar and Ben have t-shirts to put over their gowns. The minivan has become a biosphere. With gasoline, we can keep going forever.

en: Okay, maybe we are not that well provisioned after all. In the rush of the moment, it turns out that Ben and I made some moderate (although not fatal) mistakes. With Radar alone up front, Ben and I sit in the first bench, unpacking each bag and handing the items to Lacey in the wayback. Lacey, in turn, is sorting items into piles based on an organizational schema only she understands.

Radar goes ahead alone, and Ben and I sit in the front row of seats, take things out of the bags, and pass them to Lacey, who is behind us. For her part, Lacey arranges the items into piles following an organizational system that only she understands.

en: “Why is the NyQuil not in the same pile as the NoDoz?” I ask. “Shouldn’t all the medicines be together?”
vi: “Why isn't NyQuil in the same place as NoDoz?” I asked. “Aren't they both medications?”
tr: “Why isn't NyQuil in the same pile as NoDoz?” I ask. “Shouldn't all the medications be together?”
es: —Why doesn't the antihistamine go in the same pile as the caffeine pills? —I ask—. Shouldn't all the medications go together?

en: “Q. Sweetie. You’re a boy. You don’t know how to do these things. The NoDoz is with the chocolate and the Mountain Dew, because those things all contain caffeine and help you stay up. The NyQuil is with the beef jerky because eating meat makes you feel tired.”
vi: “Dear Q, you are too naive to understand this category. NoDoz goes with chocolate and Mountain Dew because they all contain caffeine and keep you awake. NyQuil goes with beef jerky because eating meat will make you tired.”
tr: “Q. Sweetheart. You are a man. You don't know how to do these things. NoDoz, chocolate, and Mountain Dew together because they all contain caffeine and help you stay awake. NyQuil with jerky because eating meat makes you feel tired.”
es: —Q, darling, you are a kid. You don't know how these things work. Caffeine goes with chocolate and Mountain Dew, which also have caffeine, which helps to keep you awake. The antihistamine, which makes you sleepy, goes with jerky because eating meat makes you tired.

en: “Fascinating,” I say. After I’ve handed Lacey the last of the food from my bags, Lacey asks, “Q, where is the food that is— you know—good?”

tr: “Fascinating,” I say. After handing the last of the food from my bags to Lacey, Lacey asks, “Q, the thing... you know... where is the good food?” 11 A medication that reduces cold symptoms, (exp. n.) 12 Caffeine-containing, a drug that makes one awake, (cf. n.)
es: —Fascinating —I replied. I pass the remaining food in the last bag to Lacey. —Q —he says to me—, where is the food that… you know… the food?

en: “Huh?”

es: Lacey takes out a copy of the list she made for me and reads it. —Bananas, apples, dried cranberries, and raisins.

en: “Oh.” I say. “Oh, right. The fourth food group wasn’t crackers.”

tr: “Oh,” I say. “Oh, right. The fourth food group wasn't crackers.” “Q!” she says angrily.
es: —Ah —I say—. Ah, okay. The fourth group wasn't salty crackers.

en: “Q!” she says, furious. “I can’t eat any of this!”

en: Ben puts a hand on her elbow. “Well, but you can eat Grandma’s cookies. They’re not bad for you. They were made by Grandma. Grandma wouldn’t hurt you.”
vi: Ben touched Lacey's elbow. "Come on, but you can eat Grandma's cookies. Grandma won't hurt you."

es: Ben grabs her by the elbow. —Well, but you can eat grandma's cookies. They won't make you feel bad. Grandma made them. And grandma would never hurt you.

en: Lacey blows a strand of hair out of her face. She seems genuinely annoyed. “Plus,” I tell her, “there are GoFast bars. They’re fortified with vitamins!”
vi: Lacey blew a strand of hair out of her face, clearly looking quite annoyed. “It's just some GoFast bars,” I said to Lacey. “They have added vitamins!”
tr: Lacey blows a strand of hair away from her face. She really looks upset. “Besides,” I say, “they have GoFast wafers. They are fortified with vitamins!”
es: Lacey blows a strand of hair away from her face. She looks very annoyed. —Besides —I tell him—, there are energy bars. They are fortified with vitamins!

en: Finally, we unpack the last bag. It contains two large T-shirts, which Radar and Ben are very excited about, because it means they can be guys-wearing-gigantic-shirts-over-silly-robes instead of just guys-wearing-silly-robes.

tr: Finally, we empty the last bag. Inside, there are two large T-shirts that Ben and Radar get very excited about when they see them, because it means they can be "guys who wear gigantic T-shirts" instead of "guys who wear stupid clothes."
es: In the end, we opened the last bag. It contains two large t-shirts, which excite Radar and Ben, because they will allow them to be guys with a giant t-shirt over a ridiculous toga instead of just guys with a ridiculous toga.

en: But when Ben unfurls the T-shirts, there are two small problems. First, it turns out that a large T-shirt in a Georgia gas station is not the same size as a large T-shirt at, say, Old Navy. The gas station shirt is gigantic—more garbage bag than shirt. It is smaller than the graduation robes, but not by much. But this problem rather pales in comparison to the other problem, which is that both T-shirts are embossed with huge Confederate flags. Printed over the flag are the words HERITAGE NOT HATE.
vi: But when Ben took off the shirt, there were two small problems. One was that it turned out that a large T-shirt from a gas station in Georgia was not the same as a large from, say, Old Navy. It looks more like a garbage bag than a T-shirt. It's smaller than the togas, but not by much. But this problem almost pales in comparison to the other, which is that both T-shirts have the Confederate flag printed on them. Above the flag, it reads HERITAGE NOT HATE.

en: “Oh no you didn’t,” Radar says when I show him why we’re laughing. “Ben Starling, you better not have bought your token black friend a racist shirt.”
vi: “Oh no,” Radar exclaimed when I showed him what we were laughing at. “Ben Starling, you wouldn't buy your symbolically black friend a racist shirt, would you?”
tr: “Oh no, this can't be real,” says Radar when I show him why we are laughing. “I hope you didn't get a racist t-shirt for your token black friend, Starling.”
es: —Oh, no —says Radar when I show him why we are laughing—. Ben Starling, you shouldn't have bought a racist T-shirt for the person who covers your black friend quota.

en: “I just grabbed the first shirts I saw, bro.”

tr: “I just grabbed the first t-shirts I saw, brother.”
es: —I grabbed the first ones I saw, mate.

en: “Don’t bro me right now,” Radar says, but he’s shaking his head and laughing. I hand him his shirt and he wiggles into it while driving with his knees. “I hope I get pulled over,” he says. “I’d like to see how the cop responds to a black man wearing a Confederate T-shirt over a black dress.”
vi: “Don't be all buddy-buddy with me right now,” Radar said, but he shook his head and laughed loudly. I handed the shirt to Radar, and he slipped it on while steering with his knees. “I hope I get pulled over by the cops,” he said. “I want to see how they react when they see a black guy wearing a Confederate flag T-shirt over a black skirt.”
tr: “Don't call me brother right now,” says Radar, but I nod and smile. I hand him the T-shirt, and he tries to put it on while steering the car with his knees. “I hope they pull me over,” he says. “I want to see how the police will react to a black guy wearing a Confederate T-shirt over a black outfit.”
es: —Don't come at me with "buddy" now —says Radar, though he shakes his head and laughs. I hand him his t-shirt. He holds the steering wheel with his knees and puts it on—. I hope the cops pull me over. I'd love to see the look on their faces when they see a Black guy with a Confederate t-shirt over a black toga.

en: For some reason, the stretch of I-95 just south of Florence, South Carolina, is the place to drive a car on a Friday evening. We get bogged down in traffic for several miles, and even though Radar is desperate to violate the speed limit, he’s lucky when he can go thirty. Radar and I sit up front, and we try to keep from worrying by playing a game we’ve just invented called That Guy Is a Gigolo. In the game, you imagine the lives of people in the cars around you.
vi: For some reason, the stretch of I-95 extending south of Florence, South Carolina, is the place to drive on a Friday night. We were caught in a dilemma in a line of cars stretching for several miles. Even though Radar didn't expect to exceed the speed limit, it was fortunate that he could still manage thirty miles per hour. Radar and I sat in the front, trying not to worry by playing a game we just came up with, called That Guy Is a Gold Digger. In this game, the player has to imagine the lives of the people sitting in the other cars around us.

es: For some reason, the stretch of I-95 south of Florence, South Carolina, is the ideal place to drive on a Friday night. We got stuck for several miles in traffic, and although Radar is desperate to exceed the speed limit, he can hopefully go fifty. Radar and I are in the front trying not to worry by playing a game we just invented called "That Guy is a Gigolo." It consists of imagining the lives of the people in the cars around us.

en: We’re driving alongside a Hispanic woman in a beat-up old Toyota Corolla. I watch her through the early darkness. “Left her family to move here,” I say. “Illegal. Sends money back home on the third Tuesday of every month. She’s got two little kids—her husband is a migrant. He’s in Ohio right now—he only spends three or four months a year at home, but they still get along really well.”
vi: We drove alongside a Hispanic woman[9] in an old Toyota Corolla. I watched her as the sky began to darken. “Left her family to come here,” I said. “Living here illegally. Sends money home on the third Tuesday of every month. She has two small children–her husband is a migrant worker. Right now, her husband is in Ohio–he's only home about three or four months a year, but the couple is doing just fine.”
tr: We are driving side by side with a Hispanic woman in a rather old Toyota Corolla. I am watching the woman through the early falling darkness. "She left her family to move here," I say. "Illegal. She sends money home on the third day of every month. Two small children Her husband is an immigrant. Currently, he is in Ohio, spending only three or four months a year at home, but they still get along really well.”
es: We go next to a Hispanic woman driving an old and dilapidated Toyota Corolla. I observe her in the early darkness. —She left her family to come here —I say—. Without papers. She sends money home on the third Tuesday of every month. She has two small children. Her husband is an immigrant. At the moment, she lives in Ohio. She only spends three or four months a year at home, but her family manages quite well.

en: Radar leans in front of me and glances over at her for half a second. “Christ, Q, it’s not so melodratragic as that. She’s a secretary at a law firm—look how she’s dressed. It has taken her five years, but she’s now close to getting a law degree of her own. And she doesn’t have kids, or a husband. She’s got a boyfriend, though. He’s a little flighty. Scared of commitment. White guy, a little nervous about the Jungle Fever angle of the whole thing.”
vi: Radar leaned forward, glancing at her for half a second. "Oh my God, Q, it's not that tragic." She is a secretary at a law firm—just look at her dress. It took nearly five years, but now she is about to get her law degree. She doesn't have children, nor is she married. But he has a lover. He is easy-going, likes to be free, afraid of commitment. A white person, slightly worried about the interracial love syndrome in this whole affair."
tr: Radar leans forward and glances at the woman for a second. “My God, Q, it's not that melodramatic. A secretary in a law firm... look at how she's dressed. It took her five years, but now she's about to get her own law degree. And she doesn't have a child or a husband. She does have a boyfriend, though. The guy is a bit flighty. He's afraid of commitment. He's afraid of being criticized for having a 'fetish for black women' because of his pale skin.”
es: Radar leans forward and looks at her for a second. —Come on, Q, it's not as melodramatic as you make it out to be. She is a secretary at a law firm. Look at how she's dressed. It took her five years, but she's about to get her law degree too. She has no kids or husband. But she has a boyfriend who is somewhat inconsistent. He's scared of commitment. A white guy who gets turned on by the ethnic vibe.

en: “She’s wearing a wedding ring,” I point out. In Radar’s defense, I’ve been able to stare at her. She is to my right, just below me. I can see through her tinted windows, and I watch as she sings along to some song, her unblinking eyes on the road. There are so many people. It is easy to forget how full the world is of people, full to bursting, and each of them imaginable and consistently misimagined. I feel like this is an important idea, one of those ideas that your brain must wrap itself around slowly, the way pythons eat, but before I can get any further, Radar speaks.
vi: “But she's wearing a wedding ring,” I remarked. To find a way to support Radar's point of view, I observed her more closely. She was on the right, a little shorter than me. I could see through the frosted window of her car, she was singing along to some song, eyes fixed on the road without blinking. There were too many people. It's easy to forget how crowded this world is, so crowded it could explode, we can imagine each person, and often imagine wrong. I felt this was an important idea, one of those thoughts that our brain has to slowly wrap around, like a python swallowing its prey. But before I could think any further, Radar spoke up.
tr: “He’s wearing a ring,” I point out. According to Radar’s defense, I have the opportunity to look at him for a long time. To my right, just below me. I can see him through the dark-tinted window and watch him as he sings along to a song, his eyes never blinking, focused on the road. There are so many people. It’s so easy to forget that the world is full of people... so full that each of those people can be imagined and is continuously imagined incorrectly. This strikes me as an important idea, one of those ideas that the brain needs to slowly wrap around like a python eating its prey, but before I can go any further, Radar speaks.
es: —She wears a wedding ring —I pointed out. I must say, in Radar's defense, that I have been able to observe her better. She is to my right, just below me. I see her through the tinted windows of her car. I watch her singing and staring straight ahead without blinking. There are a lot of people. It's easy to forget how full of people the world is, crowded, and each one of them is susceptible to being imagined and, therefore, imagined wrongly. I get the impression that it's an important idea, one of those ideas that your brain has to mull over very slowly, like pythons when they eat, but before I can take it a step further, Radar intervenes.

en: “She’s just wearing that so pervs like you don’t come on to her,” Radar explains.
vi: “She wears a ring like that so that creeps like you won't dare to come near,” Radar explained.
tr: “She only wears the ring so creeps like you won't come onto her,” explains Radar.
es: —She wears it so that perverts like you don't approach her —he explains to me. —It could be.

en: “Maybe.” I smile, pick up the half-finished GoFast bar sitting on my lap, and take a bite. It’s quiet again for a while, and I am thinking about the way you can and cannot see people, about the tinted windows between me and this woman who is still driving right beside us, both of us in cars with all these windows and mirrors everywhere, as she crawls along with us on this packed highway. When Radar starts talking again, I realize that he has been thinking, too.
vi: “Maybe.” I smiled, taking a bite of the half-eaten GoFast bar in my lap. There was silence again for a moment, and I thought about how we can and cannot see people, about the frosted glass window between me and the woman driving to our right. Both she and I were in cars with windows and mirrors everywhere, while she murmured along driving next to us on this congested road. When Radar spoke up again, I realized it had been thinking too.
tr: “Maybe.” I smile, taking a bite from the half-eaten GoFast wafer in my lap. We remain silent for a while, and I think about the ways of seeing or not seeing people and the dark-colored windows between us and the woman still walking right beside us; on this crowded highway, as the woman moves slowly with us, we are both inside the cars with all those windows and mirrors. When Radar starts talking again, I realize that he has been thinking too.
es: I smile. I pick up the half energy bar that I had left on my knees and take a bite. For a moment we remain silent and I think about how we see and don't see people, about the tinted windows that separate me from that woman driving to our right, about how the two cars, with windows and mirrors everywhere, move together at a snail's pace on this crowded highway. When Radar starts to speak, I realize that he has also been thinking.

en: “The thing about That Guy Is a Gigolo,” Radar says, “I mean, the thing about it as a game, is that in the end it reveals a lot more about the person doing the imagining than it does about the person being imagined.”
vi: “The spirit of That Guy Is a Gold Digger,” Radar said, “I mean the spirit of this game, is that it ultimately reveals much more about the person imagining than the person being imagined.”

es: —The thing about "This guy is a gigolo" —says Radar—, well, I mean as a game itself, is that in the end it says much more about the person imagining than the person being imagined.

en: “Yeah,” I say. “I was just thinking that.” And I can’t help but feel that Whitman, for all his blustering beauty, might have been just a bit too optimistic. We can hear others, and we can travel to them without moving, and we can imagine them, and we are all connected one to the other by a crazy root system like so many leaves of grass—but the game makes me wonder whether we can really ever fully become another.
vi: “Yes,” I replied. “I was just thinking the same thing.” And I couldn't help but think that Whitman, for all his fierce beauty, might have been a bit too optimistic. We can hear others, reach out to them without moving, imagine them, and we are all connected by a crazy root system, like blades of grass—but this game makes me wonder if we can ever truly become someone else completely.
tr: “Yes,” I say. “I was just thinking the same thing.” And despite all of Whitman’s terrible beauty, I can’t help but think he might be a bit too optimistic. We can hear others, go to them without moving, imagine them, and like a bunch of blades of grass, we are all connected by a crazy root system... but this game makes me wonder if we can really become someone completely different.
es: —Yes —I answered him—. I was thinking the same thing. And I can't help but feel that Whitman, for his furious beauty, might have been too optimistic. We can hear others, and we can travel to them without moving, and we can imagine them, and we are all connected by a crazy root system, like leaves of grass, but the game makes me wonder if we can really become totally another.

en: We finally pass a jackknifed truck and get back up to speed, but Radar calculates in his head that we’ll need to average seventy-seven from here to Agloe. It has been one entire hour since Ben announced that he needed to pee, and the reason for this is simple: he is sleeping. At six o’clock exactly, he took NyQuil. He lay down in the wayback, and then Lacey and I strapped both seat belts around him. This made him even more uncomfortable, but 1. It was for his own good, and 2. We all knew that in twenty minutes, no discomfort would matter to him at all, because he would be dead asleep. And so he is now. He will be awoken at midnight. I have just put Lacey to bed now, at 9 P.M., in the same position in the backseat. We will wake her at 2 A.M. The idea is that everybody sleeps for a shift so we won’t be taping our eyelids open by tomorrow morning, when we come rolling into Agloe.
vi: Finally, we passed a heavy truck that had overturned, regaining our old speed. But according to Radar's calculations, we needed to drive seventy-seven miles per hour from here to Agloe. It had been exactly an hour since Ben declared he needed to pee, and the reason was quite simple: Ben was asleep. At exactly six o'clock, he drank NyQuil[10]. He lay down in the back row of seats. Lacey and I fastened both seat belts around him. That would make Ben more uncomfortable, but 1. It was better for him, and 2. We all knew that in twenty minutes, no discomfort would bother him, because Ben would be dead asleep. And that was exactly the case. He would wake up at midnight. I had just put Lacey to sleep at 9 PM, in the same position in the back seat. We would wake Lacey up at 2 AM. The plan was for each of us to get some sleep so that in the morning we wouldn't have to use our hands to prop our eyelids open as we entered Agloe.
tr: Finally, we pass by a truck lying on its side and speed up again, but Radar calculates that we need to maintain an average of one hundred twenty-four from here to Agloe. It has been exactly one hour since Ben announced that he needed to pee, and the reason is simple: he is sleeping. He took NyQuil exactly at six o'clock. He lay down in the back, and Lacey and I fastened both seat belts on him. This made him even more uncomfortable but 1. It was for his own good and 2. We all knew that within twenty minutes, no discomfort would matter to him because he would be sleeping like the dead. And right now, he is in exactly the position we predicted. He will be woken up at midnight. I just put Lacey to bed; at nine in the evening, in the same position, in the back seat. We will wake her up at two in the morning. The idea is: Everyone will sleep in turns, so that by the time we are about to enter Agloe in the early morning, we won't have to tape our eyelids open.
es: In the end, we passed by a truck whose trailer had become detached, and we accelerated again, but Radar mentally calculates that from here to Agloe we will have to maintain an average speed of one hundred and twenty-five kilometers per hour. It has been an hour since Ben announced that he needed to pee, and for a simple reason: he is sleeping. At six o'clock sharp, he took an antihistamine. He lay down in the back seat and Lacey and I fastened both seat belts for him, which made him feel even more uncomfortable, but 1) it was for his own good, and 2) we all knew that in twenty minutes he wouldn't care in the slightest about being uncomfortable, because he would be sleeping like a log. And right now he is. We will wake him up at twelve. A moment ago, at nine, I positioned Lacey to sleep in the back seat, in the same position. We will wake her up at two. The idea is that everyone sleeps in shifts so that tomorrow, when we arrive in Agloe, we won't be falling asleep.

en: The minivan has become a kind of very small house: I am sitting in the passenger seat, which is the den. This is, I think, the best room in the house: there is plenty of space, and the chair is quite comfortable.

es: The minivan has turned into a kind of tiny house. I am sitting in the passenger seat, which is the living room. I think it is the best room in the house. It is spacious and the seat is very comfortable.

en: Scattered about the carpet beneath the passenger seat is the office, which contains a map of the United States Ben got at the BP, the directions I printed out, and the scrap paper onto which Radar has scrawled his calculations about speed and distance. Radar sits in the driver’s seat. The living room. It is a lot like the den, only you can’t be as relaxed when you’re there. Also, it’s cleaner.

en: Between the living room and the den, we have the center console, or kitchen. Here we keep a plentiful supply of beef jerky and GoFast bars and this magical energy drink called Bluefin, which Lacey put on the shopping list. Bluefin comes in small, fancily contoured glass bottles, and it tastes like blue cotton candy. It also keeps you awake better than anything in all of human history, although it makes you a bit twitchy. Radar and I have agreed to keep drinking it until two hours before our rest periods. Mine starts at midnight, when Ben gets up.

Mine starts at twelve, when Ben gets up.

It is equipped with a surround sound speaker system. Admittedly, there is only a little over five square meters of living space. And you can't arrange everything on an open floor plan.

en: Just after we pass into South Carolina, I catch Radar yawning and insist upon a driver switch. I like driving, anyway—this vehicle may be a minivan, but it’s my minivan. Radar scoots out of his seat and into the first bedroom, while I grab the steering wheel and hold it steady, quickly stepping over the kitchen and into the driver’s seat.
vi: As soon as we arrived in South Carolina, I noticed Radar yawning, so I insisted on driving. Anyway, I like driving–this car is just a minivan, but it's my minivan. Radar slipped out of the driver's seat to bedroom number one, while I quickly grabbed the wheel, held it firmly, and swiftly moved from the kitchen to the driver's seat.

Radar shifts to one side of the seat and goes into the first room while I grip the steering wheel tightly, jump over the kitchen, and settle into the driver's seat.

en: Traveling, I am finding, teaches you a lot of things about yourself. For instance, I never thought myself to be the kind of person who pees into a mostly empty bottle of Bluefin energy drink while driving through South Carolina at seventy-seven miles per hour—but in fact I am that kind of person. Also, I never previously knew that if you mix a lot of pee with a little Bluefin energy drink, the result is this amazing incandescent turquoise color. It looks so pretty that I want to put the cap on the bottle and leave it in the cup holder so Lacey and Ben can see it when they wake up.
vi: I'm gradually realizing that only by traveling can I understand many things about myself. For instance, I never thought I was the kind of person who could pee into an almost empty Bluefin energy drink bottle while driving through South Carolina at seventy-seven miles per hour–but in reality, I am that kind of person. Moreover, I never realized that if you mix a fair amount of urine with a bit of Bluefin energy drink, the result would be a strangely bright turquoise color. The color was so beautiful that I wanted to cap the bottle and place it in the cup holder for Lacey and Ben to see when they woke up.
tr: I am discovering that traveling teaches you a lot about yourself. For instance, I never thought I was the type of person who would pee into a mostly empty Bluefin energy drink bottle while speeding through South Carolina at one hundred and twenty-four kilometers per hour. .. but it turns out I am that type of person. Also, I didn't know beforehand that mixing a little Bluefin energy drink with a large amount of pee would result in a surprisingly dazzling turquoise hue. It looks so beautiful that I want to cap the bottle and leave it in the cup holder so that Lacey and Ben can see it when they wake up.
es: I'm discovering that by traveling you learn many things about yourself. For example, I never thought I would be one of those people who pee in an almost empty bottle of Bluefin energy drink while driving through South Carolina at one hundred fifteen kilometers per hour, but it turns out I am. Additionally, I didn't know that if you mix a bunch of pee with a little Bluefin, the result is a surprisingly bright turquoise color. It's so pretty that it makes me want to put the cap on the bottle and leave it on the dashboard for Lacey and Ben to see when they wake up.

en: But Radar feels differently. “If you don’t throw that shit out the window right now, I’m ending our eleven-year friendship,” he says.
vi: But Radar had a different feeling. "If you don't throw that crap out the window right now, I will end our eleven-year friendship," it said.

es: But Radar does not think the same. "If you don't throw that crap out the window right now, I'll end our eleven years of friendship," he tells me.

en: “It’s not shit,” I say. “It’s pee.”
vi: "I didn't poop," I tried to argue. "I just peed."
tr: “Not poop,” I say. “Pee.”
es: —It's not shit —he replied—. It's pee.

en: “Out,” he says. And so I litter. In the side-view mirror, I can see the bottle hit the asphalt and burst open like a water balloon. Radar sees it, too.
vi: "Get out now," Radar said unemotionally. I had no choice but to throw it away. Through the side mirror, I saw the bottle hit the asphalt, shattering like a water balloon. Radar also glanced over.
tr: “Outside,” he says. Upon this, I throw out the garbage. In the side mirror, I can see the bottle hitting the asphalt and bursting like a water balloon. Radar sees it too.
es: —Out —he says to me. So I throw it. I see it in the side mirror landing on the asphalt and exploding like a water-filled balloon. Radar sees it too.

en: “Oh, my God,” Radar says. “I hope that’s like one of those traumatic events that is so damaging to my psyche that I just forget it ever happened.”
vi: “Oh, dear Lord,” it said. “I hope that it is just one of those terrible, nerve-wracking experiences that I will forget as soon as it happens.”

es: —Fuck —says Radar—. I hope this is one of those traumatic episodes that hurt my sensitivity so much that I directly forget they happened.

en: I never previously knew that it is possible to become tired of eating GoFast nutrition bars. But it is possible. I’m only two bites into my fourth of the day when my stomach turns. I pull open the center console and stick it back inside. We refer to this part of the kitchen as the pantry.
vi: I never thought that I could get tired of GoFast nutrition bars. But it turns out I can. After just two bites of the fourth bar of the day, my stomach started to churn. I opened the drawer in front of me and put it back in. We called that place the kitchen cabinet.
tr: I never knew it was possible to get tired of eating GoFast wafers. But it is possible. By the time I felt nauseous, I had only taken two bites of the fourth one of the day. I pull open the center console and put the GoFast inside. We call this part of the kitchen the pantry.
es: I didn't know it was possible to get tired of eating energy bars. But it is. I've only taken two bites of the fourth one today and my stomach turned. I open the middle glove compartment and leave it there. We call this part of the kitchen the pantry.

en: “I wish we had some apples,” Radar said. “God, wouldn’t an apple taste good right now?”

en: “Yeah,” Radar says. “I can’t stop tapping my fingers.” I look down. He is drumming his fingers silently against his knees. “I mean,” he says, “I actually cannot stop.”
vi: "Yeah," Radar replied. "I can't stop tapping my fingers." I looked down. Radar was silently tapping his fingers on his knee. "I really can't stop." “Alright, fine, I'm not tired.

es: —Yes —Radar answers me—. I can't keep my fingers still. I take a look and see him drumming his fingers on his knees. —I really can't stop —he tells me.

en: “Okay, yeah I’m not tired, so we’ll stay up till four and then we’ll get them up and we’ll sleep till eight.”
vi: Let's stay up until four o'clock, wake the other two up, and then we'll sleep until eight o'clock.”
tr: “Alright, yes, I'm not tired, so we will stay up until four, then wake them up and sleep until eight.”
es: —Well, I'm not tired, so we'll continue until four, then we'll wake them up and go to sleep until eight.

en: “Okay,” he says. There is a pause. The road has emptied out now; there is only me and the semitrucks, and I feel like my brain is processing information at eleven thousand times its usual pace, and it occurs to me that what I’m doing is very easy, that driving on the interstate is the easiest and most pleasant thing in the world: all I have to do is stay in between the lines and make sure that no one is too close to me and I am not too close to anyone and keep leaving. Maybe it felt like this for her, too, but I could never feel like this alone.
vi: “Agreed,” she replied. A pause. Now the road was empty, only us and the pickup trucks. I felt like my brain was processing information eleven thousand times faster than normal. It turned out that what I was doing was very simple, driving on the interstate was the simplest and most pleasant thing in the world: all I had to do was stay in my lane, make sure no one got too close to me and I didn't get too close to anyone, and keep going. Perhaps she felt the same way, but I could never feel like this if I were alone.
tr: “Okay,” he says. There is a pause. The road is now empty; only the trailer trucks and I are here, I feel my brain processing information at eleven thousand times its usual speed, and I realize that what I'm doing is very simple, that driving on the interstate is the easiest and most enjoyable thing in the world: All I have to do is stay between the lines, make sure no one is too close to me and that I'm not too close to anyone, and keep going. Maybe it felt the same way to Margo, but I could never feel this way alone.
es: —Okay —he answers me. We remained silent. Now the road has become empty. It's just me and the trucks, and I feel like my brain is processing information at a rate eleven thousand times faster than usual. I suddenly think that what I'm doing is very easy, that driving on the highway is the easiest and most pleasant thing in the world. The only thing I have to do is stay between the lines, make sure no one gets too close to me and that I don't get too close to anyone, and keep moving forward. Maybe Margo felt the same way too, but I would never have felt this way on my own.

es: Radar breaks the silence. —Well, if we're not going to sleep until four...

es: He finished his sentence: —Yes, maybe we could open another bottle of Bluefin.

en: And so we do.

es: And we opened it.

en: I turn on the radio. I find an oldies station. It’s the Beatles. The song is “Good Morning.” I turn it up some. No response. So Radar turns it up more. And then more. And then the chorus comes, and he starts singing along. And then I start singing along. I think it is finally my atonal screeching that awakes them.

By the chorus, it started singing along. I joined in too, and eventually, my off-key booming voice probably woke the two of them up.

Then the chorus comes, and Radar starts to sing along. Then I start to sing along too. I think in the end, it's my off-key screams that wake them up.

And when the chorus comes, he starts singing. And I start singing too. I think what finally wakes them up are my off-key notes.

en: He pauses, and there’s a kerfuffle in the darkness back there, and I wonder if he has some physical strategy for checking the fullness of his bladder. “I think I’m okay, actually,” he says.

en: She pulls into an all-night gas station, and I get out to stretch my rubbery legs. When Lacey comes racing back to the minivan, I’m sitting in the driver’s seat. I don’t even really know how I came to be sitting in the driver’s seat, why I end up there and not Lacey. She comes around to the front door, and she sees me there, and the window is open, and I say to her, “I can drive.” It’s my car, after all, and my mission. And she says, “Really, you’re sure?” and I say, “Yeah, yeah, I’m good to go,” and she just throws open the sliding door and lies down in the first row.
vi: Lacey pulled the car into an all-night gas station, and I got out to stretch my legs, now feeling like rubber. When Lacey returned, I was sitting in the driver's seat. I really didn't know how I ended up in the driver's seat, why I was sitting there instead of Lacey. At the car door, Lacey saw that I was settled in, with the window open. I said to Lacey, "Let me drive." It was my car, and ultimately, my mission. Lacey asked, "Really? Are you sure?" and I replied, "Yeah, yeah, I'm totally fine," so Lacey slid the door open and lay down in the back seat.
tr: I pull into a gas station that's open all night, and step outside to stretch my legs that feel like rubber. When Lacey runs back to the minivan, I'm in the driver's seat. I don't even know how I got into the driver's seat or why it was me instead of Lacey who ended up there. She turns and comes to the front door and sees me there, the window is open, and I say to her, "I can drive." After all, it's my car and my responsibility. "Are you really sure?" she says, and I reply, "Yes, yes, I'm good enough to go," Lacey just slides open the door and stretches out in the first row.
es: He pulls into a gas station that's open all night and I get out to stretch my legs. When Lacey comes running back to the car, I'm sitting in the driver's seat. I don't even know how I ended up in that seat, why I'm there instead of Lacey. She walks around to the front door and sees me. The window is rolled down. —I can drive —I tell him. After all, it is my car. And my mission. —Are you sure? —he asks me. —Yes, yes, I can continue. He opens the sliding door and lies down on the first seat.

en: “Yeah, but— I don’t know,” Ben says. I can feel him looking over at me, being Serious Ben. “Just— Just remember that sometimes, the way you think about a person isn’t the way they actually are. Like, I always thought Lacey was so hot and so awesome and so cool, but now when it actually comes to being with her . . . it’s not the exact same. People are different when you can smell them and see them up close, you know?”
vi: “Yeah, but—I don't know,” Ben said. “It's just—remember that sometimes your thoughts about someone don't match who they really are. For example, I used to always think Lacey was hot and amazing, but now actually being around her... it's not exactly like that. People become very different when you can smell them and see them up close, you know?”
tr: “Yes, but... I don't know,” says Ben. I can feel that he has turned into Serious Ben and is looking at me. “It's just... Just remember that sometimes people aren't exactly as you think they are. Like how I think Lacey is very sexy, very amazing, and very cool, but now when it comes to actually being with her... it's not exactly the same, people are different when you can feel them, when you can see them up close.”
es: —Yes, but... I don't know —says Ben. I notice that he is looking at me very seriously—. But... But remember that sometimes people are not how you think they are. For example, I always thought that Lacey was really hot, that she was incredible and cool, but now, when I'm actually with her... it's not the same. People are different when you can smell them and see them up close, you know?

vi: “I know,” I replied. I know how long I've been mistaken about Margo, how distorted my perception was.

es: —I know —I reply to him. I know that for a long time I have been wrong, and very much so, imagining her.

en: “I’m just saying that it was easy for me to like Lacey before. It’s easy to like someone from a distance. But when she stopped being this amazing unattainable thing or whatever, and started being, like, just a regular girl with a weird relationship with food and frequent crankiness who’s kinda bossy—then I had to basically start liking a whole different person.”
vi: “What I mean is that it used to be very easy for me to like Lacey. Liking someone from afar is always very easy. But when she was no longer a distant wonder, and started to become, well, an ordinary girl with weird eating habits, occasionally acting like a bully–basically, I had to start liking a completely different person.”
tr: “I'm just saying it was easy for me to like Lacey from a distance before. It's easy to love someone from afar. But when she stopped being surprisingly unattainable and started being an ordinary girl with a weird relationship with food, often cranky and a bit bossy... then I had to start liking a completely different person.”
es: —I’m just saying that it used to be easy for me to like Lacey. It’s easy to like someone from a distance. But when it stops being something incredible and unattainable and starts being a normal girl, with a strange relationship with food, quite grumpy and bossy… then basically I have to start liking a totally different person.

After all this—I’m twelve hours inside this car already and you don’t think I care about her because I don’t— ” I cut myself off. “You think that since you have a girlfriend you can stand atop the lofty mountain and lecture me? You can be such a—”

After all this–I've been in this car for twelve hours and you're saying I don't care about Margo because I don't–” I paused. “You think just because you have a girlfriend now, you can stand on a high horse and lecture me? You really are–”
tr: I can feel my cheeks burning. "Are you saying that I really don't like Margo? After all this... I've been in this car for twelve hours and you don't think I care about her because I...” I cut myself off. “Do you think you can stand on top of the high mountains and lecture me just because you have a girlfriend? So much...”
es: I feel my cheeks burning. —Are you telling me that I don't actually like Margo? After all this... I've been stuck in this car for twelve hours and you think I don't care about Margo because I don't... —I interrupt myself—. You think that just because you have a girlfriend you can climb up the mountain and preach to me? Sometimes you are so...

en: I stop talking because I see in the outer reaches of the headlights the thing that will shortly kill me.
vi: I stopped speaking because I saw ahead, outside the beam of the headlights, something that was about to ruin everything for me.
tr: I stop talking because outside, at the very edge of where the headlights can reach, I see the thing that will soon kill me.
es: I stay silent because at the end of the headlights' light, I see something that will soon kill me.

en: Two cows stand oblivious in the highway. They come into view all at once, a spotted cow in the left lane, and in our lane an immense creature, the entire width of our car, standing stock-still, her head turned back as she appraises us with blank eyes. The cow is flawlessly white, a great white wall of cow that cannot be climbed or ducked or dodged. It can only be hit. I know that Ben sees it, too, because I hear his breath stop.
vi: Two cows stood innocently in the middle of the highway. In a flash, we saw them: the spotted one in the left lane, and in our lane, a gigantic creature, as wide as the car, standing motionless. It turned its head and calmly looked at us with indifferent eyes. The cow was completely white without a single spot, a white wall of a cow that couldn't be jumped over, crawled under, or circled around. The only option was to crash into it. I knew Ben had seen it too, because I heard Ben's breath stop abruptly.
tr: Two cows are standing on the main road with indifferent attitudes. They suddenly appear; a spotted cow in the left lane and in our lane, a massive creature the width of a car stands completely motionless, its head turned backward as it tries to perceive us. The cow is perfectly white; an enormous white wall made of cow, which cannot be climbed over, passed under, or bypassed. The only option is to crash. I know Ben sees it too because I hear his breath catch.
es: In the middle of the highway, there are two cows so calm. They suddenly appear in my field of vision, one cow with black spots in the left lane, and in our lane, an immense creature, the size of our car, completely motionless, with its head turned back, staring at us with blank eyes. It is absolutely white, an enormous white wall of cow that we cannot jump over, pass under, or avoid. We can only crash into it. I know that Ben sees it too, because I hear him stop breathing.

en: They say that your life flashes before your eyes, but for me that is not the case. Nothing flashes before my eyes except this impossibly vast expanse of snowy fur, now only a second from us. I don’t know what to do. No, that’s not the problem. The problem is that there is nothing to do, except to hit this white wall and kill it and us, both. I slam on the brakes, but out of habit not expectation: there is absolutely no avoiding this. I raise my hands off the steering wheel. I do not know why I am doing this, but I raise my hands up, as if I am surrendering. I’m thinking the most banal thing in the world: I am thinking that I don’t want this to happen. I don’t want to die. I don’t want my friends to die. And to be honest, as the time slows down and my hands are in the air, I am afforded the chance to think one more thought, and I think about her. I blame her for this ridiculous, fatal chase—for putting us at risk, for making me into the kind of jackass who would stay up all night and drive too fast. I would not be dying were it not for her. I would have stayed home, as I have always stayed home, and I would have been safe, and I would have done the one thing I have always wanted to do, which is to grow up.
vi: They say that life flashes before your eyes, but for me, it wasn't like that. Nothing flashed before my eyes except this vast, impossibly white expanse, now just seconds away from us. I didn't know what to do. No, that wasn't the issue. The issue was that there was nothing to do except crash into that white wall, destroying it and us, both sides. I slammed on the brakes, out of habit rather than hoping to change the outcome: it was clearly unavoidable. I raised my hands off the steering wheel. I didn't know why I did it, but I raised my hands, as if surrendering. I thought about the most mundane thing in the world: that I didn't want this to happen. I didn't want to die. I didn't want my friends to die. And honestly, as time slowed down and my hands were in the air, I had the chance for one more thought, and I thought of her. I blamed her for this deadly, ridiculous chase—for putting us at risk, for turning me into a fool driving like a maniac all night. If it weren't for her, I wouldn't be dying. I would have been at home, because I always stayed home, I would have been safe, and I would have been doing what I always wanted to do, which was to grow up.
tr: They say that your life flashes before your eyes like a film strip, but that's not the case for me. Before my eyes, nothing passes except for this incredibly vast, snow-like fur that is now just a second away from us. I don't know what to do. No, that's not the problem. The problem is that there's nothing to do except crash into this white wall and kill both it and ourselves. I'm slamming on the brakes out of habit, with no expectation: it's impossible to avoid this. I take my hands off the steering wheel and raise them up. I don't know why I'm doing this, but I raise my hands, as if I'm surrendering. I'm thinking about the most boring thing in the world: I'm thinking that I don't want this to happen. I don't want to die. I don't want my friends to die. Also, to be honest, as time slows down and my hands are in the air, I have the strength for one more thought and I think of Margo. I blame her for this absurd, deadly chase... for putting us in danger; for turning me into the kind of fool who drives fast all night without sleeping. If it weren't for her, I wouldn't be dying. I would be at home as always, safe, and doing the only thing I've ever wanted to do, which is to grow up.
es: They say that life flashes before your eyes, but in my case, it isn't like that. Nothing flashes before my eyes except that enormous expanse of white fur, now just a second away from us. I don't know what to do. No, that's not the problem. The problem is that there's nothing to do, except crash into that white wall, kill it and kill ourselves. I hit the brakes, but out of habit, without expectations. There's no way to avoid it. I don't know why, but I raise my hands, as if surrendering. I think about the most banal thing in the world: that I don't want it to happen. I don't want to die. I don't want my friends to die. And to be honest, as time slows down and my hands are in the air, I allow myself to think of one more thing, and I think of Margo. I blame her for this ridiculous and fatal chase... for putting us in danger, for turning me into an idiot who spends the night sleepless and drives too fast. I wouldn't be about to die if it weren't for her. I would have stayed home, as always, and would have been safe, and would have done the only thing I've always wanted to do, which is to grow up.

en: Having surrendered control of the vessel, I am surprised to see a hand on the steering wheel. We are turning before I realize why we are turning, and then I realize that Ben is pulling the wheel toward him, turning us in a hopeless attempt to miss the cow, and then we are on the shoulder and then on the grass. I can hear the tires spinning as Ben turns the wheel hard and fast in the opposite direction. I stop watching. I don’t know if my eyes close or if they just cease to see. My stomach and my lungs meet in the middle and crush each other. Something sharp hits my cheek. We stop.
vi: Having surrendered control of the car, I was surprised to see a hand on the steering wheel. We turned before I realized why we were turning, and saw Ben pulling the steering wheel towards him, twisting it in a desperate attempt to avoid the cow. We skidded onto the shoulder and then onto the grass. I heard the tires screeching as Ben jerked the wheel in the opposite direction. I stopped looking. I didn't know if it was because my eyes were closed, or because my eyes could no longer see anything. My stomach and lungs collided in my chest. Something sharp cut across my cheek. We came to a stop.

en: I don’t know why, but I touch my face. I pull my hand back and there is a streak of blood. I touch my arms with my hands, hugging my arms to myself, but I am only checking to make sure that they are there, and they are. I look at my legs. They are there. There is some glass. I look around. Bottles are broken. Ben is looking at me. Ben is touching his face. He looks okay. He holds himself as I held myself. His body still works. He is just looking at me. In the rearview mirror, I can see the cow. And now, belatedly, Ben screams. He is staring at me and screaming, his mouth all the way open, the scream low and guttural and terrified. He stops screaming. Something is wrong with me. I feel faint. My chest is burning. And then I gulp air. I had forgotten to breathe. I had been holding my breath the whole time. I feel much better when I start up again. In through the nose, out through the mouth.

The bottles were broken. Ben was looking at me. Ben was touching his face. He looked fine. He also hugged himself like I did. His body was still functioning. He just looked at me. Something was wrong with me. I felt like I was fainting. My chest was burning. Then I gasped for air. I had forgotten to breathe. I hadn't been breathing that whole time. I felt better when I could breathe again. Inhale through the nose, exhale through the mouth.

Then I gasp for air. I had forgotten to breathe. I had been holding my breath all that time. I feel much better when I catch it. “Inhale through the nose, exhale through the mouth.”

en: “Who is hurt?!” Lacey shouts. She’s unbuckled herself from her sleeping position and she’s leaning into the wayback. When I turn around, I can see that the back door has popped open, and for a moment I think that Radar has been thrown from the car, but then he sits up. He is running his hands over his face, and he says, “I’m okay. I’m okay. Is everyone okay?”

He quickly runs his hands over his face and says, “I'm fine. I'm fine. Is everyone okay?”

When I turn around, I see that the back door has opened, and for a moment I think Radar has shot out of the car, but suddenly he gets up. He runs his hands over his face. —I'm fine. I'm fine. Are you all okay? —he asks.

en: Lacey doesn’t even respond; she just jumps forward, between Ben and me. She is leaning over the apartment’s kitchen, and she looks at Ben. She says, “Sweetie, where are you hurt?” Her eyes are overfull of water like a swimming pool on a rainy day. And Ben says, “I’mfineI’mfineQisbleeding.”
vi: Lacey didn't respond; she jumped forward, between me and Ben. Lacey bent down in the kitchen of the apartment, looking at Ben and asked, "Where does it hurt, honey?" Lacey's eyes were brimming with tears like a swimming pool on a rainy day. And Ben replied, "It'sokit'sokQyou'rebleeding."

es: Lacey doesn't even answer. She jumps forward, between Ben and me. She leans on the kitchen counter and looks at Ben. —Honey, where did you hurt yourself? Her eyes are filled with water, like a swimming pool on a rainy day. —I'm fine, I'm fine. You're bleeding.

en: She turns to me, and I shouldn’t cry but I do, not because it hurts, but because I am scared, and I raised my hands, and Ben saved us, and now there is this girl looking at me, and she looks at me kind of the way a mom does, and that shouldn’t crack me open, but it does. I know the cut on my cheek isn’t bad, and I’m trying to say so, but I keep crying. Lacey is pressing against the cut with her fingers, thin and soft, and shouting at Ben for something to use as a bandage, and then I’ve got a small swath of the Confederate flag pressed against my cheek just to the right of my nose. She says, “Just hold it there tight; you’re fine does anything else hurt?” and I say no. That’s when I realize that the car is still running, and still in gear, stopped only because I’m still standing on the brakes. I put it into park and turn it off. When I turn it off, I can hear liquid leaking—not dripping so much as pouring.
vi: Lacey turned to me. I shouldn't have cried but I did. It wasn't because of the pain, but because I was scared, I raised my hand, Ben saved us, and now this girl was looking at me, like the way my mother used to, and that shouldn't have broken me, but it did. I knew the scratch on my face was nothing, and I tried to say that, but I kept crying. Lacey pressed on the scratch with her slender, soft fingers, telling Ben to find something to bandage it. And then a strip of the Union flag was pressed against my right cheek, near my nose. Lacey said, "Just hold it tight, it'll be okay, are you hurt anywhere else?" and I said no. At that moment I realized the car engine was still running, the engine was still on, the car had stopped only because I was still pressing the brake. I shifted to park and turned off the engine. Only then did I hear the sound of liquid flowing—not dripping but gushing.
tr: Lacey is turning to me, I shouldn't cry but I am crying, not because I am hurt, but because I am scared, because I raised my hands and Because Ben saved me, there is now a girl looking after me, and she looks at me in a way a mother would, which shouldn't make me feel vulnerable, but it does. I know the cut on my cheek isn't bad and I'm trying to say so, but I keep crying. Lacey gently and softly presses on the cut with her fingers and yells at Ben to find something that can be used as a bandage; then I have a bandage made from a Confederate flag pressed against my cheek, just to the right of my nose. Lacey says, "Hold it there tightly; it's okay, does anything else hurt?" and I say no. At that moment, I realize the car is still running, in gear, and only stopped because I am still pressing the brake. I shift the car into park and turn off the engine. When I turn it off, I can hear a liquid flowing... It's not dripping, more like pouring.
es: She turns towards me, and I shouldn't cry, but I cry, not because it hurts, but because I'm scared, I raised my hands, and Ben has saved us, and now this girl looks at me, and she looks at me like a mother, and I shouldn't break, but I break. I know the cut on my cheek is not serious, and I try to say it, but I keep crying. Lacey presses the cut with her fingers, thin and soft, and yells at Ben to give her something that can serve as a bandage, and suddenly I have a strip of the Confederate flag stuck to my cheek, just to the right of my nose. —Squeeze it for a moment —he tells me—. It's nothing. Did you hurt yourself more? I tell him no. Then I realize that the car is still running, that it is only stopped because I am still pressing the brake. I put it in neutral and turn it off. When I turn it off, I hear it leaking fluid. More than dripping, it's gushing.

en: I’m assessing damage when Ben finally schleps back to the car. But other than that, it looks immaculate. No other dents. No windows broken. No flat tires. I walk around to close the back door and appraise the 210 broken bottles of beer, still bubbling. Lacey finds me and puts an arm around me. We are both staring at the rivulet of foaming beer flowing into the drainage ditch beneath us. “What happened?” she asks.

en: “Hey,” I say, grabbing at Ben’s New Balances. “Hey, come out here.” He scoots his way out, and I offer him my hand and help him up. His hands are black with car gunk. I grab him and hug him. If I had not ceded control of the wheel, and if he had not assumed control of the vessel so deftly, I’m sure I’d be dead. “Thank you,” I say, pounding his back probably too hard. “That was the best damned passenger-seat driving I’ve ever seen in my life.”

I put my arm around his shoulder. If I hadn't surrendered the wheel, and if he hadn't acted in time, I would have been a goner for sure. “Thanks, man,” I said, patting him on the back, probably a bit too hard. “In my entire life, I've never seen such an impressive steering maneuver from the passenger seat.”

I hug him. If I hadn't let go of the steering wheel, and if he hadn't taken control so skillfully, I'm sure I would be dead. —Thanks —I say, patting him on the back, probably too hard—. You are the best co-pilot I have ever seen in my life.
