tr: Lacey is leaning over the counter, her hand on Ben's shoulder. "So, you're a hero, did you realize that? They give medals for things like this."
es: Lacey moves forward to the kitchen and places a hand on Ben's knee. —You are a hero, do you realize that? —he says to him—. They give medals for things like this.

en: “I’ve said it before and I’ll say it again: I wasn’t thinking about none of y’all. I. Wanted. To. Save. My. Ass.”
vi: "I already said it and I'll say it again: I can't think of anyone else." "I. Want." "To. Save. My." "Own." "Ass."
tr: “I said it before and I will say it again: I wasn't thinking about any of you. My own. Ass. To save. I wanted.”
es: —I have said it before and I repeat it now: I have not thought about any of you. What I wanted was to save my own skin.

en: “You liar. You heroic, adorable liar,” she says, and then plants a kiss on his cheek.
vi: "Nonsense." "You are a lovable liar with heroic qualities," Lacey said and gave it a big kiss on the cheek.
tr: "You liar. You brave, adorable liar," she says and plants a kiss on his cheek.
es: —Liar. Heroic and adorable liar —says Lacey. And he gives her a kiss on the cheek.

en: Radar says, “Hey guys, do you remember that time I was double-seat-belted in the wayback and the door flew open and the beer fell out but I survived completely uninjured? How is that even possible?”
vi: Radar continued, "Do you guys remember that time when I was sleeping in the back seat and talking in my sleep, and the car door suddenly opened and beer poured all over me, but I felt completely fine? I don't remember how it happened, it's so miraculous!"
tr: Radar, "Hey kids, do you remember the time I was strapped in the back with a double seatbelt, my door suddenly opened, and the beer spilled but I definitely escaped without injury?" "How could that be possible?" he says.
es: —Hey, guys, do you remember that time when I was lying in the back, with both seat belts on, and the door suddenly opened, all the beers broke, but I survived completely unscathed? —says Radar—. How is that possible?

en: “Let’s play metaphysical I Spy,” Lacey says. “I Spy with my little eye a hero’s heart, a heart that beats not for itself but for all humanity.”
vi: "Let's play the Metaphysical I Spy game," Lacey suggested. "I spy with my little eye a heroic heart, a heart that beats not for itself but for all of humanity."
tr: “Let's play I See Metaphysics,” says Lacey. “Right now, I see a hero's heart around, a heart that beats not for itself, but for humanity.”
es: —Let's play metaphysical I spy —says Lacey—. I spy the heart of a hero, a heart that beats not for itself, but for all humanity.

en: “I’M NOT BEING MODEST. I JUST DIDN’T WANT TO DIE,” Ben exclaims.
vi: “WHO CARES ABOUT HUMILITY. I JUST DON'T WANT TO DIE,” Ben shouted.
tr: “I'M NOT BEING MODEST. I JUST DIDN'T WANT TO DIE,” Ben shouts.
es: —I'M NOT BEING HUMBLE. I SIMPLY DIDN'T WANT TO DIE —exclaims Ben.

en: “Do you guys remember that one time, in the minivan, twenty minutes ago, that we somehow didn’t die?”
vi: "Do you remember back then on that tiny car twenty minutes ago when we didn't end up dead?"
tr: "Kids, do you remember that one time in the minivan, twenty minutes ago, when we somehow didn't die?""
es: —Guys, do you remember that time, in the car, twenty minutes ago, when for some reason we didn't die?

en: Hour Fourteen
vi: The fourteenth hour
tr: Fourteenth Hour
es: HOUR FOURTEEN

en: Once the initial shock passes, we clean. We try to shepherd as much glass from the broken Bluefin bottles as possible onto pieces of paper and then gather them into a single bag for later disposal. The minivan’s carpet is soaked with sticky Mountain Dew and Bluefin and Diet Coke, and we try to sop it up with the few napkins we’ve collected. But this will require a serious car wash, at the very least, and there’s no time for that before Agloe. Radar has looked up the side panel replacement I’ll need: $300 plus paint. The cost of this trip keeps going up, but I’ll make it back this summer working in my dad’s office, and anyway, it’s a small ransom to pay for Margo.
vi: Coming back to our senses, we started cleaning up. The whole group tried to gather all the broken Bluefin bottle pieces into paper, putting them all into a bag to throw away later. The car floor mat was soaked with Mountain Dew, Bluefin, and sticky Coke, and we tried to absorb it with paper towels. We definitely needed to wash the car thoroughly, but there was no time for that before reaching Agloe. Radar had looked up the cost to replace the sliding door: $300 plus painting. The trip expenses were slowly adding up, but I would work at my dad's office this summer to make up for it; after all, it was a small ransom to pay for Margo.
tr: As soon as the initial shock of the incident passes, we start cleaning up the area. We try to sweep as much glass as possible from the broken Bluefin bottles onto pieces of paper and then collect everything into a single bag to dispose of later. The minivan's carpet is soaked with sticky Mountain Dew, Bluefin, and diet cola, and we attempt to dry it with a few napkins we've gathered. But we'll need to go to a car wash, and we don't have time for that before Agloe. Radar checked how much it would cost to replace the necessary side panel for the minivan: $300 plus paint. The cost of this trip keeps rising. but I will make up for it by working at my father's office this summer, and besides, it will be a small atonement for Margo.
es: Once we got over the initial shock, we cleaned up. We tried to gather all the pieces of Bluefin bottle glass onto sheets of paper and put them in a plastic bag to throw away later. The minivan's carpets are sticky and soaked with Mountain Dew, Bluefin, and Diet Coke, and we tried to dry them with the few tissues we had. But the car would need a good cleaning, at the very least, and we don't have time before we get to Agloe. Radar has looked up what it will cost me to replace the side panel: 300 dollars plus the paint. This trip is getting more expensive, but I'll be able to pay back the money this summer, working at my dad's office, and anyway, it's not such a high price considering it's for Margo.

en: The sun is rising to our right. My cheek is still bleeding. The Confederate flag is stuck to the wound now, so I no longer need to hold it there.
vi: The sun rose on the right. My cheek was still bleeding. The Confederate flag had stuck to the wound, so I didn't have to hold it tightly anymore.
tr: The sun is rising from our right. My cheek is still burning. The Confederate flag is now stuck to the wound, so I no longer need to hold it there.
es: The sun begins to rise on our right. My cheek is still bleeding. Now the Confederate flag has stuck to the wound, so I no longer have to hold it.

en: Hour Fifteen
vi: Fifteenth hour
tr: The Confederate flag is now stuck to the wound, so I no longer need to hold it there.
es: FIFTEENTH HOUR

en: A thin stand of oak trees obscures the cornfields that stretch out to the horizon. The landscape changes, but nothing else. Big interstates like this one make the country into a single place: McDonald’s, BP, Wendy’s. I know I should probably hate that about interstates and yearn for the halcyon days of yore, back when you could be drenched in local color at every turn— but whatever. I like this. I like the consistency. I like that I can drive fifteen hours from home without the world changing too much. Lacey double-belts me down in the wayback. “You need the rest,” she says. “You’ve been through a lot.” It’s amazing that no one has yet blamed me for not being more proactive in the battle against the cow.
vi: A sparse line of oaks stood on the edge of cornfields stretching endlessly to the horizon. The scenery changed, but nothing else did. Interstate highways like this one made the countryside feel like just one place: McDonald’s, BP, Wendy’s. I know I probably hated the interstates and longed for the leisurely days of old, where every turn was steeped in familiar urban hues—but never mind. I like it this way. I like the continuity. I like that I can drive away from home for fifteen hours straight and the world doesn’t change too much. Lacey strapped me in the back seat with both seat belts. “You need to rest,” Lacey said. “You’ve been through a lot.” Surprisingly, no one blamed me for being so sluggish in the battle with the cow.
tr: A sparse line of oak trees slightly conceals my cornfields stretching to the horizon. The scenery changes, but everything else remains the same. Highways like this turn the country into a single place: McDonald’s, BP, Wendy’s. I probably should hate this aspect of highways and long for the golden days of yore, when every corner was surrounded by local colors and such... but I don't care. I love it. I love the consistency. I love being able to travel fifteen hours from home without the world changing too much. Lacey straps me in the back with a double seatbelt. “You need to rest,” she says. “You've been through a lot.” It's amazing that no one has accused me of not being more cautious in the fight against the cow.
es: A group of oak trees hides the cornfields that stretch to the horizon. The landscape changes, but nothing else. Highways like this one turn the country into a single place: McDonald’s, BP, and Wendy’s. I know I probably should hate this aspect of highways and long for the happy days of the past, when you could soak up the local color of each place, but oh well. I like it. I like the regularity. I like driving fifteen hours straight from home without the world changing too much. Lacey fastens my seat belts. —You need to rest —he tells me—. You've had a tough time. I am surprised that no one has blamed me for not knowing how to react in the battle against the cow.

en: As I trail off, I hear them making one another laugh—not the words exactly, but the cadence, the rising and falling pitches of banter. I like just listening, just loafing on the grass. And I decide that if we get there on time but don’t find her, that’s what we’ll do: we’ll drive around the Catskills and find a place to sit around and hang out, loafing on the grass, talking, telling jokes. Maybe the sure knowledge that she is alive makes all of that possible again—even if I never see proof of it. I can almost imagine a happiness without her, the ability to let her go, to feel our roots are connected even if I never see that leaf of grass again.
vi: Lying quietly, I could hear my friends teasing each other and laughing – not the exact words, but the intonation, the highs and lows in their stories. I liked just listening, just peacefully lying on the grass. And I decided that if we arrived on time and didn’t see Margo, the next thing we would do was: drive around Catskill, find a spot to sit aimlessly, peacefully on the grass, talk, and joke with each other. Maybe just knowing for sure that Margo was alive would make everything possible again – even though I never actually saw any evidence of that. I could almost imagine being happy without her, being able to let her go, feeling our roots intertwined, even though I might never see that patch of grass again.
tr: As I slowly drift away, I hear them making each other laugh. .. Not exactly the words, but the rhythm, the rising and falling tones of their banter. I just love listening, just idling on the grass. And if we get there on time but can't find him, I've decided what we'll do: We'll drive around the Catskills, idling on the grass, talking, joking, finding a place to sit idly and hang out. Maybe the certainty of his being alive will make these things possible again... even if I don't see proof of his being alive. The happiness without him, the power to let him go, Even if I never see the blade of grass again, I feel like I can imagine what it is like to feel that our roots are connected.
es: While I fall asleep, I hear them making each other laugh. I don't hear the exact words, just the cadence, the rises and falls of their conversation. I like to listen while lying on the grass. And I decide that if we arrive on time but don't find Margo, that's what we'll do. We'll find a spot in Catskill to spend some time, lie on the grass, chat, and joke around. Maybe knowing that she's alive makes it possible again, even though I have no proof that she is. I can almost imagine happiness without her, my ability to let her go, to feel that our roots are connected even if I never see that blade of grass again.

en: When I wake up, Radar and Ben are loudly debating the name of the car. Ben would like to name it Muhammad Ali, because, just like Muhammad Ali, the minivan takes a punch and keeps going. Radar says you can’t name a car after a historical figure. He thinks the car ought to be called Lurlene, because it sounds right.
vi: When I woke up, Ben and Radar were having a heated debate about the name of the car. Ben wanted to name it Muhammad Ali because, like Muhammad Ali, this minivan could take a hit and keep on going. Radar said you can't name a car after a historical figure. He thought it should be named Lurlene, because it sounded nice.
tr: When I wake up, Radar and Ben are loudly arguing about the name of the car. Ben wants to name it Muhammad Ali because the minivan keeps going despite taking punches, just like Muhammad Ali. Radar says a car can't be named after a historical figure. He thinks the car should be named Lurlene because it sounds right.
es: When I wake up, Radar and Ben are loudly arguing about the name of the car. Ben would like to call it Muhammad Ali, because, like Muhammad Ali, the minivan takes a punch and keeps going. Radar says you can't name a car after a historical figure. He thinks it should be called Lurlene, because it sounds nice.

en: “You want to name it Lurlene?” Ben asks, his voice rising with the horror of it all. “Hasn’t this poor vehicle been through enough?!”
vi: “Do you really want to name it Lurlene?” Ben asked, his voice rising in apparent fear. “Hasn't this poor car suffered enough?”
tr: “Do you want to name it Lurlene?” Ben asks, his voice rising in horror. “Hasn't this poor vehicle been through enough?!”
es: —Do you want to call it Lurlene? —asks Ben, raising his voice, horrified—. Hasn't this poor vehicle already been through enough?

en: I unbuckle one seat belt and sit up. Lacey turns around to me. “Good morning,” she says. “Welcome to the great state of New York.”
vi: I unfastened my seatbelt and sat up. Lacey turned to me. "Good morning," Lacey said. "Welcome to the great state of New York."
tr: I unbuckle one of the seat belts and sit up straight. Lacey turns to me. “Good morning,” she says. “Welcome to the great state of New York.”
es: I unbuckle a belt and sit down. Lacey turns around. —Good morning —he says to me—. Welcome to the great state of New York.

en: “What time is it?”
vi: "What time is it?"
tr: “What time is it?”
es: —What time is it?

en: “Nine forty-two.” Her hair is pulled back in a ponytail, but the shorter strands have strayed. “How’s it going?” she asks.
vi: "Nine forty-two." Lacey's hair was tied up, but some shorter strands had fallen out. "How do you feel?"
tr: "Nine forty-two." Her hair is tied in a ponytail, but shorter strands are loose. "How's it going?" she asks.
es: —Nine forty-two. —She has tied her hair back in a ponytail, but the shorter strands are loose—. How are you?

en: I tell her. “I’m scared.”
vi: Lacey asked. I replied, "Scared."
tr: I am telling her. “I am scared.”
es: —Scared —I answered.

en: Lacey smiles at me and nods. “Yeah, me, too. It’s like there’s too many things that could happen to prepare for all of them.”
vi: Lacey looked at me, smiled, and nodded. "Yeah, me too. It's as if too many things can happen to be ready for all of this."
tr: Lacey smiles at me and nods her head. "Yes, me too. There seems to be too much for us to be prepared for everything."
es: Lacey smiles at me and nods. —Yes, me too. It's as if too many things could happen to be prepared for all of them.

en: “Yeah,” I say.
vi: "Yes," I replied.
tr: “Yes,” I say.
es: —Yes —I comment.

en: “I hope you and me stay friends this summer,” she says. And that helps, for some reason. You can never tell what is going to help.
vi: "I hope we will still be friends this summer," Lacey said. Somehow, hearing that made me feel better. We can never tell what will make us feel better.
tr: “I hope we stay friends this summer,” he says. And somehow, it helps. You never know what will help.
es: —I hope we continue being friends this summer —he tells me. And for some reason, I feel better. You never know what will make you feel better.

en: Radar is now saying that the car should be called the Gray Goose. I lean forward a little so everyone can hear me and say, “The Dreidel. The harder you spin it, the better it performs.”
vi: Radar is saying that this car should be named Gray Goose. I leaned forward a bit so everyone could hear and said, "The Top. The harder you throw it, the faster it spins."
tr: Radar now says that the car's name should be Grey Goose. I lean forward a bit so that everyone can hear me. “Swivel. The harder you turn it, the better it works.”
es: Radar is saying that the car should be called Gray Goose. I move forward a bit so everyone can hear me. —The Dreidel. The more you spin it, the better it works.

en: Ben nods. Radar turns around. “I think you should be the official stuff-namer.”
vi: Ben nodded. Radar turned back. "I think you should be the object identification expert."
tr: He nods his head in approval. Radar turns around. “I think you should be the official namer.”
es: Ben nods. Radar turns around. —I think you should be the official namer.

en: Hour Twenty
vi: The twentieth hour
tr: Twentieth Hour
es: TWENTIETH HOUR

en: I’m sitting in the first bedroom with Lacey. Ben drives. Radar’s navigating. I was asleep when they last stopped, but they picked up a map of New York. Agloe isn’t marked, but there are only five or six intersections north of Roscoe. I always thought of New York as being a sprawling and endless metropolis, but here it is just lush rolling hills that the minivan heroically strains its way up. When there’s a lull in the conversation and Ben reaches for the radio knob, I say, “Metaphysical I Spy!”
vi: I'm sitting in bedroom number one with Lacey. Ben is driving. Radar is navigating. I was still asleep when we made our last stop, but the others had bought a map of New York. Agloe wasn't on the map, but there were only about five or six intersections north of Roscoe. I still thought of New York as a bustling metropolis, but at the moment there were only rolling, densely wooded hills that the minivan had to bravely climb. For a while, no one said anything, then Ben reached out to turn on the radio, and I said, "Let's play Metaphysical I Spy!"
tr: I'm sitting with Lacey in the first bedroom. Ben is driving the car. Radar is browsing the internet. When they last stopped, I was sleeping, but they got a map of New York. Agloe is not marked, but there are only five or six intersections north of Roscoe. I always thought of New York as an expanding and endless metropolis, but here there are only lush, rolling hills that the minivan heroically struggles to climb. When the conversation gets a bit interrupted, Ben doesn't reach for the radio button; I say, "I See Metaphysics!"
es: I am sitting in the first room with Lacey. Ben is driving. Radar is navigating. The last time they stopped, I was asleep, but they bought a map of New York. Agloe does not appear, but to the north of Roscoe, there are only five or six crossings. I had always thought that New York was an infinitely sprawling metropolis, but here you only see hills that the minivan heroically ascends. The conversation pauses for a moment, and Ben leans over to turn on the radio. —I spy something metaphysical —I say.

en: Ben starts. “I Spy with my little eye something I really like.”
vi: Ben started. "I Spy with my little eye, something that I really like."
tr: I'm starting. "Right now, I see something around that I really like."
es: Ben starts. —I spy something that I like a lot.

en: “Oh, I know,” Radar says. “It’s the taste of balls.”
vi: “Oh, I know,” Radar replied. “The taste of beer.”
tr: "Ah, I know well," says Radar. "The taste of testicles."
es: —I know —says Radar—. The taste of balls.

en: “No.”
vi: "No."
tr: “No.”
es: No.

en: “Is it the taste of penises?” I guess.
vi: "The taste of different types of newspapers, right?" I guessed.
tr: "The taste of penises?" I guess.
es: —The taste of the chicks? —I ask.

en: “No, dumbass,” Ben says.
vi: "No, that's worse!" Ben replied.
tr: "No, idiot," says Ben.
es: —No, dumbass —Ben replies to me.

en: “Hmm,” says Radar. “Is it the smell of balls?”
vi: “Hmm,” Radar continued. “Or is it the smell of balls?” "The feeling of the surface of the marble?"
tr: “Hmm,” says Radar. “The smell of testicles?”
es: —Hmm —says Radar—. The smell of the balls?

en: “The texture of balls?” I guess.
vi: I guessed further.
tr: "The texture of the testicles?" I guess.
es: —The texture of the balls? —I ask.

en: “Come on, asshats, it has nothing to do with genitalia. Lace?”
vi: "Stop it, you pervert, it has nothing to do with the male urinary organ." "What do you guess, Lace?"
tr: “Come on, assholes, it has nothing to do with genitals. Lace?” “So, how does it feel knowing you saved three lives?”
es: —Come on, idiots, it has nothing to do with genitals. Lace?

en: “Um, is it the feeling of knowing you just saved three lives?”
vi: "Yes, is it the feeling of knowing that you just saved three lives?"
tr: Lace?” “So, how does it feel knowing you saved three lives?”
es: —Hmm, the feeling of knowing that you have saved three lives?

en: “No. And I think you guys are out of guesses.”
vi: "No, all reasoning is exhausted."
tr: “No. And your guesses are exhausted.”
es: —No, and I think you two have no more turns left to guess.

en: “Okay, what is it?”
vi: “Alright, so what is it?”
tr: ‘Okay, what is it?”
es: —Okay, what is it?

en: “Lacey,” he says, and I can see him looking at her through the rearview.
vi: "It's Lacey," Ben replied, and I saw him watching her through the rearview mirror.
tr: “Lacey,” he says, and I can see that he is looking at Lacey through the rearview mirror.
es: —Lacey —she replies. I see him looking at her through the rearview mirror.

en: “Dumbass,” I say, “it’s supposed to be metaphysical I Spy. It has to be things that can’t be seen.”
vi: “Off-topic,” I said, “we're playing the metaphysical version of I Spy. It has to be something that can't be seen with the naked eye.”
tr: "Idiot," I say, "It should be Seeing Metaphysics. There have to be invisible things."
es: —Asshole —I tell him—, it's supposed to be a metaphysical I spy. They have to be things that can't be seen.

en: “And it is,” he says. “That’s what I really like—Lacey but not the visible Lacey.”
vi: “That's it,” Ben argued. “That's exactly what I like – Lacey, but not the Lacey you can see with the naked eye.”
tr: “And so it is,” he says. “This is really what I like... Lacey, but not the visible Lacey.”
es: —And it is —he answers me—. And it is what I like the most... Lacey, but not the Lacey that is seen.

en: “Oh, hurl,” Radar says, but Lacey unbuckles her seat belt and leans forward over the kitchen to whisper something in his ear. Ben blushes in response.
vi: "Oh, I feel like throwing up," Radar groaned, but Lacey unbuckled her seatbelt, leaned over the seat, and whispered something into Ben's ear. His face immediately turned bright red.
tr: “Ah, you're bluffing,” says Radar, but Lacey unbuckles her seatbelt and leans forward over the kitchen to whisper something in his ear. In response, Ben blushes.
es: —I'm going to vomit —says Radar. But Lacey unbuckles her seatbelt and leans over the kitchen to whisper something in Ben's ear. Ben turns red.

en: “Okay, I promise not to be a cheese ball,” Radar says. “I Spy with my little eye something we’re all feeling.”
vi: “Alright, I promise I won't be a cheese ball,” Radar said. “I Spy with my little eye, something we are all feeling.”
tr: “Okay, I promise I won't fool around,” says Radar. “Right now, I see something that all of us are feeling.”
es: —Okay, I promise not to be cheesy —says Radar—. I spy with my little eye something that we are all feeling.

en: I guess, “Extraordinary fatigue?”
vi: I immediately guessed, "Exhausted and out of breath?"
tr: “Extreme fatigue?” I guess.
es: —A huge fatigue? —I ask.

en: “No, although excellent guess.”
vi: “No, but good guess.”
tr: “No, nevertheless, an excellent guess.”
es: —No, although an excellent response.

en: Lacey says, “Is it that weird feeling you get from so much caffeine that, like, your heart isn’t beating so much as your whole body is beating?”
vi: Lacey said, "Isn't it a weird feeling to have too much caffeine in your system? Like your heart beating is nothing compared to your whole body pulsing?"
tr: Lacey is speaking. “Is it something about that weird feeling you get from too much caffeine? You know, like when your heart feels like it's beating all over your body?”
es: —That strange feeling that your heart isn't beating as fast as the rest of your body due to excess caffeine? —says Lacey.

en: “No. Ben?”
vi: "No." "What do you guess, Ben?"
tr: “No. Me?”
es: —No. Ben?

en: “Um, are we feeling the need to pee, or is that just me?”
vi: “Um, do we all need to pee, or is it just me?”
tr: “Eee, do we feel the need to pee, or is it just me who has a problem?”
es: —Hmm, do we feel like peeing, or is it just me?

en: “That is, as usual, just you. More guesses?” We are silent. “The correct answer is that we are all feeling like we will be happier after an a cappella rendition of ‘Blister in the Sun.’”
vi: "As usual, it's just you." "Is there anyone else guessing?" We were all silent. "The correct answer is that we will feel happier after singing 'Swelling Under the Sun' together without any accompaniment."
tr: “As usual, only you have it. Any other guesses?” We remain silent. “The correct answer is that we all feel happier after our a cappella rendition of Blister in the Sun.”
es: —Just you, as always. Any more? —We stayed silent—. The correct answer is that we all felt we would be happier after an a cappella rendition of "Blister in the Sun."

en: And so it is. Tone deaf as I may be, I sing as loud as anybody. And when we finish, I say, “I Spy with my little eye a great story.”
vi: And it was indeed so. Even though I might have tone-deafness, I still sang out loud like the others. After finishing the song, I said, "I Spy with my little eye, something really interesting."
tr: And it really is so. I may be tone-deaf, but I sing the song as loudly as everyone else. When we finish, I say, "I see a great story around right now."
es: And so it is. Although I have less ear for music than a deaf person, I sing as loudly as the others. And when we have finished, I say: I see, I see a great story.

en: No one says anything for a while. There’s just the sound of the Dreidel devouring the blacktop as she speeds downhill. And then after a while Ben says, “It’s this, isn’t it?”
vi: For a moment, no one said anything. Only the sound of the Spinner continuously devouring the asphalt as it descended the slope. After a while, Ben said,
tr: For a while, no one says anything. There is only the sound of Fırdöndü devouring the asphalt road as it speeds downhill. After a while, Ben says, "This is the story, isn't it?"
es: For a moment, no one says anything. Only the noise of the Dreidel devouring the asphalt and accelerating to climb the hill can be heard. —This one, right? —says Ben after a while.

en: I nod.
vi: “Is it this matter?” I nodded.
tr: I nod in agreement.
es: Seat.

en: “Yeah,” Radar says. “As long as we don’t die, this is gonna be one hell of a story.”
vi: "Yeah," Radar said. "As long as we don't die, this is truly a groundbreaking event."
tr: “Yes,” says Radar. “As long as we don't die, this will be a crazy story.”
es: —Yes —says Radar—. If we manage not to kill ourselves, it will be one hell of a story.

en: It will help if we can find her, I think, but I don’t say anything. Ben turns on the radio finally and finds a rock station with ballads we can sing along to.
vi: If we find her, that would be great, I thought, but said nothing. Finally, Ben turned on the radio, found a rock music station with ballads that we could sing along to.
tr: I think it would be helpful if we could find it, but I don't say anything. Finally, I turn on the radio and find a rock music station with songs we can sing along to.
es: "It wouldn't be bad if we found her," I think, but I don't say it. In the end, Ben turns on the radio and looks for a rock ballad station so we can all sing together.

en: Hour Twenty-one
vi: The twenty-first hour
tr: Twenty-First Hour
es: HOUR TWENTY-ONE

en: After more than 1,100 miles on interstates, it’s finally time to exit. It’s entirely impossible to drive seventy-seven miles per hour on the two-lane state highway that takes us farther north, up toward the Catskills. But we’ll be okay. Radar, ever the brilliant tactician, has banked an extra thirty minutes without telling us. It’s beautiful up here, the late-morning sunlight pouring down on old-growth forest. Even the brick buildings in the ramshackle little downtowns we drive past seem crisp in this light.
vi: After more than 1,100 miles on the interstate highway, it was finally time to get off. It was completely impossible to drive at seventy-seven miles per hour on a two-lane highway and continue heading north, against the Catskill Mountains. But we would be fine. Radar, an excellent strategist, had calculated a thirty-minute reserve without letting us know. This place was beautiful, with the near-noon sunlight pouring down on the ancient forest. The brick houses in the desolate residential area below also sparkled in this sunlight as we passed by.
tr: After traveling more than one thousand eight hundred kilometers on interstate highways, it's finally time to exit. It's absolutely impossible for us to go one hundred twenty-four kilometers per hour on the two-lane highway that takes us further north to the Catskills. But it won't be a problem. Since Radar is the best tactician ever, he has allocated an extra thirty minutes without telling us. This place is very beautiful, the daylight at dawn is pouring over the untouched forests. Even the brick buildings in the desolate towns we pass by look well-maintained in this light.
es: After more than 1800 kilometers on the highway, it's almost time to exit. It is completely impossible to drive at one hundred twenty-five kilometers per hour on the two-lane road that takes us further north, towards Catskill, but we will manage. Radar, always a brilliant strategist, had reserved an extra half hour without telling us anything. This is nice. The morning light illuminates the old trees. Even the brick buildings of the rundown towns we pass through seem new in this light.

en: Lacey and I are telling Ben and Radar everything we can think of in hopes of helping them find Margo. Reminding them of her. Reminding ourselves of her. Her silver Honda Civic. Her chestnut hair, stick straight. Her fascination with abandoned buildings.
vi: Lacey and I told Ben and Radar everything we could remember to help them find Margo more easily. Reminding the guys about Margo. Reminding ourselves about Margo. Her silver Honda Civic. Her light chestnut brown hair, straight and smooth. Her interest in abandoned houses.
tr: In the hope of helping them find Margo, together with Lacey, we are telling Ben and Radar everything we can think of. We remind them of Margo. We remind ourselves of Margo. Her silver Honda Civic. Her chestnut, straight hair. Her fondness for abandoned buildings.
es: Lacey and I tell Ben and Radar everything we can think of to help them find Margo. We remind them of details. We remind ourselves of them. Her silver Honda Civic. Her very straight brown hair. Her fascination with abandoned buildings.

en: “She has a black notebook with her,” I say.
vi: “Margo also has a black notebook,” I said.
tr: "He has a black notebook with him," I say.
es: —He carries a black notebook —I say.

en: Ben wheels around to me. “Okay, Q. If I see a girl who looks exactly like Margo in Agloe, New York, I’m not going to do anything. Unless she has a notebook. That’ll be the giveaway.”
vi: Ben turned to me. “Alright, if I see any girl who looks like Margo in Agloe, New York, I won't do anything. Unless she has a notebook. That's the identifying feature.”
tr: Ben suddenly turns to me. ‘Okay, Q. If I see a girl in Agloe, New York who looks exactly like Margo, I won’t do anything. Unless she has a notebook. That will be the giveaway.”
es: Ben turns towards me. —Okay, Q. If I see a girl exactly like Margo in Agloe, New York, I won't do anything unless she has a notebook. That will be the signal.

en: I shrug him off. I just want to remember her. One last time, I want to remember her while still hoping to see her again.
vi: That's the identifying feature.” I nudged Ben. I just wanted to remember her. One last time, I wanted to remember Margo while still hoping to see her again.
tr: I don’t pay attention to him. I just want to remember Margo. While I still hope to see her, I want to remember her one last time.
es: I don't pay attention to her. I just want to remember her. For the last time, I want to remember her while I still hope to see her again.

en: Agloe
vi: Agloe
tr: Agloe
es: AGLOE

en: The speed limit drops from fifty-five to forty-five and then to thirty-five. We cross some railroad tracks, and we’re in Roscoe. We drive slowly through a sleepy downtown with a café, a clothing store, a dollar store, and a couple boarded-up storefronts.
vi: The speed gradually decreased from fifty-five to forty-five, then thirty-five miles per hour. After a few railroad crossings, we arrived at Roscoe. We slowly drove through the sleepy downtown area with a café, a clothing store, a dollar store, and several storefronts with entirely boarded-up windows.
tr: The speed limit drops from ninety to seventy, then to fifty. We cross over the railroad tracks and we are in Roscoe. We slowly pass through the sleepy town center, which has a café, a clothing store, a discount shop, and a few boarded-up stores.
es: The speed limit drops from ninety to seventy, and then to sixty. We cross some train tracks and arrive in Roscoe. We move slowly through a sleepy town with a café, a clothing store, a dollar store, and a couple of storefronts boarded up.

en: I lean forward and say, “I can imagine her in there.”
vi: I lean forward and say, "I can imagine Margo being in there."
tr: Leaning forward, I say, "I can imagine Margo there."
es: —I can imagine her here —I say, leaning forward.

en: “Yeah,” Ben allows. “Man, I really don’t want to break into buildings. I don’t think I would do well in New York prisons.”
vi: "Yeah," Ben agreed. "Gosh, I don't want to break into those buildings at all. I probably wouldn't survive New York prison."
tr: “Yes,” says Ben. “Buddy, I really don't want to break into buildings without permission. I don't think I'll do well in New York prisons.”
es: —Yes —admits Ben—. Dude, I really don't want to break into buildings. I don't think I'd do very well in New York's prisons.

en: The thought of exploring these buildings doesn’t strike me as particularly scary, though, since the whole town seems deserted. Nothing’s open here. Past downtown, a single road bisects the highway, and on that road sits Roscoe’s lone neighborhood and an elementary school. Modest wood-frame houses are dwarfed by the trees, which grow thick and tall here.
vi: But the idea of exploring those houses did not particularly scare me, because the whole place seemed abandoned. No shops were open. Through the town center, there was a single street that cut through the highway. On that street was a solitary residential area and Roscoe Elementary School. The modest wooden houses were like dwarfs hiding under the tall trees with dense foliage.
tr: Since the whole town looks deserted, the idea of exploring these buildings doesn't particularly scare me. Nothing is open here. After passing the center, a single road intersects the main road, and on this road, there is Roscoe's secluded neighborhood and an elementary school. Modest wooden houses appear tiny beside the wide and tall trees.
es: Although the idea of exploring these buildings does not seem particularly alarming to me, as the whole town gives the impression of being deserted. There is nothing open. Past the center, the road crosses the highway, and on that road there is only the Roscoe neighborhood and an elementary school. The thick and tall trees make the modest wooden houses look tiny.

en: We turn onto a different highway, and the speed limit goes back up incrementally, but Radar is driving slowly anyway. We haven’t gone a mile when we see a dirt road on our left with no street sign to tell us its name.
vi: We turned onto another highway, accelerating as fast as before, but in reality, Radar was driving slowly. We hadn't gone a mile when we saw a dirt road on the left, with no signs at all.
tr: We turn onto another main road and the speed limit increases again, but Radar still drives slowly. When we see a dirt road on our left without a street sign to show us its name, we haven't even gone one and a half kilometers yet.
es: We enter another highway and increase our speed, although Radar continues to drive slowly. We have gone a little over a kilometer when we see an unpaved road to the left with no sign indicating its name.

en: “This may be it,” I say.
vi: “This could be the place,” I said.
tr: “This could be it,” I say.
es: —This could be it —I say.

en: “That’s a driveway,” Ben answers, but Radar turns in anyway. But it does seem to be a driveway, actually, cut into the hard-packed dirt. To our left, uncut grass grows as high as the tires; I don’t see anything, although I worry that it’d be easy for a person to hide anywhere in that field. We drive for a while and the road dead-ends into a Victorian farmhouse. We turn around and head back up the two-lane highway, farther north. The highway turns into Cat Hollow Road, and we drive until we see a dirt road identical to the previous one, this time on the right side of the street, leading to a crumbling barnlike structure with grayed wood. Huge cylindrical bales of hay line the fields on either side of us, but the grass has begun to grow up again. Radar drives no faster than five miles an hour. We are looking for something unusual. Some crack in the perfectly idyllic landscape.
vi: “It's just a road for cars,” Ben said, but Radar still turned in. In fact, it really did look like a road for cars, a strip of road running on solid ground. To our left, weeds grew as high as the car wheels; I couldn't see anything, but I was a bit worried that if someone wanted to hide in this field, it wouldn't be too difficult. We drove a bit further and the strip of road led to a Victorian-style farmhouse. We circled around back, turned back onto the two-lane highway, and continued north. The highway turned onto Cat Hollow Road, and we drove until we saw a strip of dirt road similar to the one earlier, this time on the right, leading to what looked like a dilapidated wooden barn. Rows of cylindrical hay bales lay in the fields on both sides of us, and the grass in the fields had started to grow back. Radar was driving at less than five miles per hour. We were looking for any signs of irregularity. A slight crack in this perfectly picturesque landscape.
tr: "It's a driveway," Ben replies, but Radar turns anyway. However, it actually looks like a dirt driveway. To our left, the uncut grass is as tall as tires; I can't see anything, but on the other hand, I'm worried that it would be easy for someone to hide anywhere here. We go for a while The road and journey end at a Victorian-style farmhouse. We turn back and head towards the two-lane highway further north again. The highway turns into Cat Hollow Road, and we go until we see a dirt road identical to the previous one, this time leading to a barn-like structure made of weathered wood on the right side of the street. In the meadows on both sides of us, large cylindrical hay bales are lined up, but the grass has started to grow again. Radar is not driving faster than eight kilometers per hour. We notice something unusual. A crack in the peaceful countryside scenery.
es: —It's the way to a house —answers Ben. But Radar turns anyway. The truth is that it looks like the path to a house, open in the packed earth. To our left, the grass grows, reaching the height of the tires. I don't see anything, although I fear it would be easy to hide anywhere in this field. We advance a stretch, and the road ends at a Victorian farmhouse. We turn around and return to the two-lane highway, further north. The highway turns towards Cat Hollow Road and we continue until we see an unpaved road identical to the previous one, this time to the right, leading to a sort of dilapidated gray wooden barn. In the fields, on both sides of us, there are huge cylindrical bales of hay, but the grass has started to grow. Radar doesn't exceed ten kilometers per hour. We are looking for something strange. Some flaw in this perfectly idyllic landscape.

en: “Do you think that could have been the Agloe General Store?” I ask.
vi: "Do people think it could be the Agloe General Store?"
tr: “Do you think this could be the Agloe Market?”
es: —Do you think it could have been the Agloe Supermarket? —I ask.

en: “That barn?”
vi: "That warehouse?"
tr: “Is this the barn?”
es: —That barn?

en: “Yeah.”
vi: “Yes.”
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “I dunno,” Radar says. “Did general stores look like barns?”
vi: “I don't know,” Radar replied. “Has there ever been a grocery store that looked like a warehouse?”
tr: "I don't know," says Radar. "Would the markets look like barns?"
es: —I don't know —Radar answers me—. Do supermarkets look like barns?

en: I blow a long breath from between pursed lips. “Dunno.”
vi: I exhale a long breath through my crooked lips. "Beats me."
tr: I let out a long breath through my pursed lips. "I don't know."
es: I let out a long sigh through my pursed lips. —I don't know.

en: “Is that—shit, that’s her car!” Lacey shouts next to me. “Yes yes yes yes yes her car her car!”
vi: "Oh my God, Margo's car!" Lacey shouted right next to me. "Yes yes yes yes yes yes Margo's car Margo's car!"
tr: “This... “Damn it, this is Margo’s car!” Lacey is shouting next to me. “Yes yes yes yes yes it’s her car it’s her car!”
es: —It's that... shit, it's his car! —Lacey shouts next to me—. Yes yes yes yes yes his car his car!

en: Radar stops the minivan as I follow Lacey’s finger back across the field, behind the building. A glint of silver. Leaning down so my face is next to hers, I can see the arc of the car’s roof. God knows how it got there, since no road leads in that direction.
vi: Radar stopped the car while I looked in the direction Lacey pointed across the field, behind the barn. A flash of silver. Leaning closer to Lacey, I saw the curved edge of the car roof. God only knows how the car got there, as there was no road leading in that direction.
tr: As I follow Lacey’s finger pointing to the other side of the field, behind the building, Radar stops the car. A silver glint. I bend down until my face is next to Lacey’s, and I can see the curve of the roof of the car. God knows how it got there, because no road leads in that direction.
es: Radar stops the minivan while I follow Lacey's finger, which points beyond the field, behind the building. A silver flash. I crouch down, place my face next to hers, and see the arc of the car's roof. God knows how it got there, because there is no path.

en: Radar pulls over, and I jump out and run back toward her car. Empty. Unlocked. I pop the trunk. Empty, too, except for an open and empty suitcase. I look around, and take off toward what I now believe to be the remnants of Agloe’s General Store. Ben and Radar pass me as I run through the mown field. We enter the barn not through a door but through one of several gaping holes where the wooden wall has simply fallen away.
vi: Radar found a parking spot, I jumped out of the minivan and ran towards her car. Empty. Unlocked. I opened the trunk. Nothing either, except for an open and empty suitcase. I looked around, and walked towards what I now believed to be the remains of the Agloe General Store. Ben and Radar passed me as I ran across the mowed grass. We didn't enter the barn through the door but through one of the gaping holes, where the wooden wall had simply fallen apart.
tr: Radar pulls over, I jump out and run towards Margo's car. Empty. Unlocked. I open the trunk. It is also empty, except for an open and empty suitcase. I look around and now move towards the structure I believe to be the remnants of the Agloe Market. As I run over the mowed grass, Ben and Radar pass me. We enter the barn not through a door, but through a gap in the wooden wall.
es: Radar stops, I jump out and run to the car. Empty. Open. I open the trunk. Also empty. There's only an open suitcase with nothing inside. I look around and head towards what I now believe are the remains of the Agloe Supermarket. Ben and Radar overtake me as I run through the mowed field. We enter the barn not through the door, but through one of the large holes that have formed where the wooden wall has fallen.

en: Inside the building, the sun lights up segments of the rotting wooden floor through the many holes in the roof. As I look for her, I register things: the soggy floorboards. The smell of almonds, like her. An old claw-footed bathtub in a corner. So many holes everywhere that this place is simultaneously inside and outside.
vi: In the warehouse, the sun shone down on the rotten wooden floorboards through numerous holes in the roof. While searching for her, I noted each thing: the damp floorboards. The smell of almonds, like her. A clawfoot bathtub in the corner. Holes everywhere, making this place both inside and outside at the same time.
tr: Inside the building, sunlight streams through numerous holes in the roof, illuminating the pieces of the decaying wooden floor. As I search for Margo, I start to perceive certain things: the soaking wet floor the boards. The scent of almonds, like her. An old, claw-footed bathtub in a corner. What makes this place both an interior and exterior space at the same time are the numerous holes everywhere.
es: Inside the building, the sun enters through the many holes in the roof and illuminates parts of the rotten wooden floor. While I search for her, I mentally take note of everything I see: the wet floorboards. The smell of almonds, like her. An old clawfoot bathtub in a corner. It is so full of holes that the building is both interior and exterior at the same time.

en: I feel someone pull hard on my shirt. I spin my head and see Ben, his eyes shooting back and forth between me and a corner of the room. I have to look past a wide beam of bright white light shining down from the ceiling, but I can see into that corner. Two long panes of chest-high, dirty, gray-tinted Plexiglas lean against each other at an acute angle, held up on the other side by the wooden wall. It’s a triangular cubicle, if such a thing is possible.
vi: I felt someone tugging hard at my shirt. I turned around and saw Ben, his eyes darting back and forth between me and a corner of the room. I had to look through a bright white area streaming down from the ceiling, but I could see that corner. Two long, chest-high, dirty and grayish plastic sheets leaned against each other forming a sharp angle, with wooden walls holding the sides. A triangular workspace, if such a thing existed.
tr: I feel someone tugging at my shirt roughly. I turn my head and see Ben, his eyes darting between a corner of the room and me. I have to look beyond a broad beam of bright white light streaming down from the ceiling, but I can see that corner. At chest height, two long, dirty, gray plexiglass sheets are leaning against each other at a narrow angle, while on the other side they rest against the wooden wall. It's a triangular-shaped nook, if such a thing is possible.
es: I feel someone pulling hard on my shirt. I turn my head and see Ben, who shifts his eyes towards a corner of the room. I have to look through a large beam of light coming in from the ceiling, but I see that corner. Two plexiglass panels approximately one meter high, dirty and tinted gray, lean against each other forming an angle against the wooden wall. It's a triangular cubicle, if a cubicle can be triangular.

en: And here’s the thing about tinted windows: the light still gets through. So I can see the jarring scene, albeit in gray scale: Margo Roth Spiegelman sits in a black leather office chair, hunched over a school desk, writing. Her hair is much shorter— she has choppy bangs above her eyebrows and everything is mussed-up, as if to emphasize the asymmetry—but it is her. She is alive. She has relocated her offices from an abandoned mini-mall in Florida to an abandoned barn in New York, and I have found her.
vi: And here is the noteworthy thing about the frosted window: light can pass through it. So I saw a poignant scene, though through a gray tint: Margo Roth Spiegelman sitting on a black leather office chair, hunched over a desk, like a student's desk, she was writing. Margo's hair was much shorter—her bangs were messy and falling over her eyebrows, everything in disarray, as if the emphasis was on eccentricity—but it was her. Margo was alive. She had moved her office from the abandoned mini-mall in Florida to an abandoned warehouse in New York, and I had found her.
tr: And here's the thing about dark-colored windows: The light still gets in. So despite being in shades of gray, I can see the shocking scene: Margo Roth Spiegelman, sitting in a black leather office chair, leaning over a school desk, writing. Her hair is much shorter, with wavy bangs over her eyebrows, and as if to emphasize the asymmetry, it's all messy—but this is Margo. Alive. She has moved her office from an abandoned shopping mall in Florida to an abandoned barn in New York, and I have found her.
es: And what happens with tinted windows is that they let light through, so I see the unsettling scene, although in grayscale: Margo Roth Spiegelman is sitting in a black leather office chair, leaning over a school desk, writing. Her hair is much shorter —the uneven bangs above her eyebrows and all messy, as if to highlight the asymmetry—, but it's her. She is alive. She has moved her office from an abandoned mall in Florida to an abandoned barn in New York, and I have found her.

en: We walk toward Margo, all four of us, but she doesn’t seem to see us. She just keeps writing. Finally, someone—Radar, maybe—says, “Margo. Margo?”
vi: We walked towards Margo, all four of us, but it seemed like she didn't notice. Margo kept writing. Finally, someone—Radar, it seemed—spoke up, "Margo." "Margo?"
tr: We are walking towards Margo, all four of us at once, but she doesn't seem to notice us. She just keeps writing. Finally, someone—maybe Radar—says, "Margo. Margo?"
es: The four of us approach Margo, but she doesn't seem to see us. She keeps writing. Finally, someone—maybe Radar—says: —Margo, Margo?

en: She stands up on her tiptoes, her hands resting atop the makeshift cubicle’s walls. If she is surprised to see us, her eyes do not give it away. Here is Margo Roth Spiegelman, five feet away from me, her lips chapped to cracking, makeup-less, dirt in her fingernails, her eyes silent. I’ve never seen her eyes dead like that, but then again, maybe I’ve never seen her eyes before. She stares at me. I feel certain she is staring at me and not at Lacey or Ben or Radar. I haven’t felt so stared at since Robert Joyner’s dead eyes watched me in Jefferson Park.
vi: She stood up and tiptoed, her hand resting on the edge of the wall of this makeshift office. If she was surprised to see us, her eyes did not show it at all. This is Margo Roth Spiegelman, about one and a half meters away from me, with dry, cracked lips, no makeup, dirt under her fingernails, and quiet eyes. I had never seen Margo's eyes so lifeless, but then again, perhaps I had never really looked into her eyes. Margo stared at me. I felt certain that she was looking at me and not at Lacey or Ben or Radar. I had not felt such an intense gaze since the dead eyes of Robert Joyner looked at me in Jefferson Park.
tr: She stands on her tiptoes; her hands are at the top of the makeshift room's walls. Even if she's surprised to see us, her eyes don't give her away. Here is Margo Roth Spiegelman, a meter and a half away from me, her lips chapped and rough, no makeup, dirt under her nails, her eyes silent. I've never seen her eyes so lifeless, but maybe I've never seen her eyes before. She's looking at me. I'm sure she's looking at me, not at Lacey, Ben, or Radar. Since the dead eyes of Kobcrl Doyner watched me in Jefferson Park, I haven't felt like I've been watched for a long time.
es: Margo stands on tiptoe, with her hands on the walls of the makeshift cubicle. If she is surprised to see us, her eyes do not show it. Here is Margo Roth Spiegelman, a meter and a half away from me, with chapped lips, no makeup, dirty nails, and mute eyes. I had never seen her eyes so dead until this point, but perhaps I had never seen her eyes before. She observes me. I am sure she is observing me, not Lacey, Ben, or Radar. I hadn't felt so observed since the lifeless eyes of Robert Joyner looked at me in Jefferson Park.

en: She stands there in silence for a long time, and I am too scared of her eyes to keep walking forward. “I and this mystery here we stand,” Whitman wrote.
vi: Margo stood silently like that for a long time, I was so afraid of her gaze that I didn't approach any closer. "We and this mystery here we stand," Whitman had written.
tr: For a long time, I stand there in silence, too scared to continue walking from their gaze. "I and this mystery, here we stand," writes Whitman.
es: She remains silent for a long time, and her eyes scare me too much to approach her. "I and this mystery here we stand," wrote Whitman.

en: Finally, she says, “Give me like five minutes,” and then sits back down and resumes her writing.
vi: In the end, Margo said, "Give me five minutes," then sat down and started writing again.
tr: Finally, Margo speaks: "Give me about five minutes." And then she sits back down and continues writing from where she left off.
es: —Give me five minutes —he says finally. He sits down again and continues writing.

en: I watch her write. Except for being a little grimy, she looks like she has always looked. I don’t know why, but I always thought she would look different. Older. That I would barely recognize her when I finally saw her again. But there she is, and I am watching her through the Plexiglas, and she looks like Margo Roth Spiegelman, this girl I have known since I was two—this girl who was an idea that I loved.
vi: I watched her write. Except for a little smudge, she looked just the same as before. I don't know why, but I had always thought she would look different. More mature. To the point where I would hardly recognize Margo when I finally met her again. But here she is, I'm looking at her through the frosted plastic, she looks like Margo Roth Spiegelman, my friend I've known since I was two—the girl who became an idea I fell in love with.
tr: I'm watching her write. Aside from being a bit messy, she looks just like she always does. I don't know why, but I always thought she would look different. I would be older. That when I finally saw her again, I would barely recognize her. But there she is, I'm watching her through the plexiglass, and she looks like Margo Roth Spiegelman, the girl I've known since I was two... the girl who was an idea I loved.
es: I watch her write. She seems the same as always, except that she is a little dirty. I don't know why, but I always thought she would be different. Older. That I would barely recognize her when I finally saw her again. But here she is, I watch her through the plexiglass, and she looks like Margo Roth Spiegelman, the girl I've known since I was two years old, the girl who was an idea I loved.

en: And it is only now, when she closes her notebook and places it inside a backpack next to her and then stands up and walks toward us, that I realize that the idea is not only wrong but dangerous. What a treacherous thing it is to believe that a person is more than a person.
vi: And only at this moment, when she closed the notebook, put it into the backpack next to her, and stood up to walk towards us, did I realize that the notion was not only wrong but also dangerous. Believing that a person is greater than themselves is such a precarious illusion.
tr: And only now, when she closes her notebook, puts it in the backpack next to her, stands up, and walks towards us, do I realize that the idea is not only wrong but also dangerous. How deceptive it is to believe that a person is more than just a person.
es: And only now, when she closes the notebook, puts it in a backpack she has next to her, stands up, and approaches us, do I realize that this idea is not only wrong but also dangerous. How deceptive it is to believe that a person is anything more than just a person.

en: “Hey,” she says to Lacey, smiling. She hugs Lacey first, then shakes Ben’s hand, then Radar’s. She raises her eyebrows and says, “Hi, Q,” and then hugs me, quickly and not hard. I want to hold on. I want an event. I want to feel her heaving sobs against my chest, tears running down her dusty cheeks onto my shirt. But she just hugs me quickly and sits down on the floor. I sit down across from her, with Ben and Radar and Lacey following in a line, so that we are all facing Margo.
vi: “Hey,” Margo said to Lacey, smiling. She hugged Lacey first, then shook hands with Ben and Radar. She raised an eyebrow, said, “Hi Q,” then hugged me, briefly and not tightly. I wanted to hold on tight. I wanted a mark. I wanted to feel her sobbing in my arms, tears smudging from her dusty cheeks onto my shirt. But Margo just hugged me quickly and sat down on the floor. I sat down in front of her. Ben, Radar, and Lacey also sat down next to me in a row, so that all of us were facing Margo.
tr: “Hey,” he says to Lacey with a smile. First, he hugs Lacey, then shakes Ben's hand, and then Radar's. Raising his eyebrows, he says, “Hi, Q,” and then hugs me quickly and softly. I want to stay like that. I want an event. I want her to sob against my chest, her tears flowing from her dusty cheeks onto my shirt. But she only hugs me quickly and sits down on the ground. Following me, Ben, Radar, and Lacey sit in a row opposite her, so we all face Margo.
es: —Hello —he says to Lacey, smiling. First, she hugs Lacey, then she shakes hands with Ben, and finally with Radar. She raises her eyebrows and says: Hello, Q. And she hugs me quickly and without squeezing. I want her to stay there. I want something to happen. I want to feel her sobbing against my chest, with tears sliding down her dirty cheeks onto my shirt. But she just hugs me quickly and sits on the floor. I sit in front of her. Ben, Radar, and Lacey also sit in a line with me, so the four of us are in front of Margo.

tr: She tosses her bangs to one side. Before speaking, she seems to be deciding exactly what to say. "I, um. Um. It's rare for me to be at a loss for words, isn't it? Lately I didn't talk much with people. Umm. I guess we should start with the question, what the hell are you doing here.”
es: She moves her bangs to one side. She seems to be deciding exactly what to say before saying it. —I… well… well… I rarely find myself at a loss for words, right? I haven't spoken much lately. I suppose we should start with: what the hell are you doing here?

en: “No need to worry,” Margo answers cheerfully. “I’m good.” She gives us two thumbs-up. “I am A-OK.”
vi: “Why worry,” Margo replied cheerfully. “I’m fine.” She gave two thumbs up. “I’m grade A fine.”

es: —You didn't have to worry —Margo replies cheerfully—. I'm fine. —She raises both thumbs—. I'm OK.

en: “You could have called us and let us know that,” Ben says, his voice tinged with frustration. “Saved us a hell of a drive.”

es: —You could have called us to tell us —says Ben with a certain tone of frustration—. We would have saved ourselves a trip that has been hell.

en: “In my experience, Bloody Ben, when you leave a place, it’s best to leave. Why are you wearing a dress, by the way?”

en: “Actually, yes,” Lacey says. “And actually he’s great. And actually you’re a bitch. And actually, I’m leaving. It’s nice to see you again, Margo. It’s been a real pleasure knowing you.”

Thanks for freaking me out, making me feel like crap for almost the entire last month of senior year, and thanks for being a bitch when we came all this way to see how you were doing. It was a pleasure knowing you.”

It was really a pleasure knowing you.”
es: —I'm telling you —Lacey replies to her—. And I'm telling you that it's great. And I'm telling you that you're a bitch. And I'm telling you that I'm leaving. Nice to see you, Margo. Thanks for terrifying me and making me feel like shit during the whole last month of my senior year of high school, and for being a bitch when we searched everywhere to make sure you were okay. It was a pleasure meeting you.

en: “You, too. I mean, without you, how would I have ever known how fat I was?” Lacey gets up and stomps off, her footfalls vibrating through the crumbling floor. Ben follows. I look over, and Radar has stood up, too.

es: —For me too. Without you, how would I have known how fat I was? Lacey gets up and stomps out. Her steps vibrate on the rickety floor. Ben goes out after her. I glance over and see that Radar has also stood up.

en: “I never knew you until I got to know you through your clues,” he says. “I like the clues more than I like you.”
vi: "I didn't know you at all until I gradually got to know you through the clues you left behind," Radar said. "I liked those clues more than I liked you."
tr: “I actually never knew you from the clues to the full extent,” he says. “I loved the clues more than I loved you.”
es: —I didn't know you until I learned about you through your clues —says Radar—. I like your clues more than I like you.

es: He turns around, grabs me by the shirt, and yells in my face: —What the hell are you doing showing up here without warning?

en: “How could I have warned you when you completely dropped off the face of the planet?!” I see a long blink and know she has no response for this, so I keep going. I’m so pissed at her. For . . . for, I don’t know. Not being the Margo I had expected her to be. Not being the Margo I thought I had finally imagined correctly. “I thought for sure there was a good reason why you never got in touch with anyone after that night. And . . . this is your good reason? So you can live like a bum?”
vi: “How could I inform you when you completely disappeared from the surface of this planet?!” I saw Margo close her eyes for a long time, and I knew she couldn't answer, so I just burst out. I was mad at Margo. Because... because, I don't know. This wasn't the Margo I had expected. This wasn't the Margo I thought I had finally imagined correctly. “I thought there must have been a legitimate reason why you didn't contact anyone after that night. And... is this your legitimate reason? Turns out you could wander around living homeless like this?”

Because she wasn't the Margo I finally thought I had imagined correctly. “I was sure there was a good reason for not having contacted anyone after that night. And... Was this your good reason? For… for… I don't know. For not being the Margo I expected. For not being the Margo I thought I had finally imagined correctly. —I assumed you had a good reason for not getting in touch with anyone since that night. But… is this your reason? en: She lets go of my shirt and pushes away from me. “Now who’s being a brat? I left the only way you can leave. You pull your life off all at once—like a Band-Aid. And then you get to be you and Lace gets to be Lace and everybody gets to be everybody and I get to be me.”
vi: Margo let go and pushed me away. “Now who's homeless? I left in the only way one can leave. Ripping my life off all at once–like a band-aid. Then you become you, Lacey becomes Lacey, someone becomes someone, and I become me.”
tr: He leaves my t-shirt and pushes it aside. "Now who is the spoiled one? I left in the only way I could be left. You pull and throw away my life in an instant... like a band-aid. But after that, you become you, I become Lace, everyone becomes themselves, and I become myself."
es: He lets go of my shirt and moves away from me. —And now who is being a spoiled child? I left in the only way one can leave. You rip your life off suddenly, like a band-aid. And then you are you, and Lace is Lace, and everyone is who they are, and I am me.

en: “Except I didn’t get to be me, Margo, because I thought you were dead. For the longest time. So I had to do all kinds of crap that I would never do.”
vi: “Except I wasn't myself, Margo, because I thought you were dead. For the longest time. So I had to do all those terrible things that I would never have done otherwise.”
tr: “I just can't be myself, Margo, because I thought you were dead. For a very long time. That's why I had to do things I would never normally do.”
es: —But I couldn't be myself, Margo, because I thought you were dead. Almost all the time. So I had to do all kinds of shit I would never have done.

en: She screams at me now, pulling herself up by my shirt so she can get in my face. “Oh, bullshit. You didn’t come here to make sure I was okay. You came here because you wanted to save poor little Margo from her troubled little self, so that I would be oh-so-thankful to my knight in shining armor that I would strip my clothes off and beg you to ravage my body.”
vi: Margo screamed, moving closer so she could look me straight in the eye. "Don't talk nonsense. You didn't come here to make sure I'm safe and sound. You came because you want to save poor little Margo from her little troubled self, so that I would be oh-so-moved by the gallant knight and strip off my clothes and beg you to ruin my body, right."
tr: Now she is screaming at me, rising on her toes by grabbing my shirt to reach my face. “Oh, don't be ridiculous. You didn't come here to make sure I was okay. You came here because you wanted to save poor little Margo from her troubled little self, so that I would be so grateful to my knight in shining armor that I would strip off my clothes and beg you to ravage my body.”
es: Now he yells at me and grabs me by the shirt to get face to face. —Nonsense. You didn't come to make sure I was okay. You came because you wanted to save poor little Margo from her problematic nature so that she would be so grateful to her knight in shining armor that she would take off her clothes and beg you to make her yours.

en: “Bullshit!” I shout, which it mostly is. “You were just playing with us, weren’t you? You just wanted to make sure that even after you left to go have your fun, you were still the axis we spun around.”
vi: “What nonsense are you talking about!” I shouted, almost like that. “You’re just playing us, right? You just want to make sure that even though you’ve left and have new fun, you will still be the axis around which we revolve.”
tr: “Stop talking nonsense!” I shout because, generally, he is talking nonsense. “You were just playing with us, weren't you? Even after you left to have fun, you wanted to make sure you were still the axis around which we revolved.”
es: —Nonsense! —I shout, and to a large extent, they are—. You were just playing with us, weren't you? You just wanted to make sure that even after you left to have fun elsewhere, everything still revolved around you.

en: She’s screaming back, louder than I thought possible. “You’re not even pissed at me, Q! You’re pissed at this idea of me you keep inside your brain from when we were little!”
vi: Margo screamed back, louder than I thought she could scream. “You don't even bother to get mad at me, Q! You're just mad because of the fantasies about me that you've been holding onto since childhood!”
tr: In response, she screams louder than I thought possible. "You're not even mad at me, Q! You're mad at the idea of me that you've kept in your head since we were kids!"
es: And she yells at me too, louder than I would have thought possible. —I haven't even disappointed you, Q! It's the idea of me that you got into your head since we were kids that has disappointed you!

en: She tries to turn away from me, but I grab her shoulders and hold her in front of me and say, “Did you ever even think about what your leaving meant? About Ruthie? About me or Lacey or any of the other people who cared about you? No. Of course you didn’t. Because if it doesn’t happen to you, it doesn’t happen at all. Isn’t that it, Margo? Isn’t it?”

Lacey or me or anyone else who cares about you? You haven't thought at all. Of course, you haven't thought about it. Because if you're okay, then nothing else matters. Isn't that right, Margo? Isn't it?"
tr: She tries to turn away from me, but I grab her shoulders and hold her in front of me. “Have you ever thought about what your leaving means? For Ruthie? For me, for Lacey, or for the other people who care about you? No. Of course you haven't. Because if something doesn't happen to you, it doesn't really happen at all. Isn't that right, Margo? Isn't it?”
es: She tries to turn around, but I grab her by the shoulders and hold her in front of me. —Have you ever thought about what it meant to leave? Have you thought about Ruthie? About me, Lacey, or any of the people who cared about you? No. Of course not. Because if it doesn't happen to you, it doesn't happen to anyone. Right, Margo? Right?

en: She doesn’t fight me now. She just slumps her shoulders, turns, and walks back to her office. She kicks down both of the Plexiglas walls, and they clamor against the desk and chair before sliding onto the ground. “SHUT UP SHUT UP YOU ASSHOLE.”
vi: Now she doesn't resist anymore. Margo just shrugged and turned away, going back to her workspace. She kicked down both hard plastic panels used as walls, which hit the table and chairs hard before sliding to the floor. "SHUT UP SHUT UP YOU JERK."

es: He no longer confronts me. He lets go, turns around, and goes back to his office. He kicks the plexiglass walls, which resonate against the desk and chair before falling to the floor. —SHUT UP SHUT UP IDIOT.

en: “Okay,” I say. Something about Margo completely losing her temper allows me to regain mine. I try to talk like my mom. “I’ll shut up. We’re both upset. Lots of, uh, unresolved issues on my side.”
vi: "Okay," I said. Something in the completely uncontrolled emotional outburst of Margo made me hold myself back. I tried to speak like my mother. "I will be silent. Neither of us is happy. There are still many, um, unresolved issues from my side."
tr: “Okay,” I say. Something about Margo completely losing her patience helps me regain mine. I try to talk like my mom. “I will shut up, we are both in a mess. From my perspective, there are a lot of unresolved issues.”
es: —Very well —I answered him. The fact that Margo completely loses her composure makes me regain mine. I try to speak like my mother. —I remain silent. We are both angry. As for me... there are many unresolved issues.

vi: Margo sat down on the swivel chair, her feet placed on what used to be the partition wall of the workspace. She looked at a corner of the warehouse. We were at least three meters apart. "How the hell did you guys find me?"

es: He sits in the chair, with his feet resting on what had been the wall of his office. He looks towards a corner of the barn. At least three meters separate us. —How the hell did you find me?

en: “I thought you wanted us to,” I answer. My voice is so small I’m surprised she even hears me, but she spins the chair to glare at me.
vi: “I thought you wanted us to find you,” I replied, speaking very softly but surprisingly Margo still heard. She turned her chair around and looked at me intently.
tr: “I thought you wanted us to do it that way,” I replied. My voice is so low that I'm surprised he even hears me, but he turns his chair to glare at me.
es: —I thought you wanted us to find you —I answered. I speak in such a low voice that I'm surprised she hears me, but she turns the chair to look at me.

en: “I sure as shit did not.”
vi: “Surely, I didn't want that.”
tr: “I am as sure as my name that I don't want it.”
es: —I can swear to you that no.

en: “‘Song of Myself,’” I say. “Guthrie took me to Whitman. Whitman took me to the door. The door took me to the mini-mall. We figured out how to read the painted-over graffiti. I didn’t understand ‘paper towns’; it can also mean subdivisions that never got built, and so I thought you had gone to one and were never coming back. I thought you were dead in one of these places, that you had killed yourself and wanted me to find you for whatever reason. So I went to a bunch of them, looking for you. But then I matched the map in the gift shop to the thumbtack holes. I started reading the poem more closely, figured out you weren’t running probably, just holed up, planning. Writing in that notebook. I found Agloe from the map, saw your comment on the talk page of Omnictionary, skipped graduation, and drove here.”
vi: “‘Song of Myself,’” I said. “Guthrie led me to Whitman. Whitman led me to the door. The door led me to the mini-mall. We discovered how to read the graffiti that had been painted over. I didn’t understand what ‘paper towns’ meant; it could be unfinished subdivisions, so I thought you had gone to such a place and would never come back. I thought you had died in one of those places, that you had committed suicide and for some reason wanted me to find you. I went to a bunch of places like that, looking for you. But then I matched the map from the souvenir shop with the pinholes on the wall. I started reading the poem more closely, realizing that maybe you weren’t running away but just hiding somewhere, making plans. Writing in that notebook. I found Agloe on the map, read your comment on the discussion page in the Omnictionary, I skipped graduation and drove straight here.”
tr: “My Own Song,” I say. “Guthrie took me to Whitman. Whitman took me to the door. The door took me to the shopping mall. We figured out how to read the overpainted graffiti. I didn’t understand the ‘paper towns’ thing; it can also mean neighborhoods that were never built, so I thought you went to one of them and never came back. I thought you died in one of these places, killed yourself, and for whatever reason, wanted me to find you. So I went to a few of them looking for you. But then, I compared the pinholes on the map from the gift shop. I started reading the poem more carefully, probably you didn’t run away I understand, you had withdrawn to your corner just by making plans. By writing something in that notebook. I found Agloe on the map, saw your comment on the talk page of Omnictionary, skipped graduation, and drove here.”
es: —The "Song of Myself" —I tell her—. Guthrie led me to Whitman. Whitman led me to the door. The door led me to the abandoned mall. We discovered how to read the hidden graffiti. I didn't understand the "paper towns" thing, because it also means subdivisions that were never built, so I thought you had gone to one of those subdivisions and that you would never come back. I thought you were dead in one of those places, that you had killed yourself and for some reason wanted me to find you. So I went to a bunch of subdivisions to look for you. But then I matched the souvenir shop map with the pinholes. I started reading the poem more carefully and thought that you probably weren't going from place to place, that you had locked yourself up to plan. To write in that notebook. I found Agloe on the map, saw your comment on the Omnictionary page, skipped graduation, and drove here.

en: “You could have just said, like, ‘Guys, you are scaring the shit out of me,’” I said.
vi: “You should have just said, ‘Hey, you guys scared me stiff.’”
tr: “You could have just said: '(. 'Kids, you're scaring me to death.”’
es: —You could have just said: "Guys, you're freaking me out" —I tell him.

en: She scoffs. “Yeah, right, ’cause that’s the Margo Roth Spiegelman everybody knows and loves.” Margo is quiet for a moment, and then says, “I knew I shouldn’t have said that on Omnictionary. I just thought it would be funny for them to find it later. I thought the cops might trace it somehow, but not soon enough. There’s like a billion pages on Omnictionary or whatever. I never thought . . .”

There are like a billion pages on Omnictionary. It never occurred to me...”

I just thought it would be fun for them to find it later. I thought the police would find me, but not in time. The Omnictionary has a billion pages. I never thought…

en: “What?”
vi: "What?"
tr: “What?”
es: —What?

en: “I thought about you a lot, to answer your question. And Ruthie. And my parents. Of course, okay? Maybe I am the most horribly self-centered person in the history of the world. But God, do you think I would have done it if I didn’t need to?” She shakes her head. Now, finally, she leans toward me, elbows on knees, and we are talking. At a distance, but still. “I couldn’t figure out any other way that I could leave without getting dragged back.”
vi: “I’ve thought a lot about you, here’s the answer to your question. And thought about Ruthie. And my parents. Of course, right? Maybe I’m the most severely solitary person in human history. But God, do you think I would do this if I didn’t have to?” Margo shook her head. Now, finally, she turned fully towards me, elbows resting on her knees, and we talked. Still far apart, but still talking to each other. “I couldn’t find any other way to leave without being pulled back.”
tr: “To answer the question, I thought about you a lot. And Ruthie. And my parents. Of course I thought about it, okay? Maybe I'm the most horribly selfish person in world history. But do you think I would have done this if I didn't need to?” He nods his head. Now, finally, he leans towards me, elbows on his knees, and we are talking. We are talking from a certain distance, but that's okay. “I couldn't think of another way to leave without being dragged back.”
es: —I have thought about you a lot, if that answers your question. And about Ruthie. And about my parents. Of course, okay? Maybe I am the most tremendously egocentric person in the history of the world. But do you think I would have done it if I didn't need to? —He shakes his head. He finally leans towards me, with his elbows on his knees, and we talk. At a certain distance, but it doesn't matter—. I couldn't think of any other way to leave without being dragged back.

en: “I’m happy you’re not dead,” I say to her.
vi: “I'm glad you didn't die,” I said to Margo.
tr: "I'm glad you're not dead," I say.
