en: “Yeah. Me, too,” she says. She smirks, and it’s the first time I’ve seen that smile I have spent so much time missing. “That’s why I had to leave. As much as life can suck, it always beats the alternative.”
vi: “Yeah, me too,” she replied, with a slight smirk. It was the first time I saw the smile that I had longed for so long. “That's why I have to go. No matter how miserable life gets, there are always other choices.”
tr: "Yes." "Me too," he says. He grins, and this is the first time I've seen that smile which I've missed for so long. "Having to leave that's the reason. No matter how miserable life is, it is always better than the alternative.”
es: —Yes, me too —he replies to me. He smiles, and it is the first time I see that smile that I have missed so much—. That's why I had to leave. No matter how fucked up life is, it's always better than death.

en: “Lacey wants to talk to Margo,” he tells me.

en: I walk over to Margo, hand her the phone, and linger there as she sits with her shoulders hunched, listening. I can hear the noises coming through the phone, and then I hear Margo cut her off and say, “Listen, I’m really sorry. I was just so scared.” And then silence. Lacey starts talking again finally, and Margo laughs, and says something. I feel like they should have some privacy, so I do some exploring. Against the same wall as the office, but in the opposite corner of the barn, Margo has set up a kind of bed—four forklift pallets beneath an orange air mattress. Her small, neatly folded collection of clothes sits next to the bed on a pallet of its own. There’s a toothbrush and toothpaste, along with a large plastic cup from Subway. Those items sit atop two books: The Bell Jar by Sylvia Plath and Slaughterhouse-Five by Kurt Vonnegut. I can’t believe she’s been living like this, this irreconcilable mix of tidy suburbanality and creepy decay. But then again, I can’t believe how much time I wasted believing she was living any other way.
vi: I walked over to Margo, handed her the phone, and lingered by her side while she sat hunched forward, listening. I heard noises coming from the phone, then I heard Margo interrupt and say, "Listen, I'm really sorry. I was just scared." And then silence. Finally, Lacey spoke again, and Margo laughed out loud, saying something in response. Thinking they needed some privacy, I started wandering around exploring. Leaning against the same wall as the workspace, but in the opposite corner of the warehouse, Margo had set up what could be called a bed—four slats beneath an orange air mattress. Margo's small, neatly folded stack of clothes was next to the bed, also on a slat. There was a toothbrush and toothpaste, with a large plastic cup from Subway. These items were on top of two books: Sylvia Plath's The Bell Jar and Kurt Vonnegut's Slaughterhouse-Five. I couldn't believe that Margo had been living like this, this irreconcilable mix of charming suburban neatness and eerie dilapidation. But then again, I couldn't believe how much time I had spent thinking she was living so differently.

Against the office wall, but in the opposite corner of the barn, Margo has set up some kind of bed: four pallets with an inflatable mattress on top. Her small collection of clothes, perfectly folded, is on another pallet, next to the bed. There is a toothbrush and toothpaste, as well as a large plastic cup. These things are on top of two books: The Bell Jar by Sylvia Plath, and Slaughterhouse-Five by Kurt Vonnegut. I find it hard to believe she has been living like this, with this irreconcilable mix of neat residential area and eerie decay. And I also find it hard to believe the time I wasted thinking she was living any other way.

en: “They’re staying at a motel in the park. Lace said to tell you they’re leaving in the morning, with or without you,” Margo says from behind me. It is when she says you and not us that I think for the first time of what comes after this.

en: “I’m mostly self-sufficient,” she says, standing next to me now. “There’s an outhouse here, but it’s not in great shape, so I usually go to the bathroom at this truck stop east of Roscoe. They have showers there, too, and the girls’ shower is pretty clean because there aren’t a lot of female truckers. Plus, they have Internet there. It’s like this is my house, and the truck stop is my beach house.” I laugh.
vi: “I’m almost self-sufficient,” Margo said, now standing next to me. “There’s a toilet out there, but it’s not very nice, so I usually go to the restroom at the truck stop north of Roscoe. They also have showers there, and the women’s shower is very clean because there aren’t many female truck drivers. Plus, they have Internet there. It’s kind of like this place is my home, and the truck stop is my seaside resort.” I laughed.

This is my home, and the truck stop is like my summer house.” I laugh.

It's as if this were my home, and the truck stop were my little beach house. I laugh.

en: She walks past me and kneels down, looking inside the pallets beneath the bed. She pulls out a flashlight and a square, thin piece of plastic. “These are the only two things I’ve purchased in the whole month except gas and food. I’ve only spent about three hundred dollars.” I take the square thing from her and finally realize that it’s a battery-powered record player. “I brought a couple albums,” she says. “I’m gonna get more in the City, though.”

en: “Yeah. I’m leaving for New York City today. Hence the Omnictionary thing. I’m going to start really traveling. Originally, this was the day I was going to leave Orlando—I was going to go to graduation and then do all of these elaborate pranks on graduation night with you, and then I was going to leave the next morning. But I just couldn’t take it anymore. I seriously could not take it for one more hour. And when I heard about Jase—I was like, ‘I have it all planned; I’m just changing the day.’ I’m sorry I scared you, though. I was trying not to scare you, but that last part was so rushed. Not my best work.”

en: As dashed-together escape plans replete with clues go, I thought it was pretty impressive. But mostly I was surprised that she’d wanted me involved in her original plan, too. “Maybe you’ll fill me in,” I said, managing a smile. “I have, you know, been wondering. What was planned and what wasn’t? What meant what? Why the clues went to me, why you left, that kind of thing.”
vi: When the hastily sketched escape plans with many clues hinting at the departure, I thought it was very impressive. But I was almost surprised that in the original plan she also wanted me to be involved. “Maybe you'll tell me,” I said, trying to smile. “You know, I've been wondering a lot. What is in the plan and what is not? What does everything mean? Why do the clues point to me, why are you leaving, that sort of thing.”
tr: I had thought that the interwoven escape plans filled with clues were quite impressive. But more than that, I was surprised that he included me in his main plan. “Could you shed some light on the things I don't know?” I said, managing to smile. “I was curious... What was planned, what wasn't? What did everything mean? Why did the clues come to me, why did you leave, things like that.”
es: As far as hastily made escape plans full of clues go, they seemed quite impressive to me. But above all, I was surprised that he had included me in his plans from the very beginning. —You'll bring me up to speed —I said, trying to smile—. Well, I wonder about many things. What you had planned and what you hadn't. What each thing meant. Why the clues were directed at me. Why you left…

en: “Um, okay. Okay. For that story, we have to start with a different story.” She gets up and I follow her footsteps as she nimbly avoids the rotting patches of floor. Returning to her office, she digs into the backpack and pulls out the black moleskin notebook. She sits down on the floor, her legs crossed, and pats a patch of wood next to her. I sit. She taps the closed book. “So this,” she says, “this goes back a long way. When I was in, like, fourth grade, I started writing a story in this notebook. It was kind of a detective story.”
vi: “Okay, fine. Alright. With that story, we have to start with another story.” Margo stood up, I followed as Margo walked gracefully, avoiding the creaky floorboards. Returning to the work corner, she searched in her backpack and took out a black leather notebook. Margo sat down on the floor, crossed her legs, and patted the wooden floor right next to her. I sat down. Margo opened the notebook. “This,” she said, “so this started a long time ago. Back around fourth grade, I started writing in here. A kind of detective story.”
tr: “Hmm, okay. Okay. We need to start this story with another story.” He stands up, avoiding the rotten parts of the floor, and I follow his steps. He returns to his office, finds and takes out a black notebook from his backpack. Sitting cross-legged on the floor, he lightly taps the piece of wood next to him with his hand. I sit down. He gently touches the closed notebook. “Now this,” he says, “doesn't go back a long time. When I was in fourth grade, I started writing a story in this notebook. It was a kind of detective story.”
es: Those kinds of things. —Hmm, okay, okay. To tell you that story, we have to start with another one. He gets up and I follow his steps, which skillfully avoid the rotten floorboards. He returns to his office, puts his hand in the backpack, and takes out the black notebook. He sits on the floor, crosses his legs, and pats the piece of floor next to him. I sit down. He rests his hand on the closed notebook. —This goes back a long time —he tells me—. When I was in fourth grade, I started writing a story in this notebook. It was a kind of detective story.

en: I think that if I grab this book from her, I can use it as blackmail. I can use it to get her back to Orlando, and she can get a summer job and live in an apartment till college starts, and at least we’ll have the summer. But I just listen.

en: “I mean, I don’t like to brag, but this is an unusually brilliant piece of literature. Just kidding. It’s the retarded wish-fulfilling magical-thinking ramblings of ten-year-old me. It stars this girl, named Margo Spiegelman, who is just like ten-year-old me in every way except her parents are nice and rich and buy her anything she wants. Margo has a crush on this boy named Quentin, who is just like you in every way except all fearless and heroic and willing to die to protect me and everything. Also, it stars Myrna Mountweazel, who is exactly like Myrna Mountweazel except with magical powers. Like, for example, in the story, anyone who pets Myrna Mountweazel finds it impossible to tell a lie for ten minutes. Also, she can talk. Of course she can talk. Has a ten-year-old ever written a book about a dog that can’t talk?”
vi: “I don't want to brag, but this is truly a rare and excellent piece of work. Alright, just kidding. It's just my ten-year-old self writing a bunch of rambling, magical, and wildly imaginative nonsense. It starts with this girl named Margo Spiegelman, who is like me when I was ten in every way, except her parents are kind, super rich, and buy her everything she wants. Margo likes a boy named Quentin, who is like you in every way, except for his heroic bravery, willingness to sacrifice to protect me, and other things. There's also a character named Myrna Mountweazel, who is like the real Myrna Mountweazel in every way, except for her extraordinary magical abilities. For example, in the story, anyone who pets Myrna Mountweazel cannot lie for ten minutes. Also, she can talk. Of course she can talk. Is there any ten-year-old who would write a story about a dog that can't talk?”
tr: ‘I mean, I don't like to brag, but this is an unusually brilliant piece of literature. I'm kidding. The absurd ramblings of my ten-year-old self, who believed in magical things that fulfilled desires. The main character is a girl named Margo Roth Spiegelman, who in every way is just like my ten-year-old self, except her parents are good, rich, and can buy her anything she wants. Margo is smitten with a boy named Quentin, who in every way is just like you; completely fearless, brave, and willing to die and risk everything to protect me, except. Also starring is Myrna Mountweazel, who is exactly like Myrna Mountweazel, except for having magical powers. Like, for example, in the story, anyone who pets Myrna Mountweazel finds it impossible to lie for ten minutes. She can also talk. Of course she can talk. Could a ten-year-old have written a book about a dog that can't talk?”
es: —Well, I don't like to brag, but it's a brilliant literary work like few others. Just kidding. They are the stupid ramblings full of desires and magic from when I was ten years old. The protagonist is a girl named Margo Spiegelman, who was like me at ten years old, except that her parents are kind and rich and buy her everything she wants. Margo likes a boy named Quentin, who is like you in every way, except that he is brave, heroic, would be willing to die to protect me, and all that. There is also Myrna Mountweazel, who is just like Myrna Mountweazel, but has magical powers. For example, in the story, anyone who pets Myrna Mountweazel cannot lie for ten minutes. And Myrna talks. Of course she talks. Has a ten-year-old ever written a book about a dog that couldn't talk?

en: “Well,” I say, “I’d rather read it.” She pulls open the book and shows me a page. The writing is indecipherable, not because Margo’s handwriting is bad, but because on top of the horizontal lines of text, writing also goes vertically down the page. “I write crosshatch,” she says. “Very hard for non-Margo readers to decode. So, okay, I’m going to spoil the story for you, but first you have to promise not to get mad.”
vi: "No," I replied, "I'd rather read it myself." Margo opened the book and showed me a page. The handwriting was very hard to read, not because Margo wrote poorly, but because on the horizontal lines, the letters also ran straight down to the bottom of the page. "I write them interwoven like that," Margo explained. "Non-Margo readers would find it hard to decipher. Alright, I'll reveal the plot to you, but you have to promise not to get mad."
tr: "Actually," I say, "I prefer to read." She opens the notebook and shows me a page. The writing is unreadable, not because Margo's handwriting is bad, but because the horizontal lines of the text are No, because it is also written vertically. "I write diagonally," he says. "It's very difficult to decipher for readers who are not Margoolmayan. That's why I will tell you the end of the story, but first you must promise not to get angry."
es: —Well —I replied—, I'd better read it. She opens the notebook and shows me a page. The text is indecipherable, not because Margo has bad handwriting, but because there are vertical lines over the horizontal ones. —I write in code —he tells me—. It's very difficult for anyone other than me to decipher it. Alright, fine, I'll tell you the ending, but first you have to promise me that you won't get mad.

en: “So anyway, I finished this story in fifth grade. A few years later, I decide I’m going to run away to Mississippi. And then I write all my plans for this epic event into this notebook on top of the old story, and then I finally do it—take Mom’s car and put a thousand miles on it and leave these clues in the soup. I didn’t even like the road trip, really—it was incredibly lonely— but I love having done it, right? So I start crosshatching more schemes—pranks and ideas for matching up certain girls with certain guys and huge TPing campaigns and more secret road trips and whatever else. The notebook is half full by the start of junior year, and that’s when I decide that I’m going to do one more thing, one big thing, and then leave.”
vi: “Anyway, in fifth grade, I finished the story. A few years later, I decided to leave for Mississippi. I wrote all the plans for that outrageous trip in this notebook, above the old story, and eventually I carried out the plan–took my mom's car, drove a thousand miles, and left clues in the soup. I didn't even like the road trip, really–it was terribly lonely–but I liked completing it, right? So I wrote more plans in here–pranks, matchmaking between girls and boys, a grand toilet papering campaign, more secret road trips, and anything else. By the beginning of tenth grade, the notebook was half full, and that's when I decided to do one more thing, a shocking one, and then leave.”
tr: ‘So anyway, I finished this story in fifth grade. A few years later, I decided I would run away to Mississippi. Then, I wrote all my plans for this epic event in this notebook, over the old story, and finally did it... I took my mom's car and drove a thousand six hundred kilometers and left clues in the soup with these letters. I didn't enjoy the journey, actually —I was incredibly lonely but I liked trying, okay? So I started writing more cross-plans... Pranks, ideas of setting certain girls up with certain guys, toilet paper attack campaigns, more secret trips, and whatever else. At the beginning of sophomore year, the notebook was half full and then, I decided I would do one more thing, one big thing, and then leave.”
es: —In the end, I finished the story in fifth grade. A few years later, I decide that I'm going to Mississippi. And then I write all my plans for the epic event in this notebook, on top of the previous story, and in the end, I leave. I take my mother's car, drive almost two thousand kilometers, and leave clues in the soup. I didn't even like the trip, to be honest. I felt very lonely. But I love having done it, you know? Then I start layering more stories, jokes, and ideas to pair certain girls with certain boys, huge house wallpapering campaigns, more road trips, and many other things. The notebook is half full when we start the last year, and that's when I decide that I'm going to do one more thing, something big, and then I'll leave.

en: She’s about to start talking again, but I have to stop her. “I guess I’m wondering if it was the place or the people. Like, what if the people around you had been different?”
vi: Margo was about to continue speaking, but I had to stop her. “I’m wondering if it’s because of the space or the people?” If the people around you were different, what would happen?”
tr: He is about to start talking again, but I have to stop him. "I think I'm wondering if the problem is the place or the people. Like, what would happen if the people around you were different?"
es: She's going to keep talking, but I have to stop her. —I wonder if it was because of the place or the people. What would have happened if the people around you had been different?

en: “How can you separate those things, though? The people are the place is the people. And anyway, I didn’t think there was anybody else to be friends with. I thought everyone was either scared, like you, or oblivious, like Lacey. And th—”
vi: “How can you separate those two sides? People are the land and the land is people. Anyway, I don't think I can be friends with anyone else. I think everyone is either scared like you, or indifferent like Lacey. And–”
tr: “How can you separate these from each other? People are places, and places are people. Anyway, I thought there was no one else to be friends with. I thought everyone was either a coward like you or insensitive like Lacey. And...”
es: —How can you separate one thing from the other? The people are the place, and the place is the people. And well, I didn't think there was anyone else I could be friends with. I thought everyone was either scared, like you, or didn't care, like Lacey. And...

en: “I’m not as scared as you think,” I say. Which is true. I only realize it’s true after saying it. But still.
vi: "I'm not as scared as you think," I said. That's right. I only realized it was true after I had declared it. But it was still true.
tr: “I'm not as cowardly as you think,” I say. Which is true. However, I realize it is true after I say it. But that's okay.
es: —I'm not as scared as you think —I tell him. And it's true. I only realize that it's true when I've already said it. But even so.

en: “I’m getting to that,” she says, almost whiningly. “So when I’m a freshman, Gus takes me to the Osprey—” I tilt my head, confused. “The minimall. And I start going there by myself all the time, just hanging out and writing plans. And by last year, all the plans started to be about this last escape. And I don’t know if it’s because I was reading my old story as I went, but I put you into the plans early on. The idea was that we were going to do all these things together—like break into SeaWorld, that was in the original plan—and I was going to push you toward being a badass. This one night would, like, liberate you. And then I could disappear and you’d always remember me for that.
vi: "I'm so fed up," Margo said, her voice almost hissing. "Then when I was in tenth grade, Gus took me to Osprey—" I tilted my head, not understanding. "The mini mall." Then I started going there by myself, just messing around and writing plans. By the end of last year, all the plans were aimed at this final escape. I don't know if it was because I was writing and rereading old stories, but I soon included you in this new plan. The main idea was that we would do all these things together—like sneaking into SeaWorld, that was in the original plan—I would push you to become a tough, prominent guy. The final night would, well, liberate you. Then I would disappear, and you would always remember me for that.
tr: “I’m getting to that part,” he says, almost whining. “After all, when I was a freshman in high school, Gus took me to Osprey...” I lower my head in confusion. “The shopping mall. I started going there alone all the time, just hanging out and writing plans. In the last year, all the plans started to be about this final escape. I don’t know if it’s because I was reading my old story at the time, but I included you in the plans a long time ago. The idea in my mind was for us to do all these things together—like sneaking into SeaWorld without permission, which was also in the main plan—and for me to encourage you to be a tough kid. This one night would liberate you. Then I could disappear, and you would always remember me for this.
es: —I'm getting to that part —he says almost complaining—. When I'm in first year, Gus takes me to the Osprey… —I shake my head, confused—. The abandoned mall. And I start going there on my own every now and then, just to hang out and write my plans. And towards the last year, all the plans started to revolve around the final escape. And I don't know if it's because I read my old story when I went, but I quickly included you in my plans. The idea was that we were going to do all those things together —like breaking into SeaWorld, which was in the original plan— and I would pressure you to be a jerk. That night I would set you free. And then I would disappear and you would always remember me.

en: “So this plan eventually gets like seventy pages long, and then it’s about to happen, and the plan has come together really well.
vi: “Finally, this plan is seventy pages long, ready to happen, with very smooth steps.
tr: “In the end, this plan reached about seventy pages in length, then it came to the implementation stage and I thought it had really come together well.
es: "In the end, the plan takes up about seventy pages, and it's about to be fulfilled, everything has gone very well, but I discover about Jase and decide to leave.

en: But then I find out about Jase, and I just decide to leave. Immediately. I don’t need to graduate. What’s the point of graduating? But first I have to tie up loose ends. So all that day in school I have my notebook out, and I’m trying like crazy to adapt the plan to Becca and Jase and Lacey and everyone who wasn’t a friend to me like I thought they were, trying to come up with ideas for letting everyone know just how pissed off I am before I ditch them forever.
vi: But then I found out about Jase, and I decided to leave immediately. Right away. I don't need to graduate. What's the point of graduating? But I have to tie up the loose ends first. So that whole day at school, I took out my notebook, frantically trying to fit the plan with Becca, Jase, and Lacey, and anyone who wasn't my friend as if I had considered them friends. I came up with more ideas to let everyone know how fed up I was before I ditched them forever.
tr: But I learned about Jase and just decided to go. Immediately. I didn't need to graduate. The purpose of graduating What was it? But first, I had to tie up my unfinished business. Throughout that day at school, I held my notebook in my hand and tried to adapt the plan like crazy to Becca, Jase, Lacey, and basically everyone who wasn't my friend, trying to come up with ideas so that everyone would know how angry I was before I left them.
es: "In the end, the plan takes up about seventy pages, and it's about to be fulfilled, everything has gone very well, but I discover about Jase and decide to leave. Immediately. I don't need to graduate. What's the point of graduating? But first I have to tie up the loose ends. So all that day, at school, I carry the notebook with me, frantically trying to adapt the plan to Becca, Jase, Lacey, and everyone who wasn't as much of a friend as I thought, trying to come up with ideas so that everyone would know how much they had disappointed me before I left them forever.

en: “But I still wanted to do it with you; I still liked that idea of maybe being able to create in you at least an echo of the kick-ass hero of my little-kid story.
vi: "But I want to do it together with you; I still hold the idea that I can at least create the image of a brave hero in my children's story within you."
tr: "But still, I wanted to do this with you; I liked the idea that I might still have the chance to create at least a reflection of the hero who kicked my ass in my childhood story, in you."
es: »But I still wanted to do it with you. I still liked the idea of maybe turning you into something like the badass hero of my childhood story.

en: “And then you surprise me,” she says. “You had been a paper boy to me all these years—two dimensions as a character on the page and two different, but still flat, dimensions as a person. But that night you turned out to be real. And it ends up being so odd and fun and magical that I go back to my room in the morning and I just miss you. I want to come over and hang out and talk, but I’ve already decided to leave, so I have to leave. And then at the last second, I have this idea to will you the Osprey. To leave it for you so that it can help you make even further progress in the field of not-being-such-a-scaredy-cat.
vi: “And then you surprised me,” Margo continued. “All those years, to me, you were a paper boy—two-dimensional like a character on a page, and two-dimensional, but still flat, like a person. But that night you became very real. And the whole thing ended so strangely, funnily, dreamily that the next morning I went back to my room and just missed you. I wanted to run over, play, and chat about random things, but I had decided to leave, so I had to go. In the last moment, I came up with the idea to show you the way to Osprey. Leaving it for you so you could further progress in the field of not-playing-the-scaredy-cat.
tr: “But then you surprised me,” she says. “For so many years, you had been a paper boy to me... You were two-dimensional as a character on a page, and even though you were different as a person, you were still flat and two-dimensional. But that night, it turned out you were real. And the night ended so strangely, funnily, and magically that I returned to my room in the morning and missed you. I wanted to come by and hang out and talk, but since I had already decided to leave, I had to go. Then at the last second, the idea of leaving Osprey to you came to mind. The idea of leaving it to you so it could help you make more progress in the area of not being a complete coward.
es: "And then you surprise me," she says to me. For me, you had been a paper boy all these years... Two dimensions as a character on paper and two other different dimensions, but also flat, as a person. But that night it turned out you were real. And it ends up being so strange, fun, and magical that I go back to my room in the morning and I miss you. I want to come find you, go out and chat, but I've already decided to leave, so I have to leave. And then, at the last second, it occurs to me to send you the Osprey. To leave it with you to help you keep moving forward on the path of not being a scared kitten.

en: “So, yeah. That’s it. I come up with something real quick. Tape the Woody poster to the back of the blinds, circle the song on the record, highlight those two lines from “Song of Myself” in a different color than I’d highlighted stuff when I was actually reading it. Then after you leave for school, I climb in through your window and put the scrap of newspaper in your door. Then I go to the Osprey that morning, partly because I just don’t feel ready to leave yet, and partly because I want to clean the place up for you. I mean, the thing is, I didn’t want you to worry. That’s why I painted over the graffiti; I didn’t know you’d be able to see through it. I ripped off the pages of the desk calendar I’d been using, and I took down the map, too, which I’d had up there ever since I saw that it contained Agloe. Then because I’m tired and don’t have anyplace to go, I sleep there. I end up there for two nights, actually, just trying to get my courage up, I guess. And also, I don’t know, I thought maybe you would find it really quickly somehow. Then I go. Took two days to get here. I’ve been here since.”
vi: "Yeah, that's it. I managed really quickly. I stuck the Woody poster on the back of the curtain, circled the song title on the record, marked two lines in the song "Soliloquy" with a different color from the one I had previously used when I actually read it myself. Then after you went to school, I climbed through your window and tucked the note in the door frame. That morning I went to Osprey, partly because I didn't feel ready, partly because I wanted to clean the place up for you. Honestly, I didn't want you to worry. So I painted over the graffiti, I didn't know you could read it. I tore up the desk calendars I had used, and took down the map. I had hung it up since I discovered Agloe was there. Then because I was tired and had nowhere else to go, I slept there. I stayed for about two nights, actually wanting to pull myself together and gather some courage, I guess. I also thought, I don't know, maybe you would quickly find this place. So I left. It took two days to get here. Since then, I've been here."
tr: ‘Well, yes. That's all. I quickly found something. I taped the Woody poster behind the blinds, circled the song on the record, and underlined those two lines in My Own Song with a different pen than the one I usually use when I actually read. After you went to school, I climbed into your window and put the piece of newspaper on your door. Then that morning I went to Osprey, partly because I didn't feel ready to leave yet, partly because I wanted to clean it up for you. So the thing is, I didn't want you to worry. That's why I painted over the graffiti; I didn't know you could see through it. I tore out the pages of the desk calendar I was using and also took down the map because I saw Agloe on it. Then I slept there because I was tired and had nowhere else to go. In the end, I stayed there for two nights, I guess I was just trying to gather my courage. And also, I don't know, maybe I thought you would somehow find it quickly. Then I went. It took me two days to get here. I've been here since then.”
es: »And yes, that's all. I think of something quickly. I stick the Woody poster on the outside of the blind, circle the song on the record, and mark the two verses from "Song of Myself" in a different color than the one I used when I read it. Then, when you've already gone to school, I sneak in through your window and put the piece of newspaper in the door. That same morning I go to the Osprey, partly because I still don't feel ready to leave, and partly because I want to leave it clean for you. Anyway, the point is that I didn't want you to worry. That's why I covered the graffiti. I didn't know you would manage to see it. I tore out the pages of the calendar I had used and also removed the map, which I had hung up since I saw it included Agloe. And then, since I'm tired and have nowhere to go, I sleep there. In fact, in the end, I spend two nights there, trying to gather the courage, I suppose. And also, I don't know, I thought maybe you would find it right away. And then I left. It took me two days to get here. And I've been here ever since.

en: She seemed finished, but I had one more question. “And why here of all places?”
vi: It seems like Margo has told everything, but I still have one more question. "Why this place?"
tr: It seemed like he was done, but I had one more question. "Why here, out of all places?"
es: It seems to be over, but I have another question left. —And why precisely here?

en: “A paper town for a paper girl,” she says. “I read about Agloe in this book of ‘amazing facts’ when I was ten or eleven. And I never stopped thinking about it. The truth is that whenever I went up to the top of the SunTrust Building—including that last time with you—I didn’t really look down and think about how everything was made of paper. I looked down and thought about how I was made of paper. I was the flimsy-foldable person, not everyone else. And here’s the thing about it. People love the idea of a paper girl. They always have. And the worst thing is that I loved it, too. I cultivated it, you know?
vi: “A paper town for a paper girl,” Margo replied. “I read about Agloe in the book ‘Amazing Facts’ when I was ten or eleven years old. I kept thinking about it. The truth is, whenever I stood atop the SunTrust building–including the last time with you–I didn’t really look down and think about how everything was made of paper. I looked down and thought about how I was made of paper. I am that fragile, easily folded, easily crumpled person, nothing else. And the problem is right here. Everyone loves the idea of a paper girl. They always have. And the worst part is, I liked it too. I nurtured that idea, you know?
tr: “A paper town for a paper girl,” he says. “When I was ten or eleven, I read about Agloe in one of those ‘amazing facts’ books. And I never stopped thinking about it. The truth is, whenever I went up to the top of the SunTrust building—including the last time we went together—I didn’t think about how everything looked so paper-like. I looked down and thought about how paper-like I was. I was the fake, foldable person, not others. And the thing about it is: people love the idea of a paper girl. They always have. And the worst part is, I loved it too. I nurtured it, you understand?
es: —A paper town for a paper girl —she answers me—. I read about Agloe in a book of "surprising things" when I was ten or eleven years old. And I never got it out of my head. The truth is that every time I went up to the SunTrust Building (including the last time I went with you), what I thought when looking down wasn't that everything was made of paper. I looked down and thought that I was made of paper. I was the weak and foldable person, not the others. And that's the point. People love the idea of a paper girl. They've always loved it. And the worst part is that I loved it too. I cultivated it, you know?

en: “Because it’s kind of great, being an idea that everybody likes. But I could never be the idea to myself, not all the way. And Agloe is a place where a paper creation became real. A dot on the map became a real place, more real than the people who created the dot could ever have imagined. I thought maybe the paper cutout of a girl could start becoming real here also. And it seemed like a way to tell that paper girl who cared about popularity and clothes and everything else: ‘You are going to the paper towns. And you are never coming back.’”
vi: “Because it's also fun. It's a concept that everyone likes. But I can't be a concept to myself, I can't be a concept my whole life. Agloe is a place where a product on paper has become real. A dot on the map has become a real place, more real than the creators of that dot could have imagined. I thought maybe the paper cut-out girl could start to become real from this place. And maybe that's the way to tell the paper girl who always wants to be admired, always concerned about clothes and other things: ‘There will be paper towns. And you will never come back.’”
tr: “Because being an idea that everyone likes is nice. But for myself • I could never be that idea, not completely. And Agloe is a place where a paper creation turned into reality. A point on the map turned into a real place, more real than the creators of the point could have imagined. I thought maybe a girl cut from paper could start to become real here too. And it seemed like a way to tell that paper girl, who cares about popularity, clothes, and things like that, ‘You will go to the Paper Towns. And you will never return,’”
es: "Because it's great to be an idea that everyone likes." "But I couldn't be the idea of myself, not entirely." "And Agloe is a place where a paper creation becomes real." "A point on the map turned into a real place, more real than the people who created that point would have imagined." "I thought that maybe here the paper silhouette of a girl could start to become real." "And it seemed to me a way to tell that girl who worried about popularity, clothes, and everything else: 'You will go to the paper towns. And you will never come back.'"

en: “That graffiti,” I said. “God, Margo, I walked through so many of those abandoned subdivisions looking for your body. I really thought—I really thought you were dead.”
vi: “That graffiti,” I said. “Oh my God, Margo, I went to so many abandoned subdivisions like that to find your body. I really thought–I really thought you were dead.”
tr: "Graffiti," I say. "God, Margo, I wandered through many of those abandoned neighborhoods looking for your body. I really... really thought you were dead."
es: —The spray-painted one —I told her—. For God's sake, Margo, I've searched through many abandoned subdivisions looking for your body. I really thought… I really thought you were dead.

en: She gets up and searches around her backpack for a moment, and then reaches over and grabs The Bell Jar, and reads to me.
vi: Margo stood up, searched in her backpack for a moment, then reached out to grab the book "The Bell Jar," and read aloud to me.
tr: She stands up and rummages through her backpack for a short while, then lies down, takes The Bell Jar, and starts reading.
es: He gets up, rummages in his backpack for a moment, takes out The Bell Jar, and reads to me.

en: “‘But when it came right down to it, the skin of my wrist looked so white and defenseless that I couldn’t do it. It was as if what I wanted to kill wasn’t in that skin or the thin blue pulse that jumped under my thumb, but somewhere else, deeper, more secret, and a whole lot harder to get at.’” She sits back down next to me, close, facing me, the fabric of our jeans touching without our knees actually touching. Margo says, “I know what she’s talking about. The something deeper and more secret. It’s like cracks inside of you. Like there are these fault lines where things don’t meet up right.”
vi: “‘But at that decisive moment, the skin on my wrist was so white and unresisting, I couldn't do it anymore. It seemed that what I wanted to kill was not in that skin, or in the thin blue vein pulsing under my finger, but somewhere else, deeper, more secretive, and infinitely harder to reach.’” Margo sat back down next to me, close, facing me, our jeans touching but our knees not. Margo said, “I understand what she meant. That somewhere else deeper and more secretive. It's like the cracks inside you. Like there are flawed lines where things don't fit together.”
tr: "'But when it came right down to it, the skin of my wrist looked so white and defenseless that I couldn't do it. It was as if what I wanted to kill wasn't in that skin or the faint, blue pulse beating under my thumb, but somewhere else, deeper, more secret, and much harder to reach. somewhere else.”’ He sits down next to me again, close to me, across from me, without our knees actually touching, the fabric of our jeans touching. He speaks: “I understand what he's talking about. What the deeper and more secret thing is, like the cracks inside. As if there are these fault lines where things don't quite come together properly.”
es: —"But when the moment came to do it, the skin on my wrist seemed so white and defenseless that I couldn't. It was as if what I wanted to kill wasn't in that skin, nor in the faint blue pulse that throbbed under my thumb, but somewhere deeper, more secret, and much harder to reach." Sit back down next to me, very close, facing me. The fabric of our jeans touches without our knees actually brushing against each other. —I know what you're talking about —says Margo—. That deeper and more secret something. They are like cracks inside you. Like faulty lines where things don't fit well.

en: “I like that,” I say. “Or it’s like cracks in the hull of a ship.”
