en: My heart has been fluttering around my chest for so long now that this variety of intoxication almost seems sustainable—but only almost. “Margo, if you just come home for the summer— my parents said you can live with us, or you can get a job and an apartment for the summer, and then school will start, and you’ll never have to live with your parents again.”
vi: My heart was dancing incessantly in my chest because this state of intoxication seemed to last forever–but only almost. “Margo, if you come to stay at my house this summer–my parents have said that you can stay with my family, or you can get a job and rent an apartment for the summer, then the college semester will start, and you will never have to live with your parents again.”
tr: My heart has been fluttering inside my chest for so long that this level of intoxication almost feels like something that could be sustained... almost. "Margo, if you come home in the summer... My mom and dad said you could live with us, or you could find a job and an apartment for the summer, then school will start and you'll never have to live with your parents again."
es: My heart has been spinning in my chest for so long that this kind of dizziness seems almost bearable, but only almost. —Margo, if you come back home for the summer… my parents have said that you can live with us, or you can look for a job and an apartment for the summer, and then classes will start and you won't have to live with your parents again.

en: “It’s not just them. I’d get sucked right back in,” she says, “and I’d never get out. It’s not just the gossip and the parties and all that crap, but the whole allure of a life rightly lived—college and job and husband and babies and all that bullshit.”
vi: “It's not just them. I feel weary from the inside,” Margo replied, “and I have never escaped it. It's not just the trivial matters, parties, and all the other dull nonsense, but the entire aura of a life lived correctly—college, job, husband, children, and all those kinds of illusions.”
tr: “The problem is not just them. I immediately return to the same situation,” he says, “and I can never escape from it. The problem is not just gossip, parties, and all that nonsense, but all the allure of a life lived the right way... that is, university, job, husband, babies, and all that nonsense.”
es: —It's not just because of them. I would get trapped again and never get out of there. It's not just the gossip, the parties, and all that crap, but the prospect of living life the way it should be lived: university, job, husband, kids, and all that bullshit.

en: The thing is that I do believe in college, and jobs, and maybe even babies one day. I believe in the future. Maybe it’s a character flaw, but for me it is a congenital one. “But college expands your opportunities,” I say finally. “It doesn’t limit them.”
vi: The issue is whether I believe in college, jobs, and perhaps one day, children. I believe in the future. Maybe it's a flaw in my character, but for me, it's innate. "But going to college will give you more opportunities," I finally said, "College doesn't reduce possibilities."
tr: The thing is, I believe in university, jobs, and maybe even babies one day. I believe in the future. Maybe this is a personality disorder, but for me, it's something innate. "But university expands my opportunities," I say finally. "It doesn't limit them."
es: The problem is that I do believe in the university, in work, and maybe in having children someday. I believe in the future. Maybe it's a flaw in my character, but in my case, it's congenital. —But the university broadens your opportunities —I finally tell him—. It doesn't limit them.

en: She smirks. “Thank you, College Counselor Jacobsen,” she says, and then changes the subject. “I kept thinking about you inside the Osprey. Whether you would get used to it. Stop worrying about the rats.”
vi: Margo smirked. “Thank you, College Counseling Expert Jacobsen,” she said, then changed the subject. “I often think of you when I'm in Osprey. Whether you're familiar with it or not. Don't worry about the rats.”
tr: Smiling. "Thank you, Guidance Counselor Jacobsen," he says and then changes the subject. "I kept thinking about you in Osprey. Whether you would get used to this place. Whether you would stop worrying about the mice."
es: Smiles with smugness. —Thank you, university advisor Jacobsen —he says to me, and changes the subject—. I thought about you a lot while inside the Osprey. About whether you would get used to it. About whether you would stop worrying about the rats.

en: “I did,” I say. “I started to like it there. I spent prom night there, actually.”
vi: “I'm familiar with it,” I replied. “I'm starting to like that place. In fact, I spent the entire prom night there.”
tr: “I'm used to it,” I say. “I started to like it there. Actually, I spent the prom night there.”
es: —That's how it was —I answered—. I started to like it. The truth is that I spent the night of the dance there.

en: She smiles. “Awesome. I imagined you would like it eventually.
vi: She laughed. "Great." "I had a feeling you would like that place."
tr: Smiling. “Amazing. I had imagined that you would eventually love it.
es: Smile. —Incredible. I imagined that in the end you would like it.

en: It never got boring in the Osprey, but that was because I had to go home at some point. When I got here, I did get bored. There’s nothing to do; I’ve read so much since I got here. I got more and more nervous here, too, not knowing anybody. And I kept waiting for that loneliness and nervousness to make me want to go back. But it never did. It’s the one thing I can’t do, Q.”
vi: "I've never gotten bored at Osprey, but that's because sooner or later I always have to go home." "When I'm here, I get really bored too." "There's nothing to do, I've read a lot since I got here." "The longer I stay, the more tense I feel, I don't know anyone." "I keep waiting for the loneliness and tension to take me home." "But that doesn't happen." "There's one thing I can't do, Q."
tr: It was never boring for me in Osprey, but that was because I had to go home at some point. I got bored when I came here. There is nothing to do; I have read a lot since I came here. Also, I became increasingly anxious here because I didn't know anyone. And I kept waiting for that loneliness and anxiety to make me want to go back. But it never happened. This is the one thing I can't do, Q.”
es: I was never bored on the Osprey, but it was because at some point I had to go back home. When I got here, I was indeed bored. There is nothing to do. I have read a lot since I arrived. Not knowing anyone made me more and more nervous. And I hoped that this loneliness and nervousness would make me go back. But it hasn't been like that. It's the only thing I can't do, Q.

en: I nod. I understand this. I imagine it is hard to go back once you’ve felt the continents in your palm. But I still try one more time. “But what about after the summer? What about college? What about the rest of your life?”
vi: I nodded. I understood that. I could imagine how hard it would be to return once you have felt the continents in the palm of your hand. But I still tried a little more. "What about the summer then? What about college? What about the rest of your life?"
tr: I nod my head in agreement. I understand this. I can imagine that once you feel the continent in the palm of your hand, it is hard to go back. But still, I try once more. “But what will happen after summer? What will happen to university? What will happen to the rest of your life?”
es: Seat. I understand it. I imagine it's hard to go back when the palms of your hands encompass continents. But I try once more. —And what will happen after the summer? What will happen with the university? What will happen with the rest of your life?

en: She shrugged. “What about it?”
vi: Margo shrugged. “What about those things?”
tr: My shoulders shrug. “What happened?”
es: He shrugs. —What will happen?

en: “Aren’t you worried about, like, forever?”
vi: “Aren't you worried about, um, forever?”
tr: “Well, aren't you worried about forever?’
es: —Aren't you worried about the future?

en: “Forever is composed of nows,” she says. I have nothing to say to that; I am just chewing through it when Margo says, “Emily Dickinson. Like I said, I’m doing a lot of reading.”
vi: “Forever is the harmony of the present,” Margo replied. I didn't know what to say, just tried to swallow as Margo said, “That's Emily Dickinson. I told you, I read a lot.”
tr: “Forever is composed of nows,” she says. I have no response to that; when Margo speaks again, I am still pondering her previous statement: “Emily Dickinson. As I said, I read a lot.”
es: "The future is made up of nows," he replies to me. I have nothing to say. I'm mulling it over when Margo says: —Emily Dickinson. As I told you, I am reading a lot.

en: I think the future deserves our faith. But it is hard to argue with Emily Dickinson. Margo stands up, slings her backpack over one shoulder, and reaches her hand down for me. “Let’s take a walk.” As we’re walking outside, Margo asks for my phone. She punches in a number, and I start to walk away to let her talk, but she grabs my forearm and keeps me with her. So I walk beside her out into the field as she talks to her parents.
vi: I think the future deserves our trust. But it's hard to argue with Emily Dickinson. Margo stood up, slung her backpack over her shoulder, and extended her hand to me. "Let's go for a walk." Once outside, Margo asked to borrow my phone. She dialed a number, and I was about to leave to give her some privacy, but Margo grabbed my hand to keep me there. So I walked with Margo to the field while she talked to her parents.
tr: I believe the future deserves our faith. But it's hard to argue with Emily Dickinson. Margo stands up, slings her backpack over her shoulder, and extends her hand to me. "Come on, let's take a walk." As we head out, Margo asks for my phone. She dials a number with a firm press, and I start to walk away to give her privacy, but she grabs my arm and keeps me by her side. So, while she talks to her parents, I walk beside her towards the meadow outside.
es: I believe that the future deserves that we believe in it. But it is difficult to contradict Emily Dickinson. Margo stands up, slings the backpack over one shoulder, and extends her hand to me. —Let's go for a walk. As we leave, Margo asks me for the phone. She types in a number and when I start to move away to let her talk, she grabs my arm to keep me with her. I walk beside her towards the field while she talks to her parents.

en: “Hey, it’s Margo. . . . I’m in Agloe, New York, with Quentin. . . . Uh. . . . well, no, Mom, I’m just trying to think of a way to answer your question honestly. . . . Mom, come on. . . . I don’t know, Mom . . . I decided to move to a fictitious place. That’s what happened. . . . Yeah, well, I don’t think I’m headed that way, regardless. . . . Can I talk to Ruthie? . . . Hey, buddy. . . . Yeah, well, I loved you first. . . . Yeah, I’m sorry. It was a mistake. I thought—I don’t know what I thought, Ruthie, but anyway it was a mistake and I’ll call now. I may not call Mom, but I’ll call you. . . . Wednesdays? . . . You’re busy on Wednesdays. Hmm. Okay. What’s a good day for you? . . . Tuesday it is. . . . Yeah, every Tuesday. . . . Yeah, including this Tuesday.” Margo closes her eyes tight, her teeth clenched. “Okay, Ruthers, can you put Mom back on? . . . I love you, Mom. I’ll be okay. I swear. . . . Yeah, okay, you, too. Bye.”
vi: So I walked with Margo to the field while she talked to her parents. "Yes, it's Margo here... I'm in Agloe, New York, with Quentin... Uh... no, mom, I want to answer you honestly... Mom, come on... I don't know, mom... I've decided to move to a place that doesn't exist. That's how it happened... Yes, well, but anyway, I didn't think I would be seen as that kind of person... Can I talk to Ruthie?... Oh, hey there, sweetie... Yeah, yeah, I love you the most... Yeah, I'm really sorry. So, it was a mistake. I thought– I don't even know what I thought, Ruthie, but I know it was my fault, from now on I'll call. I probably won't call mom, but I will definitely call you... Wednesdays, okay?... You're busy on Wednesdays? Hmm, alright. So what day works for you?... Tuesday is... yeah... so every Tuesday then... Yeah, starting this Tuesday." Margo closed her eyes tightly, her teeth slightly clenched. "Alright, good girl, now give the phone back to mom, okay?... I love you, mom. I'll be fine, I swear... Yes, okay, you too, mom. Goodbye, mom."
tr: “Hello, I'm Margo... I'm with Quentin in Agloe, New York... Ah... Well, no mom, I'm just trying to think of a way to answer your question honestly... Mom, don't... I don't know, mom... I had decided to move to an imaginary place. That's what happened... Yes, well, I don't think I'm heading that way, whatever happens... Can I talk to Ruthie?.. Hello, my friend... No, I loved you first... Yes, I wish you well. This was a mistake. I thought that... I don't know what I was thinking, Ruthie, but whatever it was, it was a mistake and I will call you from now on. I might not call my mom, but I will call you... Is Wednesday okay?.. You're busy on Wednesdays. Hmm. Okay. Which day works for you?.. Alright then. Yes, every Tuesday... Yes, including this Tuesday.” Margo closes her eyes tightly, her teeth clenched. “Okay, Ruthers, can you give the phone back to my mom?.. I love you, mom. I'm fine. I swear... Yes, okay, you too. Goodbye.”
es: —Hello, it's Margo… I'm in Agloe, New York, with Quentin… Wow… Well, no, mom, I'm just thinking about how to answer you honestly… Mom, come on… I don't know, mom… I decided to move to a fictional place. That's what happened… Yes, well, anyway, I don't think I'll go there… Can I talk to Ruthie?… Hello, sweetie… Yes, well, I loved you first… Yes, I'm sorry. It was a mistake. I thought… I don't know what I thought, Ruthie, but it was a mistake and from now on I'll call you. Maybe I won't call mom, but I'll call you… Wednesdays?… You can't on Wednesdays. Hmm. Okay. What day works for you?… Tuesdays… Yes, every Tuesday… Yes, including this Tuesday. —Margo closes her eyes and grits her teeth—. Alright, Ruthers, can you put mom on?… I love you, mom. Everything will be fine. I promise you… Yes, okay, you too. Goodbye.

en: She stops walking and closes the phone but holds it a minute. I can see her fingertips pinkening with the tightness of her grip, and then she drops it onto the ground. Her scream is short but deafening, and in its wake I am aware for the first time of Agloe’s abject silence. “It’s like she thinks my job is to please her, and that should be my dearest wish, and when I don’t please her—I get shut out. She changed the locks. That’s the first thing she said. Jesus.”
vi: Margo stopped, ended the call but still held the phone in her hand for about a minute. I saw her fingertips turn pink from gripping tightly, then she dropped the phone to the ground. Margo's scream was short but piercing, and then for the first time, I noticed the profound silence of Agloe. “My mom thinks my job is to please her, and that should be my greatest wish, and when I no longer please her, I get thrown out. She changed all the locks. That was the first thing she told me. Oh my God.”
tr: He stops walking and turns off the phone but holds it in his hand for about a minute. He grips it so tightly that I can see his fingertips turning pink, then he drops the phone to the ground. His scream is short but deafening, and then for the first time, I notice the miserable silence of Agloe. “It's as if he thinks my job is to please him and that this should be my most precious wish, and when I don't please him... I am thrown out. He changed the locks. That's the first thing he said. My God.”
es: He stops and hangs up the phone, but holds onto it for a minute. He squeezes it so hard that the tips of his fingers start to turn red. Then he lets it fall to the ground. His scream is brief but deafening, and as it echoes, I become aware for the first time of the miserable silence of Agloe. —It is believed that what I have to do is please her, that I shouldn't desire anything else, and when I don't please her... she throws me out. She has changed the locks. It's the first thing she told me. For God's sake.

en: “Sorry,” I say, pushing aside some knee-high yellow-green grass to pick up the phone. “Nice to talk to Ruthie, though?”
vi: “I'm very sorry,” I said, pushing aside the knee-high grass, half yellow and half green, to pick up the phone. “But was it fun talking to Ruthie?”
tr: “I'm sorry,” I say, pushing aside the knee-high yellow-green grass to get the phone. “Was it good to talk to Ruthie?” “Yes, Ruthie is a lovely girl.
es: —I'm sorry —I say, pushing aside the yellowish grass that reaches our knees to pick up the phone—. But everything okay with Ruthie?

en: “Yeah, she’s pretty adorable. I kind of hate myself for—you know—not talking to her.”
vi: “Yes, the girl is very nice and lovely. I feel really bad because—you know—I didn't say anything to her.”
tr: “Was it good to talk to Ruthie?” “Yes, Ruthie is a lovely girl. Actually, I hate myself for not talking to her.”
es: —Yes, she is very nice. I hate myself for... you know... not having talked to her.

en: “Yeah,” I say. She shoves me playfully.
vi: “It's okay,” I said. Margo playfully hit me.
tr: "Yes," I say. He nudges me as if joking.
es: —Yes —I tell him. He gives me a playful shove.

en: “You’re supposed to make me feel better, not worse!” she says. “That’s your whole gig!”
vi: “You were supposed to make me feel better, not worse!” Margo said. “That’s your whole talent!”
tr: “You need to make me feel better, not worse!” he says. “That's the whole point!”
es: —You are supposed to make me feel better, not worse! —he tells me—. It's your role!

en: “I didn’t realize my job was to please you, Mrs. Spiegelman.”
vi: "I didn't know it turned out my job was to please you, Ms. Spiegelman."
tr: “I hadn't realized that my job was to please you, Ms. Spiegelman.”
es: —I didn't know that what I had to do was to please you, Miss Spiegelman.

en: She laughs. “Ooh, the Mom comparison. What a burn. But fair enough. So how have you been? If Ben is dating Lacey, surely you are having nightly orgies with dozens of cheerleaders.”
vi: Margo laughed out loud. “Oh, comparing with the mothers. An honor that makes you break a sweat. But there's some truth to it. So how have you been lately? If Ben is flirting with Lacey, surely you've been having hot nights with a dozen cheerleaders.”
tr: Laughing. “Oh, the mom comparison. Very bad. But you're right. So, how are you? If Ben is dating Lacey, you must be having sex parties with dozens of cheerleaders every night.”
es: He/She laughs. —Oh, you compare me to my mother. What an insult. But I deserve it. Well, how have you been? If Ben is dating Lacey, surely you are having orgies every night with a bunch of cheerleaders.

en: We walk slowly through the uneven dirt of this field. It doesn’t look big, but as we walk, I realize that we do not seem to be getting closer to the stand of trees in the distance. I tell her about leaving graduation, about the miraculous spinning of the Dreidel. I tell her about prom, Lacey’s fight with Becca, and my night in the Osprey. “That was the night I really knew you’d definitely been there,” I tell her. “That blanket still smelled like you.”
vi: We slowly walked on the uneven ground of this field. At first glance, the field didn't seem large, but as we walked, I realized it didn't look like we were getting any closer to the trees in the distance. I told Margo about the escape from the graduation ceremony, the spectacular spins of the Top. I told her about the prom, Lacey fighting with Becca, and the night I spent at Osprey. "That was the night I really knew for sure you had been there," I said to Margo. "The blanket still smelled like you."
tr: We are walking slowly on the rugged meadow. The meadow area does not look wide, but as we walk, I realize that it does not seem like we are getting closer to the distant grove. I am telling her about dropping out of graduation, the miraculous return of Fırdöndü. I talk about the prom, Lacey’s fight with Becca, and my night at Osprey5. “It was definitely the night I truly realized you were there,” I say. “That blanket still smelled like you.”
es: We walked slowly through the uneven field. It doesn't seem big, but as we move forward, I realize that there is no way we can get closer to the trees in the background. I tell him that I skipped graduation and about the miraculous spin of the Dreidel. I tell him about the dance, Lacey's fight with Becca, and my night at the Osprey. —It was the night I knew there was no doubt you had been there —I tell her—. The blanket still smelled like you.

en: And when I say that her hand brushes up against mine, and I just grab hers because it feels like there is less to ruin now. She looks at me. “I had to leave. I didn’t have to scare you and that was stupid and I should have done a better job leaving, but I did have to leave. Do you see that yet?”
vi: When I said that, Margo's hand gently touched me, and I immediately held that hand, because it felt like there were fewer things that could be ruined at that moment. Margo looked at me. "I had to leave. I didn't need to scare you and that was really stupid. I should have left more neatly, but I really had to go. Do you understand?"
tr: When I say this, his hand lightly touches mine and I immediately grab his hand because it feels like there are fewer things left to ruin. He looks at me. “I had to go. I didn't need to scare you, it was foolish, and I should have done a better job when leaving, but I had to go. Do you understand now?”
es: And when I tell her, her hand brushes against mine, and I take it because it feels like there's not much left to ruin now. She looks at me. —I had to leave. I shouldn't have scared you, it was stupid, I should have left in another way, but I had to go. Do you understand now?

en: “Yeah,” I say, “but I think you can come back now. I really do.”
vi: “Yes,” I replied, “but I think now you can also return. That's exactly what I think.”
tr: “Yes,” I say, “but I think you can come back now. I really think so.”
es: —Yes —I tell him—, but I think you can come back now. I really believe it.

en: “No, you don’t,” she answers, and she’s right. She can see it in my face—I understand now that I can’t be her and she can’t be me. Maybe Whitman had a gift I don’t have. But as for me: I must ask the wounded man where he is hurt, because I cannot become the wounded man. The only wounded man I can be is me.
vi: “No, you don't think that way,” Margo replied, and she was right. She could see it on my face–now I understand that I can't be her and she can't be me. Maybe Whitman has a talent that I don't have. For me: I have to ask the wounded person where he is hurt, because I can't become the wounded person. The only wounded person I can be is myself.
tr: “No, you are not thinking,” he replies, and he is right. He can read it from my face... I now understand that I cannot be him and he cannot be me. Maybe Whitman had a talent that I did not possess. But I must ask the wounded man where it hurts because I cannot be the wounded man. The only wounded man I can be is myself.
es: —No, you don't believe it —he replies to me. And he is right. He sees it in my face. At last, I understand that I cannot be her, and that she cannot be me. Maybe Whitman had a gift that I do not have. As far as I am concerned, I have to ask the wounded where the wound is, because I cannot become the wounded. The only wounded person I can be is myself.

en: I stomp down some grass and sit. She lies down next to me, her backpack a pillow. I lay back, too. She digs a couple of books out of her backpack and hands them to me so I can have a pillow, too. Selected Poems of Emily Dickinson and Leaves of Grass. “I had two copies,” she says, smiling.
vi: I trampled a patch of grass and sat down. Margo lay down next to me, resting her head on the backpack. I lay down as well. Margo took some books out of the backpack and gave them to me to use as a pillow. A collection of Emily Dickinson's poetry and Leaves of Grass. “I have two books,” Margo said, smiling.
tr: I sit down, crushing the grass under my feet. He lies down next to me, his backpack as a pillow. I also lie down on my back. He searches for a few books in his backpack and hands them to me so that I also have a pillow. Selected Poems by Emily Dickinson and Leaves of Grass, “there were two,” he says with a smile.
es: I trample the grass and sit down. Margo lies down next to me, using the backpack as a pillow. I lie down on my back as well. She takes a couple of books out of the backpack and hands them to me to use as a pillow. An anthology of poems by Emily Dickinson and Leaves of Grass. —I had two copies —he tells me, smiling.

en: “It’s a hell of a good poem,” I tell her. “You couldn’t have picked a better one.”
vi: “A beautiful poem,” I said to Margo. “You couldn't have chosen better.”
tr: “A terribly good poem,” I say. “You couldn't have chosen a better one.”
es: —It's excellent —I tell him—. You couldn't have chosen better.

en: “Really, it was an impulse decision that morning. I remembered the bit about the doors and thought that was perfect. But then when I got here I reread it. I hadn’t read it since sophomore English, and yeah, I liked it. I tried to read a bunch of poetry. I was trying to figure out—like, what was it that surprised me about you that night? And for a long time I thought it was when you quoted T. S. Eliot.”
vi: "Actually, it was just a spontaneous decision that morning. I remembered a quote about doors and thought it was very fitting. But then when I got here, I read it again. I hadn't read it again since I was in tenth grade studying the national language. Yes, I really liked that poem. I tried to read a lot of poetry. I tried to understand—yes, what was it that surprised me so much about you that night? For a long time, I thought maybe it was when you read T. S. Eliot."
tr: “Really? It was a sudden decision I made that morning. I remembered the small piece about doors and thought it was perfect. But then when I came here, I read it again. I hadn't read it since literature class in the second year of high school, and yes, I liked it. I tried to read a lot of poetry. Well, that night I was trying to figure out what it was about you that surprised me. And for a long time, I thought it was when you quoted T. S. Eliot.”
es: —It was an impulsive decision that morning, truly. I remembered the passage about the doors and thought it was perfect. But then, upon arriving here, I read it again. I hadn't read it since my sophomore year of high school and, yes, I liked it. I've tried to read a lot of poetry. I was trying to figure out… what it was that surprised me about you that night. And for a long time, I thought it was when you quoted T. S. Eliot.

en: “But it wasn’t,” I say. “You were surprised by the size of my biceps and my graceful window-exiting.”
vi: “But that's not it,” I said. “You're astonished by the mouse's biceps and my charming leap through the window, aren't you?”
tr: “But it wasn't,” I say. “You were surprised by the size of my biceps and the grace with which I exited through the window.”
es: —But that wasn't it —I tell her—. You were surprised by my biceps and my elegant exit through the window.

en: She smirks. “Shut up and let me compliment you, dillhole. It wasn’t the poetry or your biceps. What surprised me was that, in spite of your anxiety attacks and everything, you were like the Quentin in my story. I mean, I’ve been crosshatching over that story for years now, and whenever I write over it, I also read that page, and I would always laugh, like—don’t get offended, but, like, ‘God I can’t believe I used to think Quentin Jacobsen was like a superhot, superloyal defender of justice.’ But then—you know—you kind of were.”
vi: Margo smirked. "Shut up and let me compliment you, you chatterbox. It's not poetry, you little mouse. What surprises me is that despite the stress and everything else, you have been like Quentin in my story. I've been writing in the margins of those pages for years, and every time I write, I reread the story, always laughing to myself, like–don't be offended–'God, I can't believe I once thought Quentin Jacobsen was such a super hot, super dedicated justice warrior.' But then–you know–you kind of are."
tr: Grinning. "Shut up so I can compliment you, idiot. It wasn't the poetry or the muscles. What surprised me was that, despite anxiety attacks and all, you were as disciplined as Quentin in my story. I mean, for years now, I've been writing crosswise over that story, and whenever I write over it, I read that page, and always, well... no offense, but I would laugh and say, 'My God, I can't believe I thought of Quentin Jacobsen as the super sexy and super loyal protector of justice.' But then I realized that, in a way, you were."
es: Smile. —Shut up and let me compliment you, dumbass. It wasn't the poetry or your biceps. What surprised me was that, despite your anxiety attacks and all that, you really were like the Quentin from my story. Well, I had been writing over that story for years, and every time I wrote, I also read that page, and I always laughed and told myself… No offense, but I told myself: "Damn, I can't believe I thought Quentin Jacobsen was a super good-looking, super loyal defender of justice." But… well… you were.

en: I could turn on my side, and she might turn on her side, too. And then we could kiss. But what’s the point of kissing her now, anyway? It won’t go anywhere. We are both staring at the cloudless sky. “Nothing ever happens like you imagine it will,” she says.
vi: I can turn sideways, she can also turn sideways, and then we can kiss each other. But in the end, what is the point of kissing her now? It won't lead anywhere. We both looked up at the clear sky. "Nothing happens the way we imagine it," she said.
tr: I can turn sideways and so can he. And then we can kiss. But what's the point of kissing him now anyway? It won't lead anywhere. We are both watching the cloudless sky. "Nothing ever turns out the way you imagine," he says.
es: I could turn around, and she could also turn around. And we could kiss. But what sense does it make to kiss her now? It's something that won't go anywhere. We both gaze at the cloudless sky. —Things never happen the way you imagine —he tells me.

en: The sky is like a monochromatic contemporary painting, drawing me in with its illusion of depth, pulling me up. “Yeah, that’s true,” I say. But then after I think about it for a second, I add, “But then again, if you don’t imagine, nothing ever happens at all.” Imagining isn’t perfect. You can’t get all the way inside someone else. I could never have imagined Margo’s anger at being found, or the story she was writing over. But imagining being someone else, or the world being something else, is the only way in. It is the machine that kills fascists.
vi: The sky at this moment is like a monochromatic contemporary painting, drawing me in with the illusion of its depth, pulling me ever upwards. "Yes, that's right," I said. But then, after a second of thought, I added, "But if we don't imagine, nothing can happen at all." Imagination is not perfect. We cannot imagine every aspect inside another person. I had never imagined that Margo could get as angry as she just did, nor the story she had written. But imagining oneself as someone else, or imagining the world differently, is the only way to get inside. That is the machine that can destroy fascists.
tr: The sky is like a monochrome modern painting, with the illusion of depth pulling me upward, towards itself. “Yes, that's right,” I say. But after thinking for a second, I add: “But if you don't imagine, nothing will happen.” Imagining is not perfect. You can't fully enter into another person. I could never imagine Margo getting angry when found or the story she wrote. But imagining being another person or the world being something else is the only way in. This is the machine that kills fascists.
es: The sky is like a contemporary monochromatic painting, its illusion of depth attracts and elevates me. —Yes, it's true —I tell him. But I think for a second and add—: But it's also true that if you don't imagine, nothing ever happens. Imagining is not perfect. You can't get inside another person. I could never have imagined Margo's rage when we found her, nor the story she was writing. But imagining that you are someone else, or that the world is something else, is the only way to enter. It is the machine that kills fascists.

en: She turns over toward me and puts her head onto my shoulder, and we lie there, as I long ago imagined lying on the grass at SeaWorld. It has taken us thousands of miles and many days, but here we are: her head on my shoulder, her breath on my neck, the fatigue thick inside both of us. We are now as I wished we could be then.
vi: Margo turned and rested her head on my shoulder, and we lay there, just as I had imagined long ago, the two of us lying on the grass in SeaWorld. It took thousands of miles and many days, but now we are here: her head resting on my shoulder, her breath on my neck, the fatigue deeply embedded in both of us. We are now just as I had once wished.
tr: He turns to me, puts his hand on my shoulder, and we lie there just like that, as I had imagined us lying on the grass at SeaWorld a long time ago. It cost us thousands of kilometers and many days, but here we are: His head on my shoulder, his breath on my neck, There is a fatigue deeply ingrained in both of us. Right now, we are just as I wished we were back then.
es: She turns towards me, rests her head on my shoulder, and we lie down, just as I imagined us in the grass at SeaWorld. We have traveled thousands of kilometers and many days, but here we are: her head on my shoulder, her breath on my neck, and the immense fatigue of both of us. We are now as I would have wished to be then.

en: When I wake up, the dying light of the day makes everything seem to matter, from the yellowing sky to the stalks of grass above my head, waving in slow motion like a beauty queen. I roll onto my side and see Margo Roth Spiegelman on her hands and knees a few feet from me, the jeans tight against her legs. It takes me a moment to realize that she is digging. I crawl over to her and start to dig beside her, the dirt beneath the grass dry as dust in my fingers. She smiles at me. My heart beats at the speed of sound.
vi: When I woke up, the daylight was fading, making everything look so special, from the golden sky to the blades of grass above me, swaying like beauty queens. I lay on my side, seeing Margo Roth Spiegelman kneeling on the ground a few meters away from me, her jeans clinging to her legs. It took me a moment to realize Margo was digging. I crawled over and started digging next to her, the soil beneath the dry grass crumbling like dust in my fingers. Margo looked at me and smiled. My heart pounded wildly like the speed of sound.
tr: When I wake up, the dying light of the day makes everything seem important, from the yellowing sky to the blades of grass waving slowly above my head like a beauty queen. I turn to the side and see Margo Roth Spiegelman a few meters away from me, with her hands on her knees, her pants clinging to her legs. It takes me a short time to realize that I am digging the ground. I crawl towards her and start digging beside her, the soil beneath the grass as dry as the dust on my fingers. She smiles at me. My heart is beating at the speed of sound.
es: When I wake up, the dim daylight makes everything seem important, from the yellowish sky to the blades of grass above my head, swaying in slow motion like a beauty queen. I turn to the side and see Margo Roth Spiegelman kneeling with her hands on the ground a few meters from me, her jeans hugging her legs. It takes me a moment to realize that she is digging. I crawl over to her and start digging beside her. The earth beneath the grass is dry as dust between my fingers. She smiles at me. My heart beats at the speed of sound.

en: “What are we digging to?” I ask her.
vi: “What are we digging?” I asked her.
tr: "Why are we digging?" I ask.
es: —What are we digging? —I ask him.

en: “That’s not the right question,” she says. “The question is, Who are we digging for?”
vi: “That's not the right question,” Margo replied. “The question should be, who are we digging for?”
tr: “That is not the right question,” he says. “The right question is, for whom are we digging.”
es: —That is not the right question —he tells me—. The question is: For whom are we digging?

en: “Okay, then. Who are we digging for?”
vi: “Alright, who am I digging the soil for?”
tr: “Alright then. Who are we digging for?”
es: —Alright. Who are we digging for?

en: “We are digging graves for Little Margo and Little Quentin and puppy Myrna Mountweazel and poor dead Robert Joyner,” she says.
vi: “I am digging a grave for little Margo, little Quentin, the dog Myrna Mountweazel, and poor deceased Mr. Robert Joyner,” Margo replied.
tr: "We are digging graves for Little Margo, Little Quentin, Puppy Myma Mountweazel, and poor dead Robert Joyner," he says.
es: —We are digging graves for little Margo, little Quentin, the puppy Myrna Mountweazel, and poor dead Robert Joyner —he answers me.

en: “I can get behind those burials, I think,” I say. The dirt is clumpy and dry, drilled through with the paths of insects like an abandoned ant farm. We dig our bare hands into the ground over and over again, each fistful of earth accompanied by a little cloud of dust. We dig the hole wide and deep. This grave must be proper. Soon I’m reaching in as deep as my elbows. The sleeve of my shirt gets dusty when I wipe the sweat from my cheek. Margo’s cheeks are reddening. I can smell her, and she smells like that night right before we jumped into the moat at SeaWorld.
vi: “I think I'm overwhelmed with all these funerals,” I said. The ground was rough and dry, crisscrossed with the paths of underground insects, looking like an abandoned ant farm. We dug into the earth with our bare hands, each handful of soil accompanied by a small cloud of dust. The two of us dug a deep and wide hole. This grave is just perfect. Soon, I was digging down to my elbows. My sleeves got dusty as I wiped the sweat off my cheek. Her cheeks turned rosy. I could smell Margo, she smelled just like that night, right before we jumped into the moat at SeaWorld.
tr: “I can't miss these funerals,” I say. The soil is clumpy and dry, like an abandoned ant nest, perforated with paths made by insects. We repeatedly dig our bare hands into the soil, and a small cloud of dust accompanies each handful of earth. We are digging a deep and wide hole. This grave must be neat. Soon, I find myself digging up to my elbows. When I wipe the sweat off my cheek, the sleeve of my t-shirt gets dusty. Margo's cheeks are turning red. I can smell her, and it smells just like that night at SeaWorld, right before we jumped into the moat.
es: —I think I support those burials —I tell him. The earth is lumpy and dry, perforated by the passage of insects like an abandoned anthill. We sink our hands into the ground again and again, and each handful of soil drags a small cloud of dust. We open a large and deep hole. The grave must be appropriate. It doesn't take long to reach my elbows. My shirt sleeve gets dirty when I wipe the sweat from my cheek. Margo's cheeks are getting redder and redder. Her scent reaches me, and it smells like that night before we jumped into the pit at SeaWorld.

en: “I never really thought of him as a real person,” she says.
vi: “I never really thought that he was a real person,” she said.
tr: "I had never thought of him as a real person," she says.
es: —I have never thought of him as a real person —she tells me.

en: When she speaks, I take the opportunity to take a break, and sit back on my haunches. “Who, Robert Joyner?”
vi: While Margo was talking, I took advantage of the break and sat down. "Who, Robert Joyner?"
tr: When she talks, I get a chance to take a break and sit down. "Who, Robert Joyner?""
es: While he speaks, I take the opportunity to pause and squat down. —In whom, in Robert Joyner?

en: She keeps digging. “Yeah. I mean, he was something that happened to me, you know? But before he was this minor figure in the drama of my life, he was—you know, the central figure in the drama of his own life.”
vi: Margo kept digging. "Yeah. He was like something that happened to me, you know? But before he was this little character in the play of my life, he was—you know, the main character in the play of his own life."
tr: He continues digging. “Yes. I mean, it was something that happened to me, do you understand? But before he took a small role in the drama of my life... he was the main character in the drama of his own life.”
es: Keep digging. —Yes. Well, you know, it was something that happened to me. But before he was a minor figure in the drama of my life, he was... well, the central figure in the drama of his own life.

en: I have never really thought of him as a person, either. A guy who played in the dirt like me. A guy who fell in love like me. A guy whose strings were broken, who didn’t feel the root of his leaf of grass connected to the field, a guy who was cracked. Like me. “Yeah,” I say after a while as I return to digging. “He was always just a body to me.”
vi: I also never thought of him as a human being. A person who also played with dirt like me. A person who also knew how to love like me. A person whose connections were all severed, who couldn't feel the roots of his grass reaching into the earth, a person who had cracked open. Like me. "Yeah," I said after a while and turned back to continue digging. "To me, he was always just a corpse."
tr: I had never thought of him as a real person either. As a man playing in the dirt like me. As a man who falls in love like me. As a man who had broken strings, who had never felt that his own grass blade root was connected to the meadow, a cracked man. Like me. “Yes," I say after a while, returning to digging. “For me, he was always a corpse. always a corpse.”
es: I have never thought of him as a person either. A guy who played on the earth like me. A guy who fell in love like me. A guy whose threads broke, who didn't feel that the roots of his blade of grass were connected to the field, a guy who was crazy. Like me. —Yes —I say after a while, as I resume digging—. It was always just a corpse to me.

en: “I wish we could have done something,” she says. “I wish we could have proven how heroic we were.”
vi: “I wish we had done something worthwhile,” she said. “I wish we had shown how heroic we are.”
tr: “I wish we could have done something,” he says. “I wish we could have proven how brave we are.”
es: —I wish we could have done something —says Margo—. I wish we could have shown how heroic we were.

en: “Yeah,” I say. “It would have been nice to tell him that, whatever it was, that it didn’t have to be the end of the world.”
vi: "Yeah," I replied. "I wish we could tell him that no matter what happens, it doesn't necessarily have to be the end of the world."
tr: “Yes,” I say. “It would be nice to tell him this, whatever happened, it didn't have to be the end of the world.”
es: —Yes. It would have been good to tell him that, whatever it was, it didn't have to be the end of the world.

en: “Yeah, although in the end something kills you.”
vi: "Yes, in the end, something did kill you."
tr: "Yes, although in the end something kills you."
es: —Yes, although in the end whatever it is will kill you.

en: I shrug. “Yeah, I know. I’m not saying that everything is survivable. Just that everything except the last thing is.” I dig my hand in again, the dirt here so much blacker than back home. I toss a handful into the pile behind us, and sit back. I feel on the edge of an idea, and I try to talk my way into it. I have never spoken this many words in a row to Margo in our long and storied relationship, but here it is, my last play for her.
vi: I shrugged. "Yeah, I know. I'm not saying everything can live forever. It's just that, everything except the last thing." I dug my hands in again, the soil here was much darker than at home. I added another handful to the pile of dirt behind me, and sat down. I felt like I was on the verge of a thought, and I tried to delve deeper into it. I've never talked this much at once with Margo, considering our long and storied relationship. But here it was, my final game for her.
tr: I shrug my shoulders. "Yes, I know. I'm not saying everything is bearable. Just that everything except the last thing is bearable." I put my hand back into the soil, the soil here is much darker than at home. I throw a handful of soil behind us and sit back down. I feel like I'm on the verge of an idea and try to get into it by talking. In our long and story-filled relationship, I have never said so many words to Margo in succession, but here it is, my last game for her.
es: I shrug my shoulders. —Yes, I know. I'm not saying that one can survive everything. Just that one can survive everything, except the last thing. I sink my hand again. The soil here is much darker than in Orlando. I throw a handful onto the pile behind us and sit down. An idea is occurring to me, and I try to make my way towards it. I have never said so many words in a row to Margo in our long and notorious relationship, but here it goes, my last performance for her.

en: “When I’ve thought about him dying—which admittedly isn’t that much—I always thought of it like you said, that all the strings inside him broke. But there are a thousand ways to look at it: maybe the strings break, or maybe our ships sink, or maybe we’re grass—our roots so interdependent that no one is dead as long as someone is still alive. We don’t suffer from a shortage of metaphors, is what I mean. But you have to be careful which metaphor you choose, because it matters. If you choose the strings, then you’re imagining a world in which you can become irreparably broken. If you choose the grass, you’re saying that we are all infinitely interconnected, that we can use these root systems not only to understand one another but to become one another. The metaphors have implications. Do you know what I mean?”
vi: "When I think about the fact that he has died–to be honest, not very often–I always think like you said, that all the internal connections inside him have snapped." "But there are a thousand ways to look at it: maybe the connections snapped, maybe the ship sank, or maybe we are grass–our roots intertwined so closely that as long as someone is alive, no one is truly dead." "I mean, we are not short of metaphors." "But we have to be careful with the metaphors we choose to use, because it is very important." "If you choose the snapped connections, you are imagining a world where you can be irreparably severed." "If you choose grass, you are implying that we are all indefinitely connected, that we can use those roots not only to understand others but to become another person." "Metaphors carry multiple layers of meaning." "Do you understand what I mean?"
tr: "When I thought about his death, let me confess, I didn't think as much as you said, I thought all the strings inside me broke. But there are thousands of ways to perceive this: Maybe the strings break, maybe our ships sink, or maybe we are grass... Our roots are so dependent on each other that as long as one is still alive, no one is dead. We are not short of metaphors, that's what I mean. But you have to be careful about which metaphor you choose because it's important. If you choose the strings, then you are imagining a world where they can break irreparably. If you choose the grass, we are all extremely mutually dependent on each other You are saying that we are connected, so we can use these root systems not only to understand each other but also to become each other. Metaphors have hidden meanings. Do you understand what I mean?”
es: —When I thought about him dying, which I admit hasn't been many times, I always thought about what you said, that his strings had broken inside him. But there are a thousand ways to see it. Maybe the strings break, or maybe our ships sink, or maybe we are grass and our roots are so interdependent that no one is dead as long as someone is alive. What I mean is that we are not short of metaphors. But you must be careful with the metaphor you choose, because it is important. If you choose the strings, you are imagining a world where you can break irreparably. If you choose the grass, you are saying that we are all infinitely interconnected, that we can use that root system not only to understand each other but to become each other. Metaphors imply things. Do you understand what I'm saying?

en: She nods.
vi: She nodded.
tr: He nods in agreement.
es: Margo nods.

en: “I like the strings. I always have. Because that’s how it feels. But the strings make pain seem more fatal than it is, I think. We’re not as frail as the strings would make us believe. And I like the grass, too. The grass got me to you, helped me to imagine you as an actual person. But we’re not different sprouts from the same plant. I can’t be you. You can’t be me. You can imagine another well—but never quite perfectly, you know?
vi: "I like the connecting threads. I've always liked them. Because they are a way to feel. But the threads make the pain seem more likely to lead to death than it actually does, I think. We are not as fragile as the threads make us believe. And I also like grass. Grass brings me to you, helps me imagine you as a real person. But we are not different branches on the same tree. I cannot be you. You cannot be me. We can imagine others very accurately—but never relatively perfectly, you understand?
tr: “I love ropes. I always have. Because that's how I feel. But I think ropes make pain seem more deadly than it is, we are not as fragile as the ropes make us believe. And I love grass too. Grass brought me to you, helped me imagine you as a real person. But we are not different sprouts of the same plant. I cannot be you. And you cannot be me. You can imagine someone else in a good way... but it will never be completely perfect, do you understand?
es: —I like threads —I continue saying—. I've always liked them. Because that's how I feel. But I think threads make pain seem more fatal than it is. We are not as fragile as threads would have us believe. And I also like grass. The grass has brought me to you, it has helped me imagine you as a real person. But we are not different sprouts from the same plant. I cannot be you. You cannot be me. You can imagine another... but never perfectly, you know?

en: “Maybe it’s more like you said before, all of us being cracked open. Like, each of us starts out as a watertight vessel. And these things happen—these people leave us, or don’t love us, or don’t get us, or we don’t get them, and we lose and fail and hurt one another. And the vessel starts to crack open in places. And I mean, yeah, once the vessel cracks open, the end becomes inevitable. Once it starts to rain inside the Osprey, it will never be remodeled. But there is all this time between when the cracks start to open up and when we finally fall apart. And it’s only in that time that we can see one another, because we see out of ourselves through our cracks and into others through theirs. When did we see each other face-to-face? Not until you saw into my cracks and I saw into yours. Before that, we were just looking at ideas of each other, like looking at your window shade but never seeing inside. But once the vessel cracks, the light can get in. The light can get out.”
vi: "Perhaps more like what you once said, we are all cracked open. As if each of us was initially a sealed ship's hull, impervious to water. And then things like this happen—people like this leave us, or don't love us, or don't understand us, or we don't understand them, we experience loss, failure, and we hurt each other. Then the hull begins to crack somewhere. And there, once the hull has cracked, the outcome is inevitable. Once the rain starts getting into the Osprey, there will never be any repair or restoration. But there is still this time in between, when the cracks are just beginning until we completely fall apart. And only during this time can we see each other, because we see ourselves through our own cracks and see others through their cracks. When have we ever looked directly at each other, face to face? Only when you look through my cracks and I look through yours. Before that, we only saw ideas of each other, like looking through a window but never seeing inside. But once the cracks have opened, light can come in. Light can shine out."
tr: “Maybe, as you said before, we are all cracking open. It’s as if each of us starts out as a waterproof shell. And something happens... someone leaves us, doesn’t love us, doesn’t understand us, or we don’t understand them and we lose, we fail, and we hurt each other. And the shell starts to crack open in some places. So yes, once the shell cracks, the end becomes inevitable. Once rain starts to pour into the Osprey, it will never be repaired. But there is a lot of time between the moment the cracks start to open and the moment we shatter. And only then can we see each other because we see the outside through our own cracks and the inside of others through their cracks. When did we ever see each other face to face? Not until you saw inside my cracks and I saw inside yours. Before that, we were just looking at each other’s ideas, like looking at the blinds on your window without ever seeing inside. But once the shell cracks, light can come in. Light can go out.”
es: »Maybe it's more like you said before, that we are all cracked. Each one of us starts off as a sealed vessel. And things happen. People leave us, or don't love us, or don't understand us, or we don't understand them, and we get lost, we fail, and we hurt each other. And the vessel starts to crack in some places. And, yes, once the vessel cracks, the end is inevitable. Once the rain starts to get inside the Osprey, it will never be refurbished. But there's all that time from when the cracks start to open until we finally crumble. And only in that time can we see each other, because we see what is outside through our cracks, and what is inside can also be seen through them. When did you and I see each other face to face? Not until you saw me through my cracks, and I saw you through yours. Until that moment we only saw ideas of each other, like looking at your blind, but without seeing what was inside. But when the vessel breaks, the light can enter. And it can exit.

en: She raises her fingers to her lips, as if concentrating, or as if hiding her mouth from me, or as if to feel the words she speaks. “You’re pretty something,” she says finally. She stares at me, my eyes and her eyes and nothing between them. I have nothing to gain from kissing her. But I am no longer looking to gain anything. “There’s something I have to do,” I say, and she nods very slightly, as if she knows the something, and I kiss her.
vi: Margo placed her fingers on her lips, looking as if she was concentrating, or as if she was hiding her lips from me, or as if she was feeling the words she wanted to say. "You really are something," Margo finally said. She looked at me intently, my eyes and her eyes and nothing between them. I would gain nothing by kissing her. But I was no longer looking for things to gain. "There's something I need to do," I said, and she nodded very slightly, as if she already knew, and I kissed her.
tr: She brings her fingers to her lips, as if she is concentrating or hiding her mouth from me or wanting to feel the words she is about to say. "There really is something about you," she says at last. She looks at me for a long time, my eyes and her eyes... there is nothing between them. There is nothing to gain by kissing her. But I no longer expect to gain anything. "There is something I have to do," I say, she nods faintly, as if she knows what it is, and I kiss her.
es: She brings her fingers to her lips, as if she were concentrating, or as if she were hiding her mouth from me, or as if she wanted to feel her words. —You are special —he finally tells me. She looks at me. My eyes, her eyes, and nothing between them. I'm not going to gain anything by kissing her, but I no longer intend to gain anything. —There is something I have to do —I tell him. Nods slightly, as if knowing what that something is. And I kiss her.

en: It ends quite a while later when she says, “You can come to New York. It will be fun. It will be like kissing.”
vi: We parted ways for a long time before Margo finally said, "You could come to New York. It would be fun. Like kissing."
tr: Our kiss ends when Margo speaks after a long time. "You can come to New York. It would be fun. Like kissing."
es: The kiss ends a while later, when she says to me: —You can come to New York. It will be fun. It will be like kissing each other.

en: And I say, “Kissing is pretty something.”
vi: And I said, "Kissing is really something."
tr: And I say, "There really is something about kissing."
es: —Kissing each other is special —I tell her.

en: And she says, “You’re saying no.”
vi: And she said, "You are refusing."
tr: He also says, "You are saying no."
es: —You're telling me no —he replies.

en: And I say, “Margo, I have a whole life there, and I’m not you, and I—” But I can’t say anything because she kisses me again, and it’s in the moment that she kisses me that I know without question that we’re headed in different directions. She stands up and walks over to where we were sleeping, to her backpack. She pulls out the moleskin notebook, walks back to the grave, and places it in the ground.
vi: I said, "Margo, I have my whole life here, I'm not you, and I–" But I couldn't say anything more because Margo kissed me again, and the moment she placed her lips on mine, I knew without needing to ask any questions, that we were heading in different directions. She stood up and went back to where we had just been sleeping, and grabbed her backpack. Margo took out a black leather-bound notebook, returned to the grave, and placed the notebook into the ground.
tr: “Margo, my whole life is there and I am not you, I...” But I can't say anything because she kisses me again and at the moment she kisses me, I absolutely understand that we are heading in different directions. She stands up and walks to where we slept, to the backpack. She takes out the notebook, walks back to the grave, and places the notebook there.
es: —Margo, my entire life is there, and I am not you, and… But I can't say anything more, because he kisses me again, and at the moment he kisses me, I know without the slightest doubt that we are on different paths. He gets up and heads to where we were lying to grab his backpack. He takes out the notebook, returns to the grave, and leaves the notebook on the ground.

en: “I’ll miss you,” she whispers, and I don’t know if she’s talking to me or to the notebook. Nor do I know to whom I’m talking when I say, “As will I.”
vi: "I'll miss you," Margo whispered. I didn't know if she was talking to me or to the notebook. I also didn't know who I was talking to when I said, "Me too."
tr: "I will miss you," he whispers, I don't know if he's talking to me or the notebook. When I speak, I don't know who I'm talking to either: "Me too."
es: —I will miss you —she whispers. And I don't know if he is talking to me or to the notebook. And I also don't know who I'm talking to when I say: —Me too.

en: “Godspeed, Robert Joyner,” I say, and drop a handful of dirt onto the notebook.
vi: "Rest in peace, Mr. Robert Joyner," I said, dropping a handful of soil onto the notebook.
tr: “May God be with you, Robert Joyner,” I say, and throw a handful of soil onto the notebook.
es: Go with God, Robert Joyner. I throw a handful of dirt onto the notebook.

en: “Godspeed, young and heroic Quentin Jacobsen,” she says, tossing in dirt of her own.
vi: "Be at peace, naive and brave Quentin Jacobsen," Margo said, releasing the handful of earth she had just dug up.
tr: “May God be with you, young and brave Quentin Jacobsen,” he says, and then he throws the soil in his hand.
es: —Go with God, young and heroic Quentin Jacobsen —says Margo, also throwing a handful of dirt.

en: Another handful as I say, “Godspeed, fearless Orlandoan Margo Roth Spiegelman.”
vi: Another handful, I said, "Be at peace, Miss Margo Roth Spiegelman of Orlando, never one to back down."
tr: “May God be with you, fearless Margo Roth Spiegelman of Orlando,” I say as I throw another handful of dirt.
es: —Go with God, brave citizen of Orlando Margo Roth Spiegelman —I say, throwing another handful.

en: And another as she says, “Godspeed, magical puppy Myrna Mountweazel.” We shove the dirt over the book, tamping down the disturbed soil. The grass will grow back soon enough. It will be for us the beautiful uncut hair of graves.
vi: And one more handful, Margo said, "Rest in peace, super dog Myrna Mountweazel." We covered the notebook with soil, leveling it with the dug-up ground. The grass will soon grow back. To us, the grass will be the untrimmed hair of the grave.
tr: "Oh, 'May God be with you, magical puppy Myma Mountvveazel,' he says as he pours another handful of soil. He pushes the soil onto the notebook, pressing and compacting it. Soon, the grass will grow. For us, the graves will have beautiful uncut hair.
es: —Go with God, magical little puppy Myrna Mountweazel —says Margo, throwing another handful. We pushed the earth over the book and tamped down the soil. The grass will soon grow back. For us, it will be the loose and beautiful hair of the graves.

en: We hold hands rough with dirt as we walk back to the Agloe General Store. I help Margo carry her belongings—an armful of clothes, her toiletries, and the desk chair—to her car. The preciousness of the moment, which should make it easier to talk, makes it harder.
vi: We held hands, our feet dirty, and walked towards Agloe General Store. I helped Margo carry her luggage—a bundle of clothes, personal hygiene items, and an office chair—to her car. The preciousness of the moment often makes people speak easily to each other, but now it was just harder to find the words.
tr: As we walk back to Agloe Market, we clasp our hardened hands together. I'm helping Margo carry her belongings to her car... an armful of clothes, toiletries, and chair. 0 the value of the moment, instead of making the conversation easier, makes it even more difficult.
es: We return to the Agloe Supermarket holding hands, which are rough from the dirt. I help Margo load her things into the car: clothes, toiletries, and the chair. The moment is so precious that, instead of facilitating the conversation, it makes it more difficult.

en: We’re standing outside in the parking lot of a single-story motel when the good-byes become unavoidable. “I’m gonna get a cell, and I’ll call you,” she says. “And email. And post mysterious statements on Omnictionary’s Paper Towns talk page.”
vi: We stood outside in the parking lot of a one-story motel, when we could no longer avoid the goodbyes. “I'll buy a cell phone, and I'll call you,” Margo said. “And email too. And post mysterious comments on the discussion section of the article about Paper Towns in the Everything Encyclopedia.”
tr: When saying goodbye becomes inevitable, we stop in the parking lot of a single-story motel. “I will get a cell phone and call you,” he says. “And I will send emails. And I will send mysterious messages to the talk page of Omnictionary.”
es: We are in front of the parking lot of a one-story motel when the farewell is inevitable. —I will get a cell phone and call you —he tells me—. And I will write you emails. And mysterious comments on the Omnictionary's page about the paper towns.

en: I smile. “I’ll email you when we get home,” I say, “and I expect a response.”
vi: I smiled. "I'll send you an email when we get home," I said, "and I'll be waiting for your reply."
tr: I'm smiling. “I will send you an email when we get home,” I say, “and I will be expecting a reply.”
es: I smile. —I will write you an email when we get home —I tell her—, and I expect a reply.

en: “You have my word. And I’ll see you. We’re not done seeing each other.”
vi: "I assure you. And I will see you again. We are not done with our meetings here yet."
tr: “I promise to send it. And we will meet. We are not done seeing each other yet.”
es: —Promised. And we will see each other. We are not going to stop seeing each other.

en: “At the end of the summer, maybe, I can meet you somewhere before school,” I say.
vi: "At the end of summer, maybe, I could meet you somewhere before school starts," I said.
tr: "At the end of summer, before school starts, I can meet you somewhere," I say.
es: —At the end of summer, I might be able to come see you, before classes start —I tell her.

en: “Yeah,” she says. “Yeah, that’s a good idea.” I smile and nod. She turns away, and I am wondering if she means any of it when I see her shoulders collapse. She is crying.
vi: "Yes," Margo replied. "Good idea." I smiled and nodded. She turned away, and I was wondering if Margo really thought so, when I saw her shoulders shaking. Margo was crying.
tr: “Yes,” he says. “Yes, this is a good idea.” Smiling, I nod my head. He turns his back and when I see his shoulders shaking, I wonder if any of what he said was true. He is crying.
es: —Yes —he answers me—. Yes, good idea. I smile and nod. He turns around and I'm wondering if he was serious when I see him hunch his shoulders. He's crying.

en: “I’ll see you then. And I’ll write in the meantime,” I say.
vi: "I will see you again. In the meantime, I will write to you," I said.
tr: “See you, and by the way, I will write to you,” I say.
es: —See you then. And in the meantime, I'll write to you —I say.

en: “Yes,” she says without turning around, her voice thick. “I’ll write you, too.”
vi: "Alright, see you," she said without turning back, her voice lowering. "I'll write to you too."
tr: "Yes," he says without turning around, his voice muffled. "I will write to you too."
es: —Yes —he answers me without turning, with a hoarse voice—. I will write to you too.

en: It is saying these things that keeps us from falling apart. And maybe by imagining these futures we can make them real, and maybe not, but either way we must imagine them. The light rushes out and floods in.
vi: It was precisely speaking these things that kept us from falling apart. And perhaps by imagining those futures, we could make them come true. Or maybe not. But in either case, we still had to imagine them. Light surged out and flowed in.
tr: The thing that prevents us from falling apart is saying these things. Maybe we can make these futures come true by imagining them, maybe we can't, but in any case, we must imagine them. Light seeps out and pours in.
es: Saying these things prevents us from falling apart. And maybe by imagining those futures we can make them real, or maybe not, but in any case, we have to imagine them. The light overflows and floods everything.

en: I stand in this parking lot, realizing that I’ve never been this far from home, and here is this girl I love and cannot follow. I hope this is the hero’s errand, because not following her is the hardest thing I’ve ever done.
vi: I stand in this parking lot, realizing that I have never been this far from home, and here is the girl I love but cannot follow. I hope this is a trivial matter for a hero, because not following her is the hardest thing I have ever done.
tr: Realizing that I have never been this far from home before, I am in this park area and the girl I love and cannot follow is right here. I hope that what is referred to as the hero's journey ends here because not following her is the most hard thing.
es: I am in this parking lot thinking that I have never been so far from home, and here is the girl I love and cannot follow. I hope this is the hero's mission, because not following her is the hardest thing I have ever done in my life.

en: I keep thinking she will get into the car, but she doesn’t, and she finally turns around to me and I see her soaked eyes. The physical space between us evaporates. We play the broken strings of our instruments one last time.
vi: I kept thinking Margo would get into the car, but no, in the end, Margo turned back, and I saw her eyes, glistening with tears. The physical distance between us disappeared. We played the broken strings on our harp once again.
tr: I keep thinking that she will get into the car, but she doesn't; finally, when she turns to me, I see her tear-filled eyes. The physical space between us evaporates. For one last time, we reach for the broken strings.
es: I think he will get into the car, but he doesn't. In the end, he turns towards me and I see his wet eyes. The physical space that separates us vanishes. We touch the broken strings of our instruments for the last time.

en: I feel her hands on my back. And it is dark as I kiss her, but I have my eyes open and so does Margo. She is close enough to me that I can see her, because even now there is the outward sign of the invisible light, even at night in this parking lot on the outskirts of Agloe. After we kiss, our foreheads touch as we stare at each other. Yes, I can see her almost perfectly in this cracked darkness.
vi: I felt Margo's hand on my back. It had already turned dark when I kissed her, but I opened my eyes and so did Margo. She was close enough for me to see her, as there was now an invisible light from within, even in the evening in this parking lot on the outskirts of Agloe. The kiss ended, we pressed our foreheads together and looked at each other. Yes, I could see her almost perfectly in this fractured darkness.
tr: I feel her hands on my back. While kissing her, the air is dark but I keep my eyes open, Margo too, so close that I can see her, even in this night at the parking lot outside Agloe, there are visible signs of that invisible light. After kissing, as we look at each other for a long time, our foreheads touch. In this darkness with cracks, I can see her almost perfectly.
es: I feel her hands on my back. And even though it's dark, I don't close my eyes while I kiss her, and neither does Margo. She is so close to me that I can see her, because even now the external sign of invisible light appears, even at night in this parking lot on the outskirts of Agloe. After kissing, we look at each other so closely that our foreheads touch. Yes, I see her almost perfectly in this cracked darkness.
